name: How many active space-focused projects will Zooniverse be hosting on March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Zooniverse is a crowdsourced science web portal operated by the Citizen Science Alliance, a collaboration of science research organizations headquartered at the University of Oxford. The site hosts projects which allow volunteers to participate in crowdsourced scientific research. Unlike many internet-based citizen science projects (such as Folding@home) which are based on distributed computing, Zooniverse projects require active participation from its human volunteers to complete research tasks; for example, looking through images from telescopes to identify features associated with planet and star formation. Research aided by Zooniverse has lead to publication of several articles in peer-reviewed scientific journals.

As of November 21, 2014, there are 10 space-focused projects on Zooniverse, 2 climate projects, 2 projects in the humanities, 9 nature (zoology and botany) oriented projects, and 2 biology projects. Five projects, all space related, have been retired. This question asks if and how this number may change over between the question publish date and March 31, 2015.

For more information, see:
  • https://www.zooniverse.org/projects
  • http://www.citizensciencealliance.org/
  • http://www.scientificamerican.com/citizen-science/zooniverse-asteroid-zoo/
  • http://www.nature.com/news/crisis-mappers-turn-to-citizen-scientists-1.16373

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

Zooniverse classifies all active projects into categories, one of which is space; see here: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: Will a maneuverable airship lift more than 60 tons of cargo above an altitude of 20 km by June 2017?
question_text:
• Airships (dirigibles) are lighter-than-air aircraft that can navigate under their own power. Possibly the most famous airship, the Hindenburg, was filled with hydrogen that burned in 1937.?? Airships were popular in the early 1900s, but declined in popularity after disasters such as the Hindenburg. Helium is used now making them much safer.
  • While large-scale passenger applications were suspended in the mid-1900s, development focused on military applications for surveillance until resource issues diverted R&D funds from airships. However, recently non-defense-related attention returned to airships as low-carbon methods for transporting goods, as carriers for telescopes to scan the skies, and as instrument carriers to measure the atmosphere. Airships have high spatial and temporal resolution, daily to seasonal coverage, and local to regional spatial coverage.
  • In Febuary 2014, the Keck Institute for Space Studies published Airships: A New Horizon for Science, a report that reviewed ?the potential of a variety of airships currently operable or under development to serve as observatories and science instrumentation platforms for a range of space, atmospheric and Earth science.? The authors ?found considerable scientific value in both low altitude (< 40 kft) and high altitude (> 60 kft) airships across a wide spectrum of space, atmospheric, and Earth science programs.? Therefore, the authors call for a prize ?for the development of a maneuverable, station-keeping, stratospheric airship, which can stay aloft at an altitude above 65 kft (20 km) for at least a full diurnal cycle (>20 hours) while carrying a science payload of at least 20 kg in mass? as part of a roadmap to stratospheric airship observatories.
Links and sources
  • http://edition.cnn.com/2013/12/09/business/airship-cargo-revolutionize-arctic-transportation/
  • Airships: A New Horizon for Science? http://kiss.caltech.edu/study/airship/final-report.pdf
  • The flying bum! 300ft-long 'airship' unveiled in Britain is the world's longest aircraft http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2570118/Worlds-longest-aircraft-revealed-300ft-long-a...
  • http://kiss.caltech.edu/workshops/airship2013/presentations/smith.pdf
  • http://www.defenseinnovationmarketplace.mil/resources/Final_LTA_report.pd

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/01/2017

Resolution Source

Press release or other official announcement from company or research group.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

An airship can be a rigid, semi-rigid, or non-rigid lighter-than-air vehicles that can generate their own thrust for maneuvers. 1 ton = 2,000 lbs.

keywords: Battery Electric Vehicles, CHAdeMO, quick charger, chemistry
name: By the end of 2015, will there more than 1,000 CHAdeMO quick charging stations for battery electric vehicles in the U.S.?
question_text:
CHAdeMO is the trade name of a quick charging method for battery electric vehicles, delivering up to 62.5 kW of high-voltage direct current via a special electrical connector. It is proposed as a global industry standard by an association of the same name. CHAdeMO is an abbreviation of "CHArge de MOve", equivalent to "charge for moving". The name is a pun?on O cha demo ikaga desuka in Japanese, translating to English as "How about some tea?", referring to the time it would take to charge a car. CHAdeMO can charge low-range electric cars in less than half an hour. According to the information posted on the official
CHAdeMO Association's website, there are 3816 CHAdeMO DC Quick chargers installed in the world as of July 2, 2014, 633 of them in the United States.

  • http://www.chademo.com/
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CHAdeMO


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The number of the CHAdeMO stations by country is available on the CHAdeMO Association's website: http://www.chademo.com/

keywords: Cybersecurity, cyber security, information analyst, salary
name: What will be the median annual salary for an Information Security Analyst for 2014?
question_text:
"Cybersecurity is perhaps the most challenging intellectual profession on the planet both because of the rate of change and because your failure is the intentional work product of sentient opponents.? ?

Information security analysts must continually adapt to stay a step ahead of cyberattackers. They must stay up to date on the latest methods attackers are using to infiltrate computer systems and on IT security. Analysts need to research new security technology to decide what will most effectively protect their organization. This may involve attending cybersecurity conferences to hear firsthand accounts of other professionals who have experienced new types of attacks.

IT security analysts are also frequently involved with creating their organization?s disaster recovery plan, a procedure that IT employees follow in case of emergency. The plan lets an organization?s IT department continue functioning. It includes preventative measures such as regularly copying and transferring data to an offsite location. It also involves plans to restore proper IT functioning after a disaster. Analysts continually test the steps in their recovery plans.

Because information security is important, these workers usually report directly to upper management. Many information security analysts work with an organization?s?computer and information systems manager?or chief technology officer (CTO) to design security or disaster recovery systems.? ??

For more information:

  • http://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/information-security-analysts.htm#tab-1
  • http://geer.tinho.net/fgm/fgm.geer.1502.pdf


This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved using the median income for Information Security analysts published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics expected to be published in December, 2015:?http://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/information-security-analysts.htm#TB_inli...

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

Fine Print

The median annual salary for an Information Security Analyst in 2013 was reported as $88,590.

name: In any fiscal quarter in FY2016, will Microsoft's revenue from cloud services exceed that of on-premise software?
question_text:
Under new CEO Satya Nadella, Microsoft has accelerated the shift from "on-premise" server offerings like Exchange to Platform as a Service (PaaS) and Software as a Service (SaaS) offerings. Products like Microsoft Azure and Office 365 are examples of the company making big bets in cloud computing to compete with Oracle, Google, and others. A shift in profit of cloud computing services over their more traditional offerings would signal a successful shift in strategy for the company and an indication cloud computing is becoming a bigger part of the overall $2T in IT spend.?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2016

Resolution Source

The question will resolve "yes" if?Microsoft, in?earnings calls or quarterly filings states more profit has come from cloud services than on-premise software.

Fine Print

Microsoft does not explicitly differentiate between revenue generated by cloud services and on premise software offerings in its Segment Information reporting: http://www.microsoft.com/investor/CompanyInfo/SegmentInfo/Overview.aspx. Thus, this question will resolve based on statements made by a Microsoft spokesperson or third party analytics / business intelligence services such as Synergy Research group: https://www.srgresearch.com . Cloud revenue may come from software, private cloud services and associated professional and technical services. In contrast, 'on premise software' includes revenue from non-cloud based software licensing and associated technical services such as Microsoft Exchange or Dynamics CRM. Note that some on-premise software may include cloud based features, and it will be up to the reporting source to establish which market segment these services fall into.

keywords: Bitcoin, wallet app, app store, Apple, Blockchain
name: When will Apple Inc. allow a Bitcoin wallet application to be downloaded via the iOS App Store?
question_text:
At the beginning of February, Apple removed it's last Bitcoin wallet app (Blockchain) from the App Store, causing an uproar among iOS- using Bitcoiners. When (if ever) will the Bitcoin apps be reintroduced?

  • Bitcoiners Destroy Their iPhones After Apple Removes Wallet From App Store
  • Apple removes 'last remaining' Bitcoin trading app from App Store
  • Apple drops top Bitcoin app from marketplace

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The question will resolve true within a given?date range if?a Bitcoin wallet application is available to download through the Apple App Store onto iOS devices.

Apple App Store:?https://itunes.apple.com/us/genre/ios/id36?mt=8

Fine Print

"allow" implies a Bitcoin wallet application is available to download through the Apple App Store onto iOS devices

keywords: climate, global temperature, drought, water conservation
name: Will the water level in Lake Mead drop below 1,075 feet by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Lake Mead is formed by Hoover Dam located on the Colorado River in the United States. It lies in both Nevada and Arizona and is a major source of water for residents of Las Vegas, Nevada. Its water level has decreased to the "drought level" of 1125 feet elevation multiple times since 1953. If it falls below 1075, a U.S. federal water shortage declaration will be initiated.

Resolution Criteria

Information found on the Lake Mead Water Database will be used for the resolution of this question.

Resolution Sources

Las Vegas Sun, New York Times

Fine Print

Water level is defined by the official source as the USBR, which reports a monthly elevation statistic.

Useful Information and Links

  • Drought-stricken Lake Mead:?http://m.lvsun.com/news/2013/aug/16/more-water-being-choked-drought-stricken-lake-mead/#.UrN8Dqgrw2s...
  • Lake Mead Water Levels:?http://www.arachnoid.com/NaturalResources/
  • Lake Mead Elevation (ft):?http://www.usbr.gov/lc/region/g4000/hourly/mead-elv.html

Related Organizations or Individuals

United States Bureau of Reclamation, http://www.usbr.gov/lc/region/g4000/hourly/mead-elv.html

name: Will a first stage launch vehicle land successfully on a solid surface on or before 31 March 2015?
question_text:
Currently, expendable launch vehicles are carrying unmanned capsules to the International Space Station.? However, a long-term goal is for launch vehicles to be fully reusable heavy lift launch vehicles.? Companies have been working on achieving a launch vehicle with a first stage launch vehicle that returns to the launch site in minutes and the second stage vehicle that returns within 24 hours.

The first step to a reusable launch vehicle is for the first stage launch vehicle to simply return to a specific geographical place as opposed to splashing down into the ocean. The second step is for a successful landing that enables the vehicle to be reused.

Sources and links
  • Next Falcon 9 Launch Could See First-stage Platform Landing
  • SpaceX reusable launch system development program

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

Offical press release or announcement from the successful company.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution


Fine Print

Successful is defined as a landing that enables the first stage hardware to be reflown. "Solid surface" may be ground or floating platforms engineered for the mission.

keywords: H5N8, Avian Influenza, Bird Flu, Epidimiology, Poultry
name: Will at least five European countries report one or more new cases of H5N8 influenza virus in poultry in the first quarter of 2015?
question_text:
An?outbreak of bird flu was reported in the UK, the Netherlands and Germany in November 2014. Migratory birds heading south for winter are probably responsible for the outbreak. The strain of the flu, identified as H5N8, has hit a Dutch chicken farm, a German turkey farm, and has infected ducks on a British farm. Hundreds of thousands of the animals have been slaughtered to prevent the spread of the virus.

  • Avian Flu Detected in the Netherlands and Britain:?http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/18/world/europe/avian-flu-detected-in-the-netherlands-and-britain.htm....
  • Bird flu strain on UK farm identified as H5N8:?http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-30098122
  • WHO braces for bird flu spread in Europe:?http://www.skynews.com.au/news/top-stories/2014/11/19/who-braces-for-bird-flu-spread-in-europe.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

The World Organization for Animal Health (OIE)?routinely monitors influenza viruses in animals. Any outbreak of H5N8 will be reported on its website:?http://www.oie.int/?

Fine Print

Poultry is defined as domestic fowls, including chickens, turkeys, geese and ducks, raised for the production of meat or eggs.

The UK, Netherlands, and Germany would have to report new cases (post December 2014)?of H5N8 to qualify as one of the countries.?

name: What share of global research papers, as reported by the SCImago Journal & Country Ranking, will the U.S. have in 2014?
question_text:
TheSCImago Journal & Country Ranking is a publicly-accessible platform run by ScimagoLab that uses SCOPUS data on academic journals to rank countries by theirpublication and citation rates and journals by their citation rates. Scopus isa bibliographic database containing abstracts and citations for academicjournal articles from approximately 20,000 peer-reviewed journals in thescientific, technical, medical, and social sciences, including arts andhumanities. It is owned by Elsevier B.V.

For2009 to 2012, SCImago reports the following for U.S. share of the global outputof scientific articles: 2009=27.2%; 2010=26.5%; 2011=25.0%; 2012=24.1%. Datafor each year are posted to the SCImago website at some point during thesubsequent year, and data from past years is also available on the site.

Thisquestion asks what the U.S. share will be of total scientific papers producedglobally in 2014, once those data are reported sometime in early 2015.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Resolution Sources

TheSCImago country ranking website, (http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php), will report the resultswhen available sometime in early 2015. The resolution percentage will be calculated by the following: (US share of documents for 2014) / (total documents amongst all countries for 2014).

Fine Print

Scimago Lab uses SCOPUS data to post country results, once available, to the SCImago website: ?http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php

Useful Information and Links

SCImagowebsites:

  • Main site:? http://www.scimagojr.com/index.php
  • Country ranking website:? http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php

Related Organizations or Individuals

Scimago Lab, http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Devreotes
name: What place will the Devreotes Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The?Devreotes team's strategy to win the race:

Our lab is testing a number of pharmacological inhibitors at low concentrations, based on the hypothesis that inhibiting the cells' normal spontaneous activity (unrelated to the gradient) will enhance their sensitivity towards the chemoattractant gradient in the device.

Dicty related?research being conducted?at the?Devreotes?Lab:

Many cells have an internal ?compass? that allows them to detect and move along extracellular chemical gradients in a process referred to as chemotaxis or directed cell migration. ?In embryogenesis chemotaxis is used repeatedly to rearrange cells, for instance, during primordial germ cell migration, organ formation, and wiring of the nervous system. ?In the adult, chemotaxis mediates normal trafficking of immune cells and is critical for inflammation. ?It also participates in wound healing, in maintenance of tissue architecture, and allows stem cells to target to and persist in their niches.

Studies of chemotaxis in the model organism Dictyostelium has uncovered mechanisms which are highly conserved in other eukaryotic cells. ?Our strategy is to use the powerful genetic analysis available in this model system to gain insights and then to test these concepts in mammalian cells such as neutrophils. ?Chemotaxis is comprised of motility, directional sensing, and polarity. ?The amoeboid movements of Dictyostelium and neutrophils towards chemoattractants are based on the periodic extension of pseudopodia, driven by actin polymerization at the front and myosin-based contraction at the rear. ?Chemoattractants activate G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), resulting in the localized accumulation of signaling molecules, which bias the direction or lifetime of the projections at the leading edge of the cell and regulate rear contraction. Cells also develop a stable polarity that enhances chemotaxis.

Chemotaxis bias depends on a network composed of multiple signaling pathways. ?Several years ago, we discovered that chemoattractants activate PI3Ks producing an accumulation of PIP3 at the leading edge of amoebae. ?We now know that this mechanism is conserved in neutrophils and many other types of eukaryotic cells. ?Unregulated production of PIP3, as occurs in cells lacking the tumor suppressor PTEN, causes many ectopic projections and impairs the directional response of migrating cells. ?Thus, localized PIP3 production is an important conserved mechanism mediating chemotactic bias. ?Surprisingly, however, cells lacking PIP3 production can still carry out chemotaxis. ?This indicates that additional pathways act in parallel or redundantly with PIP3.

?In our search for parallel pathways, we have recently focused on the gene Pianissimo (PiaA), which was derived from an early genetic screen for chemotaxis defects in Dictyostelium. ?PiaA was later shown to be a subunit of target of rapamycin complex 2 (TorC2) and required for phosphorylation of the hydrophobic motifs (HMs) of ACG kinases such as PKB and PKC. We have found that TorC2 is activated at the leading edge of the cell and causes the localized activation of PKBs and phosphorylation of PKB substrates. ?The absence of these phosphorylation events in cells lacking ?PiaA leads to a defect in chemotaxis. ?This pathway acts in parallel with PIP3 to mediate the chemotactic response. ?We are presently assessing whether the TorC2 mechanism is conserved in chemotaxing neutrophils.?

Our long term goal is a complete description of the network controlling chemotactic behavior. ?We are analyzing combinations of deficiencies to understand interactions among network components and carrying out additional genetic screens to identify new pathways involved in chemotaxis. ?A comprehensive understanding of this fascinating process should lead to control of pathological conditions such as inflammation and cancer metastasis.

Useful Links
  • Link to?Devreotes?Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

choices_field_3: Will not be available before January 1, 2018
name: When will a wireless pacemaker be commercially available in the United States?
question_text:
The principal function of artificial pacemakers is to regulate the heart beat through the application of electrical impulses. More than 4 million patients around the world use artificial pacemakers, and roughly 700,000 have them implanted each year. The current generation of pacemakers are implanted via surgery and connected to the heart via leads. While the surgery to receive a pacemaker is not highly invasive, there are some associated risks. The leads of current pacemakers can also break or disconnect over time.?

Wireless pacemaker devices currently in trials are smaller and can be implanted directly in the heart (thus requiring no leads) without a surgical procedure. The Nanotism Leadless Pacemaker manufactured by St. Jude Medical is available in some international markets but is not yet FDA approved for use in the United States. Vivek Reddy, MD, of The Mount Sinai Hospital recently reported on a clinical trial of the Nanotism, finding that after 12 months the leadless device appears to be performing comparably to conventional pacemakers.?

Medtronic has also developed a wireless pacemaker device, the Micra Transcatheter Pacing System (TPS), which is even smaller in size than the Nanotism. The Micra TPS was implanted in a patient for the first time in December 2013 as part of a global clinical trial that will enroll up to 780 patients. Initial results of the study are expected in the second part of 2014.

  • http://www.sjm.com/leadlesspacing/intl/options/leadless-pacing
  • http://www.mountsinai.org/about-us/newsroom/press-releases/leadless-pacemaker-showing-promising-resu....
  • http://newsroom.medtronic.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=251324&p=irol-newsarticle&id=1883208
  • http://www.qmed.com/mpmn/medtechpulse/how-medtronic-made-worlds-smallest-pacemaker

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Announcement of availability by the company. The event may also be covered by the news media.

Fine Print

?Wireless pacemaker? refers to an artificial cardiac pacemaker that does not use leads. ?Commercially available in the United States? indicates that the device is approved by the FDA for use in the United States.

keywords: NIPS, Computer Science, Peer Review, Editorial Review
name: 10% of  the papers submitted for the 2014 Neural Information Processing Systems Conference were duplicated and reviewed by two independent groups of reviewers. What percentage of the papers reviewed will yield inconsistent decisions?
question_text:
The question concerns one of the top machine learning conferences, NIPS. This year, as an experiment, 10% of submitted papers were duplicated and reviewed by two independent groups of reviewers which led to a decision by two independent?program committees. ?As part of the experiment, we want you to?estimate the?percentage of inconsistent decisions in this duplicated set.

So far only two people have seen both sets of decisions. They?will announce the results at the conference opening remarks,?6:30pm on Monday 8-DEC. ?(They will not forecast.)

In general, the review process is as follows: Each paper is reviewed by several reviewers ? usually three. Typically the reviewers give independent reviews, this is followed by a discussion period in which they try to achieve consensus, and then the program chairs make a decision. The decision is either to accept or reject.

The papers in the experiment are each reviewed by two independent teams of reviewers, who come to independent decisions of either accept or reject. Inconsistent means one team decides to accept and one team decides to reject.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/08/2014

Resolution Source

Resolution will be based on the official announcement at the NIPS conference. It is currently scheduled for 6:30pm on 8-DEC.

Fine Print

An inconsistent decision is either accept/reject or reject/accept. Forecasts after 6:30pm ET on Monday 8-DEC will not count.

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. For more information on how betting works for this type of question, please refer to the following tutorial: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

keywords: Nuclear Regulatory Commission, NRC, security breach, security hack, cyber
name: Will the individual(s) responsible for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) personal email security breach be identified by the end of 2014?
question_text:
According to an internal investigation by the Office of Inspector General (OIG), the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) was successfully breached three times in the past three years from unspecified foreigners and an unidentified individual(s).? One attack involved phishing emails sent to approximately 215 NRC employees which asked the employee to verify their user accounts by a login.? Just merely clicking on the link, took victims to a Google spreadsheet which wiped their system and changed their user profile.? The OIG was able to track the the individual responsible to an unnamed foreign country.? Another incident involved targeted spearphishing emails that linked to a Microsoft Skydrive storage site and infected the user's computer with malware.? In this incident, there was only one victim and the individual responsible was tracked to a foreign country.? A third attack involved an intrusion into a personal email account of an NRC employee which sent malware in the guise of a PDF file to 16 other employees from the contact list.? One of the employees who received the email was infected.? However the individual(s) responsible for this third attack have not been identified.? Investigators contacted the internet service provider for record logs on the date and time of the attack, however the ISP could not find any since the logs were destroyed.? The OIG initiated the report to document NRC security breaches in 2010 and closed the investigation in 2013.? According to Nextgov, a similar investigation is planned for 2014.? This question asks if the individual(s) responsible for the third attack will be found.

Relevant Links:

  • Nuke Regulator Hacked by Suspected Foreign Powers [Nextgov]
  • Nuclear Regulator Hacked 3 Times in 3 Years [Cnet]
  • Hackers Attach Nuclear Regulatory Commission 3 Times in 3 Years [Fox]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved true if the individual(s) responsible for the personal email security breach of the NRC (the third attack mentioned prior) will be identified by person or location by December 31, 2014.? This will be verified by government related news sources such as Nextgov, Defense News, etc., by other major news sources, or reports from the Inspector General.

Fine Print

'Identified' as defined here means if the individual(s) responsible for the third security hack will be determined by their person (i.e. name), or if the individual(s) geographical location (i.e. country) is determined. However in some cases, the name of the country is not specified. This question will still resolve true if it is reported the location of the individual(s) responsible are determined, although the actual name of the location is not specified. It is also assumed that if the individual(s) are identified, that it will be publicized since agencies are required to publicly disclose breaches if there is evidence that personal information was exposed.

name: How tall will Kingdom Tower in Saudi Arabia be when completed?
question_text:
Constructionhas started on Kingdom Tower in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. It is designed to be theworld?s first kilometer tall building, however, designers and sponsors of theproject have not revealed exactly how tall the building will be when complete, onlythat it will be at least 1000 meters. It is scheduled for completion in 2019.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.kingdomtowerskyscraper.com/
  • http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/architecture/kingdom-tower-construction-of-1km-high-new-worlds-tallest-building-to-begin-next-week-9271191.html
  • http://www.cnn.com/2014/07/01/world/meast/kingdom-tower-how-will-the-elevators-work/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

The exact,final height of Kingdom Tower will be widely reported in the general news media and announced by an official.
For the continuous variable, if the final height is outside the displayed range the question will resolve to the nearest extreme.

Fine Print

If construction is not complete by 12/31/2019, Administrators will extend the question deadline.This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. For more information on how betting works for this type of question, please refer to the following tutorial: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

keywords: Twitter, big data, predictive analytics, sentiment analysis
name: Will a public US company report the analysis of Twitter posts in the conduct of its business in a 2014 business year 10-K filing released after January 8th, 2015?
question_text:
Social media sites generate continuous streams of information regarding sentiment, creating both enormous stocks of such data and real time indicators of the same. As the prevalence of social media data has grown, the tools needed to analyze the mostly qualitative text data have advanced and matured. Analysis of these text data is being used as inputs to predictive analytics focused on everything from new product marketing to anticipating political unrest.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.economist.com/node/18750604
  • http://sherpablog.marketingsherpa.com/social-networking-evangelism-community/twitter-data-mining/
  • http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2014/04/04/twitter_economics_university_of_michigan_stanford_res...
  • http://www.technologyreview.com/view/524871/can-twitter-predict-major-events-such-as-mass-protests/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/30/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved via SEC 10-K filing which?are in the public domain once filed.

This question will resolve when any Twitter data analysis is mentioned, by any public company, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.



Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, reported use of Twitter data refers to any analysis of Twitter data reported by a US company in a 10-K SEC filing made for the January 1 to December 31, 2014 reporting year, e.g. companies that use the calendar year for their fiscal year. The mention in question must be mention of analysis of Twitter data in the conduct of a company's business, not just mention of Twitter platform or company. Twitter, Facebook, and Linkedin are excluded from the companies under consideration.

name: In 2014, a group of researchers published a paper describing the world's first superconductive metamaterial. Will a new superconductive metamaterial be created in 2015?
question_text:
In 2014, a group researchers from Towson University, the University of Maryland, and the Naval Research Laboratory announced the creation of the wolrd's first superconductive metamaterial. The metamaterial? was a compressed mixture of tin and barium titanate nanoparticles of varying composition. The metamaterial appoarch was able was able to raise the critical temperature of tin by 0.15 Kelvin. 0.15 Kelvin is a tiny amount, but a significant step in the quest for high temperature superconductivity. The researchers also found similar results with another metamaterial made with tin and strontium titanate nanoparticles.

In recent years, many researchers and scientists have postulated that metamaterials may be the key to one day achieving room temperature superconductivity.

For more information:

  • Nature - Experimental demonstration of superconducting critical temperature increase in electromagnetic metamaterials
  • Extremetech - The first metamaterial superconductor: One step closer to futuristic physics-defying contraptions
  • MIT Technology Review - How Metamaterials Could Hold the Key to High Temperature Superconductivity

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

For this question to be resolved as yes, an article describing a new superconductive metamaterial must be published between January 1, 2015, and December 31, 2015 in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters Web Of Science or Elsevier's Scopus.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution


Fine Print

Metamaterials are a new class of ordered nanocomposites that exhibit exceptional properties not readily observed in nature. These properties arise from qualitatively new response functions that are not observed in the constituent materials and result from the inclusion of artificially fabricated, extrinsic, low dimensional inhomogeneities.Superductivity is the phenomenon of zero electrical resistance and expulsion of magnetic fields in a given material.

name: When will an operating graphene-based nano-antenna be demonstrated?
question_text:
Nano-antennas have a wide variety of potential uses from communications to nanomachines to solar energy harvesting.? However, nano-antennas made out of traditional materials such as metals require too much energy for low-power applications such as nanomachines.? Graphene is an excellent candidate to make nano-antennas for low-power applications due to its 2-dimensional? characteristics ? the surface plasmon polariton (SPP) wave will allow the nano-antennas to operate at the low end of the terahertz frequency range, between 0.1 and 10 terahertz ? instead of at 150 terahertz required by traditional copper antennas at nanoscale sizes. This frequency reduction results in only a quarter of the power needed for propagation, which could be used for communication.

Nanoantennas have not yet been made out of graphene, but researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology (Georgia Tech) have proposed the concept. They are publishing a paper in IEEE?s Journal of Selected Areas in Communication that describes the design and related calculations for a graphene-based nano-antennas.

This question asks when a research group will create an actual graphene-based nano-antenna.


Resolution Criteria

The Broadband Wireless Lab at Georgia Tech and Polytechnic University of Catalonia is set to publish the theoretical work of how to create the graphene-based nano-antennas.?

Many other groups working on nano-antenna fabrication, and any of them could fabricate an operational graphene-based nano-antenna.?


Resolution Sources

This would be covered by many science news websites including Phys.org and MIT Technology Review.


Fine Print

Graphene-based nano-antenna means an antenna made out of graphene from between 10 and 100 nanometers wide and one micrometer long.

Operating means the resulting antenna transmits and/or receives at the > 0.1 terahertz frequency.

Demonstrated means announced in a press release or covered by a news outlet with a publication submitted to a peer-reviewed journal.


Useful Information and Links

  • Graphene-based nano-antennas may enable networks of tiny machines
  • Graphene Antennas Would Enable Terabit Wireless Downloads
  • Broadband Wireless Networking Lab at Georgia Tech



Related Organizations or Individuals

Dr. Ian F. Akyildiz

keywords: radar signal processing, barrel detection, TALOS suits, weapons detection
name: Will barrel detection capabilities be integrated into the US Army special armed forces' TALOS suits to identify enemy weapons' location, by the end of 2018?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well equipped as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

Threat detection is one of the critical concerns of dismounted soldiers. With advances in sensor technologies, acoustic, radar, imaging, and other multisensory technologies can help soldiers detect enemy shots/artillery from a very long distance to better prepare them with intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities. A technology like Firstguard?s Hintz radar weapon detection system can be used to detect and identify the presence of a barreled weapon aimed in the vicinity of a target before the weapon is fired. The technology uses advanced sensing and radar signal processing to detect and identify enemy barreled weapons.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/?
http://www.firstguardtech.com/5.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that may say the following: 1) the feature has been integrated into a non-prototype suit or 2) that the suits deployed on the ground have this feature.

choices_field_3: Will not be available before January 1, 2019
name: When will a display using nanorods be commercially available?
question_text:
Nanorods are artificially fabricated nanoscale objects synthesized from metals and semiconductor materials that have a range of potential applications in medical diagnostics, cancer therapy, solar cells, sensors, metamaterials, and optical devices and displays.

Recent work has demonstrated the capability of aluminum nanorods to create the red, blue, and green hues found in advanced displays. Five-micron-square pixels were created, each containing several hundred nanorods. Each nanorod measured 40 nanometers (width) by 85-155 nanometers (length) and was fabricated using electron-beam deposition. Pixel color was controlled by varying the length of each nanorod and the spacing between their rows and columns. The colors produced by these variations span a wide range, including a shade of blue which humans can perceive but standard display technologies cannot generate.

For more background, see:
  • http://www.research.ibm.com/articles/nano-counterfeit.shtml
  • http://www.nanowerk.com/nanotechnology-news/newsid=37287.php
  • http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2014/09/11/1415970111

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

A manufacturer making a nanorod-based display available commercially will announce the technical basis of its new product.

Fine Print

Examples of displays include, but are not limited to, televisions, mobile phones, billboards, computer monitors, virtual reality screens.

name: What will be the total U.S. cherry production during the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of tons?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • Total U.S. cherry production (sweet and tart)?for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 466,600 tons.
  • Cherry production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as cherries are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is?the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Cherry production is reported in thousands of tons, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service.


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. cherry production' includes sweet and tart cherries.

The '2013 marketing season' ?for sweet cherries begins 04/25/2013 and ends 08/20/2013. The '2013 marketing season' for tart cherries begins 06/25/2013 and ends 08/15/2013.


The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.

choices_field_8: Northeastern university, Natural Language Processing Lab
name: What team will score the highest in NIST?s 2015 OpenMT Chinese-To-English machine translation evaluation?
question_text:
Machine rendered translation of one human language to another is an active area of research in computer science. The benefits of being able to automatically translate from one language to another are enormous, but so are the challenges. Structurally, human languages differ in their morphology, semantics, syntax, and grammar. In addition to these structural differences, the prevalence of idiom and the contextually dependent interpretation of meaning also contribute significant difficulty to machine translation (MT).

In order to support MT research and help advance the state of the art, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) runs the Open Machine Translation Evaluation (OpenMT). Machine translation teams from around the world test their translation technology on a defined set of non-English text sources and the effectiveness of these competing technologies is evaluated. The list of answer choices for this question (see the Make a Forecast tab) is made up of participant teams in the 2012 evaluation, the most recent one completed.

The 2015 competition will be evaluating Arabic-to-English and Chinese-to-English translation, and include evaluation of machine translation of informal text, such as SMS text, as well as recorded conversational text, both of which differ significantly from formal written text. NIST is considering use of 4 metrics to score each team?s translation (BLUE, METEOR, TER, and HyTER) as well as human assessment. These metrics are commonly used in scoring machine translation and depend on such analyses as comparing machine translations to reference translations. Details of the 2015 OpenMT evaluation, including timeline, data used, and evaluation metrics are available in the links below. Evaluation results for the 2015 evaluation, which is already underway, are expected by the end of January 2015.

For more background, see:

  • http://research.google.com/pubs/MachineTranslation.html
  • http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt.cfm
  • http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt15.cfm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2015

Resolution Source

NIST will report the results of its 2015 OpenMT evaluation here:? http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt15.cfm

Fine Print

NIST has not yet indicated which evaluation metrics it will use, so in resolving this question, scores will be considered in this order: (1) BLUE, (2) METEOR, (3) TER, and (4) HyTER. That is to say, in the scenario where more than one of these metrics is used, the earliest metric on the list will be used to resolve the question.

choices_field_4: Will not be announced by January 1 2050
keywords: Math, Mathematics, Computing, Unique Games Conjecture
name: When will the Unique Games Conjecture be proven?
question_text:
NOTE: The moderator thinks this should have been asked in terms of proof rather than academic consensus -- apparently this problem is considered more amenable to proof than some related conjectures (like P=NP). With only 3 trades so far, we are considering rewording the question. Please leave any comments in the Discussion section by 12-FEB.

In computational complexity theory, the Unique Games Conjecture is a conjecture made by Subhash Khot in 2002. The conjecture postulates that the problem of determining the value of a certain type of game, known as a unique game, has NP-hard algorithmic complexity. It has broad applications in the theory of hardness of approximation. If it is true, then for many important problems it is not only too hard to get an exact solution (as postulated by the P versus NP problem), but also too hard to get a good approximation. There are important implications for constraint satisfaction problems which crop up in a wide variety of disciplines. The conjecture is unusual in that the academic world seems about evenly divided on whether it is true or not.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the Unique Games Conjectures receives 'majority/universal academic support' according to question moderator. Public, open source materials to serve as a "question judge" may be previously identified by an SME (e.g., 'STOC' and/or 'FOCS' or a publicly circulated preprint that a supermajority of practicing theoretical computer scientists acknowledge the conjectures truth, etc.). Outcome will be resolved based on the question moderator's judgment, after reviewing previously identified open source materials, at the time of question resolution. If no significant changes in academic support have been reported by the date in question, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., the academic community remains divided as to the conjecture's truth). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

'STOC' and/or 'FOCS' or a publicly circulated preprint within the theoretical computer science community

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Theoretical Computer Science Journals

Question Moderator - Scott Aaronson (MIT, CSAIL)
short_name: Unique Games Conjecture achieving majority support

keywords: Space, Moon, Moon base, Lunar outpost, moonbase, global
name: When will humans establish a permanent human base on the Moon?
question_text:
Although the return to the Moon is currently not on the agenda of the world's leading space agency, NASA, several other space agencies, commercial and non-governmental organizations are either actively working on or have announced plans to create a human base?on the Moon within the next 15-35 years. Examples include:
  1. RUSSIA. According to reports by Russian newspaper?Izvestia, Russia plans to have a lunar base and moon colony in place by 2030. In April 2014, the Russian Deputy Defense minister in charge of defense and space industries,?Dmitry Rogozin announced in state-media: ?The Moon is not an intermediate point in the [space] race, it is a separate, even a self-contained goal. It would hardly be rational to make some ten or twenty flights to the Moon, and then wind it all up and fly to the Mars or some asteroids. This process has the beginning, but has no end: we are going to come to the Moon forever." A mission to the Moon has become one of Russia's top space priorities and 2030 is widely cited as the target date for establishment of permanent presence. Read more:?http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_04_11/Russia-plans-to-get-a-foothold-in-the-Moon-Dmitriy-Rogozin-5452/,? http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_04_09/Russian-Federal-Space-Agency-is-elaborating-Moon-exploratio...
  2. CHINA.?In January 2014,?Zhang?Yuhua, deputy general director and deputy general designer of the?Chang?e-3?probe system, said in a speech at the Shanghai Science Communication Forum?that, ?In addition to manned lunar landing technology, we are also working on the construction of a lunar base, which will be used for new energy development and living space expansion." Ms Zhang stated that such a lunar base would be used to conduct energy reconnaissance on the Moon, set up industrial and agricultural production bases, as well as make use of the vacuum environment to produce medicines. Read more:?http://gbtimes.com/opinion/chinas-space-program-targets-moon-base
  3. Shackleton Energy Company intends to establish human-tended commercial mining operations on the surface of the Moon with the objective to extract water ice, convert it into propellant and deliver to propellant depots in lower Earth orbit. The company is actively raising capital for its program and expects to have established a base of human-tended operations on the Moon within eight years of program start. Read more: "Shackleton Energy Company?s Propellant Depot and Space Transportation Architecture" -?http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1089/space.2013.0014
  4. Shimizu Corporation has put forward a concept for mega-scale solar power generation on the lunar surface. The concept includes a team?of astronauts supporting robotic surface operation on site. Read more: "The Luna Ring: Lunar Solar Power?Generation" - http://www.shimz.co.jp/english/theme/dream/pdf/lunaring_e.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2029

Resolution Source

  • An official announcement must be made by the lead individual or entity reporting a successful human landing on the Moon with the intention to maintain human presence indefinitely or for at least 3 years.
  • Alternatively, we can draw on media coverage of the human landing on theMoon.
  • Alternatively, 356 days of continuous human occupation of a single facility on the Moon.

Fine Print

"Humans" - unaffiliated individuals; commercial ventures; governmental, intergovernmental or non-governmental organizations from anywhere on Earth.

"Permanent human base on the Moon" - a base operated by humans stationed on the lunar surface permanently or on a rotating basis. A Moon base can be established for a variety of reasons from advancing scientific research (e.g., lunar geology) to running a commercial operation (e.g., water extraction) or serving national interests or global public good (e.g., off-Earth seed bank).

The date the landing occurs in Universal Time will be used to judge which date range is correct.

name: Will artemisinin resistance in malaria parasites be detected in South America in 2015?
question_text:
Artemisinin-based combination treatments are the mainstay of treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria globally, but artemisinin resistance, evidenced by delayed parasite clearance after artemisinin treatment, is now prevalent across an expanding area of southeast Asia. Recently researchers found strong evidence that artemisinin-resistant falciparum malaria extends across much of Upper Myanmar, including regions close to the Indian border in the northwest.?

According to the WHO, parasite resistance to artemisinin has so far been detected in five South-East Asian countries: in Cambodia, the Lao People?s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, Thailand and Viet Nam (all in the Greater Mekong subregion). Artemisinin resistance is also suspected is some parts of South America but confirmatory studies are still ongoing.

For more information:

  • http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099%2815%2970032-0/fulltext
  • http://www.who.int/malaria/media/artemisinin_resistance_qa/en/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

The World Health Organization?s (WHO) data and statistics will be used to resolve this question. The following WHO site reports the countries in which artemisinin resistance has been confirmed: http://www.who.int/malaria/media/artemisinin_resistance_qa/en/

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: When will the Deque Conjecture be proven?
question_text:
The Deque Conjecture is a corollary of the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture and remains unproven. The Deque Conjecture is as follows: Let S be a sequence of m double-ended queue operations (push, pop, inject, eject). Then the cost of performing S on a splay tree is O(m + n).

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the Deque Conjecture is 'proven true' according to judgment rendered by question moderator. If no significant news is reported by the date in question, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., the Deque Conjecture has yet to be proven true). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Theoretical Computing Science Journals

keywords: Solar energy, solar cells, photovoltaic energy, photovoltaic cells, multijunction solar cells, tandem solar cells, concentrated photovoltaics, crystalline silicon, silicon substrates, chemistry
name: When will a crystalline silicon substrate multijunction (or tandem) solar cell  be fabricated that has an efficiency greater than the most efficient single-junction crystalline solar cell?
question_text:
Multijunctionsolar cells, also known as tandem solar cells, are solar cells made up of twoor more p-n junctions constructed on top of one another within the same monolithiccell structure. Multijunction cells are able to achieve high conversion ratesbecause each of the individual junctions is optimized for a different segmentof the spectrum of incident solar radiation.

Mostmultijunction solar cells are fabricated on geranium substrates, as germanium resultsin fewer crystal defects when bonding with the III-V semiconductor materialsused to make the solar junctions layered on top of the substrate junction.Germanium substrates are expensive relative to silicon, however, and so thereare R&D efforts underway to development processes for fabricating multijunctionsolar cells on silicon substrates, in an effort to reduce the cost of solarcells.

Scientists haveestimated an efficiency of 30.7% for a silicon substrate three-junction solar cellwith no crystal defects between individual cells, and 23.7% with realistic defectdensity. The current most efficient single-junction crystalline silicon solarcell has an efficiency of 25%. This question asks when a multijunction solarcell will be fabricated with an efficiency greater than the most efficientsingle-junction crystalline solar cell.

Several research institutions around the world are working on multijunction solar cells. These include:

  • Fraunhofer Institute for Solar Energy Systems ISE
  • Soitec (acquired Concentrix Solar)
  • CEA-Leti
  • The Helmholtz Center Berlin
  • Sharp
  • Spectrolab (part of Boeing)
  • National Renewable Energy Laboratory?s National Center for Photovoltaics


Resolution Sources

Progress in Photovoltaics publishes solar cell efficiencyrecords by category of solar cell.


Fine Print

Amultijunction solar cell is a solar cell design in which two or more separatep-n junctions are constructed monolithically within the same device.

Crystallinesilicon refers to monocrystalline silicon, as distinct from polycrystalline oramorphous crystalline.



Useful Information and Links

For reviewof the current science see IEEE JOURNALOF PHOTOVOLTAICS, VOL. 3, NO. 3, JULY 2013 1125-1131.

For newscoverage of developments, the following science outlets cover progress onmultijunction solar cells:

  • Solar Power World:?http://www.solarpowerworldonline.com/
  • Phys Org:?http://phys.org/news/
  • Semiconductor Today:?http://www.semiconductor-today.com/


Related Organizations or Individuals

National Renewable Energy Laboratory?s National Center for Photovoltaics (see http://www.nrel.gov/ncpv/) publishes a chart of research cell efficiency records in Progress in Photovoltaics. See http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1099-159X

question_text:
Crowdfunding?is the practice of funding a project or venture by raising monetary contributions from a large number of people, typically via the internet.?Crowdfunding has quickly moved from a trendy buzzword to a mainstream fundraising model.?In less than five years, Kickstarter has attracted more than five million contributors pledging close to $1 billion, funding more than 55,000 individual projects. Kickstarter's rival fundraising platform Indiegogo can boast of a campaign that single-handedly generated $12 million in pledges. Numbers like these make crowdfunding an attractive option for first-time entrepreneurs and established businesses alike, giving them the opportunity not only to raise capital but also to gain a sense of the market for a given project.?

The popularity of crowdfunding sites is?growing quickly. The?most recent report by Compete.com shows that kickstarter.com attracted over 8.6 million unique visitors in January 2015, compared to?1.5 million?in January 2014. It is one of the top crowdfunding sites in the United States.

keywords: Flu, region 4, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 4 (AL, FL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, and TN)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 4' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 4 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 4 is comprised of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 4 is 1.9%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: A recent analysis of the nitrogen in Titan's atmosphere found the moon's atmospheric nitrogen originated in conditions similar to ancient comets from the Oort cloud. Will New Horizon's analysis of Pluto's atmospheric nitrogen find similar conditions?
question_text:
A recent NASA and European Space Agency?funded study has found evidence that the atmospheric nitrogen?of?Titan, one of Saturn's moons,?originated in conditions similar to the cold birthplace of the most ancient comets from the Oort cloud. This evidence is based on the isotopic ratio of?nitrogen-14 to nitrogen-15 in Titan?s atmosphere.?The research team found that our Solar System is not old enough for this nitrogen isotope ratio to have changed as much as the ratio in Titan's nitrogen. This suggests that Titan (or at least Titan's atmosphere) is older than Saturn and other?Solar System bodies, and?is more similar to Oort cloud comets, which were formed?in the protosolar nebula before the formation of the?solar system.

The research team is now very interested to see what NASA's New Horizons spacecraft will find when arrives to study Pluto and its moon Charon in July 2015. Will Pluto's atmospheric nitrogen?show a similar isotopic ratio to Titan's?

  • Universe Today - Titan's atmosphere may be older than Saturn, new study suggests
  • Sci-News - Nitrogen in atmosphere of Titan may pre-date Saturn, study says
  • Wikipedia - Titan (moon)


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2015

Resolution Source

The findings of the New Horizons analysis of Pluto's atmosphere?will be announced by NASA on their website. The New Horizons mission is also being covered by numerous scientific news outlets, as well as the mainstream press.

Fine Print

'Similar conditions' refers to the ratio of Nitrogen-14 to Nitrogen-15 in in Pluto's atmosphere, and whether NASA or ESA releases a statement saying this ratio suggests Pluto's atmosphere originated in conditions similar to comets from the Oort cloud. There is no specific ratio that must be reached for this question to resolve as 'yes', rather this question will be resolved based on whether an official spokesperson from NASA or ESA states that the ratio found in Pluto's atmosphere suggests that its atmosphere is older than previously thought as a result of this analysis.

name: When will a qubit processor be demonstrated that has both fidelity above 99% and at least 512 qubits?
question_text:
A quantum computer would be several orders of magnitude faster than a classical computer in the execution of optimization problems.? Optimization problems are a key part of a wide range of fields from the simplicity of the traveling salesman problem, to the complexity of machine learning.? As useful as it would be, constructing a quantum computer is no easy task. To be a quantum computer three properties must be present: superposition, coherence, and entanglement.? That is, a pair of quantum bits or qubits in the computer must individually be able to hold both a one and a zero with complimentary probability, this probability for each qubit must vary in time with the other half of the pair or qubits, and when the qubits? probabilities are resolved the results for each qubit must be different.

One of the major players in the field of quantum computing, a small Canadian company named D-Wave, claimed that it had successfully created a quantum processor in 2007.? While the claim was greeted with skepticism at the time, D-Wave has since successfully demonstrated that quantum effects are occurring in their device.? However, researchers also found that the qubits are only around half entangled even in smaller groupings, suggesting that their full size 512-qubit system is even less entangled.? In addition, the qubits are arranged in a very specific and more limiting arrangement. ?Taken together, this implies that, while their system possesses a large number of qubits, it can only calculate as though it possesses a fraction of the true amount.? D-Wave?s next challenge is increasing the entanglement of their system or finding a way to create a large enough qubit system that the low percent level of utilization in their system is no longer relevant.

On the other end of the spectrum, Google has hired John Martinis to make their own version of the D-Wave chip.? Martinis has specialized in low size qubit systems with high fidelity.? He has demonstrated over 99% fidelity with two-qubit systems and consistently high fidelity with up to five-qubit systems.? Now working for Google he will attempt to bring the high fidelity to larger systems similar to those in the D-Wave system.

More Information:
www.technologyreview.com/news/530516/google-launches-effort-to-build-its-own-quantum-computer/
http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v473/n7346/full/nature10012.html
http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v508/n7497/full/nature13171.html
http://www.technologyreview.com/news/530986/three-questions-with-the-ceo-of-d-wave/
http://arstechnica.com/science/2014/06/a-quantum-computing-gun-revealed-by-quantum-smoke/
http://arstechnica.com/science/2013/08/d-waves-black-box-starts-to-open-up/

They also introduced a monthly?international rig count in 1975. This count is released on the fifth working day of each month.?

keywords: Space, Rosetta, comet, European Space Agency
name: Will Rosetta successfully fire its thrusters to begin its trip to Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko?
question_text:
In November 1993, the International Rosetta Mission was approved as a Cornerstone Mission in the European Space Agency's Horizons 2000 Science Programme.

Rosetta lifted off on March 2004 on a European Ariane 5 rocket from Kourou in French Guiana. During a circuitous ten-year trek across the Solar System, Rosetta crossed the asteroid belt and traveled into deep space. Its destination is a periodic comet known as Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

On January 20, 2014, the European Space Agency confirmed that Rosetta woke from its 31 months in hibernation used to conserve power as it arced beyond the orbit of Jupiter on a path that should take it to Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

The BBC reports: [F]rom mid-March to the end of April, ESA will be switching on the instruments one by one.? [If successful]...Rosetta will begin firing its thrusters to begin zeroing in on Comet 67P. Today, the separation is nine million km away. By mid-September, it should be reduced to just 10 km.

Links:

  • Rosetta comet-chaser phones home
  • European Space Agency: Rosetta

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2014

Resolution Source

The European Space Agency will announce the firing of the thrusters:? www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Science/Rosetta

Fine Print

This question will be resolved as ?yes? only for the successful intentional firing of Rosetta's thrusters to start its trip to the comet, as announced by the European Space Agency.

keywords: Lunar, moonwalk, moon, space, astronaut, china
name: When will the Chinese National Space Administration land a man or woman on the moon?
question_text:
• On June 22, 2006 deputy chief architect of the lunar probe project,?Long Lehao,?laid out a schedule for China's lunar exploration which identified?2024 as the target?date of China's first moonwalk.
  • China's manned spaceflight programme was launched in 1992. In 1995, Russia agreed to help with advice on technology and astronaut training. And the first of four uncrewed test flights of a Shenzhou craft took place in November 1999.
  • On October 15 2003, China became the third nation to send a human into space after completing the?Shenzhou 5 mission during which??Yang Liwei orbited the earth 14 times.
  • On September 25?2008, China successfully completed it's first spacewalk mission, Shenzhou 7.
  • A 2011 white paper published by the Chinese government outlined tentative plans to land a man on the moon confirming the nation's intention to become a major spacefaring nation. Officials in China have spoken before of their hopes for a crewed lunar mission, but the government document is the first to state the aim as a formal goal for the nation's space agency.
  • On December 14 2013, China?became the third country to steer a spacecraft onto the moon after its unmanned Chang?e-3 probe settled onto the Bay of Rainbows, as reported by?state-run television.

Resolution Criteria

An official announcement must be made by either Xinhua news agency or?the State Administration of Science, Technology and Industry for National Defense.?In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.?


Resolution Sources

The New York Times?

Fine Print

"Landing" a man or woman on the moon will be achieved by a?walk on the moon's surface by an astronaut affiliated with the CNSA.?

keywords: NAIAS 2015, Self-driving Car, Autonomous Vehicle, Concept Car
name: How many vehicle introductions (production and concept) with autonomous capability will debut at the 2015 NAIAS?
question_text:
The North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) is one of the largest auto shows in North America, held annually in Detroit, Michigan.? The NAIAS Conference is where the global automotive community comes together to catch up on the latest news and events, along with showcasing the automotive world's most anticipated vehicle premieres.? At the 2014 NAIAS, Nissan displayed the Nissan Autonomous Leaf Prototype, a concept car featuring the Nissan Autonomous Drive (AD) technology.? With the rise of many of the world's leading auto-manufacturer's researching into autonomous vehicle technology, this leads to the question of how many vehicle introductions at the 2015 NAIAS will feature autonomous capability.

Relevant Links:

  • NAIAS 2015 Conference Information
  • NAIAS 2014 Statistics | NAIAS 2013 Statistics
  • Nissan Dazzles Detroit with Concept Cars [Gizmag]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/25/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the total number of vehicle introductions of both production and concept, at the 2015 NAIAS Conference that include autonomous capability (level 2 or higher).? This will be verified by automotive news sources, other major news sources, and NAIAS news.? In addition, a statistics report by NAIAS may be released after the conference which lists all of the production and concept vehicle introductions at the 2015 NAIAS.? Note that this question asks only about the production and concept vehicle introductions debuted, not the total number of vehicles showcased at the 2015 NAIAS.

Fine Print

'Autonomous capability' is defined here as corresponding to the Combined Function Automation, or Level Two of the NHTSA classification of autonomous vehicles: "This level involves automation of at least two primary control functions [such as braking, steering, or accelerating] designed to work in unison to relieve the driver of control of those functions. An example of combined functions enabling a Level 2 system is adaptive cruise control in combination with lane centering." This definition can therefore include both fully autonomous vehicles, and semi-autonomous or vehicles with autonomous driver assisted features. Note about resolution information: For this question there may not be extensive information about each of the vehicles debuted. Shortly after the conference, the specifications of each vehicle will be researched and if there is no mention of autonomous capability, then the vehicle will not be deemed as having autonomous capability.

name: Will the average temperature for the contiguous U.S. during July 2014 be above 75?F?
question_text:
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s National Climatic Data Center maintains the monthly average temperature records for a period that dates back to 1895. The warmest average July temperature on the record was reported at 77.6?F in 2012. In 2013, the average July temperature in the contiguous U.S. was 74.3?F. The mean July temperature for all years in the 20th century was 73.5?F

https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/sotc/national/2013/7
