keywords: Millennium Prize, Clay Institute, P & NP, P vs NP, Mathematics, Math
name: When will the Clay Mathematics Institute announce a winner of the Millennium Prize for resolving the "P vs NP Problem"?
question_text:
One of the outstanding problems in computer science is determining whether questions exist whose answer can be quickly checked, but which require an impossibly long time to solve by any direct procedure. Many practically-important problems certainly seem to be of this kind, but so far no one has managed to prove that any of them really are so hard as they appear, i.e., that there really is no feasible way to generate an answer with the help of a computer. Stephen Cook and Leonid Levin formulated the P (i.e., easy to find) versus NP (i.e., easy to check) problem independently in 1971.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from The Clay Mathematics Institute website (http://www.claymath.org/millennium/) and disputes will be arbitrated by the question moderator. If nothing is reported from either source, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., "(d) Will not be announced by January 1, 2030"). Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed (e.g., direct outreach to prominent researchers in this field), provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from The Clay Mathematics Institute website. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Various mathematics journals (e.g., Journal of the ACM http://jacm.acm.org/)

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Useful Links

  • The Clay Mathematics Institute, http://www.claymath.org/
  • http://www.claymath.org/?
  • http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2009/explainer-pnp.html?
  • http://www.win.tue.nl/~gwoegi/P-versus-NP.htm

Related Organizations or Individuals

The Clay Mathematics Institute, http://www.claymath.org/

keywords: Flu, Region 6, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 6 (AR, LA, NM, OK, TX)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 6' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 6 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 6 is comprised of Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Texas.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 6 is 3.3%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will the Hubble Telescope observe water vapor plumes on Europa for a second time before May 1, 2015?
question_text:
In December of 2012, the Hubble Telescope detected 120-mile high plumes of water vapor spewing from the surface of Europa, a moon of Jupiter thought to harbor a liquid ocean under its icy crust. These plumes of water vapor were thought to have been caused by giant geysers. However, subsequent observations from Hubble in January, February, November and December of 2014 failed to spot any plumes of water vapor to confirm the existence of these geysers. Additionally, new analysis of images from NASA's Galileo probe, which studied Jupiter and its moons from 1995 through 2003, failed to find any evidence of geyser activity on Europa.

However, scientists are not discounting the possibility that the geysers exist - the eruptions may be infrequent or be influenced by Jupiter's gravitational pull.

The Hubble search for Europa's geysers is scheduled to continue through April 2015.

For more information, see:

  • Scientific American - Jupiter Moon Europa's Giant Geysers Are Missing
  • NASA - Hubble Space Telescope Sees Evidence of Water Vapor Venting off Jupiter Moon

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/01/2015

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when?NASA announces observed water vapor plumes or by the resolution date.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

The research also shows that many people are willing to pay more for the labeling.

In April 2012, the?FDA issued for public comment the "Draft Guidance for Industry: Assessing the Effects of Significant Manufacturing Process Changes, Including Emerging Technologies, on the Safety and Regulatory Status of Food Ingredients and Food Contact Substances, Including Food Ingredients that are Color Additive". At the present time, the FDA does not require labeling of food and food packaging materials that use nanotechnology.

keywords: barrel detection, skeletal pattern detection, synthetic aperture radar, SAR technology
name: Will the US Armed forces use synthetic aperture radar (SAR) technology to detect armed enemy forces? skeletal patterns along with barrel identification on the battlefront by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Threat detection is one of the critical concerns of dismounted soldiers. With advances in sensor technologies, acoustic, radar, imaging, and other multisensory technologies can help soldiers detect enemy presence from a very long distance to better prepare them with intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities. Currently, US defense forces use distance individual identification using iris, facial, voice, and gait recognition technologies. But these can be masked or altered by enemies in different successful measures. Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) design can be employed to scan a person and define his/her skeletal patterns. Even a portion of the skeleton, which is as individual as any other identifier, can be enrolled in a database to track an individual. The patent holder for this technology claims that it is not possible to mask the skeletal pattern from the penetrating SAR.? This system can generate a resolution of about 1cm and with further R&D this can be improved.

If barrel detection capabilities were added to the SAR technology along with the skeletal pattern detection, it would be very effective to detect both enemy and his/her weapon?s presence.

http://www.afcea.org/content/?q=node/11607
http://www.firstguardtech.com/5.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that the technology is being used on the ground, either as a standalone technology or as a feature in another combat-ready technology or device.

Fine Print

The question will be resolved if SAR technology is used for both skeletal and barrel detection at the same time to confirm enemy presence even over long distances.

The pilot plant?was cost effective and can produce 14,000 gallons of purified water a day. Upon the success of the pilot project, an expansion is planned?to build a complex of 36 plants?that together can pump out 2 million gallons a day.?WaterFX, the company that invented?the system, hopes to start the project within a year.

name: Will a lab confirmed case of the Chikungunya virus infection be detected in the United States in 2014?
question_text:
A widespread outbreak of the chikungunya virus has beenreported in the Caribbean region where a string of atleast 15 islands have beenaffected. Scientists fear that the virus is set to spread from Southern UnitedStates to Argentina through mosquitoes. The virus is said to spread rapidly in densecities which can make millions of people sick with rashes, fever, and agonizing,sometimes lasting, pain in fingers, wrists, elbows, toes, ankles, and knees. Untilnow more than 4000 cases have been confirmed in the lab. However, suspectedcases of people with acute fever and severe, unexplained joint pains exceeded45,000 early this week in May 2014.

The Science journal reports on the increased possibility of virus infection spreading to the US: ?the reason experts felt socertain?and the Pan American Health Organization warned countries to prepare in2011?is that the virus was causing huge outbreaks elsewhere, and its mainvector, the Aedes aegypti mosquito, iswidespread in the Americas.? The A. aegypti mosquito also transmits dengue, a disease that has similar symptoms but is more often deadly. Dengue has caused major outbreaks in Latin America and virologists say that wherever the disease occurs, chikungunya can spread as well. Additionally, soccer fans are traveling to Brazil for the World Cup in June and July and this could increase the possibility of infected cases and spread of the disease.
Virologists worry that there are no drugs for chikungunya.However, several vaccine candidates are in various stages of development - theCaribbean outbreak has revived industry attention.

For more information, see:

  • Crippling Virus Setto Conquer Western Hemisphere:?http://www.sciencemag.org/content/344/6185/678.full
  • Chikungunya in the Carribean: http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/chikungunya-saint-martin?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

CDC update: http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/
WHO news: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/en/

Fine Print

Lab-confirmed: as announced by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or the World Health Organization (WHO).

keywords: telomeres, twin paradox, space travel, aging
name: At the end of the NASA's twin experiment, will the length of telomeres of the astronaut in space be found shorter than that of his twin on earth?
question_text:
In physics, Einstein's?twin paradox?is a?thought experiment?in?special relativity?involving identical twins, one of whom makes a journey into space in a high-speed rocket and returns home to find that the twin who remained on Earth has aged more.

Some researchers are beginning to believe that space travel could have the opposite effect, and make?one prematurely old. The problem with Einstein's paradox is that it doesn't account for biology?specifically, space radiation and the biology of aging. While the astronaut twin is hurtling through space, his chromosomes are exposed to penetrating cosmic rays. This could damage his telomeres?little molecular "caps" on the ends of his DNA.

In March 2015, NASA astronaut Scott Kelly will join cosmonaut Mikhail Kornienko on a one-year mission to the International Space Station. Their lengthy stay aims to explore the effects of long-term space flight on the human body. The interesting thing about Scott is, he's a twin. His brother Mark is also an astronaut, now retired. While Scott, the test subject, spends one year circling Earth at 17,000 mph, Mark will remain behind as a control. One experiment proposed in the?NASA's twin experiment?will look at telomeres?little molecular "caps" on the ends of human DNA. Here on Earth, the loss of telomeres has been linked to aging. In space, telomere loss could be accelerated by the action of cosmic rays. Comparing the twins' telomeres could tell researchers if space radiation is prematurely aging space travelers.

  • NASA to conduct unprecedented twin experiment:?http://phys.org/news/2014-04-nasa-unprecedented-twin.html
  • NASA Selects 10 Proposals to Explore Genetic Aspects of Spaceflight:?http://www.nasa.gov/content/nasa-selects-10-proposals-to-explore-genetic-aspects-of-spaceflight/#.VJ...
  • Scientist examines effects of space travel in twin study:?http://today-archive.colostate.edu/story.aspx?id=9885
  • Was Einstein Wrong About Space Travel??http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2006/22mar_telomeres/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2017

Resolution Source

Study result?will be available?on the?NASA project page:?http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/1771.html

The result is also likely to be reported in the mainstream news and scientific press.
short_name: Effect of space travel on aging

keywords: Flu, Region 1, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 1 (CT, ME, MA, NH, RI, VT)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.
?
?? ? ? ? ? ? ?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 1' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.

The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 1 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 1 is comprised of Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont.

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 1 is 1.2%.

?In the event the end occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will a company announce plans to launch a satellite constellation that will consist of more than 66 active satellites and will provide internet service by 1 March 2015?
question_text:
• Currently the largest satellite constellation belongs to Iridium Communications.? Their constellation of 66 active communication satellites provides voice and data coverage to satellite phones, pagers, and integrated transceivers over Earth's entire surface.
  • Modern satellite Internet service is typically provided to users through geostationary satellites. The newer satellites use the Ka band to achieve high download speeds.
  • Previous attempts as large scale internet satellite projects have failed; however, as the cost of manufacturing and launching satellites falls and satellite technology has improved, it may be more likely that a company or companies may attempt again a satellite constellation than before.

Iridium satellite constellation: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iridium_satellite_constellation

03/01/2015

Official press release or announcement from the company. (Twitter postings will NOT count as official.)

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

A satellite constellation is defined as a group of artificial satellites working in concert. The announced swarm would need to consist of more than 66 active satellites to resolve this question as yes.

name: Will the 2014 World Chess Championship match between Magnus Carlsen and Viswanathan Anand require a tie-break?
question_text:
The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. A variety of news sources are expected to monitor the match with immediate updates as the match evolves.

name: Which team competing as of December 2014 will win the Google Lunar XPrize Grand Prize before December 31st, 2016?
question_text:
The $20-million Google Lunar XPrize?Grand Prize (http://lunar.xprize.org) will go "to the first team with 10% or less government funding to land a robot on the Moon (safely), move 500 meters, and stream HD mooncasts to share" with the world.

As of December 2014, five teams had been selected to compete for any or all of the program's three Milestone Prizes, demonstrating the landing capability, mobility, or video systems necessary to fulfill the XPrize requirements. (http://lunar.xprize.org/about/milestone-prizes) These teams were Astrobotic (a spin-off of the Carnegie Mellon University Robotics Institute), Japan's Hakuto; Moon Express (a private company headquartered in Silicon Valley, Calif.); Team Indus (managed by Axiom Resear Labs Private Limited and based in Bangalore, India); Part Time Scientists (an international team of dozens of scientists, engineers, and entrepreneurs).
The GLXP website notes that any of the approximately 18 teams entered (http://lunar.xprize.org/teams)?can win the Grand Prize.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

http://lunar.xprize.org
The question will be resolved when a winner is announced at the Google Lunar XPrize website, or when the final deadline passes with no winner announced or under consideration. The time will be the UTC time and date at which the winner completes the final requirement of the competition, as announced by GLXP. In the event that the time is not included in any GLXP announcement, SciCast will attempt to resolve the question from competition records.

*Question Update: In the event that two or multiple teams combine, we will resolve the question using a mixture resolution with an equal share for each answer choice

question_text:
For several years, there have?been rumors that Apple has been on the verge of launching an own-brand television, often referred to as the 'iTV'.?The company has yet to release?anything or even hint that it might be working on an HDTV product. At the same time, analysts have pointed?to signs that Apple is indeed working on an iTV, such as the suggestion that?the company?is currently testing a 65-inch OLED panel, which could be used in a television.http://bgr.com/tag/itv/

name: What will be the indexed popularity of the C computer language in March of 2015, as reported by the TIOBE index?
question_text:
The TIOBE programming community index is a measure of the popularity of programming languages, calculated from number of search engine results for queries containing the name of each language. The index covers searches in Google, Google Blogs, MSN, Yahoo!, Baidu, Wikipedia, and YouTube, and is updated once a month. An interactive, long-term chart of its results is available on the TIOBE website (http://www.tiobe.com/index.php/content/paperinfo/tpci/index.html) dating back to 2002. TIOBE focuses on Turing-complete languages, so it does not provide information about the popularity of, for instance, SQL or HTML.

November 2014 data are already available (as of November 21, 2014) and report C, Java, Objective-C, C++, C#, and PHP as the top six languages; these were also the top six languages (in the same order) in November of 2013. Below that the popularity of languages has shifted from November 2013 to November 2014. Its rating for each language is reported as a percentage with three decimal places. For example, the November 2014 rating for C is 17.469%.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.tiobe.com/index.php/content/paperinfo/tpci/index.html
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measuring_programming_language_popularity
  • http://www.infoworld.com/article/2608845/java/java-java-c-slip-in-popularity-as-domain-specific-lang...


Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

TIOBE will report its language index for March of 2015 sometime during that month, on its site:? http://www.tiobe.com/index.php/content/paperinfo/tpci/index.html

Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the reported popularity is 17%, the "Between 17% and 18%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Automated vehicles, driverless vehicles, self-driving vehicles
name: When will the first U.S. state enact legislation allowing consumer operation of driverless cars?
question_text:
Predictedsince the 1930s, the advent of driverless cars has promised to solve problemsof traffic congestion and vehicle-related accidents by removing the human elementfrom passenger car operation. Google has an active research program indriverless cars, and as the concept of truly driverless cars has started toseem more achievable, U.S. Department of Transportation's National HighwayTraffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) announced a new policy concerning vehicleautomation in May of 2013. NHTSA?s policy divides vehicle technologies into fivecategories: No automaton (Level 0); Function-specific Automation (Level 1),Combined Function Automation (Level 2), Limited Self-Driving Automation (Level3); Full Self-Driving Automation (Level 4), with driverless cars fall into Levels3 and 4. According to NHTSA Google?s current prototype would be a level threeautomated vehicle.

The NHTSA policycalls for individual states to regulate standards for automated vehicles, and theCalifornia Department of Motor Vehicles has set regulations for the testing ofautomated vehicles, but does not yet allow consumer operation of driverlesscars. In Sweden, Volvo is planning to introduce 100 driverless cars on topublic roads in 2017 as part of the world?s first large-scale autonomousdriving pilot. The Volvo cars will drive in normal, everyday road conditions,surrounded by pedestrians and other traffic, and will even be able to self-parkafter the human driver has left the vehicle.

Self-driving, driverless, and automated passenger cars are synonymous terms. ?Driverless implies a NHSTA level 3 or 4 categorized car.?

This question asks when the first state will allow consumer operation of aNHTSA Level 3 or 4 self-driving car in the U.S. "Allow consumer operation"here means the question will resolve when the legislation in question leads toactual allowed consumer use of driverless cars, i.e. the date at which itbecomes legal for consumers to use such cars as a result of passedLegislation.

Resolution Criteria

Google is the leading company in the U.S. developing driverless car systems, and several major automobile manufacturers are working on various types of vehicle automation, with Volvo at the forefront of this effort. California is the most likely state to first enact legislation allowing consumer use of driverless cars.?

Resolution Sources

Legislation allowing consumer operation of driverless vehicleswould be covered by the popular and transportation-focused press.?http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/11/25/131125fa_fact_bilger?currentPage=all

Useful Information and Links

  • U.S. Department of Transportation ReleasesPolicy on Automated Vehicle Developmet
  • Has the self-driving car at last arrived?
  • NHTSA: US now at 'historic turning point' ondriverless cars
  • Large-scale trial of driverless cars to begin onpublic roads
  • Driverless cars could be cruising Californiaroads by spring
  • Driverless cars set to roam Milton Keynes from2017, says Vince Cable

name: Which of the following changes will be reported on the topic of Nitrogen deposition in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

name: Will a Phase 1 clinical trial start recruiting participants before the end of 2014 for a study of the treatment of autism using suramin, a century-old treatment for sleeping sickness?
question_text:
Researchers at University of California, San Diego School of Medicine?tested the effect of suramin, a drug first synthesized in 1916 to treat African sleeping sickness, and found that it blocked the extracellular signaling pathway used in a mouse model of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Cells subsequently began behaving normally and autism-like behaviors and metabolism in the mice were corrected. Researchers believe these findings are sufficiently encouraging to launch a small phase 1 clinical trial with children who have ASD.

  • http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/06/140617102457.htm

Suramin is a drug developed in 1926 and is used for treatment of human sleeping sickness caused by trypanosomes.ASD: autism spectrum disorder, describes a variety of symptoms among children with autism.

name: Will the first CHAdeMO quick charge station for battery electric vehicles on mainland China be built before the end of March 2015?
question_text:
CHAdeMO is the trade name for a quick-charging method for battery electric vehicles. It delivers up to 62.5 kW of high-voltage direct current via a special electrical connector, and?is proposed as a global industry standard by an association of the same name. CHAdeMO is an abbreviation of "CHArge de MOve", equivalent to "charge for moving". The name is a pun?on O cha demo ikaga desukain Japanese, which translates to English as "How about some tea?", referring to the time it would take to charge a car. CHAdeMO can charge low-range electric cars in less than half an hour. According to?information posted on the official CHAdeMO Association's website, there are currently several?CHAdeMO DC Quick chargers installed in Hong Kong, but none in?mainland China.

  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CHAdeMO

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

The number of?CHAdeMO stations is?reported on the CHAdeMO Association's website:http://www.chademo.com/

name: How will the U.S. catch of Pacific sardines in 2014 change from the 2013 estimated catch of 112,296 metric tons?
question_text:
The Pacific sardine has experienced a severe population decrease in recent years, with stock biomass estimates dropping from 1.37 million metric tons in 2006 to 378,120 metric tons in 2014, a decrease of 70 percent.? The current sardine population crash mirrors similar crashes in Pacific sardine populations in the 1950s and 1980s. Sardines are sensitive to temperature shifts ? they prefer warmer water ? and they are believed to be profoundly impacted by a phenomenon called the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), a decades-long warm and cool cycle in the North Pacific. However, the PDO is not fully understood (it was only identified in 1997) and it can only partly explain the current crash in sardine populations.

From 2006 to 2012, commercial landings of the Pacific sardine were relatively unaffected by the population decline, with annual catches falling within the range of 138,000 to 165,000 metric tons. However, the 2013 U.S. commercial catch was the lowest in over a decade at an estimated 112,296 metric tons, with U.S. fishermen failing to meet the allowed sardine catch quota. In British Columbia, Canadian fishermen report that their fishery collapsed entirely in 2013.

Because of concerns over the impact of fishing on the already stressed sardine population, the Pacific Fishery Management Council (PFMC) has reduced the allowable U.S. Pacific catch by 70 percent from January through June 2014 ? from 18,073 metric tons during that period last year to 5,446 metric tons this year. The PFMC hopes that a reduced harvest will allow sardine stocks to replenish, though many fear that it could take years for the Pacific sardine population to recover.

  • The Atlantic: Why West Coast Sea Life Has Been Behaving So Strangely
  • Monterrey County Weekly: The modest little fish ? and Monterey icon ? contains grand teachings on how to manage fish populations.
  • Vancouver Sun: Sardine fishery collapse affects economy, ecology
  • Monterrey Bay Aquarium Research Institute: From sardines to anchovies and back in 50 years?Local fisheries part of bigger cycle affecting entire Pacific Ocean
  • NOAA Fisheries: Status of U.S. Fisheries
  • Sardine 2013 Annual Catch and 2014 Biomass Projection

The Pacific Decadal Oscillation has a strong, though not fully understood impact on sardine populations. A change in the sardine fishing quota by the Pacific Fishery Management Council would also have a direct impact on the annual sardine catch.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/30/2015

Resolution Source

NOAA Fisheries Service published its annual sardine stock assessment report for U.S. management, which list the sardine catch for the previous year, each October. Estimates are published on the Pacific Fishery Management Council website.The report detailing the 2014 catch is scheduled to be released in October 2015.

Fine Print

The annual U.S. catch is defined as that reported by NOAA Fisheries in their annual sardine stock assessment for U.S. management report

name: What will be the highest reported efficiency achieved by a metamaterial power harvester by DEC 1 2015?
question_text:
Hawkes et al designed an array of five metamaterial cells, made from split copper circuits, to harvest microwave energy. The microwaves cause an oscillating current in the material, and the copper circuits convert part of that current into usable power in the power harvester. Simulations of the structure predict a maximum efficiency of 61% for an input power of 24.25 dBM, the maximum available experimental power (at an incident power density of approximately 1.6 mW/cm2).? The research team then built a functional metamaterial power harvester capable of converting up to 36.8% of the incident RF power to DC power.

This reflects a major increase in the efficiency of converting microwaves into electrical energy ? previous attempts had only achieved 6 to 10 percent efficiency. However, the current device only achieves 60% of the theoretical efficiency.? Further optimization can increase the current efficiency; however, reaching the simulated limit may not be possible due to the effective area of the single cell, which is 78% of the entire width of the waveguide. According to of the authors "our work demonstrates a simple and inexpensive approach to electromagnetic power harvesting. The beauty of the design is that the basic building blocks are self-contained and additive. One can simply assemble more blocks to increase the scavenged power."

Sources and references:

  • A microwave metamaterial with integrated power harvesting functionality
  • Wireless device converts 'lost' energy into electric power: Metamaterial cells provide electric power as efficiently as solar panels
  • Inexpensive wireless device harnesses "lost" energy from microwave signals
  • Microwave harvesters could pluck electricity out of thin air


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/01/2015

Resolution Source

The device must be described in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomas Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

The device can be built and tested in the lab or in a company and described in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomas Reuters? Web of Science. Efficiency: RF-to-DC power conversion efficiency: the ratio of DC power outputted from the device to the RF power inputted into the device.

name: Singlet fission transforms an excited singlet state into a pair of triplet excitons and can potentially boost the efficiency of solar energy conversion. Will an inorganic solar cell exceed the Shockley?Queisser limit of 33% using singlet fission by 2017?
question_text:
• Shockley and Queisser calculated the maximum energy conversion efficiency of a single-junction photovoltaic cell to be 33% because photons with energy higher than the bandgap energy are absorbed by the cell and the excess energy is dissipated as heat.
  • The Shockley?Queisser limit assumes that a single photon creates a single electron?hole pair. If a single high-energy photon could create two electron-hole pairs, substantial efficiency gains could be achieved by reducing the energy dissipated as heat and increasing the energy converted to electron-hole pairs.
  • A MIT research group has demonstrated an organic photovoltaic cell with more than 100 percent external quantum efficiency based on this effect.

Links and sources
  • Piland, et al. Singlet Fission: From Coherences to Kinetics. J. Phys. Chem. Lett., 2014, 5 (13), pp 2312?2319
  • Singlet Fission Holds Two-for-One Potential in Solar Cells http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy12osti/53605.pdf
  • Singlet fission photovoltaics http://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/79496

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

This refers to a single junction solar cell. The efficiency of the cell must exceed 33% and be reported by a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science. The article must be published before the question deadline, otherwise the question will resolve to the status quo (i.e., "No").

name: What percentage of the US female population aged 13-17 will be vaccinated against HPV by the end of 2013?
question_text:
• Human Papiloma Virus is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. More information can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spentto vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervicalcancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the Center for Disease Control in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who would have been targeted during the original vaccination campaign. 53.8% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012. More information can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/std/hpv/HPV-monitoring-plan-revised-June-2011.pdf.
  • Questions about vaccination of males began in 2010 and revealed significantly lower levels of vaccination in comparison to females. More information can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/who/teens/vaccination-coverage.html


Development of a new vaccine; Research establishing a connection between other conditions and HPV infection; Reports on prolonged immunity from HPV vaccination

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2014

Resolution Source

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Annual National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. These results can be found on the CDC's HPV data and statistics page and in the CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

The annual survey is typically released each July.

Fine Print

HPV stands for the human papiloma virus. Forecasts should be for the rates of vaccination with at least a single dose of one of the two available HPV vaccines. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%.The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the % vaccinated is 53.8%, the "53.8-54.7%" range will be deemed correct.

question_text:
Microsoft recently demonstrated a test version of a real-time, spoken-word translation service for Skype calls.?Skype Translator, as it is currently called, allows speakers in different languages to hear the other?s words spoken in their own language.?Microsoft is planning to make the?application?publicly?available by the end of 2014.

keywords: Flu, Region 3, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 3 (DE, DC, MD, PA, VA, WV)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 3' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases in Region 3 for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across HHS region 3. Region 3 is comprised of Delaware, District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

name: What percentage of Japan?s electricity generation in 2015 will come from nuclear power?
question_text:
After the Fukushima disaster in March 2011, the Japanese government ordered all nuclear reactors shut down for stress testing to determine whether they could survive extreme events. In 2012, then-prime minister Junichiro Koizumisaid Japan would phase out nuclear power entirely by 2030. Prior to 2011, Japan?s nuclear reactors provided about 30 percent of the electricity generation in the country, but with its reactors now sittingidle Japan has had to turn to coal, oil and natural gas to meet its energy needs. This led to Japan experience its first trade deficit in three decades in 2011 because Japan has very few domestic fuel resources. In 2012, Japan was second only to China in global fossil fuelimports.

?Current prime minister Shinzo Abe and Japanese utilities are now pushing to get the nation's reactors up and running again, with the prime minister singling out reducing soaring fuel costs as a key plank of his economic reform plans. However, restarting each ofthe 50+ idling reactors in Japan could cost around $1 billion in fees and will require a six-month review under the new stricter safety regulations put in place since Fukushima. Even the most optimistic scenarios estimate Japan might be able to fire up 10 reactors per year.

keywords: Cancer, clinical trials, causation, translation, chemistry
name: Will the recent association between Sildenafil use and Melanoma, as demonstrated by Li et al., in the April 2014 issue of JAMA, prove to be a causal relationship?
question_text:
Sildenafil is a PDE-5A inhibitor commonly used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Recently, it has been shown that PDE-5A is down regulated in melanoma via a BRAF dependent mechanism. Importantly, it has been shown that downregulation of PDE-5A increases the invasive potential of melanoma both?in vitro?and?in vivo.?Moreover, the authors went on to demonstrate that human?metastatic melanomas?have reduced PDE-5A expression.

This data in combination with the fact that sildenafil has been shown to downregulate PDE-5A prompted an investigation into the incidence??of melanoma in those with self-reported?erectile dysfunction?taking sildenafil at baseline versus those with erectile dysfunction who were not using sildenafil at baseline. The analyses revealed that users of sildenafil were 84% more likely to develop melanoma during the 10 year follow up. Those with a diagnosis of cancer at baseline were excluded.?

While interesting, the authors caution readers that this association needs to be further examined to demonstrate causation. Given the biological plausibility of the hypothesis that sildenafil increases the incidence of melanoma; how likely is it?that this claim will be borne out and a causal relationship demonstrated in further analyses.?

Useful Links:
Arozarena I, Sanchez-Laorden B, Packer L, Hidalgo-Carcedo C, Hayward R, Viros A, Sahai E, Marais R. Oncogenic BRAF induces melanoma cell invasion bydownregulating the cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase PDE5A. Cancer Cell. 2011 Jan18;19(1):45-57. doi: 10.1016/j.ccr.2010.10.029. Epub 2011 Jan 6. PubMed PMID:21215707.http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1535610810004319?Li WQ, Qureshi AA, Robinson KC, Han J. Sildenafil Use and Increased Risk of Incident Melanoma in US Men: A Prospective Cohort Study. JAMA Intern Med. 2014 Apr 7. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2014.594. [Epub ahead of print] PubMed PMID:24710960.http://archinte.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1857095

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/04/2024

Resolution Source

A statement from drug licensing bodies (e.g., FDA)?defining a causative relationship between melanoma and sildenafil use will resolve this question as "yes".

Fine Print

When speaking of causal relationships, it is not meant that the variable in question must be the definitive factor leading to the development of the disease in question. As Russo and Williamson (2007) point out in the context of the medical literature causal does not imply that a factor is necessary or sufficient for the development of a disease. Rather it may, in its very least, be taken to mean that a susceptible population when exposed to the causative agent/variable in question will be more likely to develop a given disease than a non-exposed population. Moreover, this increased risk should be a result of the action of the factor itself and not the result of some other factor that varies directly with our presumptive causative agent (dependent variable) and disease status (independent variable) ie. it should not be the result of a confounding factor. As Fletcher and Fletcher (2012) state 'It (the case for causation) rests primarily on the research designs used to establish it.' The gold standard is a well designed randomised placebo controlled, double blinded (where both researchers, medical staff and participants are unaware of exposure status) trial. In theory randomisation means that known and unknown variables will be equally distributed in each group and therefore will have no bearing on the outcomes of participants. However, these trials are expensive and are practically difficult to conduct. Therefore, often observational analyses must be used. ?The Bradford-Hill criteria may be used to help evaluate the case for causation for a given factor.

name: How many concussions will be sustained in the 2014 NFL season?
question_text:
The brain trauma associated with concussions received while playing sports has started receiving considerable attention from the sports, medical, policy, and legal communities. The problem is most acute in football, where collisions involving the head are common. New research, sponsored in part by the National Football League (NFL), is evaluating how helmet construction affects the likelihood of sustaining a concussion, and also how the location of and type of head hits affects this likelihood. Helmut construction has been evaluated using accelerometers placed in helmets during live games, and location impacts have been assessed by reviewing game footage of hits that have caused concussions.

The data collected during this research, published respectively in the journals Neurosurgery and Journal of Neurosurgery, are leading to changes in (a) the helmets used by the NFL and to (b) NFL rules regarding how players can use their helmets during collisions with other players. The NFL hopes these changes lead to fewer of the type of hits most commonly associated with concussions (such as helmet-to-helmet hits) and to less-severe hits, and ultimately to fewer concussions. Preliminary data indicate these changes have resulted in fewer concussions, though it is too early to be sure.

In its annual Super Bowl Health & Safety press conference, the NFL reported 228 concussions sustained in the 2013 season, versus 261 in 2012 and 252 in 2011. These data are for the 20 games of the 4-game preseason and the 16-game regular season. The NFL also reported 90 helmet-to-helmet concussions sustained in the 2013 season, versus 117 in 2012, again across a twenty-game season.

More information can be found here:

  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14633299
  • http://thejns.org/doi/full/10.3171/2014.1.JNS13916
  • http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/hs-press-conference.pdf
  • http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/football-insider/wp/2014/01/30/number-of-concussions-down-13-per...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/31/2015

Resolution Source

Near the date of the 2015 Superbowl the NFL will publish its Super Bowl Health & Safety report for the 2014 season, which report the number and type of concussions received during the 20 game per- and regular season for 2014. This report will be available from the NFL communication site:? http://nflcommunications.com/

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%.More information on Scaled questions can be found on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

name: Will NASA lose contact with the Mars Opportunity rover by March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Spirit and Opportunity, two rovers that are part of NASA's Mars Exploration Rover (MER) Mission to explore the Martian surface and geology, were launched from Cape Canaveral on June 10, 2003 and July 7, 2003, respectively, and landed on Mars on January 4, 2004 and January 25, 2004. Not expected to last long in the harsh Martian environment, the rovers? initial mission duration was 90 days. They have outlived this expectation by many years. NASA permanently lost contact with Spirit on March 22, 2010, 6 years 2 months and 19 days after landing on Mars. The Opportunity rover is still functioning, and still sending scientific data back to NASA.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/mars-exploration-rover-opportunity-mer/
  • http://mars.nasa.gov/programmissions/overview/
  • http://www.nbcnews.com/id/21327647/
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2014/07/29/nasas-opportunity-rover-sets-a-record-for-off-world...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

NASA will announce the end of Opportunity's mission on its mission status page:? http://mars.nasa.gov/mer/mission/status.html

Fine Print

The date NASA loses contact with Opportunity is defined as the last date on which NASA communicates with the rover prior to NASA formally declaring the Opportunity mission over.

keywords: Quantum cryptography, quantum communications, quantum key distribution
name: When will the world's first quantum key distribution satellite become operational?
question_text:
Quantum key distribution is a form of communication that uses quantum mechanics to guarantee secure communication. It enables two parties to produce a shared random secret key known only to them, which can then be used to encrypt and decrypt messages. However, quantum communication is currently limited to distances of around 100 kilometers because the photons used in quantum communication tend to be absorbed by the glass in fiber-optic cables and by the atmosphere when beamed from one location to another.

One method to overcome this limitation is to send photons to an orbiting satellite, which would then retransmit the message securely when it is over another part of the planet. This is possible because the photons traveling straight up only have to negotiate a few tens of kilometers of the atmosphere before reaching space.

There are currently no satellites in the world capable of of producing coherent photons that can carry quantum information. However, there have been recent several experiments that have proven that quantum communication to space and back is indeed possible. In 2013, a Chinese team successfully reflected individual photons off an orbiting satellite to simulate a satellite sending photons to the ground. In June 2014, a group of researchers from the University of Padova conducted a similar experiment and proved that the error rate can be made low enough for quantum cryptography to work.

China has announced plans to launch a spacecraft in 2016 called the Chinese Quantum Science Satellite designed to test these concepts, though not much is known about its capabilities. European scientists have proposed a quantum communications experiment that could be sent to the international space station. A private Canadian firm called Com Dev also has announced plans to launch a low-cost microsatellite capable of quantum key distribution in the near future.

  • MIT Technology Review - The Space-Based Quantum Cryptography Race
  • IEEE Spectrum - Commercial Quantum Cryptography Satellites Coming
  • Wikipedia - Quantum Key Distribution

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Quantum cryptography is a technology with enormous potential value, and breakthroughs in quantum communication will likely be covered by a wide variety of science and technology sources, like Science Magazine, MIT Technology Review and others, as well as mainstream news sources.

Fine Print

For this question to be resolved, the satellite equipment in question must be able to send and receive photons containing quantum data from space.

keywords: Light, Matter, Photon, Electron, Positron, Breit and Wheeler process
name: Before the end of 2015, will a lab experiment provide a practical demonstration of Breit and Wheeler's theory of turning light into matter?
question_text:
Three physicists from Imperial College London have recently proposed?a simple way to physically prove a theory first devised by scientists Breit and Wheeler in 1934. Breit and Wheeler suggested that it should be possible to turn light into matter by smashing together only two particles of light (photons) to create an electron and a positron - the simplest method of turning light into matter ever predicted.

Detailed in Nature Photonics, the Imperial College design relies on a hohlraum, a small metal cylinder that holds hydrogen fuel in laser fusion experiments. Heating a hohlraum with a laser produces a dense field of X-ray photons inside. The physicists estimate that passing a jet of high-energy gamma-ray photons through the laser-excited hohlraum would make enough photons collide to produce up to 100,000 pairs of electrons and positrons. Several scientists?have expressed interest?in carrying?out such an experiment.

  • http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/05/140518164244.htm
  • https://www.sciencenews.org/article/proposed-experiment-would-create-matter-light


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

choices_field_4: Other Company or Merger/Acquisition Not Listed
keywords: Small satellites, miniaturized satellites, satellite imaging
name: Which smallsat company will be the first to provide daily re-imaging of the Earth?
question_text:
A number of start-up companies are developing small satellites to provide real time imagery of the entire Earth.? NASA's Landsat Satellite Program launched in February 2013, currently provides the same image of the Earth every eight days.? The idea of small satellites is to launch a fleet of smaller satellites that can together span the entire Earth simultaneously instead of launching one big satellite.? These smallsat companies include Planet Labs, Skybox Imaging, BlackBridge/RapidEye, and OmniEarth.?

Planet Labs has already launched its initial 28 satellites named 'Flock 1' and plans to launch over 100 more by sometime in 2015 which would allow them to provide imagery of the entire Earth.? SkyBox Imagery which Google has recently agreed to acquire, has also launched its first of 24 satellites named 'SkySat-1.'? BlackBridge which currently provides real time imagery of 5 million km^2 of the Earth daily, has secured $22 million to expand their project to RapidEye+ to greatly increase this area with an expected launch date in 2019.? OmniEarth announed a partnership in May 2014 with Harris Corp, Draper Laboratory, and Dynetics to launch 18 satellites to provide daily real time imagery of the Earth.?

Relevant Links

  • Start-Ups Aim to Conquer Space Market
  • Planet Labs Plans to Launch Over 100 Smallsats Within a Year
  • Inside a Startup's Plan to Turn a Swarm of DIY Satellites Into an All-Seeing Eye (Skybox)
  • SkyBox Imaging + Google
  • BlackBridge Unveils Concept for it's New Mission
  • OmniEarth Announces Partnership to Create Global Satellite Constellation

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when a smallsat company is the first to provide daily re-imaging of nearly all of the Earth for consumer access. This will be verified by major news sources and the company's respective site which include Planet Labs, SkyBox Imaging, BlackBridge/RapidEye, and OmniEarth.? Note that there are other companies developing ways to provide real time imagery of the Earth, such as UrtheCast.? However UrtheCast uses high definition cameras mounted on the International Space Station (ISS) to do so.? This question specifically asks of companies that will use small satellites. Note also that BlackBridge does currently provide real time imagery of the Earth, but can only provide upto 5 million km^2 of imagery daily.? They have recently secured $22 million to expand their project.

Fine Print

A 'smallsat company' is defined to be a company that uses small satellites or miniaturized satellites to provide real time imagery of the Earth.The 'Other Company or Merger/Acquisition Not Listed' choice includes any other company not listed that aims to provide real time imagery of the Earth using small satellites. It also includes any other merger/acquisition made by a set of companies not listed. A 'merger' is defined as a legal consolidation of two or more companies into one company and an 'acquisition' is defined as a company that takes over another but the acquired company still exists as an independent entity controlled by the acquirer. For example, if Digital Globe buys Planet Labs and OmniEarth, then this would be considered to be the 'Other or Merger/Acquisition Not Listed' choice and not the 'Planet Labs' or 'OmniEarth' choice. Note also that the 'Skybox Imaging + Google' choice includes both the possibility of a merging and acquirement.

name: What will retail electricity sales be for the US in 2015?
question_text:
While global demand for energy continues to grow, and the search new sources of fuel and energy attempts to keep pace with this growing demand, energy efficiency -- an idea that's been around for decades -- is seeing renewed interest. Homes, commercial and industrial buildings, and consumer products are all becoming more energy efficient through the effort of engineers and scientists.

This energy efficiency, along with other factors, has contributed to reduced electricity consumption. Between 2010 and 2013, total retail electricity sales to the US residential sector dropped from 4,933 trillion BTU to 4,746 trillion BTU, as reported by the Energy Information Administration, despite significant economic growth during that time period. However, from 2012 to 2013 there was growth. 2014 data are expected early in 2015. 2015 data are expected in early 2016.

For more information:

  • http://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21639016-biggest-innovation-energy-go-without-invisible-fuel
  • http://energy.gov/energysaver/articles/consumer-electronics-show-2013-highlights-sustainable-energy-...
  • http://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2016

Resolution Source

Electricity sales data for 2015 will be provided by the Energy Information Administration, via the topic 2.2 report, "Residential sector energy consumption," available here: http://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/monthly/index.cfm#consumption. This question will resolve when the data is updated sometime in early 2016.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

keywords: Supercomputing, Top500, Computers, Processing Speed, IBM, HP, Cray Inc.
name: How many IBM-manufactured supercomputers will make the top 10 of the June 2014 TOP500 world's fastest supercomputer rankings?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014. The June 2013 TOP500 rankings listed 5 IBM-manufactured supercomputers in the top 10.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the presented and published results of the TOP500 at the International Supercomputing Conference.

Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from TOP500 or International Supercomputing Conference. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Useful Links

  • http://www.isc-events.com/isc14/

Related Organizations or Individuals

keywords: Space, Lunar, rock samples, astronaut, china
name: Will the Chinese National Space Administration retrieve at least 2kg of lunar rock/soil samples by January 1 2018?
question_text:
• The Chang'e 5 is an unmanned Chinese lunar exploration mission currently under development, which is expected to land on the moon by 2017.
  • Chang'e 5 will be China's first sample return mission, aiming to return at least 2 kilograms of lunar soil and rock samples back to the Earth.
  • After making a soft landing on the Moon, the lander will dig and collect a lunar sample from up to 2 meters below the surface. The lander will carry engineer landing cameras, optical cameras, a lunar mineral spectrometer, a lunar soil gas analytical instrument, a lunar soil composition analytical instrument, a sampling sectional thermodetector, and a robotic drilling rig.
  • Experts say the goal of retrieving lunar samples and returning them to Earth would require a more powerful launch rocket which is currently being developed by China.
  • It is expected that a?separate mission with an experimental spacecraft to conduct crucial re-entry tests on the capsule to be used in the Chang'e-5 will be carried out sometime before 2015.
  • The European Space Agency's European Space Operations Centre (ESOC) in Darmstadt, Germany has supported CNSA's efforts and?assisted?China in landing the?Chang'e 3 on the moon.?

Resolution Criteria

An official announcement must be made by either Xinhua news agency or?the State Administration of Science, Technology and Industry for National Defense.?In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.?


Resolution Sources

The New York Times

Fine Print

Lunar rock/soil samples must actually be returned to Earth?by the Chang'e 5 mission.


Useful Information and Links

  • Helping China to the Moon:?http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Operations/Helping_China_to_the_Moon
  • China Moon Landing Cooperation:?http://www.space.com/23965-china-moon-rover-landing-cooperation.html
  • China's Lunar Rover Enters Orbit:?http://www.dailytech.com/Chinas+Lunar+Rover+Enters+Orbit+Prepares+for+Historic+Sat+Landing/article33930c.htm

Related Organizations or Individuals

The China National Space Administration (CNSA)

keywords: nanomaterial, carbon fiber, super capacitor, electric car, Volvo
name: Will nano structured batteries and super capacitors be incorporated in the bodywork of an electric vehicle available to consumers before the end of 2019?
question_text:
Volvo is working together with independent research groups to develop a means of energy storage for future electric cars that does away completely with traditional battery and super capacitors. The solution is a new type of material that integrates nano structured batteries and super capacitors together with carbon fiber, and which can be formed into body panels for a car. The result is a car much lighter and more durable, thanks to the use of nano fiber. A Volvo S80 prototype car of this kind has already been built.?

  • Volvo shows body panels that could replace batteries in electric cars http://www.motorauthority.com/news/1087758_volvo-shows-body-panels-that-could-replace-batteries-in-e...
  • Volvo develops structural, supercapacitor nanobatteries for future electric cars http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1087770_volvo-develops-structural-supercapacitor-nanobatteries-f...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Volvo: http://www.volvocars.com/pages/default.aspx
Greencarreports.com: http://www.greencarreports.com/

keywords: Space, Rosetta, comet, European Space Agency
name: Will Philae, the comet lander, wake up and send data before the end of March 2015?
question_text:
Philae made history when it landed on the comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko in mid-November 2014. The lander bounced off the surface of the comet and settled in an unknown spot that was partially shaded. The shade only enable the lander's solar panels to collect solar energy for 1.5 hours a day, which is not enough to charge the lander's battery.? The harpoons did not fire and the lander is not tethered to the surface. Originally the most optimistic scenario had Philae gathering data until March 2015, when it will become too hot to operate. (Comet 67P is currently heading toward the sun; its closest approach comes in August 2015, when the icy object will get within 115 million miles, or 186 million kilometers of the sun).

Contact with the lander was lost after nearly 57 hours on the surface of comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Philae is now in an 'idle' or hibernation mode. There is a chance that it may move and collect enough solar energy to charge its battery resulting in Philae to wake up and collect and send more data before March 2015.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The European Space Agency will announce the receipt of data.

Fine Print

This question will resolve yes if the lander sends data to the ESA on or after November 21, 2014. The communication may be relayed by the Rosetta orbiter before reaching the ESA.This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Vermont?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Vermont, 66.4% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +3.4% from 2011 (63.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 65.5%, the "65.5%-68.9%" range will be deemed correct.

The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. name: Will a paper appear in the scientific literature by the end of March 2015 reporting on in vivo optogenetic experimentation in humans?
question_text:
Optogenetics refers to the genetic insertion of a light-sensitive gene into specific neurons within the brain. Making these neurons light sensitive allows researchers to control their excitation, inhibition, and signaling. Optogenetics has become an important research tool, allowing scientists to make and test actual predictions about neuron function. The hope is that this tool will help scientists uncover deep mechanisms of brain function that hold true for a wide range of species, including humans.

Optegenetics are also being investigated for clinical application to a variety of human disease conditions associated with neural degeneration, including Parkinson's disease and retinitis pigmentosa, a form of blindness caused by degeneration of the retina at the back of the eye. Extensive optogenetic studies have been done with mice, and some with other animals including macaques (primates). To date, no in vivo optpgenetic experiments in human test subjects have been reported.

For more background, see:

  • http://thebrainbank.scienceblog.com/2013/08/05/controlling-the-brain-with-light-where-are-we-at-with...
  • http://www.cell.com/neuron/abstract/S0896-6273%2809%2900210-4
  • http://www.bioopticsworld.com/articles/print/volume-7/issue-4/departments/biooptics-breakthroughs/op...
  • http://www.bioopticsworld.com/articles/print/volume-7/issue-4/departments/biooptics-breakthroughs/op...


Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The question will resolve as ?yes? if an article appears by 03/31/2015 in a peer-reviewed science journal indexed by Thomson Reuters?s Web of Science index.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution/
