name: When will 99.9% of the top 1 million email domains in the world be immune to Heartbleed?
question_text:
The Heartbleed vulnerability (http://blog.cloudflare.com/answering-the-critical-question-can-you-get-private-ssl-keys-using-heartb...)exposes server memory over a network connection. Remote attackers may collect other user's access credentials, session content, and server-side private?encryption keys.

Alexa (http://www.alexa.com/topsites) tracks top sites, and Zmap (https://zmap.io/heartbleed/mail.html) tracks which of the top 1 million mail sites remain vulnerable to Heartbleed. Any service which uses a vulnerable version of OpenSSL is exposed to the problem.

Here is a paper presented in 2008 which examines?vulnerability management policies intended to?reduce potential exposure windows (LINK)

Some common culprits for a slow response time include poor site?administration, difficulty reconciling a patch with site's code, and?lengthy review & testing procedures.?

As of 4/16/14, 6199 domains were listed on Zmap's Heartbleed report.?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2014

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when there are 1,000 or less?email domains?listed on?Zmap's Heartbleed Bug Health Report:?https://zmap.io/heartbleed/mail.html.

Fine Print

Zmap's Heartbleed Bug Health Report is not updated daily, so the number of sites vulnerable to Heartbleed on any given day will be based on the most recent report appearing on Zmap.io. The list of "top 1 million email domains" is calculated by Alexa Internet, Inc. Additional information on Alexa rankings here: https://alexa.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/200449744-How-are-Alexa-s-traffic-rankings-determined-

name: How many concussions will be sustained in the 2014 NFL season from helmet-to-helmet collisions?
question_text:
The brain trauma associated with concussions received while playing sports has started receiving considerable attention from the sports, medical, policy, and legal communities. The problem is most acute in football, where collisions involving the head are common. New research, sponsored in part by the National Football League (NFL), is evaluating how helmet construction affects the likelihood of sustaining a concussion, and also how the location of and type of head hits affects this likelihood. Helmut construction has been evaluated using accelerometers placed in helmets during live games, and location impacts have been assessed by reviewing game footage of hits that have caused concussions.

The data collected during this research, published respectively in the journals Neurosurgery and Journal of Neurosurgery, are leading to changes in (a) the helmets used by the NFL and to (b) NFL rules regarding how players can use their helmets during collisions with other players. The NFL hopes these changes lead to fewer of the type of hits most commonly associated with concussions (such as helmet-to-helmet hits) and to less-severe hits, and ultimately to fewer concussions. Preliminary data indicate these changes have resulted in fewer concussions, though it is too early to be sure.

In its annual Super Bowl Health & Safety press conference, the NFL reported 228 concussions sustained in the 2013 season, versus 261 in 2012 and 252 in 2011. These data are for the 20 games of the 4-game preseason and the 16-game regular season. The NFL also reported 90 helmet-to-helmet concussions sustained in the 2013 season, versus 117 in 2012, again across a twenty-game season.

More information can be found here:

  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14633299
  • http://thejns.org/doi/full/10.3171/2014.1.JNS13916
  • http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/hs-press-conference.pdf
  • http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/football-insider/wp/2014/01/30/number-of-concussions-down-13-per...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/31/2015

Resolution Source

Near the date of the 2015 Superbowl the NFL will publish its Super Bowl Health & Safety report for the 2014 season, which report the number and type of concussions received during the 20 game per- and regular season for 2014. This report will be available from the NFL communication site:? http://nflcommunications.com/


Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%. More information on Scaled questions can be found on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

name: How many measles cases will be reported in California in 2015?
question_text:
According to?CDC,?102 people from 14 states in the U.S.?were reported to have?caught measles?between?January 1 and January 30, 2015.?The majority of the people who got measles were unvaccinated, and were part of ongoing outbreak linked to an amusement park in California. The outbreak was first announced by?the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) on January 7, with?seven confirmed cases.?On Monday, Feb 2,?the CDPH said?the number of confirmed measles cases in the state?had risen?to 92.

For more information:?

12/31/2015

name: On what date will Dolly be upgraded to a hurricane?
question_text:
Between 1968 and 2013, 52.1% of named tropical storms developed into hurricanes. The first two tropical storms of the 2014 Atlantic hurricane season, Arthur and Bertha, both achieved hurricane status. The fourth named storm of the season will be named Dolly.

2014 Atlantic hurricane season: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Atlantic_hurricane_season

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/04/2014

Resolution Source

National Hurricane Center of the National Weather Service: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/

Fine Print

This question resolves as soon as Tropical Storm Dolly is upgraded to a hurricane. If it forms and dissipates without achieving hurricane status before September 5, it immediately resolves to "Will not be upgraded before September 5." Dates are based on EDT or EST as used by the National Hurricane Center. All terms and definitions defer to those used by the National Hurricane Center.

name: When will F3 LLC?s lab-on-a-chip, engineered to detect MRSA quickly and cheaply without growing a culture, be available for purchase?
question_text:
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a bacterium that is resistant to several antibiotics, making it hard to treat in humans.? It is important to diagnose MRSA early as it is resistant to several ?first line? antibiotics.? However, diagnosis requires a multiple day lab culture that is expensive, which may make doctors reluctant to order the test. A viable alternative to cultures is a so-called lab-on-a-chip that integrates laboratory tests on a single chip.

F3 has licensed technology and developed a lab-on-a-chip (also called a biochip). The device isolates the DNA from a sample of the wound. The DNA flows through a nanofluidic channel where it comes into contact with carbon nanotubes which have been functionalized with complementary DNA. An electric field is applied to the probes and if the MRSA DNA binds to the complementary DNA, the electric field changes, resulting in a ?positive? reading from the biochip. The company claims that the biochip can screen patients in 2 hours at a 10 times lesser cost.

?F3 entered 510(k) trials for the biochip (technically called NESDEP IU) in 2013. 510(k) approve is a necessary but not sufficient requirement for this product being available commercially.

Links and sources

  • F Cubed?s Biochip vs. the Hospital Superbug http://spectrum.ieee.org/biomedical/diagnostics/f-cubeds-biochip-vs-the-hospital-superbug
  • F3 http://www.fcubed.biz/Medical-Diagonostics
  • Frost & Sullivan Applauds F Cubed for its Game-Changing MRSA Screener, the NESDEP IU http://www.frost.com/prod/servlet/press-release.pag?docid=291741274

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Press release or other official announcement from the company.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

510(k) is a premarket submission made to the FDA to demonstrate that the device to be marketed is at least as safe and effective, that is, substantially equivalent, to a legally marketed device that is not subject to pre-market approval (PMA). Submitters must compare their device to one or more similar legally marketed devices and support their substantial equivalency claims. http://hub.ucsf.edu/content/what-501kIn molecular biology, biochips are essentially miniaturized laboratories that can perform hundreds or thousands of simultaneous biochemical reactions.

keywords: Proton, standard model, particle physics, grand unified theory, particle decay
name: Will evidence of proton decay be reported in the scientific literature by the end of 2017?
question_text:
The StandardModel of particle physics, a theory that addresses the electromagnetic, weak,and strong nuclear interactions, predicts that protons are stable subatomicparticles that do not decay. Grand Unified Theories are theories that addressthe hypothetical merging of these three interactions into a single, unifiedinteraction at sufficiently high energies. Grand Unified Theories allow for thepossible decay of protons into lighter subatomic particles, such as pion-positronpairs or pion-muon pairs, and some such theories even require proton decay.

Because protondecay is one of the few observable implications of the various proposed GrandUnified Theories, it became the focus of major experimental physics starting inthe early 1980s. To date, however, all attempts to observe proton decay havefailed. Scientists look for evidence of proton decay by looking for signs ofproton-sourced subatomic particle generation in large tanks of super-purewater. The principal detection activity ongoing currently is taking place atthe Super-Kamioka Neutrino Detection Experiment facility, located under MountKamioka in Gifu Prefecture, Japan. In 2009, scientists working at this facilityreported in PHYSICAL REVIEW LETTERS nodetection of proton decay from prolonged observation of 50,000 tons of water,but used data from this detection period to estimate lower limits on proton lifetimeof between 6.6 and 8.2 E33 years.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://arxiv.org/abs/0903.0676
  • http://laguna.ethz.ch/LAGUNA/Welcome.html
  • http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-search-for-proton-decay/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

Detection ofproton decay will be reported in the scientific literature. Given the significanceof such an observation, it will also likely be reported in the popular press.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of West Virginia?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of West Virginia, 45.2% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -5.4% from 2011 (50.6%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 44.3%, the "44.3%-47.7%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Coronavirus, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, MERS, MERS-COV
name: Will there be a lab-confirmed case of the coronavirus Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS or MERS-COV) identified in the United States by 1 June 2014?
question_text:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is viral respiratoryillness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by a coronavirus calledMERS-CoV. Most people who have been confirmed to have MERS-CoV infectiondeveloped severe acute respiratory illness. They had fever, cough, andshortness of breath. About half of these people died.? The symptoms have been more severe than seasonal influenza. However, the two viruses are not known to be related or linked.?

Despite the first casebeing discovered in 2012, little is known about how the virus spreads to peoplefrom animal hosts.However, it is known that the virus spreads from human to human. In addition, bats and camels have been been found to be infected with MERS.


So far, all the cases have been linked to countries inor near the Arabian Peninsula through residence in or travel to, indicating that modes of transmission outside of the Arabian Peninsula are through travel. Since April 2012,? lab-confirmed cases fromthe following countries have been identified:

  • France
  • Italy
  • Jordan
  • Kuwait
  • Oman
  • Qatar
  • Saudi Arabia
  • Tunisia
  • United Kingdom (UK)
  • United Arab Emirates (UAE)?
No cases have been identified in the U.S yet.

Travel has been the primary way in which MERS-CoV has spread to people out side the Middle East.? This suggests that human infection of MERS-CoV in the United States will most likely be a result of travel.

This virus hasspread from ill people to others through close contact. On 10 November 2013,the Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia announced the detection of MERS- CoV ina specimen taken from an ill camel owned by a laboratory - confirmed case fromJeddah. This case had direct contact with the ill camel.

It may be likely that MERS has already spread to more countries, but has not been detected to lack of knowledge or access to testing. However, in Sept 2013 the MERS gene was mapped and in Dec 2013, a group published a paper on their development of isothermal real-time RT-RPA, which they claim is ideal for rapid mobile molecular MERS-CoV monitoring. Therefore, it is more likely than ever that a case will be detected in the next 6 months.

This question asks if a case will be identified in the U.S.by 1 June 2014.

Resolution Criteria

No

Resolution Sources

The spread of MERS ?COV to the U.S. would be coveredby all major publications such as the New York Times, etc.

Fine Print


  • Lab-confirmed: as announced by the CDCor ProMed Mail.

Useful Information and Links

  • The World Health Organization on Coronavirus infections: http://www.who.int/csr/disease/coronavirus_infections/en/index.html
  • WHO update on MERS-CoV: http://www.who.int/csr/disease/coronavirus_infections/Update12_MERSCoV_update_22Nov13.pdf
  • CDC MERS information: http://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/mers/

Related Organizations or Individuals

ProMed Mail: http://www.promedmail.org/ ; CDC GDD program: http://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/gdder/

keywords: Flu, Region 7, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 7 (IA, KS, MO, NE)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 7' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 7 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 7 is comprised of Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, and Nebraska.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 7 is 1.7%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: On NOV 2015, what will be the (performance-weighted) gigaflops per core of the Top 500?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

This question asks what the average performance efficiency in terms of power consumption will be of the Top500 when weighted by system performance.

Questions from the Jun and Nov 2014 Top 500

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/30/2015

Resolution Source

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 statistics published at?http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources
Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list?

Fine Print

By performance-weighted, we mean the average of all 500 machines, weighted by each machine?s raw computing performance (Rmax Gflops).So for example, the performance-weighted average <u>efficiency</u> (Gflops/watt) is calculated by: (1/500) * ?i wi * ei, where ei is the efficiency of machine i, and wi is the weight given to that machine. The weight is always that machine?s proportion of the total Top500 computing power (Rmax Gflops): wi = Rmaxi / (?i Rmaxi), where Rmaxi is the Rmax score (Gflops) for machine i.

name: Will the ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter aid in the resolution of the nature of the Martian plumes discovered in 2012?
question_text:
On February 16, 2015, Nature published an article which discussed the mystery of the Martian plumes spotted in 2012. The origin?and composition?of these clouds is unknown, but the European Space Agency (ESA) states Hubble Space Telescope information coupled with amateur observations, are being used by a team?of astronomers to solve the mystery.

The features exhibited day-to-day variability, and were seen at the morning terminator but not at the evening limb, which indicates rapid evolution in less than 10?hours and a cyclic behavior. For particles reflecting solar radiation, clouds of CO2-ice or H2O-ice particles with an effective radius of 0.1?micrometers are favored over dust. Alternatively, the plume could arise from auroral emission, of a brightness more than 1,000 times that of the Earth?s aurora, over a region with a strong magnetic anomaly where aurorae have previously been detected. Importantly, both explanations defy our current understanding of Mars? upper atmosphere.

The team of astronomers is looking to gain additional information from the space agency's ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter, scheduled to launch in 2016.?

For more information:?
  • Martian mystery plume puzzles scientists
  • Bizarre Martian Plumes Discovered by Amateur Astronomers

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

This question will resolve based on information published by NASA,?major news sources, scientific journals or by the resolution date, whichever comes first.?

SciCast question administrators reserve the right to resolve the question using additional reputable resources not listed above.?

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:?http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

For this question to resolve as "True", the ExoMars Orbiter must gather some portion of those data used to determine the cause of the "martian plumes". Nature - source, essence

name: Will a confirmed case of H3N2 variant (H3N2v) flu in the US be reported between January 1, 2015 and March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Swine flu viruses do not normally infect humans. However, sporadic human infections with influenza viruses that normally circulate in swine have occurred. When this happens, these viruses are called ?variant viruses?. H3N2v is a variant of H3N2 influenza virus?that infected 321 people in the United States in 2011 and 2012. In 2013, 19 cases of H3N2v were reported in the United States across five states. In 2014 there have been two reported cases, both in Ohio. Since 2012 there have been 18 total hospitalizations due to H3N2v,?including one death among these patients.?

  • H3N2v:?http://www.flu.gov/about_the_flu/h3n2v/index.html
  • Influenza A (H3N2) Variant Virus:?http://www.cdc.gov/flu/swineflu/h3n2v-cases.htm


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

The CDC reports flu cases (including H3N2v flu) in its weekly FluView:?

http://www.cdc.gov/flu/swineflu/h3n2v-cases.htm

http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/

keywords: swarming, unmanned surface vehicles, autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence
name: When will the US Navy debut autonomous unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) fitted with the Office of Naval Research?s (ONR) new CARACaS (Control Architecture for Robotic Agent Command and Sensing) system in international waters?
question_text:
US Navy?s advanced high-value unit (HVU) ships are a formidable force against enemies when out in open waters. However, when these ships are anchored or approaching or leaving a port, they are extremely vulnerable to attacks by smaller and swift moving enemy boats, because they find it difficult to maneuver in tight and narrow locations. Back in 2000, an inflatable craft full of explosives resulted in 17 dead and 39 wounded sailors when it attacked the US Navy?s USS Cole destroyer in Yemen. The US Navy has been working ever since the disaster on technologies to protect these ships.

Adapted from the technology used in NASA?s Mars Rover, US Navy?s Office of Naval Research (ONR) fitted small boats with an autonomous CARACaS (Control Architecture for Robotic Agent Command and Sensing) system. These unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) with radar and infrared sensors and software on board can guard advanced ships in troubled waters and ?swarm? enemy entities if they attempt to attack or even come too close to the HVU ships. Swarming capabilities through this technology were tested successfully in August 2014 on the James River in Newport News, VA in the presence of industry, academia, and government entities.

For more information:
http://www.navaldrones.com/CARACAS.html
http://www.wired.com/2014/10/navy-self-driving-swarmboats/
http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/06/tech/innovation/navy-swarm-boats/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

An announcement or news release by the US Navy, the ONR, or a firm that fits these autonomous systems on small boats for the Navy that the USVs have been deployed in international waters to guard a high-value ship. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first. For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

Unmanned surface vehicles (USVs): In this case, we refer to unmanned vessels that can maneuver easily in water bodies and have swarming capabilities to protect high-value ships.The question would resolve when the USVs are first debuted in international waters to guard a high-value ship.?

keywords: nanoparticle, cobalt oxide, hydrogen, water splitting, chemistry
name: Before the end of 2015, will a solar-to-hydrogen efficiency rate of 10% be reported from a water-splitting experiment?
question_text:
Photo-catalytic water splitting experiments have been tried since the 1970s. In 2013,?scientists from the University of Houston reported using cobalt oxide nanoparticles as a catalyst to successfully produce hydrogen from water under visible light. This water-splitting?experiment has the potential to create a clean and renewable source of energy. However the energy conversion rate they reported was only?5%, which is too low to be commercially viable.

Researchers Split Water Into Hygrogen, Oxygen Using Light, Nanoparticles: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/12/131215160904.htm

question_text:
Inspired by the human spleen, a team from Harvard's Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering has developed a "biospleen" that uses magnetic nanoparticles to filter out bacteria and other pathogens from blood?in patients with sepsis. The device exceeded the team's expectation with its ability to cleanse human blood tested in the laboratory, and also increased survival in animals with infected blood.

keywords: RRAM, ReRAM, Computer Memory, Computer storage, Non-volatile
name: When will resistive random access memory (RRAM) be used in a commercially available smartphone?
question_text:
Resistive random access memory (RRAM) is a nonvolatile (retains information even if power is lost) memory type being developed by several companies that can be used for both speed and storage.? One prototype of RRAM being developed by Crossbar Inc. compared to NAND flash memory, comes in at half the size, has 20 times faster write speeds (140MB/s), reads data at 17MB/s, has 20 times lower power consumption, and ten times more endurance.? The Crossbar prototype can also store a terabyte on a chip the size of a postage stamp.? Crossbar Inc. plans to release an RRAM product for embedded chips (like those in car dashboards or coffee makers) by the end of 2014.?

Researchers at Rice University have developed an improved way to manufacture RRAM that can be made using regular equipment at room temperatures, requires much less power than earlier techniques of RRAM, and is denser than earlier RRAM prototypes with the capacity to store nine bits per cell.? James Tour, a professor at Rice University who led the research says they expect to make a deal with a memory manufacturer sometime in August 2014.? This question asks when RRAM will find its way into a commercially available smartphone.

Relevant Links:

  • Denser, Faster Memory Challenges Both DRAM and Flash [MIT Tech. Review]
  • Super-Dense Computer Memory [MIT Tech. Review]
  • Future Phones Could House a Terabyte of Memory [Engadget]
  • Rice's Silicon Oxide Memories Catch Manufacturers' Eye

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when a commercially available smartphone uses resistive random-access memory (RRAM or ReRAM) technology for either speed or storage purposes.? This will be verified by major news sources, smartphone reviews by sources such as CNET, Engadget, etc. or the smartphone manufacturer's specs page.

Fine Print

'Commercially available' means the smartphone is available to the general public for purchase.

keywords: Flu, Region 4, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 4 (AL, FL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, and TN)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 4' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 4 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS region 4 is the highest. Region 4 is comprised of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: What will the hashrate of the Bitcoin blockchain be on September 30, 2014?
question_text:
Bitcoin is?a peer-to-peer cryptographic currency that issues new money and tracks transactions without a central authority.?
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Bitcoin

The blockchain is a transaction database shared by all nodes participating in a system based on the Bitcoin protocol. A full copy of a currency's block chain contains every transaction ever executed in the currency. With this information, one can find out how much value belonged to each address at any point in history.?Every block contains a hash of the previous block. This has the effect of creating a chain of blocks from the genesis block to the current block. Each block is guaranteed to come after the previous block chronologically because the previous block's hash would otherwise not be known. Each block is also computationally impractical to modify once it has been in the chain for a while because every block after it would also have to be regenerated. These properties are what make double-spending of bitcoins very difficult. The block chain is the main innovation of Bitcoin.
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Blockchain

The hash rate is the measuring unit of the processing power of the Bitcoin network. The Bitcoin network must make intensive mathematical operations for security purposes. When the network reached a hash rate of 10 Th/s, it meant it could make 10 trillion calculations per second.
More information:?https://bitcoin.org/en/vocabulary#hash-rate,?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Mining

<u>Relevant articles:</u>
  • How Bitcoin mining works?
  • Nvidia Poised to steal Cryptocurrency Mining Crown from AMD with Maxwell
  • Is Bitcoin mining the new gold rush??

- If a more sophisticated mining technology is discovered, the odds of reaching a higher hashrate will increase;- If government regulators provide clear guidance on Bitcoin use, it could increase trust in the system and increase the number of miners (and therefore the hashrate);- If large companies like Google or Amazon begin to accept Bitcoin, it could increase trust in the system and increase the number of miners (and therefore the hashrate)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/29/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by consulting the blockchain.info measure of the blockchain hashrate.

Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the hash rate is 50,000,000 GH/s, the "Between 50,000,000 GH/s - 75,000,000GH/s" range will be deemed correct.

A new antisense compound developed by Saint Louis University scientists restored learning, memory and other behaviors in mice genetically engineered to have Alzheimer's disease. name: Will Stanford?s Folding@Home distributed computing project exceed 30 PetaFLOPS on July 1st 2014?
question_text:
Folding@home(F@H) is a distributed computing project run by Stanford University directed atdisease research into protein folding, computational drug design, and othertypes of molecular dynamics. This research is highly computationally intensive,and so F@H makes use of the idle resources of personal computers owned byvolunteers from all over the world. These distributed computers are connectedto F@H via the internet and receive (relatively) small, discrete computationaltasks which they process, sending the results back to F@H.

As of April25, 2014, F@H had 7,393,135 CPUs participating, generating 22,321 native TFLOPSof computational power for the medical research F@H is conducting, or 22.321 PetaFLOPS(quadrillions of calculations per second). By comparison, as of November2013, the world?s fastest supercomputer was Tianhe-2, a supercomputer developedby China?s National University of Defense Technology, with a performance of33.86 PetaFLOPS.

F@H officiallyattained a sustained performance level higher than one native petaFLOP onSeptember 16, 2007. On February 18, 2009, F@H achieved five native petaFLOPS,and nine on September 9, 2013.

For morebackground, see:

  • https://folding.stanford.edu/home/about-us/
  • http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=osstats2
  • http://biochem218.stanford.edu/Projects%202010/Ito%202010.pdf


Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2014

Resolution Source

The F@Hwebsite reports participation statistics at the following website:? http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=osstats2

The table atthis link reports ?Native TFLOPS? in the first column of data, with a total inthe last row. This question will resolve yes if this total is 30,001 or greateron July, 1 2014.




Fine Print

Exceed 30 PetaFLOPS means 30,001 or more native TFLOPS as reported by: http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=osstats2

name: Which organization will officially confirm first that they have conducted an experiment in which the amount of energy released through a fusion reaction exceeded the amount of energy being absorbed by the fuel?
question_text:
Nuclear fusion is a nuclear reaction in which atomic nuclei of low atomic number fuse to form a heavier nucleus with the release of energy.The National Ignition Facility is a U.S. government lab that went into operation in 2009 and is the current focus of national efforts to refine the fusion process and achieve net energy gains through inertial confinement fusion.

In October 2013, it was widely reported that the National Ignition Facility had realized a net energy gain from a fusion reaction (seen as a major milestone in fusion research), though those reports have not been confirmed by the lab. However, there are other groups working on this problem including Sandia National Laboratories in New Mexico, the Joint European Torus, Culham Centre for Fusion Energy in the UK, National Fusion Research Institute in Daejeon, and the Petawatt Aquitaine Laser in France.



Resolution Sources

This would be widely covered, especially in the New York Times Science News

Fine Print

An official spokesperson?from a fusion laboratory, or an article published in a laboratory owned journal?must communicate the milestone has been achieved. New York Times science section will be used as the official resolution publication, but the article must identify the source of the announcement.

  • National Ignition Facility
  • Joint European Torus?

name: On November 2030, what will be the Top 500 performance share by vendor?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500, and you think IBM?s machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust IBM?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

keywords: Antimatter Mass, Antigravity, Antihydrogen, Gravitational Interaction, Particle Physics
name: Will the ALPHA and AEgIS experiments conducted by CERN indicate that the ratio of gravitational mass to inertial mass of antihydrogen is positive or negative?
question_text:
Measurements are underway to determine the ratio of gravitational mass to inertial mass of antihydrogen. ?For ordinary matter, it has been shown (the Weak Equivalence Principle) that the gravitational mass and inertial mass of an object are identical (i.e. ratio of gravitational/inertial = 1).? The gravitational mass and inertial mass of antimatter has not yet been observed and may have the same ratio as ordinary matter (i.e. positive), or it may be negative, or it may have a different magnitude than ordinary matter and be positive or negative (i.e. positive or negative ratio not equal to 1 or -1).? There is no definitive empirical evidence to prove this as of yet.

Currently, the ALPHA and AEgIS experiments at CERN are attempting to measure this ratio.? ALPHA has published their first results: ?-65 < ratio of gravitational/inertial < 110.? These initial results conclude that the ratio is somewhere between the range of -65 and 110, and therefore does not rule out the possibility of a positive or negative ratio.? However as CERN states, these results far from answer the question.? More precise measurements and more samples are being taken to reduce this range such that a positive or negative ratio is known (e.g. if the spread is reduced to 1% then the result may be: 0.99 < ratio < 1.01 depending on if the ratio is positive and magnitude is consistent with 1 and vice versa).

If the ratio of gravitational to inertial mass of antihydrogen is negative this may imply that antimatter 'falls up' as opposed to ordinary matter which 'falls down.' ?If the ratio of antihydrogen is positive this may imply that inertial and gravitational mass are equal, hence supporting the Weak Equivalence Principle.? The ratio may also be a magnitude greater than or less than 1 or -1.? This would indicate that antimatter falls down at a different rate than ordinary matter (if ratio is positive and magnitude is not equal to 1), or antimatter falls up at a different rate (if ratio is negative and not equal to -1). See this animation developed by CERN.

Resolution Criteria

Refinements in detectors, traps, and techniques, and production of sufficient antihydrogen will provide statistically significant results.? In this case, statistically significant will be taken to mean if the published report or research article indicates the ratio is strictly between two positive or two negative values regardless of the varying magnitude (i.e. the ratio may not be strictly 1 or -1 to resolve as positive or negative).

Resolution Sources

This question will be resolved by research articles and reports published by CERN/the ALPHA Experiment and the AEgIS Experiment.

Fine Print

Gravitational mass corresponds to the mass in Newton?s Law of Universal Gravitation (that is m1/m2 in F = G(m1/m2)/r^2. ?Inertial mass corresponds to the mass in Newton?s Second Law of Motion (that is the m in F = ma). For the purposes of this question, the answers 'Positive' and 'Negative' include all possible magnitudes of the ratio for that sign.? Meaning, all positive values for 'Positive' and all negative values for 'Negative' are included in the answer choice (and not strictly values of 1 or -1).

Useful Information and Links

  • ALPHA Probes Antimatter Gravity
  • Physicists Attempt to Measure Gravitational Mass of Antihydrogen
  • Weighing the Implications of Negative-Mass Antimatter
  • Giving Weight to Antimatter [Muller et al. UCBerkeley, Auburn University]
  • Note:? Advice and clarification from Professor Phil Rubin and Professor Robert Ellsworth from the George Mason School of Physics, Astronomy, and Computational Sciences (SPACS) was taken in writing this question.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Science (AAAS), Nature

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Idaho?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Idaho, 51.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +5.8% from 2011 (45.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. name: Will at least one-third of worldwide nanotechnology patent documents published in the first half of 2014 have a Chinese priority?
question_text:
Progress in developing technologies?can be measured by a number of indicators?including publications, patents, standards, and the processes and products that have emerged as a result of research.?China's share of published?nanotechnology papers soared from less than 10 per cent of the global total in 2000, to nearly a quarter by 2009 ? overtaking the United States.?In April 2005, China issued national standards for nanotechnology and set up material specification standards. It also created committees to oversee technical standards and health, safety and environment institutions.

  • % of nanotechnology patent documents with Chinese priority:?2013 (through November 20) = 29%;?
  • % of nanotechnology patent documents with Chinese priority:?2012 = 21%
  • Growth of?nanotechnology research in China
  • Stanford article on Chinese Nano manufacturing growth

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2014

Resolution Source

Espace patent database

Query for numerator:http://worldwide.espacenet.com/searchResults?compact=false&ST=advanced&PR=cn&locale=en_EP&PD=2014010...

Query for denominator:http://worldwide.espacenet.com/searchResults?compact=false&ST=advanced&locale=en_EP&PD=20140101-2014...

Fine Print

Nanotechnology patent documents defined as those published in the Espace database with an International Patent Classification of B82: Nanotechnology. First half of 2014 defined as 1/1/2014 - 6/30/2014. Priority document is the first document filed in a patent family (in simple terms, a set of patents related to the same underlying invention), so priority country represents where the first patent application for the invention was filed.

name: Will the Microsoft Windows 10 operating system be available to consumers before the end of April 30, 2015?
question_text:
There have been various rumors regarding the release date for the Windows 10 operating system. Some rumors have suggested late 2014 or early 2015, though the former seems wide of the mark. While claims and reports are all over the place, it seems like Windows 10 should?be released?before September 2015 at the latest. In January 2014, well-known Microsoft blogger Paul Thurrott said he believes the company plans to release Windows 9, codenamed Threshold (now known as Windows 10) in April 2015, less than three years after Windows 8.

Note: this question previously referred to Windows 9, however Microsoft officially changed the name to Windows 10. This should not affect forecasting decisions per se since the OS after Windows 8 is still what is referred to.

question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.

We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. keywords: Great Lakes, Global Warming, Ice Coverage
name: What will be the peak mean ice concentration in Lake Huron during the 2013/2014 winter?
question_text:
Understanding the major effect of ice on the Great Lakes is crucial because it impacts a range of societal benefits provided by the lakes, from hydropower generation to commercial shipping to the fishing industry. The amount of ice cover varies from year to year, as well as how long it remains on the lakes. GLERL scientists are observing long-term changes in ice cover as a result of global warming.

According to an analysis by NOAA's Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, ice covered 88.4 percent of the Great Lakes on February 13. Not since early 1994 has ice been so widespread on the Great Lakes. Graphs showing the ice cover trends?for each of the Great Lakes from?1973 to 2002?can be found here.

As of 02/14/2014, the mean concentration of ice in Lake Huron was 95.0%. Daily reports can be found here under the section 'Modeled Ice Coverage'.?A chart showing the yearly average maximum ice coverage of Lake Huron can be found here.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/10/2014

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved by via the Lake Huron Ice Cover webpage maintained by the NOAA, and by consulting the 'Modeled Ice Concentration' section.?


Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the peak ice coverage is 96.0%, the "96%-97%" range will be deemed correct.

name: When will the Split Conjecture be proven?
question_text:
The Split Conjecture is a corollary of the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture and remains unproven. The Split Conjecture is as follows: Let S be any permutation of the elements of the splay tree. Then the cost of deleting the elements in the order S is O(n).

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the Split Conjecture is 'proven true' according to decision rendered by question moderator. If no significant news is reported by the date in question, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., the Split Conjecture has yet to be proven true). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Mainstream conferences and journals in Theoretical Computer Science

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Theoretical Computing Science Journals

name: Physicists from the University of Texas-Arlington have recently published a paper describing a new method of detecting moons orbiting exoplanets by using radio waves. Will an exomoon be discovered using this technique before 2020?
question_text:
A group of physicists from the University of Texas-Arlington have recently published a paper describing a new method of detecting moons orbiting exoplanets using radio waves. This approach is based on the group's analysis of the radio wave emissions that result from the interaction between Jupiter?s magnetic field and its moon Io. The team builds on earlier theories about using radio wave observations to discover exoplanets, but applies it in a new way. They focus on Io and its ionosphere, a charged upper atmosphere that is likely created by the moon?s extremely active volcanoes. During its orbit, Io?s ionosphere interacts with Jupiter?s magnetosphere, a layer of charged plasma that protects the planet from radiation, to create a frictional current that causes radio wave emissions. These are called ?Io-controlled decametric emissions? and the researchers believe finding similar emissions near known exoplanets could be key to predicting where other moons exist.

The paper even pinpoints two exoplanets where the group is ?cautiously optimistic? that the observational community could apply the study?s calculations to search for exomoons the size of our moon with future, more sensitive radio telescopes ? Gliese 876b, which is about 15 light years way, and Epsilon Eridani b, which is about 10.5 light years away.

Sources in links:
  • UT-Arlington News: Follow the radio waves to exomoons, AT-Arlington physicists say
  • Wikipedia: Exomoon

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

The confirmed discovery of an exomoon using this new radio wave technique would likely be covered by a variety of science publications, such as Science Magazine and Nature.

name: Will the value of new investments in renewable energy in the US be higher in the second quarter of 2015 than it was in the second quarter of 2014?
question_text:
The Bloomberg New Energy Finance Desktop collates all renewable energy organizations, projects and investments according to transaction type, sector, geography and timing. Quarterly reports are available for download on BNEF website,?and include historical data and current trends in clean energy investment.

According to BNEF, the total new?investment in renewable energy in?the United States was $12.9B?in the second quarter of 2014 (April to June, 2014). This represents a 30% increase over the?$9.8B?reported in Q2 of 2013.?It?reverses a previous downward trend in investment, which had fallen from $16.7B in Q2 2011, to $14.7B in Q2 2012, to $9.8B in Q2 2013.

For more information:?

name: Will a working spaser made completely out of carbon nanotubes and graphene be demonstrated before 1 June 2015?
question_text:
?Spaser? is short for surface plasmon amplification by stimulated emission of radiation. It is the nanoplasmonic counterpart of a laser, except that a laser admits photons while in a spaser photons are replaced by surface plasmons and the resonant cavity is replaced by a nanoparticle.? A theoretical model of a spaser was proposed in 2003 and a working spaser consisting of a 44-nm-diameter nanoparticles with a gold core and dye-doped silica was demonstrated by Noginov et al. in 2009.

Monash University Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering engineers have modeled the world?s first spaser to be made completely out of carbon. Rupasinghe et al. propose a carbon-based spaser design in which a graphene nanoflake resonator is coupled to a carbon nanotube gain element. The authors state that the use of graphene and carbon nanotubes "offers such advantages as mechanical strength and thermal stability." They assert that their design can be experimentally realized using the common nanofabrication techniques.

Links and sources

  • Stockman, M. Spasers explained. Nature Photonics 2, 327 - 329 (2008) http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/v2/n6/full/nphoton.2008.85.html
  • Rupasinghe, C. et al. Spaser Made of Graphene and Carbon Nanotubes ACS Nano, 2014, 8 (3), pp 2431?2438 http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/nn406015d
  • Plasmon http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plasmon

name: Will at least 3,000 positive A (H3) influenza tests be reported to CDC during any week in the first quarter of 2015?
question_text:
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention?announced?on Thursday that it is too late to make new flu vaccines for the current flu season that could better protect against the predominant flu virus now circulating in the United States. CDC said one component of this year's flu vaccine is only partially protective against the predominant flu virus, known as influenza A (H3N2), which has mutated since the current flu shots were made. Past seasons dominated by H3N2 strains of flu have been severe. In 2013, there were over 4,000 postive A (H3) tests reported to CDC on the second week of the year.?
  • CDC Warning: Flu Viruses Mutate and Evade Current Vaccine:?http://www.nbcnews.com/health/cold-flu/cdc-warning-flu-viruses-mutate-evade-current-vaccine-n261226

name: Will a "nano nose" mobile explosive detection device be available for purchase in Israel before the end of June 2015?
question_text:
Scientists are using nano technology to develop ultra sensitive explosive detection sensors. In Israel, researchers at the University of Tel Aviv have devised an electronic chip with microscopic chemical sensors that can detect explosives in air at concentrations as low as parts per quadrillion. Currently being developed by the Herzliya company Tracense, the device is mobile, inexpensive, and works in real time with great accuracy, more sensitive than a dog's nose. Expected to go on the market next year, a prototype of the device is currently undergoing multiple and extensive field tests.

  • http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/07/140723111141.htm


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2015

Resolution Source

A product announcement by?the Israeli company Tracense:?http://www.tracense.com/

Fine Print

The term "nano nose" refers to an explosives detection sensor, with the name used to compare it to a dog's nose. Purchase by a government would satisfy the requirements of this question.

name: When will the first car equipped with vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) safety technology be offered for sale to the general public in the US?
question_text:
In February 2014, the US Department of Transportation's (DOT) National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) announced that it will begin taking steps to enable vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication technology for light vehicles. This technology would improve safety by allowing vehicles to "talk" to each other and ultimately avoid many crashes altogether by exchanging basic safety data, such as speed and position, ten times per second.

The technology uses a radio signal to continually transmit a vehicle's position, heading, speed and other information. Similarly equipped cars and trucks would receive the same information, and their computers would alert drivers to an impending collision. The Obama administration said it is taking a first step toward the requirement that all cars and light trucks being equipped with technology that enables them to warn each other of potential danger in time to avoid collisions.

  • U.S. Department of Transportation Announces Decision to Move Forward with Vehicle-to-Vehicle Communication Technology for Light Vehicles: http://www.nhtsa.gov/About+NHTSA/Press+Releases/2014/USDOT+to+Move+Forward+with+Vehicle-to-Vehicle+C...
  • Government wants to make cars talk to each other: http://news.yahoo.com/govt-wants-require-cars-talk-160548877.html
  • NHSTA proposed policy would require vehicle-to-vehicle technology in new cars, light trucks: http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1113215014/nhsta-vehicle-to-vehicle-communication-081914/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

name: Will Toyota sell more than 1,000 hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (FCV) in the US before the end of 2015?
question_text:
Toyota will launch production of its first commercially available hydrogen fuel-cell vehicle before the end of the year, earlier than expected, according to a report from Japan. Toyota first revealed plans to get into the hydrogen car market last year, at the Tokyo Motor Show. It has produced a number of prototypes in recent years, but the Japanese giant has been suggesting it might go the fuel-cell route as an alternative to depending on battery-electric vehicles to meet tough new Zero-Emission Vehicle, or ZEV, standards.

Toyota has suggested that?the?vehicle will reach the American market some time in 2015.

keywords: wearable electronics, universal access device, password authentication, AES 128-bit encryption
name: Everykey is a Bluetooth enabled wristband that can unlock password-protected websites or electronic key-protected devices with the users' login credentials to allow instant access. Will the first shipment of Everykey occur before April 2015?
question_text:
A team of graduates from Case Western University has developed a wearable electronics wristband called Everykey that can unlock password protected electronics, websites, and other controlled access devices. Everykey can seamlessly connect to multiple Bluetooth-enabled devices at the same time and unlock them with the user?s login credentials with AES 128-bit encryption. Everykey has successfully raised money through a Kickstarter campaign to manufacture the product and the company hopes to ship pre-ordered products to customers by March 2015.

name: Will an orbiting body system be discovered in space before the end of 2019 which could verify at least one of the 13 new three-body problem solution families recently discovered by two Belgrade physicists?
question_text:
In the 300 years since the "three-body problem" was first recognized, only three families of solutions have been found. Now, with the help of computer simulation,?two physicists have discovered 13 new families of solutions. The discovery could help astrophysicists understand new planetary systems.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-body_problem

Resolution Sources

Physics Review Letters

Fine Print

In 1887, mathematicians Bruns and Poincare showed that there is no general analytical solution for the three-body problem given by algebraic expression and integrals. The motion of three bodies is generally non-repeating, except in special cases.

Useful Information and Links

http://news.sciencemag.org/physics/2013/03/physicists-discover-whopping-13-new-solutions-three-body-...

name: What will be the total U.S. lemon production during the 2013-2014 marketing season, in thousands of tons?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Citrus Fruits Summary' following the conclusion ?of the marketing season in September. This full-text report contains the annual summary, by state and citrus fruit crop, of acreage, yield, production, utilization (fresh and processed), price, and value of the current year crop and revised previous two years' crop.
  • U.S. lemon production for the 2012-2013 marketing season totaled 912,000 tons.
  • Lemon production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as lemons are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination. Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary'.?

Lemon production is reported in thousands of tons, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.

Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service

Fine Print

The '2013-2014 marketing season' begins 08/01/2013 and ends 07/31/2014. This question will be accepting forecasts until 09/19/2014.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary' that is published annually in September.

Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Citrus Fruits Summary 2013:?http://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/Todays_Reports/reports/cfrt0913.pdf

name: On November 2015, what will be the Top 500 performance share by vendor?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The November? 2015? ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conferencee is scheduled to occur between November 15, 2015 ? November 20, 2015.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500, and you think IBM?s machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust IBM?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

name: What will data gathered by the Dawn spacecraft determine the white spots on the surface of dwarf planet Ceres to be?
question_text:
A big?white spot on Ceres was discovered by?the Hubble Space Telescope when?it first captured images of the dwarf planet?in 2003 and 2004.?In subsequent images taken, the spot remains visible. Now, in images taken?from the Dawn spacecraft, currently on approach to Ceres, there is not only one spot but?several others.?One of the most anticipated aspects the Dawn spacecraft being in orbit around Ceres?is discovering what those spots are. They are hypothesized to be ice, cryovolcanos, geysers, or something else entirely.?It is suspected with relative certainty that these are a?real feature not image artifacts, since they show up in most of the recent Hubble images and now the Dawn images.?Dawn will hopefully be able to determine what the spots are, probably via photographic evidence.

Dawn arrives at Ceres on March 6, when it will be captured into orbit.?The spacecraft?will begin its closest orbit around Ceres in late November 2015, at a distance of about 375?km. This orbit is designed to acquire data for 3 months with Dawn's gamma-ray and neutron detector (GRaND) and gravity investigation.

For more information

  • First Hubble and Now Dawn Have Seen This White Spot on Ceres. What is it??http://www.universetoday.com/118358/first-hubble-and-now-dawn-have-seen-this-white-spot-on-ceres-what-is-it/
  • Closer view of Ceres shows multiple white spots:?http://phys.org/news/2015-02-closer-view-ceres-multiple-white.html#ajTabs
  • Dawn?(spacecraft):http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawn_%28spacecraft%29

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Question will be resolved based on news from?NASA news on its Dawn mission site:?http://www.nasa.gov/content/ceres-target-of-nasas-dawn-mission/#.VNkpDPmjOm4. News?may also?appear on science news sites such as phys.org and space.com

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

name: When will a proof be published showing L=RL?
question_text:
L is the class of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine with logarithmic space -- i.e., O(log n) bits of read/write memory, on inputs of size n. RL is the class of decision problems solvable by a randomized Turing machine with logarithmic space and polynomial time, such that the machine accepts with probability ?1/2 if the answer is "yes," and with probability 0 if the answer is "no." (If we don't impose the condition of polynomial time, then we get the possibly-larger class NL.) It's clear that L is a subset of RL; this question asks whether the two classes are equal. L vs. RL is one of the main frontier open problems in the theory of derandomization.

Today, many complexity theorists conjecture that L=RL, because this conclusion is known to follow from the existence of "good enough" pseudorandom generators. Saks and Zhou proved that RL (and even the "larger" class BPL) are contained in deterministic (log n)3/2 space, improving the (log n)2 bound that follows from Savitch's Theorem. Meanwhile, in 2005 Reingold proved that L=SL, where SL is an important subclass of RL corresponding to search on undirected graphs: [PS] For a more recent discussion of the L vs. RL problem, see for example: this piece (also by Reingold).

A proof of L=RL would almost certainly consist of a deterministic logspace simulation of RL, together with its analysis (though a nonconstructive proof is theoretically possible). Since RL is contained in P, a proof of L?RL would require proving L?P as a first step, considered an enormous breakthrough in complexity theory. A proof that the answer is independent of the ZF axioms will be considered to resolve the bet. Proofs of independence from weaker formal systems will not count.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on judgment delivered by question moderator. If nothing is reported from this source, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed (e.g., direct outreach to prominent researchers in this field), provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from question moderator. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Question Moderator - Scott Aaronson (MIT, CSAIL)

name: Before the start of 2020, will a drug that reverses diabetes be approved by the FDA for use in the US?
question_text:
A team of researchers from Indiana University School of Medicine has recently discovered that an enzyme called 12-LO promotes the obesity-induced oxidative stress in the pancreatic cells that leads to pre-diabetes, and diabetes. 12-LO's enzyme action is the last step in the production of certain small molecules that harm the cell. The findings?could enable the development of drugs that? interfere with this enzyme, preventing or even reversing diabetes.

  • Single enzyme is necessary for development of diabetes:?http://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-08-enzyme-diabetes.html#ajTabs


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019
