A major development related to the?treatment?of diabetes is likely to be?reported in mainstream scientific journals such as Science, Nature, New England Journal of Medicine, Molecular and Cellular Biology,?ADA's Diabetes,?and in the science section of major?news outlets.

name: How many states will report at least one case of a human West Nile infection to the CDC by 1 August 2014?
question_text:
• West Nile virus is an arthropod-borne virus (arbovirus) most commonly spread by infected mosquitoes. West Nile virus can cause febrile illness, encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or meningitis (inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal cord).
  • As of January 7, 2014, 48 states and the District of Columbia reported cases of West Nile virus infections that occurred in 2013 in people, birds, or mosquitoes. A total of 2,374 cases of West Nile virus disease in people, including 114 deaths, have been reported to CDC for 2013. The only two states that did not report a West Nile virus infection in 2013 were Alaska and Hawaii.
  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US at http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • Since it is more likely West Nile infections will appear in a few states by August 1 rather than many states, the bins used in "safe mode" forecasting are asymmetrical based approximately on a log scale.
  • CDC case count is updated once a week during the transmission season.
  • As of June 10, 2014, there was one state with at least one incidence of human West Nile virus.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/01/2014

Resolution Source

  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US. Their surveillance page will resolve this question - http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • In theory, CDC case counts are updated once a week during the transmission season. The first update after August 1, 2014 will be used to resolve this question.
  • The CDC has not been releasing maps every Tuesday/weekly as is stated on their website. If the CDC does release a report August 1 that says as of July 31 that report will be used to resolve the question. However, it is more likely that the CDC will release a report after August 1 and that number will resolve the question even if it includes August data.

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. For more information on how betting works for this type of question, please refer to the following tutorial: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Virginia?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Virginia, 50.9% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +4.0% from 2011 (46.9%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 50.0%, the "50.0%-53.4%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will the International Sun-Earth Explorer 3 start to collect data and send it to Earth?
question_text:
International Solar-Environment Explorer (ISEE-3) was launched in late 1978 to study the interaction between the Earth?s magnetic field and solar wind. In 1983, it was redirected to study comets, winning the ?space race? to encounter a comet. In 1997, NASA ended the Explorer?s mission and ordered the probe shut down.? Though only a carrier signal was supposed to be left operating, the probe was not powered off after a brief contact in 1999. In 2008, NASA located the Explorer using the Deep Space Network.

The Explorer?s current trajectory will bring it close to Earth in August 2014 giving the chance for it to be put to use once more to study solar wind. However, the equipment needed to transmit the signals to capture the Explore was decommissioned at NASA in 1999.?

Two teams are attempting to contact the Explorer and have it successfully fire its thrusters to get back to its station between the Earth and the Sun. A 18-meter satellite dish at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory still has the right hardware and may attempt to contact the Explorer.? The other team is a crowd-funded team who will use the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico to make contact with the Explorer. They are using embedded systems technology to construct radio components in software and build the necessary components to contact the Explorer.

Once the Explorer fires its thrusters, it can be commanded to slow down and return to its orginal position and provide additional measurements to be sent back to Earth.

Links and sources

  • Space Thief Or Hero? One Man's Quest To Reawaken An Old Friend http://www.npr.org/2014/03/18/289628696/space-thief-or-hero-one-mans-quest-to-reawaken-an-old-friend
  • Space Hackers Prepare to Reboot 35-Year-Old Spacecraft http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/satellites/space-hackers-prepare-to-reboot-35-year-old-spacecraft
  • ISEE-3 Reboot Project by Space College, Skycorp, and SpaceRef http://www.rockethub.com/42228


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An official with the successful team will announce the collection of data. This may be covered in the scientific press.

Fine Print

This question will resolve to "yes" when the Explorer takes a measurement and that data is received by a team on Earth.

name: Will a "nano nose" mobile explosive detection device be available for purchase in the US by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Scientists are using nanotechnology to develop ultra sensitive explosive detection sensors. In Israel, researchers at the University of Tel Aviv have devised an electronic chip with microscopic chemical sensors that can detect explosives in air at concentrations as low as parts per quadrillion. Currently being developed by the Herzliya company Tracense, the device is mobile, inexpensive, and works in real time with great accuracy, more sensitive than a dog's nose. Expected to go on the market next year, a prototype of the device is currently undergoing multiple and extensive field tests.

  • http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/07/140723111141.htm


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

A product availability announcement?by the Israeli company Tracense:?http://www.tracense.com/?

Fine Print

The term "nano nose" refers to an explosives detection sensor, with the name used to compare it to a dog's nose. "Available for purchase in the US" is general and includes the possibility of the device being offered for sale to a restricted set of buyers in the US or being offered for sale to the general public.

keywords: Flu, Region 2, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 2 (NJ, NY, PR, VI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 2' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 2 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 2 is comprised of New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 2 is 2.3%.

?In the event the end occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of North Dakota?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of North Dakota, 60.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +9.1% from 2011 (51.2%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 59.4%, the "59.4%-62.8%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Math, Mathematics, Computing, Dynamic Optimality Conjecture
name: When will the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture be proven?
question_text:
Regarding splay trees, the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture is an unproven conjecture of great interest from the original Sleator and Tarjan paper. This conjecture claims that splay trees perform as well as any other binary search tree algorithm up to a constant factor. 'Dynamically optimal': attains a constant competitive ratio, after amortizing over linearly many operations. The competitive ratio of a binary search tree is the worst case ratio between the number of comparisons and rotations required to perform a sequence of accesses in that binary search tree and the minimal number of comparisons and rotations required to perform that sequence of accesses in any binary search tree which is modified only by using rotations.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture is 'proven true' according to question moderator's judgement. If no significant news is reported by the date in question, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture has yet to be proven true). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Theoretical Computing Science Journals

keywords: Supercomputing, Top500, Computers, Processing Speed, Graph500, Computing Technologies, LINPACK
name: Will the same machine hold the #1 rank on the Top500 and Graph500 lists compiled in June 2014?
question_text:
The TOP500 and Graph500 lists are independently compiled and released twice a year; June and November. The Top500 list employs the LINPACK benchmark as a test of computing power (http://www.top500.org/project/linpack/ ) while the Graph500 list employs TEPS which measures Traversal Edges Per Second on a search through a large unweighted graph (http://www.graph500.org/specifications#sec-1 ). In the June 2013 list, the #1 ranked Graph500 computer appeared at #3 on the Top500 list, and the #1 ranked computer on the Top500 list appeared in the #6 position on the Graph500.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the TOP500 list compiled in June 2014 awards the #1 ranking to the same computer that appears in #1 spot of the June 2014 ranking compiled by Graph500. Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 and Graph500 lists published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/ and http://www.graph500.org/ Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 and Graph500 lists. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list and Graph 500: http://www.graph500.org/

Useful Links

  • http://www.top500.org/statistics/list
  • http://www.graph500.org/

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list and Graph 500: http://www.graph500.org/

keywords: Great Lakes, Global Warming, Ice Coverage
name: What will be the peak mean ice concentration in Lake Superior during the 2013/2014 winter?
question_text:
Understanding the major effect of ice on the Great Lakes is crucial because it impacts a range of societal benefits provided by the lakes, from hydropower generation to commercial shipping to the fishing industry. The amount of ice cover varies from year to year, as well as how long it remains on the lakes. GLERL scientists are observing long-term changes in ice cover as a result of global warming.

According to an analysis by NOAA's Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, ice covered 88.4 percent of the Great Lakes on February 13. Not since early 1994 has ice been so widespread on the Great Lakes. Graphs showing the ice cover trends?for each of the Great Lakes from?1973 to 2002?can be found here.

As of 02/14/2014, the mean concentration of ice in Lake Superior was 94.0%. Daily reports can be found here under the section 'Modeled Ice Coverage'.?A chart showing the yearly average maximum ice coverage of Lake Superior can be found here.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/10/2014

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved by via the Lake Superior Ice Cover webpage maintained by the NOAA, and by consulting the 'Modeled Ice Concentration' section.?


Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the peak ice coverage is 96.0%, the "96%-97%" range will be deemed correct.

name: How many near-Earth large asteroids will NASA detect in 2014?
question_text:
The U.S. NationalAeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), through its Near Earth ObjectProgram, monitors so-called Near-Earth Objects (NEOs). NEOs are comets andasteroids that have been nudged by the gravitational attraction of nearbyplanets into orbits that allow them to enter the Earth's vicinity. NEOs thatare asteroids are called Near Earth Asteroids, or NEAs.

NASA?s NEOprogram tracks NEAs from a variety of observation points around the globe,including the Catalina Sky Survey (CSS) and Spacewatch near Tucson Arizona; theLINEAR project near Socorro New Mexico; Pans-STARRS1 on Maui, Hawaii; and LONEOSnear Flagstaff, Arizona.

NASA makespublic all NEA discoveries on the NEO Program webpage. NEAs estimated to be?kilometer sized or larger? are referred to as large. Between 1995 and 2013NASA reported an average of 36.5 large near Earth asteroids per year, with alow of 6 in 1996 and a high of 93 in 2000. Thisquestion asks how many large near Earth asteroids NASA will report for 2014 atthe end of the year.

Up-to-dateNEO data, including that for large asteroids, can be found here:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/stats/More can belearned about NASA?s NEO program here:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/index.html



The population of comets and asteroids in the solar system is believed to be quite constant, as they were mostly created during the formation of the solar system some 4.6 billion years ago.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

NASA reportsup-to-date data on large asteroids on the NEO program webpage, and that page (http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/stats/) will be used to resolve the question according to what NASA reports on 12/31/2014.



Fine Print

The estimation of asteroid size is imprecise, but NASA unambiguously classifies objects discovered through NEO as large or otherwise.

keywords: data breach, data security, PHI, PII, identity theft, cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Will at least 250 data breaches in the US be reported by the ITRC between January 1, 2015 and March 31, 2015?
question_text:
A data breach is a security incident in which sensitive, protected or confidential data is copied, transmitted, viewed, stolen or used by an individual unauthorized to do so. Data breaches may involve financial information such as credit card or bank details, personal health information (PHI), personally identifiable information (PII), trade secrets of corporations or intellectual property.?In the cyber world,?breaches also consist of the exposure of user names, emails and passwords without involving sensitive personal identifying information.? In 2014, a total of 744 breaches were reported through December 16, according to a list compiled by Identity Theft Resource center (ITRC)?with incidents confirmed?by various media sources and/or notification lists from state governmental agencies. ?The ITRC list is published on Tuesday of each week throughout of the year.

  • Data Breach:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_breach
  • ITRC Data Breach:?http://www.idtheftcenter.org/id-theft/data-breaches.html

3/31/2015

Fine Print

The breach list includes four types of information compromised: Social Security number, Credit Card/Debit Card number, Email/Password/User Name, Protected Health Information.

keywords: Photovoltaics, Solar energy, Alternative energy, Sustainable energy, Energy, Manufacturing, Production Cost, Silicon
name: Will the average component pricing for commercial silicon-based photovoltaic modules drop below $0.68 per watt before January 01, 2014?
question_text:
According to the SEIA Q2 report summary:

Pricing for polysilicon and PV components increased for the first time in more than two years in Q2 2013 due to strong demand pick-up from Japan, the EU, and China and a more consolidated supply chain. Blended polysilicon prices increased by 9% to $19/kg, while blended module ASPs for Q2 were up to $0.68/W, 7% higher than Q1 2013 levels of $0.64/W. Module pricing in particular was affected by increasing prices for Taiwanese cells, some of which are purchased by Chinese module suppliers for use in U.S.-bound products in order to avoid import duties on Chinese cell production. Module pricing has already climbed further to levels of around $0.70/W in Q3 2013.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved "yes" if the cost of production for a commercial silicon-based photovoltaic module drops below $0.68 per watt before January 01, 2014. The outcome will be resolved based on findings of the question moderator. If the question moderator is unable to confirm a resolution of question by its resolution date of January 01, 2014, the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., cost of production for a commercial silicon-based photovoltaic module has not dropped below $0.68 per watt before January 01, 2014). Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from GTM Research and the SEIA. name: Will the hash rate of the Bitcoin blockchain exceed 100,000,000 GH/s by December 31, 2014?
question_text:
Bitcoin is?a peer-to-peer cryptographic currency that issues new money and tracks transactions without a central authority.?
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Bitcoin

The blockchain is a transaction database shared by all nodesparticipating in a system based on the Bitcoin protocol. A full copy of acurrency's block chain contains every transaction ever executed in thecurrency. With this information, one can find out how much value belonged toeach address at any point in history.Every block contains a hash of the previous block. This hasthe effect of creating a chain of blocks from the genesis block to the currentblock. Each block is guaranteed to come after the previous blockchronologically because the previous block's hash would otherwise not be known.Each block is also computationally impractical to modify once it has been inthe chain for a while because every block after it would also have to beregenerated. These properties are what make double-spending of bitcoins verydifficult. The block chain is the main innovation of Bitcoin.
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Blockchain

The hash rate is the measuring unit of the processing powerof the Bitcoin network. The Bitcoin network must make intensive mathematicaloperations for security purposes. When the network reached a hash rate of 10Th/s, it meant it could make 10 trillion calculations per second.
More information:?https://bitcoin.org/en/vocabulary#hash-rate,?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Mining

<u>Relevant articles:</u>
  • How Bitcoin mining works?
  • Nvidia Poised to steal Cryptocurrency Mining Crown from AMD with Maxwell
  • Is Bitcoin mining the new gold rush??


- If a more sophisticated mining technology is discovered, the odds of reaching a 100,000,000 GH/s hashrate will increase;- If government regulators provide clear guidance on Bitcoin use, it could increase trust in the system and increase the number of miners (and therefore the hashrate);- If large companies like Google or Amazon begin to accept Bitcoin, it could increase trust in the system and increase the number of miners (and therefore the hashrate)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by consulting the blockchain.info measure of the blockchain hashrate.

Fine Print

None

name: Will Jupiter's Great Red Spot shrink below 9,000 miles in diameter before January 1, 2016?
question_text:
The Great Red Spot (GRS) is a massive, persistent anticyclonic storm south of Jupiter's equator. Observations from Earth show the GRS has existed for at least 300 years. Based on images from the Hubble telescope in May 2014, the diameter of GRS was measured at approximately 10,250 miles across, the smallest the storm has ever been measured. By comparison, the Great Red Spot was 14,500 miles across when NASA's Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 spacecraft flew by Jupiter in 1979. Historic observations as far back as the late 1800s gauged the storm to be as large as 25,500 miles on its long axis.

Astronomers have known that the Great Red Spot has been shrinking since the 1930s. A study by scientists at the University of California, Berkeley found that the spot lost 15?percent of its diameter along its major axis between 1996 and 2006. Starting in 2012, amateur observations have revealed a noticeable increase in the GRS's shrinkage rate. The GRS's "waistline" is getting currently smaller by 580 miles per year, and the rate of shrinkage is increasing.

  • Scientific American - Jupiter's Great Red Spot Now Just Pretty Good
  • HubbleSite - Hubble Shows that Jupiter's Great Red Spot is Now Smaller than Ever Seen Before
  • Hubble Space Telescope YouTube -The Incredible Shrinking Great Red Spot
  • Wikipedia - Atmosphere of Jupiter


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

NASA will continue to report findings and observations on the Great Red Spot, as will the Hubble Telescope's website. Stories on continued shrinking of the Great Red Spot will also likely be covered by scientific publications and the mainstream press.

Fine Print

This question is specifically asking if the Great Red Spot will shrink to less than 9,000 miles in diameter at its longitudinal axis, or widest point.
short_name: Great Red Spot less than 9k miles in diameter

keywords: Solar energy, solar towers, solar updraft towers, collectors, chimneys
name: When will a solar updraft tower with an output of at least 500kW become operational somewhere in the Continental United States?
question_text:
A solarupdraft tower is a renewable-energy production method first proposed in 1903.It combines three well-proven technologies: greenhouses, chimneys, and windturbines. Air contained in a large greenhouse-like structure (the collector)around the base of a tall tower is heated by the sun, and the resultingconvection causes air to rise up the tower. This airflow drives turbines, whichproduce electricity. While the science of solar updraft towers is wellunderstood and fairly elementary, few actual towers have been built given theirexpense. The best-known tower was a pilot scale facility built in Manzanares,Spain in 1982, which operated for eight years, producing about 50kW, before theinexpensive materials used to build it failed. A few other very small towershave been built for study purposes. A commercial scale tower has been built in Jinshawanin Inner Mongolia, China, with an output of 200 kW, but that facility?s plan isultimately for a 277 hectare collector and a tower that produces 27.5 MW.

A companybased in Australia, EnviroMission Limited, has signed a memorandum ofunderstanding in the Middle East to work cooperatively with developmentagencies in the region to build and operate updraft towers, and is workingtoward a plant being built in the U.S., seeking various licenses and otherprerequisites for construction. This question asks when EnviroMission, or someother entity, will see an updraft tower through to completion and operation.

Resolution Criteria

EnviroMission Limited is the most likely organization to be associated with the construction of a solar updraft tower in the United States, though other groups might also seek to construct a U.S. updraft tower.

Resolution Sources

If a solar updraft tower were to become operational in the Continental United States, news of its completion and operation would be covered by a mix of general and technically-focused news media, as well as energy related news media.

  • New YorkTimes Science Section (general media)
  • IEEE Spectrum (technology news media)
  • Recharge(renewable energy news)

Fine Print

Operational will be defined as the tower generating electric power at the stated output for commercial distribution.

Useful Information and Links

  • Design of Commercial Solar Updraft Tower Systems?
  • Middle East solar skyscraper MoU
  • Solaripedia
  • Will Balloons Boost the Solar Updraft Tower Idea?

keywords: Biofuels, renewable energy, cellulosic biofuel production, chemistry
name: How much cellulosic biofuels will the US produce in 2014, as reported in the Environmental Protection Agency?s Renewable Fuel Standard EMTS Informational Data?
question_text:
Cellulosicbiofuels are an advanced biofuel that are produced from lignocellulose, a materialthat makes up the mass of most plants. Because it is made from breaking down lignocellulose,cellulosic biofuel can be produced from diverse and abundant plantmaterials?anything from wood chips and plant waste to common grasses?as opposedto conventional biofuels, which typically require corn or cane sugar to producefuel.?

TheEnvironmental Protection Agency, under the Renewable Fuel Standard, hasmandated domestic oil refiners to blend an increasing amount of cellulosicbiofuels into gasoline?6.6 million gallons in 2011, 8.65 million in 2012 and 14million in 2013. However, successes in laboratory cellulosic biofuel productionhave yet to be translated into viable, large-scale commercial production. In2012, only 20,000 gallons of cellulosic biofuels were produced domestically,and less than 200,000 gallons in 2013 as of December. Several large-scalecommercial cellulosic biofuels plants have been constructed in the last twoyears, many of which have suffered from setbacks and delays, are now scheduledto begin production in late-2013 and 2014. Estimates for domestic cellulosicbiofuels production in 2014 range from as low as 200,000 gallons to as high as5 million gallons with all of the new plants running at full capacity.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Resolution Criteria

There are several facilities for the commercial production of cellulosic ethanol scheduled to begin production in late 2013 or 2014, including plants owned by DuPont, POET-DSM Advanced Biofuels, Abengoa Bioenergy and Gulf Coast Energy.?


Resolution Sources

?The EPA?s RenewableFuel Standard Moderated Transaction System (EMTS) website: http://www.epa.gov/otaq/fuels/rfsdata/index.htm

Fine Print

The answer?should be published sometime in 2015 by Renewable Fuel Standard Moderated Transaction System (EMTS) website, found at http://www.epa.gov/otaq/fuels/rfsdata/index.htm

name: How many threatened species will the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species identify in its next published update?
question_text:
The InternationalUnion for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) maintains and publishes the IUCN RedList of Threatened Species, widely recognized as the most comprehensive andobjective global approach for evaluating the conservation status of plant andanimal species. In order to produce the Red List, IUCN draws upon a network ofscientists and partner organizations working in almost every country in theworld.

The Red Listidentified species as threatened if they are classified by the IUCN asCritically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), or Vulnerable (VU). Species canalso be classified as extinct (EX) or extinct in the wild (EW); or in one of severalnon-threatened categories: Lower Risk/conservation dependent (LR/cd), NearThreatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD), Least Concern (LC).

In the 2012, 2013, and 2014 releases of the Red List, the IUCN reported 20,219, 21,286, and 22,176threatened species respectively. The IUCN updates its list at least annually,so a new update should be available and published in 2015.

For morebackground, see:
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved when the IUCN publishes its next update to the RedList. The current list is version 2014.1 from 12 June 2014. The next updated list, once published, will be available in Table 1 and linked to here:? http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics

Fine Print

IUCN definitions are being used for endangered species, per the discussion in the Background discussion.
short_name: IUCN Total Threatened Species, Part II

name: Will the NIST 2015 OpenMT Arabic-To-English machine translation evaluation be a split decision?
question_text:
Machine rendered translation of one human language to another is an active area of research in computer science. The benefits of being able to automatically translate from one language to another are enormous, but so are the challenges. Structurally, human languages differ in their morphology, semantics, syntax, and grammar. In addition to these structural differences, the prevalence of idiom and the contextually dependent interpretation of meaning also contribute significant difficulty to machine translation (MT).

In order to support MT research and help advance the state of the art, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) runs the Open Machine Translation Evaluation (OpenMT). Machine translation teams from around the world test their translation technology on a defined set of non-English text sources and the effectiveness of these competing technologies is evaluated. The list of answer choices for this question (see the Make a Forecast tab) is made up of participant teams in the 2012 evaluation, the most recent one completed.

The 2015 competition will be using up to 4 metrics to score each team?s translation: ?BLUE, METEOR, TER, and HyTER. These metrics are commonly used in scoring machine translation and depend on such analyses as comparing machine translations to reference translations, and also tend to be highly correlated with one another. However, it is possible for a specific MT technology to score higher than a competing approach on one metric, but lower on another. Evaluation results for the 2015 evaluation, which is already underway, are expected by the end of January 2015.

For more background, see:

  • http://research.google.com/pubs/MachineTranslation.html
  • http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt.cfm
  • http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt15.cfm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2015

Resolution Source

NIST will report the results of its 2015 OpenMT evaluation here:? http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt15.cfm

Fine Print

A split decision means that different teams score the highest for at least two of the scoring metrics used (BLUE, METEOR, TER, and HyTER).

keywords: Cybersecurity, cyber security, information analyst, salary
name: When the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports median salary data for 2014, will the median annual salary for an "Information Security Analyst" for 2014 have risen above the 2013 figure by more than 5%?
question_text:
"Cybersecurity is perhaps the most challenging intellectual profession on the planet both because of the rate of change and because your failure is the intentional work product of sentient opponents.? ?

Information security analysts must continually adapt to stay a step ahead of cyberattackers. They must stay up to date on the latest methods attackers are using to infiltrate computer systems and on IT security. Analysts need to research new security technology to decide what will most effectively protect their organization. This may involve attending cybersecurity conferences to hear firsthand accounts of other professionals who have experienced new types of attacks.

IT security analysts are also frequently involved with creating their organization?s disaster recovery plan, a procedure that IT employees follow in case of emergency. The plan lets an organization?s IT department continue functioning. It includes preventative measures such as regularly copying and transferring data to an offsite location. It also involves plans to restore proper IT functioning after a disaster. Analysts continually test the steps in their recovery plans.

Because information security is important, these workers usually report directly to upper management. Many information security analysts work with an organization?s?computer and information systems manager?or chief technology officer (CTO) to design security or disaster recovery systems.?
? ?
For more information:
  • http://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/information-security-analysts.htm#tab-1
  • http://geer.tinho.net/fgm/fgm.geer.1502.pdf


This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved using the median income for Information Security analysts published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics expected to be published in December, 2015:?http://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/information-security-analysts.htm#TB_inli...

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

Fine Print

The median annual salary for an Information Security Analyst in 2013 was reported as $88,590.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Beta
name: What place will the Beta Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The Beta Team's Strategy to Win the Race:

If you want to run fast, you should not be sticking to the ground too much. Therefore, our athletes carry a mutation that results in decreased cell-substrate adhesion.

Dicty related?research going on at the?Beta Lab:

In our work on chemotactic locomotion, we combine a well-established model organism for actin based motility, the single-celled ameba?Dictyostelium discoideum, with novel experimental techniques that allow the precise spatiotemporal addressing in easily tunable, highly controlled chemical environments. In a microfluidic gradient mixer, the chemotactic response of?D. discoideum?cells to stationary, linear gradients of the chemoattractant cyclic adenosine 3',5'-monophosphate (cAMP) was investigated. In shallow gradients of less than 0.001 nM/mm, no directional response was observed and cells exhibited a constant basal motility. In steeper gradients, cells moved up the gradient on average. The chemotactic speed and the motility increased with increasing steepness up to a plateau at around 0.1 nM/mm. In very steep gradients, above 10 nM/mm, the cells lost directionality and the motility returned to the sub-threshold level. In the regime of optimal response, the difference in receptor occupancy at the front and back of the cell is estimated to be only about 100 molecules.

Useful Links
  • Link to?Beta Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

keywords: Biodiversity, Ecosystem, Habitat, Ecological Footprint, Environment
name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "Ecological footprint and related concepts" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

Useful Links

  • http://www.cbd.int/gbo/?
  • https://www.cbd.int/cop/

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: When will commercial production of a microprocessor on a 450 millimeter silicon wafer begin?
question_text:
According to?Wall Street Journal?s Don Clark on March 13 2014, chip makers have slowed plans to build a new generation of plants that would drive down semiconductor manufacturing costs. ??Historically, each advance in wafers has reduced the cost of each chip by about 30%. ?Chip makers made their last transition over a decade ago, introducing wafers that were 300 millimetres in diameter or about 12 inches. The next proposed shift would enlarge wafers to 450 millimeters or about 18 inches.??

The transition to the large wafer?could be under threat because of the huge upfront costs of building next-generation plants. Industry analysts estimate that chip manufacturers will need to invest as much as $10 billion in upfront outlays for plants and equipment for a?single high-volume factory. ?As recently as March 2014, however,?Intel Corporation said it is on track to produce microprocessors on 450 mm?silicon wafers even after a major supplier, ASML, said it would stop developing the machines needed for the move to the larger wafers.

The?G450C?consortium reported?that they see?no real barriers to implementing 450mm?wafers from a technical standpoint. The Global 450 Consortium (G450C) is a 450 mm?wafer and equipment development program which is leveraging industry and government investments to demonstrate 450mm process capabilities.?

In 2005, the 450mm fabrication facilities?were reported to be?on track for production in 2012. But that?never happened. ?Industry executives had set 2016 as the target date but that is being?pushed back to 2018, according to?SEMI?and?IC Knowledge. ?VLSI Research doesn?t see 450mm fabs moving into production until 2020 to 2025. ?Mark Durcan, CEO of Micron,?says?450mm may never happen.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2029

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved using the electronics industry press which includes publications such as IEEE Spectrum, EE Times, and EDN. Other possible sources will be the major semiconductor manufacturers and the Global 450 Consortium.

Fine Print

Commercial production begins when the first commercial chips from 450-millimeter wafers are shipped from a semiconductor fabrication plant.

keywords: Flu, national, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the U.S. 2014-2015 flu season?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select National?
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.

For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for the U.S. is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across all HHS regions (i.e., across the continental U.S.) is the highest.

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

keywords: World Chess Championship, Magnus Carlsen, Viswanathan Anand
name: In their 2013 meeting, Magnus Carlsen beat Viswanthan Anand 6??3? to become the new world chess champion. Will Magnus Carlsen win the 2014 World Chess Championship match and defend his title?
question_text:
The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. A variety of news sources are expected to monitor the match with immediate updates as the match evolves.

keywords: neutrophils, dicty, irimia, mgh, race, cells, slime, mold
name: Which team will win the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
For background on each team's entry and strategy go to the SciCast Dicty Race Page.
You can also enter the scientist's name into the SciCast Search box, or you can see all the strategies at this page sponsored by the race: ?Dicty Race Team Site.

The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Engineered cell lines?will be shipped from labs around the world and attempt to complete the race course in the shortest amount of time and with the fewest mistakes (wrong turns).?Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The maze used in the race is manufactured in the lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using stereomicroscope cameras.

Quotes from race organizer Daniel Irimia:

On growth in the field of?cell migration:
What we're trying to do here is to have the people from the biology side and the people from the engineering side (together) so we can bring more tools to the race.?

Public appeal of the race:
It's really easy to understand movement. It's ingrained in our brains. We see something moving, we pay attention to that. So this is a way of promoting science to the general public by saying that in science, we only know this much and we need to learn more to make an impact on health. With the whole situation with science funding today, it's an important message to get out.

Applications in medicine:
In cancer, it would be ideal to stop the movement of cancer cells and stop metastasis so we could then deal with the cancer in a more effective way. Also if you look at the top 10 diseases in the world, seven of them are related to chronic inflammation. When you say inflammation, then you are talking about immune cells including neutrophils, which move from the blood to tissue. We need drugs to stop this movement that happens with inflammation but we don't want to stop this movement completely because (then) we'd become unprotected from microbes. So there's this tricky situation in places where cell migration takes place.

Useful Links:
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

name: Will Google acquire Twitch by the end of September 2014?
question_text:
There have been reports that Youtube (owned by Google) is working out a deal to acquire Twitch, a video game broadcasting service for more than $1 billion.? Twitch.tv, competing to be the ESPN of video games, is a popular platform that allows gamers to broadcast and watch live PC or console games.? It has also become popular for hosting live video game trade shows and competitions.

Relevant Links
  • Youtube to Acquire Videogame Streaming Service Twitch for $1 Billion
  • Major League Gaming, Twitch Compete to Become the ESPN of Videogames
  • What is Twitch and Why Does Google Think It's Worth $1 Billion?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/30/2014

Resolution Source

This will resolve true if Google announces that it bought the company Twitch by September 30, 2014.? This will be confirmed by a statement from Google or Twitch, and by major news outlets.? This will also resolve true regardless of the decision for Google to incorporate Twitch into Youtube, or keep Twitch as a separate service.

keywords: sensing technology, biotechnology, and organic electronics, sports medicine
name: When will the first professional sports team use on-body biosensors during an actual sports contest?
question_text:
Advances in sensing technology, biotechnology, and organic electronics are making it possible to measure human vital signs and other aspects of physiological condition in humans. New sensors that are placed directly on human skin are being developed for use in real-time health and biomarker measurement.

At the same time, technology in general and sensors specifically are being used more and more frequently in the sports world, in an effort to better train athletes and improve athletic performance. It is only a matter of time before professional sports leagues use on-skin sensor real time during games to gauge performance and use collected data to decided on hydration and other potential in-game interventions.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.uc.edu/news/nr.aspx?id=17241
  • http://www.bbc.com/news/business-17097958
  • http://www.hitachi.com/rev/pdf/2008/r2008_03_101.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Use of on-skin sensors during a live game will be reported by the national press. Statements made by players, coaches or other team staff may also be used to resolve the question. In cases of uncertainty, administrators reserve the right to consult outside subject matter experts and/or pause the question to evaluate evidence.?

Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, professional sports teams include those in the National Football League (NFL), Major League Baseball (MLB), Major League Soccer (MLS), National Hockey League (NHL), and the National Basketball Association (NBA).

choices_field_7: greater than or equal to 800 Wh/kg
keywords: Battery technology, electric vehicles, mobile technologies, chemistry
name: What will be the energy density of the first Lithium-Sulfur prototype battery that can sustain at least 1,000 charge-discharge cycles without more than a 10% capacity loss?
question_text:
Electric cars are currently powered by lithium-ion batteries.? Lithium-ion batteries can have different chemicalcomposition such as lithium manganese oxide, lithium cobalt oxide,lithium iron phosphate,lithium-manganese,or lithium vanadium oxide.? Alternativesto current lithium-ion batteries are lithium-sulfur batteries, which can holdas much as four times more energy per mass than current lithium-ion batteries. Forelectric vehicles to have a 300-mile range, the battery should provide acell-level specific energy of 350 to 400 Watt-hours/kilogram (Wh/kg). Thiswould require almost double the specific energy of current lithium-ionbatteries (about 200 Wh/kg). The batteries would also need to have at least1,000, and preferably 1,500, charge-discharge cycles without showing anoticeable power or energy storage capacity loss.

The lithium-sulfur batteries? mainobstacles are unwanted side reactions between the anode and cathode electrodesthat reduce the battery's lifetime. Researchers at Pacific NorthwestNational Lab published a paper in Nature Communications on January 9,2014, describing a solution they developed to decrease the sulfur leakage byshielding the anode with a graphite layer. The new anode quadrupled thelifespan of the lithium-sulfur battery system the team tested.

Another research team Duan et al.published in Journal ofMaterials Chemistry A in January2014 details of a Li-S ?reversible capacity of 500 mAh/g after 50 cycles at a current density of 200 mA/g, which ensures astable specific energy of 410 Wh/kg.?These results have been shown with small, thin-film lab-scale batteries. To truly know if Li-S batteries are viable, similar results need to be shown with larger and thicker prototype batteries.

ARPA-E funds companies seeking tobuild a Li-S prototype batteries; examples include:

  • In February 2013 PolyPlus accepted $4.5 million to furtherdevelop Li-S to commercial viability. At the end of the three-year ARPA-E program, PolyPlushas agreed to deliver an aqueous Li-S prototype with 400 Wh/kg and 650 Wh/kg toan external evaluator for testing and PolyPlus said they could exceed thisgoal.?
  • Vorbeck Materials received a$1.5 million grant for a lithium sulfur battery that would improve the energydensity and charge time of today?s batteries.
  • IonPower, in collaboration with BASF, Lawrence Berkeley National Lab,and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, seek to accelerate the development ofpractical, economical and safelithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries for powering electric vehiclesmore than 300 miles between charges
Links:
  • Holistic Cell Design by Berkeley Lab Scientists Leads to High-Performance, Long Cycle-Life Lithium-Sulfur Battery
  • Battery development may extend range of electric cars

ARPA-E?s continued funding of these projects increases the probability that this outcome will occur.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

02/01/2016

Resolution Source

The energy density of the first announced Li-S battery prototype tested with at least 1000 cycles will resolve this question.

The energy density number may be announced directly by the company and verified by an external evaluator. This announcement may be covered by ARPA-E press releases if achieved through one of their projects. It may be published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomas Reuters' Web of Science. The question will also be resolved if the announcement is covered by a major publication such as the New York Times, the Chicago Tribune, Popular Science, Science Magazine, etc. Any of these methods must clearly describe the measured energy density as well as the external validation.

Fine Print

Discharge cycle is defined as delivering all stored energy from a fully charge state.

keywords: smartphone, iris authentication, iris recognition, biometrics
name: Will a smartphone with a built-in iris recognition system be commercially available by July, 2016?
question_text:
There are currently numerous efforts to come up with authentication solutions for electronic devices beyond passwords. At the Mobile World Congress 2015, running from March 2 through March 5 in Barcelona, Fujitsu?presented a prototype smartphone with a built-in?iris authentication system. The biometric authentication approach uses infrared light to acquire the pattern formed by the iris. These patterns?are unique for each individual, much like a fingerprint. Tim Hornyak, Tokyo correspondent, IDG News Service, said the prototype being shown at the Barcelona event was the first of its kind for a?smartphone, according to the company.?

For more information:

  • Fujitsu shows iris recognition system that unlocks phones:?http://phys.org/news/2015-03-fujitsu-iris-recognition.html
  • Iris authentication is beginning to show up in mobile?devices:?http://venturebeat.com/2015/03/01/iris-authentication-is-beginning-to-show-up-in-mobile-devices/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2015

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved when?a smartphone with a built-in?iris recognition system is available?in retail stores or online?(via amazon.com, walmart.com, bestbuy.com, target.com, etc.)?or when the bidding closes?on June 30th 2016, whichever?is sooner.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Commercially available means that the smartphone will be for sale on the retail market.

keywords: Sierpinski numbers, prime number, composite number
name: When will another Sierpinski number candidate below 78,557 be ruled out as a Sierpinski number?
question_text:
A Sierpinski number is an odd natural number k for which the integers of the form k*2^n + 1 are composite for all natural numbers n (where ^ denotes exponent). Polish mathematician Waclaw Franciszek Sierpinski proved that there are infinitely many odd integers k which have this property. The sequence of currently known Sierpinski numbers begins with: 78557, 271129, 271577, 322523? The number 78557 was proved to be a Sierpinski number by John Selfridge in 1962.

To prove that 78557 is the smallest Sierpinski number, one must show that all the odd numbers smaller than 78557 are not Sierpinski numbers. That is, for every odd k below 78,557 there exists a positive integer n such that k*2^n + 1 is prime. In 2002 a distributed computing project called Seventeen or Bust was established to solve the so-called ?Sierpinski problem,? the problem of ruling out all remaining Sierpinski candidates below 78557. At the time there were seventeen candidates, hence the project name. As of February 20, 2015, only six candidates remain. Primes have been found for the eleven other original 17 candidates numbers, eliminating them for contention as Sierpinski numbers.

For more information, see:

  • http://mathworld.wolfram.com/SierpinskisCompositeNumberTheorem.html
  • http://www.seventeenorbust.com/
  • http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022314X08000462
  • http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022314X1200265X

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

The Seventeen or Bust project website (www.seventeenorbust.com) announced the discovery of any new prime numbers that eliminate candidate numbers from contention.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

keywords: NAIAS, EyesOn Design Award, car design
name: Which automobile manufacturer will win the Best Concept Vehicle award for the 11th Annual EyesOn Design Competition at the 2015 NAIAS?
question_text:
The North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) EyesOn Design Awards honor the most significant automotive designs on display at NAIAS as determined by global leaders of design from automotive manufacturers, academic chairs of transportation design programs, and design leaders from other fields.? These awards recognize the best production and concept vehicles debuted at the NAIAS in terms of design excellence, in areas including aesthetics and innovation, concept implementation, functionality, and spirit of industrial design. This question asks which automobile manufacturer will win the 2015 NAIAS EyesOn Design award for the Best Concept Vehicle.

Relevant Links:

  • EyesOn Design Awards at NAIAS Information
  • Volvo, Ford Win 2014 EyesOn Design Awards at NAIAS
  • Cadillac ELR Upsets Corvette Stingray For ?Eyes On Design? Award (2013)
  • NAIAS 2012 EyesOn Design Awards go to Ford Fusion and Lexus LF-LC
  • EyesOn Design Award Winners: 1989-2014

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/25/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the automobile manufacturer that wins the EyesOn Design award for the Best Concept Vehicle.? This will be verified by the EyesOn Design site, or other major news sources.

Fine Print

The answer choices follow the format: 'car manufacturer (brands manufactured if multiple).' The reason for adding car brands in parenthesis was to make forecasting easier and to clarify which car brands belong under which manufacturer. The choice for a car manufacturer is not necessarily limited to the brands listed in parenthesis. Note: In the event that the award comes in as a tie (such as in 2013), the question will be resolved as a mixture settlement. Also, the name for the 'Best Concept Vehicle' is also termed, 'EyesOn Design Award for Design Excellence ? Concept Vehicle.'Note: In the event that a car brand belongs to multiple manufacturers, then the resolution will be to the manufacturer with the largest percentage of ownership.

name: Will Google announce development of a smartwatch at or before the Google I/O 2014 Conference?
question_text:
With the increasing popularity around smartwatches, and the rumor that Apple is also developing an iWatch, this leads to the question if Google will develop an official Google smartwatch.? In March 2014, Google announced development of their software for smartwatches, named Android Wear.? LG and Motorola also have revealed smartwatches using the Android Wear platform, the LG G Watch and the Moto 360.? This asks the question if Google will announce development of an official smartwatch at or before the Google I/O Conference, just like Google developed an official tablet/phone (Nexus) for their Android OS.

Relevant Links:
  • Google Watch: Release Dates, News, and Rumors
  • Google IO 2014: Ten Things We Expect

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/26/2014

Resolution Source

This question will resolve true if Google announces development of an official smartwatch at or before the 2014 Google I/O Conference which takes place during June 25-26, 2014.? The conference sessions will be live streamed at the Google I/O page.? This may also be confirmed by major news outlets.

Fine Print

A smartwatch is defined in this question to be, 'a computer based wristwatch that provides an extension to a smartphone' [PC Mag].Although Motorola was owned by Google and recently bought by Lenova, this is not the 'official' Google smartwatch. The official smartwatch would be sold directly by Google, similar to how the Nexus phone and tablets are sold (http://www.google.com/intl/all/nexus/). Possible names that have been rumored are 'The Google Gem' or 'The Google Glass Watch.' The assumptions of ?sold directly? are that Google makes their own website for the watch and markets it under the google.com domain, just like it did with the Nexus products. In addition, it would have 'Google' as the first identifier in the name such as in the 'Google Nexus' or 'Google Chromebook Pixel.' 'Announcement of development' is defined to be if Google gives news about developing a smartwatch, gives release dates for a smartwatch, or presents a prototype or production ready smartwatch.

name: On November 2020, what will be the Top 500 performance share by cores per socket?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by cores per socket, and you think 8 core/socket machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust the chances of 8 core/socket machines towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list
