name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Hawaii?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Hawaii, 64.6% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -8.5% from 2011 (73.1%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 63.7%, the "63.7%-67.1%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Cyber grand challenge, cybersecurity, DARPA, cyber security
name: Will the DARPA Grand Challenge, the pure robot Capture the Flag contest at DefCon 2015, be won by a non university-based team?
question_text:
With the coming advent of the Internet of Things, data insecurity is on track to become physical insecurity. The same code that powers today?s networked computers ? code that is routinely compromised by attackers ? is making its way into our vehicles, our smart homes, our connected culture, and?our augmented reality.? This future requires a fundamentally different mentality when thinking about how networked devices will be defended.?
? ?
Today?s attackers have the upper hand due to the problematic economics of computer security. Attackers have the concrete and inexpensive task of finding a single flaw to break a system. Defenders, on the other hand, are required to anticipate and deny any possible flaw ? a goal both difficult to measure and expensive to achieve. Only automation can upend these economics.

The ultimate test of wits in computer security occurs through open competition on the global Capture the Flag (CTF) tournament circuit. In CTF contests, experts reverse engineer software, probe its weaknesses, search for deeply hidden flaws, and create securely patched replacements. How hard is this work? The Heartbleed?flaw in OpenSSL went undiscovered for two years before it was found by a Google engineer doing line-by-line audit of the source code. The Shellshock flaw in Bash went undiscovered for 21 years until it was found by an Akamai engineer working in his spare time. Discovery of exploitable flaws of these sorts requires the same type of reverse engineering excellence that CTFs are designed to hone.

For more information:?

  • http://www.cybergrandchallenge.com/


This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/12/2015

Resolution Source

The winners will be announced at?http://www.cybergrandchallenge.com/.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

keywords: Flu, Region 3, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 3 (DE, DC, MD, PA, VA, WV)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???

  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 3' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 3 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 3. Region 3 is comprised of Delaware, District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

keywords: plague, pneumonic plague, Black Death, Madagascar
name: Will at least 10 new confirmed cases of pneumonic plague in Madagascar be reported to the WHO in the first quarter of 2015?
question_text:
On Nov 4th, 2014 the WHO was notified by the Ministry of Health of Madagascar of an outbreak of plague. The first case was identified on August 31, and the patient died on September 3. However WHO was not notified until November. The bubonic plague outbreak in Madagascar has seen more than 130 confirmed cases and claimed 47 lives. In the bubonic form of plague, where there are swellings known as buboes in the lymph nodes, the disease is susceptible to treatment with antibiotics; however, in the pneumonic form of the disease, which affects the lungs, the disease can be communicated from one person to another through coughing. In the current outbreak, only about 2% of the reported cases are of the?pneumonic?form.?

  • Plague - Madagascar:?http://www.who.int/csr/don/21-november-2014-plague/en/
  • The plague is back in a big way:?http://magazine.good.is/articles/madagascar-black-death-outbreak
  • WHO: Plague in Madagascar Could Spread:?http://learningenglish.voanews.com/content/who-plague-in-madagascar-could-spread/2541606.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

Cases will be reported to WHO and published in outbreak news:?http://www.who.int/csr/don/21-november-2014-plague/en/
The Ministry of Health of Madagascar (Ministere de la Sante Publique)?is another official source to be consulted:?http://www.sante.gov.mg/

keywords: Dark matter,  particles weakly interacting massive particles, WIMPs, weakly interacting slim particles, WISPs
name: Will the Large Underground Xenon dark matter experiment in Lead, SD detect the dark matter particles weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) or weakly interacting slim particles (WISPs) by the end of 2014?
question_text:
The Large Underground Xenon experiment attempts to directly detect interactions between WIMPs and WISPs dark matter and ordinary matter on Earth. The LUX experiment, a vat of 368 kilograms of liquid xenon cooled to minus 150 degrees Fahrenheit is located 4,850 ft (about 1 mile) underground at the Sanford Underground Laboratory in Lead, South Dakota.

Dark matter has never been directly detected on Earth, though hints have been detected. LUX is designed so that dark matter particles, passing through Earth, will occasionally hit the xenon nuclei in the underground vat, causing flashes of light that can be picked up by the experiment's 122 photomultiplier tubes, situated in arrays above and below the xenon. The experiment will allow researchers to detect even faint dark matter interactions with unprecedented sensitivity.


Resolution Sources

Numerous scientific journals and news outlets would likely report this advancement, including:

  • Science Magazine
  • Nature
  • BBC News
  • The New York Times Science Section

Fine Print

"directly detect" dark matter is defined by J. L. Feng, Ann. Rev. Astron. Astrophys.48, 495 (2010). It is a defined phrase and standard in the field and any announcement would use the phrase "directly detect".

from the paper:

"Direct detection: dark matter can scatter o normal matter through X SM --> X SM interactions, depositing energy that may be observed in sensitive, low background detectors."


Useful Information and Links

  • LUX Dark Matter
  • Large Underground Xenon (LUX) dark matter detector
  • Dark Matter Experiment Has Detected Nothing, Researchers Say Proudly
  • First results from LUX dark matter detector rule out some candidates
  • No sign of dark matter in underground experiment


Related Organizations or Individuals

Large Underground Xenon http://lux.brown.edu/LUX_dark_matter/Home.html

name: IBM recently signed a 10-year agreement to help China clean up its pollution problems by using its big data analytics technology. Will Beijing be able to achieve its goal of a 25% reduction in fine particulate matter (PM2.5) air pollution by the end of 2017?
question_text:
Facing?significant air pollution problems in Beijing and elsewhere, the leaders of China have declared a "war on pollution". One stated?goal?is to, by 2017,?reduce?Beijing's PM2.5 level?- the concentration of?fine particulate matter that poses the greatest risk to human health -?by 25%. However the city's own government officials are skeptical about hitting that goal in 2017, because Beijing's pollution woes are usually complicated. Now IBM thinks it can change that outlook. The company recently signed a 10-year agreement to help China clean up its pollution problems by using its big data analytics technology, as well as the "internet of things", weather modeling and supercomputing.

  • How IBM is using big data to fix Beijing's pollution crisis:?http://qz.com/230689/how-ibm-is-using-big-data-to-fix-beijings-pollution-crisis/

Fine Print

PM2.5 is made up of fine particles of liquid or solid matter in the Earth's atmosphere that are under 2.5 micrometers in diameter.

name: When will the first primate be cloned?
question_text:
Scientistshave been able to produce genetically identical animals since 1979 using a methodof cloning called embryo splitting. It was not until 1996, however, thatresearchers succeeded in cloning the first mammal using genetic material taken froman adult animal. After 276 attempts, Scottish researchers finally produced thenow famous Dolly, the lamb cloned from the udder cell of a 6-year-old sheep.Cloning is accomplished by transferring DNA of the adult donor animal cell intoan egg cell that has had its own DNA-containing nucleus removed. The combined eggis allowed to develop into an early-stage embryo in the lab is then implantedinto the womb of an adult female animal, where it gestates to term.

Since Dolly,many other mammal species have been cloned, including cat, deer, dog, horse,mule, ox, rabbit and rat, but cloning primates has proven more difficult. To date,no primate has been successfully cloned from an existing adult animal, though arhesus monkey has been cloned by embryo splitting, and in 2007, scientists wereable to create macaque embryos from an adult macaque. Attempts to implant theseembryos into the wombs of surrogate female macaques, however, were notsuccessful.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://news.sciencemag.org/2003/04/problem-cloning-primates
  • http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7094215.stm
  • http://www.genome.gov/25020028#al-2


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Successful cloningof a primate would be reported in the scientific literature, the science press,and the popular press.



Fine Print

Successful primate cloning means the live birth via surrogate mother of an animal cloned from the genetic material of an adult of the same species.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Alaska?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the State of Alaska, 56.1% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -3.4%?from 2011 (59.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are?developed based on the variation in the?rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use?the standard deviation (SD)?of these rates of change to?compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs?and center?the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range?of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change)?in the 7 interior bins of each question,?to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS - Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results?can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html#12

Fine Print

HPV stands for the Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a term defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 55.2%, the "55.2%-58.6%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will the Goldbach Conjecture be solved by 2025?
question_text:
The Goldbach conjecture dates back to a letter from Christian Goldbach from 1742 where he conjectures that an odd number greater than 7?can be formed as a sum of 3 primes and any even number can be formed as a sum of 2 primes. ?The latter is known as the "strong" Goldbach conjecture and the former the "weak" or "odd"?Goldbach conjecture. Obviously the strong Goldbach conjecture implies the weak Goldbach conjecture since 3 can be added to any even number to create an odd number. ?In 2013 the weak Goldbach conjecture was claimed to be proven by Harold Helfgott and no one in the Math community has found any errors in the proof to date. ?However it is unlikely that the progress in the weak conjecture can be used to solve the strong result. ?As of now the strong conjecture has been proven for numbers greater than 2x10^1346 and has been confirmed by computer for?numbers less than 10^18. ?It is reasonable to assume the lower bound will be increased each year, but without a significant reduction in the upper bound the proof is out of reach by computer, unless there is a great leap in computational power of computers

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2024

Resolution Source

A proof in a peer reviewed mathematical journal.

keywords: Honey bee, colony, honey, farming, agriculture, USDA
name: What percent of managed honey bee colonies in the US will be lost during the 2013-2014 winter?
question_text:
Estimates of winter loss for managed honey bee (Apis mellifera) colonies are an important measure of honey bee health and productivity. Last year's loss of bee colonies was 31.1% which is slightly higher than the previous 6-year average loss of 30.5 percent.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the BeeInformed winter loss survey for 2013/2014. It is anticipated that this report will be released on May 1 2014. If nothing is published by the BeeInformed organization by May 1 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Fine Print

Reported % loss of honey bees will be rounded to the nearest tenth of a percent to determine the correct answer.

Useful Links

  • Report on the National Stakeholders Conference on Honey Bee Health (USDA): http://www.usda.gov/documents/ReportHoneyBeeHealth.pdf

keywords: Supernova, skywatching, Type Ia supernova, Variable Star
name: When will the newly discovered supernova in galaxy M82 reach peak luminosity?
question_text:
On Tuesday,January 21, a group of students at the University College London discovered anew supernova in galaxy M82, making it the closest observed supernova indecades. Astronomers from Caltech have confirmed the supernova and classifiedit as a young, reddened Type Ia supernova. These kinds of objects are thoughtto originate in a close binary system where at least one star is a white dwarf,or a small, dense core of a star that has ceased undergoing nuclear reactions.?

Images fromthe supernova-hunting KAIT robotic telescope at the Lick Observatory inCalifornia confirm the object was not present as recently as 15 January,meaning the supernova is at most a few days old. Type 1a supernovae typicallyreach peak luminosity (the point at which the supernova is brightest) afterapproximately 19 days.

  • Slate - Nearby Galaxy M82 Hosts a New Supernova!
  • CBS News - Exploding Star: New Supernova Discovery is the Closest in Years
  • Universe Today - Bright New Supernova Blows Up in Nearby M82, the Cigar Galaxy
  • Cosmoquest Blog
  • AAVSO Light Curve Generator for SN 2014J
  • AAVSO Blog for SN 2014J



Accepting Forecasts Until:

13 FEB 2014

Resolution Source

Supernova are quite newsworthy, and a variety of mainstream sources, including the New York Times, BBC News, Science Magazine, etc., will likely describe the supernova and the time at which it achieves peak luminosity.

Astronomy Magazine's website would also cover the news.
http://www.astronomy.com/

Alternatively, a definitive?assessment by the?American Association of Variable Star Observers may be offered for resolution. (SN 2014J Blog)

Fine Print

Type Ia supernovae have a characteristic light curve, with a distinct peak. Peak luminosity is defined as the point at which the supernova is more luminous than any point prior or after.
short_name: New supernova in M82 reaches peak luminosity

name: When will the first Watson-based app be available for sale to the public on the Apple iOS operating system?
question_text:
Watson is anartificial intelligence (AI) computing system developed by IBM that usesadvanced natural language processing, machine learning, and other AI techniquesto answer open domain questions in a range of fields of human knowledge,including general knowledge.

In 2011,Watson competed on the television game show Jeopardy! against two former humanchampions. For that application of the technology, Watson had access to 200million pages (4 terabytes) of structured and unstructured content, includingthe full (off-line) text of Wikipedia. After the two scheduled matches, Watsonhas scored more than three times as many points (awarded on the show asdollars) as the human contestants.

In early2014 IBM has announced a number of commercial application areas for Watson,aiming to generate $10 billion in annual revenue from these applications within10 years. The company is hosting the Watson Mobile Developer Challenge to findthe best ideas for mobile apps that can take advantage of Watson?s cognitivecomputing capabilities.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://researcher.ibm.com/researcher/view_project.php?id=2099
  • http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304887104579306881917668654

keywords: digital currency, social innovation, P2P, BitCoin, cryptocurrency
name: Will there be a new digital currency based on a P2P network, whose real money supply will be valued at more than $1 billion in 2014?
question_text:
After Bitcoin was founded in 2009, at least one new digital currency has emerged each year. Most of these currencies are based on P2P networks and are not issued by governments. Currently there are only a few that have a significant value in real currencies, that are being?issued by central banks?(http://www.technologyreview.com/news/513661/bitcoin-isnt-the-only-cryptocurrency-in-town/).

The question asks you to estimate whether besides BitCoin, any other existing or novel P2P-based digital currency will be valued at at least 1 billion USD in total money supply on the market, by 31-DEC-2014.

The question will be resolved when there are credible reports in financially-savvy mass media outlets (such as WSJ, The Economist, Reuters, Forbes, BBC, CNN) and/or a report from a governmental agency (i.e. US Department of Treasury) that such a currency is valued as?at least $1 billion USD in total money supply.

Resolution Sources

  • www.economist.com
  • www.wired.com
  • www.cnn.com
  • www.reuters.com

Fine Print

Real money supply refers to the total value of the respective digital currency in circulation,?in terms of a central bank issued currency (in this case, the USD). A digital currency is a currency issued by any non-governmental entity that can be exchanged with?real goods and services and is not physically printed on paper. A P2P network is defined here:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer-to-peer

Useful Links

  • http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21590901-it-looks-overvalued-even-if-digital-currency-crashes-...

keywords: Magnus Carlsen, Viswanathan Anand, World Chess championship, draw
name: How many games will be drawn at the 2014 World Chess Championship match between Magnus Carlsen and Viswanathan Anand in Sochi, Russia this November?
question_text:
The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. A variety of news sources are expected to monitor the match with immediate updates as the match evolves.

Official FIDE website
2014 World Chess Championship [Wikipedia]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/28/2014

Resolution Source

http://www.fide.com
http://www.chess.com

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%.

keywords: computer chess, chess rating, chess engine
name: When will the first computer chess engine achieve a rating of at least 3400?
question_text:
Computer chess is computer architecture encompassing hardware and software capable of playing chess without human guidance. Since May 1997, when Deep Blue narrowly defeated Garry Kasparov 3.5-2.5, computers have vastly surpassed humans in their playing strength and the corresponding rating. The question asks you to estimate the date when a computer chess engine will surpass the rating of 3400 as listed on the index provided by the CCRL (Computer Chess Rating Lists), a website whose authors?have run?engine tests since 2006.

  • Computer Chess Wikipedia

The arrival of >7-man chess endgame tablebases, breakthroughs in supercomputing technology, changes in the form of computation of computer chess ratings

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

The outcome of this question will be based on a computer chess engine's achieving a rating of at least?3400 on the day?of the completion of the relevant game. The achievement and?exact date when it has occurred will be reported by the Computer Chess Rating Lists (CCRL).

Fine Print

The term "computer chess rating" may sound confusing even to professional chess players as it has not been as uniformly established in the community as the FIDE rating for human chess players. A variety of web sources enlist engines' ratings under their own definitions of the term. Another issue concerns the time control used by the playing engines. For the purposes of this question, the index published at http://www.computerchess.org.uk/ccrl/4040/ will be used to determine the answer. The time control exceeds that of a rapid game and can thus be deemed a more objective measure of the rating. Please note that this question refers specifically to the 'classical time control rating' of the chess engine, and not its rapid or blitz rating"
short_name: First computer chess engine rating of 3400

name: Will a demonstration of aneutronic fusion to directly create electricity be announced in 2015?
question_text:
Nuclear fusion is a nuclear reaction in which atomic nuclei of low atomic number fuse to form a heavier nucleus with the release of energy.? Research into harnessing the power of fusion to create electricity has focused on the deuterium-tritium fuel cycle, which releases up to 80% of the energy as neutrons. These neutrons are then used to heat water to produce steam, which produces electricity. However, the process results in radioactive waste.

Aneutronic fusion does not release more than 1% of its energy as neutrons and can directly produce electricity. Many different companies and labs are working on demonstrating anetronic fusion using the following systems/methods (not exhaustive):

  • Dense Plasma Focus system
  • Inertial electrostatic confinement
  • Colliding Beam Fusion Reactor
  • Z-pinch

Fusion requires confining fuel at high temperatures for a period of time. One firm, using the dense plasma focus system, achieved a record temperature of 1.8 billion degrees. However, the firm is still working on achieving the required densities needed to achieve aneutronic fusion.

Sources and links
  • Aneutronic fusion http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aneutronic_fusion
  • Fusion reactions from >150?keV ions in a dense plasma focus plasmoid http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/pop/19/3/10.1063/1.3694746
  • Lerner, Eric J. and Murali, S. Krupakar and Shannon, Derek and Blake, Aaron M. and Roessel, Fred Van, Physics of Plasmas (1994-present), 19, 032704 (2012), DOI:http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.3694746
  • Inside the Dynomak: A Fusion Technology Cheaper Than Coal http://spectrum.ieee.org/energy/nuclear/inside-the-dynomak-a-fusion-technology-cheaper-than-coal

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science, announced in an official press release from the company or lab that achieved the milestone or from the funding agency.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

Aneutronic fusion is any form of fusion power where neutrons carry no more than 1% of the total released energy."Directly create energy" means any direct method of creating electricity that does not involve the water-to-steam-to-turbine process. Examples include inductive, electrostatic, and photoelectric.

choices_field_4: Will not be announced by January 1 2050
keywords: Matrix Multiplication, Proofs, Math, Mathematics, Theory, Computer Science
name: When will a proof be published showing Matrix Multiplication in O(n^{2+?}) time, for every constant ? > 0?
question_text:
Given A and B, two n*n square matrices over a field F, the matrix multiplication problem is to output the product C=A*B. Here, the "allowed operations" are to take products and affine combinations over F; these operations can be combined into an arbitrary circuit, which must have n2 outputs corresponding to the entries of C. The circuit can be completely different for each input size n, in a nonuniform manner; on the other hand, the same circuit must work for an arbitrary field F (though it need not work for rings). Let S(n) bethe size of the smallest such circuit for multiplication of two n*nmatrices. Then this question is asking whetherS(n)=O(n2+?) for every constant ?>0.

Equivalently, let ? (the "matrix multiplication exponent") be the infimum over all c such that S(n)=O(nc); then this question is asking whether ?=2. The obvious upper bound, ?=3, was improved by a long sequence of algorithms, starting with that of Strassen in 1968 (??2.78). The current record, ??2.373, was proved by Vassilevska Williams, building in part on work of Stothers (both of whom were building on the important 1990 result ??2.376, due to Coppersmith and Winograd): [PDF]

Meanwhile, the only lower bound known remains the "obvious" bound ??2, which comes from the fact that any matrix multiplication circuit must have n2 inputs and n2 outputs. (Indeed, for general algorithms, we know nothing better than S(n)?c*n2, though Ran Raz proved S(n)?c*n2*log(n) for a restricted class of algorithms.) Opinion on the question remains divided: some theoretical computer scientists profess belief that ?=2, but an ambitious program to prove that, due to Umans, Kleinberg, et al., has not (yet) panned out. Thus, at present, there is no clear proposal for what an algorithm achieving ?=2 would look like.


If the forecaster believes the answer is "yes" to the question that asks whether a rigorous proof that ?=2 will be true, then this question asks to answer when this proof will be created. It is plausible that such a proof would involve at least some nonconstructive elements, and this is perfectly acceptable.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on judgment delivered by question moderator. If nothing is reported from this source, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed (e.g., direct outreach to prominent researchers in this field), provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the question moderator. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Useful Links


  • http://www.cs.stanford.edu/~virgi/matrixmult-f.pdf
  • We also have a binary version of this question.
  • We also have a question about a corresponding algorithm. (Remember, the proof can be non-constructive, so it may not imply an algorithm. But an algorithm for sufficiently small ? may constitute a proof.)

Related Organizations or Individuals

Question Leader - Scott Aaronson (MIT, CSAIL)

name: Will the Galileo navigation system's second Full Operational Capability (FOC) satellite currently in orbit begin transmission by May 31, 2015?
question_text:
Galileo is a satellite-based global navigation satellite system currently being built by the European Union (EU) and European Space Agency (ESA), named after the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei. The EU is building Galileo in part to become independent of the US GPS and Russian GLONASS systems. When finished, the system will include 30 satellites.

To date, four In-Orbit Validation (IOV) satellites and two Full Operational Capability (FOC) satellites have been put in orbit, though the latter two, launched in August of 2014, were accidently placed in the wrong orbit. After much maneuvering of the satellite?s orbit, the first of these FOC satellites started transmitting L-band navigation signals on November 29, 2014. The second FOC satellite is expected to be activated in early 2015, though the Galileo program has experienced various delays since inception.

For more information, see:
  • http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/The_future_-_Galileo/What_is_Galileo
  • http://gpsworld.com/the-system-first-galileo-foc-satellite-on-the-air/
  • http://spacenews.com/40118galileo-delay-could-save-arianespace-from-difficult-decision/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

Activation of a second Galileo FOC satellite will be announced by the European Space Agency here:
http://www.esa.int/For_Media/Press_Releases
http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/The_future_-_Galileo/What_is_Galileo.

This question will resolve when the data is updated sometime in early 2016.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.?

keywords: Flu, Region 8, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 8 (CO, MO, ND, SD, UT, WY)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 8' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases in Region 8 for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across HHS region 8. Region 8 is comprised of Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming. ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

keywords: renewable energy, energy towers, downdraft towers
name: Will a downdraft energy tower that can generate a net positive amount of energy be built in the U.S. by the end of 2019?
question_text:
The conceptof a downdraft-driven energy tower has been around for several decades. Ahypothetical tower would generate electricity by pumping water up a very tall(1 kilometer +) hollow tower and spraying it as a fine mist; the water wouldevaporate, cooling the air around it and causing that cool air to fall withinthe tower, causing turbines at the base of the tower to turn and thus generateelectricity. The water could be collected and condensed at the bottom of thetower and recirculated to the top of the tower, to maintain a continuousdowndraft. In principle, the energy generated by the turbines could be used tomaintain the water circulation and leave energy left over for public consumption.

The conceptshares certain features of the solar updraft tower (see https://scicast.org/#!/questions/146/safe). The greater the temperaturedifference between the air and water, the greater the energy efficiency.Therefore, it is believed that downdraft energy towers would work best in hotdry climates.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.marketwatch.com/story/solar-wind-energy-tower-inc-obtains-conditional-financing-commitment-for-first-solar-tower-in-arizona-2014-05-05
  • http://m.washingtonpost.com/blogs/innovations/wp/2014/07/07/can-this-2250-foot-tower-produce-enough-clean-energy-to-replace-power-plants/?tid=HP_technology
  • http://envgis.technion.ac.il/publications/energy%20tower%20potential.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

If an energytower were to become operational in the United States and generate net energy,news of its completion and operation would be covered by a mix of general andtechnically-focused news media, as well as energy related news media.

Fine Print

Generating a net positive amount of energy in the context of this question means the tower will generate more energy than is required to keep the water circulating and thus be able to generate electricity for outside consumption.

name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "trends in extent of selected biomes, ecosystems, and habitats" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversityloss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

Useful Links

  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/gbo/gbo2/cbd-gbo2-en.pdf
  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/publications/gbo/gbo3-final-en.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

The fourth edition of the Global Diversity Outlook report issued by The Convention on Biological Diversity: http://www.cbd.int/gbo/

question_text:

  • On October 14, 2014, PLOS: Outbreaks, Dr. Charles Haas published a paper that questioned this widely accepted incubation period. Dr. Haas stated that this calculation was based on epidemiological data from previous Ebola outbreaks and does not account for outliers. He states that his analysis of the data shows that ?from 0.1 to 12% of the time, an individual case will have a greater incubation time than 21 days?.

name: On June 2014, what will be the (performance-weighted) gigaflops per watt of the Top 500?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014.

This question asks what the average performance efficiency in terms of power consumption will be of the Top500 when weighted by system perfomance.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 statistics published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

Byperformance-weighted, we mean the average of all 500 machines, weighted by eachmachine?s raw computing performance (Rmax Gflops).


So for example, theperformance-weighted average <u>efficiency</u> (Gflops/watt) is calculatedby:? (1/500) * ?i wi * ei, where eiis the efficiency of machine i, and wi is the weight given to thatmachine.? The weight is always that machine?s proportion of the total Top500computing power (Rmax Gflops): wi = Rmaxi / (?iRmaxi), where Rmaxi is the Rmax score (Gflops) formachine i.


Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

keywords: Teixobactin, antibiotic, clinical trial, IChip, soil bacteria
name: Will teixobactin, a candidate antibiotic identified using Northeastern University's IChip device, enter a US human clinical trial before the end of 2017?
question_text:
Researchers from Northeastern University recently announced that they have?developed an electronic device called IChip to isolate antibiotic compounds in their natural environment - soil. ?The IChip sandwiches bacteria between two permeable sheets of membrane and is then?inserted into the ground for two weeks. The chemicals produced by the microbes of bacteria are then studied for the antibiotic cultures that naturally grow in dirt. The new technology?has the potential to lead to the discovery of new classes of antibiotics.

10,000 strains of bacteria were studied by researchers, and 25 new compounds were discovered. The most successful of the compounds was teixobactin, which was found to kill bacteria by breaking down its protective cell walls and stopping the growth of new cells.

Teixobactin has yet to be tested on humans, although scientists have seen it have positive results when tested on mice. The researchers estimate it will take a few years before the new antibiotic drug enters human clinical trials.

  • A new antibiotic kills pathogens without detectable resistance:?http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature14098.html
  • U.S. scientists discover powerful new antibiotic:?http://www.newsweek.com/new-antibiotic-found-dirt-298216

keywords: neutrophils, dicty, irimia, mgh, race, cells, slime, mold
name: Which team in the Dicty World Race will enter the fastest cell in the contest?
question_text:
For background on each team's entry and strategy go to the SciCast Dicty Race Page.
You can also enter the scientist's name into the SciCast Search box.

The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Engineered cell lines?will be shipped from labs around the world and attempt to complete the race course in the shortest amount of time and with the fewest mistakes (wrong turns).?Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The maze used in the race is manufactured in the lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using stereomicroscope cameras.This question asks which team will enter the cell that completes the maze in the shortest time
Useful Links:
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage

05/17/2014

Fine Print

The fastest cell in the race will be the one single cell that completes the maze in the least amount of time. The team who entered this cell will accept the prize on behalf of?the speedy little critter owing to the fact that the cell will die before it can blow its prize money. Since transit time for individual cells?will need to be determined by video analysis, there may be several days of delay after the race has been concluded before the winner is announced.?

name: How many base pairs will the smallest genome discovered by the end of 2016 contain?
question_text:
Currently, the organism with the smallest known genome is nasuia deltocephalinicola, a bacterium with only 112,091 base pairs in its genome. The bacterium helps insect hosts synthesize amino acids. All of the recent record holders for smallest known genome inhabit the same ecological niche inside plant-feeding insects. By comparison the human genome contains 3.2 billion base pairs. As the genetic makeup of more and more species of bacteria are mapped, this record may well fall.

For more information, see

  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23918810
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasuia_deltocephalinicola
  • http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2013/08/23/and-the-genomes-keep-shrinking/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The discovery of a new smallest-known genome creature will be reported in the scientific literature, and possibly in the popular science press.

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%. More information on Scaled questions can be found on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

keywords: NASA, asteroids, NEO, near earth object
name: How close will the closest near Earth object that is tracked by NASA come to Earth in the 60 days between August 2nd and September 30th 2014?
question_text:
The U.S. NationalAeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), through its Near Earth ObjectProgram, monitors so-called Near-Earth Objects (NEOs). NEOs are comets andasteroids that have been nudged by the gravitational attraction of nearbyplanets into orbits that allow them to enter the Earth's vicinity.

NASA?s NEOprogram tracks objects from a variety of observation points around the globe,including the Catalina Sky Survey (CSS) and Spacewatch near Tucson Arizona; theLINEAR project near Socorro New Mexico; Pans-STARRS1 on Maui, Hawaii; and LONEOSnear Flagstaff, Arizona.

As NASAdiscovers significant new NEOs it names and tracks them, and then reports theiractual closest approach distances to Earth once those closest approach distanceshave occurred. Note that these data are reported only for objects of sufficientsize to be named and tracked by NASA; they exclude the large number of smallmeteorites that strike the Earth?s atmosphere every day and harmlessly ablate inthe atmosphere.

Recently, sixty-sixNASA-tracked NEOs reached their closest approach to Earth between January 3,2014 and February 11, 2014 (including only objects that came within 0.1 astronomicalunit of Earth). Of these, the closest came within 0.3 lunar distances fromEarth, and 13 came within 0.5 lunar distances. This question asks what theclosest approach reported by NASA will be for all NEOs that reach their closestapproach to Earth between April1st and May 30th 2014.

NASA reportsactual closest approach data for NEOs here:?http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/neo_caMore can belearned about NASA?s NEO program here:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/index.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/30/2014

Resolution Source

NASA reportsup-to-date closest approach data on the webpage http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/neo_ca, and this question will beresolved by evaluating the closest approach for the 60-day period of August 2ndto September 30th 2014 on September 30, 2014.

Fine Print

The range of possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the closest near Earth object is 1.00 LD, the "between 1.00 and 4.00 lunar distances" range will be deemed correct.
short_name: Near Earth object closest approach, Part II

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Illinois?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Illinois, 41.2% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -10.4% from 2011 (51.6%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 40.3%, the "40.3%-43.7%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will a lithium anode lithium electrolyte battery reach a coulombic efficiency of at least 99.9 percent for more than 150 cycles by January 1, 2017?
question_text:
• The wide-spread lithium electrolyte batteries do not have lithium anodes because lithium anodes grow dendrites that reach out and short-circuit the battery. Hence why lithium commercial batteries have anodes made of other materials such as silicon.
  • A pure lithium anode would provide a higher energy density than current designs because of its highest specific capacity (3,860?mAh?g?1) and the lowest anode potential of all.
  • Zheng et al have gotten closer with a design that ?coat[s] the lithium metal anode with a monolayer of interconnected amorphous hollow carbon nanospheres helps isolate the lithium metal depositions and facilitates the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase. [They] show that lithium dendrites do not form up to a practical current density of 1?mA?cm?2. The Coulombic efficiency improves to ?99% for more than 150 cycles. This is significantly better than the bare unmodified samples, which usually show rapid Coulombic efficiency decay in fewer than 100 cycles.?
Links and Sources
  • Zheng, G., et al., Interconnected hollow carbon nanospheres for stable lithium metal anodes. Nat Nano, 2014 http://www.nature.com/nnano/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nnano.2014.152.html
  • Pure Lithium in Battery May Generate More Powerful Battery http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/pure-lithium-in-battery-may-generate-more-powerful-battery/
  • coulombic efficiency http://pvcdrom.pveducation.org/BATTERY/effic.htm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

The coulombic efficiency = the number of charges that enter the battery during charging / the number that can be extracted from the battery during discharging.

name: When will the Bitcoin blockchain first register over 150,000 transactions in a single day?
question_text:
Bitcoin is?a peer-to-peer cryptographic currency that issues new money and tracks transactions without a central authority.?
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Bitcoin

The blockchain is a transaction database shared by all nodes participating in a system based on the Bitcoin protocol. A full copy of a currency's block chain contains every transaction ever executed in the currency. With this information, one can find out how much value belonged to each address at any point in history.?Every block contains a hash of the previous block. This has the effect of creating a chain of blocks from the genesis block to the current block. Each block is guaranteed to come after the previous block chronologically because the previous block's hash would otherwise not be known. Each block is also computationally impractical to modify once it has been in the chain for a while because every block after it would also have to be regenerated. These properties are what make double-spending of bitcoins very difficult. The block chain is the main innovation of Bitcoin.
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Blockchain

A Bitcoin transaction is a a signed section of data that is broadcast to the networkand collected into blocks. It typically references previous transaction(s) anddedicates a certain number of bitcoins from it to one or more new public key(s)(Bitcoin address).
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Transaction

Relevant articles:
  • This virtual globe shows (almost) every Bitcoin transaction and freshly minted block in real-time?
  • Mt. Gox Halts All Transactions in New Bitcoin Setback?
  • Cryptocalypse now: Bitcoin's issue with 'transaction malleability'?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/01/2015

Resolution Source

The Blockchain.info measure of number of transactions per day will be consulted to resolve the question.

Fine Print

A blockchain transaction will be considered "registered" if it is counted by the official blockchain.info measure: https://blockchain.info/charts/n-transactions?timespan=all&showDataPoints=false&daysAverageString=1&show_header=true&scale=0&address=

name: MH370 search: How many days after the Australian contracted search begins, will MH370 wreckage be found?
question_text:
Malaysia and Australia agreed that Australia will lead the search for MH370, which?makes Australia responsible for the contracting of the commercial services for the search efforts. On 04-JUN-2014, the Australian Government via ATSB?published?a Request for Tender for services relating to the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.?

  • AUS Tender: Request for Tender for Provision for Services relating to the Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
  • RFT No. 570-04:?Request for Tender for Provision for Services relating to the Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
The close date for bids is 30-JUN-2014. At some point, the winner will be announced, the?contract will be awarded, and the?contracted search will?begin. ?Day 0 is the day the contracted search begins, so it is possible -- however unlikely -- that wreckage will be found sooner.

If MH370 wreckage is found before or on?Day 0, this resolves as "0". ?If wreckage is not found by Day 400, this resolves as "400".?

Scaled Question

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. ?Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units (days). ?Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. ?As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. ?

Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. ?Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move a binary question exactly to 0% or 100%.
To maximize your own expected gain, you should move the forecast towards your own estimate of the expected value. ?So if the question is how many heads will be observed on 100 tosses of a fair coin, you should move the estimate towards 50. ?Note that you should also do that if the tosses are going to be with either a double-headed or double-tailed coin, but you don't know which.

Question writers try to set the range to cover at least 90% of envisioned resolutions. ?However, it is known that people's 90% ranges only contain the true value about 50% of the time, so it will be interesting to see if our guidelines help writers be better calibrated.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved based on corroborated information between the Malaysian, Australian and Chinese governments. All governments must acknowledge the wreckage is in fact from MH370 in order for the question to resolve to the appropriate day. Should there be variance as to the days in which the governments share wreckage finding information,?the question will resolve to the day in which the specified wreckage was found, not the day information was delivered by the last of the three governments.?

Fine Print

* "MH370 Wreckage" is defined as at least 10% of the plane's airframe (wings, tail, fuselage) OR the black boxes. It includes any intact location of the plane. It excludes isolated smaller debris, floating or washed up on shore, unless the debris contains the black boxes. The found parts must be positively identified as from MH370. * The "find" occurs when there is official identification that the candidate find is from MH370. It will likely be at least a couple of days after initial contact. In the event of a remote detection (radar, sonar) which cannot be investigated within 4 weeks, an official declaration that it is >95% likely to be MH370 will suffice as a "find".

name: The Keck Institute for Space studies recently called for a prize for a maneuverable airship that can stay aloft at an altitude above 20 km for at least 20 hours while carrying a payload of at least 20 kg. Will a group develop such an airship by 2020?
question_text:
• Airships (dirigibles) are lighter-than-air aircraft that can navigate under their own power. Possibly the most famous airship, the Hindenburg, was filled with hydrogen that burned in 1937.?? Airships were popular in the early 1900s, but declined in popularity after disasters such as the Hindenburg. Helium is used now making them much safer.
  • While large-scale passenger applications were suspended in the mid-1900s, development focused on military applications for surveillance until resource issues diverted R&D funds from airships. However, recently non-defense-related attention returned to airships as low-carbon methods for transporting goods, as carriers for telescopes to scan the skies, and as instrument carriers to measure the atmosphere. Airships have high spatial and temporal resolution, daily to seasonal coverage, and local to regional spatial coverage.
  • In Febuary 2014, the Keck Institute for Space Studies published Airships: A New Horizon for Science, a report that reviewed ?the potential of a variety of airships currently operable or under development to serve as observatories and science instrumentation platforms for a range of space, atmospheric and Earth science.? The authors ?found considerable scientific value in both low altitude (< 40 kft) and high altitude (> 60 kft) airships across a wide spectrum of space, atmospheric, and Earth science programs.? Therefore, the authors call for a prize ?for the development of a maneuverable, station-keeping, stratospheric airship, which can stay aloft at an altitude above 65 kft (20 km) for at least a full diurnal cycle (>20 hours) while carrying a science payload of at least 20 kg in mass? as part of a roadmap to stratospheric airship observatories.
Links and sources
  • Airships: A New Horizon for Science? http://kiss.caltech.edu/study/airship/final-report.pdf
  • The flying bum! 300ft-long 'airship' unveiled in Britain is the world's longest aircraft http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2570118/Worlds-longest-aircraft-revealed-300ft-long-a...
  • http://kiss.caltech.edu/workshops/airship2013/presentations/smith.pdf
  • http://www.defenseinnovationmarketplace.mil/resources/Final_LTA_report.pd

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/01/2020

Resolution Source

Press release or other official announcement from company or research group.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

An airship can be a rigid, semi-rigid, or non-rigid lighter-than-air vehicles that can generate their own thrust for maneuvers.

name: Will an announcement of the discovery of an exoplanet using the optical vortex coronagraph method occur in 2015?
question_text:
An optical vortex is a zero of an optical field - a point of zero intensity. An optical vortex is also known as a screw dislocation or phase singularity. It is the foundation of a vortex coronagraph, a method designed to block out the direct light from a star so that nearby objects ? which otherwise would be hidden in the star's bright glare ? can be resolved. This method can be used to find exoplanets, as detailed in 2010 by Serabyn et al. in a paper that described ?the potential of small space telescopes aiming at? high-contrast exoplanet observation?.

Sources and links

  • Optical vortex http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_vortex
  • Serabyn, E., D. Mawet, and R. Burruss, The Potential of Small Space Telescopes for Exoplanet Observations. Space Telescopes and Instrumentation 2010: Optical, Infrared, and Millimeter Wave, 2010. 7731: p. 7. http://proceedings.spiedigitallibrary.org/proceeding.aspx?articleid=749981
  • Astronomical demonstration of an optical vortex coronagraph. http://www.opticsinfobase.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-16-14-10200
  • The Terrestrial Planet Finder coronagraph: technology and mission design studies. http://spie.org/Publications/Proceedings/Paper/10.1117/12.551539

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An official press release from the researcher?s institution or funding agency or a paper published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: When will a fully autonomous (self-driving) car made by a major auto maker drive more than 60 miles in the United States?
question_text:
Predicted since the 1930s, the advent of driverless cars has promised to solve problems of traffic congestion and vehicle-related accidents by removing the human element from passenger car operation. Google has an active research program in driverless cars, and as the concept of truly driverless cars has started to seem more achievable, U.S. Department of Transportation's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) announced a new policy concerning vehicle automation in May of 2013. NHTSA?s policy divides vehicle technologies into five categories: No automaton (Level 0); Function-specific Automation (Level 1), Combined Function Automation (Level 2), Limited Self-Driving Automation (Level 3); Full Self-Driving Automation (Level 4), with driverless cars falling into Levels 3 and 4. According to NHTSA Google?s current prototype would be a level three automated vehicle.

Last year (2013) Mercedes-Benz S500?s Intelligent Drive research vehicle drove roughly 60 miles without any input from the driver, making the company the first? major automotive manufacturer to demonstrate one of their vehicle?s ability to effectively navigate both urban and interurban roads without driver input. Many other companies such as Ford, BMW, Nissan, and GM are testing and offering semi-autonomous driving features on their cars.

Links and sources

  • Autonomous cars could be on the road by 2018, CEO says http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/2014/06/autonomous-cars-could-be-on-the-road-by-2018-ceo-says.html
  • Frankfurt Auto Show: Mercedes shows off fully autonomous S-Class, production cars coming by 2020 http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/2014/06/autonomous-cars-could-be-on-the-road-by-2018-ceo-says.html.
  • Driverless Cars Are Further Away Than You Think http://www.technologyreview.com/featuredstory/520431/driverless-cars-are-further-away-than-you-think/
  • http://www.autosaur.com/car-brands-complete-list/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Official announcement by the company

Fine Print

Self-driving, driverless, and automated passenger cars are synonymous terms. ?In order for this question to resolve, the car used to determine the resolution must be level 3 autonomous or higher, as defined by NHTSA.For this question to resolve to yes at a particular date, the whole trip must take place from start to finish without any input from the driver. The car must be made by a major automotive manufacturer, not a third-party R&D center.

name: Will new data demonstrating the potential of magnetic mirror confinement's potential to generate nuclear fusion be made public by March 31, 2015??
question_text:
The concept of magnetic-mirror plasma confinement was proposed in the mid-1950s.?The first small-scale open magnetic plasma trap machine ("probkotron") was built in 1959 at the Budker institute of Nuclear Physics in Novosibirsk, Russia.?By the late 1960s, magnetic mirror confinement was considered a viable technique for producing fusion energy. In the United States, ?fforts were initially funded under the United States Atomic Energy Commissions' Project Sherwood. A machine design was first published in 1967.?

However, the concept has a number of technical challenges including maintaining the non-Maxwellian velocity distribution. This meant that instead of many high energy ions hitting one another, the ion energy spread out into a bell curve. The ions then thermalized, leaving most of the material too cold to fuse. Collisions also scattered the charged particles so much that they could not be contained. Lastly, velocity space instabilities contributed to the escape of the plasma.

Recently, Lockheed Martin has announced?its project focused on the?construction of fusion reactors using magnetic mirror confinement to contain the reaction.?This announcement has been met with?skepticism?from the scientific community. This pressure may result the release of research to prove the concept.?

For more information:

  • http://phys.org/news85222065.html
  • https://cosmosmagazine.com/technology/lockheed%E2%80%99s-fusion-project-breaking-new-ground

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: Will the use of nanoparticles as catalysts to split water in order to produce hydrogen fuel be reported before the end of 2015?
question_text:
Chemists from Berkeley Lab's Materials?Science Division recently published?a study?using bimetallic nanparticles of gold and copper as catalysts for?carbon dioxide reduction. The scientists expect the effects they observed during the experiment to be?relevant?in a wide range of applications,?notably other areas of catalysis?such as hydrogen evolution and oxygen reduction reactions.

  • On the road to artificial photosynthesis: Study reveals key catalytic factors in carbon dioxide reduction:?http://phys.org/news/2014-09-road-artificial-photosynthesis-reveals-key.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

A paper?will be published?in a high profile technical publication such as Nature/Natural Communication, where bimetallic nanoparticle catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction?were reported:?http://www.nature.com/ncomms/index.html
short_name: Water splitting catalysts for hydrogen fuel

name: What will be the average rating of the top 10 chess players in the world on JAN 01 2016?
question_text:
2700chess.com?includes players with ratings over 2699.9, and?publishes updated chess ratings typically in less than one hour after the conclusion of the relevant games. According to their site, the following image will reflect their current info:

More information about chess ratings can be found at the World Chess Federation (FIDE)


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The outcome of this question will be resolved by taking the average of the top 10 rated chess players?based on the ratings posted by 2700chess.com on JAN 01 2016. Please note that this question refers specifically to the average 'classical time control rating' of the players, and not their rapid or blitz rating.
short_name: Chess top 10 average rating on JAN 01 2016
