name: On June 2014, what will be the geographic region of the Top 500 winner?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved "Other" if the TOP500 list compiled in June 2014 awards the #1 ranking to a geographic region?other than the 4 specified, otherwise the question will be resolved to one of the given 4 geographic regions. Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

name: On November 2014, what will be the Top 500 performance share by cores per socket?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The November? 2014? ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conferencee is scheduled to occur between November 16, 2014 ? November 21, 2014.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by cores per socket, and you think 8 core/socket machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust the chances of 8 core/socket machines towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

name: How many days in May 2014 will tree pollen concentration levels measure 'high' or 'very high' in Chicago, Illinois?
question_text:
• The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (AAAAI) is a professional organization with more than 6,800 members in the United States, Canada, and 72 other countries. This membership includes allergist/immunologists, other medical specialists, allied health and related healthcare professionals - all with a special interest in the research and treatment of allergic and immunologic diseases.
  • The National Allergy Bureau (NAB) is the section of the AAAAI?s Aeroallergen Network responsible for reporting current pollen and mold spore levels.The Aeroallergen Network is comprised of pollen and spore counting stations staffed primarily by AAAAI member volunteers who generously donate their time and expertise. The NAB currently provides the most accurate and reliable pollen and mold levels from approximately 79 counting stations throughout the United States, one counting station in Canada, and six counting stations in Argentina. The stations use air sampling equipment to collect airborne pollen and spores which are then examined microscopically. This information is also used for research to aid in the diagnosis, treatment and management of allergic diseases.Pollen counts from the NAB stations are based on actual counts, which reflect the real day to day weather events. Predicted counts reported on many websites may be based on pollen data from previous years and general weather forecasts.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/07/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on data reported by the?AAAAI NAB Pollen and Mold Report/Calendar of Data for the month of May 2014, which can be found here:?http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=AllergenCalendar&stationid=147&qsFullDate=05/06/2014

Fine Print

The NAB pollen levels were developed using the NAB Scale, which can be found here: http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=reading_charts3&statid=147.The concentrations in the chart were statistics from all certified counting sites.

The concentrations were translated into levels based on the following:
?- Low levels are concentrations that are less than the median or 50th percentile (i.e. half the counts were below the median.)
- Moderate levels are concentrations that fall between the 50th and 75th percentile
- High levels fall between the 75th and 99th percentile
- Very high levels are above the 99th percentile (99% of the counts are below this level)

"Chicago, IL" refers to data collected from the NAB pollen count station in 'Illinois - Chicago Area (Melrose Park)'

name: Hitachi plans to offer a high density glass-based storage medium, able to store thousands of times more data than a DVD for millions of years. Will glass-based storage, capable of holding at least 1TB of data, be commercially available by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Japanese electronics giant?Hitachi, Ltd.?has said it may be able to bring to market by 2015 a glass-based data storage medium that is high density, storing 40MB of data per square inch, highly heat and water resistant, and capable of holding data for hundreds of millions of years. ?Hitachi developed a technology for the semi-perpetual storage of digital data in fused silica glass, in collaboration with the laboratory at the Graduate School of Engineering, Kyoto University. ?The data is recorded using a laser, and can be read using an optical microscope.?

Using nanostructured glass, scientists at the University of Southampton have experimentally demonstrated the recording and retrieval processes of five dimensional digital data by femtosecond laser writing. ?Data written to the ?Superman memory? crystal has the potential to store a staggering 360 terabytes of data (equivalent to 75,000 DVDs) on a standard-sized disc, thermal stability up to 1000?C, and could remain intact for a million years, virtually unlimited lifetime data storage. The data-storage technique uses a laser to alter the optical properties of fused quartz at the nanoscale.

Additional articles:
Hitachi targets 2015 for glass-based data storage that lasts 100 million years

Data Saved in Quartz Glass Might Last 300 Million Years

5D 'Superman memory crystal' heralds unlimited lifetime data storage

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Hitachi, Ltd news release (http://www.hitachi.com/New/cnews/index.html)?
Scientific American (http://www.scientificamerican.com/)?
[IOP] Physics World (http://physicsworld.com/)

Fine Print

Commercially available means offered for sale to the public.

name: When will the Bailiwick of Jersey have over 50 companies that accept Bitcoin as a form of payment?
question_text:
Treasury Minister Phillip Ozouf and the Bit.Coin Campaign Group are aiming to make the Bailiwick of Jersey the world's first 'Bitcoin Island.'? Their goal is not just to have companies offer Bitcoin as an alternative form of payment, but to also create an entire banking sector in the Island of Jersey based on the Bitcoin cryptocurrency.?

Although there requires a number of legal and financial decisions to be made to implement an entire banking sector based on Bitcoins, there are currently 12 companies as of June 2014 in the Bailiwick of Jersey that accept Bitcoins.? This question asks when will 50 or more companies in Jersey offer Bitcoins as a form of payment.

Relevant Links:

  • Tax Haven Jersey Now Wants to Become 'Bitcoin Island'
  • 'Bitcoin Isle' Might Be Next on Jersey's Docket
  • Jersey Group in Campaign to Create 'Bitcoin Isle'

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when 50 or more registered companies in the Bailiwick of Jersey accept Bitcoin as a form of payment.? This will be verified by the Bitcoin Friendly Companies Map at the Bit.coin.je campaign website.

Fine Print

The Bailiwick of Jersey is a country off the coast of Normandy, France which consists of the Island of Jersey and a number of other uninhabited islands.

name: Will a cocktail of genes able to reprogram human adult cells into pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) be reported in a scientific journal before the end of 2015?
question_text:
Researchers working at Whitehead Institute, together with scientists from?the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, have developed a new cocktail of genes that?can?effectively coax adult mouse cells to become pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). Using bioinformatic analysis of a network of 48 genes key to the reprogramming process, the team designed a new combination of genes - Sall4, Nanog, Esrrb, and Lin28 (SNEL). Roughly 80% of SNEL colonies made from mouse cells were of high quality and passed the most stringent pluripotency test currently available, the tetraploid complementation assay.?

However, for all of its promise, the current version of SNEL seems unable to reprogram human cells, which are generally more difficult to manipulate than mouse cells.
  • New reprogramming factor cocktail produces therapy-grade induced pluripotent stem cell: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/08/140828165908.htm
  • The developmental potential of iPSCs is greatly influenced by reprogramming factor selection: http://www.cell.com/cell-stem-cell/abstract/S1934-5909(14)00299-9

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The result?may?be?published in?leading stem cell journals such as Cell Stem Cell?http://www.cell.com/cell-stem-cell/home, where the development of SNEL from mouse cells?was reported.

Information may?also be available?from Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research?http://wi.mit.edu/research

Fine Print

Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) are adult cells reprogrammed back to an embryonic stem cell-like state. They hold the potential to cure damaged nerves, regrow limbs and organs, and perfectly model a patient's particular disease.

name: When will a method that has been demonstrated to store qubit (units of quantum information) superpositional states indefinitely at room temperature with less than 50 percent data loss be published in a peer-reviewed journal?
question_text:
Several hurdles must be overcome before quantum computing becomes a reality. One major challenge is the storage of quantum data?qubits. Qubits are extremely unstable, and currently require very low temperatures to retain a stable state. A 2011 experiment was able to store qubits for 180 seconds at cryogenic temperatures. However, a subsequent experiment reported in November of 2013 that it?was able to store qubits for 3 hours at cryogenic temperatures and 39 minutes at room temperature by using charged phosphorus donors in purified silicon (previous attempts at storing qubits had used neutral donors). The room-temperature-qubits needed to be refrozen in order for their data to be read, and only 37 percent of the qubits retained their state during the process.

The ability to store qubits in a stable state at room temperature indefinitely would represent a massive step forward in quantum computing.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Resolution Criteria

Resolution Sources

Scientific publications, such as Nature, as well as mainstream news outlets would likely cover such a breakthrough in quantum computing.

Fine Print

'Room temperature?, in this case, is any temperature above 298 K (24.85 C), as defined in the paper:

Saeedi, Kamyar, et al. "Room-Temperature Quantum Bit Storage Exceeding 39 Minutes Using Ionized Donors in Silicon-28." Science 342.6160 (2013): 830-833.
Standard time definitions:
  • 'Before' means up until the start (00:00:00) of the date.
  • 'Between' means from the start (00:00:00) of the first date up until the start of the second date (23:59:59 of the previous day).
  • 'After' means after the end (23:59:59) of the date.

Useful Information and Links

  • http://www.theverge.com/2013/11/14/5104668/qubits-stored-for-39-minutes-quantum-computer-new-record?
  • http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-24934786 http://www.sfu.ca/sfunews/stories/2013/quantum-computers-one-step-closer-to-reality.html
  • Saeedi, Kamyar, et al. "Room-Temperature Quantum Bit Storage Exceeding 39 Minutes Using Ionized Donors in Silicon-28." Science 342.6160 (2013): 830-833.
  • Steger, M., et al. "Quantum information storage for over 180 s using donor spins in a 28Si ?semiconductor vacuum? Science 336.6086 (2012): 1280-1283.
  • Qubit. Wikipedia. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qubit
  • Morton, J. J. L., A. M. Tyryshkin, et al. (2008). "Solid-state quantum memory using the 31P nuclear spin." NATURE 455(7216): 1085-1088.

name: Will F3 LLC?s lab-on-a-chip, engineered to detect MRSA quickly and cheaply without growing a culture, successfully complete their 510(k) clinical trials by 1 Jan 2016?
question_text:
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a bacterium that is resistant to several antibiotics, making it hard to treat in humans.? It is important to diagnose MRSA early as it is resistant to several ?first line? antibiotics.? However, diagnosis requires a multiple day lab culture that is expensive, which may make doctors reluctant to order the test. A viable alternative to cultures is a so-called lab-on-a-chip that integrates laboratory tests on a single chip.

F3 has licensed technology and developed a lab-on-a-chip (also called a biochip). The device isolates the DNA from a sample of the wound. The DNA flows through a nanofluidic channel where it comes into contact with carbon nanotubes which have been functionalized with complementary DNA. An electric field is applied to the probes and if the MRSA DNA binds to the complementary DNA, the electric field changes, resulting in a ?positive? reading from the biochip. The company claims that the biochip can screen patients in 2 hours at a 10 times lesser cost.

?F3 entered 510(k) trials for the biochip (technically called NESDEP IU) in 2013.

Links and sources

  • F Cubed?s Biochip vs. the Hospital Superbug http://spectrum.ieee.org/biomedical/diagnostics/f-cubeds-biochip-vs-the-hospital-superbug
  • F3 http://www.fcubed.biz/Medical-Diagonostics
  • Frost & Sullivan Applauds F Cubed for its Game-Changing MRSA Screener, the NESDEP IU http://www.frost.com/prod/servlet/press-release.pag?docid=291741274

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

Press release or other official announcement from the company.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.


Fine Print

510(k) is a premarket submission made to the FDA to demonstrate that the device to be marketed is at least as safe and effective, that is, substantially equivalent, to a legally marketed device that is not subject to pre-market approval (PMA). Submitters must compare their device to one or more similar legally marketed devices and support their substantial equivalency claims. http://hub.ucsf.edu/content/what-501kIn molecular biology, biochips are essentially miniaturized laboratories that can perform hundreds or thousands of simultaneous biochemical reactions.

keywords: chemistry, employment, jobs, unemployment, American Chemical Society
name: What will the unemployment rate for ACS chemists be in 2014?
question_text:
Each year, the American Chemical Society reports on the unemployment rate for ACS chemists in the Salary and Employment survey.? Results are based upon a comprehensive survey of ACS members (totalling more than 161,000).? Analyses of the annual data are published in Chemical & Engineering News.?In 2011, ACS chemists unemployment reached an all-time high of 4.7%, and has since declined to 3.5% in 2013.? The annual survey and publication of the results dates back more than 20 years.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

9/30/2014

Resolution Source

The official record of these results will be Chemical & Engineering News.?It is expected that the results will be published in September, 2014.

Fine Print

"ACS chemists" are those chemists who complete and return the 2014 ACS Salary and Employment survey."Unemployment" is as defined by the ACS, and does not include underemployment.

categories: Business of Science,Computational Sciences,Information Systems,Engineered Technologies,Transportation
keywords: unmanned military vehicles, autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence, autonomous ground technology
name: US Defense contractors are working to bring autonomous ground vehicle technology to the battlefront to reduce risking human lives. When will the US Army debut unmanned self-driving military vehicles in a logistical convoy operation?
question_text:
US Defense contractors Oshkosh Defense and Lockheed Martin are working to bring autonomous ground vehicle technology to US military forces on the battlefront. With this technology, US military can carry cargo with lesser personnel and reduce threats to human lives. But with an increased number of unmanned vehicles, it would appear to enemy forces like there are more personnel; thus discouraging potential attacks.

Currently, Oshkosh?s autonomous driving technology called TerraMax, equipped with radar and LIDAR, can electrically control engine speed, braking, and steering in addition to autonomously controlling a central tire inflation systems and driveline locks to maneuver in deep mud or sand. These systems are not entirely autonomous because an operator can give orders to the unmanned vehicle when it comes into contact with obstacles in its path. Controlled by operators who can be farther back in a convoy, these unmanned vehicles can lead a convoy in enemy territory.? Operators can set vehicle speed, following distance, access a live map of the entire convoy, and obtain diagnostics on the vehicles. Oshkosh has spent three years working with the Marine Corp Warfighting Lab and the Office of Naval Research to get the technology ready for use in battlefronts.
Lockheed Martin took part in a Capabilities Advancement Demonstration in January 2014 along with other contractors to display the promising progress in this work.

For more information:
http://www.wired.com/2014/06/oshkosh-autonomous-minesweeping/
http://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/military-robots/lockheeds-robotic-trucks-pass-real-world...
http://spectrum.ieee.org/cars-that-think/robotics/military-robots/robot-minesweeper-vehicle-demoed-i...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

An announcement or news release by the US armed forces or a firm that fits these autonomous systems in unmanned military vehicles in a convoy operation. Announcements by industry analysts in the technology news media. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first. For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

The question is looking for the first use of ground-based autonomous driving technology in unmanned Army vehicles in a supply or logistics mission based convoy operation. These vehicles would be considered to be at least at Level 3 on the NHSTA scale "Vehicles at this level of automation enable the driver to cede full control of all safety-critical functions under certain traffic or environmental conditions and in those conditions to rely heavily on the vehicle to monitor for changes in those conditions requiring transition back to driver control."

keywords: Flu, Region 9, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 9 (AZ, CA, HI, NV, AS, MP, FM, GU, MH, PW)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 9' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 9 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 9 is comprised of Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, American Samoa, Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Guam, Marshall Islands, and Republic of Palau.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 9 is 2.7%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will the drug SmartInsulin enter Phase I human trials by December 31, 2014?
question_text:
Six million people in the US have diabetes that must be controlled by insulin. These diabetics check their blood multiple times a day and calculate the amount of insulin needed to control their blood sugar. In the early 2000s Todd Zion created an insulin-lectin gel to control diabetes. The engineered molecule automatically responds to changes in blood-sugar level. When blood sugars are high then the modified insulin-lectin molecule binds to extra sugar allowing the insulin to work by binding to cell receptors. When blood sugars are normal the insulin-lectin molecules binds to itself preventing the molecule from binding to cell receptors.

In 2010 Merck acquired Zion?s start-up for his drug Smart Insulin (SmartInsulin). They have be further developing the technology and recently several publications have reported that the drug will enter human trails by the end of 2014. As of November 13, 2014, clinicaltrails.gov does not report any clinical trails for the drug Smart Insulin (SmartInsulin) or Merk?s reported name for the drug, L-490.

Links and sources
Why Are So Few Blockbuster Drugs Invented Today? http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/16/magazine/why-are-there-so-few-new-drugs-invented-today.html?_r=0

SmartCells CEO Reflects on Strategy Leading to $500M Exit with Merck? http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2010/12/03/smartcells-ceo-reflects-on-strategy-leading-to-500m-exit-wi...

Merck to Buy Biotech Company Developing Diabetes Drug
http://online.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703865004575649270661657104

keywords: wave energy, renewable energy, wave park, electricity
name: Will a wave farm, an installation to generate electricity from wave energy, on the west coast of the United States begin to produce electricity and sell it to the power grid by the end of 2017?
question_text:
The Electric Power Research Institute estimated that?wave energy along the United States? coastline could produce?1,170 terawatt-hours per year, enough to supply half of the United States? annual electricity demand. Another study looking at the cost of integrating wave energy into the Pacific Northwest?s current power grid found that wave power would only cost $1.09 per kilowatt, compared to the $1.20 per kilowatt for wind. ?

However, the lack of willingness to invest in wave and tidal energy projects has halted the construction of wave parks in the Pacific Northwest over the last few years.?In 2011, Scotland-based Aquamarine Power gave up its hopes to tap Oregon?s abundant wave-energy source, citing regulatory hurdles. In March 2014, a wave park project?from Ocean Power Technologies to float 100 energy-producing?buoys off the coast,?the Reedsport OPT Wave Park Plan?sunk under soaring costs. At that time, it was the only wave energy project that have?a license issued by the??Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC)?in the United States.

Currently there are two?wave park projects in California that have?been issued HydroKinetic Preliminary Permits by FERC. Under the preliminary permits, Houston-based electric utility?company?Dynergy will build the?Estero Bay Wave Park and the Point Estero Wave Park at Morro Bay, California.? Dynergy's plan is?to start generate electricity for sale in the commercial testing phase of the project, after the completion of?the initial?demonstration phase.?
? ?
For more information:

  • Wave Power Could Supply Half the U.S. With Cheap Electricity?Here?s Why It Doesn't:?http://news.yahoo.com/wave-power-could-supply-half-u-cheap-electricity-233654273.html
  • Reedsport OPT Wave Park Plans Terminated:?http://mhk.pnl.gov/tethys-stories/reedsport-opt-wave-park-plans-terminated
  • FDRC HydroKinetic Projects:?http://www.ferc.gov/industries/hydropower/gen-info/licensing/hydrokinetics.asp
  • Estero Bay Wave Park:?http://mhk.pnl.gov/ferc-sites/estero-bay-wave-park
  • Piont Estero Wave park:?http://mhk.pnl.gov/ferc-sites/point-estero-wave-park

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

It is also likely to be reported?in?mainstream news and popular science outlets.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

A wave farm, also called wave power farm or wave energy park, is a collection of machines in the same location and used for the generation of wave power electricity.Any project must be built under the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's HydroKinetic-Wave Permit.

keywords: Claytronics, Programmable Matter, Carnegie Mellon, Intel Labs
name: Carnegie Mellon and Intel are collaborating on programmable-matter claytronic atoms, or catoms, that can assemble into larger structures. When will the team develop a millimeter-scale catom prototype that can be programmed to move in 3 dimensions?
question_text:
The IEEE Spectrum 50th Anniversary Issue predicts what the future will be like in 2064, 50 years from 2014, based on eight current technologies.? One of these technology domains is Programmable Matter.? It envisions a future in which a type of matter can transfigure itself based on user input or autonomous sensing to create complex objects.

In general, there are currently two approaches to developing programmable matter:? Engineering and Chemistry.? The Engineering approach is essentially to create a system made from tiny, nanosize computers that reconfigure themselves to whatever object.? The Chemistry approach is to create molecules or nanoscale particles that can self assemble into complex forms or objects.? Carnegie Mellon in collaboration with Intel Labs are developing a form of programmable matter termed Claytronics.? Claytronics uses reconfigurable nanoscale robots (termed claytronics atoms or 'catoms') to form objects.? These catoms would be nanoscale robots that have the ability to move, stick together, communicate, change color, and compute their location in relation to other catoms, effectively creating different objects once millions of catoms are joined together.

The Claytronics Project Team also has two research domains:? developing the hardware of the claytronic atom (or catom) itself, and developing software for the catom that can manage the shaping of millions of catoms into a 3D form.? In terms of hardware they currently have macroscale prototypes that deal with specific aspects of catom technology including planar catoms, stochastic catoms, cubes, and a millimeter scale prototype.? Currently, the millimeter scale prototype moves in one dimension (motion along a straight line).? This question asks when a millimeter scale prototype will be made that moves in three dimensions?

Relevant Links:
  • IEEE Spectrum 50th Anniversary Issue (June 2014)
  • Infinitely Malleable Materials:? People Will Conjure Objects as Easily as We Now Play Music or Movies
  • Carnegie Mellon Claytronics Project Page
  • Carnegie Mellon Claytronics Concept Video
  • Claytronics Discovery Channel Feature Story

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when a millimeter scale catom prototype that moves in three dimensions is developed by the Carnegie Mellon-Intel Labs Claytronics Team.? This will be verified by the Carnegie Mellon Claytronics Project Page.

Fine Print

A 'millimeter scale catom prototype' is defined to be a catom prototype that is under 1 cm (10 millimeters or smaller). A prototype that moves in three dimensions means that the catom can move in the x, y, and z coordinates. Note also that the answer choices include the first day of the year until the last. For example, '2016' includes January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016.

name: Recently researchers demonstrated the first high-brightness infrared and visible electroluminescence from solution-processed organometal halide perovskites. Will a perovskite-based LED diode laser be demonstrated by 2017?
question_text:
Organometal halide perovskites are easily synthesized through solution processing. Perovskites dissolve in common solvents and assemble to form perovskite crystals when dried, making them appealing in comparison with expensive high-brightness light-emitting diodes that typically rely on expensive high-temperature and high-vacuum processes. Perovskite LEDs are made when substrates are spin-coated with the organometal halide solution to produce a thin layer of perovskite, which ?sets up conditions for the electron-hole capture process to produce light emission? as the lead author explained here. This method may allow large-scale LED applications that are not feasible under current LED process methods that require high heat and vacuum conditions.

Links and sources

  • Tan, Z.-K., et al., Bright light-emitting diodes based on organometal halide perovskite. Nat Nano, 2014.
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laser_diode

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Bruce
name: What place will the Bruce Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

Info from Terri Bruce's webpage:

T.S. Eliot once wrote, ?Genuine poetry can communicate before it is understood,? and, so it is also with every cell in our body. ?How do cells communicate?? It is a fascinating question that lies at the center of many biological mysteries. Fundamental knowledge of the strategies that cells use to transmit information to their neighbors and their surrounding environment is necessary in order to understand a range of biological processes from immune responses to tissue organization and organogenesis, as well as disease progression, wound healing and regeneration. My research program focuses on investigating the principles of communication between cells as well as between cells and their microenvironment through the study of cell microvesicles. Because of their early dismissal as cellular debris, the study of microvesicles is a very new field. As such, a wide number of fundamental questions remain. Most of the research to date has been in the identification of microvesicle shedding from various normal and disease state cells and in the initial formation and exocytosis of microvesicles from these cells. In contrast, investigations into the uptake of these bodies by recipient cells and the subsequent dissemination of their contents have been limited.

In my lab, we strive to understand the fundamental pathways involved in the packaging, trafficking, and exocytosis of microvesicles by host cells and the subsequent uptake, trafficking and dissemination of microvesicle cargo by target cells.

As the manager of the Clemson Light Imaging Facility, I am also interested in developing new imaging techniques for use in a variety of experimental systems and for analysis of advanced materials.

Useful Links
  • Link to?Terri Bruce Website
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

keywords: photonic molecule, quantum computing, photonic computing
name: When will an operating photonic molecule based logic gate be reported in the scientific literature?
question_text:
In a September 2013 issue of Nature (see below), scientists reported the creation of photonic molecules, groupings of massless photons that are bonded to one another in a manner reminiscent of the way atoms bond to form molecules. Among the application areas that this discovery augurs is the creation of a quantum logic gate in the form of a photonic gate. A quantum gate requires interactions between individual quanta, and the discovery of interacting photons offers a possible mechanism for this interaction.

A quantum gate is a quantum computing circuit operating on qubits, the quantum equivalent to bits in classical computing. Qubits have 2 possible states, just as bits, though unlike bits they can exist in a superimposition of their based states, i.e. more than one state at once. Quantum gates are also reversible, meaning there is a one-to-one mapping between vectors of inputs and outputs . The resulting logic that can be implemented with quantum gates is quite distinct from classical Boolean logic and is opening new possibilities for computation.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v502/n7469/full/nature12512.html
  • http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/09/130925132323.htm
  • http://www.gizmag.com/photonic-molecules-pave-the-way-for-quantum-computers-and-lightsabers/29924/
  • http://www.ijarcsse.com/docs/papers/Volume_3/10_October2013/V3I9-0363.pdf
  • http://web.cecs.pdx.edu/~mperkows/CLASS_VHDL_99/tran888/lecture003-reversible-logic.pdf



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

A paper published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

name: Will the U.S. be the world leader in total oil production in 2015?
question_text:
In the 2013 World Energy Outlook, the International Energy Agency (IEA) projected that the U.S. would surpass Saudi Arabia in total oil production by the end of 2015. The U.S. is experiencing rapid growth in total oil production due to recent technological advances in horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, although there is uncertainty in how long this growth can be sustained.

While the WEO13 report is not freely available online, it's contents were summarized in the many news articles:

  • U.S. to Be Top Oil Producer by 2015 on Shale, IEA Says
  • U.S. to Surpass Saudi as Top Oil Producer by 2016 - IEA
  • U.S.-led Shale Boom No Long-Term Threat for OPEC's Oil - IEA
  • IEA Press Quotes page

According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), U.S. average daily total oil production increased from 7.322 million barrels per day (mbpd) in 2006 to 10.045 mbpd in 2012. Over that period, average daily oil production in Saudi Arabia increased from 10.659 mbpd to 11.717 mbpd. In 2013, U.S. oil production continued to increase to an average of 11.685 mbpd in October. Saudi Arabia averaged 11.730 mbpd in October of 2013.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The EIA provides this data, although there is a delay of several months.

Fine Print

"Total oil production" is defined to include crude oil, lease condensates, natural gas plant liquids, and other liquids. (It does not include refinery gains; if refinery gains are included, the U.S. surpassed Saudi Arabia in late 2012.)

name: Undervaccinated populations are susceptible to a strain of polio derived from a newly vaccinated person called circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus  (cVDPV).  How many cases of cVDPV will be reported between August 26, 2014 and March 3, 2015?
question_text:
In 2014, only 3 countries in the world remain polio-endemic: Nigeria, Pakistan and Afghanistan. In 1994, the WHO Region of the Americas was certified polio-free, followed by the WHO Western Pacific Region in 2000 and the WHO European Region in June 2002. On 27 March 2014, the WHO South-East Asia Region was certified polio-free, meaning that transmission of wild poliovirus has been interrupted in this bloc of 11 countries stretching from Indonesia to India. This achievement marks a significant leap forward in global eradication, with 80% of the world?s population now living in certified polio-free regions.

Vaccine-derived polioviruses (VDPVs) are rare strains of poliovirus that have genetically mutated from the strain contained in the oral polio vaccine. ??The oral polio vaccine contains a live, attenuated (weakened) vaccine-virus. When a child is vaccinated, the weakened vaccine-virus replicates in the intestine and enters into the bloodstream, triggering a protective immune response in the child. Like wild poliovirus, the child excretes the vaccine-virus for a period of six to eight weeks. Importantly, as it is excreted, some of the vaccine-virus may no longer be the same as the original vaccine-virus as it has genetically altered during replication. This is called a vaccine-derived poliovirus.

The vaccine-derived polioviruses are one reason that eradication of the polio virus is perferred. Once the virus is eradicated then vaccinations, and hence the vaccine-derived poliovidrueses, can be stopped.? Between 10 June - 9 December 2014 18 total cVDPV cases were reported.

Sources and links
  • Just one poliovirus left to go? http://www.sciencemag.org/content/346/6211/795.full?
  • Polio Eradication http://www.polioeradication.org/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/01/2015

Resolution Source

http://www.polioeradication.org/Dataandmonitoring/Poliothisweek/Circulatingvaccinederivedpoliovirus.aspx will resolve this question. The map posted during the week of March 1 ? 7 will resolve this question.?
?
For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

The dates are approximate - the map with the closest dates to the dates in the question (expected release between March 1st and 7th) will resolve this question.

name: Will a phase 2a clinical trial show that AstraZeneca's Src tyrosine kinase inhibitor, a drug original developed for cancer treatment, is effective for treating the lung disease Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)?
question_text:
Experimental drugs proven safe but perhaps not sufficiently effective in initial testing or against a first disease target may sit gathering dust on the shelves of pharmaceutical companies. An NIH-sponsored effort based on a crowdsourcing strategy to establish collaborations between industrial and academic partners to repurpose these therapeutic compounds was met with an overwhelming response and has led to clinical testing of a broad range of pilot projects. The scope of the pilot limits investigators to using the agents in their original formulation and with short period of support (2-3 years) to complete phase 1b and 2a clinical trials. It will be a few years before we know what the success rate is of phase 2a clinical trials established using this strategy.

In the initial phase, NCATS funding was awarded to nine projects in 2013, including the investigations of an AstraZeneca Src tyrosine kinase inhibitor originally developed for cancer treatment for its therapeutic uses in Alzheimer's disease and Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) treatment.

  • NIH turns to crowdsourcing to repurpose drugs:?http://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-07-nih-crowdsourcing-repurpose-drugs.html#inlRlv
  • The NIH-Industry New Therapeutic Uses Pilot Program: Demonstrating the Power of Crowdsourcing:?http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1089/drrr.2014.0006
  • New Therapeutic Uses 2013 Project Awards:?http://www.ncats.nih.gov/research/reengineering/rescue-repurpose/therapeutic-uses/projects-2013.html...
  • Project information:?http://projectreporter.nih.gov/project_info_results.cfm?aid=8599141&icde=19464013
?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

Project information and status can be found in NIH RePORT:?http://projectreporter.nih.gov/project_info_description.cfm?aid=8599141&icde=19464013
short_name: Repurposing cancer drug to treat LAM

keywords: Wind turbines, wind power, renewable energy
name: When will floating wind turbines be used in a commercial offshore wind turbine farm?
question_text:
Floating wind turbines may be viable replacements for traditional offshore wind turbines, which have fixed bottoms that are expensive to install and limit the turbine operation to relatively shallow waters (30-50 meter maximum depth). Floating wind turbines can be installed in deep waters to exploit strong and sustained offshore winds and enable off shore wind turbines to be moved out of sight of shores. The number of floating wind turbines installed around the world number is predicted to rise significantly in the next few years. However, there are still some engineering challenges to overcome as current materials used in these turbines are expensive and may not be commercially viable in currently deployed designs.

Sources and Links

  • Wikipedia on Floating Wind Turbines http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_wind_turbine
  • Floating Wind Turbines Headed for Offshore Farms http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/green-tech/wind/floating-wind-turbines-headed-for-offshore-farms

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

An official announcement from the company or consortium that deploys the floating off shore wind turbine.

Fine Print

A commercial wind farm can be anywhere in the world for this question to resolve to yes.For the purposes of this question, a commercial wind farm is defined as more than two floating wind turbines in the same location that are connected to the grid with at least 18 MW install capacity.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Strassmann & Queller
name: What place will the Strassmann & Queller Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The?Strassmanm & Queller team's strategy to win the race:

We trust in nature?s ability to create the ultimate competitor. Whether they are traversing the depths of soil to hunt the perfect morsel, or tracking a chemical signal through a synthetic maze, wild Dicty cells will crush the competition and prove that nature knows best!?

Dicty related?research going on at the?Strassmanm & Queller Lab:

Genomics.?? We have recently sequenced four new genomes of Dictyostelids, and have also resequenced 20 D. discoideum genomes. ? We are now using these to test for adaptive evolution and arms races. ?We are also looking at patterns of purifying selection to ask about Dicty in its natural environment: what kinds of bacteria is it adapted to and how often does it go through the social and sexual cycles.

Experimental evolution.?One of the advantages of a microbial system is that it is amenable to hypothesis testing using experimental evolution. Our most recent study along those lines demonstrated that altruism could be lost in as few as 30 rounds of fruiting body formation, if relatedness is sufficiently low. This provides strong support for the theory of kin selection. We are using this technique to look at a variety of other aspects of Dictyostelium behavior, and we are characterizing the newly-evolved selfish mutants.

Dictyostelium phylogenetics.?Social interactions within species have different characteristics compared to interactions between species, so it is important to know if interacting pairs belong to the same species. We have published a phylogeny of Dictyostelium discoideum and closely related clones, and are working on close relatives to this species from the neotropics.

Dictyostelium sex.?The sexual process involves meiosis, like any good eukaryote. It also involves cannibalism, a great deal of recombination, and at least four mating types. This is a rich area for exploring the interface between sociality, cheating, and sex.

Useful Links
  • Link to?Strassmann & Queller Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

name: Will the average recorded global land and ocean surface temperature in January, 2015 be the highest ever recorded?
question_text:
Since 1880, the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration (http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/)?has been collecting extensive data relating to atmospheric sciences.?As Earth's climate continues to change, the deviation from previous mean temperatures?are expected to increase.?

According to NOAA, the average global land and ocean surfaces temperature for?month of?January, 2014 was the fourth warmest on record,?54.8?F; this was 1.17?F above the 20th century average. Major news headlines report that 2014 has been a relatively mild year all in all suggesting a similar trend in 2015.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2014

name: Will ALL of the four candidates picked by the ESA?S ExoMars Landing Site Selection Workshop be included for further analysis in the official ESA working group?s list of potential landing sites?
question_text:
ExoMars is a large mission to Mars with the goal of searching for evidence of Martian life, past or present. ExoMars is currently under development by the European Space Agency (ESA) in collaboration with the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos). The agency received proposals for the following eight landing sites:
  • Coogoon Valles
  • Hypanis Vallis
  • Mawrth Vallis 1
  • Mawrth Vallis 2
  • Oxia Palus
  • Oxia Planum
  • Simud Vallis
  • Southern Isidis
On April 3, 2014, ESA announced that ?60 scientists and engineers came together 26?28 March for the first ExoMars 2018 Landing Site Selection Workshop, held at ESA's European Space Astronomy Centre near Madrid. Their task was to begin the process of drawing up a shortlist of the most suitable landing locations for ESA's first Mars rover.? From the proposed landing sites, the following four potential landing sites for the rover were shortlisted:
  • Mawrth Vallis
  • Oxia Planum
  • Hypanis Vallis
  • Oxia Palus

The ESA Landing Site Selection Working Group will recommend a final shortlist of up to four candidate sites in June 2014 for more detailed analysis.

Links and Sources
  • ESA ? robotic exploration of Mars - http://exploration.esa.int/mars/
  • Scientists favour four ExoMars landing sites http://exploration.esa.int/mars/53941-scientists-favour-four-exomars-landing-sites/
  • Proposed landing sites for ExoMars 2018 mission http://exploration.esa.int/mars/53944-proposed-landing-sites-for-exomars-2018-mission/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/01/2014

Resolution Source

European space agency http://exploration.esa.int/mars/

name: How many days in May 2014 will tree pollen concentration levels measure 'high' or 'very high' in Washington, DC?
question_text:
• The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (AAAAI) is a professional organization with more than 6,800 members in the United States, Canada, and 72 other countries. This membership includes allergist/immunologists, other medical specialists, allied health and related healthcare professionals - all with a special interest in the research and treatment of allergic and immunologic diseases.
  • The National Allergy Bureau (NAB) is the section of the AAAAI?s Aeroallergen Network responsible for reporting current pollen and mold spore levels.The Aeroallergen Network is comprised of pollen and spore counting stations staffed primarily by AAAAI member volunteers who generously donate their time and expertise. The NAB currently provides the most accurate and reliable pollen and mold levels from approximately 79 counting stations throughout the United States, one counting station in Canada, and six counting stations in Argentina. The stations use air sampling equipment to collect airborne pollen and spores which are then examined microscopically. This information is also used for research to aid in the diagnosis, treatment and management of allergic diseases.Pollen counts from the NAB stations are based on actual counts, which reflect the real day to day weather events. Predicted counts reported on many websites may be based on pollen data from previous years and general weather forecasts.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/07/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on data reported by the?AAAAI NAB Pollen and Mold Report/Calendar of Data for the month of May 2014, which can be found here:?http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=AllergenCalendar&stationid=60&qsFullDate=05/05/2014

Fine Print

The NAB pollen levels were developed using the NAB Scale, which can be found here: http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=reading_charts3&statid=147

The concentrations in the chart were statistics from all certified counting sites. The concentrations were translated into levels based on the following:

- Low levels are concentrations that are less than the median or 50th percentile (i.e. half the counts were below the median.)
- Moderate levels are concentrations that fall between the 50th and 75th percentile
- High levels fall between the 75th and 99th percentile
- Very high levels are above the 99th percentile (99% of the counts are below this level)

"Washington, DC" refers to data collected from the NAB pollen count station in 'Washington - DC (Walter Reed Army Medical Center)'

name: When will be the first reported occurrence of fraud by an individual passing off an AAM-produced item as a genuine antique of value?
question_text:
Additive Manufacturing (AM) is defined by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) as a manufacturing process in which 3D digital design data is used to build up a component in layers by depositing material. This is in stark contrast to traditional manufacturing in which material is removed from a solid block to create the product. The AM process starts by drawing a 3D model of the product on CAD software. The software takes this drawing and slices it digitally into thin cross sections. The printer is then loaded with the desired material such as metals or plastics, and uses an AM technique such as selective laser sintering (SLS) or stereolithography (SLA) to build the product layer by layer until complete. This process is being applied in industries as diverse as aviation, aerospace, automotive, medical, and others.?

Fujifilm, in partnership with the Van Gogh Museum of Amsterdam,?recently announced they had developed a new process that allowed them to?duplicate Van Gogh paintings with incredible accuracy. The process, called reliefography, uses 3D scanners and printers to duplicate the painting,?the frame, and?even the torn labels and hand written notes on the back of the canvas. The process can even mimic the exact brush strokes of the original.?This leads to the question if counterfeiters will exploit AAM technology to create antiques and sell them as original pieces.

Relevant Links:
  • 3D Printing and Scanning Can Now Produce Near Flawless Art Forgeries [Gizmodo]
  • 3D Printer Duplicates Paintings Down to the Last Brush Stroke [Endgaget]


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

This question will resolve true at the first reported occurrence of?an item produced using AAM technology is discovered to be sold or attempted to be sold, in place of a genuine antique of value (as defined in the Fine Print section). This will confirmed by reports from major antique associations?such as the Antique Dealers Association of America or by major news outlets such as CNN, New York Times, BBC, etc.

Fine Print

In this instance, "genuine antique of value" is defined as a small, high-value item such as coins, small statuettes, or heirlooms that would require expert analysis to verify its authenticity.

keywords: Magnus Carlsen, Viswanathan Anand, World Chess championship, chess rating
name: What will Magnus Carlsen's classical time control live rating be on 28th November 2014 after the completion of the World Chess Championship match in Sochi?
question_text:
The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. A variety of news sources are expected to monitor the match with immediate updates as the match evolves.

  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2014
  • http://www.fide.com

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/28/2014

Resolution Source

The resolution of this question will be based on the information provided by http://2700chess.com upon the completion of the World Chess Championship match.

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface.

Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%.

In the event the championship match does not occur or Magnus Carlsen does not participate, the question will remain open and Carlsen's rating on November 28, 2014 will be used to resolve this question.

name: Which region will have the highest growth rate in cloud computing services, measured as CAGR, from 2015 to 2017?
question_text:
Analysts such as Gartner, Forrester, and IDC are estimating the size of the cloud computing market will be anywhere from $125B to $250B by 2017. While there is broad agreement this industry segment will see significant growth, it's unclear which geographic region will experience the highest adoption rates. As of 2014, the Americas had the largest cloud computing spend but most agree this share will shrink over time.?This question seeks to understand what part of the world will adopt - and spend - the most?on cloud computing services.?

  • Here are some prognostications about what the cloud computing industry will see in 2015:?http://www.zdnet.com/forresters-2015-cloud-predictions-docker-rises-storage-pricing-war-claims-lives...
  • IDC's cloud research:?http://www.idc.com/prodserv/FourPillars/Cloud/index.jsp
  • Gartner projected growth for cloud computing by region through 2016:?http://www.forbes.com/sites/louiscolumbus/2013/02/19/gartner-predicts-infrastructure-services-will-a...?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved via reports released by major industry analysts such as Gartner, Forrester, or IDC.

Fine Print

"Cloud computing" is defined as spending on IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service), PaaS (Platform as a Service), or SaaS (Software as a Service). In cases where a precise metric is not reported we will defer to subject matter experts in the field to determine the correct answer.

keywords: RNA interference, RNAi, drug development, drug approval, nucleotide small interfering RNA, siRNA
name: Will an RNA interference-based drug be approved by the FDA by the end of 2016?
question_text:
The 2006 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded jointly to Andrew Z. Fire and Craig C. Mello for their discovery of RNA interference gene silencing by double-stranded RNA. Fire and Mello?s work followed the 2001 publication in Nature of a seminal article showing that 21-nucleotide small interfering RNA (siRNA) duplexes specifically suppress expression of endogenous and heterologous genes in different mammalian cell lines.

These discoveries have spawned an enormous amount of public and private investment in developing RNA interference (RNAi) based drugs. While no drugs have yet come to market, RNAi-based therapeutics are in Phase II and Phase III clinical trials. Overall there are about 15 RNAi-based drugs in clinical trials from several research groups and companies.

For more background, see:

  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11373684
  • http://www.technologyreview.com/featuredstory/530631/gene-silencing-drugs-finally-show-promise/
  • http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2006/
  • http://www.fiercedrugdelivery.com/story/market-research-firm-rna-based-drugs-exceed-1-billion-sales-...
  • http://zon.trilinkbiotech.com/2014/05/12/rnai-drugs/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

FDA approval of an RNA interference drug will be reported by the FDA and in the medical press.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the District of Columbia?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the District of Columbia, 57.8% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +2.8% from 2011 (55.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 56.9%, the "56.9%-60.3%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Flu, region 3, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 3 (DE, DC, MD, PA, VA, WV)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 3' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 3 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 3 is comprised of Delaware, District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 3 is 2.0%.

In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

keywords: data breach, data security, PHI, PII, identity theft, cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Will at least 6% of data breaches reported in the US by the ITRC in the first quarter of 2015 be in the banking/credit/financial sector?
question_text:
A data breach is a security incident in which sensitive, protected or confidential data is copied, transmitted, viewed, stolen or used by an individual unauthorized to do so. Data breaches may involve financial information such as credit card or bank details, personal health information (PHI), personally identifiable information (PII), trade secrets of corporations or intellectual property.?In the cyber world,?breaches also consist of the exposure of user names, emails and passwords without involving sensitive personal identifying information.? The current data of?2014 indicates?5.6% data breaches?are reported by the bank/credit/financial sector, according to a list compiled by Identity?Theft?Resource center (ITRC)?with?incidents confirmed?by various media sources?and/or notification lists from state governmental agencies. ?The ITRC list is published on Tuesday of each week throughout of the year.

  • Data breach:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_breach
  • Data breach report:?http://www.idtheftcenter.org/id-theft/data-breaches.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

ITRC 2015 Data Breach Report:?http://www.idtheftcenter.org/id-theft/data-breaches.html

Fine Print

The banking/credit/financial sector includes entities such as banks, credit unions, credit card companies, mortgage and loan brokers, financial services, investment firms and trust companies, payday lenders and pension funds.

keywords: Coronavirus, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, MERS, MERS-COV
name: Will there be a second lab-confirmed case of the coronavirus Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS or MERS-COV) identified in the United States by May 31, 2014?
question_text:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by acoronavirus?called MERS-CoV. Most people who have been confirmed to have MERS-CoV infection developed severe acute respiratory illness. They had fever, cough, and shortness of breath. About half of these people died.? The symptoms have been more severe than seasonal influenza. However, the two viruses are not known to be related or linked.??

Despite the first case being discovered in 2012, little is known about how the virus spreads to people from animal hosts.However, it is known that the virus spreads from human to human. In addition, bats?and camels?have been been found to be infected with MERS.?


So far, all the cases have been linked to countries in or near the Arabian Peninsula through residence in or travel to, indicating that modes of transmission outside of the Arabian Peninsula are through travel. Since April 2012,? lab-confirmed cases from the following countries have been identified:

  • France
  • Italy
  • Jordan
  • Kuwait
  • Oman
  • Qatar
  • Saudi Arabia
  • Tunisia
  • United Kingdom?
  • United Arab Emirates ??
  • United States (first case confirmed on May 2 by CDC)
Travel has been the primary way in which MERS-CoV has spread to people out side the Middle East.? This suggests that human infection of MERS-CoV in the United States will most likely be a result of travel.?

This virus has spread from ill people to others through close contact. On 10 November 2013, the Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia announced the detection of MERS- CoV in a specimen taken from an ill camel owned by a laboratory - confirmed case from Jeddah. This case had direct contact with the ill camel.?

It may be likely that MERS has already spread to more countries, but has not been detected to lack of knowledge or access to testing. However, in Sept 2013 the MERS gene was mapped and in Dec 2013,?a group published a paper on their development of isothermal real-time RT-RPA, which they claim is ideal for rapid mobile molecular MERS-CoV monitoring. Therefore, it is more likely than ever that a case will be detected in the next 6 months.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting from major reputable news sources or an official announcement from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
