name: How many new mammal species will be discovered between January 1st and March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Scientists have identified and classified roughly 2 million species of plants, animals and microbes on Earth, but estimate that there are millions more left to discover. New species are, accordingly, constantly being discovered and described. The most commonly discovered new species are insects. New mammal species discoveries are rare, but they do occur (about once per year), typically in remote geographies that haven't been well studied. Some animals, that may look similar to known species, are found to be new species only when scientists have the opportunity to assess their genomes.

In February 2014, a?new?species?of?dasyurid?marsupial was described in ZOOTAXA.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.livescience.com/43620-new-species-marsupial-antechinus.html
  • http://www.mnn.com/earth-matters/animals/photos/9-newly-discovered-species/caqueta-monkey
  • http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/26/tiny-wallaby-among-three-mammals-glimpsed-for-first-tim...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

A new mammal species will be reported in the peer-reviewed scientific literature - in a journal?indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in a company official press release.
?
This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

"Discovered" here means a finding that is reported in the peer-reviewed scientific literature.

name: When will a vaccine for Ebola Virus Disease be licensed for clinical use?
question_text:
The Ebola virus disease, formerly known as Ebola haemorrhagic fever, is a severe, often fatal illness in humans. As of April 10, 2014, the Guinea Ministry of Health announced a total of 157 suspect and confirmed cases of Ebola Hemorrhagic Fever (Ebola), including 101 deaths, in the districts of Gu?k?dou, Macenta, Kissidougou, Dabola, Djingaraye, and Conakry, the capital. There is no licensed vaccine available for Ebola; however, many research groups are working on on and clinical trials have started.? And due to recent outbreak in Africa, there may be increase focus on vaccine development.

?For example, The US National Institutes of Health Laboratory of Virology at the Vaccine Research center is working on a vaccine and has at least one in trials: ?A Phase I Marburg DNA vaccine candidate proved safe, well-tolerated, and immunogenic. Preliminary analysis of a Phase Ib clinical trial utilizing concomitant administration of the Ebola and Marburg vaccine candidates shows the products and vaccination strategy to be safe and well-tolerated.?

Links and sources

  • A list of clinical trials: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=ebola&Search=Search
  • NIH Laboratory of Virology http://www.niaid.nih.gov/topics/ebolaMarburg/Pages/vaccineDevelopment.aspx
  • World Health Organization: Ebola virus disease http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/
  • Outbreak of Ebola in Guinea and Liberia http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/outbreaks/guinea/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Science section of major newspapers, the journals Nature and Science, the official WHO Ebola page.

Fine Print

?licensed?-approved by the US FDA or similar organization or listed on the World Health Organization?s Ebola information page: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/

keywords: CO2, Carbon Dioxide, Atmosphere, Mauna Loa Laboratory
name: Will the average annual concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere recorded by NOAA's Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii exceed 400 PPM in 2014?
question_text:
Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO) is a premier atmospheric research facility that has been continuously monitoring and collecting data related to atmospheric change since the 1950's. The undisturbed air, remote location, and minimal influences of vegetation and human activity at MLO are ideal for monitoring constituents in the atmosphere that can cause climate change.

The MLO records show that the annual average atmospheric CO2 concentration was 396.38 ppm in 2013, 393.82 ppm in 2012, and 391.63 ppm in 2011. The average annual increase rate is 2.1 ppm per year in the last ten years from 2004 to 2013.

The observatory is part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) - Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL) - Global Monitoring Division (GMD).

http://co2now.org/Current-CO2/CO2-Now/annual-co2.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Mauna Loa Observatory:
http://co2now.org/Current-CO2/CO2-Now/annual-co2.html

name: In the 2013 Annual Report from the National Poison Data System (NPDS), will analgesics be the number one substance class for exposures among adults in the US?
question_text:
Analgesics were the number one class of exposures among adults in the 2012 NPDS report (12.46% of exposures), just ahead of sedatives/hypnotics/anti-psychotics (10.88%). These two classes were well above all others in terms of number of exposures.

  • National Poison Data System https://aapcc.s3.amazonaws.com/pdfs/annual_reports/2012_NPDS_Annual_Report.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/30/2014

Resolution Source

American Association of Poison Control Centers' National Poison Data System: http://www.aapcc.org/data-system/

Based on past publication timelines, the 2013 NPDS report should be published in late 2014.


Fine Print

Analgesics are a class of drugs used to relieve pain. Overdoes of analgesics will result in drug poisoning.Adults are defined by NPDS as being >= 20 years old.

  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 51.3%, the "51.3%-54.7%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will photovoltaics installations in the United States exceed a total of 10,500 (MW) before January 01, 2014?
question_text:
Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the GTM Research and the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA) 'U.S. Solar Market Insight: Year in Review 2013'. It is anticipated that this year-in-review will be released in March of 2014. If nothing is published by GTM Research and the SEIA by March 31, 2014, the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., the total photovoltaics installations in the United States has not exceeded a total of 10,500 (MW) before January 01, 2014). Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from GTM Research and the SEIA). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

name: Before the end of 2025, will NASA be able to capture an asteroid and shuttle it into lunar orbit for further human exploration?
question_text:
NASA plans to launch the Asteroid Redirection Mission?(ARM) robotic spacecraft at the end of this decade. The agency is working on two concepts for capturing an asteroid: one?would use an inflatable system, similar to a bag, while?the other would capture a boulder off of a much larger asteroid using a robotic arm. NASA is expected to?choose one of the two concepts in late 2014.

After an asteroid mass is captured, the spacecraft will redirect it to a stable orbit around the moon called a ?Distant Retrograde Orbit?. Astronauts aboard NASA's Orion?spacecraft, launched from a Space Launch System (SLS)?rocket, will then explore the asteroid, hopefully some time?in the mid-2020s.

  • What is NASA's Asteroid Redirection Mission??http://www.nasa.gov/content/what-is-nasa-s-asteroid-redirect-mission/#.U_e0JPldXy0
  • NASA bets on asteroid mission as best path to Mars:?https://www.sciencenews.org/article/nasa-bets-asteroid-mission-best-path-mars

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2025

Resolution Source

NASA ARM:http://www.nasa.gov/content/what-is-nasa-s-asteroid-redirect-mission/#.U_e0JPldXy0

name: What will be the peak percentage of users accessing Google via IPv6 at the end of July 2015?
question_text:
From a FAQ by Google about IPv6:
IPv4 is the current version of the Internet Protocol, the identification system the Internet uses to send information between devices. This system assigns a series of four numbers (each ranging from 0 to 255) to each device. IPv4 only allows for about 4 billion addresses and the Internet needs more room than that. IPv6 is the new version of the Internet Protocol and expands the number of available addresses to a virtually limitless amount?340 trillion trillion trillion addresses.

The?Google IPv6 traffic graph?is one of the most watched barometers of global IPv6 deployment. Some milestones from the traffic graph:

  • February 22nd, 2014 it hit 3%
  • June 28th, 2014 it hit 4%
  • October 4th, 2014 it hit 5%
  • And it appears to be on track to hit 6% in early 2015
Previous IPv6 questions on SciCast:
  • When will the IPv6 traffic measured by Google surpass 4%?
  • What will be the peak percentage of users accessing Google via IPv6 at the end of January 2015?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

7/26/2015

Resolution Source

Unlike the previous question, this question asks you to predict the peak IPv6 traffic during a specific 7 day window, of July 27th to August 2nd (inclusive), 2015. The value used will be the maximum of the 7 "Total IPv6" measurements for those days, in Google's IPv6 adoption data, available?here. This is to minimize the effect of predictable intraweek fluctuations on the traffic and simplify forecasting.

News about additional adoption milestones will likely also be reported by the?Internet Society's Blog.

name: Pluto's exact size has been difficult to determine due to its distance from Earth and light refraction in Pluto's atmosphere. What will the New Horizons space probe determine Pluto?s diameter to be when it flies by the dwarf planet in July 2015?
question_text:
A May 2014 study in the journal Icarus conducted an analysis of the methane in the dwarf planet Pluto's atmosphere and has concluded that Pluto has a diameter of roughly 2367 kilometers, which is an increase over the previous estimate of 2306 kilometers. This new estimate would make Pluto larger than its intrastellar rival for largest dwarf planet, Eris, which is estimated to have a diameter of about 2325 kilometers.

Pluto's exact size has been difficult to determine due to its distance from Earth and light refraction in Pluto's atmosphere. However, NASA's New Horizons space probe is due to fly within 10,000?km (6,200?mi) of Pluto to study the dwarf planet in July 2015. The probe's instruments should be able to finally determine Pluto's diameter and atmospheric density and composition, before the probe moves on to study objects in the Kuiper Belt.

  • Scientific American - Pluto Bids to Get Planetary Status Back
  • NASA - About New Horizons
  • Wikipedia - New Horizons


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/01/2015

Resolution Source

NASA will report its findings from the New Horizon mission on its website. Scientific publications, such as Scientific American and Science Magazine, and mainstream press, such as BBC News and the New York Times, are also likely to cover the New Horizon findings. If no measurements are reported by 12/01/15, this question will resolve as 2,367km, or the most current measurement on record (not reported by New Horizons).?

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move a binary question exactly to 0% or 100%.

name: When will a commercially available electric field based fire suppression system be available?
question_text:
The risks of unplanned fire are omnipresent, and all existing fire suppression methods have drawbacks, including damage to the assets they are intended to protect (e.g. water-based fire suppression) and toxicity (e.g. chemical-based fire suppression). New research at Harvard University has shown that an alternating electrical field can be used to extinguish a fire. This discovery promises to lead to new fire suppression technology that does not rely on water or chemicals.

For more information, see:

  • http://gmwgroup.harvard.edu/research/index.php?page=16
  • http://www.darpa.mil/newsevents/releases/2012/07/12.aspx
  • http://spectrum.ieee.org/energy/fossil-fuels/fighting-fire-with-electricity

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

The availability of a commercial electric field based fire suppression system would be reported in the popular press.

This question will resolve when such a system first becomes available or by the beginning of the last answer choice period (i.e. January 1 2020), whichever comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Pennsylvania?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Pennsylvania, 57.4% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +5.5% from 2011 (51.9%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 56.5%, the "56.5%-59.9%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Internet of Things, sensors, digital information, network connected devices, wireless devices
name: The Internet of Things (IoT) consisted of about 20 billion connected devices at the end of 2013. How many 'things' will be connected to the Internet by the end of 2014?
question_text:
The term Internet of Things was first coined by Kevin Ashton in a presentation in 1999. As he stated, "the Internet of Things has the potential to change the world, just as the Internet did -- maybe even more so."

The Internet of Things (IoT) includes technologies for identification, IoT architecture, service-oriented-architecture, communications (Bluetooth, ZeegBee, and so on), cognitive radios, network discovery, data and signal processing, data discovery and search, power and energy storage, security and privacy, and many others. ?The number of things that are connectable to the Internet is estimated to be approaching 200 billion, but not all of those things are actually wired and communicating on the Internet. ?In 2013, according to EMC?s Digital Universe study (http://www.emc.com/leadership/digital-universe/2014iview/index.htm), some 20 billion are connected devices. ?By 2020, this number will grow by 50% to 30 billion connected devices.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/01/2015

Resolution Source

The EMC (http://www.emc.com/) conducts an annual Digital Universe study, in conjunction with IDC. ?The study estimates the amount of digital information produced and the number of things connected to the Internet?annually.?Digital Universe of Opportunities: Rich Data and the Increasing Value of the Internet of Things, the latest study, reports 2013 estimates?of the digital universe and?was published in April 2014. ?The next report would be expected to be published?in April 2015 and provide 2014 estimates, which will be used to resolve this question.

Fine Print

This question will resolve based on the estimated number of connectable things in 2014 as reported in the Digital Universe study conducted by the EMC in conjunction with the IDC.IDC (https://www.idc.com/) describes the IoT as a network connecting ? either wired or wireless ? devices (things) that is characterized by automatic provisioning, management, and monitoring.The ranges in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated number reported in the Digital Universe Study is 21.0 billion, the "21-22 billion" range will be deemed correct.
short_name: Number of Things Connected to the Internet

keywords: Biodiversity, Ecosystem, Habitat, Plants, Animals, Fish, Farming
name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "trends in genetic diversity of domesticated animals, cultivated plants, and fish species of major socio-economic importance" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

Useful Links

  • http://www.cbd.int/gbo/
  • https://www.cbd.int/cop/
  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/gbo/gbo2/cbd-gbo2-en.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: Will researchers make contact with the defunct International Sun-Earth Explorer 3?
question_text:
International Solar-Environment Explorer (ISEE-3) was launched in late 1978 to study the interaction between the Earth?s magnetic field and solar wind. In 1983, it was redirected to study comets, winning the ?space race? to encounter a comet. In 1997, NASA ended the Explorer?s mission and ordered the probe shut down.? Though only a carrier signal was supposed to be left operating, the probe was not powered off after a brief contact in 1999. In 2008, NASA located the Explorer using the Deep Space Network.

The Explorer?s current trajectory will bring it close to Earth in August 2014 giving the chance for it to be put to use once more to study solar wind. However, the equipment needed to transmit the signals to capture the Explore was decommissioned at NASA in 1999.?

Two teams are attempting to contact the Explorer and have it successfully fire its thrusters to get back to its station between the Earth and the Sun. A 18-meter satellite dish at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory still has the right hardware and may attempt to contact the Explorer.? The other team is a crowd-funded team who will use the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico to make contact with the Explorer. They are using embedded systems technology to construct radio components in software and build the necessary components to contact the Explorer.

Links and sources

  • Space Thief Or Hero? One Man's Quest To Reawaken An Old Friend http://www.npr.org/2014/03/18/289628696/space-thief-or-hero-one-mans-quest-to-reawaken-an-old-friend
  • Space Hackers Prepare to Reboot 35-Year-Old Spacecraft http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/satellites/space-hackers-prepare-to-reboot-35-year-old-spacecraft
  • ISEE-3 Reboot Project by Space College, Skycorp, and SpaceRef http://www.rockethub.com/42228

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

An official with the successful team will announce the success or failure of their experiment. This would be covered in the scientific popular press.

Fine Print

?Contact? will be made when the team sending a signal to the explorer to command it into a mode receives a signal back from the explorer. This will resolved the question as ?Yes?.

name: Will the Hubble telescope identify a suitable Kuiper belt object for NASA's New Horizon's space probe to investigate after its flyby of Pluto before October 1, 2014?
question_text:
NASA's New Horizon's probe, launched in January 2006, is scheduled to reach Pluto in July 2015. After observing the dwarf planet and its moons, NASA plans to send the spacecraft on to examine one or two objects in the Kuiper Belt, a region of the solar system that extends beyond Neptune. However, mission scientists have been unable to identify suitable Kuiper belt objects (KBOs) using large telescopes on the ground, so the mission has reserved observing time on the Hubble telescope to aid their search.

New Horizons has been given an allotment of 40 Earth orbits of Hubble observing time, or about 40 hours. If it finds two faint KBOs during that period, then a second observing period of 156 orbits will begin. The first set of observations is meant to show whether there are enough faint KBOs, statistically speaking, for it to be worth Hubble?s time to continue with the full search for a suitable KBO.

Time is of the essence because the team must identify at least one KBO target by roughly the end of August to be able to follow its trajectory for at least a year and accurately plan a visit. The probe has limited fuel; mission scientists intend to fire the probe?s thrusters soon after the Pluto flyby next summer in order to accurately set it on a course to visit a KBO.

  • Wikipedia - New Horizons
  • NASA - NASA Hubble to Begin Search Beyond Pluto for a New Horizons Mission Target
  • Scientific American - Telescope Will Search for Spacecraft's Post-Pluto Target
  • Christian Science Monitor - After Pluto, what's next for NASA's New Horizons probe

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/30/2014

Resolution Source

NASA will report the findings of its Hubble search on its website. The progress of the New Horizons mission is also being reported on by many scientific and mainstream news sources. NASA must announce that they have identified a specific target(s) that they intend to track and eventually navigate the probe towards.

Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, a 'suitable' Kuiper Belt Object is one NASA determines worthy of investigation with the New Horizons probe.The question will be resolved when NASA announce whether or not they have identified one or more suitable Kuiper belt objects. If no announcement is made by September 30, the question will resolve as "No".
short_name: Identify Kuiper belt object for investigation

name: How many threatened mammals will the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species identify in its next published update?
question_text:
The InternationalUnion for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) maintains and publishes the IUCN RedList of Threatened Species, widely recognized as the most comprehensive andobjective global approach for evaluating the conservation status of plant andanimal species. In order to produce the Red List, IUCN draws upon a network ofscientists and partner organizations working in almost every country in theworld.

The Red Listidentified species as threatened if they are classified by the IUCN asCritically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), or Vulnerable (VU). Species canalso be classified as extinct (EX) or extinct in the wild (EW); or in one of severalnon-threatened categories: Lower Risk/conservation dependent (LR/cd), NearThreatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD), Least Concern (LC).

In 2011,2012 and 2013 releases of the Red List, the IUCN reported 1,138, 1,139, and 1,143threatened mammals respectively. Note the from its February 2009 report to itsApril 2010 report, the IUCN reported a decline of 11 in the number ofthreatened mammals. The IUCN updates its list at least annually, so a newupdate should be available and published soon.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved when the IUCN publishes its next update to the RedList. The current list is version 2013.2 from 21 November 2013. The next updated list, once published, will be available in Table 1 and linked to here:? http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics









Fine Print

IUCN definitions are being used for endangered species, per the discussion in the Background discussion.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in states with historically 'somewhat high' HPV vaccination coverage?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • The 'somewhat high' HPV vaccination group of states is comprised of the following: (2011 coverage rate % / 2012 coverage rate %)
    • Delaware?(60.2 / 67.2)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/475/trades/create/safe
    • Maine?(56.1 / 61.7)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/489/trades/create/safe
    • Minnesota (55.5 / 59.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/493/trades/create/safe
    • Nebraska (59 / 67.5)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/498/trades/create/safe
    • New Hampshire (65.8 / 52.2)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/500/trades/create/safe
    • New Jersey?(55.5 / 54.6)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/501/trades/create/safe
    • New York (46.6 / 56)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/503/trades/create/safe
    • North Dakota (51.2 / 60.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/505/trades/create/safe
    • Oregon (68.6 / 58.5)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/514/trades/create/safe
    • Pennsylvania (51.9 / 57.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/515/trades/create/safe
    • Washington (66.5 / 64.5)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/525/trades/create/safe
    • Wisconsin (65.7 / 50.5)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/527/trades/create/safe
  • These are primarily states with somewhat Democratic constituencies, high longevity, and high rates?of DTAP vaccination.
  • The vaccination rate of the group will be determined by calculating an unweighted arithmetic mean of the 2013 data for the 12 states.
Related Predict Question:?What percentage of the US female population aged 13-17 will be vaccinated against HPV by the end of 2013?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here: http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

Clusters of states were created by first analyzing state-level variables that correlate with HPV vaccination coverage in 2011 and 2012. The model for predicting HPV vaccination coverage explained over half the variation among states. On the most useful variables, states in a given cluster are more similar to each other than to states in other clusters. The range of possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 58.5%, the "Between 58.5% and 60.0%" range will be deemed correct.

name: What happened to Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370?
question_text:
On March 8, 2014, a Boeing 777 aircraft operating under Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 went missing on its directed route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. ?The aircraft consisted of 227 total passengers and 12 crew members which departed from Kuala Lumpur International Airport at 12:41 am. ?The aircraft sent its last transponder signal at 1:21 am. ?A search and rescue mission currently spans about 100,000 nautical miles including the South China Sea near the location of the last transponder signal, the Malacca Strait along the west coast of Malaysia, and the Andaman Sea. ?At first it was reported that the ACARS engine data systems had ceased, but now it appears that pings were received 4-5 hours after the transponders stopped. Media reports have been inconsistent.

Bayesian search theory began with vessels and objects missing at sea, and is most highly developed for nautical environments. ?Although the core work is highly mathematical, it often begins with subjective weighing of scenarios and integration of initially sparse and?conflicting information. ?SciCast provides a platform to do this, and to relate scenarios to outcomes. ?Although we do not have an elegant map interface, we would like to see how well we can collectively integrate disparate information and update over time.?

Relevant Links:
  • Malaysia Airlines: ?What we know about flight MH370 [BBC]
  • Theories Grow without Facts on Lost Flight: [NYT]?
  • SciCast question on the find location.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2014

Resolution Source

OfficialMalaysian government news reported in?mainstream news sources (e.g. CNN, BBC, Reuters, AP). We will wait at least 24 hours for possible retractions or clarifications.

Fine Print

"Aircraft failure" includes structural, mechanical, or electrical failures leading to a crash or unintended landing. A safe emergency landing probably falls into this category.
"Pilot error/incapacitation" includes various kinds of "pilot error" including disorientation, over-control, and inattention.
"Deliberate diversion" includes traditional hijacking and deliberate diversion by the pilots or crew. The unlikely event of a pilot suicide would also fit in this scenario.
"Onboard bomb" includes explosions from something brought on board the craft.
"Shot down" includes deliberate or mistaken missile or other external attacks on the plane, by anyone.
"Other/Unresolved" includes anything not in the above, or having no answer by 30-JUN-14.

name: Will a Phase III clinical trial for GlaxoSmithKline's experimental Ebola vaccine begin recruiting by March 31st, 2015?
question_text:
Phase I trial data was published on November 16th, 2014 for a study of an Ebola vaccine from GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), showing a positive immunological response against the Ebola virus. The vaccine?uses a type of chimpanzee cold virus, known as chimpanzee adenovirus type 3 (ChAd3), as a carrier to deliver genetic material from two strains of the Ebola virus ? the Sudan strain and the Zaire strain, which is responsible for the current Ebola outbreak in west Africa.?

GSK has been working with the NIH to accelerate development of both this bivalent version of the candidate vaccine and a monovalent version targeting only the Zaire strain in response to the current Ebola epidemic.?These developments?have led to further trials which are expected to include?phase III clinical trials and the vaccination of frontline healthcare workers in Africa.?

For more information:

  • http://www.gsk.com/en-gb/media/press-releases/2014/gsk-statement-on-first-phase-1-trial-results-of-a...
  • http://www.gsk.com/en-gb/media/press-releases/2014/new-european-consortium-formed-to-help-further-ad...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The phase III?clinical trial will be listed in ClinicalTrials.gov as "Recruiting".?This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.
short_name: Ebola vaccine phase III clinical trial recruitment

categories: Business of Science,Computational Sciences,Information Systems,Engineered Technologies,Physics
keywords: TALOS suit, shot detection, threat detection, weapon detection
name: Will the U.S. Army special armed forces' TALOS suits (also called 'Iron Man' suits) be equipped with enemy weapon detection capabilities by the end of 2018?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well protected as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

Threat detection is one of the critical concerns of dismounted soldiers. With advances in sensor technologies, acoustic, radar, imaging, and other multisensory technologies can help soldiers detect enemy shots/artillery from a very long distance to better prepare them with intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities. As an example, Raytheon?s Boomerang series provides enemy shooter detection capabilities to forces at the battlefront through their Boomerang Warrior-X, Boomerang Air, and Boomerang III. Boomerang uses passive acoustic detection, computer-based signal processing, and both auditory and visual indications to detect and report relative shooter azimuth and elevation information.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/?

http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/11/19/talos-iron-man-suit_n_4300576.html

http://www.cbsnews.com/news/u-s-special-forces-advances-iron-man-suit-project/

http://boomerang.bbn.com/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that may say the following: 1) the feature has been integrated into a non-prototype suit or 2) that the suits deployed on the ground have this feature.

Fine Print

"Enemy weapon detection capabilities" specifically refers to shot detection technology built into the suits. If any form of shot detection is integrated into the suit, the question will be resolved. Prototypes will not be considered for the purpose of this question.

keywords: mars, astronaut, NASA, space exploration, manned mission
name: Space agencies for the United States, the European Union, the Russian Federation, and China have announced ?plans for plans? for manned missions to Mars, with target landing dates in the 2030s. When will a human being actually set foot on the surface of Mars?
question_text:
<pre>Engineers have contemplated a manned mission to Mars since the first detailed technical assessment was published by Werner Von Braun in 1947.? Following the success of the Apollo program in putting astronauts on the moon, ?space exploration advocates have championed Mars as a logical next step in human space exploration.? The space-faring nations who have announced their intention to eventually launch a manned Mars mission include the United States, the European Space Agency, Russia, Japan, China and India. ??In recent years, a number of private entities, such as Mars One, the Mars Initiative, and the Inspiration Mars Foundation have emerged to develop privately-funded mars missions.? For more information on the history of Mars manned mission planning, see:??http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manned_mission_to_Mars

Apart from the political and policy considerations, such as program cost and conflicting national priorities, launching a successful manned mission to Mars poses a number of fundamental? engineering challenges that will require development of new technologies and approaches to enable mission success.? In addition to such fundamental needs as life support and propulsion, ?engineers will have to develop ways to protect astronauts from the health effects of prolonged exposure to high-energy cosmic rays and other ionizing radiation, as well as the negative effects of prolonged low-gravity on human health.</pre>

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2034

Resolution Source

This event will be covered by every major news outlet with priority given to the following sources:?National Aeronautics and Space Administration, European Space Agency.

Fine Print

In order for the question to resolve in the positive, a human being must set foot and walk on the surface of Mars.

name: Will the 2014 Nobel Prize in Medicine be awarded in any of these fields?
question_text:
Established in 1900s, the Nobel Foundation awards the annual Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Economic Sciences, Literature, and Peace. ?Recipients must be living, and in no case may the prize be divided among more than three persons.? Between 1901 and 2013, 561 prizes have been awarded. ?In some years, some prizes have not been awarded: the latest was 1972 when the Peace prize was not awarded. (Source:?nobelprize.org)

Resolution Sources

Science section of The New York Times

Useful Information and Links

The Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institute:?http://www.nobelprizemedicine.org/

Related Organizations or Individuals

The Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet, http://www.nobelprizemedicine.org/

keywords: World Health Organization, International Health Regulations, public health, core capacities
name: How many countries will self-report to have met WHO International Health Regulations (2005) core capacity requirements by AUG 01 2014?
question_text:
Since 15 June 2007, the world has been implementing the International Health Regulations (2005). This legally-binding agreement applies to 194 countries across the globe including all WHO Member States and significantly contributes to global public health security by providing a new framework for the coordination of the management of events that may constitute a public health emergency of international concern. By its implementation the IHR will improve the capacity of all countries to detect, assess, notify and respond to public health threats.IHR States Parties had until 15 June 2012 to meet their IHR core surveillance and response requirements, including at designated airports, ports and certain ground crossings. A majority of States Parties, however, have requested and obtained a two-year extension to this deadline and, in exceptional circumstances, may be granted an additional extension, not exceeding two years. Since the deadline for the extension expires this June, this question asks how many of the IHR States Parties will comply by the deadline.

  • WHO about the International Health Regulations (2005)
  • IHR (2005) FAQs
  • Additional IHR (2005) resource from George Washington University


While this is not anticipated, if WHO changed the checklist or in another way altered the mechanisms for self-reporting, that could impact the outcome of this question. Likewise, on an individual country level, many factors could impact their ability to comply with IHR 2005 by June 2014, but the answer buckets are such that these individual factors will not likely impact the overall outcome of the question; likewise, with only 5.5 months remaining, there is less opportunity for outside events to dramatically alter a country's plans for achieving IHR 2005 compliance by the June 2014 deadline.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/01/2014

Resolution Source

WHO collates information on self-reporting on IHR core capacities by each country, and also information on which countries have requested an extension (meaning they are self-reporting that they have not yet met all core capacity requirements)

Regional WHO offices may also gather information relevant to the countries in their region, and each will likely publish a report on their region's?IHR implementation and compliance in 2014:

  • AFRO (Regional Office for Africa)
  • EMRO (Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean)
  • EURO (Regional Office for Europe)
  • PAHO (Pan American Health Organization)
  • SEARO (Regional Office for South-East Asia)
  • WPRO (Western Pacific Region)


Fine Print

"Self-report" is defined according to the WHO's own checklist and is based on the country's own self-assessment using said checklist, not whether or not the country has actually met all core capacities.

name: What will be the peak percentage of users accessing Google via IPv6 at the end of January 2015?
question_text:
From a FAQ by Google about IPv6:
IPv4 is the current version of the Internet Protocol, the identification system the Internet uses to send information between devices. This system assigns a series of four numbers (each ranging from 0 to 255) to each device. IPv4 only allows for about 4 billion addresses and the Internet needs more room than that. IPv6 is the new version of the Internet Protocol and expands the number of available addresses to a virtually limitless amount?340 trillion trillion trillion addresses.

The?Google IPv6 traffic graph?is one of the most watched barometers of global IPv6 deployment. It exceeded 4% the weekend of June 28th, 2014. (That was the subject of a previous SciCast question.) Before that,?it crossed 3% on?February 22nd, 2014

Here is an?article?about passing the 3% threshold.?

Internet Service Providers and anyone who is supporting devices connected to the Internet globally is affected by the potential scarcity of Internet addresses.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/25/2015

Resolution Source

Unlike the previous question, this question asks you to predict the peak IPv6 traffic during a specific 7 day window, of January 26th to February 1st (inclusive), 2015. The value used will be the maximum of the 7 "Total IPv6" measurements for those days, in Google's IPv6 adoption data, available here. This is to minimize the effect of predictable intraweek fluctuations on the traffic and simplify forecasting.

News about additional adoption milestones will likely also be reported by the Internet Society's Blog.

keywords: NASA, EmDrive, impossible drive, thrust, RF, propulsion, cannae drive, drive
name: Will NASA's measurement of thrust from an 'impossible' space drive be reproduced on the next try?
question_text:
The EmDrive, which has been called an 'impossible drive' in the news,?is claimed to produce thrust without propellant. Last year, a Chinese team built a version of an EmDrive and claimed to?measure non-zero thrust. More recently, a team from NASA published results that also found non-zero thrust, although it was 1,000 times?less than what the Chinese team measured. The findings have fueled public interest into whether?the measurement of thrust was?spurious or whether this is the first?hint of new physics and a new way to travel through space.

The end of NASA's recent paper says that their near-term objective is to reproduce these results at an independent test facility, such as Glenn Research Center (GRC), Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), or Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory. The question is: Will the next test of an?'impossible drive' at one of these three locations?confirm that it produces?positive thrust in a vacuum?

References

  • NASA's published test results:?http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2014-4029
  • A recent Q&A news article about the 'impossible drive':?http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-08/07/10-qs-about-nasa-impossible-drive


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An announcement, abstract, paper, web page, or other form of communication by NASA,?GRC, JPL, or Johns Hopkins University.

Fine Print

'Impossible drive' in the question title refers to any of a class of RF thrusters that claim to work without propellant, including but not limited to EmDrive, Q-drive, Cannae drive, or some custom modification of their designs. If multiple designs are tested and at least one generates positive thrust in a vacuum, this question will resolve YES. Vacuum is defined as a pressure below 1 Pa (don't worry, this is not much). If zero thrust is within the range of the error bars, this question will resolve NO, even if the mean of the confidence interval is positive. If no answer is published by the end of 2015, this question will resolve NO. Only measurements from groups the listed in the recent NASA paper (GRC, JPL, or Johns Hopkins Applied Physics) will count; measurements from other groups will not count toward resolution of this question. To resolve YES, the date of the first publication must be before 01/01/2016. For example, an announcement in 2016 of experiments performed in 2015 will resolve as NO.

keywords: Australia, Greenhouse gases, Kyoto Protocol, Emissions, CO2, Carbon Dioxide, Pollution, Global Warming
name: Will Australia reduce its greenhouse gas emissions unconditionally by 5% below their 2000 levels by January 01, 2020?
question_text:
Australia is one of the top 20 polluting countries in the world and produces more carbon pollution per person than any other developed country in the world. Without a comprehensive plan, Australia's emissions are projected to increase by 24 per cent between 2000 and 2020. Recognising the importance of responding to the climate change challenge, countries all over the world are acting to reduce their emissions. The message is clear: Australia needs to reduce its carbon pollution and do its fair share.In December 2007, Australia ratified the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, agreeing to limit annual carbon pollution to an average of 108 per cent of 1990 levels during the Kyoto period (2008 to 2012).Australia has also committed to reducing its emissions by between 5 and 15 or 25 per cent below 2000 levels by 2020. The five per cent target is unconditional. The up to 15 per cent and 25 per cent targets are conditional on the extent of international action. On 27 January 2010, Australia formally submitted its full target range to the Copenhagen Accord. The decision to maintain the full range is consistent with the approach taken by other countries.The Australian Government has also committed to a long-term target to cut pollution by 80 per cent below 2000 levels by 2050.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of Australia's National Inventory Report which is submitted to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) as part of Australia's reporting obligations under that Convention and the Kyoto Protocol (KP). Official statements released by the Australian Government's Department of the Environment may also be referenced to determine resolution. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from Australia's National Inventory Report or official statements released by the Australian Government's Department of the Environment. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Australian Department of the Environment (National Inventory Report)

Fine Print

"Unconditionally" is defined as independent of the extent of international action, "By" should be interpreted to mean at some point prior to the end (23:59:59 ET) of the previous day of December 31, 2019, "5% below their 2000 levels" is defined as 5% below approximately 550 MtCO2-e.

Useful Links

  • http://www.climatechange.gov.au/climate-change/greenhouse-gas-measurement-and-reporting/tracking-aus...
  • ?http://www.climatechange.gov.au/climate-change/greenhouse-gas-measurement-and-reporting/australias-e...
  • http://unfccc.int/kyoto_protocol/compliance/items/3024.php

Related Organizations or Individuals

The enforcement branch of the compliance committee of the Kyoto Protocol.

keywords: World Chess Championship, Magnus Carlsen, Viswanathan Anand
name: How many games will Magnus Carlsen win during the World Chess Championship match in Sochi in November 2014?
question_text:
The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. A variety of news sources are expected to monitor the match with immediate updates as the match evolves.

Official FIDE website
2014 World Chess Championship [Wikipedia]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/28/2014

Resolution Source

The resolution of this question will be based on the official score of the match conducted by the organizer of the tournament. It will be reported by multiple news sources. The major ones include:
http://www.chessbase.com
http://www.chess.com
http://www.fide.com

Fine Print

This question asks how many of the 12 scheduled non-tie-break games will be won by Magnus Carlsen, not what his final score will be. This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%.

name: Will facial recognition software with an error rate equal to or less than that exhibited by humans in facial recognition tasks (2.47%) be demonstrated before March 31st 2015?
question_text:
A wide variety of companies and government agencies are interested in the potential of facial recognition software.? For government agencies the interest lies mainly in law and national security.? Numerous police departments in the US and recently the Calgary police in Canada have adopted facial recognition as a method of tracking down criminals.? Thus far there is no evidence that the police departments are comparing surveillance footage with ordinary citizens; rather, they use mug shots of known criminals and compare that to footage of criminals in the act.? However, privacy activists have pointed out the danger that in the future the comparison database will include driver's license photos, so every citizen can be tracked.

The National Institute of Standards and Statistics (NIST) recently ran a test of the variety of facial recognition services now on the market.? The accuracy varied wildly based on the quality of the photo, the number of images to search through, and age of the subject.? Younger subjects have more similar faces than older faces and therefore it is more difficult for the software to accurately identify young people.? The error rate of results ranged from 4.1% for the best software under the best circumstances, to 66.9% with the worst software and worst circumstances.? Other sources put the error rate of the FBI facial recognition software at around 20%, leading to concerns that false positives may become problematic, particularly if the comparison database is expanded to include driver's license photos.
?
In the private sector Facebook is also pursuing facial recognition software, ostensibly as an improvement over its current photo tagging system.? They have managed to reach an error rate of only 2.75%.? When it comes to recognizing the faces of other humans, people have an error rate of 2.47%, suggesting that Facebook is getting close to human levels of accuracy.? Part of their success is due to an advance they have made in one of the tricky areas of facial recognition.? Often in photographs the entire face of a person is not visible, rendering ordinary facial comparison difficult as it removes many of the comparison points.? Facebook has developed an algorithm which takes a face and adjusts it so that every face is compared at the same angle.? This technique has significantly improved their accuracy.

https://www.facebook.com/download/233199633549733/deepface.pdf

name: Which organization(s) will publish the first paper describing a net energy positive Low Energy Nuclear Reaction (also known as cold fusion) device or process in a journal indexed on Thomson Reuters Web of Science?
question_text:
Low Energy Nuclear Reactions (LENR), or cold fusion, is a type of nuclear reaction that occurs at room temperature, as opposed to the conventional hot fusion reactions found in nuclear power plants, which occur at extremely high temperatures. ?

There are several groups and organizations working on LENR technology today. Prominent Italian inventor Andrea Rossi received a patent for a device he claimed capable of net energy positive LENR in 2011, which allegedly works by infusing heated hydrogen into nickel powder, transmuting it into copper and producing heat. Rossi has never let anyone see the inner workings of his device, and he refused to allow independent testing of the device until 2013. The researchers who conducted that test of Rossi?s device have written a paper detailing their findings, but it has yet to be published in a peer review journal. NASA is also developing LENR technology in their Langley Research Center using a nickel lattice and hydrogen ions. The hydrogen ions are sucked into the nickel lattice, and then the lattice is oscillated at a very high frequency. This oscillation produces a reaction that turns the nickel into copper and creates a lot of energy in the process. In 2012, the Sydney Kimmel Institute for Nuclear Renaissance was established at the University of Missouri to carry out LENR research. LENR research is also conducted at the US Naval Research Laboratory and CERN.

Resolution Criteria

This question will be judged on 01 January 2016.

The administrator will directly confirm the publication is indexed by the Web of Science as final resolution.

Resolution Sources

Numerous scientific journals and news outlets would likely report if this paper makes it through the peer review process, including Science Magazine, BBC News, the New York Times, and others.

The administrator will directly confirm the publication is indexed by the Web of Science as final resolution.

Fine Print

For the question to resolve a paper must be published detailing a net energy positive LERN device or process.

The paper must be published in a publication indexed in Thomas Reuters Web of Science.

Useful Information and Links

  • NASA Langley Research Center
  • CERN
  • Energy Catalyzer
  • Infinite Energy
  • Extremetech?- NASA's cold fusion technology

Related Organizations or Individuals

No single leading authority on topic
short_name: First peer reviewed LENR (cold fusion) paper

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Delaware?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Delaware, 67.2% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +7.0% from 2011 (60.2%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 66.3%, the "66.3%-69.7%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will a new Heartbleed-like exploit be publicly known by June 1, 2014?
question_text:
The Heartbleed vulnerability (http://blog.cloudflare.com/answering-the-critical-question-can-you-get-private-ssl-keys-using-heartb...)exposes server memory over a network connection. The vulnerability exists in the OpenSSL software library used by many websites to secure communications between client and server. A client may request a heartbeat exchange with a server and?exploit the vulnerability by?specifying a data size larger than the actual data sent.

In vulnerable versions of OpenSSL, the server will reply and will make up the difference in requested data size and actual data size with data from?memory. This data from memory comes from the web server process heap and in many cases will?contain information?not associated with?the current client session. Such heap data has been shown to contain keys from other sessions, other users' access credentials, and server-side private keys.

In any client-server exchange, the possibility exists that the server will reveal memory contents not associated with the current session. Such vulnerabilities may be triggered by user-specified input, as with Heartbleed, may be triggered by environmental factors (e.g., load), or may be currently and unintentionally passed in network traffic but not yet recognized as such.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

5/31/14

Resolution Source

Assignment of a CVE identifier where the CVE item description indicates client-side exposure of non-session server memory data. The vulnerability must have been demonstrated and the memory data returned cannot be a single constant or known pattern with no security implications. The new vulnerability cannot be a different service that uses OpenSSL and is simply vulnerable to the Heartbleed exploit. The CVE initial posting date must be after 4/21/14 and before 6/1/14.?http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/search?execution=e2s1

Fine Print

  • Session vs. Process: Modern operating systems have adequate process memory space isolation; this class of vulnerability is concerned with access to memory data outside of the current session but still within the main process.
  • Heartbleed-like: A client-driven IP-network-accessible vulnerability that exposes server memory not associated with the client session.
  • Vulnerability and Exploit: A vulnerability is a weakness, and an exploit is the use of that weakness.
  • Network-based vs. Web-based: Web-based refers to HTTP or HTTPS traffic, network-based means any IP network communications.

question_text:

While the use of commercial UAVs are highly regulated by the FAA, there is a provision in the policy which allows research into UAV use for?governmental functions. name: If the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded in the branch of Organic Chemistry or Inorganic Chemistry, will at least one of the following individuals be awarded the prize: George Whitesides, James Stoddart, Omar Yaghi, Michael Gratzel, Chad Mirkin?
question_text:
Established in 1900s, the Nobel Foundation awards the annual Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Economic Sciences, Literature, and Peace. ?Recipients must be living, and in no case may the prize be divided among more than three persons.? Between 1901 and 2013, 561 prizes have been awarded. ?In some years, some prizes have not been awarded: the latest was 1972 when the Peace prize was not awarded.?(Source:?nobelprize.org)

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on reporting by www.nobelprize.org. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from NobelPrize.org. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

name: Will there be at least one female winner of a Fields Medal in 2014?
question_text:
The Fields Medal, officially known as International Medal for Outstanding Discoveries in Mathematics, is a prize awarded to up to four young mathematicians under the age of 40. The medal is awarded every four years at the International Congress of Mathematics (ICM) and is often viewed as the greatest honor a mathematician can receive. The next Fields Medal will be awarded at ICM in Seoul in August 2014.To date, there have not been any female winners of the Fields Medal.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fields_Medal

name: When will the first Hyperloop-like system begin public operations?
question_text:
From Wikipedia:

The?Hyperloop?is a conceptual high-speed transportation system envisioned by entrepreneur?Elon Musk,[1][2]?incorporating reduced-pressure tubes in which pressurized capsules ride on a cushion of air, driven by a combination of?linear induction motors?and air compressors.[3]

The conceptual route runs from the?Los Angeles?region to the?San Francisco Bay Area, paralleling the?Interstate 5?corridor for most of its length, with an expected journey time of 35 minutes, meaning that passengers would traverse the 354-mile (570?km) route at an average speed of ~598?mph (962?km/h), with a top speed of 760?mph (1,220?km/h).

A preliminary design document was made public in August 2013, which included an estimate of a?US$6 billion?construction cost for a passenger-only version of the system, while a version allowing for transportation of both passengers and vehicles was estimated at?US$7.5 billion. The cost projections have been questioned by transportation engineers and others, who contend that the sum is unrealistically low given the scale of construction required and the level of unproven technology involved. The technological and economic feasibility of the idea is unproven and a subject of significant debate. A Hyperloop-like system has the following characteristics: immunity to weather, cars that never experience crashes, an average speed twice that of a typical jet aircraft, low power requirements and the ability to store energy for 24-hour operations.[4][5][6][7]

Resolution Sources

The New York Times, The Guardian, The Wall Street Journal, The Times, CNN

Fine Print

For an outcome to come true, the Hyperloop-like system must carry its first passengers in normal (non-test) operations within the calendar year or years specified.

Useful Information and Links

  • Hyperloop
  • Hyperloop Demonstrator?
  • Hyperloop Alpha Whitepaper

name: Before the end of 2015, will a curved 55" OLED TV be for sale in the U.S. with a suggested retail price under $5,000?
question_text:
An OLED TV screen uses a display technology called OLED (Organic Light Emitting Diodes). OLEDs are made by placing thin films of organic (carbon based) materials between two conductors. When electrical current is applied, a bright light is emitted. An OLED display works without backlight.?It can thus display deep black levels and?be thinner and lighter than a liquid crystal display. OLEDs can be printed onto any suitable substrate by an inkjet printer or even by screen printing, theoretically making them cheaper to produce. However, fabrication of the OLED substrate is more costly. Currently the retail price of Samsung's 55" Class S9C Series OLED TV is $8,999.99 in the U.S. market. Similarly, the LG 55EA9800 curved 55" OLED TV is selling for suggested price of $7,999.99.

  • OLED: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OLED
  • OLED TV: http://www.oled-info.com/oled-tv
  • http://www.samsung.com/us/video/tvs/KN55S9CAFXZA
  • http://www.lg.com/us/tvs/lg-55EA9800-oled-tv


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Retail price of the TV sets can be found on?companies' websites:
www.samsung.com
www.lg.com
www.sony.com
or by checking online stores such as Amazon:? www.amazon.com

Fine Print

OLED TV uses organic light emitting diodes for display. TV's greater than 55" will be considered for this question. The Manufacturers Suggested Retail Price (MSRP) must be less than $5,000 USD for this question to resolve in the affirmative.

name: When will a wearable sweat sensor that communicates wirelessly with a smartphone be sold to consumers?
question_text:
• Sweat sensors (known as electrodermal response sensors) measure sweat characteristics by a small flow of electricity on your skin. Sweat data can comes from a mixture of your body?s responses to exertion, ambient temperature, excretion, and sweating off bacteria and dirt. Sweat sensors are widely used in laboratories to diagnosis disease and monitor biological functions. ?
  • GE Global Research announced that they are? ?developing small wireless sensors for measuring biological markers in sweat that affect our stress and energy levels?, saying ?we can do it with a blood test, but we would like to detect the early signs of stress and fatigue non-invasively.?
  • Electrodermal response sensors are cheap to manufacture and can be easily integrated into wearables ? if the technology to get the sensor to communicate wirelessly is perfected. In addition, Apple?s new Apple Watch was rumored to include a sweat sensor, though this is not a feature in the Apple Watch announced in September 2014.

Links and sources
  • Sensing Sweat In Real-Time Using Wearable Micro-Fluidics? http://www.rsc.org/binaries/LOC/2010/PDFs/Papers/011_0014.pdf
  • Wearable electrochemical sensors for monitoring performance athletes http://doras.dcu.ie/16472/1/Wearable_sensors_for_sports_atheletes.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Announced in a company official press release.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

The wireless sensor must be available in a commercially item such as a watch or commercial stand alone sensor. R&D tools will not count for resolution.

Bitcoin is?a peer-to-peer cryptographic currency that issues new money and tracks transactions without a central authority.?
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Bitcoin

Square Wallet is?a mobile payment system developed by Square, Inc.?that allows its users to set up a tab?and pay for their order simply with their name or barcode?using a stored credit, debit, or gift card.
More information:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square,_Inc.

Integration into Square Wallet means that Square Wallet users will be able to send and receive Bitcoins using their Square account.

name: How many days in May 2014 will tree pollen concentration levels measure 'high' or 'very high' in New York, New York?
question_text:
• The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (AAAAI) is a professional organization with more than 6,800 members in the United States, Canada, and 72 other countries. This membership includes allergist/immunologists, other medical specialists, allied health and related healthcare professionals - all with a special interest in the research and treatment of allergic and immunologic diseases.
  • The National Allergy Bureau (NAB) is the section of the AAAAI?s Aeroallergen Network responsible for reporting current pollen and mold spore levels.The Aeroallergen Network is comprised of pollen and spore counting stations staffed primarily by AAAAI member volunteers who generously donate their time and expertise. The NAB currently provides the most accurate and reliable pollen and mold levels from approximately 79 counting stations throughout the United States, one counting station in Canada, and six counting stations in Argentina. The stations use air sampling equipment to collect airborne pollen and spores which are then examined microscopically. This information is also used for research to aid in the diagnosis, treatment and management of allergic diseases.Pollen counts from the NAB stations are based on actual counts, which reflect the real day to day weather events. Predicted counts reported on many websites may be based on pollen data from previous years and general weather forecasts.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/07/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on data reported by the?AAAAI NAB Pollen and Mold Report/Calendar of Data for the month of May 2014, which can be found here:?http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=AllergenCalendar&stationid=189&qsFullDate=05/04/2014

Fine Print

The NAB pollen levels were developed using the NAB Scale, which can be found here: http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=reading_charts3&statid=147

The concentrations in the chart were statistics from all certified counting sites. The concentrations were translated into levels based on the following:

- Low levels are concentrations that are less than the median or 50th percentile (i.e. half the counts were below the median.)
- Moderate levels are concentrations that fall between the 50th and 75th percentile
- High levels fall between the 75th and 99th percentile
- Very high levels are above the 99th percentile (99% of the counts are below this level)

?"New York, New York" refers to data collected from the NAB pollen count station in 'New York - New York (Fordham College at Lincoln Center)'
