keywords: Flu, Region 1, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 1 (CT, ME, MA, NH, RI, VT)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 1' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases in Region 1?for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across HHS region 1. Region 1 is comprised of Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont. ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Nebraska?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Nebraska, 67.5% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +8.5% from 2011 (59.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 66.6%, the "66.6%-70.0%" range will be deemed correct.

Particularly, it aims to allow fully?anonymous transactions via so-called "masternodes". In May 2014 the DRK/BTC exchange rate varied from 0.004 to over 0.028, briefly?making it the third largest market cap?cryptocurrency.

keywords: US Electric Grid, Cybercrime, Cybersecurity, cyber security, Malware
name: Will a  power outage occur in any part of the United States as a result of a cyber attack on a U.S. electric grid by March 31, 2015?
question_text:
The U.S. national power grid is a complex, aging, and interconnected network of electrical and communication technologies, and is therefore vulnerable to power outages from a number of variables.? This includes weather, equipment failure, over-demand, and physical attacks.? However since the power grid is reliant on communication technologies, a power outage can also occur due to a cyber attack.? Most recently in November 2014, Michael Rogers, director of the National Security Agency (NSA) stated that China and 'one or two' other (undisclosed) countries have the ability to launch a cyber attack that could shut down the entire U.S. power grid and other critical infrastructure.? This was in response to a piece of malware that had been detected in China of which the director of NSA stated:? "It enables you to shut down very segmented, very tailored parts of our infrastructure that forestall the ability to provide that service to us as citizens."? This leads to the question if any part of the US national power grid will experience a power outage due to a cyber attack by March 31, 2015.


Relevant Links:
  • NSA Director: Yes, China Can Shut Down Our Power Grids [Business Insider]
  • China Could Shut Down U.S. Power Grid With Cyber Attack, Says NSA Chief [Newsweek]
  • Double Threat: US Grid Vulnerable on Two Fronts [CNBC]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved true if it is publically reported that a power outage (as defined in the 'Fine Print') occurs in any part of the United States due to a cyber attack on a U.S. electric grid between January 10 and March 31, 2015.? This can be verified by the Eaton Corp. Blackout Tracker which lists power outages in the entire U.S. (and conveniently lists the reasons for them), along with local news sources or major news sources such as BBC, Reuters, etc. confirming that the power outage was due to a cyber attack.

Fine Print

A 'power outage' for the purpose of this question is defined as a loss of electric power in a given area which affects at least 1,000 people and lasts for more than one hour. A 'cyber attack' is defined as a successful exploitation or unauthorized access to a computer, computer system, or electronic communications network that makes up the U.S. power grid.

keywords: Google glass, price, glasses, google, wearables
name: When Google Glass is released to the general public, what will its intial price be?
question_text:
Currently Google is testing its product through its Google Explorer program, where selected individuals can get the glasses for $1500 each. Some claim that a generalized release date will be announced for 2014, but as of ?yet there have been no official substantiation to those rumors. There are also rumors that the price will be reduced significantly when the consumer version is released.

  • How much does Google Glass cost to manufacture?

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules


Scaled Question
This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. ?Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected price in U.S. dollars. ?Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual price will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. ?As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface. ?
Should the actual price be below $300, or above $1200, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%. For more information on Scaled questions, check out the SciCast blog article here:?http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Price will be announced by Google: www.google.com. If a consumer version of Google Glass is not released by the end of 2014, the question deadline will be extended. The ranges that make up the?possible answers in Safe Mode?will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range.

Fine Print

The price refers to the most basic version of Google Glass made available to consumers.

keywords: Flu, Region 9, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 9 (AZ, CA, HI, NV, AS, MP, FM, GU, MH, PW)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 9' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 9 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 9 is the highest. Region 9 is comprised of Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, American Samoa, Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Guam, Marshall Islands, and Republic of Palau.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

keywords: tactical eyewear, augmented reality, Google glass,weapons detection
name: Will the US Army issue augmented reality technology enabled contact lenses to detect enemy weaponry and IEDs on the battlefront by the end of 2015?
question_text:
?Augmented reality? (AR) is technology that superimposes a computer-generated image on a user?s view of the real world, hence providing a composite view. In commercial applications, smartphone apps using AR have revolutionized travel by superimposing data about hotels, restaurants, and tourist spots atop the real world. Google Glass further revolutionized the world of computing by making it wearable and hands-free, making AR more mainstream.

The US Army is working to equip dismounted soldiers on the battlefront with wearable computers like Google Glass to provide tactical information flow and protection from enemy forces in their environment. The Army is working with different organizations to come up with a head-mounted, see-through display technology that can increase soldiers? awareness of their surroundings by providing information about what is not visible to the naked eye. For example, this technology can help detect snipers hiding out of plain sight behind a building on the battlefront. Specifically, DARPA is working with a company called Innovega iOptics to develop AR-enabled contact lenses that project information in the field of vision near the eye, allowing the wearer to view data while still focusing on the more distant real-world scene.

http://www.afcea.org/content/?q=node/13002
http://trajectorymagazine.com/component/k2/item/1621-augmenting-reality.html
http://innovega-inc.com/defense-field-operations.php


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that the technology is being used on the ground, either as a standalone wearable or as a feature in another combat-ready wearable technology or device.

Fine Print

The contact lenses must be equipped with augmented reality (AR) technology that can superimpose a computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, graphics or GPS data on the user?s live view of the real world in a combat zone for enhanced battlefront intelligence.

keywords: Energy Storage, Smart Grid, Renewable Energy
name: Which form of grid level energy storage, other than pumped hydro, will have the largest contribution to the US energy grid by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Currently the main form of energy storage is pumped hydro storage.? Excess energy is used to pump water uphill and when demand increases the water is allowed to flow back downhill, turning a turbine and producing energy.? This method is only 70-75% efficient and has strict terrain limitations.? The simplicity of this method has led to widespread usage even as it prevents major improvements in efficiency or ease of implementation.? Of the 24.6GW of energy storage in the U.S 95% is pumped hydro storage.? The most likely candidates for superseding pumped hydro storage are the forms of energy storage that comprise the remaining 5% of energy storage: thermal, battery, compressed air, and flywheel.

Thermal energy storage is closely bound to renewable energy sources, particularly solar energy.? It is the practice of storing heat energy in materials such as molten salt during off hours and then using that heat energy to produce steam and turn a turbine during times of high demand.? Naturally, solar energy has a high heat component but other forms of energy production give off "waste" heat that could instead be stored with this method.

The classic method of energy storage is through the use of batteries.? While there are several different types of batteries that might be used for grid level storage, each possible type currently suffers some combination of high cost, poor scalability, short lifespan, and slow discharge rate.? Further advancements might alleviate the aforementioned drawbacks and enhance the benefits.

Compressed air storage is very similar to pumped hydro storage with the distinction that it is pressure rather than gravitational potential energy that is used to store the energy.? In addition to storing energy, the compression also heats up the air.? Under certain systems this heat is recycled and used to reheat the air during the operation of the energy raising the energy efficiency of this method.? Unfortunately, even with recycled heat energy this method maxes out at around 70% efficiency.

Flywheels store energy as rotational kinetic energy.? A mass rotates inside a vacuum and as energy is supplied the rpm increase.? To expend energy the process runs the other way, rotational speed is decreased to supply rotation to a turbine that is producing energy.? This form of storage tends to have a very long life span but it can be expensive and scaling up to grid level is still difficult with regards to the materials of the flywheel.

**Admin Update:?There are no restrictions on the sizes of rated power or the durations for which the storage must operate. Part of the goal with this was to get a sense of where grid level battery storage was headed so every status project will count aside from projects that have been decommissioned. In the interest of accuracy, unverified entries should not be counted.

More information:
Energy Overview
Thermal
Battery
Compressed Air Storage
Flywheels

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

A report on Grid Energy Storage from the Department of Energy or a comparison of the forms of grid level energy storage via the Department of Energy Global Energy Storage Database at http://www.energystorageexchange.org/.

The data will be retrived from the database in Jan 2016 and only data up to 12/31/2015 will be used.

keywords: Flu, Region 8, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 8 (CO, MO, ND, SD, UT, WY)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 8' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 8 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 8 is comprised of Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 8 is 1.3%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.
?

name: Will the CDC announce a new recommended treatment for gonorrhea by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Gonorrhea is a common sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by infection?with bacteria.??CDC estimates that, annually, 820,000 people in the United States get new gonorrheal infections, and less than half of these infections are detected and reported to CDC. In 2013, 333,004 cases of gonorrhea were reported to CDC.

Gonorrhea is adapting quickly to antibiotic treatments. In 2007, the antibiotic ciprofloxacin lost its CDC recommendation for treating gonorrhea because studies demonstrated that 13.8% of patient samples were resistant to the drug. Between 2007 and today, the CDC has had to change the recommended gonorrhea treatment twice by increasing the dosage of the antibiotic cephalosporin and changing the drug combination. So far, no cephalosporin-resistant gonorrhea cases have been identified in the United States, according to CDC. However, several such cases have been reported in other countries, such as Japan, France and Spain. The resistant bacteria are called by CDC ?an urgent threat?.??

  • Three Infections You Should Worry About More Than Ebola:?https://www.yahoo.com/health/three-infections-you-should-worry-about-more-than-ebola-98972940552.htm...
  • Genomic sequencing of?Neisseria gonorrhoeae?to respond to the urgent threat of antimicrobial-resistant gonorrhea:?http://www.cdc.gov/amd/project-summaries/treating-gonorrhea-threat.html
  • Super Gonorrhea Is On The Rise In The US:?http://www.businessinsider.com/ciprofloxacin-resistance-and-gonorrhea-incidence-2014-3
  • Gonorrhea is about to become impossible to treat:?http://www.theverge.com/2014/3/12/5500246/gonorrhea-is-about-to-become-impossible-to-treat

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The recommendation will be made by CDC?- www.cdc.gov


Fine Print

CDC refers to the Centers for Disease Control and PreventionA "new treatment" refers to a new drug treatment that is different from the current recommended treatment. The current CDC guidelines on gonorrhea treatment recommend using cephalosporin, along with a second antibiotic, either azithromycin or doxycycline. For patients with a severe allergy to cephalosporins, CDC recommends a single dose of azithromycin orally.

keywords: Sustainability, Energy, DOE, Commercial office space,
name: What will be the energy use intensity in Washington, DC for Office Type Buildings in 2014?
question_text:
Energy use intensity (EUI) accounts for all sources of energy that a building consumes throughout a year and is expressed in kBtu/sf/year.

Commercial buildings represent just under one-fifth of U.S. energy consumption, with office space, retail space, and educational facilitiesrepresenting about half of commercial sector energy consumption.

From http://energy.gov/eere/buildings/buildings-performance-database:

The Buildings Performance Database (BPD) unlocks the power of building energy performance data. The platform enables users to perform statistical analysis on an anonymous dataset of tens of thousands of commercial and residential buildings from across the country. Users can?compare performance trends among similar buildings to identify and prioritize cost-saving energy efficiency improvements and assess the range of likely savings from these improvements.

Relevant Links

  • http://energy.gov/eere/buildings/buildings-performance-database
  • http://buildingsdatabook.eren.doe.gov/ChapterIntro3.aspx
  • http://www.eia.gov/consumptioncommercial/index.cfm


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/01/2015

Resolution Source

We will use the Building Performance Database:
http://energy.gov/eere/buildings/buildings-performance-database

In order to have a valid result, all office type facilities must be included.

In February 2014, the peer group median EUI was 196 kBtu/sf/Year.



Fine Print

This question applies only to office type facilities located in the District Of Columbia.The energy use intensity is calculated as a peer group median.At this time, February 2014, the energy use intensity (represented as a peer group median) for office type facilities in DC is 196 kBtu/sf/year.These office type facilities are as follows ( as defined in the Building Performance Database): Office - Administrative or ProfessionalOffice - Bank or other financialOffice - GovernmentOffice - Medical non diagnosticOffice - Mixed useOffice - OtherOffice - UncategorizedA British Thermal Unit (BTU) is the amount of heat energy needed to raise the temperature of one pound of water by one degree F.1kBtu = 1,000 Btu1 W = 3.415 Btu/Hr1 cubic foot of natural gas is approximately 1,000 Btu.

name: When will one of the five major US broadcast networks first broadcast 4KTV over-the-air?
question_text:
In 2009, the US broadcast television system transitioned to all-digital broadcasting. This transition overlapped with the parallel transition to the use of high-definition television in the US. While digital television does not need to be in high-definition, many of commercial channels that are broadcast over the air are in fact broadcast in high definition.

Currently, the highest definition commercially used standard is 1920 ? 1080 pixels, often referred to as 1080 resolution. CBS, NBC, and PBS all broadcast using a form of 1080 resolution called 1080i. ABC and FOX user a lower resolution standard called 720p, which is a 1280 ? 720 pixel resolution (still considered high definition).

Recently, several consumer electronic manufacturers have begun to sell so-called 4K TV, or ultra high definition displays with native resolutions of?3840 ? 2160? pixels, or four times the pixel density of 1080 resolution. Broadcasting at this level would take up a larger share of broadcasters' constrained spectrum, and so it is unclear when or whether broadcasters might decide to broadcast in 4K TV.

For more information, see:

  • http://beta.techradar.com/us/news/television/4k-tv-broadcasts-are-on-the-way-but-there-are-problems-...
  • http://www.satellitetoday.com/regional/2014/09/22/directv-to-begin-4k-broadcasts-this-year/
  • http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2014/10/16/good-question-when-will-we-see-broadcasts-in-4k/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

If any of the five major US broadcasters (CBS, NBC, PBS, ABC, FOX) begin to broadcast in 4KTV they will announce such a transition publicly.

This question will resolve when any of these broadcasters begins 4KTV broadcasting, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

This question considers 4KTV broadcasts by the five major US broadcasters: CBS, NBC, PBS, ABC, and FOX

name: Will SpaceX achieve a soft landing at sea with its  resusable Falcon 9 rocket booster after resupplying the International Space Station?
question_text:
SpaceX, a private space and aeronautics company, has created an experimental vertical takeoff-vertical landing (VTVL) rocket booster system, capable of delivering payloads into orbit and then reentering the atmosphere in controlled flight before soft landing back to earth, without breaking up and disintegrating on the way down as most booster rockets do. This system, if proven viable, could dramatically reduce the cost of spaceflight by making expensive rocket boosters reusable.

SpaceX has been testing VTVL systems since 2012, beginning with low altitude launches and landings. In the first test mission of reusable rockets to space in September 2013, one of SpaceX's Falcon 9 rockets successfully reignited its first stage engines and survived reentry, but then subsequently spun out of control and broke up on impact with the Pacific Ocean. SpaceX plans to add landing legs the next test of the VTVL system, a resupply of the International Space Station currently scheduled from March 30 to April 4, which it believes will stabilize the rocket enough for a controlled decent down into a soft landing in the Atlantic Ocean. If successful, this mission will lead to further tests, including reentry on land.

  • Space X
  • MIT Technology Review - SpaceX set to launch world's first reusable booster
  • Space.com - SpaceX adds landing legs to Falcon 9 rocket for next launch, Elon Musk says
  • Wikipedia - Grasshopper (rocket)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/18/2014

Resolution Source

Both NASA and SpaceX will announce the results of the upcoming ISS resupply mission

  • www.spacex.com
  • http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/structure/launch/#.Uyn8fF7D4Y0

Fine Print

'Soft landing' is defined as a controlled landing where no serious damage to the spacecraft is incurred
short_name: Soft sea landing with resuable rocket

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Tennessee?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Tennessee, 54.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +8.3% from 2011 (46.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 53.4%, the "53.4%-56.8%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Solar energy, biomass, liquid fuel, isopropanol, photosynthesis
name: Will a bionic leaf, which uses bacteria to convert solar energy into liquid fuel, achieve an efficiency greater than 2% by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Scientists from a team spanning Harvard University's Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Harvard Medical School and the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University have created a system that uses bacteria to convert solar energy into a liquid fuel. Their work involves an "artificial leaf", which uses a catalyst to make sunlight split water into hydrogen and oxygen, with a bacterium engineered to convert carbon dioxide plus hydrogen into the liquid fuel isopropanol.

The team's immediate challenge is to increase the bionic leaf's ability to translate solar energy to biomass by optimizing the catalyst and the bacteria. Their goal is 5 percent efficiency, compared to nature's rate of 1 percent efficiency for photosynthesis to turn sunlight into biomass.?"We're almost at a 1 percent efficiency rate of converting sunlight into isopropanol," Harvard professor?Daniel?Nocera said. "There have been 2.6 billion years of evolution, and Pam (Silver) and I working together a year and a half have already achieved the efficiency of photosynthesis".

For more information:

  • Bionic leaf: Researchers use bacteria to convert solar energy into liquid fuel:?http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/02/150209161423.htm
  • Efficient solar-to-fuels production from a hybrid microbial?water-splitting catalyst system,?Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 2015; 201424872 DOI:?http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2015/02/06/1424872112

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when the discovery is published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science, or in the Proceedings of National Academy of Science www.pnas.org.?The development may also be reported on?science news websites such as?http://www.sciencedaily.com/,?http://phys.org/, and?http://www.gizmag.com/

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever?comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

choices_field_0: Sri Lanka will have more threatened species than Thailand
choices_field_1: Thailand will have more threatened species than Sri Lanka
choices_field_2: The two countries will have the same number of threatened species
name: Which country, Thailand or Sri Lanka, will have more threatened species on the next published IUCN Red List of Threatened Species?
question_text:
The InternationalUnion for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) maintains and publishes the IUCN RedList of Threatened Species, widely recognized as the most comprehensive andobjective global approach for evaluating the conservation status of plant andanimal species. In order to produce the Red List, IUCN draws upon a network ofscientists and partner organizations working in almost every country in theworld.

The Red Listidentified species as threatened if they are classified by the IUCN asCritically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), or Vulnerable (VU). Species canalso be classified as extinct (EX) or extinct in the wild (EW); or in one of severalnon-threatened categories: Lower Risk/conservation dependent (LR/cd), NearThreatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD), Least Concern (LC).

In Red Listversion 2013.2 (21 November 2013), the IUCN reports 571 threatened species forSri Lanka and 573 for Thailand. The IUCN updates its list at least annually, soa new update should be available and published soon.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved when the IUCN publishes its next update to the RedList. The current list is version 2013.2 from 21 November 2013. The next updated list, once published, will be available in Table 5 and linked to here:? http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics








Fine Print

IUCN definitions are being used for endangered species, per the discussion in the Background discussion.
short_name: IUCN Sri Lanka vs Thailand Threatened Species

choices_field_10: University of Southern California, Information Sciences Institute
choices_field_5: Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences and Wright State University
name: What team will score the highest in NIST?s 2015 OpenMT Arabic-To-English machine translation evaluation?
question_text:
Machine rendered translation of one human language to another is an active area of research in computer science. The benefits of being able to automatically translate from one language to another are enormous, but so are the challenges. Structurally, human languages differ in their morphology, semantics, syntax, and grammar. In addition to these structural differences, the prevalence of idiom and the contextually dependent interpretation of meaning also contribute significant difficulty to machine translation (MT).

In order to support MT research and help advance the state of the art, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) runs the Open Machine Translation Evaluation (OpenMT). Machine translation teams from around the world test their translation technology on a defined set of non-English text sources and the effectiveness of these competing technologies is evaluated. The list of answer choices for this question (see the Make a Forecast tab) is made up of participant teams in the 2012 evaluation, the most recent one completed.

The 2015 competition will be evaluating Arabic-to-English and Chinese-to-English translation, and include evaluation of machine translation of informal text, such as SMS text, as well as recorded conversational text, both of which differ significantly from formal written text. NIST is considering use of 4 metrics to score each team?s translation (BLUE, METEOR, TER, and HyTER) as well as human assessment. These metrics are commonly used in scoring machine translation and depend on such analyses as comparing machine translations to reference translations. Details of the 2015 OpenMT evaluation, including timeline, data used, and evaluation metrics are available in the links below. Evaluation results for the 2015 evaluation, which is already underway, are expected by the end of January 2015.

For more background, see:

  • http://research.google.com/pubs/MachineTranslation.html
  • http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt.cfm
  • http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt15.cfm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2015

Resolution Source

NIST will report the results of its 2015 OpenMT evaluation here:? http://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/mig/openmt15.cfm

Fine Print

NIST has not yet indicated which evaluation metrics it will use, so in resolving this question, scores will be considered in this order: (1) BLUE, (2) METEOR, (3) TER, and (4) HyTER. That is to say, in the scenario where more than one of these metrics is used, the earliest metric on the list will be used to resolve the question.

name: Will Metaio have a commerically available version of Thermal Touch by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Metaio is developing a headset that combines thermal imaging with augmented reality.? This essentially allows a user with the headset to turn any surface into a 'touch screen.'? The Augmented Reality blog lists its applications:? "Imagine pushing directions to your device simply by touching a static map in a shopping mall, building complex, or airport; children could bring play to new levels and launch digital content directly from their toys; design professionals could visualize their digital and 3D creations on their real world counterparts; and service technicians could pull up information just by touching an object in real life."? It may also be applied to smartphones and other wearable technologies.

They are expected to present a prototype at the Inside AR - Augmented Reality Conference on July 8 2014.? This leads to the question of when the product will be commercially available?

Relevant Links:

  • Thermal Touch Can Turn Any Surface Into an Augmented Reality Touchscreen
  • Metaio Unveils Thermal Imaging R&D for Future Use

name: At the end of 2015, will there be at least 3 open clinical trials in the US examining the use of antisense therapy to treat leukemia?
question_text:
Antisense therapy is a form of treatment for genetic disorders or infections. When the genetic sequence of a particular gene is known to be causative of a particular disease, it is possible to synthesize a strand of nucleic acid (DNA, RNA or a chemical analogue) that will bind to the messenger RNA (mRNA) produced by that gene and inactivate it, effectively turning that gene "off". This is because mRNA has to be single stranded for it to be translated. Alternatively, the strand might be targeted to bind a splicing site on pre-mRNA and modify the exon content of an mRNA.

Currently there is one open clinical trial?in the US examining the use of?antisense therapy?to treat leukemia, according to the NIH clinical trials database:?http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=antisense&recr=Open


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

NIH Clinical Trials website:?http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=antisense&recr=Open

Fine Print

Clinical trials are determined to be 'open' if they are defined as such by NIH's clinicaltrials.gov website. This may include trials at various stages, including recruiting participants (or yet to do so), underway, or yet to publish results.

keywords: U.S., Oranges, Value, Production, USD, 2013-2014, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total value of U.S. orange production for the 2013-2014 marketing season, in thousands of USD?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Citrus Fruits Summary' following the conclusion of the marketing season in September. This full-text report contains the annual summary, by state and citrus fruit crop, of acreage, yield, production, utilization (fresh and processed), price, and value of the current year crop ad revised previous two years' crop.?
  • The value of?U.S. orange production for the 2012-2013 marketing season totaled 2,063,549 in thousands USD.
  • The value of orange production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as oranges are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average value of production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in value of?productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary'.?

Total value of orange production is reported in thousands of USD, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. orange production' includes Valencia, Early, Midseason, and Navel varieties.

The '2013-2014 marketing season' for Valencia oranges ?begins 01/01/2013 and ends 12/20/2013. The '2013-2014 marketing season' for Early, Midseason, and Navel oranges begins 09/25/2013 and ends 06/15/2014.

'Total value of production' is the 'packinghouse-door equivalent'. 'Packinghouse-door' equivalent is defined as all fruit, regardless of methods of sale, converted to a price it would have brought if the entire crop, or segment thereof being priced, had been sold at the packinghouse-door.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary' that is published annually in September.


Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Citrus Fruits:?http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/MannUsda/viewDocumentInfo.do?documentID=1031
  • USDA NASS Citrus Fruits Summary 2013:?http://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/Todays_Reports/reports/cfrt0913.pdf
  • Honeybee Colony Collapse Disorder:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony_collapse_disorder
  • NRDC Honeybee Pollination:?http://www.nrdc.org/wildlife/animals/files/bees.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service

Through this process, a private company?transforms into a public company. Initial public offerings are used by companies to raise expansion capital, to possibly monetize?the investments of early private investors, and to become publicly traded enterprises.More information: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initial_public_offering

keywords: Avian Flu, Research, Infectious disease, Influenza, Gain of function, chemistry
name: Will scientists create a fully air-transmissible, mammalian-infectious strain of avian influenza in a laboratory setting by the end of 2014?
question_text:
Many influenza researchers around the world are gravely concerned about the re-emergence of H5N1 in bird populations in Asia and the unprecedented human case fatality rate. While the global human population is currently protected because H5N1 rarely infects humans and cannot easily spread, some scientists are attempting to preempt a pandemic and uncover key transformations that would make H5N1 significantly more virulent. Generally, these experiments are classified as ?gain-of-function? research. The ultimate aims of these experiments are to improve public health and increase scientific knowledge.

In 2011, two landmark papers were submitted to the scientific journals Science and Nature. These studies independently identified several amino acid mutations in the viral surface protein hemagglutinin that enables aerosol transmission between ferrets. Even though these studies took different approaches and arrived at the same mutations, these may not be the only, or most effective, mutations that enable aerosol transmission. These mutagenesis (artificial mutation) studies attempt to simulate antigenic drift.? Subsequent studies have shown that recombination between previous human influenza strains and H5N1 could also enable aerosol transmission. These studies suggest antigenic shift could result in the emergence of a pandemic H5N1 strain.?

Since then, scientists have shifted their concern to high pathogenic avian influenza strain?H7N9 (a variant of H5N1) as well as other strains including H3N2.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

The results must be published in a peer-reviewed journal and accessible on the US National Library of Medicine and National Health Institutes'?PubMed.gov database by Dec. 31, 2014.

Fine Print

"Mammalian-infectious viruses" are viruses that can efficiently infect a mammalian host and cause disease before being cleared by the host's immune system (assuming the host has not been previously immunized or vaccinated against the pathogen). "Air-transmissible" means that sputum or respiratory droplets from an infected mammal that contain virus particles will infect other mammals of the same species when the sputum or droplets are expelled from the mammalian host and subsequently inhaled by a healthy mammal. Also, this question asks about a virus that is not self-limiting meaning that given an ideal population of unvaccinated individuals, the virus can be passed from person to person ad infinitum. (Currently, most strains of circulating bird flu do not infect mammals and when they do, they are not air-transmissible. We refer to these viruses as "self-limiting.")

name: Will one of the top 5 insurance companies in California offer a liability insurance package for driverless vehicles cheaper than the equivalent package for a human driven car by an under 25 year-old male driver by July 1st, 2016?
question_text:
"For decades, insurers have invested heavily in their abilities to assess individual risk and price accordingly. As one CEO told me, ?Insurers with better information make smarter underwriting decisions and slaughter those with less; that?s the nature of the business.? But driverless technology will take human error out of the equation and make underwriting less important. The basis of competition will shift to other aspects of the business, such as customer relationships, claims processing, expense management and distribution."

Today?s market leaders have the expertise necessary to reimagine what insurance in the world of driverless cars could look like. They have the trusted brands, strong customer relationships and operating capabilities to smooth and even accelerate the transition to technologies that promise to save tens of thousands of lives, hundreds of thousands of injuries and hundreds of billions of dollars in accident-related losses each year. That?s not a bad place from which to start inventing the future."

Currently, California requires manufactures to obtain an instrument of insurance, safety bond, or proof of self-insurance in the amount of 5 million dollars?prior to the start of testing a driverless car?in the state.

Since every state mandates?some level of?auto insurance, this market is poised to change dramatically when driverless cars enter the market. It would be expected that some major insurance companies would jump right?into this maelstrom.

For more information:
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/chunkamui/2013/03/28/will-auto-insurers-survive-their-collision-with-dri...
  • geer.tinho.net/geer.uncc.9x13.txt



This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2016

Resolution Source

The insurance rates would be publicly available on the insurers website. Additionally, an announcement of coverage is expected from?a company press release and from?major news sources.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.?

Fine Print

The top 5 auto insurance companies in California are: StateFarm, AAA, Allstate, Mercury Insurance Group, and Mid Century Insurance Company. This question will be resolved if a liability insurance plan for a driverless car is available to the general public and is of equal or lesser cost than an equivalent liability insurance plan for a human driven car from the same company. The location, type of vehicle, driver demographic (an under 25 year-old male), and coverage must be equivalent.

name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "Trends in invasive alien species" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

Useful Links

  • https://www.cbd.int/cop/

name: Will an arrangement of qubits be created resulting in a gate error rate less than or equal to 1 in 1,000 be created by 1 January 2016?
question_text:
Several hurdles must be overcome before quantum computing becomes a widely available. One hurdle has the unreliability of quantum hardware compared to classical hardware. To address this hurdle, University of California at Santa Barbara?s Barends et al. arranged a unique configuration of qubits to create a reliable system.? The group created cross-shaped qubits (?Xmons?). The team then placed five Xmons in a single row where each qubit talked to its nearest neighbor.? With this arrangement, the group achieved an average single-qubit gate fidelity of 99.92% and a two-qubit gate fidelity of up to 99.4%

To build a quantum computer, a two-dimensional array of qubits will need to have a per-step fidelity threshold of about 99%.? However, to make quantum computer widely commercially viable, the error rate should be less than or equal to 1 in 1,000 (99.9% per-step fidelity rate). ?

Links and sources

  • Superconducting quantum circuits at the surface code threshold for fault tolerance http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v508/n7497/full/nature13171.html
  • Superconducting qubit array points the way to quantum computers http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2014-04/uoc--sqa042314.php

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

Publication in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

?error rate less than or equal to 1 in 1,000? = less than or equal to a 99.9% per-step fidelity rate.

name: In January 2015, will Beijing's monthly average PM2.5 concentration be below 110 micrograms per cubic meter?
question_text:
Historical data collected by the US Embassy in Beijing since 2008 indicates that?the pollutant concentrations of?tiny particulate matter known as PM2.5 are higher in the winter months, particularly in January and February.?From 2008 to 2014, the average PM2.5 level in Beijing in January was approximately 115 micrometers per cubic meter. In January 2014, PM2.5 concentration spiked numerous times, hitting levels of 350, 500, 671, and even a record-shattering 723 micrograms per cubic meter.?

To combat the air pollution?problem, the Chinese?government announced?a ?name and shame? campaign near the end of 2013 to single out the cities that fell the furthest behind their required reductions. And in early 2014, China tightened those required cuts?to anywhere from 5 percent to 25 percent per year depending on the city. The question is whether?the new?laws?will lead to a reduction in?Beijing's PM2.5?pollution levels in January 2015.

  • http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/03/26/3419489/china-smog-cities-failing/
  • http://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2014/07/03/when-air-quality-in-beijing-and-shanghai-is-least-awfu...
  • http://www.stateair.net/web/historical/1/1.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2015

Resolution Source

Data obtained?from the US Department of State Air Quality Program:?http://www.stateair.net/web/historical/1/1.html
Hourly averages are reported on the US Embassy's twitter page:?https://twitter.com/beijingair

Fine Print

The question will be resolved based on statistics published by the U.S. State Department.Beijing?s air pollution levels are published by the U.S. State Department, which gathers the data via a monitor installed at the U.S. Embassy. Hourly data is reported on the Embassy's twitter page https://twitter.com/beijingair.The State Department cautions the data hasn?t been fully verified or validated, as the readings come from one isolated monitoring station.

name: Will an unmanned aerial vehicle collide with a commercial airliner over U.S. airspace before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), drones, or?remotely piloted aircraft?(RPAs) are gaining global prominence as many companies, notably?Amazon?and Google?are exploring the possibility of?delivering packages through the air.?This commercial interest is in addition?to drones currently used for government applications. Due to the rise in?this interest and investment, it is likely that?airspace will become more highly populated,?increasing the probability of a collision between a UAV and a commercial airliner.

"Unmanned aircraft are flying now in the national airspace system under very controlled conditions. Operations potentially range from ground level to above 50,000 feet, depending on the specific type of aircraft. However, UAS operations are currently not authorized in Class B airspace, which exists over major urban areas and contains the highest density of manned aircraft in the National Airspace System."

While the use of commercial UAVs are highly regulated by the FAA, there is a provision in the policy which allows research into UAV use for governmental functions.?
??
FAA regulations for drones in the United States can be found here:?

  • https://www.faa.gov/uas/
  • https://www.faa.gov/uas/regulations_policies/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

A collision will be reported in a?press release. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

This question refers to all UAS (Unmanned Aircraft Systems) as defined by the FAA which includes model aircraft.

keywords: Facebook, Twitter, China, Internet, Shanghai Free Trade Zone
name: Will Facebook and/or Twitter be available in China's Shanghai Free Trade Zone before June 2014?
question_text:
In an article published in September 2013,?by South China Morning Post, anonymous government sources indicated the Shanghai free trade zone would be taking bids for licenses to provide internet services within the zone,?and lift a ban on websites likes Facebook and Twitter.?

Another article published in September 2013, by Global Times,?indicated the Shanghai free trade zone would have internet management equivalent to that of the rest of China.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome and condition will be resolved based on reporting from one or more of the following sources: BBC News or Reuters or Economist Online (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/ or http://www.reuters.com/ or http://www.economist.com). If nothing is reported in these sources, then "status quo" outcome will be assumed, (i.e. Facebook and Twitter are not made available in China's Shanghai Free Trade Zone, no new foreign telecommunications firm wins a license in the SFTZ). Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed (e.g. RFERL), provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from BBC News, Reuters, or Economist Online. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, Administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.?

Resolution Sources

Outcome will be resolved based on reports from Facebook Profile webpage and/or Twitter official account, or from any of the following sources (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/ or http://www.reuters.com/ or http://www.economist.com)

Fine Print

For a "yes" resolution to occur, either Facebook or Twitter or both must be available to all residents of the Free Trade Zone (not just people with Virtual Private Networks (VPNs)) by the date of the question.

"Available" means that all residents of the SFTZ will have full and unlimited access to Facebook and/or Twitter websites. The access must be uninterrupted and uncensored for at least 48 consecutive hours. If the residents of the SFTZ are given access for at least 48 consecutive hours, but the sites are later blocked, it would still produce a "yes" outcome.

China's Shanghai Free Trade Zone means China Shanghai Pilot Free Trade Zone.

"Before" should be interpreted to mean at or prior to the end (23:59:59 ET) of the previous day.?

Useful Information and Links

  • China to lift ban on Facebook - but only within Shanghai free-trade zone
  • No special access to banned websites at free trade zone in Shanghai
  • China (Shanghai) Pilot Free Trade Zone

Related Organizations or Individuals

Shanghair Pilot-Free Trade Zone: http://en.shftz.gov.cn/homepage.asp

name: In which of the following subfields will the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics be awarded?
question_text:
Established in 1900, the Nobel Foundation awards the annual Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Economic Sciences, Literature, and Peace. Recipients must be living, and in no case may the prize be divided among more than three persons.

Between 1901 and 2013, 561 prizes have been awarded. In some years, some prizes have not been awarded: the latest was 1972 when the Peace Prize was not awarded.

Resolution Criteria

The Nobel Prize Committee must determine and announce a winner of the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics.

The question moderator reserves the right, if necessary, to refine or clarify the definitions of the sub-fields cited in this question to conform to more authoritative or accepted taxonomies of science.

keywords: Dark Matter, WIMPs, SuperCDMS, CDMS, SNOLAB, WIMP
name: Will the SuperCDMS dark matter detector at SNOLAB start to hunt for WIMPs before the end of 2017?
question_text:
In July 2014,?the U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Science and the National Science Foundation announced support for a suite of upcoming experiments to search for dark matter that will be many times more sensitive than those currently deployed. One of the?DOE- and NSF-approved projects is called SuperCDMS-SNOLAB, to be built at SNOLAB in Sudbury, Canada.?SuperCDMS?plans to?use hockey puck?sized disks of solid germanium to detect WIMPs through heat and electrical signals.?Development is underway, and it is hoped construction will begin in 2014.

  • http://news.sciencemag.org/funding/2014/07/two-big-dark-matter-experiments-gain-u-s-support
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryogenic_Dark_Matter_Search
  • http://www.labcanada.com/news/international-dark-matter-experiment-comes-to-snolab/1003167573/?&er=N...



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

Information and news will be available from:
SuperCDMS webpage:?http://cdms.berkeley.edu/
SNOLAB:https://www.snolab.ca/

Fine Print

Dark matters are believed to be made of difficult-to-detect particles called Weakly Interacting Massive Particles or WIMPs, which usually pass through ordinary matter without leaving a trace.Cryogenic Dark Matter Search or CDMS, uses an array of semiconductor detectors at millikelvin temperatures, to detect the interactions of WIMP dark matter with terrestrial materials. The "super" in the SuperCDMS refers to a larger, improved detector than the earlier version.

keywords: cancer stem cell, Tarceva, erlotinib hydrochloride, Velcade, bortezomib, clinical trial
name: Will a clinical study into the use of Velcade to overcome resistance to cancer drug Tarceva in advanced cancer patients start recruiting participants before the end of 2014?
question_text:
Drugs most commonly used to treat breast, lung, and pancreatic cancers eventually become ineffective and actually encourage drug-resistance and tumor growth through the development of cancer stem cells. A new study from the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) has found that cancer tumor cells develop properties similar to stem cells, which enable them to develop drug-resistance and survive throughout the body. Cancer stem cells, which cause tumors to grow, are similar to embryonic stem cells because they proliferate and spread throughout the body.?

The drug Velcade is already approved for treatment of relapsed multiple myeloma. Laboratory studies showed that Velcade also seems to resensitize cancer cells that had become resistant to another drug called Tarceva, a cancer drug that cancer stem cells selectively resist. Tarceva is commonly used to treat some lung and pancreatic cancers. Studies?suggest that Velcade reverses cancer stem cells properties and drug-resistance, restoring Tarceva's effectiveness.

  • Stem cells increase in cancer patients, possibly from drug resistance: http://guardianlv.com/2014/04/stem-cells-increase-in-cancer-patients-possibly-from-drug-resistance/
  • Study of Erlotinib in Combination With Bortezomib: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00895687?term=%22velcade%22+AND+%22tarceva%22&rank=1

?




Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Case clinical trial data can be found?at http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00895687?term=%22velcade%22+AND+%22tarceva%22&rank=1
short_name: Clinical study of cancer drug resistance

keywords: Flu, Region 3, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 3 (DE, DC, MD, PA, VA, WV)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 3' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 3 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 3 is comprised of Delaware, District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 3 is 2.0%.

In the event the end occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Minnesota?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Minnesota, 59.4% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +3.9% from 2011 (55.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 58.5%, the "58.5%-61.9%" range will be deemed correct.

name: When will a prototype hydrogen car use nanorod-based hydrogen sensors?
question_text:
Nanorods are artificially fabricated nanoscale objects synthesized from metals and semiconductor materials that have a range of potential applications in medical diagnostics, cancer therapy, solar cells, sensors, metamaterials, and optical devices and displays.

Nanorod-based sensors have been proposed for hydrogen detection in fuel-cell vehicles. The hydrogen used to power fuel-cell vehicles is highly explosive, but also colorless and odorless and therefore difficult to detect. Fuel cell cars are still in the development phase, with no commercially available vehicles currently available to the public, but any future commercially available car would require hydrogen sensors to detect leaks in the hydrogen fuel tank. Gold nanorods have been shown to be effective hydrogen sensors, and anticipated for use in fuel-cell cars.

For more background, see:

  • http://nanotechweb.org/cws/article/tech/56701
  • http://news.ufl.edu/archive/2006/05/for-the-future-hydrogen-economy-a-tiny-self-powered-sensor.html
  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22740090

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An auto manufacturer producing a prototype fuel cell car with nanorod hydrogen sensors would announce the technical basis of its detection system, and its use would be covered by the science and technology press.
