keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, M?ller-Taubenberger
name: What place will the M?ller-Taubenberger Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The?M?ller-Taubenberger Team's Strategy to Win the Race:

We?re sending a low-adhesive mutant into battle! Instead of forming excessive adhesion complexes, these cells dash?through any maze, while their fellow competitors are still busy de-adhering.

Dicty related?research going on at the?M?ller-Taubenberger?Lab:

1. Dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton in Dictyostelium
In order to analyze the dynamics of the actin filament system cells, we express fluorescent fusion proteins as specific probes for the actin cytoskeletonin Dictyostelium and use different microscopic techniques to explore these cells. We also investigate different actin regulators like for instance the actin-binding proteins coronin and Aip1 (actin-interacting protein 1). We have characterized the in vivo functions of these two regulators, and have shown that coronin and Aip1 are important for maintaining the balance of actin filament dynamics and the spatiotemporal control of actin turnover. Furthermore, we are interested in the functional characterization of nuclear actin-related proteins (Arps) and actin variants.

2. Regulation of cytokinesis in Dictyostelium
Cell division is a well-coordinated process that involves mitosis bringing about division of the genetic material, followed by cleavage of the cell body. Our work aims at a more detailed understanding of these processes in particular the role of the cytoskeleton and the regulatory components. We have identified several actin-binding proteins that are contributing to proper cytokinesis. In addition, we have described a SIN (septation initiation network)-homologous pathway which is involved in cytokinesis in Dictyostelium.

3. Fluorescent probes for live cell imaging studies in Dictyostelium
The introduction of fluorescent proteins as molecular tags has opened a wide field of applications in order to monitor the location, redistribution, and movement of proteins in living cells. GFP and its variants can be fused to many proteins without altering their intrinsic functions. Over the past years, we have developed a number of different probes that are suitable for live cell imaging studies.

4. Cytoskeletal dynamics in migrating leukocytes and Dictyostelium amoebae
Directed migration of leukocytes or Dictyostelium amoebae requires a finely tuned organization of the cytoskeleton. To analyze this in more detail, we exploit the wealth of data available from Dictyostelium mutants to understand the motile behavior of leukocytes at the cell biological, biochemical and structural level. The focus is on filamins and formins, two important protein classes in the actin system, and their roles in both amoebae and leukocytes. Filamins and formins are major players especially in leukocyte motility, chemotactic movement, cell polarity, cell spreading and adhesion. In particular, we are interested in filamin and formin binding partners and the analysis of inter-cytoskeletal interactions (e.g. filamin/actin/vimentin, formin/actin/microtubules) in leukocytes. Furthermore, we employ different types of microfluidic devices for the detailed analysis of directed cell migration of Dictyostelium amoebae and leukocytes under different conditions. (Supported by SFB 914; Project A7 together with Michael Schleicher)

Useful Links
  • Link to?M?ller-Taubenberger?Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

name: Will NASA spacecraft Dawn confirm the existence of an ocean of liquid water on Ceres, the dwarf planet in the asteroid belt?
question_text:
NASA's?Dawn spacecraft should enter orbit around Ceres ? the largest object in the main asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter ? on March 6, 2015.??The?dwarf planet?Ceres ? which is about 590 miles (950 kilometers) wide ? is thought to have a lot of water, based on its low overall density.?However, it's unclear at the moment how much, if any, of this water is in liquid form.?Earlier this year,?scientists announced the discovery of water-vapor emission from Ceres.

When it reaches the dwarf planet in March, Dawn will?map Ceres' surface in detail and beam home a great deal of information about the body's geology and thermal conditions before the scheduled end of its prime mission in July 2015.

  • NASA Spacecraft Approaching Dwarf Planet Ceres:?http://news.yahoo.com/nasa-spacecraft-approaching-dwarf-planet-ceres-163731951.html
  • Could the Dwarf Planet Ceres Support Life??http://www.space.com/28068-dwarf-planet-ceres-life-dawn-mission.html



Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/31/2015

Resolution Source

NASA Dawn mission:?http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/dawn/main/#.VKRVlSvF_94

This question will resolve as "no" if an announcement is not made?by NASA by the resolution date.

Fine Print

The confirmed existence of either a surface or subsurface ocean of liquid water will cause the question to resolve positively.

name: How close will the closest near Earth object that is tracked by NASA come to Earth between April 1st and May 30th 2014?
question_text:
The U.S. NationalAeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), through its Near Earth ObjectProgram, monitors so-called Near-Earth Objects (NEOs). NEOs are comets andasteroids that have been nudged by the gravitational attraction of nearbyplanets into orbits that allow them to enter the Earth's vicinity.

NASA?s NEOprogram tracks objects from a variety of observation points around the globe,including the Catalina Sky Survey (CSS) and Spacewatch near Tucson Arizona; theLINEAR project near Socorro New Mexico; Pans-STARRS1 on Maui, Hawaii; and LONEOSnear Flagstaff, Arizona.

As NASAdiscovers significant new NEOs it names and tracks them, and then reports theiractual closest approach distances to Earth once those closest approach distanceshave occurred. Note that these data are reported only for objects of sufficientsize to be named and tracked by NASA; they exclude the large number of smallmeteorites that strike the Earth?s atmosphere every day and harmlessly ablate inthe atmosphere.

Sixty-sixNASA-tracked NEOs reached their closest approach to Earth between January 3,2014 and February 11, 2014 (including only objects that came within 0.1 astronomicalunit of Earth). Of these, the closest came within 0.3 lunar distances fromEarth, and 13 came within 0.5 lunar distances. This question asks what theclosest approach reported by NASA will be for all NEOs that reach their closestapproach to Earth between April1st and May 30th 2014.

NASA reportsactual closest approach data for NEOs here:?http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/neo_caMore can belearned about NASA?s NEO program here:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/index.html

The population of comets and asteroids in the solar system is believed to be quite constant, as they were mostly created during the formation of the solar system some 4.6 billion years ago.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/30/2014

Resolution Source

NASA reportsup-to-date closest approach data on the webpage http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/neo_ca, and this question will beresolved by evaluating the closest approach for the 60-day period of April 1stto May 30th 2014 on May 30, 2014.

name: Will Open Garden offer an encryption feature for its peer-to-peer networking app FireChat by the end of 2014?
question_text:
Pro-democracy protestors in Hong Kong are using FireChat to resist centralized surveillance of internet by the government. The messaging app created by Open Garden can send and receive messages without an internet connection. It uses peer-to-peer Bluetooth and Wi-Fi Direct connections to link to other FireChat enabled devices. If you get enough of those devices in the same area, the result is a massive mesh network in which every handset can message every other handset in daisy-chain fashion - without ever sending a packet over an internet router.?

One current?limitation of FireChat is that it?requires users to register with an email address and user name, and it does not encrypt messages in transit or on the device. Open Garden has been working on an encryption feature for FireChat, but have not confirmed its release date.

  • Why Hong Kong protesters are using Firechat for peer-to-peer communications on their mobiles: https://www.yahoo.com/tech/why-hong-kong-protesters-are-using-firechat-for-98734282244.html
  • Could this app create a free, secret web? http://www.forbes.com/sites/parmyolson/2014/06/05/could-this-app-create-a-free-secret-web/
  • Schneier on Security: Firechat https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2014/10/firechat.html
  • Firechat prepares encryption feature: http://www.forbes.com/sites/parmyolson/2014/09/29/firechat-prepares-encryption-feature-as-it-drives-...
?

12/31/2014

question_text:
Battelle?and R&D Magazine?annually forecast global research and development (R&D) funding as?a public service for use by policy makers, corporate research leaders, researchers, educators, and economists. The latest forecast titled 2014 Global R&D Funding Forecast?predicts?US$1,618?billion in 2014, an increase of 3.9% over 2013. ?

The U.S.?National Science Foundation?estimates worldwide R&D expenditures totaled an estimated $1,435 billion in 2011, the latest NSF data available. The corresponding NSF estimate for 5 years earlier in 2006 is $1,051 billion. Ten years earlier, in 2001, it was $753 billion. ?By these figures, growth in total global R&D has been rapid, averaging 6.4% annually over the 5-year period and 6.7% annually over the 10-year period. ?

Fine Print

Foreign currencies are converted to U.S. dollars through purchasing power parity (PPP) to compute R&D expenditures. The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the reported value is US$1,639 Billion, the "Between US$1,639 - US$1,660 billion" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will a report of a high temperature superconductor achieving a transition temperature of 195 Kelvin or higher be published before the start of 2020?
question_text:
Superconductors conduct electricity without resistance below a certain temperature.? Superconductivity was first discovered in 1911 in metal mercury below 4 Kelvin (-269.15 degree Celsius). For decades after that it was thought that superconductivity could only happen at extremely low temperatures, close to absolute zero (0 degree Kelvin, or -273 degree Celsius). Since 1987, however, scientists have discovered several compounds whose resistance drops down to zero at much higher temperatures. The highest transition temperature at which a compound becomes a?superconductor is currently at 138 Kelvin (-135 degree Celsius). For comparison, the sublimation point of dry ice is 195 Kelvin (-78.5 degree Celsius).

Researchers from Cambridge University have recently made a breakthrough in identifying the origin of superconductivity in high-temperature superconductors. They found that ripples of electrons, known as charge density waves or charge order, created twisted "pockets" of electrons in these materials, from which superconductivity emerges.? "By identifying other materials which have similar properties, hopefully it will help us find new superconductors at higher and higher temperatures, even perhaps materials which are superconductors at room temperature, which would open up a huge range of applications," said Dr Sebastian of the Cavendish Laboratory.

  • http://phys.org/news/2014-06-superconducting-secrets-years.html#inlRlv
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconductivity
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-temperature_superconductivity






Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

The discovery of high temperature superconductors would be reported by major scientific journals such as Nature (www.nature.com), Science (www.sciencemag.org), etc.

Fine Print

The critical temperature is the temperature at which materials become superconductors with zero electrical resistance.

name: Will perovskite solar cells prepared with room temperature processes enter the commercial market by the end of 2016?
question_text:
In December 2013, it was that a group of researchers from the University of Valencia has developed a thin film low cost photovoltaic device with high power conversion. The solar cell developed by the researchers from the University's Institut de Ciencia Molecular (ICMol) consists of a thin perovkite film sandwiched in between two very thin organic semiconductors. The hybrid organic-inorganic perovskite material can be prepared easily with room temperature process and at low cost. The power conversion efficiency of this kind of solar cell can reach 12%.

Resolution Sources

Nature Photonics

Also material science news sources:
http://www.materials360online.com/

http://www.sciencedaily.com/news/matter_energy/materials_science/

http://phys.org/chemistry-news/materials-science/

Fine Print

A perovskite structure is any material with the same type of crystal structure as calcium titanium oxide (CaTiO3), known as the perovskite structure, or XIIA2+VIB4+X2?3 with the oxygen in the face centers. Perovskites take their name from this compound, which was first discovered in the Ural mountains of Russia by Gustav Rose in 1839 and is named after Russian mineralogist L. A. Perovski (1792?1856).

Useful Information and Links

  • Perovskite-Based Solar Cells?

name: Will NASA land a telepresence robot on Venus by 2020?
question_text:
NASA space explorers use telepresence to operate robots on Mars while safely tucked inside orbiting habitat. This technology could also potentially find use in investigating Venus in the future. In the 2000s, the Venus In-Situ Explorer (VISA) was proposed to NASA's New Frontiers program. Although the mission is no longer listed as a New Frontiers program candidate as of 2014, the Principal investigators have kept refining and promoting the mission concept.

How telerobotics could help humanity explore space: http://www.space.com/15585-space-exploration-telerobotics-technology.html

keywords: UAV, unmanned aerial vehicle, QinetiQ, Zephyr, Phantom Eye
name: Will an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) break the world endurance record of 14 days (set in 2010 by QinetiQ's Zephyr) before the end of 2015?
question_text:
The Zephyr 7 holds the official endurance record for an unmanned aerial vehicle for its flight from July 9 to July 23, 2010, lasting 336 hours and 22 minutes (14 days). Record claims have been verified by the Federation Aeronaution International (FAI) for both duration and altitude (21,562 meters/70745 ft).

Currently Boeing is testing a demonstrator Phantom Eye, a high altitude, long endurance (HALE) UAV, designed to achieve the goal of more than 60,000 feet in altitude and to stay airborne for seven to ten days. Titan Aerospace is working on building a solar powered high altitude, light weight drone, Solara 50, that is designed to fly at an altitude of 65,000 ft for five years nonstop. Titan was recently purchased by Google.

FAI Record ID #16052: http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=16052
Status update: Boeing's Phantom Eye takes a huge step forward: http://www.boeing.com/boeing/Features/2014/02/bds_phantomeye_status_02_12_14.page#.UvvYW8rVawk.twitt...

keywords: Ice, global warming, climate change, superior, lakes
name: When will Lake Superior completely thaw from the 2013/2014 winter?
question_text:
Understanding the major effect of ice on the Great Lakes is crucial because it impacts a range of societal benefits provided by the lakes, from hydropower generation to commercial shipping to the fishing industry. The amount of ice cover varies from year to year, as well as how long it remains on the lakes. GLERL scientists are observing long-term changes in ice cover as a result of global warming.

According to an analysis by NOAA's Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, ice concentration of Lake ?Superior peaked at?95.74 percent on March 05.?Not since early 1994?has ice been so widespread on the Great Lakes. Graphs showing the ice cover trends?for each of the Great Lakes from?1973 to 2002?can be found?here.

On May 04, 2014 the?mean concentration of ice in Lake Superior was?36.65%. Daily reports can?be found?here?under the section 'Modeled Ice Coverage'.

05/31/2014

keywords: Photothermal therapy, nanoparticles, cancer, clinical trials, medicine
name: When will a phase 1 clinical trial for photothermal therapy with nanoparticles begin?
question_text:
Photothermal therapy? uses?electromagnetic radiation, primarily infrared?radiation, for the treatment of various medical conditions, including?cancer. One way to destroy a cancer cell is to heat it above 42 degrees Celsius. However, this also damages the surrounding tissue.? By using nanoparticles the heat can be focused on the cancer cells, leaving the healthy tissue untouched.

    Molecules of a specific size, between 20-300 nm, tend to accumulate in greater quantities inside tumor cells, rather than inside ordinary tissue.? Nanoparticles within that size range can theoretically be injected into the body where they slowly pile up within cancer cells.? The nanoparticles can then be excited with photon energy from outside of the body, efficiently converting the supplied energy to heat.? This raises the temperature within the cancer cells to fatal levels without harming the surrounding cells. As an example of this, magnetic heating nanoparticles have been shown to induce localized heating in prostate cancer tumors in preclinical trials. Many researchers are working on functionalizing gold nanoparticles, nanorods, nanospheres, nanocages for killing cancer cells using photothermal therapy.

    Sources and Links
    Nanoparticles for photothermal therapies
    http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2014/nr/c4nr00708e#!divAbstract

    Photothermal therapy
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photothermal_therapy

    State of the art: Morbidity and quality of life during thermotherapy using magnetic nanoparticles in locally recurrent prostate cancer: results of a prospective phase I trial.
    http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=17523023[uid]

    Accepting Forecasts Until:

    01/01/2017

    Resolution Source

    Reported in a publication listed on PubMed.gov or as listed on clinicaltrials.gov

    Fine Print

    The experiment must use electromagnetic radiation. Begin = as listed at the Study Start Date on clinicaltrials.govPhase 1 = as listed under phase on clinicaltrials.gov

keywords: nano, nanocellulose, screen, flexible, ACS, C&EN, chemistry
name: When will a handheld, flexible nanocellulose video screen be comercially available for sale?
question_text:
The cover story of?Chemical & Engineering News' June 30, 2014 Issue titled "Nano From The Forest" describes nanocellulose as tiny cellulosic particles that are poised to make big impact on materials technology. Nanostructured cellulose materials?are found?tucked inside the fibrous cellulose matrices that provide mechanical strength to wood and plants and are highly abundant. These materials are being touted for their ability to take various forms, such as gels and films, and for the breadth of their potential applications, including electronics and tissue engineering.

A quick scan of chemistry journal tables of contents shows that researchers continue to come up with sophisticated applications that benefit from the useful properties of nanocellulose. Flexible electronics recently joined the list. Electronic circuits that bend, stretch, and adopt unusual shapes without losing function could be the basis of wearable computers, advanced medical implants, and other devices. A common difficulty in fabricating such gadgets is the high thermal expansion coefficients of the flexible plastic substrates upon which the circuits are typically deposited.

Because nanocellulose is both light and strong, and most importantly, transparent, it could make the ideal material to replace glass or plastic in display screens. The nanocellulose could be made into a flexible but strong and durable coating for the bendable displays, enabling all sorts of fancy formats and screens.?

Helpful Links:
  • http://cen.acs.org/articles/92/i26/Nano-Forest.html
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxqbuOjWV2s
  • http://www.techradar.com/news/world-of-tech/future-tech/the-amazing-material-that-promises-flexible-...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/01/2017

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on any major news source or specs listed on a manufacturer's?website.

Fine Print

The device must be handheld and branded as 'portable'. The question will resolve when the device is available for purchase by the general public.

name: What percentage change in world forest area will be reported for 2013 versus 2012?
question_text:
The globe?s forests provide the world?s primary source of oxygen, biodiversity, wood and paper products,?and are also essential as a source of agricultural products. They also play a?key role in?watershed?maintenance, soil protection, and pollution abatement. Despite their?importance, the world?s forests are continually being threatened by deforestation. According to the United Nations, subsistence farming is responsible for 48% of deforestation, commercial agriculture is responsible for 32%, logging for 14%, and fuel wood removal makes up 5%.

Estimates of annual rates of deforestation vary widely, though the number is in the millions of acres per year. The World Bank World Development Indicators includes forest cover (percentage of total) for all countries and for the globe. The most recent World Bank data indicate that 30.97% of the world's land is forested, down from 32.06% in 1990.

For more information, see:

  • http://environment.nationalgeographic.com/environment/global-warming/deforestation-overview/
  • http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/about_forests/deforestation/
  • http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/landsat/news/40th-top10-amazon.html
  • http://www.pnas.org/content/111/2/567.short

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The World Bank forest data are provided here: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.LND.FRST.ZS. The "TABLE" data will be used to resolve the question.

These data are currently up to 2012; 2013 data are not yet reported. This question will resolve when the new data are updated. For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.???

Fine Print

The percentage change will be calculated from those data reported by the World Bank in the data table: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.LND.FRST.ZS

name: What West African country will be third to detect the Ebola Virus in 2014 after Guinea and Liberia?
question_text:
The Ebola Virus Disease (EVD), formerly known as Ebola haemorrhagic fever, is a severe, often fatal illness in humans. As of April 16, 2014, the World Health Organization has reported EVD in 2 West African Countries ? Guinea and Liberia.? Suspected cases have occurred in Mali and Sierra Leone, but tests did not indicate EVD.? The World Health Organisation (WHO) said earlier this month that it would take two to four months to contain the Ebola outbreak, which WHO said had been one of the most challenging it had ever faced.

name: Prior to the end of 2016, will the Lymphocyte Genome Sensitivity (LGS) blood test for detecting cancer be approved by the FDA for use in the US?
question_text:
Researchers from the University of Bradford (UK)?have devised a simple blood test that can be used to diagnose whether or not people have cancer. The Lymphocyte Genome Sensitivity (LGS) test looks at white blood cells and measures the damage caused to their DNA when subjected to different intensities of ultraviolet light (UVA). The results of the empirical study show a clear distinction between the damage to white blood cells?in patients with cancer, versus patients with?pre-cancerous conditions and?healthy patients. A clinical trial is currently underway at Bradford Royal Infirmary in the UK. If LGS proves to be a useful cancer diagnostic test, it could be a valuable addition to the more traditional investigative procedures for detecting cancer.?
The team lead by medical science professor Diana Anderson published their findings in FASEB Journal in July 2014,?and?Bradford University has filed patents for the test technology. In addition, members of the research team plan to take the LGS test to market with a spin-off company called Oncascan that licensed the technology from the university for development.

  • http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/07/140728094410.htm

  • http://www.oncascan.com/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

name: In which of the following sub-branches will the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry be awarded?
question_text:
Established in 1900, the Nobel Foundation awards the annual Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Economic Sciences, Literature, and Peace. Recipients must be living, and in no case may the prize be divided among more than three persons.

Between 1901 and 2013, 561 prizes have been awarded. In some years, some prizes have not been awarded: the latest was 1972 when the Peace Prize was not awarded.

Resolution Criteria

The Nobel Prize Committee must determine and announce a winner of the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

The question moderator reserves the right, if necessary, to refine or clarify the definitions of the sub-branches cited in this question to conform to more authoritative or accepted taxonomies of science.

name: Will the International Sun-Earth Explorer 3 be successfully commanded to fire its thrusters by researchers?
question_text:
International Solar-Environment Explorer (ISEE-3) was launched in late 1978 to study the interaction between the Earth?s magnetic field and solar wind. In 1983, it was redirected to study comets, winning the ?space race? to encounter a comet. In 1997, NASA ended the Explorer?s mission and ordered the probe shut down.? Though only a carrier signal was supposed to be left operating, the probe was not powered off after a brief contact in 1999. In 2008, NASA located the Explorer using the Deep Space Network.?

The Explorer?s current trajectory will bring it close to Earth in August 2014 giving the chance for it to be put to use once more to study solar wind. However, the equipment needed to transmit the signals to capture the Explore was decommissioned at NASA in 1999.?

Two teams are attempting to contact the Explorer and have it successfully fire its thrusters to get back to its station between the Earth and the Sun. A 18-meter satellite dish at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory still has the right hardware and may attempt to contact the Explorer.? The other team is a crowd-funded team who will use the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico to make contact with the Explorer. They are using embedded systems technology to construct radio components in software and build the necessary components to contact the Explorer.

Links and sources
  • Space Thief Or Hero? One Man's Quest To Reawaken An Old Friend http://www.npr.org/2014/03/18/289628696/space-thief-or-hero-one-mans-quest-to-reawaken-an-old-friend
  • Space Hackers Prepare to Reboot 35-Year-Old Spacecraft http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/satellites/space-hackers-prepare-to-reboot-35-year-old-spacecraft
  • ISEE-3 Reboot Project by Space College, Skycorp, and SpaceRef http://www.rockethub.com/42228

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

An official with the successful team will announce the success or failure of their experiment. This would be covered in the scientific popular press.

Fine Print

Commanded is defined as the team sending a signal to the explorer to command it to fire its thrusters and the explorer fires its thrusters.

keywords: Flu, Region 5, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 5 (IL, IN, MI, MN, OH, WI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???

  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 5' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 5 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 5. Region 5 is comprised of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: In September 2014 a paper was published that asserted that electromagnetism promotes pluripotency. Will a second research group publish a paper confirming the increase efficiency in iPS due to electromagnetic fields before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
During embryonic development, specific cells such a muscle, blood, or bone cells arise from embryonic stem cells via gene-triggered cellular changes.? To do research or to grow new cells from stem cells, historically a human embryo was required. However, in the recent past scientists discovered and developed methods to reprogram non-embryonic cells (somatic/ differentiated cells) to have the same properties as embryonic cells termed induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells.

In 2006, Kazutoshi Takahashi and Shinya Yamanaka established for the first time murine ES-like cell lines from mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) and skin fibroblasts by simply expressing four transcription factor genes encoding Oct4, Sox2, Klf4, and c-Myc (Figure 1) (Takahashi & Yamanaka 2006). They called these somatic cell-derived cell lines induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells. This method is quite inefficient.

Baek et al published a paper in September 2014 in ACS nano detailed their experiment where they were apparently successful in increasing the efficiency of the creation of iPS with the use of extremely low-frequency electromagnetic fields (EL-EMF) They report ?EL-EMF-treated cultures exhibited an increase in colonies undergoing reprogramming as assessed by alkaline phosphatase (AP) staining, with a maximum increase in efficiency observed 15 days after infection and exposure to 50 Hz, 1 mT EL-EMF...EL-EMF exposure during the 2 weeks of dox treatment resulted in a significant increase in the expression of endogenous Oct4, Sox2, and Nanog relative to controls.

This work has been met with skepticism, and researchers are working to reproduce the results of Baek et al.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/15/2015

Resolution Source

Published as a paper, letter, or new article in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science such as Science, Nature, or PNAS.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

To resolve as ?yes? the group must demonstrate that the EL-EMF treated cultures have a higher efficiency than the their control group.

keywords: nuclear energy, uranium, uranium concentrate, uranium enrichment, mining
name: How much uranium concentrate will be produced in the US in 2014?
question_text:
Nuclear power accounted for was 19.4% of total US electric energy generation in 2013, or about 790 TWh of electricity. At those levels, the US is the world's largest supplier of commercial nuclear power. The United States also has the 4th largest uranium reserves in the world. The uranium mining process mixes uranium ore with groundwater, creating a solution which is filtered and dried to produce uranium oxide concentrate of the chemical formula U3O8. The vast majority of nuclear power reactors require enriched uranium fuel in which the proportion of the uranium-235 isotope has been raised from the natural level of 0.7% to between 3.5% to 5%. Modern enrichment plants use a centrifuge process to create enriched uranium, which is turned into uranium dioxide (UO2) powder. This powder is then pressed to form small fuel pellets, which are then heated to make a hard ceramic material. The pellets are then inserted into thin tubes to form fuel rods that fuel nuclear power plants.

Since 2000, US production of uranium concentrate (U3O8) has varied from an estimated low of 2 million pounds in 2003 to a high of 4,658,842 pounds (measured) in 2013. The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) reports quarterly and annual uranium concentrate production levels for the US. It is due to report 2014 full year numbers in February 2015.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.eia.gov/uranium/production/quarterly/
  • http://www.world-nuclear.org/nuclear-basics/how-is-uranium-ore-made-into-nuclear-fuel-/
  • http://uraniuminvestingnews.com/20259/peninsula-energy-signs-offtake-deal-with-utility-company.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

02/28/2015

Resolution Source

name: On November 2020, what will be the?Top 500 performance share by processor generation?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by processor generation, and you think IvyBridge machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust the chances of IvyBridge machines towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

name: Will the overall U.S. experience a white Christmas in 2013?
question_text:
The average snow depth in the U.S. on December 25 for the past 10 years is 3.4 inches.? The question asks whether the average snow depth will exceed 3.5 inches on the same date in 2013.

Resolution Criteria

snowfall, low temperatures

Resolution Sources

National Snow Analyses

Fine Print

A "white Christmas" occurs when an average of more than 3.5 inches of snow are on the ground across the geographic area on December 25, 2013.? The National Snow Analyses by the U.S. National Weather Service and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration provide the average snow depth throughout the region on a daily basis.

name: When will Magnus Carlsen be superseded as the World Chess Champion?
question_text:
• The 23 year old?Magnus Carlsen of Norway is the highest rated?chessplayer in the world?on the FIDE rating list and, as of November 2013,?the reigning World Chess Champion.?
  • The current World Chess Championship cycle begins with a?FIDE Grand Prix and, with a few provisions,?leads up to the Candidates Tournament whose winner becomes the challenger to the title, later fought for in the format of a match against the reigning World Champion.

A change of the form of the current World Chess Championship cycle

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2023

Resolution Source

The outcome of this question will be based either on a decisive score of a World Championship match or based on?any reason why Magnus Carlsen would be deprived of the currently held title without a match. The possible reasons include, and are not limited to, Carlsen's declaring that he will no longer compete or Carlsen's death while still holding the title.?Multiple major?international news sources are expected to closely monitor a chess match of that caliber, such as:

  • New York Times
  • Chess News

Fine Print

'Superseded' as used here does not imply that Magnus Carlsen would necessarily lose the title based on the result of a match. If for any reason Carlsen ceases to be regarded as the World Chess Champion and a new chess player claims the title instead, the question will be resolved. Such possible reasons include, and are not limited to, Carlsen's declaring that he will no longer actively compete or Carlsen's death while still holding the title.

keywords: Gravitational waves, cosmology, big bang, retraction
name: Will the March 2014 announcement of the observation of primordial B-mode in the polarization of the cosmic microwave background be retracted?
question_text:
On March 17, 2014, a team of researchers working with the Background Imaging of Cosmic Extragalactic Polarization 2 (BICEP2) telescope announced their observation of pinwheel-like swirls in the polarization of the cosmic microwave background.? To study the CMB signal, however, researchers first had to subtract the "foreground" of microwaves generated by dust within our galaxy. This step is currently being scrutinized by many as a source of error that may invalidate the team?s previous findings.

According to an article on Sciencemag.org:

To subtract the galactic foreground, BICEP researchers relied on a particular map of it generated by the European Space Agency's spacecraft Planck, which mapped the CMB across the entire sky from 2009 until last year. However, the BICEP team apparently interpreted the map as showing only the galactic emissions. In reality, it may also contain the largely unpolarized hazy glow from other galaxies, which has the effect of making the galactic microwaves coming from any particular point of the sky look less thoroughly polarized than they actually are. So using the map to strip out the galactic foreground may actually leave some of that foreground in the data where it could produce a spurious signal, Falkowski explains. "Apparently, there is something that needs to be corrected, so at this point the BICEP result cannot be taken at face value," he tells Science.

BICEP researchers are not ready to concede the point, however. Clement Pryke, a cosmologist at the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, and a co-principal investigator for the BICEP team, acknowledges that the foreground map is an important and thorny issue. Part of the problem is that the Planck team has not made the raw foreground data available, he says. Instead, BICEP researchers had to do the best they could with a PDF file of that map that the Planck team presented at a conference. Moreover, Pryke says, conversations with members of the Planck team leave it uncertain exactly what is in the key plot. "It is unclear what that plot shows," he says.

Links and sources
Blockbuster Big Bang Result May Fizzle, Rumor Suggests
http://news.sciencemag.org/physics/2014/05/blockbuster-big-bang-result-may-fizzle-rumor-suggests?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Like the first announcement, a retraction will be covered by the Science section of the New York Times as well as science journals such as Nature and Science.

Fine Print

Retract ? an official from the original group that announced the observation will announce that a mistake was made and that they retract their findings they announced in March of 2014.

keywords: Nuclear Fusion, ITER, Superconductivity, Superconducting Cable System
name: Will an innovative superconducting cable system, recently developed by a research group in the Netherlands, be incorporated in the ITER project?
question_text:
The superconductivity research group of the University of Twente (UT) has claimed a breakthrough crucial to the success of nuclear fusion reactors by developing a highly ingenious and robust superconducting cable system. The cables are less susceptible to heat and are able to withstand the immense forces inside fusion reactors for a very long time. Nuclear fusion is a nuclear reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei collide at very high speed and join to form a new type of atomic nucleus. The fusion of two nuclei with lower masses than iron generally release energy. Nuclear fusion takes place in the heart of the reactor, in plasma with temperature of 150 million degrees Celsius.

The world's largest nuclear fusion reactor, ITER, is under construction in Cadarache in France as a joint project of the US, EU, Russia, India, Japan, South Korea and China. It is expected to start operation by 2020. The developer of the new cable system expects it will become a global standard in nuclear fusion reactors, so this question asks whether this new cable technology will be featured in the ITER reactor.

Resolution Criteria

The new cable system or underlying technology must actually be used in the ITER reactor vessel as constructed for this question to resolve "True".

Resolution Sources

World Nuclear News

Fine Print

ITER, an acronym of International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor, is an international nuclear fusion research and engineering project, which is currently building the world's largest experimental tokamak nuclear fusion reactor in southern France.

To resolve as true, the new cable system or its fundamental technological advancements must be used in the construction of the reactor vessel.

Useful Information and Links

  • Breakthrough: Progress Toward Nuclear Fusion Power Station
  • ITER

Related Organizations or Individuals

International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER), www.iter.org
short_name: Superconducting cable in nuclear fusion reactor

keywords: Photothermal therapy, nanoparticles, cancer, clinical trials, medicine
name: Photothermal therapy with nanoparticles has generated much interest as a physical therapeutic technique to kill cancer. Will a clinical trial show photothermal therapy with nanoparticles to reduce tumor size by 2019?
question_text:
Photothermal therapy? uses?electromagnetic radiation, primarily infrared?radiation, for the treatment of various medical conditions, including?cancer. One way to destroy a cancer cell is to heat it above 42 degrees Celsius. However, this also damages the surrounding tissue.? By using nanoparticles the heat can be focused on the cancer cells, leaving the healthy tissue untouched.

    Molecules of a specific size, between 20-300 nm, tend to accumulate in greater quantities inside tumor cells, rather than inside ordinary tissue.? Nanoparticles within that size range can theoretically be injected into the body where they slowly pile up within cancer cells.? The nanoparticles can then be excited with photon energy from outside of the body, efficiently converting the supplied energy to heat.? This raises the temperature within the cancer cells to fatal levels without harming the surrounding cells. As an example of this, magnetic heating nanoparticles have been shown to induce localized heating in prostate cancer tumors in preclinical trials. Many researchers are working on functionalizing gold nanoparticles, nanorods, nanospheres, nanocages for killing cancer cells using photothermal therapy.

    Sources and Links
    Nanoparticles for photothermal therapies
    http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2014/nr/c4nr00708e#!divAbstract

    Photothermal therapy
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photothermal_therapy

    Morbidity and quality of life during thermotherapy using magnetic nanoparticles in locally recurrent prostate cancer: results of a prospective phase I trial.
    http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=17523023[uid]

    Accepting Forecasts Until:

    01/01/2020

    Resolution Source

    Reported in a publication listed on PubMed.gov or as listed on clinicaltrials.gov

    Fine Print

    The experiment must use electromagnetic radiation.

keywords: Ice, Arctic, Climate, Ice caps, Oceans
name: What will the average arctic sea ice extent be for September 2014?
question_text:
Passive microwave satellite data reveal that, since 1979, winter Arctic ice extent has decreased about 3 to 4 percent per decade. Sea ice typically covers about 14 to 16 million square kilometers in late winter in the Arctic and 17 to 20 million square kilometers in the Antarctic Southern Ocean. On average, the seasonal decrease is much larger in the Antarctic, with only about 3 to 4 million square kilometers remaining at summer's end, compared to approximately 7 million square kilometers in the Arctic.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of The National Snow and Ice Data Center in their "State of the Cryosphere" section http://nsidc.org/cryosphere/sotc/sea_ice.html . It is anticipated that this will be updated with the relevant September 2014 data sometime before October 21 2014. If nothing is published by The National Snow and Ice Data Center by October 21, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Polar Science Center
http://psc.apl.washington.edu/

Fine Print

Sea Ice Index data are derived from daily gridded sea ice concentration that come from two sources: The Near-Real-Time DMSP SSM/I-SSMIS Daily Polar Gridded Sea Ice Concentrations (NRTSI product) data created at and distributed from NSIDC with data set ID NSIDC-0081 and the Sea Ice Concentrations from Nimbus-7 SMMR and DMSP SSM/I-SSMIS Passive Microwave Data (GSFC product) created at the Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) and distributed from NSIDC with data set ID NSIDC-0051.

Useful Links

  • http://nsidc.org/cryosphere/sotc/sea_ice.html
  • http://nsidc.org/data/docs/noaa/g02135_seaice_index/#monthly_extent_image
  • The National Snow and Ice Data Center http://nsidc.org/

Related Organizations or Individuals

The National Snow and Ice Data Center http://nsidc.org/

name: What will be the monthly averaged arctic ice volume for SEP-2014?
question_text:
Sea ice volume is an important climate indicator. It depends on both ice thickness and extent and therefore more directly tied to climate forcing than extent alone. However, Arctic sea ice volume cannot currently be observed continuously.

Observations from satellites, Navy submarines, moorings, and field measurements are all limited in space and time. The assimilation of observations into numerical models currently provides one way of estimating sea ice volume changes on a continuous basis.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the Polar Science Center's Arctic Sea Ice Volume Anomaly. It is anticipated that this will be updated with the relevant September 2014 data sometime before October 31 2014. If nothing is published by The Polar Science Center' by October 31, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

name: When will a demonstration of a solar cell made of perovskite nanowires be announced?
question_text:
• Perovskites solar cells were discovered in 2009 with an efficiency of ~4%. Further research resulted in drastic improvements in efficiency to 20.1% as of November 13, 2014. This rate of change is unmatched in other solar cell technologies. The most recent gain for perovskite solar cells went from about 17% in mid 2014 to 20.1% in late 2014.
  • In 2013 researchers showed that single-nanowire solar cells displayed efficiencies beyond the Shockley-Queisser limit. The enhanced light absorption is shown to be due to a light concentrating property of the standing nanowire.
  • In 2014, researchers published a method of synthesizing perovskite nanowires.
Sources and links
  • Krogstrup, P., et al., Single-nanowire solar cells beyond the Shockley-Queisser limit. Nat Photon, 2013. 7(4): p. 306-310. http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/v7/n4/full/nphoton.2013.32.html
  • Building a new nanowire for solar cells http://actu.epfl.ch/news/building-a-new-nanowire-for-solar-cells/
  • Endre Horv?th, Massimo Spina, Zsolt Szekr?nyes, Katalin Kamar?s, Richard Gaal, David Gachet, and L?szl? Forr?. Nanowires of Methylammonium Lead Iodide (CH3NH3PbI3) Prepared by Low Temperature Solution-Mediated Crystallization. Nano Letters 2014 14 (12), 6761-6766?? http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/nl5020684

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An official press release from the researcher?s institution or funding agency or a paper published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

Perovskite nanowires must be used in the solar cell itself as the light absorbing material.Demonstrate: a working solar cell is built using perovskite nanowires as at least a portion of the light absorbing material and a current is measured when the cell is exposed to light.

keywords: Time algorithm, math, mathematics, algorithm, exponential, SAT
name: When will a classical algorithm be authored to solve 3-SAT faster than exp(o(n))?
question_text:
In computational complexity theory, the exponential time hypothesis is an unproven computational hardness assumption formalized by Impagliazzo & Paturi (1999) stating that 3-SAT (or any of several related NP-complete problems) cannot be solved in subexponential time in the worst case.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the Traversal Conjecture is 'proven true' based on judgement rendered by question moderator. If no significant news is reported by the date in question, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e.,no subexponential time algorithm for solving SAT-3 exists). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

Computer science academic journals

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Question moderator

name: How many countries will report at least one case of wild poliovirus in 2014?
question_text:
In 2014, only 3 countries in the world remain polio-endemic: Nigeria, Pakistan and Afghanistan. In 1994, the WHO Region of the Americas was certified polio-free, followed by the WHO Western Pacific Region in 2000 and the WHO European Region in June 2002. On 27 March 2014, the WHO South-East Asia Region was certified polio-free, meaning that transmission of wild poliovirus has been interrupted in this bloc of 11 countries stretching from Indonesia to India. This achievement marks a significant leap forward in global eradication, with 80% of the world?s population now living in certified polio-free regions.

However, endemic transmission is continuing in Nigeria, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. As of Dec. 10, 2014, the following countries have reported a case of polio in 2014:
Pakistan
Afghanistan
Nigeria
Somalia
Equatorial Guinea
Iraq
Cameroon
Syria
Ethiopia

Sources and links

  • Just one poliovirus left to go? http://www.sciencemag.org/content/346/6211/795.full?
  • Polio Eradication http://www.polioeradication.org/
  • Vaccine-derived polioviruses? http://www.polioeradication.org/Polioandprevention/Thevirus/Vaccinederivedpolioviruses.aspx

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/31/2015

Resolution Source

The World Health Organization?s polio data and statistics will be used to resolve this question: http://www.polioeradication.org/Dataandmonitoring/Poliothisweek.aspx
It will be checked on February 4, 2015 and the number listed on that day for 2014 will resolved this question.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

question_text:
Three Egyptians died of H5N1 virus?in the last week of November 2014, according to the country's health ministry. Egypt has confirmed 11 cases of the virus in people this year, including 6 who have died.

H5N1 is a type of influenza virus that causes a highly infectious, severe respiratory disease in birds. Human cases of H5N1 avian influenza have occurred occasionally, but it is difficult to tranmist the disease from person to person. When people do become infected, the mortality rate is about 60%. Between 2003 and Oct 2014 there were 668 confirmed human cases of H5N1 infections in 15 coutries, leading to 393 deaths. Egypt has reported 177 of the confirmed cases and 63 of the deaths.

question_text:

  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • The 'very low' HPV vaccination group of states is comprised of the following: (2011 coverage rate % / 2012 coverage rate %)
    • Alabama (49.5 / 46.6)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/457/trades/create/safe
    • Arkansas (36.1 / 41.2)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/471/trades/create/safe

Fine Print

Clusters of states were created by first analyzing state-level variables that correlate with HPV vaccination coverage in 2011 and 2012. The model for predicting HPV vaccination coverage explained over half the variation among states. On the most useful variables, states in a given cluster are more similar to each other than to states in other clusters. The range of possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 46.0%, the "Between 46.0% and 48.0%" range will be deemed correct.

name: When will the first publication reporting the observation of the conversion of photons into matter be published?
question_text:
In a paper published in May 2014 in Nature Photonics, researchers from Imperial College London claim to have devised a method of converting light (photons) into matter (electrons and positrons). Breit and Wheeler's 80-year-old theory that two photons could crash together and produce matter (a positron and an electron) has never been observed in a laboratory, and the method described in the paper adapts technology used in fusion research and can be implemented at existing facilities.

The method proposes gathering a vast number of very high-energy photons by firing an intense beam of gamma-rays into a dense cloud of photons within a tiny, gold-lined cylinder. This vacuum-filled cylinder, called a "hohlraum", is usually used in nuclear fusion research. The cloud of photons inside it is made from extraordinarily intense X-rays and is about as hot as the Sun. Hitting this very dense cloud of photons with the powerful gamma-ray beam raises the probability of collisions that will create matter.

  • Nature Photonics - A photon-photon collider in a vacuum hohlraum
  • BBC News - UK Discovery 'Starts Race' to Turn Light into Matter

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2016

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved when publication observing the conversion of photons into matter appears in a peer-reviewed journal.

Academic journals, like Nature Photonics, are a likely place to publish such an article. Proof of converting light into matter would also be covered by mainstream media organizations, such as the New York Times and BBC News.

Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, a "publication" is an article in a peer-reviewed journal that is published in Thomson Reuters' Web of Science.

keywords: Physics, Nobel Prize, Particle Physics, Atomic/Molecular/Optical Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Astrophysics

question_text:
Established in 1900s, the Nobel Foundation awards the annual Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Economic Sciences, Literature, and Peace. ?Recipients must be living, and in no case may the prize be divided among more than three persons.? Between 1901 and 2013, 561 prizes have been awarded. ?In some years, some prizes have not been awarded: the latest was 1972 when the Peace prize was not awarded.?(Source:?nobelprize.org)

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on reporting by www.nobelprize.org. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from NobelPrize.org. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

name: Engineered water nanostructures have been shown to inactivate dangerous pathogens at eight times the natural rate without toxic residue. How much faster than the natural rate will this technology inactivate surface bacteria according to the next record rate published?
question_text:
Infectious diseases are an important public health problem affecting millions of people each year. These include viral diseases such as avian influenza (AI/H5N1) and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), as well as bacterial infections. The use and misuse of antibiotics has led to the development of drug-resistant bacteria, including resistant strains of tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and staph bacteria (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). In addition, serious foodborne illnesses can arise from pathogenic organisms found on fresh produce. Current methods of disinfection for produce and other contaminated surfaces rely heavily on chemicals and irradiation.

Recent work by Philip Demokritou, Georgios Pyrgiotakis, and others suggests that engineered water nanostructures (EWNS) may constitute a safe, ?green,? and cost-effective new method for inactivating bacteria in the air and on surfaces. In Pyrgiotakis et al. (2012), the authors demonstrate that EWNS have the potential to inactivate gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria on surfaces. A forthcoming publication Pyrgiotakis G., et al achieves surface inactivation rates of 0.63 Logs/hr at an EWNS concentrations of 9,000 #/cm3 and 0.83 Logs/hr at an EWNS concentrations of 32,000 #/cm3. In the latter case, the rate is over eight times faster than the natural inactivation rate of 0.097 Logs/hr.

A new bug killer
http://www.economist.com/news/technology-quarterly/21603236-water-particles-could-provide-powerful-a...

A novel method for bacterial inactivation using electrosprayed water nanostructures
http://rd.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11051-012-1027-x

A chemical free, nanotechnology-based method for airborne bacterial inactivation using engineered water nanostructures
http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlepdf/2014/en/c3en00007a?page=search

Mycobacteria inactivation using Engineered Water Nanostructures (EWNS)
http://www.nanomedjournal.com/article/S1549-9634%2814%2900119-1/abstract

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2017

Resolution Source

The new rate must be published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

?How much faster? refers to the multiples of the control group inactivation speed over a 60 minute period, and may be for any surface bacteria. This question asks about the next paper that has a faster inactivation than the structures cited in the background.

name: Will NASA detect a near Earth object (NEO) with an estimated Earth impact risk of greater than 0.081 by the end of 2014?
question_text:
The U.S. NationalAeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), through its Near Earth ObjectProgram, monitors so-called Near-Earth Objects (NEOs). NEOs are comets andasteroids that have been nudged by the gravitational attraction of nearbyplanets into orbits that allow them to enter the Earth's vicinity.

NASA?s NEOprogram tracks objects from a variety of observation points around the globe,including the Catalina Sky Survey (CSS) and Spacewatch near Tucson Arizona; theLINEAR project near Socorro New Mexico; Pans-STARRS1 on Maui, Hawaii; and LONEOSnear Flagstaff, Arizona.

As NASAdiscovers new NEOs it estimates the likelihood of these objects impactingEarth, along with the estimated timeframe for impact. NASA makes public all NEOdiscoveries and impact estimates on the NEO program webpage. Currently, the NEOwith the highest estimated Earth impact likelihood is object 2010 RF12, with animpact likelihood of 0.081. 2010 RF12 was discovered in September of 2010. Ifit does collide with Earth, the date of that collision is estimated to be between2095 and 2112.

NASA reportsthe impact estimates and time frames for 457 NEOs on the NEO program webpage.Objects are added to this list as discovered and removed from the list whenNASA no longer considers impact possible. Impact likelihood estimates rangefrom a high of 0.081 for object 2010 RF12 to a low of 1.1e-10 (or less than 1in 9 billion chance of impact). This question asks whether an object will bedetected by the NEO program in 2014 with an estimated impact probabilitygreater than 0.081, including a potential upward revision of the probability for 2010 RF12 itself.

Estimates ofthe impact probability for all near Earth objects can be found here:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/
More can belearned about NASA?s NEO program here:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/index.html

The population of comets and asteroids in the solar system is believed to be quite constant, as they were mostly created during the formation of the solar system some 4.6 billion years ago.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

NASA reportsup-to-date impact likelihood estimates of the impact probability for all NEOobjects:? http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/

Thisquestion will be resolved by evaluating the highest impact probability reportedon this page on December 31, 2014.



Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, Near Earth Objects are defined as those objects that NASA detects and for which it reports impact probabilities. These objects can be found at: http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/

keywords: China, Lunar Program, Chang'e 3, Lunar Lander, Lunar Rover, Moon, Space Exploration
name: Will Chang'e 3's Jade Rabbit Lunar Rover achieve operational status on the surface of the moon?
question_text:
China successfully launched a spacecraft Monday morning 12/2/2013, on a two-week journey to deliver a robotic rover to the surface of the moon. The mission marks China's first attempt at soft-landing a spacecraft on an extra-terrestrial body, and their first attempt to deploy and operate a remotely controlled vehicle on such a body to collect samples and data for analysis.

The Chang'e 3 lunar lander was launched atop a Long March rocket from southwest China's Xichang Satellite Launch Center, reported the official Xinhua News Agency. Chang'e 3 aims to land on the moon's Bay of Rainbows, and deploy a six-wheeled, solar-powered lunar rover the Yutu, or Jade Rabbit, to look for natural resources and conduct geological surveys for three months.

Accomplishing these firsts could benefit the nation's future plans to land Chinese astronauts on the moon and develop their interests in it for scientific and other purposes.

Resolution Criteria

Achieving operational status for the Jade Rabbit will be defined as having been successfully deployed from Chang'e 3, under power with controlled mobility and at least one of its scientific instruments operational in order to conduct its mission objectives, and successfully communicating with mission control for the minimum purpose of sending its data.

Resolution Sources

CNTV

Fine Print

    Note that achieving operational status for the Jade Rabbit does not require the Chang'e 3 to meet its proximity criteria to its target landing site, so long as the Jade Rabbit becomes operational as defined above.

    The question moderator reserves the right to extend the trading if warranted by changes to the mission parameters.

    Useful Links

    • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chang%27e_3
    • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinus_Iridum
    • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_landing_%28rocketry%29
    • http://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?topic=26848.285
    • http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/12/china-change3-rover-to-the-moon/





    Related Organizations or Individuals

    China's National Space Administration

name: Will a hospital purchase a paraxial ray optics based cloaking apparatus for use during surgery by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Scientists at the University of Rochester have found an inexpensive novel configuration to hide objects from view through three-dimensional, continuously multi-directional cloaking. Using a combination of four standard optical lenses, the researchers have provided a mathematical method for this type of cloaking that can work for angles of up to 15 degrees. The researchers determined the lens type, power needed, and the exact distance to separate the four lenses so that they could both cloak an object and leave the background undisturbed ? paraxial ray optics cloaking. Using a technique called ABCD matrices that describes how light bends when going through lenses, mirrors, or other optical elements, the Rochester Cloak can be scaled up as large as the size of the lenses, allowing fairly large objects to be cloaked.

The scientists believe that this type of cloaking would potentially be useful for a surgeon to "look through his hands to what he is actually operating on" or it can be applied for driving assistance in the case of trucks to allow drivers to see through blind spots on their vehicles.

http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/09/140929085221.htm
http://arxiv.org/pdf/1409.4705v1.pdf
http://www.cnet.com/news/invisibility-cloak-uses-lenses-to-bend-light/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An announcement or news release by a firm that builds paraxial ray optics based cloaking into surgical aids in the form of a wearable technology for surgeons or as a device that can be installed in an operation theater. Announcements in the news media or medical magazines. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

Cloaking is a method that can be used to hide objects from some parts of the electromagnetic spectrum.

name: Will researchers demonstrate a temporary tattoo containing an iontophoretic-biosensing platform to measure diabetic?s glucose levels that provides continuous monitoring for more than 8 hours?
question_text:
• Bandodkar et al. published a proof of concept technical report detailing a temporary tattoo that measured patient?s glucose level noninvasively for an hour through a iontophoretic-biosensing platform.
  • The temporary tattoo coupled an amperometric biosensor with a reverse iontophoresis operation. The device first extracts ISF glucose and then uses selective amperometric biosensing with a glucose oxidas modified Prussian Blue transducer at a low potential.
  • Current tattoos only monitored glucose for an hour. To achieve continuous glucose monitoring a tattoo must be developed that can be used for many hours.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

This question will resolve to yes if a research group publishes a paper describing a temporary tattoo containing an iontophoretic-biosensing platform that measures glucose for 8 hours.

A few?weeks earlier, only 12 states, mostly in the Midwest, had confirmed cases of the virus. Within days, it was reported in New York and Connecticut, and has since reached California and Washington.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Kimmel
name: What place will the Kimmel Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

Dicty related?research being conducted?at the?Kimmel Lab:

Organizing the embryonic body plan is a major requisite governing early metazoan development, with morphogen signaling central to establishing and specifying cell fates. One of these pathways involves Wnt/wingless signaling and includes 7-transmembrane (7-TM) target receptors and a downstream effector, the protein kinase, GSK3. In Dictyostelium, stimulation of a family of 7-TM receptors by its ligand, the secreted chemoattractant/morphogen, cAMP, also establishes a fundamental developmental organization, the anterior/posterior axis. We have shown that different cAMP receptor subtypes act antagonistically to promote or to inhibit cell-specific differentiation and axis formation. These antagonistic pathways converge at GSK3 in the context of cell fate determination. The latter inhibitory pathway parallels Wnt/wingless signaling through the 7-span frizzled receptors to control GSK3 activity and axes formation in Drosophila, Xenopus, and other metazoa. Separately, we have identified a novel tyrosine kinase, ZAK1, that is required for receptor-mediated activation of GSK3 during development, and have shown that recombinant ZAK1 will phosphorylate and consequently activate mammalian GSK3 in vitro. Remarkably, this 7-TM receptor-dependent activation of GSK3 may act independently of G proteins. These studies may reveal new mechanisms involving protein tyrosine kinases that are critical for cell fate specification or tumor suppression in other systems.

Useful Links
  • Link to?Kimmel Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?
