name: By the end of 2015, will Microsoft revise the "Patch Tuesday" framework by providing regular updates more than once per month?
question_text:
Patch Tuesday?is perhaps the most anticipated and feared day of the month for network administrators and security managers. They wait eagerly for the next batch of patches from Redmond, glad to have some protection against attacks on the vulnerabilities that have popped up since the previous month's release.?But they dread it too, and with good reason, given the massive amount of work involved in rolling out a dozen or more patches to thousands of systems.

Microsoft moved to a monthly?patch schedule?after some pointed requests by large customers who were having a hard time dealing with the steady and unpredictable flow of patches. And many IT managers still say they like knowing exactly what's coming down the pike and when. Indeed, the monthly bulk patch release has served to increase awareness of available security fixes in both the enterprise and the consumer market.

In addition to the convenience of receiving updates once a month, this process makes it more difficult for malware developers to reverse engineer software updates fast enough to reliably outpace patching.?Microsoft?pioneered the idea of distributing patches en masse one day?per month, effectively clogging the pipeline at reverse?engineering enterprises with numerous fixes, to make?it more difficult to isolate weaknesses?as when?distributed one at a time. However, some are too critical to?wait for the appointed?Tuesday?and are released as soon as?possible.?

Despite its strengths, Microsoft consistently releases patches outside of the regular?monthly cycle.?This is an attempt to prevent critical?vulnerabilities from going?unpatched until the following scheduled Tuesday.?Given the rise in both prevalence and scope of cyber attacks, it is reasonable to assume that patches will continue to be released outside of the schedule?more frequently, which may cause?Microsoft to revise?their strategy. ?


For more information:

  • technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms15-jan.aspx
  • http://www.computerweekly.com/feature/Microsoft-should-scrap-Patch-Tuesday

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will resolve as "true" if a public?announcement is made announcing Microsoft has revised their?"Patch Tuesday" framework to consistently?releasing regular patch updates?more than once per month.

The name of the new framework is irrelevant to the resolution of this question.?This question will be resolved when an announcement is made or on the resolution date.

The question will resolve using information released by?Microsoft.?

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.?

keywords: Flu, national, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the U.S. 2014-2015 flu season?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select National?
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across all 10 HHS regions (i.e., the continental U.S.).

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

Bitcoin is?a peer-to-peer cryptographic currency that issues new money and tracks transactions without a central authority.?
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Bitcoin

Bitcoin mining is the process of adding transaction records to Bitcoin's public ledger of past transactions. This ledger of past transactions is called the blockchain?as it is a chain of blocks. The block chain serves to confirm?transactions to the rest of the network as having taken place. Bitcoin nodes use the block chain to distinguish legitimate Bitcoin transactions from attempts to re-spend coins that have already been spent elsewhere.
See more:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Mining

A 51% attack can be carried out against the Bitcoin network if a dishonest miner controls more than 50% of the network's computing power. The attacker would be able to: reverse transactions (double spend), prevent transactions from gaining confirmations, or prevent miners from mining valid blocks.
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Weaknesses#Attacker_has_a_lot_of_computing_power

Relevant articles:
  • Bitcoin Miners Ditch Ghash.io Pool Over Fears of 51% Attack
  • Bitcoin's Fatal Flaw Was Nearly Exposed
  • 51% Attack

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Mining power will be resolved by consulting the pool data on blockchain.info. An official announcement from Bitcoin's core developers may also be used to resolve this question.

Fine Print

An individual miner or pool of miners will be considered to control more than 50% of the Bitcoin network if the hashrate distribution of nodes controlled by the individual or pool exceeds 50% of the distribution on blockchain.info: https://blockchain.info/pools

name: When will researchers announce the conversion of methane to methanol at room temperature through the use of metal-organic frameworks?
question_text:
In a new article published in April 2014 in Nature Chemistry, a group of researchers report they were able to convert ethane into ethanol and acetaldehyde at room temperature through the use of laboratory-built molecules called metal-organic frameworks, or MOFs, formed from metal atoms that are linked together by organic, carbon-based molecules in a honeycomb shape.

This report opens the possibility of a process that could convert methane, the main component in natural gas, to methanol, a liquid fuel, without the high temperatures of current industrial processes. A room temperature transformation would require less energy and could dramatically lower the cost of producing liquid methanol, a clean-burning alternative fuel.

  • Scientific American - A New Chemical Recipe Raises Prospect of Inexpensive Fuel
  • Nature Chemistry - Oxidation of ethane to ethanol by N2O in a metal?organic framework with coordinatively unsaturated iron(II) sites
  • Wikipedia - Metal-Organic Framework

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2019

Resolution Source

The article in question must appear in a peer-reviewed journal that is published in Thomson Reuters' Web of Science. A breakthrough in the production of liquid methanol during the current natural gas boom will likely be covered by a variety of scientific publications and the mainstream press, as well.

Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, the article in question must appear in a peer-reviewed journal that is published in Thomson Reuters' Web of Science.Room temperature is defined at a range between 20? and 25? C.

name: Will a new clinical study on the potential benefits of calorie restriction be launched before the end of 2014?
question_text:
Caloric restriction (CR), or calorie restriction, is a dietary regimen that is based on low calorie intake. "Low" can be defined relative to the subject's previous intake before intentionally restricting calories, or relative to an average person of similar body type. Caloric restriction without malnutrition has been shown to work in a variety of species, among them yeast, fish, rodents and dogs to decelerate the biological aging process, resulting in longer maintenance of youthful health and an increase in both median and maximum lifespan.Two trials have been performed involving primates, but have not demonstrated increases in median lifespan. A study of rhesus monkeys begun in 1987 by the National Institute on Aging published results in August 2012 that found evidence of health benefits, but did not demonstrate increased median lifespan. A study by the University of Wisconsin beginning in 1989 is still ongoing.
http://www.nature.com/news/calorie-restriction-falters-in-the-long-run-1.11297



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

http://clinicaltrials.gov/

Fine Print

The question resolves positive provided a clinical study starts in 2014 with CR as the regimen, irrespective of the target benefit (e.g. longer life, specific health benefit etc).

name: Will a new clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of calorie restriction in slowing the progression of neurological diseases such as Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease, and Alzheimer's disease start before the end of June 2015?
question_text:
Recent studies by Dr. Mark P. Mattson, chief of the National Institute on Aging's (NIA) Laboratory of Neurosciences, and colleagues have found that intermittent fasting and calorie restriction affect the progression of neurological diseases similar to Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease, and Alzheimer's disease in mice. In one study, rats and mice ate a low-calorie diet or were deprived of food for 24 hours every other day. Both methods improved glucose metabolism, increased insulin sensitivity, and increased stress resistance. Researchers have long been aware that calorie restriction extends life span, but this study showed that improved glucose metabolism also protects neurons in experimental models of Parkinson's and stroke.

Many large cloud providers such as Amazon, Google, and Microsoft have begun supporting Docker. name: Will the Bcl3-inhibiting drug, claimed to reduce the spread of breast cancer cells, enter clinical trials before the end of July 2014?
question_text:
Researchers at Cardiff University are developing a novel compound known to reverse the spread of malignant breast cancer cells. The vast majority of deaths from cancer result from its progressive spread to vital organs, known as metastasis. Recent studies has identified a previously unknown critical role for a potential cancer causing gene, Bcl3, in metastatic breast cancer. It has been shown that suppressing this gene reduced the spread of cancer by more than 80%. Dr. Richard Clarkson from Cardiff University's European Cancer Stem Cell Research Institute, and his team has identified a drug candidate that potently inhibits Bcl3. The compound was trialed on mice, and has shown it could completely inhibit the development of the mice's metastasis tumors.

Work in underway to progress the compound to clinical trials.

Drug to reverse breast cancer spread in development: http://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-01-drug-reverse-breast-cancer.html



Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Cardiff University: http://cardiff.ac.uk/
Cancer Research UK clinical trials database: http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/cancer-help/trials/trials-search/



Fine Print

The clinical trial will likely to take place in UK, where the university is located.

keywords: Perovskite, solar cells, lead-free, solar energy, photovoltaics, chemistry
name: What will be the next highest published efficiency of a tin-based perovskite solar cell?
question_text:
In early May 2014, two labs announced the creation of a lead-free perovskites solar cell. Perovskites solar cells were discovered in 2009 with an efficiency of ~4%. Further research resulted in drastic improvement in efficiency to 17.9%. These solar cells use lead, and due to concern over lead toxicity, researchers have been working on developing a cell that is free of lead.

Two groups successfully reached this goal, creating cells with efficiencies of just around 6% for cells with the compositions of CH3NH3SnI3.?? According to IEEE Spectrum: ?The tin-based cells, for example, actually produce a higher voltage than the original lead perovskite cells. ?It may well be that tin ends up being higher efficiency,? says Snaith.?


Links and sources

  • Hao, F., et al.? ?Lead-free solid-state organic?inorganic halide perovskite solar cells.? Nature Photonics (4 May 2014) http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nphoton.2014.82.html
  • Noel, N., et al. ?Lead-Free Organic-Inorganic Tin Halide Perovskites for Photovoltaic Applications.? Energy Environ. Sci., 2014, Accepted Manuscript http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2014/ee/c4ee01076k#!divAbstract
  • Two Labs Get the Lead Out of Promising Perovskite Solar Cells http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/green-tech/solar/two-labs-get-the-lead-out-of-promising-perovskite-solar-cells

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

A paper published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

Tin-based solar cell: a lead-free perovskite cell that contains tin.Efficiency rounded to the nearest tenth decimal place will be used to answer this question. "Next highest published efficiency"-the next paper published after May 6, 2014 that reports higher efficiency (ratio of the electrical output of the cell to the incident energy in the form of sunlight) than 5.73%. If no report on this topic is released by the question deadline, the question will resolve as 5.8 on the scale ("No Change / Very Small Change (<4% increase)) in Safe Mode.

keywords: Flu, region 10, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 10 (AK, ID, OR, WA)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 10' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 10 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 10 is comprised of Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, and Washington.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 10 is 1.1%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will the endangered status of the Horseshoe Crab, Limulus polyphemus, be changed from "near threatened" by March 31st, 2015?
question_text:
Human uses of the horseshoe crab started thousands of years ago with the indigenous people around the world. Today, they are used as bait for fisheries and their blood has become critically important?in medicine, where it has been applied for eye research and ensuring that our medicines are free of harmful bacteria.

Horseshoe crab blood is collected to induce an important pharmaceutical called Limulus amoebocyte lysate (LAL), which is used to test for human pathogens in human blood, tissues, and intravenous drugs. In order to meet this demand,?over 600,000 crabs?are captured each year during the spring mating season, to "donate" around 30% of their blood in a handful of specialist facilities in the United States and Asia. The blood is worth $60,000 a gallon in a global industry valued at $50 million a year.

As a result, horseshoe crab numbers declining, with the world's largest population in Delaware Bay reportedly reduced by between 75%?and 90% in the past 15 years. Although there are welfare procedures in harvesting the blood, between 10-30% of donor crabs die in the process. One?study?showed that survivors are also impaired after release and often incapable of mating, further threatening the population."It's difficult because the blood is crucial for human health issues but the biomedical industry needs to keep the population steady," says Christopher Chabot, a biology professor at Plymouth State, who led the study. "We suggest decreasing the time they are out of water, and maintaining an ambient temperature for transportation ... there is a lesser mortality rate if you keep them cool."

For more information:?

  • http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/04/health/this-crabs-blood-could-save-your-life/
  • http://www.endangeredspeciesinternational.org/horseshoecrabs.html
  • http://marinebio.org/species.asp?id=281



Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The status can be found here from the?International Union for Conservation of Nature:?http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/11987/0?or here?http://www.endangeredspeciesinternational.org/

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

keywords: proton magnetism, proton magnetic moment, antiproton magnetism, antiproton magnetic moment, particle physics, quantum physics
name: When will physicists successfully achieve a direct high-precision measurement of the antiproton?s magnetic moment?
question_text:
Antimatter and matter are mirror images of each other andwhen they meet, they annihilate each other in a flash of energy. Physicistsclaim that antimatter and matter were produced in equal amounts during the BigBang.? However, the universe is filledwith matter rather than antimatter ? so how come there was any matter left atall after the Big Bang? In the race to understand the Universe?s missingantimatter, physicists are working towards high-precision measurement of protonand antiproton magnetic moments. Any difference between the values of the twomay reveal why we were left with only matter.?

In a closer step towards understanding the Universe?smissing antimatter, a team of physicists directly measured the magnetic momentof the proton with high-precision using the double Penning-trap technique. ?Until now, the magnetic moment has only beenmeasured indirectly by analyzing the spectrum of an atomic hydrogen maser in amagnetic field. The new, most precise proton magnetic moment has been recordedat 3.3 parts per billion, which is 760 times more precise than the next bestdirect measurement made in 2012, and three times more precise than the nextbest indirect measurement made 42 years ago.
Physicists hope to use the same doublePenning-trap technique to achieve high-precision measurement of the antiproton?smagnetic moment at CERN. When CERN?s facility, known as the AntiprotonDecelerator re-opens this summer, Antihydrogen Trap (ATRAP), Baryon AntibaryonSymmetry Experiment (BASE) and three other groups will be using it in the race tofind any discrepancies between matter and antimatter.
?
For more information:
Proton's magnetism measured with greatest precision yet http://www.nature.com/news/proton-s-magnetism-measured-with-greatest-precision-yet-1.15310?
Precision measurement: The magnetic proton http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v509/n7502/full/509571a.html?
Direct high-precision measurement of themagnetic moment of the proton, A. Mooser, S. Ulmer, K. Blaum, K. Franke, H. Kracke, C. Leiteritz, W. Quint, C. C. Rodegheri, C. Smorra & J. Walz http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v509/n7502/full/nature13388.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

A paper published in a peer reviewed journal indexed byThomson Reuters? Web ofScience.? News report in science and technology press orpopular press.

Fine Print

In this new "direct" calculation, physicists measured the magnetism of the proton by trapping, storing and studying a single particle. Direct precision measurement is a very difficult process since such measurement involves a magnetic field with a larger spatial inhomogeneity. The earlier most precise measurement was achieved indirectly by means of spectroscopic studies of atomic hydrogen and input from separate theoretical calculations.

keywords: Solar energy, solar cells, photovoltaic energy, photovoltaic cells, multijunction solar cells, tandem solar cells, concentrated photovoltaics
name: Will the confirmed conversion efficiency for a multijunction, or tandem, solar cell (with any number of junctions) reach or exceed 46% by the end of 2014?
question_text:
Multijunctionsolar cells, also known as tandem solar cells, are cells made up of two or morep-n junctions constructed on top one another within the same monolithic cellstructure. Multijunction cells are able to achieve high conversion ratesbecause each of the individual junctions is optimized for a different segmentof the spectrum of incident solar radiation. As of September of 2013, afour-junction cell design developed jointly by the Fraunhofer Institute forSolar Energy Systems ISE, Soitec, CEA-Leti and the Helmholtz Center Berlinachieved an efficiency of 44.7% at concentrated illumination of 297 suns. Theefficiency of multijunction solar cells increases with the concentration ofincident solar radiation, and so most of record-breaking conversionefficiencies have been achieved under conditions of concentrated light,typically of 300x and above.?

Whenresearch laboratories achieve what they believe to be a new conversion record,their designs are independently confirmed, or verified, by other researchfacilities before they can be published as confirmed efficiency benchmarks.Overall conversion efficiencies for multijunction solar cells have been risingsteadily from 16% in 1983 to the current 44.7% level. The devices themselvescan be made up of anywhere from two to six layered junctions. This questionassess whether any multijunction device will have a reported confirmedefficiency of 46% or greater by the end of 2014.

Resolution Sources

Newmultijunction conversion efficiency records are reported in a range oftechnical news outlets that cover the solar industry, including bothspecialized outlets covering solar technology, such as Solar Power World, andalso general science-related outlets, such as phys.org.

Fine Print

Amultijunction solar cell is a solar cell design in which two or more separatep-n junctions are constructed monolithically within the same device. Reported,or verified, conversion efficiency is the conversion efficiency measured in thelab that has been reproduced (thus confirmed or verified) independently by asecond institution.

Useful Information and Links

Typicalarticles and websites include:

  • http://www.solarpowerworldonline.com/2013/01/multi-junction-solar-cell-to-break-efficiency-barrier/
  • http://phys.org/news/2013-02-multijunction-solar-cell-efficiency-goal.html
  • http://www.semiconductor-today.com/news_items/2013/APR/SHARP_260413.html

Related Organizations or Individuals

When new efficiency records are achieved these are confirmed by a second, independent laboratory before being reported as confirmed new efficiency records.

name: A NASA research team is currently conducting a small, low-budget experiment attempting to create a warp in spacetime. Will NASA's White?Juday warp-field interferometer experiment create a microscopic instance of a warping of spacetime before 2020?
question_text:
The White?Juday warp-field interferometer is an experiment attempting to create a microscopic instance of a warping of spacetime, led by Harold White of NASA's Johnson Space Center. This is the first of two currently planned spacetime warping experiments by NASA, this first experiment being a low-budget, 'low-fidelity' project using ordinary positive energy to try to warp local spacetime.

In the experiment, the interferometer splits a laser beam into two beams. Very high energy capacitors are placed around a small region of one beam. In theory, the beam will pass through the high energy region as though it were a shorter distance and take less time to travel through the region with the capacitors turned on versus off.? When the two beams are recombined, detectors look for tiny changes in the interference pattern.

The second planned experiment will attempt to extract negative energy to warp local spacetime using a line of technology called Q-thrusters, which work off the principle of pushing off of the quantum vacuum. The ultimate goal of these NASA projects is to prove or disprove the possibility of spacetime metric engineering with reasonable amounts of energy.

  • Wikipedia - White?Juday warp-field interferometer
  • Decoded Science - Faster then the speed of light? NASA looks at warp drive.
  • Scientific American - Warp Drive Research Key to Interstellar Travel
  • Wikipedia - Warp-Field Experiments

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

NASA will report any conclusive breakthroughs in warp field research on their website. Additionally, any such breakthrough will definitely be covered by scientific publications, as well as the mainstream press.

Fine Print

A conclusive breakthrough will resolve this question.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by a coronavirus called MERS-CoV. Most people confirmed to have MERS-CoV infection developed severe acute respiratory illness. They had fever, cough, and shortness of breath. About 30% of people confirmed to have MERS-CoV infection have died.

There is currently an outbreak of MERS-CoV going on in Saudi Arabia.?Between 3 and 19 November 2014, the National IHR Focal Point for the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA) notified WHO of 18 additional cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infection, including 4 deaths.

Fine Print

Number of cases will be based on report to WHO by Saudi Arabian authorities.

name: Which of the following will be found to contain graph non-isomorphism by 1 January 2018?
question_text:
Graph non-isomorphism is the language of encodings of pairs of non-isomorphic graphs (in the usual sense of an isomorphism from graph theory). This problem is known to lie in co-NP.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on judgment delivered by the question moderator. If nothing is reported from this source, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the question moderator. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means prior to the end of the day on 1 January 2018 (11:59:59 pm ET).

Related Organizations or Individuals

Question Moderator - Scott Aaronson (MIT, CSAIL)

name: When will a medical testing company provide a blood test for major depressive disorder (MDD)?
question_text:
Blood tests are routine for an enormous range of medical conditions. To date, however, there is no blood test for major depressive disorder (MDD), also known as clinical depression, major depression, unipolar depression, or unipolar disorder. Recent research has identified several genetic markers in blood that appear at different levels (versus control group) in patients who self-reported as depressed. This research has raised the prospect of a clinically reliable blood test for MDD.

Most standardized blood-based diagnostic testing is performed by medical testing companies.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.scopus.com/record/display.url?eid=2-s2.0-84907367946&origin=inward&txGid=05F6C174DFE9F756...
  • http://www.newsweek.com/first-blood-test-depression-holds-promise-objective-diagnosis-270951
  • http://www.questdiagnostics.com/home/physicians/testing-services.html


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

The availability of a blood test from a medical testing company will be reported by the company offering the test. These companies indicate what conditions they offer tests for on their websites, e.g. for Quest Diagnostics: http://www.questdiagnostics.com/home/physicians/testing-services.html.

This question will resolve when a test is first made available, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.


Fine Print

A blood test for depression is any offered with the word "depression" in it's label. The test in question must be a direct test of a depressive disorder, not of a medical condition such as a thyroid condition.

choices_field_4: No additional conifers will be sequenced
name: What will be the next conifer species whose genome is sequenced by January 1, 2017?
question_text:
Conifer species have existed for morethan 200?million years. They make-up most forests and are ecologically andeconomically important making them interesting to genome sequencingresearchers. Conifer?s genomes are very large, requiring researchers toresearch new techniques to sequence the genomes. ?

Recent advances have enabledresearchers to sequence the very large genome of the loblolly pine tree genome.On March 20, 2014, Neale et al. reported their sequencing of a loblolly pinetree genome using an inventive technique that combined the whole genome shotgunapproach with ?new computational approaches to reduce the assembly problem to atractable scale.? The loblolly pinetreegenome has 22.18 billion base pairs, making it thelargest genome sequenced to date. Previously, the record had been held by thesequencing of the Norway spruce genomewith its approximately 20 billion base pairs. ?

Future sequencing of conifer species maydepend on these advances or may depend on future advances.

Sequencing also depends on funding for the work. The Funding for the Loblolly Pine Genome Project is provided by the USDA with the goal of the development "of a high quality reference genome sequence for loblolly pine, Douglas-fir and sugar pine by means that can serve as a model approach for sequencing other large, complex genomes and empower the forest tree biology research community and the broader biological research community in the practical use and application of this resource." A reference sequence for slash pine is also planned to be created in this program.

Links and Sources

  • Decoding the massive genome of loblolly pine using haploid DNA and novel assembly strategies http://genomebiology.com/2014/15/3/R59/abstract
  • Largest Genome Ever Sequenced http://news.sciencemag.org/biology/2014/03/scienceshot-largest-genome-ever-sequenced?ref=em
  • The Norway spruce genome sequence and conifer genome evolution http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature12211.html
  • Genetics Society of America http://www.genetics-gsa.org
  • Pine reference sequence http://pinegenome.org/pinerefseq/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Publication in a scientific journal.

Fine Print

The publication date of the paper describing the genome sequencing in a scientific journal will determine the resolution to this question.

name: How many states will report at least one 2014 case of a human West Nile virus neuroinvasive disease by 1 July 2014?
question_text:
• West Nile virus is an arthropod-borne virus (arbovirus) most commonly spread by infected mosquitoes. West Nile virus can cause febrile illness, encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or meningitis (inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal cord).
  • As of January 7, 2014, 48 states and the District of Columbia reported cases of West Nile virus infections that occurred in 2013 in people, birds, or mosquitoes. A total of 2,374 cases of West Nile virus disease in people, including 114 deaths, have been reported to CDC for 2013. The only two states that did not report a West Nile virus infection in 2013 were Alaska and Hawaii.
  • Less than 1% of people who are infected will develop a serious neurologic illness such as encephalitis or meningitis. Neuroinvasive disease cases were reported to the CDC from the following states for 2013: Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming.
  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US at http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • The CDC case count is updated once a week during the transmission season.
  • Since it is more likely West Nile infections will appear in a few states by July 1 rather than many states, the bins used in "safe mode" forecasting are asymmetrical based approximately on a log scale.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2014

Resolution Source

  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US. Their surveillance page will resolve this question - http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • The CDC case count is updated once a week during the transmission season. The first update after July 1, 2014 will be used to resolve this question.

Fine Print

In one in every 150 infections, the virus gets into the brain (encephalitis) or into the tissues covering the brain and spinal cord (meningitis). This is what the CDC calls "neuroinvasive" West Nile disease.

keywords: Flu, Region 6, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 6 (AR, LA, NM, OK, TX)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???

  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 6' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 6 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 6. Region 6 is comprised of Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Texas.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: When will the Australian contracted search awarded to Fugro under RFT 570-04 for MH 370 begin?
question_text:
Between Malaysia and Australia, it was agreed upon that Australia will lead the search for MH 370. The inclusion of this agreement makes Australia responsible for the contracting of the commercial services that take on the search efforts.?The Australian Government via ATSB?published?a Request for Tender for provision for services relating to the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on June 4, 2014. The bids were closed on June 30, 2014 and on August 6, 2014 the Australian Government selected Dutch oil-and-gas consulting firm Fugro to lead the search for MH370 (the subject of Q#730).

  • AUS Tender: Request for Tender for Provision for Services relating to the Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
  • RFT No. 570-04:?Request for Tender for Provision for Services relating to the Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
Note:? this question is an extension of a previously resolved question, Q#735.? The most recent projection (as of 09/25) is that the search will begin in October.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/06/2014

This question will be resolved based on the date the first airplane, ship or submarine is deployed to the search area and paid for under the the contract awarded to Fugro as a result of RFT 570-04. The date and time of said deployment based on the AEST time zone will be used to settle this question. The commencement of data log analysis or satellite imagery will not be used to resolve this question.? Other searches executed by the the Australian or other Government or private entities will not count toward resolution.

name: Will global mobile cellular subscriptions reported by the International Telecommunication Union surpass the number of people on the planet by the end of 2014?
question_text:
The InternationalTelecommunication Union (ITU) is the United Nations specialized agency forinformation and communication technologies. It is responsible for allocatingglobal radio spectrum and satellite orbits, developing technical standards thatensure global network interoperability, and advocates for bringingtelecommunications connectivity to all the world?s people, regardless of wherethey live or the resources at their disposal.

As part ofits mission the ITU maintains statistics on a range of topics related to informationand communication technology (ICT). A summary of these statistics are presentedin the organization?s annual ICT Facts and Figures report, released during thefirst quarter of each calendar year for the preceding year. The report foryearend 2014 is expected to be publicly published early in 2015.

The 2013report was released on February 27, 2014, and reports 6.84 billionmobile-cellular subscriptions for yearend 2013, up from 6.41 billion the yearbefore. As of April 15, 2014, the U.S. Census Bureau estimate of globalpopulation was 7.16 billion.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/default.aspx
  • http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/facts/default.aspx
  • http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Documents/facts/ICTFactsFigures2013-e.pdf
  • http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Documents/statistics/2013/ITU_Key_2005-2013_ICT_data.xls
  • http://www.census.gov/popclock/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The ITU willreport global mobile-cellular subscriptions for 2014 in its 2014 ICT Facts andFigures report, available here when published:?http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/facts/default.aspx. The publication also reportsworld population.

name: Will a nanomachine containing a nanomotor successfully deliver a drug to a targeted location in a human being by 2019?
question_text:
Chemotherapy is just one application where it would be preferable for drugs to be delivered to just the tumor instead of to the tumor and all the healthy cells in the body as currently done. One way to deliver medicine in this fashion is through nanomachines. These machines measure less than a micron and can be injected into the body to find tumors or other specific cells. Once found, the nanomachine could release the drug in a very targeted fashion. Currently these machines exist in different forms, but not in the form with a nanomotor and the ability to deliver drugs in the body. However, recent advances in nanomotors make this more of a possibility than before.

Links and sources
  • Smallest and Fastest Nanomotor Could Advance Drug Delivery http://spectrum.ieee.org/nanoclast/devices/smallest-and-fastest-nanomotors-to-date-could-advance-drug-delivery
  • Nakano, T., et al. Cooperative drug delivery through molecular communication among biological nanomachines. in Communications Workshops (ICC), 2013 IEEE International Conference on. 2013. http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=6649344&tag=1
  • Kim, K., et al., Ultrahigh-speed rotating nanoelectromechanical system devices assembled from nanoscale building blocks. Nat Commun, 2014. 5. http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2014/140407/ncomms4632/full/ncomms4632.html
  • Wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanorobotics#Nanomedicine

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

The mechanism must be on the nano-scale (less than a micrometer) with a mechanical working motor and shown to be able to carry and release drugs and be inserted into a human being.

name: What kind of a computing device will be used to create the first 8-man chess endgame tablebase?
question_text:
• Chess endgame tablebases are computer databases of chess endings with precise and exhaustive calculations showing optimal play in any position with 100% certainty, under the constraint of the maximum number of pieces on the board.?
  • A game-theoretical value (win, loss or draw) is provided for each possible move in each possible position?along with the number of moves necessary to achieve the result with optimal play for both sides.?
  • The first endgame tablebases (4-man)?were built in the late 1980s. In 2005, 6-man endings were solved in Nalimov Tablebases widely used by chessplayers and chess engine programmers.?
  • Experts didn?t expect 7-man positions to be fully?cracked and?catalogued until after 2015, but Russian?programmers?Viktor Zakharov and Vladimir Makhnychev, associated with Convekta Ltd,?managed to solve the problem?in just 6 months culminating in August 2012,?using a new algorithm run on the Lomonosov supercomputer based in the Moscow State University.
  • The importance of the anticipated arrival of the 8-man tablebase lies not only in the impact on the understanding of chess endings and the game of chess in general, but also in how it will be an expression of computing power and algorithm efficiency.?
  • Chess News
  • World Chess Federation
  • Endgame Tablebase Wikipedia

breakthroughs in supercomputing technology, development of more effective evaluation algorithms

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2025

Resolution Source

Question?will be resolved based on a public announcement of the arrival?of the relevant tablebase. Potential media outlets include, but are not limited to:

  • Chess.com
  • World Chess Federation
  • Chessok
  • Chessnews

Fine Print

If the question resolves as a combination of a quantum computer and a supercomputer, neither the sole option of 'quantum computer' nor 'supercomputer' will be deemed to have resolved correctly

keywords: CERN, BASE, Antiproton Decelerator, CPT symmetry, proton, antiproton, Standard Model, magnetic moment
name: Will CERN's AD be able to detect any evidence that would violate the charge-parity-time (CPT) symmetry in its BASE experiment in 2014?
question_text:
The BASE experiment will exploit CERN's existing Antiproton Decelerator (AD) to trap and measure a single antiproton's magnetic moment, and compare it with the same measurement on a proton. Any difference will imply a violation of CPT symmetry, which would point to physics beyond the Standard Model.

  • CERN: the European Organization for Nuclear Research based in the northwest suburb of Geneva on the Franco-Swiss border.
  • BASE: an experiment at CERN that will make comparison measurements of antiproton and proton magnetic moment. Any difference between the two measurements will imply the violation of CPT symmetry.
  • Charge-parity-time symmetry (CPT)?is a fundamental?symmetry?of?physical laws?under the simultaneous?transformations?of?charge conjugation?(C),?parity transformation?(P), and?time reversal?(T).
  • AD: Antiproton Decelerator

Resolution Sources

Physics World

Fine Print

In order for the question to resolve true, the AD must be used to trap a single antiproton and make the most precise measurement of its magnetic moment.

Useful Information and Links

  • The world of physics in 2014: http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2013/dec/19/the-world-of-physics-in-2014
  • BASE: http://base.web.cern.ch/content/welcome-0

Related Organizations or Individuals

CERN's BASE collaboration
short_name: Testing CTP by antiproton's magnetic moment

name: On 15 September 2014, will the Arctic sea ice extent be less than that of 15 September 2013?
question_text:
Sea ice regulates exchanges of heat, moisture and salinity in the polar oceans.?The seasonal sea ice cycle affects both human activities and biological habitats.?Ice thickness, its spatial extent, and the fraction of open water within the ice pack can vary rapidly and profoundly in response to weather and climate.?On average, the seasonal decrease is much larger in the Antarctic, with only about 3 to 4 million square kilometers remaining at summer's end, compared to approximately 7 million square kilometers in the Arctic. Over the past several years, Arctic minima have been only 4 to 6 million square kilometers.

More information about Sea Ice can be found here, courtesy of the NSIDC's 'State of the Cryosphere'.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/14/2014

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved according to?Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency's Arctic Sea Ice Monitor:?http://www.ijis.iarc.uaf.edu/en/home/seaice_extent.htm.

Fine Print

The question asks whether the extent of Arctic sea ice on September 15, 2014, will be less than the corresponding value from the previous year. The sea ice extent is the total surface area of the Arctic under ice cover. On 15 September 2013, the Arctic sea ice extent was 4,834,931 square kilometers. Reporting from the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency's Arctic Sea Ice Monitor will be used to settle this question.

question_text:

Apple is expected to release a new product, the?Apple Watch, in "early 2015". How many Apple Watches will be sold during Apple's fiscal year 2015? This question will resolve based upon the value reported in Apple's annual report submitted to the SEC (form 10-K), which is expected to be available in late October, 2015. (For comparison, Apple's fiscal year 2014 ended September 27, 2014, and its form 10-K was filed on October 27, 2014.) This form will be available from the SEC via the EDGAR service, and will probably also be posted at?http://investor.apple.com/sec.cfm.

Apple's Annual Report for FY2015?(form 10-K) filed with the SEC, to be found at?http://investor.apple.com/sec.cfm?and expected to be available in late October, 2015.

Fine Print

If more than 200 million Apple Watches are sold during FY2015, this question will resolve at "200 million".

name: Will the WHO recommended composition of the influenza virus vaccine for the 2015-16 northern hemisphere flu season contain A(H3N2)-like virus?
question_text:
In February of each year, the WHO consults with experts from?Collaborating Centers in the US, UK, Australia, Japan and China,?plus other partners, to review data gathered by the worldwide network of influenza laboratories.?The WHO then makes recommendations for the composition of the seasonal influenza vaccine for the Northern Hemisphere. The vaccine viruses recommended by WHO for the 2014-15 northern hemisphere influenza season are the same as those for the 2013-14 influenza season, and contain an A/California/7/2009(H1N1)pdm09-like virus, an A/Texas/50/2012(H3N2)-like virus, and a B/Massachusetts/2/2012-like virus.?

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Arizona?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Arizona, 54.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -1.0% from 2011 (55.3%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%.The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 53.4%, the "53.4%-56.8% range will be deemed correct.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in states with historically 'very high' HPV vaccination coverage?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC): http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • The 'very high' HPV vaccination group of states is comprised of the following : (2011 coverage rate % / 2012 coverage rate %)
    • Connecticut (60.5 / 57.6)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/474/trades/create/safe
    • District of Columbia (55.0 /?57.8)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/485/trades/create/safe
    • Hawaii (73.1 / 64.6)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/478/trades/create/safe
    • Iowa (53.5 / 57.5)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/482/trades/create/safe
    • Massachusetts (61.1 / 69.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/491/trades/create/safe
    • Rhode Island (76.1 / 73.7)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/516/trades/create/safe
    • Vermont (63.0 ?/ 66.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/523/trades/create/safe
  • These states are?primarily Northeastern states with very Democratic constituencies, high longevity, and high rates of DTAP vaccination.
  • The vaccination rate of the group?will be determined by calculating an unweighted?arithmetic mean of the 2013 data for the 7 states.
Related Predict Question:?What percentage of the US female population aged 13-17 will be vaccinated against HPV by the end of 2013?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here: http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

Clusters of states were created by first analyzing state-level variables that correlate with HPV vaccination coverage in 2011 and 2012. The model for predicting HPV vaccination coverage explained over half the variation among states. On the most useful variables, states in a given cluster are more similar to each other than to states in other clusters.The range of possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 63.0%, the "Between 63.0% and 65.0%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Dairy, Powder Milk, Global Dairy Trade
name: Will the trade price of Whole Milk Powder fall below $3000 per tonne by December 31, 2014?
question_text:
The Global Dairy Trade (GDT) is an auction platform for internationally traded commodity dairy products.? GDT provides a reliable and transparent means for buying and selling dairy commodity products from around the world through an online auction process.? Two auctions are held every month, attracting hundreds of active bidders; between them, they represent more than 90 countries.? Sellers are based in USA, Europe, India and Oceania and together offer a diverse range of product lines.? Over the last 5 years they have sold millions of metric tonnes of dairy product via GDT, with a combined tonnage of nearly 900,000 metric tonnes in 2013.? The market recognizes that GDT provides a credible reference price for globally traded dairy commodities.? Sellers are confident that their product is selling for the current market price, and buyers know that they will never pay more than any other bidder for that product.

Recently global dairy trade prices have seen significant decreases, especially in whole milk powder.? The industry is also observing how Fonterra, one of the top sellers in the GDT is closing deals and influencing the prices.

Relevant Links
  • Whole Milk Powder Price Statistics
  • Global Dairy Trade Price Index Statistics
  • Global Dairy Trade Falls 4.2%
  • Fonterra's Forecast Payout May Be Cut

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/30/2014

Resolution Source

The Global Dairy Trade publishes bi-weekly statistics on trade prices for butter and other milk derived products.? This question will resolve true if the 'Average Winning Price' for Whole Milk Powder is below $3000 per tonne by December 31, 2014.

Fine Print

'tonne' is a unit of mass equivalent to 1,000 kilograms or 2,204.6 pounds, it is also known as the metric ton in the USA.

keywords: influenza, flu, vaccine, B virus, WHO
name: Will the WHO recommended composition of the influenza virus vaccine for the 2015-16 northern hemisphere flu season contain B/Massachusetts/2/2012-like virus?
question_text:
In February of each year, the WHO consults with experts from?Collaborating Centers in the US, UK, Australia, Japan and China,?plus other partners, to review data gathered by the worldwide network of influenza laboratories.?The WHO then makes recommendations for the composition of the seasonal influenza vaccine for the Northern Hemisphere. The vaccine viruses recommended by WHO for the 2014-15 northern hemisphere influenza season are the same as those for the 2013-14 influenza season, and contain an A/California/7/2009(H1N1)pdm09-like virus, an A/Texas/50/2012(H3N2)-like virus, and a B/Massachusetts/2/2012-like virus.?

  • Recommended composition of influenza virus vaccines for use in the 2014-2015 northern hemisphere influenza season:?http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/recommendations/201402_recommendation.pdf
  • Select viruses for the seasonal influenza vaccine:?http://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/season/vaccine-selection.htm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2015

Resolution Source

Recommendation will be made by WHO in February 2015:?http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/recommendations/en/

keywords: Flu, Region 4, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 4 (AL, FL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, and TN)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 4' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 4 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 4 is comprised of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 4 is 1.9%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will the first LightSail spacecraft successfully unfurl its Mylar sheets along its booms to form its 32-square-meter sail when it is launched in 2015?
question_text:
Solar sails are propelled by the momentum that photons impart when they bounce off a reflective surface. This method of propulsion can provide?slow but?steady acceleration to high speeds, which could cut?down on the cost and mass of interplanetary missions.?

LightSail is a CubeSat and is a citizen-funded project by The Planetary Society. The Society is planning on sending two small spacecraft into Earth orbit carrying large, reflective sails measuring 32 square meters (344 square feet). The first mission is a planned May 2015 test flight that the society hopes will pave the way for a second, full-fledged solar sailing demonstration in 2016.?

Solar sails are currently thought to be the best bet to get to the stars, and the May flight will check that the sail deployment and other systems work as designed. ?

For more information: ?

  • http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/space-flight/privatelyfunded-solar-sail-prepared-for-launch
  • http://sail.planetary.org/
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/27/science/space/new-phase-of-space-travel-hopes-to-set-sail-on-sunli...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by an announcement by The Planetary Society:?http://www.planetary.org.?

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

?successfully? means that (1) the Mylar sails are deployed from their storage cavities, and (2) the booms fully extend all sails. http://www.planetary.org/blogs/jason-davis/2014/20140924-lightsail-sails-ditl.htmlThe first mission is currently scheduled for May, 2015. If the mission is postponed, this question will be extended to after the updated launch date. If the mission is cancelled, the question will be resolved as "No".

keywords: U.S., Lemon, Value, Production, USD, 2013-2014, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total value of U.S. lemon production for the 2013-2014 marketing season, in thousands of USD?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Citrus Fruits Summary' following the conclusion of the marketing season in September. This full-text report contains the annual summary, by state and citrus fruit crop, of acreage, yield, production, utilization (fresh and processed), price, and value of the current year crop ad revised previous two years' crop.?
  • The value of?U.S. lemon production for the 2012-2013 marketing season totaled 405,220 in thousands of USD.
  • The value of lemon production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as lemons are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average value of production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in value of?productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary'.?

Total value of lemon production is reported in thousands of USD, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.

Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service

Fine Print

The '2013-2014 marketing season' begins 08/01/2013 and ends 07/31/2014.

'Total value of production' is the 'packinghouse-door equivalent'. 'Packinghouse-door' equivalent is defined as all fruit, regardless of methods of sale, converted to a price it would have brought if the entire crop, or segment thereof being priced, had been sold at the packinghouse-door.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary' that is published annually in September.

Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Citrus Fruits:?http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/MannUsda/viewDocumentInfo.do?documentID=1031
  • USDA NASS Citrus Fruits Summary 2013:?http://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/Todays_Reports/reports/cfrt0913.pdf
  • Honeybee Colony Collapse Disorder:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony_collapse_disorder
  • NRDC Honeybee Pollination:?http://www.nrdc.org/wildlife/animals/files/bees.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service

name: Will the World Health Organization classify e-cigarettes as tobacco products under the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) in 2014?
question_text:
Electronic cigarettes use battery powered cartridges to produce a nicotine-laced inhalable vapor. The e-cigarette industry has been booming in the last two years. Analysts have estimated the worldwide sale of e-cigarettes?to be?$3 billion in 2013.?
In a meeting in November 2013, WHO indicated it would favor applying similar restrictions to all nicotine-containing products. It views e-cigarettes as a "threat" and wants them classified the same way as regular tobacco products under the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC). ?However, leading scientists have urged the?WHO not to classify e-cigarettes as tobacco products, arguing that doing so jeopardizes a major opportunity to slash disease and deaths caused by smoking. Proposed regulation would mean smokers find it harder to access a less risky alternatives.
The Geneva-based WHO said its position on e-cigarettes was still in flux ahead of a key meeting on the FCTC scheduled for October 13-18, 2014?in Moscow, where proposed regulations will be discussed.

  • http://news.yahoo.com/top-scientists-warn-not-stub-e-cigarettes-230843364--finance.html
  • http://www.clivebates.com/documents/WHObureausummary.pdf
  • http://www.gpb.org/news/2014/05/27/e-cigarette-industry-is-%E2%80%98wild-wild-west%E2%80%99



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

The World Health Organization's Framework Convention of Tobacco Control:?http://www.who.int/fctc/en/

Fine Print

WHO: World Health Organization

categories: Computational Sciences,Information Systems,Engineered Technologies,Prize-Eligible Nov & Jan
name: On NOV 2014, what will be the (performance-weighted) gigaflops per watt of the Top 500?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The Nov 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between Nov 16, 2014 ? Nov 21, 2014.?

This question asks what the average performance efficiency in terms of power consumption will be of the Top500 when weighted by system performance.

Questions from the Jun 2014 Top 500

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/22/2014

Resolution Source

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 statistics published at?http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources
Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list?

Fine Print

By performance-weighted, we mean the average of all 500 machines, weighted by each machine?s raw computing performance (Rmax Gflops).So for example, the performance-weighted average <u>efficiency</u> (Gflops/watt) is calculated by: (1/500) * ?i wi * ei, where ei is the efficiency of machine i, and wi is the weight given to that machine. The weight is always that machine?s proportion of the total Top500 computing power (Rmax Gflops): wi = Rmaxi / (?i Rmaxi), where Rmaxi is the Rmax score (Gflops) for machine i.
