name: Industry association SEMI reported that 2013 worldwide sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment reached US $31.58 billion. What will the total be for 2014?
question_text:
SEMI, the global industry association for companies that supply manufacturing technology and materials to the world?s chip makers, reported that worldwide sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment totaled $31.58 billion in 2013, representing a year-over-year decrease of 14%. The data are available in the?Worldwide Semiconductor Equipment Market Statistics (SEMS) Report.

SEMI projects that worldwide sales of new semiconductor manufacturing equipment will contract 13.3% to $32.0 billion in 2013, according to the?SEMI Year-end Forecast.?In 2014, SEMI expects strong positive growth resulting in a global increase of 23% in sales and?2015 sales are expected to continue to grow 2.4%.

Electronic Design?reports?Gartner anticipates 2014 semiconductor capital spending will increase by just over 14%, followed by 13.8% growth in 2015.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The SEMS Report which is?expected to be released in March 2015

Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the reported value is $33.5 Billion, the "Between $33.5 and $35.6 Billion" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Natural gas, Energy Information Administration (EIA), nonrenewable energy
name: Will the U.S. become a net exporter of natural gas by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Due to recent technological advances in horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, U.S production of natural gas has increased dramatically. In the 2014 Annual Energy Outlook the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) projects that the U.S. will become a net exporter of natural gas in 2016, a revision from last year's estimate of 2018. The U.S. has been a net importer of natural gas since the late 1950s.

Relevant Links:

  • Natural Gas Explained [EIA.gov]
  • Natural Gas Monthly
  • Time Series Chart of U.S. Natural Gas Imports
  • Annual Energy Outlook 2014 Early Release Report


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) publishes annual and monthly data on net natural gas imports and exports in the Natural Gas Monthly report.? If annual net exports of natural gas are greater than annual net imports for a given year then the U.S. will be a net exporter.

Fine Print

For the purpose of this question, "net exports" will be assessed on an annual basis for the year 2016.
short_name: U.S. net exporter of natural gas

name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "Status and trends of linguistic diversity and numbers of speakers of indigenous languages" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

Useful Links

  • http://www.cbd.int/gbo/?
  • https://www.cbd.int/cop/
  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/gbo/gbo2/cbd-gbo2-en.pdf
  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/publications/gbo/gbo3-final-en.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

The fourth edition of the Global Diversity Outlook report issued by The Convention on Biological Diversity

name: Will a new drug resistant "Superbug" be responsible for a fatal infection in a U.S. hospital before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
The public health threat of antibiotic resistant strains of bacteria or superbugs?was highlighted last year in a WHO report?that warned the world was entering a ?post-antibiotic era?. The UK?s chief medical officer, Sally Davies, put antibiotic resistance on the government?s national risk register, alongside terrorist attacks and pandemic flu. In December, a report commissioned by David Cameron warned that failure to tackle drug-resistant infections will cost the global economy up to $100tn USD by 2050.

Antibiotic resistant strains of bacteria or superbugs infect over 2 million people annually?in the United States?alone and kill at over 23,000. New resistant bacterial strains are continuing to be isolated including the drug resistant superbug CRE which?appeared in U.S. hospitals within the?past five years.?

For more information:
  • http://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/
  • http://www.who.int/drugresistance/documents/surveillancereport/en/
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/04/world/asia/superbugs-kill-indias-babies-and-pose-an-overseas-threa...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved according to the Center for Disease Control.?

www.cdc.gov, www.who.org

Fine Print

"Superbug" refers to a strain of bacteria resistant to one or more antibiotics that would normally be used to treat it. "Fatal infection" refers to any human who has died due to an infection from the new bacterial strain. The infection must be contracted within the United States.

*Admin Update: For this question to resolve as ?true? (1) a bacterium that was not previously known by medicine to have acquired significant drug resistance to a class of antibiotics acquired resistance or (2) a known resistant but treatable bacterium that acquired drug resistance to a different class of antibiotics would have to cause a fatal infection.

keywords: perovskite oxides, memristors, nanoionics, nanoscale resistive switching
name: Will a working prototype using perovskite oxide memristors for ultra-fast data storage in a nanoscale memory device be produced by 2016?
question_text:
As flash memory is approaching fundamental scaling limits in the face of Big Data computing requirements, a team of researchers at the RMIT Functional Materials and Microsystems Research Group have built a novel nano-structure: a nanometer-thin stacked structure created using synthesized perovskite oxide material which is more than "10,000 times thinner than a human hair" providing scalable, ultra-fast, non-volatile and low energy 'memristive' performance. Memristors are the precursors to high-density nanoscale memories and the building blocks for neuromorphic computing ? mimicking the human brain where the memory element's behavior is dependent on its past actions. Memristors are touted as a revolutionary replacement for current hard drive technologies such as Flash, SSD and DRAM, in part because they can retain memory even through power loss.

Project Leader Dr. Sharath Sriram, says, "The structure we developed could be used for a range of electronic applications -- from ultrafast memory devices that can be shrunk down to a few nanometers, to computer logic architectures that replicate the versatility and response time of a biological neural network. While more investigation needs to be done, our work advances the search for next generation memory technology that can replicate the complex functions of human neural system -- bringing us one step closer to the bionic brain."
For more information:
http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/09/140929090352.htm
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adfm.201401278/full
http://www.scientificcomputing.com/news/2014/10/nano-scale-data-storage-mimics-brain-cells-boost-mem...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

An announcement or news release by a firm that creates a working prototype. Announcements by industry analysts in the technology news media. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.
short_name: pervoskite oxide memristors for data storage

name: On November 2014, what will be the Top 500 perfomance share by geographic region?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The November? 2014? ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conferencee is scheduled to occur between November 16, 2014 ? November 21, 2014.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by geographic region, and you think North America?s share will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust North America?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

keywords: Dark Matter, WIMPs, LZ, SURF, xenon
name: Will the second generation dark matter detector LUX-Zeplin (LZ) start to hunt for WIMPs before the end of 2017?
question_text:
In July 2014, the U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Science and the National Science Foundation announced support for a suite of upcoming experiments to search for dark matter that will be many times more sensitive than those currently deployed. These so-called Generation 2 Dark Matter Experiments include the LUX-Zeplin (LZ) experiment, to be managed by?scientists?from DOE's Lawrence Berkley National Laboratory?and located at the Sanford Underground research facility (SURF).

  • http://phys.org/news/2014-07-next-generation-dark-green.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

Information and news on the project?can be found from Berkeley Lab's LZ Dark Matter Experiments webpage:?http://lz.lbl.gov/

Fine Print

Physicists believe dark matter could be made of difficult-to-detect particles called Weakly Interacting Massive Particles or WIMPs, which usually pass through ordinary matter without leaving a trace. The current LUX-Zeplin experiment consists of a one-third ton liquid xenon detector that sits deep underground where it is shielded from cosmic rays and is poised to find WIMPs. When one of these particles passes through the xenon detector, it should occasionally produce an observable flash of light.
short_name: LZ detector to hunt for WIMPs

name: Will a proof be published by 2050 showing Matrix Multiplication in O(n^{2+?}) time, for every constant ? > 0?
question_text:
Given A and B, two n*n square matrices over a field F, the matrix multiplication problem is to output the product C=A*B. Here, the "allowed operations" are to take products and affine combinations over F; these operations can be combined into an arbitrary circuit, which must have n2 outputs corresponding to the entries of C. The circuit can be completely different for each input size n, in a nonuniform manner; on the other hand, the same circuit must work for an arbitrary field F (though it need not work for rings).

Let S(n) be the size of the smallest such circuit for multiplication of two n*n matrices. Then this question is asking whether S(n)=O(n2+?) for every constant ?>0. Equivalently, let ? (the "matrix multiplication exponent") be the infimum over all c such that S(n)=O(nc); then this question is asking whether ?=2.

The obvious upper bound, ?=3, was improved by a long sequence of algorithms, starting with that of Strassen in 1968 (??2.78). The current record, ??2.373, was proved by Vassilevska Williams, building in part on work of Stothers (both of whom were building on the important 1990 result ??376, due to Coppersmith and Winograd): [PDF]

Meanwhile, the only lower bound known remains the "obvious" bound ??2, which comes from the fact that any matrix multiplication circuit must have n2 inputs and n2 outputs. (Indeed, for general algorithms, we know nothing better than S(n)?c*n2, though Ran Raz proved S(n)?c*n2*log(n) for a restricted class of algorithms.) Opinion on the question remains divided: some theoretical computer scientists profess belief that ?=2, but an ambitious program to prove that, due to Umans, Kleinberg, et al., has not (yet) panned out. Thus, at present, there is no clear proposal for what an algorithm achieving ?=2 would look like.

A "yes" answer to this question would consist of a rigorous proof that ?=2. It is plausible that such a proof would involve at least some nonconstructive elements, and this is perfectly acceptable. A "no" answer would consist of a rigorous proof that ??2. Since, at present, we lack the techniques for proving such circuit lower bounds, such a proof would be considered an enormous breakthrough in complexity theory. A proof that the answer is independent of the ZF axioms will be considered to resolve the bet. Proofs of independence from weaker formal systems will not count.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on judgment delivered by question moderator. If nothing is reported from this source, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed (e.g., direct outreach to prominent researchers in this field), provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the question moderator. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

Question Leader - Scott Aaronson (MIT, CSAIL)

keywords: Flu, region 6, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 6 (AR, LA, NM, OK, TX)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 6' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 6 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 6 is comprised of Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Texas.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 6 is 3.3%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will Google announce development of an Android TV at or before the Google I/O 2014 Conference?
question_text:
A number of TV systems are in production or already in the market such as the Playstation TV announced during E3 2014 (for North America), the Apple TV already in the market, and the Amazon Fire TV.? This leads to the question if Google will announce an Android TV in the Google I/O 2014 Conference.? There are rumors that suggest Google will announce this during the I/O 2014 Conference, but this has not been confirmed.

In general, 'Android TV' is defined to be a hardware and/or software platform that uses Android apps (from Google's Play Store) to provide TV, movie, or video game services. name: When will the first chess player achieve a rating of at least 2900?
question_text:
Since the 1970s when?the basic version of the modern chess rating was introduced, we have observed 7 chess players cross the rating of 2800, a notably prestigious feat in the chess world. Garry Kasparov's record of 2856 achieved in March 2000 has been broken by the current World Champion Magnus Carlsen, whose recent astonishing performances have elevated his rating into 2882 as of February 2014. The question asks you when a chess player will achieve a?rating of 2900 or higher.

Potential change of chess rating system

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

The outcome of this question will be resolved based on the published chess rating updates made by?FIDE (F?d?ration?Internationale des ?checs) or?2700chesss.com, which includes players with ratings over 2699.9, and?publishes updated chess ratings typically in less than one hour after the conclusion of the relevant games.Please note that this question refers specifically to the 'classical time control rating' of the player, and not their rapid or blitz rating"

name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "Connectivity ? fragmentation of ecosystems " in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

name: When will a manned submarine achieve speeds at or above 100 knots underwater using supercavitation?
question_text:
Supercavitation is the use of cavitation effects to create a bubble of gas inside a liquid large enough to encompass an object traveling through the liquid, greatly reducing the drag on the object and enabling it to move at very high speeds. This technique has to date only been applied to projectiles, such as torpedoes and underwater mine clearance systems. However, there are several projects in the works that are attempting to use supercavitation in new types of underwater submarines capable of transporting people and equipment underwater at speeds much higher than possible with current submersibles.

In 2005, DARPA announced the 'Underwater Express program', a research project to evaluate the potential of supercavitation. The program was scheduled to begin sea testing a small-scale version of a supercavitation-enabled vehicle in 2011, but has not publicized any of the results as yet. The U.S. Navy already has a ship, called GHOST, that it claims utilized supercavitation propulsion, though it is a hydrofoil and not a submarine.

Recently, Chinese scientists announced they are working on a?submarine that would?use supercavitation for civilian transportation. These scientists claim that their technology combines liquid-membrane technology with supercavitation, significantly reducing the challenges? to launching and control the craft.

Sources in links:

  • PopSCI - DARPA readies an ultra-fast mini-sub
  • Bloomberg - This stealth boat may be too innovative for the Pentagon
  • CityLab - Shanghai to San Francisco in under two hours?
  • Wikipedia - Supercavitation

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

For this question to be resolved, a manned submarine or underwater craft achieving speeds over 100 knots must be confirmed by an official government source or reported in an academic paper published in a journal indexed in Thomson Reuters Web of Science.

name: Will ultra-fast optical switches be developed by 31-DEC-2015 using the luminescent polymer (plastic) material that recently demonstrated Bose-Einstein Condensation (BEC) under room temperature at an IBM lab?
question_text:
Scientists at IBM Research have demonstrated Bose-Einstein condensation under room temperature, using a thin luminescent polymer (plastic) film developed by chemists at the University of Wuppertal in Germany. The phenomenon lasts for only a few picoseconds, but the scientists believe this is already long enough to use bosons to create a source of laser-like light and/or an optical switch for future optical interconnects. These components are important building blocks to control the flow of information in the form of zeros and ones between future chips and can significantly speed up their performance while using less energy.

Resolution Sources

  • Science magazine
  • Nature magazine
  • IEEE Spectrum

Fine Print

A Bose-Einstein condensation is a quantum phenomenon which occurs when a diluted gas of particles (bosons) are cooled to near absolute zero (-273 Celsius, -459 Fahrenheit). At this temperature intriguing macroscopic quantum phenomenon occurs in which the bosons all line up like ballroom dancers. This was first demonstrated in 1995 at extreme temperature.

The development of room temperature BEC plastic optical switch is considered when a working prototype model is built with the material and reported to the science and engineering community.

"By" is defined as prior to the end (23:59:59 pm ET) of the indicated date.

Useful Information and Links

  • BEC Demonstration with Plastic Film
  • IBM Scientists Demonstrate Quantum Phenomenon

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: Will Google make end-to-end PGP encryption a core feature in Gmail by August 2014?
question_text:
As a result of growing debate over user data surveillance, end-to-end encryption systems such as Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) are gaining in popularity. PGP is a form of public-key cryptography introduced in1991 which uses two sets of keys:
1)Public keys that can be uploaded tokey servers for anyone to view/use to encrypt messages;
2)Private keys that only individual users holdand are used to decrypt and sign messages.?
PGP has been toutedas a good method of end-to-end encryption that prying eyes on the web would findhard to crack. However, PGP encryption and key management poses some practical difficulties for users. For example, if a user forgets her key, it isimpossible to recover that key, and so messages encrypted using it are effectively lost.
Currently, the PGP plugin can be used in Gmail but only advanced web users are aware of this option and know to use it. News reports in April 2014 indicate that Google plans to makePGP encryption easy to use for all Gmail users. Widespread adoption of this technology by Google would be somewhat contrary to the company's business model -- if thecompany cannot read user messages, it cannot use them to direct targeted ads. With millions of email users, Google is in a good position to introduce mainstreamend-to-end encryption.
For more information, see:

  • http://venturebeat.com/2014/04/21/google-is-researching-ways-to-make-encryption-easier-to-use-in-gmail/
  • http://www.pcworld.com/article/2146721/google-reportedly-working-on-making-email-encryption-easier.html
  • http://www.wired.com/2014/04/google-crypto-gmail/


Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

Google will announce availability of PGP on their website, via blogs or company news. http://www.google.com/press/
Industry news reports could also resolve the question.



Fine Print

PGP will be defined as a "core feature" in Gmail when Google makes PGP a regular opt-in choice in Gmail's mail settings that all users, including novices in online security practices, can easily use.

name: When will Apple Watch be available for sale?
question_text:
The Apple Watch was announced by Apple in September 2014. It is a highly anticipated smartwatch that connects to Apple?s iPhones. Apple Watch has many health- and fitness-related features including an accelerometer and heart rate sensor . In addition, the watch shows text messages and mail notifications as well as functions as a phone with a microphone and speaker. It also have a NFC chip that will allow it to work with Apple Pay. The watch will run a new Apple operating system.

Apple announced that the watch would be for sale in ?early 2015? and recent reports point to ?spring 2015?. It is not clear if the delay is due to software or supply issues.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/31/2015

Official announcement.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

keywords: U.S., Almonds, Value, Production, USD, 2013, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total value of U.S. almond utilized production for the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of USD?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • The value of?U.S. almond utilized?production, (yield based on in-shell equivalents),?for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 4,347,200 in thousands USD.
  • The value of almond production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as almonds are solely dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Total value of almond production is reported in thousands of USD, in-shell equivalents,?thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service.


Fine Print

The 'total value of?U.S. almond utilized?production' is the yield based on 'in-shell?equivalents'.

The '2013 marketing season' for almonds begins 08/05/2013 and ends 11/15/2013.

'Total value of production' is the 'packinghouse-door equivalent'. 'Packinghouse-door' equivalent is defined as all fruit, regardless of methods of sale, converted to a price it would have brought if the entire crop, or segment thereof being priced, had been sold at the packinghouse-door.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.


Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts:?http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/MannUsda/viewDocumentInfo.do?documentID=1113
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Preliminary Summary:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-01-25-2013.pdf
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 11/19/2013 Sequestration Announcement:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-11-19-2013.txt
  • USDA Agricultural Statistics Annual:?http://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/Ag_Statistics/
  • Honeybee Colony Collapse Disorder:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony_collapse_disorder
  • NRDC Honeybee Pollination:?http://www.nrdc.org/wildlife/animals/files/bees.pdf
  • American Beekeeping Federation Pollination Facts:?http://www.abfnet.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=14

Related Organizations or Individuals

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service

Related Questions

  • Honeybee Colony Collapse
  • Almond Utilized Production

keywords: Almond, Harvest, California, Agriculture, Farming, Crops, Bee Colony Collapse
name: How many billions of pounds of almond meat will be harvested in California in 2013?
question_text:
California's 2013 almond production is forecast at 1.85 billion meat pounds, down 7.5 percent from May's subjective forecast and 2 percent below last year's crop. After a very cold winter, the 2013 almond crop began bloom 2 weeks later than normal. Bloom was strong and fast, which shortened overlap and pollination time. High winds in early April knocked nuts and branches off trees, as well as knocking down some trees. Nonpareil drop was reportedly heavy. Despite the late bloom, harvest is expected to start earlier than normal this year. Mite pressure has been high this year. Water has been a concern for growers in the San Joaquin Valley this year, as rainfall was very low and allotments have been reduced.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the USDA's 2013 California Almond Objective Measurement Report. It is anticipated that this report will be released in January 2014. If nothing is published by the USDA by January 31, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

  • www.almondboard.com
  • Scientific American

Fine Print

"Pounds of almond meat" is defined as the total pounds of almond meats (whole, chipped and broken, and in-shell meats). In-shell almonds will be converted to meat pounds in accordance with FCIC approved procedures., "In 2013" is defined as new installations occurring from 01/01/2013 - 12/31/2013. Reported number of pounds of almond meats harvested should be rounded to the nearest hundredth of a billion to determine the correct answer.

Useful Links

  • http://www.nass.usda.gov/Statistics_by_State/California/Publications/Fruits_and_Nuts/201306almom.pdf
  • ?http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=migratory-beekeeping-mind-boggling-math

Related Organizations or Individuals

USDA, http://www.usda.gov/wps/portal/usda/usdahome

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Oregon?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Oregon, 58.5% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -10.1% from 2011 (68.6%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 57.6%, the "57.6%-61.0%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: TALOS suits, inertial measurement, GPS, IMUs
name: Will inertial measurement units be integrated into US Special forces' TALOS suits to help dismounted soldiers detect their own location on the battlefront, by the end of 2018?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well equipped as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

An inertial measurement unit, or IMU, is an electronic device that measures and reports on a craft's velocity, orientation, and gravitational forces, using a combination of accelerometers and gyroscopes, sometimes also magnetometers. IMUs are typically used to maneuver aircraft, including unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), among many others, and spacecraft, including satellites and landers. Recent developments allow for the production of IMU-enabled GPS devices. If TALOS suits are equipped with IMUs, they can help provide accurate location information to the armed forces at the battlefront.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/?

http://www.darpa.mil/Our_Work/MTO/Programs/Micro-Technology_for_Positioning,_Navigation_and_Timing_%...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that may say the following: 1) the feature has been integrated into a non-prototype suit or 2) that the suits deployed on the ground have this feature.

keywords: inner ear, deaf, medicine, drugs, FDA, chemistry
name: When will the pharmaceutical industry produce a new drug to aid the deaf, by targeting the inner ear?
question_text:
The pharmaceutical industry?has done little in producing drugs to help aid against hearing loss. Currently some small drug firms are working to create drugs that work on the inner ear, while other firms are targeting the central nervous system, which processes sound. (CEN, Sound Science)

Some biotechs are working on drugs that target the inner ear, where sound is first perceived, whereas others are focused on the central nervous system, where sound is processed. Some want to treat damage that has already occurred; others hope to prevent it. Several of their projects are reaching late-stage development, and big pharma is starting to pay attention.

Drug companies find a lot to like about hearing loss: large numbers of patients, a lack of treatments, clinical trials with clear-cut end points, and a small universe of hearing specialists to call on. But the newness means they are starting from scratch when it comes to designing and recruiting for trials. ?The thing about hearing is it is actually pretty much white space,? says Barbara Domayne-Hayman, chief business officer of Autifony Therapeutics, a biotech firm developing treatments for hearing loss. ?There are no precedents, no templates. We?re figuring out how to do it as we go along.?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2028

Resolution Source

The question will be resolve when the Food and Drug Administration approves a drug that targets the inner ear for the purpose of lessening or mitigating?deafness and/or hearing loss in?humans.?

Fine Print

The drug must allow patients, clinically defined as deaf, to hear at a level greater than that of which they heard before, to satisfy the requirements of this question.

keywords: perovskite solar cell, solar cell windows, chemistry
name: Will a commercial building with perovskite solar cell windows be completed by the end of 2018?
question_text:
Oxford University physicist Dr. Henry Snaith and his Oxford PV group used perovskite material to develop thin-film solar cells that can be printed directly onto glass to be used as semitransparent, solar energy harvesting windows in large buildings.? The technology is patented in the US and samples are to be produced in a couple of years. Volume production of the cells is planned?to begin?in 2017.

name: How many threatened birds species will the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species identify in its next published update?
question_text:
The InternationalUnion for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) maintains and publishes the IUCN RedList of Threatened Species, widely recognized as the most comprehensive andobjective global approach for evaluating the conservation status of plant andanimal species. In order to produce the Red List, IUCN draws upon a network ofscientists and partner organizations working in almost every country in theworld.

The Red Listidentified species as threatened if they are classified by the IUCN asCritically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), or Vulnerable (VU). Species canalso be classified as extinct (EX) or extinct in the wild (EW); or in one of severalnon-threatened categories: Lower Risk/conservation dependent (LR/cd), NearThreatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD), Least Concern (LC).

In 2011, 2012,2013 and 2014 releases of the Red List, the IUCN reported 1,253, 1,313, 1,308, and 1,373threatened bird species respectively. The IUCN updates its list at least annually, so a newupdate should be available and published in 2015.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved when the IUCN publishes its next update to the RedList. The current list is version 2014.1 from 12 June 2014. The next updated list, once published, will be available in Table 1 and linked to here:? http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics

If no report is released by 12/31/2015, the deadline of this question may be extended until an update is posted.

Fine Print

IUCN definitions are being used for endangered species, per the discussion in the Background discussion.

name: When will the cause of the 250 km high Martian plumes, first seen in 2012, be determined?
question_text:
On February 16, 2015,?Nature published an article which discussed the mystery of the Martian plumes spotted in 2012. The origin?and composition?of these clouds is unknown, but the European Space Agency (ESA) states Hubble Space Telescope information coupled with amateur observations, are being used by a team?of astronomers to solve the mystery.

The features exhibited day-to-day variability, and were seen at the morning terminator but not at the evening limb, which indicates rapid evolution in less than 10?hours and a cyclic behavior. For particles reflecting solar radiation, clouds of CO2-ice or H2O-ice particles with an effective radius of 0.1?micrometers are favored over dust. Alternatively, the plume could arise from auroral emission, of a brightness more than 1,000 times that of the Earth?s aurora, over a region with a strong magnetic anomaly where aurorae have previously been detected. Importantly, both explanations defy our current understanding of Mars? upper atmosphere.

The team of astronomers is looking to gain additional information from the space agency's ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter, scheduled to launch in 2016.?

For more information:?

  • Martian mystery plume puzzles scientists
  • Bizarre Martian Plumes Discovered by Amateur Astronomers

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

This question will resolve based on information published by NASA,?major news sources, scientific journals, or by the resolution date, whichever comes first.

SciCast question administrators reserve the right to resolve the question using additional reputable resources not listed above.?

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:?http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Cloud - visible mass in the atmosphere composed of ice crystals (CO2 ice or H20 ice ) or dust crystals

question_text:
Screens continue to improve with each generation of smartphones. The HTC One X?had a 720p HD screen; the?Galaxy S4?and?HTC One?both stepped up to 1080p Full HD displays; and we are now seeing 2K displays on the likes of the?LG G3. The trend would suggest, therefore, that 4K displays will be commonplace within the next few generations of flagship phones. Sharp is reporting to have a 4K display smartphone ready for release in 2016. There are also rumors that the Galaxy S6, the next flagship smartphone?from Samsung?due to be released early next year, will feature a 4K display screen. name: Will California get more than 6 inches of precipitation in February 2015?
question_text:
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration made a prediction in March that there is about 50% chance of an El Nino developing this summer or fall. Because El Nino's warm pool feeds thunderstorms above, it creates increased rainfall across the east-central and eastern Pacific Ocean. Significantly wetter winters were present in northwest? Mexico and the southwest United States, including central and southern California, after the 1997 El Nino event. The monthly total precipitation in California was over 11 inches in February 1998. Historically, the average monthly total precipitation in California during February is?approximately 3.7 inches, based on data collected throughout the state from 1895 to 2014.

  • El Nino may bring good weather news? - depending on where you are :http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/06/us/el-nino-weather/index.html
  • NOAA NCDC Climate at Glance: http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cag/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement

2/28/2015

Fine Print

Precipitation data by state is reported by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Climatic Data Center for each month.

keywords: Coronavirus, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, MERS, MERS-COV
name: Will there be a lab-confirmed case of the coronavirus Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS or MERS-CoV) identified in Egypt by 1 October 2014?
question_text:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012 caused by a coronavirus called MERS-CoV. Despite the first case being discovered in 2012, little is known about how the virus spreads to people from animal hosts. However, it is known that the virus spreads from human to human. In addition, bats and camels have been found to be infected with MERS. ??So far, all the cases have been linked to countries in or near the Arabian Peninsula through residence in or travel to, indicating that modes of transmission outside of the Arabian Peninsula are through travel. Since April 2012,?lab-confirmed cases from the following countries have been identified:

  • France
  • Italy
  • Jordan
  • Kuwait
  • Oman
  • Qatar
  • Saudi Arabia
  • Tunisia
  • United Kingdom (UK)
  • United Arab Emirates (UAE) ?
No cases have been identified in Egypt yet. ??

??This virus has spread from ill people to others through close contact. Travel has been the primary way in which MERS-CoV has spread to people outside the Middle East.? This suggests that human infection of MERS-CoV to Egypt will most likely be a result of travel. On 10 November 2013, the Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia announced the detection of MERS- CoV in a specimen taken from an ill camel owned by a laboratory - confirmed case from Jeddah. This case had direct contact with the ill camel. ??

It may be likely that MERS has already spread to more countries, but has not been detected due to lack of knowledge or access to testing. However, in Sept 2013 the MERS gene was mapped and in Dec 2013, a group published a paper on their development of isothermal real-time RT-RPA, which they claim is ideal for rapid mobile molecular MERS-CoV monitoring. Therefore, it is more likely than ever that a case will be detected in the next 6 months.

Chu et al found MERS RNA in four camels in Egypt that had been imported from Sudan and Ethiopia.

Sources and references:
  • Vietnam on high alert over flu risk
  • Middle Eastern Virus More Widespread Than Thought
  • MERS Coronaviruses in Dromedary Camels, Egypt
  • The World Health Organization on Coronavirus infections
  • WHO update on MERS-CoV
  • CDC MERS information

Accepting Forecasts Until:

10/01/2014

Resolution Source

WHO update on MERS-CoV: http://www.who.int/csr/disease/coronavirus_infections
CDC MERS information: http://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/mers/
CDC GDD program: http://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/gdder/

Fine Print

Lab-confirmed: as announced by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or the World Health Organization (WHO).

keywords: Mars, Curiosity Rover, NASA, Space, Extraterrestrial life, organic matter
name: Will the Mars Curiosity Rover discover organic matter on Mars by September 1, 2014?
question_text:
• In 2003, scientists measured methane plumes rising over Mars, which many thought indicated macrobiotic life on the planet. However, in September 2012, the Curiosity Rover team reported in Science Magazine that the rover had not detected atmospheric methane reducing the probability of current methanogenic microbial activity on Mars. The Mars Curiosity Rover is still exploring and testing soils on Mars and may find organic material by end of 2014.
  • On December 9, Science reported "Curiosity?s new analyses of sediment from the bed of a long-vanished lake hint that Mars harbors substantial amounts of organic matter of some sort, although no one is yet willing to attribute it to ancient life...Curiosity?s Glavin [team member Daniel Glavin of NASA?s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland] says the results are ?exciting,? but he and the rest of the SAM [Sample Analysis at Mars] team are more cautious in print. So is organic geochemist Mark Sephton of Imperial College London, who is not on the Curiosity team. The results are ?very consistent with organic carbon,? he says, but he adds that so far they are ?tantalizing? rather than definitive.

Resolution Criteria

Information that organic matter attributed to ancient life must be reported in an official Mars Science Laboratory?research paper, or delivered by a NASA official spokesperson.

Resolution Sources

Space.com News, ScienceDaily, New York Times Science Section

Fine Print

"Organic matter" is defined as?compounds that come from the remains of once-living organisms. For the purposes of this question, the matter must be attributed to ancient life.

Useful Information and Links

  • Kerr, Richard. "New Results Send Mars Rover on a Quest for Ancient Life." Science. 9 Dec 2013 http://news.sciencemag.org/chemistry/2013/12/new-results-send-mars-rover-quest-ancient-life
  • NASA official Mars Curiosity Rover website: http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/msl/#.UpETX41Q1O4Kerr, R. A. (2013).
  • ?"Roving Into Martian Waters." SCIENCE 342(6156): 304-306. http://www.sciencemag.org/content/342/6156/304.full
  • Chang, Kenneth. ?Life on Mars? Well, Maybe Not.? New York Times. September 19, 2013. http://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/20/science/space/mars-rover-comes-up-empty-in-search-for-methane.html
  • Webster, C. R., P. R. Mahaffy, et al. (2013). "Low Upper Limit to Methane Abundance on Mars." SCIENCE 342(6156): 355-357. http://www.sciencemag.org/content/342/6156/355.abstractJet Proposal Laboratory. NASA.
  • ?Mars, Water and Life.? http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/msp98/why.html
  • Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. "NASA Mars rover Curiosity finds water in first sample of planet surface." ScienceDaily, 26 Sep. 2013. Web. 23 Nov. 2013.

Related Organizations or Individuals

The U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration Mars Science Laboratory Science Team, which is chaired by John Grotzinger and Michael Meyer.

name: Will a statistically significant number of patients enrolled in the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Molecular Analysis for Therapy Choice (MATCH) program display a positive reaction to the assigned treatment by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Traditionally, attempts to treat or cure cancer have divided cancer types into categories by the organ in which the cancer originated ? hence why cancers are known by names such as lung cancer, breast cancer, etc.? However, a new technique in the fight against cancer focuses instead on the genetic mutation that fuels the growth of the cancer cell as well as its potential spread to the rest of the body.? This technique results in a new focus for cancer drugs and a new format for cancer treatment trials.?

The new form of cancer drugs focus on blocking the specific mutation that changes ordinary cells into the cancer cells that that multiply out of control.? A wide variety of drugs that target different mutations make it possible that the particular mutation of a cancer can be matched by a drug designed for the purpose of stopping that mutation.? This type of targeted drug treatment is only possible because advances in gene sequencing have lowered the price to the point where any of 50-60 mutations can be identified in an individual patient?s cancer and the appropriate drug can be prescribed.

One of the challenges of targeted drugs is that it can be difficult assembling a sufficient number of patients to run a clinical trial. To combat this flaw a new format of study referred to as a ?basket study? has been developed. Basket studies involve combining a group of patients with different kinds of cancer that have the same underlying mutation and attempting to treat them with a drug targeted at the mutation. Due to the small size of the studies and the varied kinds of cancer possessed by the participants, control groups are nearly impossible to assemble; therefore, the results of the trial must be very dramatic to be sure that they are statistically significant.

The National Cancer Institute is launching a program called Molecular Analysis for Therapy Choice (MATCH) which will run a collection of basket studies focusing on a set of cancer mutations for which drugs are already available. This program is intended to demonstrate the value of basket studies as well as provide information on the impact of mutation targeted drugs.

For more information:
  • General Information on basket studies:
  • NCI Match program:
  • Preliminary results of first basket study:
  • More Information: Page 1, Page 2

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Announced in an official National Cancer Institute press release or published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Positive reaction refers to either a shrinking of the size of the tumor or the progression-free survival of the patient (the length of time during and after treatment that the cancer did not get worse). Either will be noted in the NCI press release on the result of the clinical trial. See for example http://www.cancer.gov/newscenter/newsfromnci/2014/OvarianNCT01116648ASCO

If the statistical significance of the study is not stated in explicitly, the question will be resolved as "No".

*Admin Update: The threshold for statistical significance is?p<0.05. If the study?s conclusions are valid only for p>0.05 or if they are not stated the question will resolve as "No".

name: Will ICANN delegate the operation of the generic top level domain "dot health" to an organization with no experience or expertise in healthcare in 2014?
question_text:
People turn to theInternet for advice on healthcare issues, sometimes second-guessing theirdoctor, to the extent that the phrase ?Dr. Google? is now common currency. Yetit is also obvious that much health and well-being advice on the net is bogus.The argument can thus be made that there should be a safe top-level Internetdomain name for reliable health information, where it would not be possible topost fraudulent claims of cures or ill-conceived, dogmatic advice on health. Thereis a lively debate going on around this serious public interest issue,occasioned by a major recent development.

The reason forthe debate is a decision by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names andNumbers (ICANN) to expand the range of global or generic top-level domains(gTLDs). ICANN is a largely self-referential body concerned with governance ofthe Internet, especially the allocation of gTLD names to organizations that bidto manage them. It was in the news recently when the US government announcedthat it would relinquish its special relationship with ICANNso as to avoid the impression that governance of the internet might be in thehands of one government. ICANN iscurrently proposing to allocate about a dozen health-related gTLDs, including?.doctor?, ?.nurse?, ?.hospital?, and others. For some of these, a websiteusing the relevant extension would have to be owned by an appropriatelyqualified person or organization: to be ?someone.doctor?, someone would have toshow that they are accredited as a physician (compare ?.edu? for educationalinstitutions). However, this principle has not been extended to all domains.

Mostcontroversial among the new gTLDs is the domain ?.health?, which, as thingsstand, is poised to be awarded to one of three commercially-oriented bidderswho seem to have little or no track record or expertise in healthcare, or anycommitment to public health. Despite this, ICANN does not consider it necessaryto not impose any further restriction or qualification on the use of ?.health?,so whoever gets control of it would be free to license its use by anyone, nomatter how irrelevant or misleading. This would evidently be subject to abuse. It is expensive both to apply for and tomaintain a gTLD ($185,000 non-returnable up front and $25,000 per annum) sothat commercial pressure will bias domain controllers not to discriminate toomuch on who is allowed to use it ? provided they are willing to pay enough.

ICANN posts Information about the process ofallocation of the ".health" domain name at http://icannwiki.com/index.php/.health. None of the three candidates appears tohave the necessary competence, or be prepared to seek a partner who has, tosafeguard health information on the net. The World Health Organization (WHO)bid for the ?.health? gTLD in 2000, when ICANN decided to postpone award of thedomain. The WHO has since been discouraged, arguably blocked, by a minority of influentialmember governments from bidding for the domain name again. Senior officerswithin the WHO have been frustrated by restrictions even to voicing theirobjections to the three current proposals. There is a good case to be made thatthe allocation of this gTLD should be postponed until questions about its usehave been explored and safeguards against its abuse have been put in place.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

The next meeting of ICANN is set to take place in London in the week of June 22nd, 2014. If ".health" is delegated on this occasion, the question will have been resolved and an announcement will appear on the ICANN website to the effect that ".health" ?has been delegated to an applicant.
If not resolved by the June meeting, the next 2014 ICANN meeting date will be used for resolution (details have not yet been announced). If no 2014 ICANN meeting delegates ".health" to an applicant, the question will resolve 'No'.

Fine Print

ICANN: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. Its operation is described on its website, beginning at:http://www.icann.org/en/about/welcome. "To reach another person on the Internet you have to type an address into your computer -- a name or a number. That address must be unique so computers know where to find each other. ICANN coordinates these unique identifiers across the world. Without that coordination, we wouldn't have one global Internet.In more technical terms, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) coordinates the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) functions, which are key technical services critical to the continued operations of the Internet's underlying address book, the Domain Name System (DNS). The IANA functions include: (1) the coordination of the assignment of technical protocol parameters including the management of the address and routing parameter area (ARPA) top-level domain; (2) the administration of certain responsibilities associated with Internet DNS root zone management such as generic (gTLD) and country code (ccTLD) Top-Level Domains; (3) the allocation of Internet numbering resources; and (4) other services. ICANN performs the IANA functions under a U.S. Government contract." [Recent developments appear to have Generic top level domain or gTLD: A domain such as .com or .org is a gTLD; ICANN has embarked on a program of massive expansion of possible gTLDs. Operation of gTLDs is "delegated" to organizations that apply for that privilege. Successful applicants may operate their delegated gTLDs for profit.WHO: The World Health Organization "is the directing and coordinating authority for health within the United Nations system. It is responsible for providing leadership on global health matters, shaping the health research agenda, setting norms and standards, articulating evidence-based policy options, providing technical support to countries and monitoring and assessing health trends." (quoted from its website http://www.who.int/about/en/)

keywords: UV photodetector, quantum efficiency, solar-blind sensor
name: Will solar-blind sensors, made using the low-cost UV photodetector developed by researchers at Northwestern University, be deployed by the US armed forces before the end of 2019?
question_text:
Researchers from Northwestern University have developed the world's highest quantum efficiency ultraviolet (UV) photodetector, an advance in technology that could aid in the detection of missiles and chemical and biological threats.The development of UV photodetectors has been driven by numerous applications in the defense, commercial, and scientific arenas. Until recently, photomultiplier tubes or silicon photodectors with UV band-pass filters were the only viable options for imaging in this important spectral range. Thanks to technological and scientific advances in the III-Nitride material system, high aluminum composition AlxGa1-xN-based semiconductor structures have become a promising alternative.

The military is interested in developing ground- and air-based solar-blind sensors to detect the UV signature of an active missile plume and provide early warning and potentially allow for missile tracking and ultimately interception. The military could also use the UV detectors and sources to detect biological threats.

Resolution Sources

Military Technology

Fine Print

Low-cost high efficiency ultraviolet (UV) photodetectors with high aluminum composition AlxGa1-xN-based semiconductor structures.

Military application of this technology would include sensors to detect missiles and chemical and biological threats.

Useful Information and Links

World's highest quantum efficiency UV photodetectors developed: http://phys.org/news/2013-12-world-highest-quantum-efficiency-uv.html

Related Organizations or Individuals

US Department of Defense

name: Will GlaxoSmithKline's experimental Ebola vaccine be used to vaccinate healthcare workers in Sierra Leone or Liberia  by March 31st, 2015?
question_text:
Phase I trial data was published on November 16th, 2014 for a study of an Ebola vaccine from GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), showing a positive immunological response against the Ebola virus. The vaccine?uses a type of chimpanzee cold virus, known as chimpanzee adenovirus type 3 (ChAd3), as a carrier to deliver genetic material from two strains of the Ebola virus ? the Sudan strain and the Zaire strain, which is responsible for the current Ebola outbreak in west Africa.

GSK has been working with the NIH to accelerate development of both this bivalent version of the candidate vaccine and a monovalent version targeting only the Zaire strain in response to the current Ebola epidemic.?These developments?have led to further trials which are expected to include?phase III clinical trials and the vaccination of frontline healthcare workers in Africa.?

keywords: Flu, Region 10, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 10 (AK, ID, OR, WA)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 10' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 10 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS region 10 is the highest. Region 10 is comprised of Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, and Washington.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: When will the first 3D-printed blood vessel be successfully transplanted into a human being?
question_text:
A team from Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston has managed to successfully fabricate blood vessels using a three-dimensional bioprinting technique, according to a report from?Phys.org. Researchers started by making a fiber template from a naturally derived sugar-based molecule called agarose and?enclosed the mold with a gelatin-like substance called hydrogel.?The fibers became the blood vessel channels after the fiber templates were removed.

Ali Khademhosseini, director of the Brigham and Women?s Hospital Biomaterials Innovation Research Center:

Engineers have made incredible strides in making complex artificial tissues such as those of the heart, liver and lungs. In the future, 3D printing technology may be used to develop transplantable tissues customized to each patient's needs or be used outside the body to develop drugs that are safe and effective.

Blood vessels form the basis of our circulatory system, allowing blood to flow freely delivering essential nutrients and clearing hazardous waste from our organs.?The interior walls of human blood vessels contain a special layer of endothelial cells. These cells perform the key functions of vascular biology, such as filtering fluids. ?Without that layer of cells, 3D printed blood vessels would not be as efficient as their organic counterparts. One of the most exciting outcomes of the recent trial at?Brigham and Women's Hospital?is that the researchers?noted the successful formation of endothelial monolayers within the channels.?

Researchers at?the University of Louisville in Kentucky have printed human heart valves and small veins with cells, according to?Stuart Williams, a cell biologist whose?team is working on creating the first??bioficial heart?. The biggest challenge is to get the cells to work together as they do in a normal heart, according to?Professor Williams. They have also successfully tested the tiny blood vessels in mice and other small animals and Professor Williams believes scientists will be able to print parts and assemble an entire heart in three to five years.

Useful Links:
  • Bioengineers from the UPenn printing blood vessel networks out of sugar [VIDEO]
  • Scientists Can Now 3D Print Human Blood Vessels - Gizmodo
  • Scientists Have 3D-Printed Embryonic Stem Cells
  • Bioprinting new organs - Medical Xpress
  • 3-D printing and its impact on the medical implant industry

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2016

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when the lab manufacturing the vessels, or the doctors performing the procedure make an official statement that the vessels were accepted by the the host. Administrators may also consult?medical journals, or other reputable science news sources reporting on the topic.

Fine Print

The vessels must be manufactured using a 3D/AAM process which may or may not utilize cells from the host as materials for the build. The vessels must be then transplanted into a human and demonstrate the ability to carry the patient's blood between organic vessels or organs.

name: Will Virgin Galactic begin commercial flights aboard SpaceShipTwo by the end of 2014?
question_text:
Virgin Galactic has reached an agreement with the Federal Aviation Administration(FAA) for how the company?will use airspace during suborbital flights.?Company officials have said they hope to begin commercial flights aboard SpaceShipTwo out of New Mexico's Spaceport America by the end of 2014.?Almost 700 people, including numerous celebrities, have paid up to $250,000?to book a two-hour journey on SpaceShipTwo, which would include a planned five minutes of weightlessness.

The deal, which was announced on May 29, outlines how Virgin Galactic will work with the FAA's air traffic control center Albuquerque and the New Mexico Spaceport Authority to safely provide clear airspace for SpaceShipTwo space plane.

In addition to addressing the legal and political concerns over the intended spaceflight,?Virgin galactic has also had?to make modifications to their flight system, having recently?switched?from a rubber-based solid fuel to a plastic-based fuel for the motor that's designed to power its SpaceShipTwo.

keywords: U.S., Blueberries, Production, Tons, 2013, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total U.S. blueberry production during the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of tons?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • Total U.S. blueberry?production (cultivated and wild)?for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 282,300 tons.
  • Blueberry production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as blueberries are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is?the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Blueberry production is reported in thousands of tons, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. blueberry production' includes cultivated and wild blueberries.

The '2013 marketing season' begins 05/2013 and ends 09/2013.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.
