keywords: Flu, Region 10, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 10 (AK, ID, OR, WA)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 10' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 10 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 10. Region 10 is comprised of Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, and Washington.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

choices_field_5: Will not be available before January 1, 2020
name: Roughly 25 million people in the U.S. have diabetes, and many of them use blood glucose monitors to test their blood sugars every day. When will a prickless glucose monitor be commercially available to US consumers?
question_text:
Roughly 25 million people in the U.S. have diabetes, and many of them use blood glucose monitors to test their blood sugars every day. This type of monitor requires a drop of blood via a prick to the finger or other part of the body.? In addition, these monitors require the use of disposable test strips. Because these nuisances affect a large market, many researchers have been working to develop a prickless glucose monitor. Prototypes have included measurement of glucose through saliva, an infrared patch, and an earlobe monitor.?

Recently, Pacifici et al. have made progress on the use of a nano-sized interferometer to measure glucose in saliva using quartz coated in silver and marker molecules. However, prick-less glucose monitoring of any type still must overcome the major challenge of accurate and effective glucose monitoring when compared to blood-based testing.

Links and sources
  • Prickless Glucose Monitor That Uses Spit Takes Giant Step Forward http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/biomedical/diagnostics/prickless-glucose-monitor-that-uses-spit-t...
  • Plasmonics Promises Better Biosensors http://spectrum.ieee.org/biomedical/diagnostics/plasmonics-promises-better-biosensors
  • Non-invasive blood glucose monitoring using near-infrared spectroscopy http://www.edn.com/design/medical/4422840/Non-invasive-blood-glucose-monitoring-using-near-infrared-spectroscopy

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

Official announcement by the company will resolve this question to yes.

Fine Print

Prickless - a method of measuring glucose without drawing blood or breaching the skin.Commercially - available for consumers to purchase.

*Admin Update: For this question to resolve as true, a prickless glucose monitor must be available to consumers in the United States.?

name: Will GE and Sasol's new AbMBR technology, which cleans waste water while generating biogas for power production, be comercially available by the end of June 2015?
question_text:
General Electric's power and water division, along with?energy and chemical company Sasol, recently announced they have jointly developed a new technology that cleans waste water from Sasol facilities while generating biogas. The companies have named the technology Anaerobic Membrane Bioreactor Technology (AbMBR), and plan to further develop it at a demonstration plant at Sasol's R&D campus in Sasolburg, South Africa. The companies anticipate the technology will be comercially ready early in 2015.

name: Will the cost to encode data in DNA drop below US $1,240 by the end of 2015?
question_text:
The digital storage industry?makers of the tapes, disks, and other gear that have become the archives and the retrieval tools of the information age?achieved its status by doubling storage capacity about every 18 months. While hard drive and solid-state drive manufacturers are attempting to increase storage densities and push the limits on speed and performance, a handful of researchers around the world are working hard?on the next generation of systems and devices. Some are focusing on Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) while others are examining other storage methods. (See the related question on glass-based data storage medium.) ?Although the feasibility of DNA storage was first demonstrated in 1988, this approach has now?begun to take shape over the last few years. ?Researchers estimate that encoding data in DNA currently costs US$12,400 per megabyte and costs an estimated US$220 per megabyte to read that data back. Researchers also estimate that if the price of DNA synthesis comes down by two orders of magnitude, as it is expected to do in the next decade, DNA data storage will soon cost less than archiving data on magnetic tapes. ?The focus of our question is how long will it take for the?price of DNA synthesis to come down by one order of magnitude. ?

According to EMC?s?Digital Universe study?(http://www.emc.com/leadership/digital-universe/2014iview/index.htm), the digital universe will grow by a factor of 10 between 2013 and 2020. ?

Reading material

Data Storage in DNA?

DNA Is The Next Big Data Storage Technology?

Storing data as DNA ? as easyas ACTG? ?

Why DNA Will Someday Replacethe Hard Drive

A New Approach to InformationStorage ?

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Technology Review http://www.technologyreview.com/?
Nature http://www.nature.com
The Economist http://www.economist.com/

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in states with historically 'somewhat low' HPV vaccination coverage?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • The 'somewhat low' HPV vaccination group of states is comprised of the following: (2011 coverage rate % / 2012 coverage rate %)
    • Florida (50 / 39.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/476/trades/create/safe
    • Idaho (45.5 / 51.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/479/trades/create/safe
    • Illinois (51.6 / 41.2)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/480/trades/create/safe
    • Indiana (40.8 / 48.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/481/trades/create/safe
    • Kansas (37.2 / 42.7)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/486/trades/create/safe
    • Maryland (45.7 / 42.7)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/490/trades/create/safe
    • Michigan (55.6 / 48.1)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/492/trades/create/safe
    • Missouri (49.5 / 51.6)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/495/trades/create/safe
    • Montana (52.9 / 55.1)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/497/trades/create/safe
    • North Carolina (54.4 / 53.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/504/trades/create/safe
    • Ohio (45.5 / 56.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/512/trades/create/safe
    • South Dakota (58.1 / 51)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/518/trades/create/safe
    • Virginia (46.9 / 50.9)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/524/trades/create/safe
  • These are primarily Midwestern states with slightly low DTAP vaccination rates. ?They are near the average of U.S. states on variables such as population age, politics, and longevity.
  • The vaccination rate of the group will be determined by calculating an unweighted arithmetic mean of the 2013 data for the 13 states.
Related Predict Question:?What percentage of the US female population aged 13-17 will be vaccinated against HPV by the end of 2013?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here: http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

Clusters of states were created by first analyzing state-level variables that correlate with HPV vaccination coverage in 2011 and 2012. The model for predicting HPV vaccination coverage explained over half the variation among states. On the most useful variables, states in a given cluster are more similar to each other than to states in other clusters. The range of possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 49.0%, the "Between 49.0% and 50.5%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will Boeing announce that it has started building a full-size, operational version of its unmanned aerial vehicle Phantom Eye before the end of 2015?
question_text:
Boeing's Phantom Eye demonstrator was recently promoted to experimental status by the U.S. Air Force 412 Operations Group based on the recommendation of officials at NASA's Dryden Flight Research Center. The liquid hydrogen-fueled, high altitude long endurance (HALE) unmanned aircraft system (UAS) had completed six tests at Edwards AFB in California since 2012. As an experimental aircraft operating within the USAF Test Center, it can now leave the protected air space over Edwards AFB for a test range several miles away to complete its endurance and altitude testing.? In the coming months, Boeing is preparing for more Phantom Eye flights designated to achieve the program's intended goal of more than 60,000 feet in altitude, while also increasing endurance with each flight. Following testing of the demonstrator aircraft (which is a 60-70% scale model), a full-size, operational version of Phantom Eye may be built.

Status Update: Boeing's Phantom Eye takes a huge step forward: http://www.boeing.com/boeing/Features/2014/02/bds_phantomeye_status_02_12_14.page#.UvvYW8rVawk.twitt...
Boeing Phantom Eye: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Phantom_Eye


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Information will be available on the company's official website: http://www.boeing.com/boeing/index.page

Fine Print

The Phantom Eye demonstrator is a 60%-70% scale design of an objective system. An operational version of the aircraft will be larger and is expected to stay airborne for seven to ten days.

keywords: Flu, region 1, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 1 (CT, ME, MA, NH, RI, VT)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?
?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?? ? ? ? ?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 1' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.

The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 1 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 1 is comprised of Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont.

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 1 is 1.2%.

In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

choices_field_13: None of these companies will offer such a car by the question deadline
name: Which of the major automotive manufacturers will be first to offer a fully autonomous (self-driving) car to consumers in the US?
question_text:
Predicted since the 1930s, the advent of driverless cars has promised to solve problems of traffic congestion and vehicle-related accidents by removing the human element from passenger car operation. Google has an active research program in driverless cars, and as the concept of truly driverless cars has started to seem more achievable, U.S. Department of Transportation's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) announced a new policy concerning vehicle automation in May of 2013. NHTSA?s policy divides vehicle technologies into five categories: No automaton (Level 0); Function-specific Automation (Level 1), Combined Function Automation (Level 2), Limited Self-Driving Automation (Level 3); Full Self-Driving Automation (Level 4), with driverless cars fall into Levels 3 and 4. According to NHTSA Google?s current prototype would be a level three automated vehicle.

Last year (2013) Mercedes-Benz S500?s Intelligent Drive research vehicle drove roughly 60 miles without any input from the driver, making the company the first? major automotive manufacturer to demonstrate one of their vehicle?s ability to effectively navigate both urban and interurban roads without driver input. Many other companies such as Ford, BMW, Nissan, and GM are testing and offering semi-autonomous driving features on their cars.

Links and sources

  • Autonomous cars could be on the road by 2018, CEO says http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/2014/06/autonomous-cars-could-be-on-the-road-by-2018-ceo-says.html
  • Frankfurt Auto Show: Mercedes shows off fully autonomous S-Class, production cars coming by 2020 http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/2014/06/autonomous-cars-could-be-on-the-road-by-2018-ceo-says.html
  • Driverless Cars Are Further Away Than You Think http://www.technologyreview.com/featuredstory/520431/driverless-cars-are-further-away-than-you-think/
  • http://www.autosaur.com/car-brands-complete-list/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Official announcement by company

Fine Print

Self-driving, driverless, and automated passenger cars are synonymous terms. ?The car must be made by a major automotive manufacturer as a model available to consumers, not an after-market addition.
short_name: Who will offer the first self driving car

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Kentucky?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Kentucky, 51.2% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +5.2% from 2011 (46.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 50.3%, the "50.3%-53.7%" range will be deemed correct.

The technology is geared towards soldiers on the battlefield.? There is also an engineering?team at University of Toronto that recently won an international prize for their PrintAlive Bioprinter that can 3D print skin grafts?including hair follicles and sweat glands.?The university researchers are working with a burn unit at Toronto's Sunnybrook Hospital.

keywords: wireless drones, internet access, solar-powered drones
name: When will Google or Facebook debut internet connectivity to consumers using solar-powered drones?
question_text:
The future growth of technology companies like Facebook andGoogle depends on getting the next 5 billion people, who are disconnected fromany form of internet connectivity, in the developing world online. ?Once these new users are plugged into theInternet, Facebook and Google are confident that they will benefit extensivelyfrom new users who will want to connect with friends around the world, sharephotos, use maps, conduct information searches and so on.

Google, with its Project Loon, has used a network ofballoons to provide internet connectivity in New Zealand?s South Island. ProjectLoon?s goal for 2014 is to establish a ring of uninterrupted connectivityaround the 40th southern parallel, so that pilot testers at this latitude canreceive continuous service via balloon-powered Internet. ?Buying Titan Aerospace?s solar powered dronesthat can stay at upwards of 60,000 feet for almost 5 years, will help powerProject Loon even further as these high-altitude drones will behave as wirelessrepeaters.? Google hopes to beam affordableInternet connectivity across the skies in currently unserved areas.

On the other hand, Facebook, bought UK based Ascenta fortheir high-altitude, solar-powered drones that can also fly up high for longperiods of time. Facebook also set up a coalition called ?Connectivity Lab? toprovide affordable Internet access around the world using drones, satellites,and lasers.

For more information:
Google drones: http://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/04/14/fight-for-internet-drones-heats-up-as-google-buys-drone-company-originally-sought-by-facebook/

keywords: CO2, Mauna Loa, Hawaii, Greenhouse Gases, Climate Change
name: Will the average CO2 level for February 2015 be above 400 ppm, according to readings from Mauna Loa, Hawaii?
question_text:
NOAA/ESRL's Global Monitoring Division (GMD) collects observations and conducts research related to trends and global distributions of atmospheric constituents that are capable of forcing change in the climate of Earth through depletion of the global ozone layer and affecting baseline air quality, thereby modifying the atmospheric radiative environment.? These atmospheric constituents include carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's), and others.? The GMD collects data from key measurement stations located across the world, in addition to four Baseline Observatories.? These four Baseline Observatories are situated at:? Barrow, Alaska; Trinidad Head, California; Summit, Greenland; Mauna Loa, Hawaii; American Samoa; and South Pole, Antarctica.?

Recently in April 2014, for the first time in the past 800,000 years, the average monthly CO2 level surpassed 400 ppm according to data from the Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO) in Hawaii.? It is estimated that during the Earth's Ice Ages and up until the Industrial Revolution, CO2 levels ranged around 200 to 300ppm.? Ralph Keeling, who runs the monitoring program at Mauna Loa (and whose father began the monitoring effort at Mauna Loa, now known as the Keeling Curve) said, "It still feels a bit surreal now to be reporting concentrations over 400 ppm.?Even though it was pretty much inevitable that we would get to this point, it still takes some getting used to."

When the MLO Observatory started monitoring CO2 levels in 1958, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere was around 317 ppm, and reached an average CO2 level above 400 ppm for the months of April, May, and June 2014.? From July to December 2014, the average monthly CO2 has asymptotically neared 400 ppm, with values ranging from 395 to 399 ppm.? This question asks if the average carbon dioxide (CO2) level for the month of February 2015 will again exceed 400.00 ppm for the baseline observatory at Mauna Loa, Hawaii.

Relevant Links:

  • First time in 800,000 years: April's CO2 Levels Above 400 ppm [CBS]
  • CO2 Levels above 400 PPM Threshold for Third Month in a Row [Scientific American]
  • What Does This Number Mean [Scripps Institute of Oceanography]
Data Links:
  • Current Trends in Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide (CO2) at Mauna Loa, Hawaii
  • Historical Time Series of Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Data at Mauna Loa, Hawaii
  • Historical Raw Data of Carbon Dioxide (CO2) at Mauna Loa, Hawaii

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/07/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved true if the average CO2 level for the month of February 2015 for Mauna Loa, Hawaii as reported by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is above 400.00 parts per million (ppm).? This will be verified by the Mauna Loa Observatory, which is a part of the NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL) Global Monitoring Division (GMD).? Note that the average CO2 level must be above 400.00 ppm in order to resolve as true, if the average CO2 level is exactly 400.00 ppm (as reported by NOAA) then this question will resolve as false.

Fine Print

Note: the CO2 level statistics are usually published on the 5th or 6th of the following month. The release of the February 2015 statistics for Mauna Loa is estimated to release on March 5/6 2015.

keywords: genomics, diagnosis, prognosis, neurology, brain disorders
name: Will genomic testing replace clinical diagnosis in any of the common neurological disorders by the end of 2015 ?
question_text:
The common (i.e. not exceptionally rare)diseases of the brain (migraine,?Alzheimer's disease,?epilepsy,Parkinson's disease,?levy body dementia,?amyotrophic lateralsclerosis) have a substantial familial background. Currently, many multi-centricor even multi-national studies collect large numbers of patients, families andtheir DNA to unravel hereditary and genetic relationships. One of thegoals is to find?biomarkers with diagnostic or prognosticrelevance.??Currently, diagnosis of these conditions relies onhistory, and neurological examination, with?some supporting?findingsfrom neuroimaging, neurophysiology or?CSF. Even in the small percentageof families with a known mutation, the predictive?value of current DNAfindings is low.

This question asks whether the modern genomic studies (and?big data analyses) will allow?amore accurate diagnosis/prognosis?in the majority of patients with any of these neurological diseases compared to current standards?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules


Resolution Criteria

Large scale genomic studies with high quality clincial (longitudinal follow up) data may be an indicator for the outcome to resolve true.?

Resolution Sources

Any of the following medical journals could be a resolution source:

  • NEJM
  • BMJ
  • LANCET
  • JAMA
  • Brain
  • Neurology
  • Annals of Neurology
  • JAMA Neurolog
  • JNNP

Fine Print

A diagnostic DNA test?will beconsidered "successful" if it can replace one of the?current?first line test or augment these tests to produce clinically accepted diagnostic or prognostic information in a majority of patients in a target population.

For example, after a first seizure clinicalevaluation, EEG and MRI are used to produce a?rough estimate of recurrencerisk. This may result in advice that may include starting antiepileptic drugs, notto drive for some specified interval, etc.?Currently even thediagnosis?of a genetic generalized epilepsy does not indicate performing any specificDNA testing or counseling.For aDNA test to qualify in this example as having met the criteria of the question it would need to be applicable and efficacious in?the vast majority of patientsafter?first seizure. It would either make EEG or MRI obsolete or?allow a diagnostic or prognostic statement for these patients in a clinically accepted and relevant way.?

Related Organizations or Individuals

American Academy of Neurology, European Academy of Neurology, NINDS, NICE

name: When will the first holographic display be available in a commercial smartphone?
question_text:
• Most commercial phones have 2D screens while some phones have "3D" screens; however, no commercial phone has a true 3D screen where an object or space can be seen from any angle. This is called a holographic display, which represents the true image of a 3D object.
  • The HP Labs spin-out Leia uses a light-filed display system of diffraction gratings, producing 64 different versions of each image, which allows a viewer to move around an object or person shown on the display as if it was right in the room with them. 3D glasses are not needed to view the image (a.k.a Autostereoscopy).
  • Even with current progress, it?s not feasible with cost-effective equipment; however, as computers get faster it is more likely to be integrated into a commercial smart phone.

Links and sources
  • Holographic Displays Coming to Smartphones. http://spectrum.ieee.org/consumer-electronics/audiovideo/holographic-displays-coming-to-smartphones
  • Insane holographic smartphone just one-upped Amazon Fire phone http://www.techradar.com/news/phone-and-communications/mobile-phones/insane-holographic-smartphone-just-one-upped-amazon-fire-phone-1257981
  • New 3-D Display Could Let Phones and Tablets Produce Holograms http://www.technologyreview.com/news/512716/new-3-d-display-could-let-phones-and-tablets-produce-holograms/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when an announcement by a company official is made or on the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

For the purpose of this question, the holographic display in question must incorporate light-field display technology. The product must be on sale to the general public by the date in question.

name: Will a high-speed 3D image of cellular replication in living tissue captured using SCAPE (Swept Confocally Aligned Planar Excitation Microscopy) be reported by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Elizabeth Hillman, associate professor of biomedical engineering at Columbia University Medical Center (CUMC), has developed a new 3D microscope prototype dubbed "SCAPE" (Swept Confocally Aligned Planar Excitation Microscopy), which requires no mounting of samples or other special preparation, and is capable of imaging freely moving living samples at speeds 10 to 100 times faster than current laser-scanning microscopes. The Columbia team has already imaged an amazing array of subjects, including zebrafish larvae and neurons flashing in a living brain using fluorescent protein techniques. "The ability to perform real-time 3D imaging at cellular resolution in behaving organisms is a new frontier for biomedical and neuroscience research" said Professor Hillman.

Many further applications for SCAPE are envisaged by the CUMC researchers, including capturing images of cellular replication, function, and motion in living tissue, and imaging 3D cell cultures. These areas may be particularly enhanced by SCAPE, according to the team, as these are applications where molecular biology imaging methods have fallen behind the latest tools and techniques.

  • New high-speed 3-D microscope gives deeper view of living things:?http://phys.org/news/2015-01-high-speed-d-microscope-deeper-view.html
  • "SCAPE" microscope offers faster and simpler imaging of freely moving samples:?http://www.gizmag.com/scape-high-speed-3d-scanning-microscope/35680/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when the discovery is published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in an official press release from the research institution. Official sources include but are not exclusive to?Columbia Engineering?http://engineering.columbia.edu/?and?Columbia University Medical Center (CUMC)?http://www.cumc.columbia.edu/.?

The development may also be reported on?science news websites such as?http://www.sciencedaily.com/,?http://phys.org/, and?http://www.gizmag.com/

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

keywords: Space, Rosetta, comet, European Space Agency
name: When will the Rosetta?s small robotic lander, Philae, land successfully on the surface of a comet?
question_text:
In November 1993, the International Rosetta Mission was approved as a Cornerstone Mission in ESA's Horizons 2000 Science Programme.

Rosetta lifted off on March 2004 on a European Ariane 5 rocket from Kourou in French Guiana. During a circuitous ten-year trek across the Solar System, Rosetta crossed the asteroid belt and travel into deep space. Its destination is a periodic comet known as Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

On January 20, 2014, the European Space Agency confirmed that Rosetta woke from its 31 months in hibernation used to conserve power as it arced beyond the orbit of Jupiter on a path that should take it to Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. The BBC reports: On January 20, 2014, the European Space Agency confirmed that Rosetta woke from its 31 months in hibernation used to conserve power as it arced beyond the orbit of Jupiter on a path that should take it to Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

The BBC reports: [F]rom mid-March to the end of April, ESA will be switching on the instruments one by one.? [If successful]...Rosetta will begin firing its thrusters to begin zeroing in on Comet 67P. Today, the separation is nine million km away. By mid-September, it should be reduced to just 10 km.

Links:

  • Rosetta comet-chaser phones home
  • ESA: Rosetta

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/06/2015

Resolution Source

The European Space Agency will announce the successful landing of Philae.

Fine Print

?Land successfully? means that the lander (Philae) touches down at the intended comet with the lander intact and is able to execute its first step of firing a harpoon to anchor the lander to the ground and prevent it escaping from the comet?s extremely weak gravity.

The new screens will be made using conductive silver nanowire ink which is patterned using a polyester base. The screens can be used for both small devices such as phones and tablets and large ones, such as big (touch) screen TVs. They can also be used in applications that require rounded?or curved?surfaces, or conformity to angles.

keywords: solar energy, microwave power transmission, retrodirective beam control
name: Will a demonstration of wireless power transmission with retrodirective beam control be reported by the end of March 2015?
question_text:
As part of the?JAXA and Japan Space Systems-funded space-based Solar Power System (SSPS)?program, Japanese researchers expect to perform a ground?experiment in which a beam of hundreds of watts will be transmitted over about 50 meters.?This will?be the world?s first demonstration of high-power and long-range microwave transmission with the critical addition of retrodirective beam control. The microwave transmitter consists of four individual panels that can move in relation to one another in order to simulate antenna motion in orbit. Each panel, measuring 0.6 meters by 0.6 meters, contains hundreds of tiny transmitting antennas and receiving antennas to detect the pilot signal, as well as phase controllers and power management systems. Each panel will transmit 400 W, so that the total beam will carry 1.6 kW in this early-stage experiment. This experiment is the first of a series experiments in?an ambitious plan by the Japanese scientists to harvest solar power in space and bring it down to earth.

  • How Japan Plans to Build an Orbital Solar Farm:?http://spectrum.ieee.org/green-tech/solar/how-japan-plans-to-build-an-orbital-solar-farm
  • Practical Application of Space-based Solar Power Generation:?http://global.jaxa.jp/article/interview/vol53/index_e.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

keywords: Emissions; coal; natural gas; greenhouse gas; climate change, chemistry
name: How will 2013 U.S. greenhouse gas emissions differ from 2012 emissions levels when the 2013 Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks is released?
question_text:
The EPA develops an annual report called the Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks, which tracks total annual U.S. emissions and removals by source, economic sector, and greenhouse gas going back to 1990. The 2012 report, released in April 2014, found that U.S. emissions decreased by 3.4 percent from 2011 to 2012, which dropped greenhouse gas emissions in the US to their lowest levels in 17 years. This follows the overall trend in decreasing greenhouse emissions in the US dating back to 2007. Much of this decrease can be attributed to a rapid drop in coal-fired electricity generation, and a corresponding rise in electricity generated by cleaner fuels, especially natural gas. In 2012, coal-fired generation dropped by 12.3 percent, while gas-fired electricity production increased by 20.4 percent.


  • EPA - National Greenhouse Gas Emissions Data
  • MIT Technology Review - Natural Gas Fuels Recent Drop in U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/04/2015

Resolution Source

The EPA's Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks for 2013 will be released in April of 2015 and can be found here: National Greenhouse Gas Emissions Data

Fine Print

The answer will be rounded to the nearest tenth decimal point for resolution.

keywords: Great Lakes, Global Warming, Ice Coverage
name: What will be the peak mean ice concentration in Lake Ontario during the 2013/2014 winter?
question_text:
Understanding the major effect of ice on the Great Lakes is crucial because it impacts a range of societal benefits provided by the lakes, from hydropower generation to commercial shipping to the fishing industry. The amount of ice cover varies from year to year, as well as how long it remains on the lakes. GLERL scientists are observing long-term changes in ice cover as a result of global warming.

According to an analysis by NOAA's Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, ice covered 88.4 percent of the Great Lakes on February 13. Not since early 1994 has ice been so widespread on the Great Lakes. Graphs showing the ice cover trends?for each of the Great Lakes from?1973 to 2002?can be found here.

As of 02/14/2014, the mean concentration of ice in Lake Ontario was 40.1%. Daily reports can be found here under the section 'Modeled Ice Coverage'.?A chart showing the yearly average maximum ice coverage of Lake Ontario can be found here.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/10/2014

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved by via the Lake Ontario Ice Cover webpage maintained by the NOAA, and by consulting the 'Modeled Ice Concentration' section.?


Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the peak ice coverage is 48.0%, the "48%-52%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: QLED, quantum dot, nanoparticles, 3D printing, contact lens
name: Will a study of a functioning 3D-printed quantum dot LED contact lens be published by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Recent reports from researchers at Princeton University describe the successful incorporation of?quantum dots into?3D-printed?contact lenses, allowing?these lenses to project beams of light. Such bionic contact lenses could be used to provide virtual retina displays?that?draw a?raster?display (like a?television) directly onto the?retina?of the eye. The user sees what appears to be a conventional display floating in space in front of them.?The contact lenses?could have a variety of uses, from assisting the visually impaired to the video game industry.??

The 3D printed contact lens created by Princeton?is?not wearable as yet. The lens itself is made of hard plastic, which is unsuitable to be worn on the eye, and the QLEDs require an external power supply.

  • Bionic eye: 3D printing merges contact lens and QLEDs:?http://www.cnet.com/news/bionic-eye-3d-printing-merges-contact-lens-and-qleds/
  • Virtual retinal display:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_retinal_display
?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

An official press release from the researcher?s institution or funding agency or a paper published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

The development is also likely to be reported by technology sites such as Nanowerk?http://www.nanowerk.com, IEEE Spectrum?http://spectrum.ieee.org/, and C/NET?http://www.cnet.com/



Fine Print

A "functioning" lens for the purposes of this question is defined as 1st wearable and 2nd must be able to display an image or pattern for the user.

name: Will more measles cases be reported in the U.S. by the CDC in 2015 than in 2014?
question_text:
From January 1 to January 23 2015, 68 people from 11 states in the US were reported to have measles.?Most of these cases?were part of a large, ongoing outbreak linked to an amusement park in California. A few days later, on Tuesday January 26, the measles cases in California alone were reported to have reached?74.?The overwhelming majority of people infected are unvaccinated, including at least one infant too young to receive the immunization program.

The deadly disease was declared to have been eliminated?in the U.S. in 2000, only?to resurface in the last few years.?There were 220 cases in 2011, and 2014 saw a spike to?644 cases, according to the CDC.?

For more information:

  • Measles cases and outbreaks:?http://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html
  • US measles outbreak is bad, and it's getting worse:?http://www.cnbc.com/id/102375852
  • California Measles Outbreak Shows How Quickly Disease Can Resurface in U.S.:?https://www.yahoo.com/health/california-measles-outbreak-shows-how-quickly-108833971042.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/10/2016

Resolution Source

This question will resolve using data recorded by the?CDC's measles cases and outbreaks report:?http://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

name: Will 2015 be the warmest year since records began (in 1880), based on combined global land and ocean surface temperature?
question_text:
Signs are increasingly pointing to the formation of an El Ni?o in the next few months, possibly a very strong one. When combined with the long-term global warming trend, a strong El Ni?o?may mean 2015?will become the hottest year on record.

  • Is a super El Ni?o coming that will shatter extreme weather and global temperature records? http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/03/26/3417812/el-nino-extreme-weather-global-temperature/

keywords: bitcoin, 2016 US presidential election, campaign contribution
name: Will bitcoin be accepted for campaign contributions by any declared candidate(s) in the 2016 US presidential election?
question_text:
Bitcoin is an experimental, decentralized digital currency that enables instant payments to anyone, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin uses peer-to-peer technology to operate with no central authority: managing transactions and issuing money are carried out collectively by the network.

Texas Rep. Steve Stockman announced recently that he will accept donations in bitcoin in his campaign for US Senate against incumbent Sen. John Cornyn.

Resolution Sources

CNN, NPR, NY Times and other major news outlets

Fine Print

This question will resolve true if any of the 2016 US presidential candidates accepts bitcoin for his/her campaign efforts.

Useful Information and Links

keywords: Flu, Region 9, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 9 (AZ, CA, HI, NV, AS, MP, FM, GU, MH, PW)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???

  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 9' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 9 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 9. Region 9 is comprised of Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, American Samoa, Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Guam, Marshall Islands, and Republic of Palau.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: Will the Axion Dark Matter Experiment detect axions by July 2014?
question_text:
Recently, physicists at the University of Washington's Center for Experimental Nuclear Physics and Astrophyics have begun an experiment using what they claim to be?"the most sensitive axion detector in operation" to hunt for axion particles.

Resolution Criteria

No

Resolution Sources

Science, Nature, Physics Review Letters. This question will be accepting forecasts until 06/30/14

Fine Print

The axion is a hypothetical elementary particle postulated by the Peccei?Quinn theory in 1977 to resolve the strong CP problem in quantum chromodynamics (QCD). If axions exist and have low mass within a specific range, they are of interest as a possible component of cold dark matter.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Tschirhart
name: What place will the Tschirhart  Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

For more information on The Tschirhart Lab, and the work they are doing, please visit their website here: Tschirhart ?Lab

Useful Links
  • Link to?Tschirhart??Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

keywords: Wind turbines, wind power, renewable energy
name: Will a 2 MW or larger floating wind turbine prototype be installed in the US in 2014?
question_text:
Floating wind turbines may be viable replacements for traditional offshore wind turbines, which have fixed bottoms that are expensive to install and limit the turbine operation to relatively shallow waters (30-50 meter maximum depth). Floating wind turbines can be installed in deep waters to exploit strong and sustained offshore winds and enable off shore wind turbines to be moved out of sight of shores. As of June 1, 2014, one floating test turbine in Penobscot Bay is the only offshore wind turbine in U.S. waters.? This number is predicted to rise significantly in the next few years. However, there are still some engineering challenges to overcome as current materials used in these turbines are expensive and may not be commercially viable in currently deployed designs.

Sources and Links

  • Wikipedia on Floating Wind Turbines http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_wind_turbine
  • Floating Wind Turbines Headed for Offshore Farms http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/green-tech/wind/floating-wind-turbines-headed-for-offshore-farms

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

An official announcement from the company or consortium that deploys the floating off shore wind turbine.

Fine Print

Prototype also includes a test platform.

name: When will UHD programming be available from Netflix on optical disc?
question_text:
After manydecades of relatively little technological change, U.S. television underwentsignificant change beginning in the mid-1990s as broadcast television stationsbegan broadcasting in high definition. Cable companies followed suit and todayhigh definition on broadcast television iswidely available. It is also available to be played from a physical medium viaBlu-ray DVDs, which can play content with resolutions of up to 1080x1920 pixels,referred to as 1080p and 1080i resolution (where the p and i refer to thespecifics of the way the 1080 horizontal lines of each image are displayed),with 1080p considered the superior technology.

Work isunderway to make resolutions greater than 1080p commercially available, withso-called 4K UHD (2160p) resolution getting the most attention. In April of2014, Netflix began making 4K programming available for streaming with theintroduction of its in-house production ?House of Cards.? Streaming is currentlythe only way such 4K programming is available, but it is expected that thisprogramming will be available on optical disc as an upgraded Blu-ray format atsome point in the future.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.cnet.com/news/what-is-4k-uhd-next-generation-resolution-explained/
  • http://variety.com/2013/digital/news/netflix-house-of-cards-season-2-will-stream-in-ultra-hd-to-4k-t...
  • http://www.tomshardware.com/news/blu-ray-4k-uhd-blu-ray-optical-media,25744.html

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved by the Netflix website, which will indicateavailability of UHD optical disc based content. See:? https://pr.netflix.com/WebClient/clientNewsSearchAction.do?contentGroupId=10491&contentGroup=Press+Releases



Fine Print

UHD for this question includes any content resolution that is greater than 1080x1920 pixels in both the height and width dimension.

name: How many people will be employed in life, physical, and social science occupations in the US in 2015?
question_text:
The overwhelming majority of scientific progress is made by formally trained scientists. The overall supply of scientists available to work within industry, universities, and government labs is a closely watched macroeconomic metric widely believed to have a significant impact on the long-term economic growth of a nation.

While forecasting future skill mix in the economy is challenging, it is believed that jobs will become more and more dependent on at least some degree of formal science training in the future. In the short term, policy makers and scientists alike closely watch the number of scientists employed in the economy, as reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. From 2013 to 2014, the total number of scientists (life, physical, and social) grew from 1.307 million to 1.355 million persons.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.bls.gov/cps/cpsaat09.htm
  • http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/future-jobs-depend-on-a-science-based-economy/
  • http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2010-08/10-best-jobs-future-0


Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2016

Resolution Source

Science employment data is reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, here: http://www.bls.gov/cps/cpsaat09.htm (see the Life, physical, and social science occupations data row). These data are updated annually during the first quarter.

This question will resolve when the 2015 data are reported.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Kay
name: What place will the Kay Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The?Kay team's strategy to win the race:

We have adapted our strategy in response to the setup of the obstacle course that the cells have to navigate in order to win this particular race. Seeing that the corridors of the maze are rather narrow we opted for giving the cells some extra squeezing power. We did this by overexpressing a RacGEF that we speculate enhances the acto/myosin cortex in the back of the cell. This extra power gives the cells an edge over the competition.

Dicty related?research going on at the?Kay Lab (more info on their website):

Our main goal is to understand chemotaxis: the complicated and fascinating process whereby cells move along chemical gradients. We also have a broad interest in the biology of the social amoeba Dictyostelium, as represented by our recent discovery of the mating-type locus and aspidocytes (environmentally resistant cells) as well as the previous identification of polyketide signals active in the social stage.

Chemotaxis must have arisen early eukaryotic evolution and now serves many purposes. It is vital in the immune system, for wound healing and in embryonic development and it allows Dictyostelium amoebae to chase bacterial prey or aggregate together. Based on evolutionary conservation, we use Dictyostelium as our main experimental tool to study chemotaxis because it offers great experimental advantages over all other systems.

Useful Links

If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. keywords: Speech Synthesis, Brain Computer Interface, Brain Machine Interface
name: When will a brain computer interface (BCI) that can translate brain signals to audible speech be commercially available?
question_text:
The BrainGate research team has developed a brain computer interface (BCI) prototype that allows a paralyzed person to control a robotic arm using their thoughts (the Thought Experiment).? Although still in the preliminary stage, this BCI works by locating the firing of neurons in the motor cortex region of the brain and translating it to arm or leg movements.? The same concept is also being applied for human speech.?

Currently speech synthesizers are available that can translate text into artificial human speech.? However researchers are working on a BCI that can translate brain signals themselves into audible speech using a voice synthesizer.? One of the research teams is led by Edward Chang, a neurosurgeon at the University of California SF.? Chang and his team published a paper in Nature in 2013 describing how they used an electrode array to record electrical activity of the motor cortex that causes speech related movements of the lips, tongue, and vocal cords.? These patterns can then be analyzed to detect phonetic features.? Neural Signals Inc. is also developing a speech prosthesis through the Speech Restoration Project.? Their approach uses a neurotrophic electrode implanted in the speech motor cortex of the brain to decode neural signals which are then translated into speech by a voice synthesizer.? There are 39 phonemes in English, and deconstructing these would allow speech to be reconstructed.? Currently the prototype has decoded half of these phonemes.? This question asks when will a commercially available BCI be made that can effectively translate thoughts into speech.

Relevant Links:

  • A Speech Synthesizer Direct to the Brain [MIT Tech Review]
  • A Prosthesis for Speech [MIT Tech Review]
  • Sounds of Silence [BU Today]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved if a brain computer interface is made commercially available that can translate brain signals into audible human speech.? The BCI may be invasive, partially invasive, or non-invasive.? This will be verified by major news sources and the company page such as Neural Signals Inc.

Fine Print

A 'brain computer interface' is defined in general as a direct communication pathway between the brain and an external device.'Commercially available' means the BCI is available to the general public for purchase.

keywords: Yahoo, Mail, Email, PGP, E2EE, End-to-End, Encryption
name: Will Yahoo Offer End-to-End (E2EE) Encryption as a Feature in Yahoo Mail by June 30, 2015?
question_text:
Following in the footsteps of Google, Yahoo's Chief Information Security Officer, Alex Stamos announced at the Black Hat 2014 Conference that the company wants to offer end-to-end encryption for Yahoo Mail by 2015.? They plan to use the OpenPGP encryption standard and will modify Google's existing End-to-End Plugin for Yahoo Mail.

Relevant Links:

  • Yahoo Wants to Keep Your Email Safe From Prying Eyes [Engadget]
  • Yahoo Mail to Support End-to-End PGP Encryption by 2015 [PcWorld]
  • Yahoo to Roll Out End-to-End Encryption Option for All Yahoo Mail Users in 2015 [Washington Post]


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved if Yahoo offers an end-to-end encryption system such as PGP for Yahoo Mail Services (web-based or mobile) by June 30, 2015.? This may be in the form of a plugin, user-driven feature, or a permanent feature.? 'Plugin' is defined as an external program that is installed with Yahoo Mail, like Google's End-to-End plugin.? 'User driven feature' means Yahoo offers an option for the user to enable or disable end-to-end encryption, such as through the settings options.? 'Permanent Feature' means that Yahoo incorporates end-to-end encryption as a permanent feature directly into Yahoo Mail.? This will be verified by technology related news sources such as Engadget, Cnet, etc. and other major news sources such as Yahoo News, Washington Post, etc.

keywords: Coronavirus, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, MERS, MERS-COV
name: In how many African countries will a lab-confirmed case of the coronavirus Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS or MERS-CoV) be detected by 1 October 2014?
question_text:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by a coronavirus called MERS-CoV. Despite the first case being discovered in 2012, little is known about how the virus spreads to people from animal hosts. However, it is known that the virus spreads from human to human. In addition, bats and camels have been found to be infected with MERS. ??So far, all the cases have been linked to countries in or near the Arabian Peninsula through residence in or travel to, indicating that modes of transmission outside of the Arabian Peninsula are through travel. Since April 2012,?lab-confirmed cases from the following countries have been identified:
  • France
  • Italy
  • Jordan
  • Kuwait
  • Oman
  • Qatar
  • Saudi Arabia
  • Tunisia
  • United Kingdom (UK)
  • United Arab Emirates (UAE) ?
As of March 16, 2014, the only cases identified in Africa have been in Tunisia. ?? ??

On November 10, 2013, the Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia announced the detection of MERS- CoV in a specimen taken from an ill camel owned by a laboratory - confirmed case from Jeddah. This case had direct contact with the ill camel. ??It may be likely that MERS has already spread to more countries, but has not been detected due to lack of knowledge or access to testing.

In Sept 2013 the MERS gene was mapped and in Dec 2013, a group published a paper on their development of isothermal real-time RT-RPA, which they claim is ideal for rapid mobile molecular MERS-CoV monitoring. Therefore, it is more likely than ever that a case will be detected in the next 6 months.

Chu et al found MERS RNA in four camels in Egypt that had been imported from Sudan and Ethiopia.

Since it is much more likely MERS will spread to a few countries rather than many countries, the bins used in "safe mode" forecasting are asymmetrical based approximately on a log scale.

Sources and references:
  • Vietnam on high alert over flu risk
  • Middle Eastern Virus More Widespread Than Thought
  • MERS Coronaviruses in Dromedary Camels, Egypt
  • The World Health Organization on Coronavirus infections

10/01/2014

keywords: Flu, Region 4, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 4 (AL, FL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, and TN)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 4' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 4 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 4. Region 4 is comprised of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "Area of forest, agricultural and aquaculture ecosystems under sustainable management" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

keywords: metallic ferroeletrics, polar metals, computational materials, metallic ferroeletrics, noncentrosymmetric metals, chemistry
name: Will researchers synthesize strontium-calcium ruthenate, a newly predicted polar metal?
question_text:
A basic tenet of materials science is that metals have a symmetrical distribution of free electrons around the nuclei of their atoms.? In the 1960s, researchers hypothesized that metals may exist with an asymmetrical distribution of free electrons, so that they are polar, but also have free electrons. 30 ?polar metals? (aka noncentrosymmetric metals) have been discovered since then.

Because these polar metals display interesting characteristics, Danilo Puggioni and James M. Rondinelli used density functional theory calculations to predict a new polar ruthenate - SrCaRu2O6 from a ?two-step material selection process based on a weak electron?lattice coupling principle that considers the symmetry and atomic species participating in the inversion-lifting lattice modes, and the susceptibility of the cations? electronic configurations to a metallic state.?

Currently SrCaRu2O6 is only theoretical and Ruggioni and Rondinelli are working with several labs to synthesize the compound.

Links and sources

  • Puggioni, D. and J.M. Rondinelli, Designing a robustly metallic noncenstrosymmetric ruthenate oxide with large thermopower anisotropy. Nat Commun, 2014. 5. http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2014/140317/ncomms4432/full/ncomms4432.html
  • Drexel Researchers Open Path to Finding Rare, Polarized Metals http://drexel.edu/now/news-media/releases/archive/2014/April/PolarMetals/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Publication in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

keywords: cryptograhic systems, discrete logarithm, algorithmic theory,
name: Will researchers provide a practical demonstration of the newly discovered weakness in the discrete logarithm problem, used widely in cryptography, by December 31, 2014?
question_text:
Cryptography seeks to secure information by using difficult mathematicalproblems that even the most powerful machines and the most sophisticatedalgorithms find challenging to solve. The discrete logarithm problem is toutedas one of the ?holy grails? of the algorithmic number theory that is usedwidely in cryptographic systems.

Researchers at the Laboratoire Lorrain de Recherches enInformatique et ses Applications (CNRS/Universit? de Lorraine/Inria) and theLaboratoire d'Informatique de Paris 6 (CNRS/UPMC) presented their new algorithmthat solves one aspect of the discrete logarithm problem at Eurocrypt 2014 heldin Copenhagen on 11-15 May 2014 and published their theory in Advances in Cryptology.Several cryptographic systems, especially those used in smart cards and RFIDchips, are possibly vulnerable as a result of this development. It is thereforenot an option rely on this variant of the discrete logarithm for cryptographicapplications.
This development is in theoretical stages and needs refiningbefore it is possible to provide a practical demonstration of the weakness ofthis variant of the discrete logarithm.

For more information:
New algorithm shakesup cryptography: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/05/140515163739.htm
Press release: http://www2.cnrs.fr/en/2393.htm
A Heuristic Quasi-Polynomial Algorithm for DiscreteLogarithm in Finite Fields of Small Characteristic, Razvan Barbulescu, PierrickGaudry, Antoine Joux, Emmanuel Thom?, Advances in Cryptology ? EUROCRYPT 2014,Lecture Notes in Computer Science, Volume 8441, 2014, pp 1-16.
http://rd.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-642-55220-5_1

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Apaper published in a peer reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web ofScience.
News report in science and technology press or popularpress.

Fine Print

A practical demonstration will be possible when the algorithm will be successfully used to break into one of the real-world applications of cryptographic systems using the discrete algorithm problem.

name: What will be the highest research cell efficiency of a perovskite solar cell included on the NREL PV chart on March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Perovskites solar cells were discovered in 2009 with an efficiency of ~4%. Further research resulted in drastic improvements in efficiency to 20.1% as of November 13, 2014. This rate of change is unmatched in other solar cell technologies. The most recent gain for Perovskite solar cells went from about 17% in mid 2014 to 20.1% in late 2014.

The National Center for Photovoltaics (NCPV) at NREL focuses on technology innovations that drive industry growth in U.S. photovoltaic (PV) manufacturing. The NCPV is a central resource for our nation's capabilities in PV research, development, deployment, and outreach. NCPV publishes a new research cell efficiency chart as records are confirmed.? The chart is published at http://www.nrel.gov/ncpv/images/efficiency_chart.jpg

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The NCPV chart is published at http://www.nrel.gov/ncpv/images/efficiency_chart.jpg.

Fine Print

The NCPV chart will be checked on 3/31/2015 and the highest listed value for the perovskite cell will be used. (The highest value for stabilized or not-stabilized perovskite solar cells will resolve this question if there are values for both types of solar cells.) The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the reported efficiency is 22%, the "Between 22% - 23%" range will be deemed correct.
