name: When will a commercial prototype of prosthetic limbs powered by a neuromorphic electronic chip be available?
question_text:
• Neuromorphic researchers in the United Statesand Europe are using electronic circuits and compiler software to buildelectronic systems that mimic neurons and synapses ? circuitry modeled on the powerof a human brain.
  • In April 2014, Stanford bioengineers developed afast and energy-efficient microchip based on the human brain, Neurogrid, whichis 9,000 times faster and uses significantly less power than a typical PC.
  • The Neurogrid is a circuit board of 16custom-designed "Neurocore" chips that can simulate 1 million neuronsand billions of synaptic connections.
  • Neurogrid is by far the most cost-effective wayto simulate neurons, and the Stanford scientists? goal is to create a systemaffordable enough to be widely used in research.
  • The team of scientists at Stanford are working ona neuromorphic? chip similar to the humanbrain that can drive prosthetic limbs with the speed and complexity of humanactions.
  • Currently, the team has a small prosthetic armin their lab that is controlled by Neurogrid to execute movement commands inreal time.
  • The next step for the team is to lower costs andcreate compiler software that engineers and computer scientists with noknowledge of neuroscience can use to solve problems ? such as controlling ahumanoid robot ? using Neurogrid.
For more information:
  • Ben Varkey Benjamin, Peiran Gao, Emmett McQuinn,Swadesh Choudhary, Anand R. Chandrasekaran, AMixed-Analog-Digital Multichip System for Large-Scale Neural Simulations.Proceedings of the IEEE, 2014; 1DOI: 10.1109/JPROC.2014.2313565
  • Scientistscreate circuit board modeled on the human brain http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/04/140428134051.htm?
  • Press release: Stanfordbioengineers create circuit board modeled on the human brain http://news.stanford.edu/pr/2014/pr-neurogrid-boahen-engineering-042814.html



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Fine Print

Currently, there is a proof of concept prototype available. Moving this to an affordable and commercial prototype stage requires new and efficient fabrication materials that are cheap and small enough to embed in the human brain.This question will resolve when a prototype that can be built and sold to consumers is announced by an official.

keywords: quantum computing, factorization, semiprimes, primes, minimization algorithm, qubits
name: Will quantum factorization of a semiprime larger than 56,153 (the current record) be reported by the end of March 2015?
question_text:
Researchers recently?set a new record for the quantum factorization of the largest number to date, 56,153. This beat?the previous record of 143?set in 2012.?They have shown that the exact same room-temperature nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiment used to factor 143 can actually factor an entire class of numbers called semiprimes,?numbers with exact two prime factors,?although this was not known until now. Because this computation, which is based on a minimization algorithm involving 4 qubits, does not require prior knowledge of the answer, it outperforms all implementations of Shor's algorithm to date, which do require prior knowledge of the answer. Expanding on this method, the researchers also show theoretically?how the same minimization algorithm could be used to factor even larger numbers, such as 291,311, with only 6 qubits. Unlike the factorization of 56,153, the factorization of 291,311 has not yet been experimentally implemented, so it doesn't count as a new record yet.

New largest number factored on a quantum device is 56,153:?http://phys.org/news/2014-11-largest-factored-quantum-device.html#jCp

Quantum factorization of 56153 with only 4 qubits:?http://arxiv.org/abs/1411.6758

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

The new development may be posted on arXiv.org, an Open Archives Initiative (OAI)-compliant archive of electronic preprints in physics, mathematics, computer science, and non-linear sciences. It may also?be reported on the science, research and technology news website phys.org?

keywords: Chikungunya, emerging infectious diseases, vector borne diseases, climate change
name: Will there be a locally transmitted case of Chikungunya virus in the contiguous U.S. by September 1, 2014?
question_text:
From?http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/geo/united-states.html:

  • Chikungunya is not a?nationally notifiable disease?in the United States. However, chikungunya cases can be reported to ArboNET, the national surveillance system for arthropod-borne diseases.
  • From 2006?2013, studies identified an average of 28 people per year in the United States with positive tests for recent chikungunya virus infection (Range 5?65 per year). All were travelers visiting or returning to the United States from affected areas, mostly in Asia. Only a quarter of the cases were reported to ArboNET.
  • Beginning in 2014, cases have been identified in travelers returning from the Caribbean. As of July 8, a total of 153 chikungunya cases have been reported to ArboNET from U.S. states and territories (Table). Fifteen locally-transmitted cases have been reported from Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. All other cases occurred in travelers returning from affected areas in the Caribbean (N=134), the Pacific Islands (N=3), or Asia (N=1). To date, no local transmission has been identified in the continental United States.
  • With the recent outbreaks in the Caribbean and the Pacific, the number of chikungunya cases among travelers visiting or returning to the United States from affected areas will likely increase. These imported cases could result in local spread of the virus in the continental United States.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

09/01/2014

Resolution Source

Official CDC counts of Chikungunya cases, per State, are released every Tuesday here:?http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/geo/united-states.html. The site distinguishes between patients infected while on travel outside of the U.S. and those who contracted the disease locally.?

This site will be checked on 09/02/2014, which is a Tuesday, as it will list all cases through September 1, 2014.?

Fine Print

In this case, "locally transmitted" means there is a case of a patient with Chikungunya who did not get infected with the virus through travel outside of the contiguous lower 48 States, but contracted the virus locally through infected mosquitoes.

name: Will the Northeastern region of the United States have a milder January in 2015 than it did in 2014?
question_text:
The US Climate Prediction Center issued an El Nino warning in March 2014, forecasting the possible arrival of the periodic phenomenon in which warming of the Pacific Ocean triggers dramatic weather changes for around the globe. Past El Nino events have brought heavy rain and flooding to California and made winter warmer with less snow in the Midwest and Northeast. If the El Nino occurs, a milder winter in the Northeastern region of the US may be more likely.

The January 2014 monthly average temperature in Northeastern US region was 18.7 degree Fahrenheit, the coldest since 2009.

  • Forecasters see El Nino warming of Pacific Ocean: http://phys.org/news/2014-03-el-nino-pacific-ocean.html
  • So long, California drought? US Issues El Nino watch: http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-03-06/so-long-california-drought-u-dot-s-dot-issues-el-ni-...
  • NOAA NCDC Climate at a Glance http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cag/time-series/us/tmp/1/101/0/1/1895-2014?base_prd=true&begbaseyear=1901&e...


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

The monthly average temperature of the Northeastern climate region is reported by NCDC of NOAA: http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cag/time-series/us/tmp/1/101/0/1/1895-2014?base_prd=true&begbaseyear=1901&e...


Fine Print

The Northeastern region of the US is identified by the NCDC scientists and includes the six New England states of ME, NH, VT, MA, RI, and CT, plus the states of NY, PA, NJ, DE, and MD.

keywords: U.S., Avocado, Value, Production, USD, 2013, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total value of U.S. avocado production for the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of USD?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • The value of?U.S. avocado production?for the 2012 marketing season was unknown at the time of the USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Preliminary Summary' published in January 2013 due to incomplete data at that time. Complete data from the 2012 marketing season is unknown due to the 2013 budget sequestration.
  • The value of?U.S. avocado production for the 2011 marketing season?totaled 406,047 in thousands USD.
  • The value of avocado production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as avocados are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past two marketing seasons, in which data has been available,?to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past two marketing seasons, in which data has been available, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Total value of avocado production is reported in thousands of USD, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service.


Fine Print

The '2013 marketing season' in Florida begins 06/20/2012 and ends 03/01/2013. The '2013 marketing season' in California begins 11/01/2012 and ends 10/2013.

'Total value of production' is the 'packinghouse-door equivalent'. 'Packinghouse-door' equivalent is defined as all fruit, regardless of methods of sale, converted to a price it would have brought if the entire crop, or segment thereof being priced, had been sold at the packinghouse-door.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.

name: When will an artificial blood cell product derived from stem cells enter clinical trials?
question_text:
Artificial blood cell products have not been approved by the FDA despite many years of research. However, research continues due to the widespread shortage of blood products and infections transmitted by transfusions. Recent research has focused on producing red blood cells from stem cells in vitro for routine transfusion. Cord blood stem cells and embryonic stem cells have shown an ability to differentiate and proliferate and induced pluripotent stem cells have been shown to be an unlimited source for Red Blood Cell production.

On April 14, 2014, Forbes reported that Marc Turner, medical director at the Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service, announced they had ?manufactured blood to the appropriate quality and safety standards for transfusion into a human being.? The ?artificial blood was derived from stem cells that have been made from an adult donor?s skin or blood. These donor cells are genetically rewound to become induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells.?

Links and sources

  • First Artificial Red Blood Cells?Made http://www.forbes.com/sites/paulrodgers/2014/04/14/first-artificial-red-blood-cells-made/

name: Will antimicrobial resistant pathogens ever make antimicrobial medicines useless by 2035?
question_text:
Antimicrobial compounds have been synthesized or extracted from nature.

There is a shortage of companies makingantibiotics, limited number of available antibiotics, and increased amount ofantimicrobial resistant organisms.

However, new research on the microbiome suggests that the good bacteria and microbes that live in our skin and in out gut at least some might produce antimicrobial compounds. These natural compounds are only now being discovered.

The U.S. Global Health Security Agenda lists addressing antimicrobial resistance has a top objective.

Resolution Criteria

Pharmaceutical and biotechnological companies would have to regain interest and invest in development of antimicrobial medicines that can be effective even again multiple drug resistant pathogens. This question will accept forecasts until 12/31/2035

Resolution Sources

Science: http://www.sciencemag.org/magazine

Nature: http://www.nature.com/

Fine Print

Antimicrobial resistance refers to the ability of a microbe (bacteria, virus, fungus, parasite) to survive and grow in the presence of antimicrobials (antibiotics, antivirals, antifungals).Antimicrobial medicines refers to synthetic or natural drugs that prevent infection or growth of a microbe.

For the purpose of this question "uselessness" of antimicrobials will be defined to be the point at which the established antimicrobial industry at the time?would no longer be?economically viable even to speculative investors.

Useful Information and Links

The Forum on Microbial Threats has begun examining the microbiome of the human body. During its public discussions, the Forum has discussed antimicrobial properties of commensal microbes.? The Forum's website is http://www.iom.edu/Activities/PublicHealth/MicrobialThreats.aspx

The Biotechnology Industry Organization might offer insight into new research and development efforts from the private sector. Its website is: http://www.bio.org/

Nature, Science, Journal of Virology, and other scientific journals have published numerous studies and/or news articles on antimicrobial medicines.


Related Organizations or Individuals

pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies

keywords: Vaccine, Respiratory Syncytial Virus, RSV, human trials
name: In the search for a vaccine against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), when will a clinical grade protein based on the metastable antigenic site specific to the prefusion state of the RSV fusion (F) glycoprotein be available for human tests?
question_text:
According to the National Institutes of Health, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is ?the most common cause of bronchiolitis (inflammation of small airways in the lungs) and pneumonia in children less than one year old and the most common cause for hospitalization in children under five. Worldwide, it is estimated that RSV is responsible for nearly 7 percent of deaths in babies aged 1 month to 1 year; only malaria kills more children in this age group.? Scientists have searched for years for a vaccine against RSV. A few vaccines have made it into human trials, but none that have been effective.

On Oct. 31, 2013, scientists announced that ?a carefully engineered RSV protein? focused on the metastable? antigenic site specific to the prefusion state of the RSV fusion (F) glycoprotein, had ?triggered a remarkably potent antibody response? in animals.? RSV has a protein on its surface (F) that ?orchestrates its fusion with cells during the infection process?.? In May 2013, researchers announced they ?crystalized a potent antibody bound to the prefusion F structure, spotlighting a site on the virus that was especially vulnerable to neutralization.? The team went on to stabilize the shape of the antibody protein and found a variant that produced the desired antibodies in animal tests.? After refinement, the next step is to test this protein in humans to see if it produces the same potent antibody response.



Resolution Criteria

?Available for test in humans? ? the protein is available for human test, though human tests may not have started yet.

Vaccine Research Center (VRC) at the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland is working on an RSV vaccine.

Resolution Sources

This advancement will be covered by major science news outlets such as:

  • Science Magazine
  • Nature Magazine
  • Science section of major newspapers (e.g., New York Times, Chicago Tribune, Boston Globe)
In addition, the Center (VRC) at the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland will most likely publish a press release.

Fine Print

The question will resolve based on information from the Vaccine Research Center. Question will close before this date if available before the date.

Useful Information and Links

  • Cohen, J. (2013). "VACCINES Structural Biology Triumph Offers Hope Against a Childhood Killer." SCIENCE 342(6158): 546-547.
  • McLellan, J. S., M. Chen, et al. (2013). "Structure-Based Design of a Fusion Glycoprotein Vaccine for Respiratory Syncytial Virus." SCIENCE 342(6158): 592-598.
  • McLellan, J. S., M. Chen, et al. (2013). "Structure of RSV Fusion Glycoprotein Trimer Bound to a Prefusion-Specific Neutralizing Antibody." SCIENCE 340(6136): 1113-1117.
  • NIH. ?NIH scientists develop candidate vaccine against respiratory syncytial virus.? October 31, 2013. Press Release.
  • PUB MED Search Page
  • Clinical Trials RSV Search Page

Related Organizations or Individuals

Vaccine Research Center (VRC) at the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland

name: What will the average contiguous U.S. temperature be for January 2015?
question_text:
As Earth's climate continues to change, the deviation from previous mean temperatures?are expected to increase. According to?NOAA?(the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration),?the average temperature of the 20th century,?during the month of January was?30.4?F in the United States. However, the average for this past year for the same period?was 30.3?F.

In addition, meteorologists are forecasting this winter to have a 65% chance of an "El Nino," which is likely to bring cooler?than usual weather due to colder ocean temperatures around the?Equatorial Pacific.

For more information:?

  • NOAA -- Global Summaries
  • El Ni?o

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/31/2015

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved using January climate summary?posted by?the National Climate Data Center (NCDC):?http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/sotc/.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

According to the National Climate Data Center, the average January temperature from the 20th century was 30.4?F.

keywords: malaria, Roll Back Malaria partnership, Global Malaria Action Plan, GMAP
name: Will the GMAP goal of eliminating malaria in 8-10 new countries by DEC 31 2015 be achieved?
question_text:
This question focuses on one out of the five targets of the Global Malaria Action Plan (GMAP). We have already failed to reduce malaria incidence by 50% by 2010, and yet many remain committed to trying to eliminate deaths in 8-10 countries by 2015, and preventable deaths to near zero overall. Not only is malaria a huge burden for many in the developing world, and especially in sub-Saharan Africa and among children, from a broader perspective, this initiative speaks to the international community's efforts to set ambitious goals, and may help us monitor what the best response should be if we fail to meet these targets.?

From?http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/rbmgmap.html:

World leaders and the global malaria community gathered on occasion of the?2008 MDG Malaria Summit?on September 25, 2008, in New York to endorse an ambitious?Global Malaria Action Plan - GMAP.?The GMAP?provides a global framework for action around which partners can coordinate their efforts. The GMAP presents (i) a comprehensive overview of the global malaria landscape, (ii) an evidence-based approach to deliver effective prevention and treatment to all people at risk and (iii) an estimate of the annual funding needs to achieve the goals of the RBM Partnership for 2010, 2015 and beyond.The GMAP?outlines the RBM Partnership's vision for a substantial and sustained reduction in the burden of malaria in the near and mid-term, and the eventual global eradication of malaria in the long term, when new tools make eradication possible. To reach this vision, the targets of?the GMAP?are to:

  • Achieve universal coverage, as recently called for by the UN Secretary-General, for all populations at risk with locally appropriate interventions for prevention and case management by 2010 and sustain universal coverage until local field research suggests that coverage can gradually be targeted to high risk areas and seasons only, without risk of a generalized resurgence;
  • Reduce global malaria cases from 2000 levels by 50% in 2010 and by 75% in 2015;
  • Reduce global malaria deaths from 2000 levels by 50% in 2010 and to near zero preventable deaths in 2015;
  • Eliminate malaria in 8-10 countries by 2015 and afterwards in all countries in the pre-elimination phase today; and
  • In the long term, eradicate malaria world-wide by reducing the global incidence to zero through progressive elimination in countries.

As malaria is transmitted by mosquitoes, and sensitive to environmental perturbations, it is conceivable that a large environmental incident in one or more of the countries currently in the elimination stage would set back their progress towards elimination, and thus affect the outcome of this question. Likewise, further financial commitments from donor countries or foundations, in a concerted, coordinated fashion, and focusing on elimination, could accelerate progress towards a "yes" outcome.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The WHO's annual World Malaria Report summarizes malaria data, including incidence data, per country - for example, the 2013 report can be found here:?http://www.who.int/malaria/publications/world_malaria_report_2013/en/index.html

Likewise, the RBM Partnership also conducts Monitoring and Evaluation, both on programs and also to keep track of progress towards the 2015 targets:?http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/gmap/4-9.html


Fine Print

"Elimination" is defined by the Roll Back Malaria (RBM) Partnership, a key stakeholder in the GMAP, as zero incidence of locally transmitted infection. GMAP's goal also specifies that these ten countries must be "new" countries, as of 2008 - in other words, the country must have had incidence of locally transmitted infection at least up until 2008 (it must not have eliminated malaria prior to 2008). The 2008 WHO World Malaria Report can be used to define these countries: http://www.who.int/malaria/publications/atoz/9789241563697/en/index.html.

keywords: hurricane, New York City, state of emergency
name: In 2014, will an Atlantic hurricane or tropical storm prompt the mayor of New York City to declare a state of emergency?
question_text:
Eighty-four tropical or subtropical cyclones have affected the state of New York Since the 17th century. The strongest of these storms was the 1938 New England Hurricane, which struck Long Island as a Category?3 storm on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. Killing more than 600?people, it was also the deadliest.

In late October 2012, Hurricane Sandy?made landfall near Atlantic City with 90 mph winds. It is the largest hurricane ever recorded in the Atlantic Basin, with wind gusts topping 100 mph in some parts of the New York Metropolitan area. On October 26th, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo declared a statewide state of emergency and asked for a pre-disaster declaration.

  • List of New York Hurricane: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_New_York_hurricanes
  • Hurricane Sandy: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy

12/31/2014

Fine Print

name: How much shale gas will China produce in 2014?
question_text:
China is estimated to hold the largest technically recoverable reserves of shale gas in the world?nearly twice as much as the U.S. However, China is facing large technological, geological, technical and topological hurdles in developing its shale gas resources, and China?s domestic oil and natural gas companies do not have the experience or technological base that the United States was able to tap into in order to quickly develop its resources once they became economical.

China?s most promising shale gas basin, the Sichuan, is in a deeply faulted region. Not only does this limit the utility of horizontal drilling, but also the frequency of earthquakes in the region will raise fears that they are being caused by hydraulic fracturing. This region is mountainous, which slows the?movement of equipment from site to site and adds to the cost of production. Because of these difficulties, of the 117 billion cubic meters of natural gas that China produced in 2013, only 0.2 billion cubic meters came from shale.

This has led the Chinese government to cut its ambitious 2020 target for shale gas development roughly in half. However, China's largest oil and gas companies, China National Petroleum Corp. and Sinopec, are optimistic about their production capabilities in the next few years: Sinopec?s flagship shale gas project is the?Fuling project, which is currently? producing 3.2 million cubic meters of shale gas per day. This led the company to increase their projections?for 2015 to 5 billion cubic meters, up from earlier projections of 1 billion cubic meters. China National Petroleum Corp. lags behind Sinopec, but recent success caused the company to increase?their expectations to 2.6 billion cubic meters in 2015 ? an upward revision of their planned target by nearly 75 percent.

Sources in links:
  • MIT Technology Review - China's Shale Gas Bust
  • Reuters - China find shale gas challenging, halves 2020 output target
  • Forbes - China's Shale Production Falls Short, but Goals Remain in Place

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

International Energy Agency - http://www.iea.org/topics/China/news/
The answer may be reported on by major new organization, but they should cite an official source such as the IEA or the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Fine Print

If the answer resolves outside the range, the question will resolve to the closest extreme.

keywords: Flu, Region 2, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 2 (NJ, NY, PR, VI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???

  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 2' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 2 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 2. Region 2 is comprised of New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: Will a smartphone with an antibacterial glass panel containing iron nanoparticles be commercially available before the end of 2016?
question_text:
A Korean research team has successfully developed a method to make low-cost and high-performance antibacterial glass panels using iron nanoparticles. These glass panels are expected to be utilized in smartphones, owing to their antibacterial nature and their transparency and durability. Antibacterial films using silver nanoparticles have already been commercialized because they have strong antibacterial effects. However, silver nanoparticles are vulnerable to repetitive touch as they do not stick strongly to transparent glass. The Korean team solved this problem using iron nanoparticles, inserting?titanium nanoparticles between the iron nanoparticles and glass to increase the adhesive strength.

  • Tech to produce antibacterial glass panels to be used for smartphone touch panels:?http://www.businesskorea.co.kr/article/6535/antibacterial-electronics-tech-produce-antibacterial-gla...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

Information is likely to be reported by smartphone companies such as Samsung, Apple etc.?http://www.samsung.com/us/?www.apple.com

Information may also be reported in the business and popular science press, as part of the coverage of new smartphone releases.

name: Will quantum key distribution be integrated into a commercially available mobile device by 1 January 2017?
question_text:
Quantum key distribution (QKD) uses quantum mechanics to guarantee secure communication. It enables two parties to produce a shared random secret key known only to them, which can then be used to encrypt and decrypt messages.

Messages can be encrypted and transmitted using traditional techniques; however, the key to encrypt and decrypt messages is encrypted exploiting quantum mechanical properties of photons. This method guarantees secure communication between two parties, because, due to quantum indeterminacy, the key cannot be observed by a third party without changing the quantum states. If the key is observed, it is changed in ways such as the receiver can detect eavesdropping and communication is stopped.

Current quantum cryptography technology is expensive and bulky, which limits it to fixed physical locations. However, recent advances by Zhang et al. enables one party using QKD to decode the key using an optical chip and? ?opens the way for quantum enhanced secure communications between companies and members of the general public equipped with handheld mobile devices, via telecom-fiber tethering.?

Links and Sources

  • University of Bristol. "Quantum cryptography for mobile phones." www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/04/140403132331.htm
  • Zhang et al. Reference-Frame-Independent Quantum-Key-Distribution Server with a Telecom Tether for an On-Chip Client. Physical Review Letters, 2014; 112 (13) DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.112.130501
  • Physicists Test Quantum Cryptography For Handheld Mobile Devices http://www.technologyreview.com/view/518451/physicists-test-quantum-cryptography-for-handheld-mobile...
  • HP Press Release: Quantum Key Distribution: Systems Security Lab http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press_kits/2008/hplabsemea/demo-qkd.pdf
  • Mitsubishi Electric: Quantum Cryptography http://www.mitsubishielectric.com/company/rd/research/highlights/communications/quantum.html
  • Quantum key distribution http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_key_distribution

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

An announcement by the manufacturer ofa commercially available device will resolve this question.

keywords: Particle physics, quantum mechanics, axion, dark matter, Axion Dark Matter Experiment
name: Will the Axion Dark Matter Experiment (ADMX) start to collect data in its search for an axion by March 1, 2014?
question_text:
Axions are theorized by Roberto Peccei and Helen Quinn to solve the charge-parity (CP) symmetry problem. The Axion Dark Matter Experiment (ADMX) is located at the University of Washington and aims to detect the very weak conversion of dark matter axions into microwave photons as evidence of axions. In 2010, the ADMX team showed that the specially designed amplifiers worked as hoped. As of November 1, 2013, they had not started to collect data.

Resolution Sources

Science Magazine http://www.sciencemag.org

Fine Print

The experiment will be considered to be collecting data when the ADMX begins to collect data toward its goal. This does not include any data collection for equipment testing purposes.

  • Marquit, Miranda. ?Is dark matter made of axions?? Physics.org March 3, 2008
  • ADMX | Axion Dark Matter eXperiment - University of Washington.
  • Adrian Cho. ?Dark Matter's Dark Horse.? Science 1 November 2013: 342 (6158), 552-55?

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: How many threatened species will the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species identify in its next published update?
question_text:
The InternationalUnion for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) maintains and publishes the IUCN RedList of Threatened Species, widely recognized as the most comprehensive andobjective global approach for evaluating the conservation status of plant andanimal species. In order to produce the Red List, IUCN draws upon a network ofscientists and partner organizations working in almost every country in theworld.

The Red Listidentified species as threatened if they are classified by the IUCN asCritically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), or Vulnerable (VU). Species canalso be classified as extinct (EX) or extinct in the wild (EW); or in one of severalnon-threatened categories: Lower Risk/conservation dependent (LR/cd), NearThreatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD), Least Concern (LC).

In the 2011, 2012 and 2013 releases of the Red List, the IUCN reported 19,570, 20,219, and 21,286threatened species respectively. The IUCN updates its list at least annually,so a new update should be available and published soon.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved when the IUCN publishes its next update to the RedList. The current list is version 2013.2 from 21 November 2013. The next updated list, once published, will be available in Table 1 and linked to here:? http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics




Fine Print

IUCN definitions are being used for endangered species, per the discussion in the Background discussion.

choices_field_5: Will not be available by January 1, 2022
keywords: Neuromorphic chips, neuromorphic computing, microchips, brain emulation
name: When will the first product containing a neuromorphic microchip go on sale to the general public?
question_text:
The fundamentals of microchip design have not changed since integrated circuits (ICs) were invented in the late 1950s. Increases in IC density over the last five decades have resulted in over a billion-fold multiplication of the number of circuits deployed within a single integrated circuit. The fundamental architecture of ICs, however, has not changed in this time.

In order to further boost their performance and application range, scientists have begun developing chips modeled after the human brain. These chips, called neuromorphic chips, depart radically from current chip design and function, and promise to be better suited than conventional chips to tasks like pattern recognition, tasks the human brain handles with remarkable efficiency and accuracy.

IBM has recently announced significant advances in the development of neuromorphic chips, and is actively working to move the technology into commercial application. Other companies such as Qualcomm are also working on neuromorphic chips, though it is unclear when these efforts will result in products available to consumers.

  • http://online.wsj.com/articles/ibm-unveils-chip-simulating-brain-functions-1407434402
  • http://www.technologyreview.com/featuredstory/526506/neuromorphic-chips/
  • http://vlsi.cornell.edu/~ni49/neuromorphic.html
  • http://inthecapital.streetwise.co/2014/08/11/darpas-creates-cheap-computer-chip-like-your-brain/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2022

Resolution Source

The sale of the first commercial product using neuromorphic chips will be announced by the company selling the product. Such a development will also be covered by a variety of technology news sources.

Fine Print

The product in question must have at least one neuromorphic microchip.

name: How many potential ExoMars mission landing sites will the ESA working group officially decide to study further?
question_text:
ExoMars is a large mission to Mars with the goal of searching for evidence of Martian life, past or present. ExoMars is currently under development by the European Space Agency (ESA) in collaboration with Roscosmos (the Russian Federal Space Agency). The agency received proposals for the following eight landing sites:

  • Coogoon Valles
  • Hypanis Vallis
  • Mawrth Vallis 1
  • Mawrth Vallis 2
  • Oxia Palus
  • Oxia Planum
  • Simud Vallis
  • Southern Isidis
On April 3, 2014, ESA announced that ?60 scientists and engineers came together 26?28 March for the first ExoMars 2018 Landing Site Selection Workshop, held at ESA's European Space Astronomy Centre near Madrid. Their task was to begin the process of drawing up a shortlist of the most suitable landing locations for ESA's first Mars rover.? From the proposed landing sites, the following four potential landing sites for the rover were shortlisted:
  • Mawrth Vallis
  • Oxia Planum
  • Hypanis Vallis
  • Oxia Palus
The ESA Landing Site Selection Working Group will recommend a final shortlist of up to four candidate sites in June 2014 for more detailed analysis.

Links and Sources
  • ESA ? robotic exploration of Mars -http://exploration.esa.int/mars/
  • Scientists favour four ExoMars landing sites http://exploration.esa.int/mars/53941-scientists-favour-four-exomars-landing-sites/
  • ?Proposed landing sites for ExoMars 2018 mission? http://exploration.esa.int/mars/53944-proposed-landing-sites-for-exomars-2018-mission/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/01/2014

Resolution Source

Europeanspace agency http://exploration.esa.int/mars/

keywords: Flu, Region 5, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 5 (IL, IN, MI, MN, OH, WI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 5' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 5 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 5 is comprised of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 5 is 1.7%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

keywords: Magnus Carlsen, Viswanathan Anand, World Chess championship, score
name: How many points will Magnus Carlsen finish with at the end of regulation play at the World Chess Championship match in Sochi in November 2014?
question_text:
The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. A variety of news sources are expected to monitor the match with immediate updates as the match evolves. Tie-break games are not considered in this question.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2014
http://www.fide.com

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/28/2014

Resolution Source

The resolution of this question will be based on the official score of the match conducted by the organizer of the tournament. It will be reported by multiple news sources. The major onces include:
http://www.chessbase.com
http://www.chess.com
http://www.fide.com

Fine Print

Regulation play is defined as the (up to) 12 games played prior to any tie-break games.

keywords: antimicrobials; antibiotics; FDA; pathogens; drug development; drug regulation
name: How many of FDA?s priority pathogens will still be on the list by 2025?
question_text:
In June 2013, the FDA proposed a list of pathogens that have the potential to pose a serious threat to public health. This was in response to a provision in FDASIS, the Generating Antibiotic Incentives Now (GAIN) provision. The intent of this legislation was to encourage development of new drugs for pathogens that are considered public health priorities. New drugs that qualify for GAIN incentives would have to target one from the list of qualifying priority pathogens, updated by the Commissioner of the FDA as priorities change. Changes in this list would indicate efforts to produce new therapeutics or control infections are working to the point that these pathogens no longer represent a critical public health threat or that other infections have increased in priority status. More information can be found here:?http://www.fda.gov/regulatoryinformation/legislation/federalfooddrugandcosmeticactfdcact/significant...


Development of new antibiotics or antimicrobials; emergence of drug resistant pathogens;

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2024

Resolution Source

The US Food and Drug Administration. FDA is required to announce any changes in the Federal Register. Any changes to the qualifying pathogens list can be found by searching for FDA GAIN qualifying pathogens.


Fine Print

The 18 priority or qualifying pathogens included on the list in 2013 are: Acinetobacter species, Aspergillus species, Burkholderia cepacia complex, Campylobacter species, Candida species, Clostridium difficile, Enterobacteriaceae (e.g., Klebsiella pneumoniae), Enterococcus species, Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, Non-tuberculous mycobacteria species, Pseudomonas species, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus agalactiae, S. pneumoniae, S. pyogenes, and Vibrio cholerae

name: Will Google's glucose monitoring "smart" contact lenses get FDA approval by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Google is working on a smart contact lens prototype that monitors glucose levels in tears. The contact lenses will make the?measurements using a tiny wireless chip and miniaturized glucose sensor that are embedded between two layers of soft contact lens material. Google is?testing prototypes that can generate a reading once per second. In April of 2014, Google has obtained two patents for the?cutting edge, biometric sensor technology. Google still has to get FDA approval for these glucose monitoring smart contact lenses.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Texas?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Texas, 51.2% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +2.4% from 2011 (48.8%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 50.3%, the "50.3%-53.7%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: ISS, Space station, NASA, shuttle, commercial
name: Will a NASA astronaut be transported to the International Space Station in a commercial spacecraft by DEC 1 2017?
question_text:
• The Russian built?Soyuz spacecraft are used for transport to and from the International Space Station (ISS).
  • America?s domestic launch and crew transportation capability was lost when Atlantis closed out the Space Shuttle Program (SSP) at the conclusion of STS-135. NASA created the Commercial Crew Program (CCP)?
  • NASA?s Commercial Crew Program (CCP)?is currently funding three private companies to build transportation systems that can remove NASA?s reliance on the Russian Soyuz to ferry American astronauts to the ISS.
  • The CCP?is currently in the Commercial Crew integrated Capability (CCiCAP) stage, maturing from the Commercial Crew Development (CCDev) drive that resulted in three companies earning NASA money to develop their spacecraft to be able to carry NASA astronauts.
  • In April 2013,?NASA?s planning group realigned the US Crew Vehicle -1 (USCV-1) mission to a launch date of November 30, 2017.
  • Russian Soyuz capsules used to?take at least two days to rendezvous with the ISS, due to?carefully timed maneuvers necessary?for a spaceship to safely meet the orbiting laboratory. However, a?new launch process that was implemented in early 2013 allowed?three astronauts to make?the trip in just under 6 hours.


Resolution Criteria

Liftoff must take place before December 1 2017 for the question to resolve as "Yes" (i.e.., plans for future launches, no matter how definitive, will not constitute a positive outcome to this question).?In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.?


Resolution Sources

The New York Times

Fine Print

The commercial spacecraft must be manufactured by a company funded by NASA under the Commercial Crew Program.?



Useful Information and Links

  • Bringing Down the ISS:?http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/08/bringing-down-iss-plans-stations-demise-updated/
  • 2017 ISS Crew Mission:?http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/04/uscv-1-nasa-slip-iss-commercial-late-2017/
  • Soyuz:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soyuz_(spacecraft)#Soyuz_TMA-M_.282010.2F.....29
  • Fastest Trip to ISS:?http://www.newscientist.com/blogs/shortsharpscience/2013/03/speedy-astronauts-make-the-fas.html
  • CCDev:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Crew_Development


Related Organizations or Individuals

choices_field_11: Will not be implemented before January 1
keywords: traffic, signals, sensors, networks, wireless, AI
name: When will a metropolitain area of over 250,000 people wirelessly network all traffic signals and sensors so that an AI system can optimize 2-dimensional traffic flow in real-time?
question_text:
Optimizing traffic flow would reduce average travel time, and it would also save fuel. There is a chicken and egg aspect to the problem, because wireless networking requires controls with wireless modules, but commercial development of these wireless modules depends on the feasibility of practical applications. Implementation is difficult because of competing jurisdictions.

Case Study: Phoenix, Arizona, Improving traffic flow with ITS:?Phoenix, Arizona has 1,100 traffic signals on 4,800 miles of streets. ?In August 2010 the city launched the first phase of its wireless mesh network to connect 420 radios to 412 traffic signals in the Phoenix area.

City Automates Traffic?Management and Gains Unlimited New Possibilities: Midland, Texas, implements an outdoor wireless mesh network to manage traffic and creates a foundation for citywide service delivery.

Upgrading Citywide Traffic Signal Systems Over Broadband Wireless Mesh Networks:?Wireless mesh networks have become a more frequently used method of communication for traffic applications. The City of Chattanooga, TN, USA, is upgrading its traffic signal system, which will eventually connect approximately 400 signals in the region.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2035

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved according to a report published in a journal, or based on a statement from a public official in the metro area that has implemented the system.

The system must be in use, it must control signals at least 50 intersections, no more than 20% of the intersections can be along any one road, it must use encrypted messaging, it must take into account (as a minimum) time of day, weather, and scheduled events, and the system must be capable of responding in less than 15 minutes to any unanticipated traffic congestion problem.

Fine Print

Metropolitan area: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) defines such an economic area as a geographical space within which a number of economic links are concentrated. Commuting is at the heart of a metropolitan region, as it brings together firms and workers through transport and telecommunications infrastructure. The OECD List of Urban Areas by Country report identifies metropolitan areas by country and by population size. This report found at www.oecd.org/regional/regional-policy/ALL.pdf will be used to establish the list of metropolitan areas of over 250,000 people. The following terms are defined at http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/The term "all" as used in all traffic signals and sensors is defined as the whole quantity or extent of traffic signals and sensors in a particular metropolitan area. The term "AI" means Artificial Intelligence. It is the theory and development of computer systems able to perform tasks normally requiring human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and translation between languages.The term "real-time" in terms of computing relates to a system in which input data is processed within milliseconds so that it is available virtually immediately as feedback.

name: How many new moons of Pluto will be reported by NASA's New Horizons spacecraft by the end of July 2015?
question_text:
NASA's New Horizons spacecraft has traveled 3 billion miles and is nearing the end of its nine-year journey to Pluto. Scientists are keeping the spacecraft?on track for a flyby on?July 14th,?when New Horizons pass Pluto?at a distance of 7,700 miles from the dwarf planet at a?speed of nearly 31,000 mph.?Over the coming?months, New Horizons will take hundreds of pictures of Pluto.

Beginning in the spring, the cameras and spectrometers aboard the spacecraft will be able to provide image resolutions higher than the most powerful telescopes on Earth. Eventually, the spacecraft will obtain images sharp enough to map Pluto and its moons more accurately than achieved by all?previous planetary reconnaissance missions.

Pluto is the largest object in the Kuiper Belt. Five moons have been found so far around Pluto. More could be lurking out there, awaiting discovery by New Horizons.

For more information:

  • NASA spacecraft almost to Pluto: Smile for the camera!?http://news.yahoo.com/nasa-spacecraft-almost-pluto-smile-camera-153919436.html
  • Moons of Pluto:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moons_of_Pluto
  • NASA's New Horizon spacecraft begins first stages of Pluto encounter:?http://www.nasa.gov/press/2015/january/nasa-s-new-horizons-spacecraft-begins-first-stages-of-pluto-e...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

7/31/2015

Resolution Source

The question?will be resolved when news is announced by NASA's New Horizons mission:?http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/newhorizons/main/index.html#.VMlBuP6jOm4. The news is also likely to be reported on?news sites?such as cnn.com, yahoo.com, space.com

Fine Print

A moon, is a celestial body that orbits another body (a planet, dwarf planet, or small Solar System body), which is called its primary, and that is not artificial. There is not an established lower limit on what is considered a "moon", as natural satellites will be referred to in this section. Every natural celestial body with an identified orbit around a planet of the Solar System, some as small as a kilometer across, has been identified as a moon.The moons of Pluto currently known are Charon, Styx, Nix, Kerberos, and Hydra; these will not be considered for this question.

keywords: Robotics, systems, software, robots, disaster response, research, competiton
name: Which team will win the DARPA Robotics Challenge taking place on June 5-6 2015?
question_text:
The DARPA Robotics Challenge (DRC) is a DARPA-sponsored competition of robot systems and software teams vying to develop robots capable of assisting humans in responding to natural and man-made disasters.?DARPA is the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, an agency of the United States Department of Defense responsible for the development of new technologies for use by the military.?

Sixteen teams competed at trials on December 20-21, 2013 at the Homestead-Miami Speedway, guiding their robots through tasks that tested mobility, manipulation, dexterity, perception, and operator control mechanisms. The eight best-performing teams will receive DARPA funding through to the finals scheduled for?December 20-21, 2014.? Other teams using independent sources of funding are also invited to compete. The winning team will receive a $2 million prize.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/06/2015

Resolution Source

Representatives from?DARPA will determine the winner and the results will be posted to The Robotics Challenge official website.

Fine Print

None

name: When will a piloted solar plane fly around the world only on solar energy?
question_text:
• In 2012, Solar Impulse 1 flew from Switzerland to Spain and Morocco (in multiple stages) powered only by solar power.
  • In 2013, the solar-powered piloted plane flew from San Francisco to New York City (in multiple stages) powered only by solar power.
  • The speed of the aircraft was limited by the capacity of the lithium polymer batteries, which were charge by the sun. The speed resulted in flights between waypoint lasting 19 to 24 hours.
  • The Solar Impulse 1 set many records for a solar plane including longest duration flight (26 hours 10 minutes), absolute height, and free distance.
  • In June 2014, the next generation solar plane Solar Impulse 2 completed its first test flight in Switzerland. It is built with the goal of flying around the globe with 17,000 solar cells, four brush-less motors, and lithium batteries with an electrolyte that allow an energy density of 260 watt-hours per kilogram.
Links and sources
  • Solar Impulse 2: Plane makes inaugural flight
  • http://www.solarimpulse.com
  • Solar Plane With Global Aims Makes First Flight

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

An official from the successful team will announce the trip and it would be certified by the F?d?ration A?ronautique Internationale.

Fine Print

Any solar powered plane can resolve this question but it must have a pilot on the aircraft and fly only with solar power. The flight does not need to be continuous - as in past flights it may stop at waypoints during its trip.

keywords: Solar Roadways, Smart Highway, Smart Grid, Intelligent Highway System
name: Will Solar Roadways be installed on any public roadway in the U.S. for public use by 2020?
question_text:
Solar Roadways Inc, a startup company founded in 2006, is developing solar powered road panels to eventually form a 'smart highway.'? Their aim is to replace the current asphalt roads with solar powered road panels that would include technologies such as electrical power generation (by photovoltaic cells underneath the road surface), the ability to light the road panels to show road markings and other traffic markings (by LED lights), ability to heat the surface of the road so that it can be kept clear of snow/ice, and the ability to detect objects on the road and display relevant traffic messages.? The current prototype consists of three layers (top down):? The Road Surface layer which is made of high strength tempered glass on top with photovoltaic cells, LEDs, and a heating element underneath.? The Electronics layer which consists of a microprocessor and support circuitry to control the lightning, communications, heating element, object detection, etc.? And the Base Plate layer which distributes the electrical power generated to homes and businesses.

In 2009, Solar Roadways received $750,000 from the Federal Highway Administration to develop a prototype, and in June 2014 raised $2.2 million through a crowdfunded campaign on Indiegogo.? Currently, they have built a prototype parking lot and aim to have a finished product by the end of 2015.? However they would first test the final product on parking lots and sidewalks, before trying it on residential roads, and eventually the highway, says Scott Brusaw, founder of Solar Roadways Inc.? They have several private tests lined up in Sandpoint, Idaho including a few parking lots and sidewalks.? Although this has caught the attention of government, industry, and media outlets, it has also created a fair share of critics who are skeptical of the engineering and safety aspects of Solar Roadways.?

This question asks if Solar Roadways will be installed on any public roadway for public use (i.e. not for testing) by 2020.? This is significant since this would imply that the Solar Roadways has passed engineering and safety regulations as deemed by the regulatory agencies.? ??

Relevant Links:

  • Crowdfunding Campaign Raises $2.2 Million to Build Solar Roadways
  • The Centuries Old Technology Behind Solar Roadways, Indiegogo's Most Popular Campaign Ever
  • On the Not So Sunny Side of the Street
  • Solar Roadways Indiegogo Campaign Video

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved if a production ready Solar Roadway is installed on any public road in the U.S. for public use (i.e.? not for testing purposes) by 2020.? This will be verified through the Solar Roadways Inc. FAQ page, news page, or other major news sources.

Fine Print

A 'private road' is defined as a road owned and maintained by a private individual, organization, or company other than the government and which is intended for motor vehicle use. This may include roads such as parking lots and residential roads. A 'public road' is defined as a road maintained by the government which is intended for motor vehicle use, such as interstates and highways (or U.S. routes). 'Public use' means it is open to the general population to drive on and use. 'Production ready' means the road is not in testing phase, which assumes the road has passed all safety and environmental inspections. Note that it is also assumed the government will not open a solar roadway for public use if it is still in testing phase.

keywords: touchscreen passwords, mobile device security, password security
name: When will free-form gestures be used as access passwords in commercial touchscreen mobile devices?
question_text:
People conduct many personal andbusiness activities using mobile devices including communication(emails/IM/SMS etc.), banking, home access key, and as a mobile wallet. Traditionally, touch screen mobile devices like phonesand tablets either use typed passwords or ?connect-the-dot? pattern basedpasswords. A new study by engineers at Rutgers University along with collaboratorsfrom Max-Planck Institute for Informatics and University of Helsinkishows that free-form gestures where one can sweep her fingers across thetouchscreen device, can be used in place of currently used security mechanisms.The researchers found that shoulder-surfers were able to easily reproducetraditional character-lock passwords and pattern-based passwords but found itdifficult to replicate a free-form squiggly finger(s) stroke.?

For further research and testing of the viability of this authentication, the researchers plan to develop and test guidelines for replicable, high-security gestures. Further trials will be necessary to better analyze andunderstand the security and management of free-form password authentication; and the researchers hope to pique the interest of experts when they publish their findings at MobiSys ?14 in June 2014, a premier international conference in mobile?computing.?
?
For more information: ?
  • Squiggly lines maybe the future of password security http://www.homelandsecuritynewswire.com/dr20140606-squiggly-lines-may-be-the-future-of-password-security?
  • User-GeneratedFree-Form Gestures for Authentication: Security and Memorability http://arxiv.org/abs/1401.0561

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

News reports in science and technology pressor popular press.

Fine Print

Free-form gestures can be created by sweeping one?s fingers in shapes across the screen of a touchscreen mobile device and can be used for mobile authentication. This type of security access feature must be a standard available option built-in to the hardware of commercial touchscreen devices.

name: Will the average price of a US domestic plane ticket decline in the first two quarters of 2015?
question_text:
In 2014 and early into 2015, the price of crude oil has been steadily decreasing. The average consumer sees this most easily when they go to pay for gasoline for their cars. Airlines, too, have a newfound surplus (the money they are saving from the oil). The cost of jet fuel, for example, has fallen 43% from the price a year ago, yet the prices still remain to be constant.

Recently in the United States, in 2014, the second quarter price of an average domestic plane ticket was $395.62 (see all data history), similar to quarters before but a huge difference from other years. While many believe that airline prices will not go down with the current steadily decreasing oil prices, there are some who recognize that it is a possibility for oil prices to greatly decrease in early 2015 and this drastic decline in price will indeed cause a lower than average ticket price.

For additional information:

  • Average US Domestic Flight Data
  • Airfare Prices

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2015

Resolution Source

This will be resolved using the 2015?quarterly data

Fine Print

For it to decline, BOTH the first and second quarter prices must be lower than the average price of an airline ticket in the fourth quarter of the 2014; however, the second quarter, 2015 average does not have to be less than the first quarter average.

This question refers to the U.S. Average (Inflation-Adjusted $) on the data table.

name: What will the tenth most popular computer language, as reported by the TIOBE index, be for March of 2015?
question_text:
The TIOBE programming community index is a measure of the popularity of programming languages, calculated from number of search engine results for queries containing the name of each language. The index covers searches in Google, Google Blogs, MSN, Yahoo!, Baidu, Wikipedia, and YouTube, and is updated once a month. An interactive, long-term chart of its results is available on the TIOBE website (http://www.tiobe.com/index.php/content/paperinfo/tpci/index.html) dating back to 2002. TIOBE focuses on Turing-complete languages, so it does not provide information about the popularity of, for instance, SQL or HTML.

November 2014 data are already available (as of November 21, 2014) and report C, Java, Objective-C, C++, C#, and PHP as the top six languages; these were also the top six languages (in the same order) in November of 2013. Below that the popularity of languages has shifted from November 2013 to November 2014. Its rating for each language is reported as a percentage with three decimal places. For example, the November 2014 rating for Java is 14.391%.

For November 2014, the 8th through 12th most popular languages, respectively, were: JavaScript; Perl; Visual Basic.NET; Visual Basic; and R.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.tiobe.com/index.php/content/paperinfo/tpci/index.html
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measuring_programming_language_popularity
  • http://www.infoworld.com/article/2608845/java/java-java-c-slip-in-popularity-as-domain-specific-lang...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

TIOBE will report its language index for March of 2015 sometime during that month, on its site:? http://www.tiobe.com/index.php/content/paperinfo/tpci/index.html

keywords: Flu, Region 2, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 2 (NJ, NY, PR, VI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 2' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases in Region 2 for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across HHS region 2. Region 2 is comprised of New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Alabama?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the State of Alabama,?46.6% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -2.9%?from 2011 (49.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are?developed based on the variation in the?rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use?the standard deviation (SD)?of these rates of change to?compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs?and center?the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range?of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change)?in the 7 interior bins of each question,?to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS - Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results?can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html#12

Fine Print

HPV stands for the Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a term defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 45.7%, the "45.7%-49.1%" range will be deemed correct.

name: On November 2030, what will be the Top 500 performance share by geographic region?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share by geographic region, and you think North America's machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust North America's chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list
