name: When will the first product containing a microchip that uses nanotube transistors go on sale to the general public?
question_text:
According to Moore's Law, the dimensions of individual devices in an integrated circuit have been decreased by a factor of approximately two every two years. This scaling down of devices has been the driving force in technological advances since late 20th century. According to the semiconductor industry?s roadmap, by 2020 transistors must have features as small as five nanometers to keep up with the continuous miniaturization of computer chips. Nanotubes appear to be one of the only technologies that looks capable of keeping the advance of computer power from slowing down by offering a practical way to make both smaller and faster transistors.

IBM has recently announced that the company is now aiming to have transistors built using carbon nanotubes ready to take over from silicon transistors soon after 2020. In 1998, researchers at IBM made one of the first working carbon nanotube transistors, and last year the company announced it had made? chips with 10,000 nanotube transistors. Also in 2013, researchers at Stanford created the first simple computer built using only nanotube transistors, but the computer's components were bulky and slow compared to current silicon transistors.

  • MIT Technology Review - IBM: Commercial Nanotube Transistors Are Coming Soon
  • Wikipedia - Carbon nanotube field-effect transistor

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2023

Resolution Source

The sale of the first commercial microchip using nanotube transistors will be announced by the company selling the chip. Such a development will also be convered by a variety of technology news sources.

Fine Print

The product in question must have at least one microchip made up of nanotube transistors.

keywords: qubit, quantum computer, topological, hall effect
name: Will a research group report the synthesis of a topological qubit before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
A qubit?is a unit of quantum information (the quantum analogue of the classical bit).? In classical computing, a bit is either one or zero; however, a qubit can be a superposition of both. Therefore, up to two bits can be encoded using Superdense coding. The coding and the entanglement of qubits in superposition results in much faster computation - several orders of magnitude faster than a classical computer in the execution of optimization problems.? Several hurdles must be overcome before quantum computing becomes a widely available including the fact the entanglement using trapped quantum particles is unstable.

In 2002, researchers proved that a topological quantum computer can, in principle, perform any computation that a conventional quantum computer can do. Topological qubits are qubits hosted by topologically ordered states instead of trapped quantum particulars and are more stable.?
?Synthesis of a topological qubits have yet to be reported in a peer-reviewed publication, though a few labs are working on the problem including Bell Labs and Microsoft.

?Links and sources
Topological qubits: A bit of both Vishveshwara, Smitha Nature Physics 7.6 (Jun 2011): 450-451 http://www.nature.com/nphys/journal/v7/n6/full/nphys2014.html

Microsoft?s Quantum Mechanics http://www.technologyreview.com/featuredstory/531606/microsofts-quantum-mechanics/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/30/2015

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in a company official press release.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: Will Bluefin-21 locate the black box from Malaysian Airlines flight MH-370?
question_text:
Underwater operations company Phoenix International has a contract with the U.S. Navy to use Bluefin-21 to search the Indian Ocean for?signs of the missing Malaysian Airlines flight MH-370. With the recent report of detecting the possible "ping" signals from the flight's black box, the searchers may launch a Bluefin-21 to investigate. The vehicle can create sonar map of the ocean floor and collect underwater images with a camera. However, since the water depth at the search area is approximately 4,500 meters, which is about the limit of the vehicle, the task could be tricky.

keywords: obesity, public health, body mass index
name: How many states will have combined overweight and obese population in excess of 70% of all adults according to the CDC's 2014 Prevalence and Trends Data?
question_text:
Obesity is a medical condition in which excess body fat has accumulated to the extent that it can negatively effect health. Obesity is measured using the body mass index (BMI), a metric obtained by dividing a person's weight by the square of his or her height. When the BMI exceeds 30 kg/m2, a person is considered obese, while the range of 25-30 kg/m2 is defined as overweight.

A wide range of causes for obesity are under investigation, beyond diet and levels of physical activity, including such things as genetics, environmental pollutants (which are thought to interfere with lipid metabolism), and even contagious agents. Given the large number of people affected and the wide range of resulting health problems and associated costs, much scientific research is being conducted to reduce and prevent obesity.

In the most recent (2013) statistics reported by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), via the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS), Arkansas had the highest share of state adult population that was either overweight or obese, at 69.9%. Five states were at 68% or higher, 12 were at 67% or higher, and 19 were at 66% or higher.

Updated data for 2014 are expected the second half of 2014.

For more information, see:
  • http://www.cbsnews.com/news/taxing-sugary-sodas-could-help-fight-childhood-obesity/
  • http://www.cdc.gov/obesity/data/adult.html
  • http://apps.nccd.cdc.gov/brfss/list.asp?cat=OB&yr=2013&qkey=8261&state=All
  • http://www.cdc.gov/brfss/about/about_brfss.htm
  • http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/obesity-is-now-so-normal-that-parents-can-t-see-it-in-thei...

Updated BRFSS will be reported here:? http://apps.nccd.cdc.gov/brfss/ (select "Overweight and Obesity (BMI)" for Category), and used for resolution.

Fine Print

The District of Columbia is considered a state for the purposes of this question, so the total population under consideration is 51 states.

name: Will the recent resurgence of polio in Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia result in increased polio eradication efforts by December 31, 2014?
question_text:
Every day, new polio infections are identified throughout the world. Polio outbreaks have remerged in severalcountries during the past few months, including in Syria and Somalia.Polio eradication efforts have been hampered by scientific and health challenges, political challenges, and security challenges.?The?only pathogen to be effectively eradicated?is smallpox; polio virus?has different characteristics than smallpox virus.??Efforts in Nigeria have faced significant political difficulties, including?rejection of Western-made polio vaccine.?Polio vaccine workers continue to be killed in Pakistan.?Despite these challenges, foundations and charitable organizations continue to support polio eradication efforts.?In April 2013, 80 countries launched the Scientific Declaration on Polio Eradication.

Resolution Criteria

The global community must work together to provide a safe environment in which polio immunization workers can work, affordable vaccines to low income countries, and vaccines developed and/or sent from non-Western countries.

Resolution Sources

Promed mail: http://www.promedmail.org/MMWR: http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/

Fine Print

As there is no cure for polio, polio eradication efforts are defined as anything related to the prevention of the disease; namely the?polio vaccine/immunization.?

This question will resolve to be true if eradication efforts (e.g., vaccine/immunization) have increased in 2014 from the previous year as reported by the Global Polio Eradication Initiative, the World Health Organization, and/or the Centers for Disease Control.

Useful Information and Links

News article on reemergence of polio: http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/on-faith/polio-resurfacing-in-muslim-majority-countries/2013/...
Global Polio Eradication Initiative website: http://www.polioeradication.org/Scientific Declaration on Polio Eradication accessible at: http://vaccines.emory.edu/poliodeclaration/CDC's Polio Eradication Efforts: www.cdc.gov/polio/updates/

Related Organizations or Individuals

Global Polio Eradication Initiative

keywords: Stem cells, stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency, STAP, retraction
name: Will Nature retract one or more of the January 2014 papers by H. Obokata et al. describing stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency (STAP)?
question_text:
In January 2014, a group of researchers led by Haruko?Obokata announced their success using an acid bath to turn body cells into stem cells describing the technique as ?stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency.? This method surprised many with its ease.

Prior to 2006, it was thought that body cells (also known as differentiated somatic cells) could not be turned back into the pluripotent stem cells from which they originated. In 2006, Dr. Shinya Yamanaka led a group that discovered that differentiated somatic cells could be reprogrammed into a pluripotent stem cell by changing the transcription factors. This was a fundamental discovery; however, the process produced very low yields of stem cells. In addition, the changing of transcription factors tended to generate tumors. These issues, as well as the complexity required to generate stem cells, have spurred many scientists to explore different methods to induce pluripotency.

Both of Dr. Obokata?s papers claim to have generated pluripotent stem cells through surprisingly simple methods of exposing somatic cells to stressful conditions such as acid baths, toxin exposure, or physical stress. These papers have been met with wide spread skepticism and many scientists are attempting to recreate the experiments.? The results of the papers have been called into question and Dr. Obokata?s home institution and the publishing journal, Nature, are investigating the charges. Recently, one author of the paper has called for its retraction.

Sources and Links
  • Study Says New Method Could Be a Quicker Source of Stem Cells http://nyti.ms/1a1LU9A
  • One Author of a Startling Stem Cell Study Calls for Its Retraction http://nyti.ms/1dJwAOg
  • Call for acid-bath stem-cell paper to be retracted http://blogs.nature.com/news/2014/03/call-for-acid-bath-stem-cell-paper-to-be-retracted.html
  • Acid bath offers easy path to stem cells? http://www.nature.com/news/acid-bath-offers-easy-path-to-stem-cells-1.14600
  • Stimulus-triggered fate conversion of somatic cells into pluripotency? http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v505/n7485/full/nature12968.html
  • Bidirectional developmental potential in reprogrammed cells with acquired pluripotency? http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v505/n7485/full/nature12969.html
  • Knoepfler Lab Stem Cell Blog http://www.ipscell.com/stap-new-data/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The journal Nature will issue the retraction notice if it occurs.

Fine Print

Confirm as announced by the group and published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters Web of Science.

keywords: Antibiotics, Biotech, FDA, GAIN Act, QIDP, chemistry
name: How many QIDP designated drugs will the FDA approve by the end of 2014?
question_text:
The June 2014 Issue of C&EN discussed the antibiotic drug industry and the regulatory efforts to increase awareness and production.? The World Health Organization (WHO) published a report describing what could be a post-antibiotic era.? This would mean that minor cuts and scratches could become life threatening and joint and tissue implants could be at risk of being affected.? Three suggestions have been presented to revive the antibiotic industry:? "clear and reasonable expectations from regulatory authorities on the data needed to approve an antibiotic, better approaches by researchers to finding new treatments for bacterial infections, and a willingness by the public to value new antibiotics in a way that rewards innovation."

In July 2012, Congress passed a bill requiring the FDA to create incentives for antibiotic research and production which resulted in the Generating Antibiotic Incentives Now (GAIN) Act.? This allows companies to conduct smaller trials for approval, and in some cases allows studies of different types of infections to be combined.? Additionally it allows for antibacterials addressing serious or life threatening infections known as qualified infectious disease products (QIDP's), for expedited and priority review, and once approved have five years of market exclusivity.? By June 2014, the FDA has granted 46 QIDP designations and has approved two QIDP designated drugs:? Dalvance on May 23, 2014 and Sivextro on June 20, 2014.? Currently, there are a number of QIDP designated drugs under FDA review and in Phase III trials (see infographic on C&EN article).? This question asks how many will be approved by the end of 2014?

Relevant Links:
  • A Bacterial Battle [C&EN]
  • FDA Adds Three New Pathogens to GAIN Qualifying List, But Impact Remains Unclear [RAPS]
  • Antibiotics Unrest [BioCentury]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the total number of QIDP designated drugs that the FDA approves by December 31, 2014.? The drugs that the FDA approves for each month can be found at the Drugs@FDA Database, under 'Drug Approval Reports by Month' and under the 'Original New Drug Approvals (NDAs and BLAs).'? The possible QIDP designated drugs are found for the drugs labeled with a 'P' or priority review drug under the 'Review Classification' tab.? The drugs labeled with a 'P' would have to verified if they were indeed QIDP designated by FDA press releases or news sources.? For example, for June 2014, Tedizolid Phosphate is listed with a 'P' and its press release confirms that it is QIDP designated.? Alternatively, Atazanavir is listed with a 'P' also but the press release indicates it is not QIDP designated.? The FDA Press Release page can be found here.

Fine Print

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. ?Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. For more information on how betting works for this type of question, please refer to the following tutorial:http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/

Note that the FDA may not provide a press release for each drug approved (although it is assumed they will). In that case other news sources may be used to verify the drug's classification. It is also assumed that the FDA will indicate if a drug is QIDP designated in the press release.

keywords: Flu, region 2, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 2 (NJ, NY, PR, VI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 2' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January. The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 2 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 2 is comprised of New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.


The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 2 is 2.3%.

?In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will a candidate vaccination for the Chikungunya virus infection successfully complete Phase II trials by  the end of 2015?
question_text:
A widespread outbreak of the chikungunya virus has beenreported in the Caribbean region where a string of at least 15 islands have beenaffected since December 2013. Scientists fear that the virus is set to spread from Southern UnitedStates to Argentina through mosquitoes. In 2004, the virus infection affectedmillions in East Africa and the Asia Pacific region. The virus is said tospread rapidly in dense cities which can make millions of people sick with rashes,fever, and agonizing, sometimes lasting, pain in fingers, wrists, elbows, toes,ankles, and knees. Until now more than 4000 cases have been confirmed in thelab. However, suspected cases of people with acute fever and severe,unexplained joint pains exceeded 45,000 early in May 2014.

Virologists worry that there are no drugs for chikungunya.However, several vaccine candidates are in various stages of development - theCaribbean outbreak has revived industry attention. The University of TexasMedical Branch in Galveston has designed a live vaccine, based on a weakenedversion of the chikungunya virus, licensed to Japanese pharma company Takeda. Testingon animal studies suggests that one shot of the vaccine will providelong-lasting protection. Takeda is reportedly working to begin human studiesand testing. ?However, expensivepreclinical studies to make sure the vaccine virus won't revert to a more pathogenicform is needed first. Another vaccine candidate, developed at the VaccineResearch Center of the National Institutes of Health and licensed to Merck,consists of virus-like particles?empty protein shells resembling the virus thattrigger immunity. It has already passed Phase 1 of safety studies in humans in April 2014. However,testing a vaccine?s ability to prevent chikungunya in the real world ischallenging. The investigators are moving to evaluate the antibody response to the vaccine four weeks after the last vaccination.
For more information, see:????????????????????????????????????????????????
Crippling Virus Setto Conquer Western Hemisphere: http://www.sciencemag.org/content/344/6185/678.full
Chikungunya in the Carribean: http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/chikungunya-saint-martin
CDC on Chikungunya: http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/
Clinical Trials for Chikungunya: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/record/NCT01489358?term=Chikungunya&rank=1

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

CDC update: http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/
WHO news: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/en/
Clinical Trials update on vaccinations: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov?
A pharmaceutical company or researchers who develop the vaccine will publish the information in the science or popular press.



Fine Print

A vaccine candidate will successfully complete Phase II trials when the drug or treatment is found effective when given to a larger group of people to further evaluate its safety for the next phase.

keywords: black holes, quasars, super massive black holes
name: When will researchers find a black hole larger than S5 0014+81?
question_text:
Black holes are mathematically defined regions of spacetime exhibiting such strong gravitational pull that no particle or electromagnetic radiation can escape their radii. The boundary of the region from which no escape is possible is called the event horizon. Black holes cannot be directly observed or measured, but their existence and mass can be inferred from their impact on the space around them. Scientific consensus accepts that black holes exist in nature.

It is believed that very large black holes, called super massive black holes (SMBHs), are located at the centers of many galaxies, and that these black holes power highly luminous quasars. The largest SMBH currently on record is the black hole theorized to power the S5 0014+81 quasar, whose mass has been estimated at 40 billion solar masses.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2015/02/25/astronomers-find-a-shockingly-a...
  • http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v518/n7540/full/nature14241.html
  • http://www.researchgate.net/publication/234198517_The_most_luminous_quasar_-_S5_001481


Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/1/2020

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in the press.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Black hole mass cannot be directly measured, but is estimated by astronomers from what the observe about the behavior of space in the vicinity of suspected black holes. When they estimate the mass of a specific black hole it may come with a range. For the purposes of this question, the upper bound of any newly estimated range that is above 40 billion solar masses will be considered larger than S5 0014+81.

name: When will an exascale supercomputer appear on the Top 500 list?
question_text:
As of November 2014 (http://www.top500.org/lists/2014/11/),?the fastest publicly known supercomputer in the world is the Chinese Tianhe-2, with a 34 petaFLOPS (PFLOPS)?maximum performance. The fastest US supercomputers are the Cray Titan (17.6 PFLOPS) and IBM Sequoia (17.2 PFLOPS). Recently the US Department of Energy has contracted IBM to build?two new supercomputers, named Sierra and Summit, to exceed 100 PFLOPS performance (http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/45387.wss).

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/20/2022

Resolution Source

http://www.top500.org

Fine Print

1 exaFLOPS = 1000 petaFLOPS = 1 quintillion floating point operations per secondFor the purpose of this question, the maximum performance score Rmax attained on the LINPACK test (or its official Top500 successor) will be used rather than the theoretical peak performance Rpeak.

If the top500 schedule changes we will?resolve by the closest month: Jun would include lists published between Mar-Aug and Nov would include lists published between?Sep-Feb.

name: Will the number of Facebook users worldwide decline in 2014?
question_text:
Two doctoral candidates in mechanical and aerospace engineering at Princeton University claimed that Facebook would behave like an infectious disease, experiencing a spike before its decline. They applied a modified epidemiological model to predict that the social network will lose 80% of its users by 2017.

The number of Facebook users increased by 22% from 2012 to 2013. At the end of 2013, there were 1.3 billion monthly active Facebook users.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Georgia?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Georgia, 52.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +3.9% from 2011 (48.4%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 51.4%, the "51.4%-54.8%" range will be deemed correct.

name: When will the Australian contracted search for MH 370 begin?
question_text:
Between Malaysia and Australia, it was agreed upon that Australia will lead the search for MH 370. The inclusion of this agreement makes Australia responsible for the contracting of the commercial services that take on the search efforts.?The Australian Government via ATSB?published?a Request for Tender for provision for services relating to the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on June 4, 2014.?

name: What share of U.S. corn crops will the USDA report as consisting of stacked genetically modified corn at the end of July 2014?
question_text:
Genetically modifiedinsect-resistant crops containing a gene from the soil bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) have been growncommercially in the U.S. since 1996. These bacteria produce a protein that istoxic to specific insects, protecting the modified plants over their entirelifecycle. Crops have also been genetically modified to be herbicide-tolerant(HT). These crops were developed to survive application of specific herbicides targetedat weeds, providing farmers with a broader variety of options for weed control.

In recentyears more and more genetically modified crops have included both Bt and HT modifications.These so-called "stacked" varieties are available for cotton andcorn. Plantings of stacked corn made up 71 percent of all U.S. corn acres in2013, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA). TheUSDA will update these share statistics next on 7/31/2014.

For morebackground, see:

  • USDA?Adoption of Genetically Engineered Crops Data Set
  • USDA?Adoption of Genetically Engineered Crops Trends
  • Telegraph article: GM crops given green light by government?


Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The USDAwill update statistics on the share of U.S. genetically modified crops on7/31/2014. These data will be available at:?http://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/adoption-of-genetically-engineered-crops-in-the-us.aspx#.U2fHilfRayQ

name: When will the first externally introduced automobile computer virus be reported?
question_text:
Software controlled integrated circuits have been embedded into automobiles for many years, but more recently select computerized components within cars have been installed with external communication capability accomplished via Internet protocol suite. The advent of such "internet enabled" cars has raised concerns that consumer driven cars could be infected with computer viruses or malware introduced to car systems via external internet communications. Such an externally introduced automotive computer virus could compromise vehicle operations, up to and including causing cars to crash.

For more information, see:

  • www.autosec.org/pubs/cars-usenixsec2011.pdf
  • http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/20/us-autos-hackers-idUSBRE87J03X20120820
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/adriankingsleyhughes/2012/08/21/researchers-automobile-computer-viruses-...
  • http://www.wired.com/2010/03/hacker-bricks-cars/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

The infection of a consumer automobile with an externally originating computer virus will be reported by the popular press.

This question will resolve when any such infection is mentioned, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.?

Fine Print

This question asks about the introduction of a virus to a consumer automobile from an external source. It excludes instances of hacking into systems designed to provide remote control of cars.

name: Will Manhattan's municipal parking system launch near field communication (NFC) enabled pay-by-phone parking by June 30, 2015?
question_text:
In April?2013, the New York City Department of Transportation announced the start of?pilot programs in the Bronx?allowing motorists to pay for parking?a using smartphone app, and to view real-time curbside parking availability. Motorists who participate in the PayByPhone pilot can simply scan a QR code or use near field communication at Muni-Meters in the pilot area to load the PayByPhone app and pay for parking.

Following the success of the early pilot programs, New York City mayor Bloomberg said in late 2013 that the?search had begun for a company to offer the pay-by-phone service to the city's 14,000 parking meters.

  • Mayor Bloomberg And Transportation Commissioner Sadik-khan Announce New Pilot Program To Pay Parking Meters Remotely And Launch Real-time Parking Availability Map:?http://www1.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/129-13/mayor-bloomberg-transportation-commissioner-sadi...
  • Pay-By-Phone Parking Headed To?NYC:?http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/12/27/pay-by-phone-parking-headed-to-nyc/
  • Mayor Bloomberg Announces the Launch of PayByPhone in New York City:?https://paybyphone.com/nyc-launch/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2015

Resolution Source

Question?can be resolved by consulting the New York City Department of Transportation:
http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/motorist/motorist.shtml

The launch of pay by phone parking is also likely to be covered in major New York press, such as the New York Times www.nytimes.com

Fine Print

The pay-by-phone parking service must have near-field-communication (NFC) payment system enabled. Private parking systems are excluded from consideration. Manhattan refers to Manhattan, New York.

name: Will researchers develop a synthetic vaccine for polio by July 1st, 2016?
question_text:
Vaccine-derived polioviruses (VDPVs) are rare strains of poliovirus that have genetically mutated from the strain used in the oral polio vaccine. The oral vaccine contains a live, attenuated (weakened) vaccine virus. When someone is vaccinated, the weakened vaccine virus replicates in the intestine and enters into the bloodstream, triggering the protective immune response.? Those vaccinated will excrete the vaccine virus for a period of six to eight weeks. The excreted vaccine virus may mutate genetically from its original form. This new mutation is called a vaccine-derived poliovirus. Unvaccinated people can potentially be infected with polio from these waste products.

One way to prevent this transmission from recently vaccinated person to unvaccinated people is to use a synthetic polio vaccine.?This work is built on researchers' success with a synthetic vaccine for foot and mouth disease. Researchers have reported that they ?have assembled the components of the new polio vaccine, which is awaiting effectiveness studies.?

For more information:

  • Synthetic vaccine http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_vaccine
  • Just one poliovirus left to go?? http://www.sciencemag.org/content/346/6211/795.full?
  • Polio Eradication http://www.polioeradication.org/
  • Vaccine-derived polioviruses?http://www.polioeradication.org/Polioandprevention/Thevirus/Vaccinederivedpolioviruses.aspx



Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2016

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in a company official press release.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

A synthetic vaccine consists of antigens that have been produced synthetically. These antigens (generally polypeptides and carbohydrates found in or on the viral capsid) cannot infect humans, but still trigger the immune system to produce antibodies that protect the body from the live virus.

name: On November 2017, what will be the Top 500 performance share by vendor?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances?of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500, and you think IBM?s machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust IBM?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

keywords: prime numbers, Mersenne primes, public-key encryption
name: Will a new Mersenne prime be discovered by March 31, 2015?
question_text:
A Mersenne prime is a prime number of the form 2^n-1 (^ indicates to the power of). Primes of this format are named after the French monk Marin Mersenne who studied them in the early 17th century. All Mersenne primes found since 1997 have been discovered by the ?Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search? (GIMPS), a distributed computing project operated via the Internet. The most recent (and thus largest) Mersenne prime discovered is 2^57,885,161 ? 1, discovered on 25 January 2013.

Prime numbers play a central role in public-key cryptography, and are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.mersenne.org/
  • www.newscientist.com/article/dn23138-new-17milliondigit-monster-is-largest-known-prime.html
  • http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2013/06/online_credit_card_security_the_rsa...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The discovery of a new Mersenne prime will be reported on the GIMPS website: http://www.mersenne.org/primes/

Fine Print

The new Mersenne prime must be announced between November 26, 2014 and March 31, 2015.

name: When will a vaccine for the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus enter Phase 1 trials?
question_text:
• Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by a coronavirus called MERS-CoV. Most people who have been confirmed to have MERS-CoV infection developed severe acute respiratory illness. They had fever, cough, and shortness of breath. About half of these people died.?
  • Since April 2012, 254 laboratory?confirmed cases of human infection with MERS?CoV have been reported? to WHO, including? 93 deaths .? As of April 24, 2014, reporting countries in the Middle East include Jordan, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar,? Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA) and the United Arab Emirates (UAE ); in Europe: France,? Germany, Greece, Italy and the United Kingdom (UK); in North Africa: Tunisia; and in Asia:? Malaysia and the Philippines.
  • On April 30, 2014, the University of Maryland and Novavax announced their development of an investigational vaccine candidate, which neutralized antibodies in mice.
  • The vaccine candidates were made using Novavax's recombinant nanoparticle vaccine technology and based on the major surface spike (S) protein, the surface protein responsible for attaching the virus to cells. Novavax previously demonstrated that spike protein nanoparticles could protect animals against lethal live challenge using the SARS-CoV virus.
?? ?
?Links and sources
  • C. M. Coleman et al. Purified coronavirus Spike protein nanoparticles induce coronavirus neutralizing antibodies in mice. Vaccine. In press, April 13, 2014.
  • New experimental vaccine produces immune response against MERS virus. http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2014-04/uoms-nev043014.php

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

Phase 1 trials as listed on http://www.clinicaltrials.gov

Fine Print

Phase 1 trials as listed on http://www.clinicaltrials.gov

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Oklahoma?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Oklahoma, 55.1% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +5.3% from 2011 (49.8%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 54.2%, the "54.2%-57.6%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Flu, Region 7, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 7 (IA, KS, MO, NE)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 7' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 7 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS region 7 is the highest. Region 7 is comprised of Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, and Nebraska.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: How many unclassified languages will the Ethnologue language catalog report in its 18th edition?
question_text:
There are currently over 7,000 languages spoken in the world, though that estimate varies by source and how languages are counted. Ethnologue: Languages of the World is a comprehensive reference work cataloging all of the world?s known living languages. Compilation of Ethnologue data is an active research project involving hundreds of linguists and other researchers around the world. It is widely regarded to be the most comprehensive source of information on language use and prevalence.

Virtually all languages in the world are related to other languages within language families, groups of languages that are themselves related to other language families. However, there is a small number of languages that linguists have been unable to definitively associate with any other known languages. When scholarly consensus emerges that an unclassified language is in fact not related to any other language, it becomes knows as a language isolate. Language isolates are rare -- the only one known to exist in Europe, for example, is Basque.

In the most recent edition (17th) of Ethnologue, 64 languages are identified as unclassified. As scholarly work continues with many of these languages, it is possible that some may be found to have links with other languages, or ultimately be classified as language isolates. Either of these scenarios lowers the number of unclassified languages. Newly discovered unclassified languages are also possible, potentially adding to the number.

For more background, see:
  • http://www.ethnologue.com/subgroups/unclassified
  • http://www.ethnologue.com/statistics/
  • http://aboutworldlanguages.com/language-isolates
  • http://languagesindanger.eu/book-of-knowledge/list-of-languages/chontal/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

Language status data from Ethnologue?s 18th edition, due in early 2015, will be used to resolve this question, and will be reported here:? http://www.ethnologue.com/subgroups/unclassified

name: Will the Allegheny Front region, as defined by the NOAA, experience a white Christmas in 2013?
question_text:
The average snow depth in the Allegheny Front on December 25 for the past 10 years is 1.6 inches.? The question asks whether the average snow depth will exceed 1.5 inches on the same date in 2013.

Resolution Criteria

snowfall, low temperatures

Resolution Sources

National Snow Analyses

Fine Print

A "white Christmas" occurs when an average of more than 1.5 inches of snow are on the ground across the geographic area on December 25, 2013.? The National Snow Analyses by the U.S. National Weather Service and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration provide the average snow depth throughout the region on a daily basis.

Useful Links

http://www.nohrsc.noaa.gov/nsa/

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: Will GlaxoSmithKline's experimental Ebola vaccine enter Phase III clinical trials by March 31st, 2015?
question_text:
Phase I trial data was published on November 16th, 2014 for a study of an Ebola vaccine from GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), showing a positive immunological response against the Ebola virus. The vaccine?uses a type of chimpanzee cold virus, known as chimpanzee adenovirus type 3 (ChAd3), as a carrier to deliver genetic material from two strains of the Ebola virus ? the Sudan strain and the Zaire strain, which is responsible for the current Ebola outbreak in west Africa.?

GSK has been working with the NIH to accelerate development of both this bivalent version of the candidate vaccine and a monovalent version targeting only the Zaire strain in response to the current Ebola epidemic.

http://www.gsk.com/en-gb/media/press-releases/2014/gsk-statement-on-first-phase-1-trial-results-of-a...

http://www.gsk.com/en-gb/media/press-releases/2014/new-european-consortium-formed-to-help-further-ad...

keywords: gravitational waves, Bicep2, astrophyiscs, big bang, inflation theory, Nobel Prize
name: Will the scientists at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics who reported the discovery of gravitational waves be awarded a Nobel Prize in Physics for this work within the next 5 years?
question_text:
On 17 March 2014, astronomers at the Harvard?Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics announced that they had detected and produced "the first direct image of gravitational waves across the primordial sky" within the cosmic microwave background, providing strong evidence for inflation and the Big Bang. If confirmed, the observation will rank among the greatest scientific discoveries of the past 20 years.



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

The outcome will be resolved when the Nobel Foundation announces the prize winner(s) in mid October of each year. Report will be found at www.nobelprize.org

Fine Print

A Nobel Prize in Physics will be awarded to scientists from the Background Imaging of Cosmic Extragalactic Polarization 2 (BICEP2) collaboration group for their detection of gravitational waves in any year between 2014 and 2019.

name: Will there be an outbreak of Iridoviridae in the environment in SE Asia in 2014?
question_text:
The family Iridoviridae comprises of the genera Iridovirus, Chloriridovirus, Lymphocystivirus, Megalocytivirus, and Ranavirus. These viruses affect both freshwater and marine fish species and have the potential to cause significant disease in aquaculture and in the environment. Little is known about the pathogenesis of iridoviruses. The pathogenesis is, however, temperature dependent and iridoviruses are thus confined to poikilothermic hosts.

Resolution Sources

www.who.int

Fine Print

An outbreak is classified as such by the WHO:?http://www.who.int/topics/disease_outbreaks/en/
The United Nations maintains definitions of major geographic regions of the world. https://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm
Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar (Burma), Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Timor-Leste, and Vietnam are included in Southeast Asia. Of the parts of the world whose nation status is disputed, Admin is making the call that the Spratly Islands are in Southeast Asia (world politics permitting).

Useful Links

www.who.int

Related Organizations or Individuals

http://www.who.int/topics/disease_outbreaks/en/

name: Will there be at least one 2014 Fields Medal winner with US nationality?
question_text:
The Fields Medal, officially known as International Medal for Outstanding Discoveries in Mathematics, is a prize awarded to up to four young mathematicians under the age of 40. The medal is awarded every four years at the International Congress of Mathematics (ICM) and is often viewed as the greatest honor a mathematician can receive. The next Fields Medal will be awarded at ICM in Seoul in August 2014.

Based on nationality, the US has the largest number of Fields Medal winners (12), but it has not had any winners since 1998 (i.e. it had no winners in the last 3 awards in 2002, 2006, 2010).

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fields_Medal
http://www.icm2014.org/en/awards/awards


Accepting Forecasts Until:

8/12/2014

Resolution Source

The winners will be announced by the International Mathematical Union (IMU) during the International Congress of Mathematicians August 13-21 in Seoul, South Korea http://www.icm2014.org/en/awards/awards

Fine Print

Nationality of the winner will be determined based on individual nationality, not the location of organization with which the winner is affiliated.

name: Will a 3D printed car be available for public purchase before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
3D printed cars are widely expected to become available for public purchase at some point?during 2015. Currently, 3D printed cars are made up of plastic components and then outfitted with an electric car battery, a motor, suspension, and wheels. Each?car currently take about 44 hours to make. Several companies have been experimenting with making 3D cars, but one in particular, Local Motors, seems to be close to creating one for public purchase. Local Motor's 3D printed car was on site at the 2015 Detroit Auto Show and held a press conference claiming that their car was not just a "science experiment."?

For More Information:

  • http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/detroit-auto-show/2015/01/12/local-motors-show-print...
  • http://localmotors.com

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

Resolving criteria will be form major news networks and press releases from possible 3D printing companies, such as:
?http://localmotors.com

Fine Print

For the purpose of this question 'public purchase' refers to commercially available to the public from a manufacturer.

name: What percentage of the US female population aged 13-17 will be vaccinated against HPV by the end of 2014?
question_text:
• Human Papiloma Virus is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. More information can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spentto vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervicalcancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the Center for Disease Control in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who would have been targeted during the original vaccination campaign. 53.8% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012. More information can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/std/hpv/HPV-monitoring-plan-revised-June-2011.pdf.
  • Questions about vaccination of males began in 2010 and revealed significantly lower levels of vaccination in comparison to females. More information can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/who/teens/vaccination-coverage.html

Development of a new vaccine; Research establishing a connection between other conditions and HPV infection; Reports on prolonged immunity from HPV vaccination


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2015

Resolution Source

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Annual National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. These results can be found on the CDC's HPV data and statistics page and in the CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

The annual survey is typically released each July.

Fine Print

HPV stands for the human papiloma virus. Forecasts should be for the rates of vaccination with at least a single dose of one of the two available HPV vaccines. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%.The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the % vaccinated is 53.8%, the "53.8-54.7%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will more than a million preprint submissions be available on arXiv at the end of December 2014?
question_text:
ArXiv is an Open Archives Initiative (OAI) compliant online archive of electronic preprints in physics, mathematics, computer science,?quantitative biology, quantitative finance and statistics.?In many fields of mathematics and physics, almost all scientific papers are?self-archived?on?ArXiv. Begun on August 14, 1991, arXiv.org passed the half-million article milestone on October 3, 2008.?The article submission rate has been continuously?growing over recent years, and reached?more than 8,000 per month by late 2014. The total number of articles?available on?ArXiv stood at 994,833?on December 9, 2014.

  • arXiv:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ArXiv
  • arXiv monthly submission rates:?http://arxiv.org/stats/monthly_submissions

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

arXiv statistics are documented on its website in real time. The monthly submission rate since its inception is graphed here:?http://arxiv.org/stats/monthly_submissions

Fine Print

The number of articles available includes articles that were migrated to arXiv rather than being submitted directly, and excludes articles that have been deleted, as reported on the arXiv website.

name: Will a new candidate drug to treat fibromyalgia enter clinical trials in 2014?
question_text:
Fibromyalgia is a common syndrome in which a person has long-term, body-wide pain and tenderness in the joints, muscles, tendons, and other soft tissues. Fibromyalgia has also been linked to fatigue, sleep problems, headaches, depression, and anxiety. It is estimated to affect 2-4% of the population. Currently there are three FDA approved medications for fibromyalgia treatment: Lyrica(pregbalin), Cymbalta (duloxetine), and Savella (milnacipran).

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

http://clinicaltrials.gov/

name: Will the Battelle/R&D Magazine forecast for China?s total 2015 national research spending meet or exceed the country?s goal of  2.2% of GDP?
question_text:
China was once known as the world?s factory, devoting 1.98% of its gross domestic product to science and technology research in 2012. China's current Five Year Plan has fixed a macroeconomic goal of spending 2.2% of GDP on research by 2015, toward becoming an innovation-based economy by 2020. ? See?Key targets of China's 12th five-year plan

China has ramped-up its research and development (R&D) spending and recently?for the first time has overtaken Europe on this key measure of innovation, according to the latest estimates of research intensity by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

China tops Europe in R&D intensity
http://www.nature.com/news/china-tops-europe-in-rd-intensity-1.14476

China spending more than Europe on science and technology as GDP percentage, new figures reveal
http://www.scmp.com/news/china-insider/article/1410178/china-spending-more-europe-science-and-techno...

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

Projected?R&D expenditure as a percent of GDP?will be determined by?the annual?R&D Magazine/Battelle Global R&D Funding Forecast is published annually in early December. Check the magazine's URL at?http://www.rdmag.com/? or?Battelle.?

Fine Print

This question will be resolved by taking the PROJECTED R&D spending for 2015 as a % of GDP, which is reported yearly by R&D magazine. Because we are examining projected R&D spending, the data will be available in December 2014.Gross Domestic Product (GDP) refers to the total economy of a nation or region. It is the market value of all officially recognized final goods and services produced within a year.

name: Will researchers announce additional evidence that stone toolmaking co-evolved with language development?
question_text:
Oldowan tools represent the earliest known stone toolmaking of prehistory, which date from the Lower Paleolithic period, from 2.6 million years ago up until 1.7 million years ago. Oldowan toolmaking was complex and geographically widespread, suggesting it was a learned skill, but also remained relatively unchanged for a period of approximately 700,000 years, suggesting the social process for the transmission of this skill was inefficient, and thus did not include language.

A January 2015 paper in Nature Communications reports on an experiment conducted with 184 adult human subjects which examined how well rudimentary tool making skills are passed with and without the benefit of language. The authors show improved skill transmission when language is used, and propose that prehistoric tookmaking entered into a new phase of development (Acheulean toolmaking) as language co-evolved with toolmaking, enabling more rapid advances in technology. Specifically, the authors hypothesize that toolmaking led to a need for more effective knowledge transmission, and thus the co-evolution of language and toolmaking.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150113/ncomms7029/full/ncomms7029.html
  • http://arstechnica.com/science/2015/01/tool-making-may-have-made-language-genes-more-useful/
  • http://www.ai-journal.com/article/view/ai.1505/298


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

Publication in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Anything that researchers present in a peer-reviewed journal article (see section below on question resolution) as evidence that stone toolmaking co-evolved with language development will be considered as such.For example, in the paper referenced above, the authors state the following regarding the data to come from their experiment, "...later technologies would have reinforced the gene-culture co-evolutionary dynamic. Such a process could have lasted for millions of years (and may be ongoing), with more complex communication allowing the stable and rapid transmission of increasingly complex technologies, which in turn generate selection for even more complex communication and cognition, and so forth. Although this places little necessary constraint on when teaching and language may have evolved, our central contribution is to provide evidence that Oldowan tools, produced by hominins since at least 2.5?mya, were involved in this dynamic."

name: In 2014, will the Arctic sea ice minimum day occur after September 15th?
question_text:
Each year, the Arctic sea ice minimum marks the day?when the sea ice extent is at its lowest. The sea ice minimum occurs at the end of the summer melting season. The summer melt season usually begins in March and ends some time during September. The sea ice minimum has been occurring later in recent years because of a longer melting season. The Arctic sea ice minimum day was on September 13th 2013, after an unusually cool summer in the northernmost latitudes. In 2012, the Arctic ice reached to its minimum extent on September 16th.

http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=82094

Accepting Forecasts Until:

9/15/2014

Resolution Source

NASA Earth Observatory: http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=82094

Fine Print

The Arctic sea ice minimum marks the day, each year, when the sea ice extent is at its lowest. Sea ice extent is a measurement of the area of ocean where there is at least some sea ice. Usually, scientists define a threshold of minimum concentration to mark the ice edge; the most common cutoff is at 15 percent.

keywords: quasicrystal, Shechtmanite, aperiodic structure, quasiperiodical structure, chemistry
name: Will a lab-grown single-element quasicrystal be reported in a scientific journal before the end of 2020?
question_text:
Quasicrystal structures were first discovered by Dr. Dan Shechtman in 1984. Since then quasicrystals have been found in alloys, polymers and nanoparticle systems. However, a quasicrystal composed of a single element has not yet been found. Recently, a research group in Japan has successfully fabricated a three-dimensional structure of a quasicrystal composed of a single element. The team was able to grow a single-element quasicrystal structure consisting of multiple atomic layers. The success is a significant step forward toward achieving single-element quasicrystals.

Resolution Sources

Nature, Science, IEEE Spectrum, MIT Technology Review

Fine Print

Quasicrystals are?substances with a structure that is ordered but not periodic. They were discovered in 1984 by Dr. Dan Shechtman (who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2011).

Useful Information and Links

  • Researcher's Fabricate 3D Structure Single-Elememt of Quasicrystal
  • Templated 3D Growth of Quasicrystalline Lead
  • Quasicrystal

Related Organizations or Individuals

International Union of Crystallography

name: Will the global gender gap in the number of internet users decline in 2014?
question_text:
The InternationalTelecommunication Union (ITU) is the United Nations specialized agency forinformation and communication technologies. It is responsible for allocatingglobal radio spectrum and satellite orbits, developing technical standards thatensure global network interoperability, and advocates for bringingtelecommunications connectivity to all the world?s people, regardless of wherethey live or the resources at their disposal.

As part ofits mission the ITU maintains statistics on a range of topics related to informationand communication technology (ICT). A summary of these statistics are presentedin the organization?s annual ICT Facts and Figures report, released during thefirst quarter of each calendar year for the preceding year. The report foryearend 2014 is expected to be publicly published early in 2015.

The 2013report was released on February 27, 2014, and reports 1.463 billion maleinternet users and only 1.301 female users.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/default.aspx
  • http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/facts/default.aspx

The ITU willreport global total, male, and female internet users for 2014 in its 2014 ICTFacts and Figures report, available here when published:? http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/facts/default.aspx



Fine Print

Internet users include individuals who have used the Internet from any location in the last three months (three months is the suggested reference period, but country practices may vary).

name: Will the number of U.S. counties with infestations of Hemlock Woolly Adelgids, an invasive insect species, decrease in 2014 from the previous year?
question_text:
The severe winter of 2013-2014 has been very harsh for several invasive insect species found in the United States, including the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid, originally from Japan. This insect feeds on the sap of Hemlock trees, often killing the tree. Since its introduction in the 1950's in Virginia, the adelgid has spread to 11 eastern states and now causes over $70 million in losses to the U.S. government annually.

While it has no natural predators in the U.S., it is vulnerable to extreme cold. Researchers are estimating the recent winter has killed off over 80 percent of adelgids across the East Coast and speculate the species may died out entirely in some areas.

  • The Atlantic Cities - Here's a reason not to hate the Polar Vortex
  • Wikipedia - Hemlock Woolly Adelgid
  • U.S. Forest Service - Hemlock Woolly Adelgid

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2015

Resolution Source

Hemlock Woolly Adelgid infestations by county are determined by the US Forest Service in its Forest Health Protection Program

http://na.fs.fed.us/fhp/hwa/maps/distribution.shtm

name: Will Google or Facebook first debut internet connectivity to consumers using solar-powered drones?
question_text:
The future growth of technology companies like Facebook andGoogle depends on getting the next 5 billion people, who are disconnected fromany form of internet connectivity, in the developing world online. ?Once these new users are plugged into theInternet, Facebook and Google are confident that they will benefit extensivelyfrom new users who will want to connect with friends around the world, sharephotos, use maps, conduct information searches and so on.
Google, with its Project Loon, has used a network ofballoons to provide internet connectivity in New Zealand?s South Island. ProjectLoon?s goal for 2014 is to establish a ring of uninterrupted connectivityaround the 40th southern parallel, so that pilot testers at this latitude canreceive continuous service via balloon-powered Internet. ?Buying Titan Aerospace?s solar powered dronesthat can stay at upwards of 60,000 feet for almost 5 years, will help powerProject Loon even further as these high-altitude drones will behave as wirelessrepeaters.? Google hopes to beam affordableInternet connectivity across the skies in currently unserved areas.
On the other hand, Facebook, bought UK based Ascenta fortheir high-altitude, solar-powered drones that can also fly up high for longperiods of time. Facebook also set up a coalition called ?Connectivity Lab? toprovide affordable Internet access around the world using drones, satellites,and lasers.
For more information:
Google drones: http://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/04/14/fight-for-internet-drones-heats-up-as-google-buys-drone-company-originally-sought-by-facebook/
Google drones: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/20/facebook-google-buying-into-drones-profit-motive

Google: http://www.google.com/loon/? http://googlepress.blogspot.com/http://www.google.com/press/

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the U.S. Virgin Islands?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the U.S. Virgin Islands, 28.7% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +2.3% from 2011 (26.4%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 27.8%, the "27.8%-31.2%" range will be deemed correct.

name: When will the U.S. Army's special armed forces debut the TALOS suits (also called Iron Man suits) on the battleground?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well equipped as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

Analysts and experts forecast that the suit maybe ready sometime within 2016-2018.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/

http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/11/19/talos-iron-man-suit_n_4300576.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media that the TALOS suits are being or have been deployed on the ground in a combat zone.

Fine Print

'Debut on the battleground' is defined as deployment to a combat zone.

Its?investment jumped to?$81.2B in 2014, accounting for?more than 30% of?total?new investments in renewable energy.?However, the recent reports of a slow down in China's economic growth, combined with?the world decline in oil prices, could have an impact on its?investment in renewable energy.

For more information:
