name: Will Google announce development of an Android In-Car System at or before the Google I/O 2014 Conference?
question_text:
With the launch of Apple CarPlay at the WWDC 2014 Conference, this leads to the question if Google will also develop an Android in-car rival to Apple.? CarPlay is an in-car system that integrates iPhone functions and apps such as making calls, getting directions, listening to music, etc. to the car's digital entertainment system.? It allows the user to make these commands through speak commands to Siri, touchscreen, or knobs/controls.? It is scheduled to be available by select car manufacturers in 2014.?

There are rumors that Google is developing an in-car system for Android named KITT that would allow Android phones to connect to their car's digital entertainment system to allow voice commands such as searching Google, messaging, etc. ??

Relevant Links:
  • Google I/O 2014:? What to Expect Including Android, Nexus, Glass, and More
  • Google IO 2014: Ten Things We Expect
  • Apple CarPlay:? Everything You Need to Know About iOS in the Car

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/26/2014

Resolution Source

This question will resolve true if Google announces development of an Android In-Car System at or before the 2014 Google I/O Conference which takes place during June 25-26, 2014.? The conference sessions will also be live streamed at the Google I/O page.? This may also be confirmed by major news outlets.

Fine Print

In general, an 'Android In-Car System' is defined to be a software and/or hardware system that integrates Android functions such as making calls, messaging, getting directions, etc. by voice command to the car's digital system, or through a touchscreen or knobs/controls (if a hardware system is released). It is rumored to be called KITT. It would be similar to Apple CarPlay however it may or may not be a dashboard addition and software combination like the Apple CarPlay is (i.e it may just be a feature added to Android phones and not a dashboard installation in collaboration with car manufacturers. Note that the details of an Android In-Car System are not exactly known).'Announcement of development' is defined to be if Google gives news about developing an Android In-Car System, gives release dates for an Android In-Car System, or presents a prototype or production ready version.
short_name: Android Car System at Google I/O 2014

categories: Biology & Medicine,Business of Science,Chemistry,Computational Sciences,Engineered Technologies,Mathematics
keywords: memristors, nanoionics, nanoscale resistive switching, neural networks, artificial neural networks
name: When will a memristor-based computer chip that can mimic the human brain's computing capability be available in the marketplace?
question_text:
As flash memory is approaching fundamental scaling limits in the face of Big Data computing requirements, a team of researchers at the RMIT Functional Materials and Microsystems Research Group have built a novel nano-structure: a nanometer-thin stacked structure created using synthesized perovskite oxide material and providing scalable, ultra-fast, non-volatile and low energy 'memristive' performance. Memristors are the precursors to high-density nanoscale memories and the building blocks for neuromorphic computing ? mimicking the human brain where the memory element's behavior is dependent on its past actions. Project Leader Dr. Sharath Sriram, says, "The structure we developed could be used for a range of electronic applications -- from ultrafast memory devices that can be shrunk down to a few nanometers, to computer logic architectures that replicate the versatility and response time of a biological neural network. While more investigation needs to be done, our work advances the search for next generation memory technology can replicate the complex functions of human neural system -- bringing us one step closer to the bionic brain."

Another team of researchers at the Boise State University are working on an NSF funded project to create a computer chip that mimics the neural functions of the human brain using memristors. The researchers hope to create an artificial neural network using this computer chip design as soon as in the next year or two. The team's research builds on recent work from scientists who have derived mathematical algorithms to explain the electrical interaction between brain synapses and neurons.

http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/09/140929090352.htm
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adfm.201401278/full
http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/08/130814144705.htm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

Annoucement or press release by any company that has successfully created a computer chip that can process information identical to the human neural ability. Announcements by industry analysts in technology news media. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first. Administrators reserve the right to consult outside subject matter experts to determine whether the chip possesses?the capability to?learn, adapt and respond to its environment in a manner similar to the human brain.

Fine Print

'A memristor-based computer chip that can mimic the human brain's computing power' is defined as an integrated circuit design that can replicate the exact electrical interactions between the human brain synapses and neurons. In simple words, this bionic computer chip will have the ability to process information like the human brain that has the ability to learn, adapt and respond to its environment.
short_name: memristor IC chip mimicking human brain

name: Will a research team demonstrate the use of a topological insulator in non-volatile magnetic memory by January 1, 2018?
question_text:
• Magnetoresistive random-access memory (MRAM) stores memory through magnetic storage elements making it non-volatile unlike conventional random-access memory chip technologies that store data as an electric charge. However, a relatively large amount of power is needed to store a bit in traditional MRAM. Recent research has focused on spin transfer torque or spin transfer switching, which uses spin-aligned electrons and lowers the amount of current needed to write the cells.
  • In the search for magnetic memory that is low power and non-volatile, Mellnik et al. published experiments showing that ?charge current flowing in-plane in a thin film of the topological insulator bismuth selenide (Bi2Se3) at room temperature can indeed exert a strong spin-transfer torque on an adjacent ferromagnetic permalloy (Ni81Fe19) thin film, with a direction consistent with that expected from the topological surface state.? They hypothesize that the strength of the torque per unit charge current density in Bi2Se3 can enable ?very efficient electrical manipulation of magnetic materials at room temperature, for memory and logic applications.? This is currently theoretical and has not been experimentally shown.
Sources and Links
  • Magnetoresistive random-access memory
  • Spin-transfer torque
  • Magnetic storage
  • Topological insulator
  • Mellnik, A.R., et al., Spin-transfer torque generated by a topological insulator. Nature, 2014. 511(7510): p. 449-451.://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v511/n7510/full/nature13534.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Published results in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science, describing that the use of a topological insulator in non-volatile magnetic memory has been experimentally shown.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

Nonvolatile = devices that do not require the continuous application of power to retain information.Topological insulators are characterized by an insulating bulk and metallic surface or edge state protected by time-reversal symmetry. The magnetic memory must use topological insulators as room-temperature sources of spin-transfer torque.

name: Will a lab-confirmed case of MERS-CoV infection be reported in Pakistan by the end of 2014?
question_text:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by a coronavirus called MERS-CoV. ?This virus is spread through close contact, such as caring for or living with an infected person. So far, all?confirmed cases have been linked to countries in and near the Arabian Peninsula. The countries that have original confirmed cases are Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates (UAE), Qatar, Oman, Jordan, Kuwait, Yemen, Lebanon, and Iran. Thirteen other countries including the United States have reported travel-associated infection cases. Most recently, Turkish officials?notified WHO of a confirmed infection?of a citizen who worked in Saudi Arabia before he developed symptoms and traveled home for medical care.

keywords: DNA, sequencing, next-gen, encephilitis, bacterium, virus, fungus, parasite, autoimmune
name: Doctors saved the life of a boy suffering from encephalitis when a sequencing test turned up DNA of a lethal bacteria in his cerebrospinal fluid. What type of pathogen will this test discover next in a critically-ill patient suffering from encephalitis?
question_text:
Next-generation sequencing was recently?used to identify the cause of encephalitis in Joshua Osborn,?a teenage boy who had been critically ill in the intensive care unit for several weeks. ?A battery of tests had failed to reveal the cause, so?doctors asked Joshua's parents for permission?to run one more test using the experimental next-gen sequencing technology, hoping to find DNA from the pathogen causing his encephalitis. The test showed that?Joshua?s cerebrospinal fluid contained DNA from a potentially lethal type of bacteria called Leptospira, which can readily treated with penicillin. Within two weeks of initiating therapy, Joshua?had recovered and was discharged.?

Encephalitis could be a particularly fruitful field in which to exploit next-gen sequencing's?newly demonstrated ability. In a seven-year study, California Encephalitis Project investigators found that 63 percent of cases went undiagnosed. The problem, says Charles Chiu, MD, PhD, professor of laboratory medicine and infectious diseases at UCSF and a senior investigator in the study, is that ?the causes of encephalitis are broad in scope,? ranging from infectious agents, especially in immunosuppressed individuals, to non-infectious autoimmune disease and vasculitis.

For years, scientists have been sequencing DNA to identify pathogens. But until now, the process has been too cumbersome to yield useful information about an individual patient in a life-threatening emergency.To identify a pathogen, the researchers extract every scrap of DNA in a sample from a patient, which might be blood, cerebrospinal fluid or stool. Then they sift the genetic fragments for those belonging to pathogens.The technique already has proved valuable for investigating mysterious disease outbreaks, and a number of scientists have begun to hope it can be adapted to the diagnosis of individual patients? infections. Rather than test for a suspected pathogen, a doctor could simply run a DNA test that could identify the culprit no matter what it is ? virus, bacterium, fungus or parasite.

Useful Links:?
  • NYT article:?In a First, Test of DNA Finds Root of Illness
  • Next-Gen technology useful in?diagnosing encephalitis?
  • Dr. Chiu's paper on comparing DNA fragments with genetic sequences via the cloud

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

Reports from any a major news source or medical journal.?

Fine Print

The next pathogen identified, for the purposes of this question, must be different than Leptospira, which was found in the case of Joshua Osborne. The pathogen identified must be the suspected cause of encephalitis in the patient. The sequencing test must return results in time for doctors to begin treating the patient.

Parasite refers to an "obligate parasite" which is a?parasitic?organismthat cannot complete its life-cycle without exploiting a suitable host.

name: When will a single confirmed exploitation of the Heartbleed bug result in exposure of personally identifiable information (PII) of more than 1 million users?
question_text:
The Heartbleed vulnerability (http://blog.cloudflare.com/answering-the-critical-question-can-you-get-private-ssl-keys-using-heartb...) exposes server memory over a network connection. Remote attackers may collect other user's access credentials, session content, and server-side private?encryption keys.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

Open sources will be used to identify breaches where PII was exposed, the number of users affected, and the exploit used (Heartbleed). To answer this question in the affirmative, a breach must be legitimately attributed to the Heartbleed vulnerability, and exposure of 1 million or more unique users must be reported. The date for the event will be considered the date the breach is reported to have occurred if a single day, or if sustained, then the date the breach is reported to have exceeded 1 million users if known, or the date the breach started if not.

This question will be accepting forecasts until July 31, 2014?to account for delay in reporting of a breach.?If no reports of such a breach are known by July 31, 2014, the question will resolve as "Will not occur before July 1, 2014"

A breach may be attributed to Heartbleed if the data itself was collected via the Heartbleed vulnerability, or if the credentials used to gain access and/or expose the data were collected via the Heartbleed vulnerability.

Open sources will include mainstream media and other topic-specific sites, such as:
?? http://www.idtheftcenter.org/ITRC-Surveys-Studies/2014databreaches.html


Fine Print

A breach may be attributed to Heartbleed if the data itself was collected via the Heartbleed vulnerability, or if the credentials used to gain access and/or expose the data were collected via the Heartbleed vulnerability."Single confirmed exploitation" means an attack against a single target by one or more sources where the PII of 1 million or more users is exposed. The attack(s) may be sustained over days, weeks, or months; it is the total exposure from a single targeted organization that matters in this question. "Organization" here means a single legal or government entity with a common data store from which the data is exposed."Personally Identifying Information (PII)" is as defined in NIST 800-122 (http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-122/sp800-122.pdf, section 2.1): "PII is any information about an individual maintained by an [organization], including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual?s identity, such as name, social security number, date and place of birth, mother?s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information."

name: Which organization will be the first to observe a Population III star by December 31st, 2017?
question_text:
Population III, or metal-free, stars are a theoretical population of stars composed almost entirely of hydrogen and helium. These stars are hypothesized to have been the first stars following the Big Bang, when the only elements in the universe were hydrogen, helium and trace amounts of lithium and beryllium. Their fusion reactions to create heavier elements and supernova expulsion of those heavier elements would have allowed for the creation of more metal-heavy stars (like our sun) and planets found in the universe today.

Common theory holds that typical masses for Population III stars would be expected to be several hundred solar masses, which is more massive than the vast majority of stars observed in the universe today. These massive stars were thought have lifetimes far shorter than today?s stars, ending in a particular type of supernova, called a pair-instability supernova, that is associated with massive, metal-poor stars. In the last decade, several extremely bright, energetic supernovas have been observed and identified as possible pair-instability supernovas, with precursor stars that must have been several hundred solar masses and metal-poor, raising the possibility that Population III stars still exist in the universe today. These observed pair-instability supernovas were found in dwarf galaxies containing few elements heavier than hydrogen and helium ?conditions very similar to the early universe.

There are several organizations that could be the first to observe a Pop III star:
??? ?Sloan Digital Sky Survey
??? ?NASA and its Hubble Telescope, Fermi Gamma-Ray Telescope and planned James Webb Space Telescope
???? ?European Space Agency and its Gaia Telescope
??? ?Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey?
??? ?Cosmic Evolution Survey

The identification of more pair-instability supernovas; the identification on specific dwarf galaxies that could likely support Population III stars

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

The observation of a Population III star must be published in a journal indexed by Thomson Reuter's Web of Science.

Fine Print

The answer "none of the organizations listed here" also includes the possibility that no organization will observe such a?star by the resolution date.

name: Will lab experiments conducted with Josephson junctions prove the existence of axions by the end of 2015?
question_text:
A mathematical scientist from the University of Cambridge, Christian Beck, has proposed a possible way to test for the existence of axions - theoretical particles that might be the components of dark matter.? In his paper published in Physics Review Letters in December 2013, Beck suggests it might be possible to detect the existence of axions by using Josephson junctions.

http://arstechnica.com/science/2013/12/could-dark-matter-be-hiding-in-plain-sight-in-existing-experiments/

http://prl.aps.org/abstract/PRL/v111/i23/e231801

Resolution Sources

Physics Review Letter

Fine Print

Axion is a hypothetical elementary particles postulated by the Peccei-Quinn theory in 1977 to resolve the strong charge parity problem in quantum chromodynamics (QCD). If axions exist and have low mass within a specific range, they are of interest as a possible component of cold dark matter.

Josephson junction is a device made of a very thin insulating layer sandwiched between two slices of superconducting material, across which a current can flow indefinitely long with any voltage applied.

The question will resolve "true" if Josephson junctions are used to prove the existence of axions prior to the start of 2016.

Useful Information and Links

  • Possible Test for?Existence of Axions
  • Axion

Related Organizations or Individuals

American Physical Society

keywords: autonomous car, driverless car, self-driving car, robot car, autonomous vehicle
name: When will the first reported collision occur between an autonomous vehicle and a human driven vehicle on a public road?
question_text:
The number of cars worldwide exceeded 1.015 billion in 2010 and is projected to grow by 21% between 2011 and 2016. ?Earlier this year, the OECD's International Transport Forum forecast that the number of cars worldwide would reach 2.5 billion by 2050. ?World Health Organization?s Global Status Report on Road Safety 2013 showed that 1.24 million people were killed on the world?s roads in 2010, and another 20 to 50 million sustain nonfatal injuries as a result of road traffic crashes.

Research by the Eno Center for Transportation claims that even with adoption rates of just 10%, autonomous vehicles could help save $25 billion annually, while 50% of crashes and related injuries could be avoided. ?The same study showed that to eradicate all accidents in which human error is proven to be a factor, 90% of all vehicles would need to be autonomous.

Google plans to have driverless cars in the market by 2018. ?Nissan reports that it will make fully autonomous vehicles, which can drive without human intervention, available to the consumer by 2020. ?Intel predicts that autonomous car will be available in the market by 2022, Daimler predicts this will happen?by 2025, and the Insurance Information Institute predicts 2028-2032 is when this will happen. ?

Additional reading on autonomous vehicles is available by clicking?the following items.
  • When will a judiciary that calls corporations people call robots people?
  • Nissan?s Robot Car Passes Its License Test
  • Nevada Issues a Driver's License to Google's Self-Driving Car
  • Road cleared for self-driving cars in California
  • Green light by lawmakers for driverless cars
  • STUDY: Self-driving cars could prevent 90 percent of road traffic accidents

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2033

Resolution Source

This question will resolve based on reporting by?the popular press or in the technology press such as IEEE Spectrum,?MIT Technology Review magazine, and?WIRED magazine.?

Fine Print

An autonomous car, also known as a driverless car, self-driving car or robot car, is an autonomous vehicle capable of fulfilling the human transportation capabilities of a traditional car. As an autonomous vehicle, it is capable of sensing its environment and navigating without human input.The Nevada law defines an autonomous vehicle to be "a motor vehicle that uses artificial intelligence, sensors and global positioning system coordinates to drive itself without the active intervention of a human operator."A driverless car (sometimes called a self-driving car, an automated car or an autonomous vehicle) is a robotic vehicle that is designed to travel between destinations without a human operator. To qualify as fully autonomous, a vehicle must be able to navigate without human intervention to a predetermined destination over roads that have not been adapted for its use.Only collisions that result in injury to a driver or passenger of either vehicle will satisfy this question.

keywords: endgame tablebase, Nalimov Tablebase, Lomonosov Tablebase
name: Will the 9-man chess endgame tablebase be created before JAN 01 2030?
question_text:
• Chess endgame tablebases are computer databases of chess endings with precise and exhaustive calculations showing optimal play in any position with 100% certainty, under the constraint of the maximum number of pieces on the board.?
  • A game-theoretical value (win, loss or draw) is provided for each possible move in each possible position?along with the number of moves necessary to achieve the result with optimal play for both sides.?
  • The first endgame tablebases (4-man)?were built in the late 1980s. In 2005, 6-man endings were solved in Nalimov Tablebases widely used by chessplayers and chess engine programmers.?
  • Experts didn?t expect 7-man positions to be fully?cracked and?catalogued until after 2015, but Russian?programmers?Viktor Zakharov and Vladimir Makhnychev, associated with Convekta Ltd,?managed to solve the problem?in just 6 months culminating in August 2012,?using a new algorithm run on the Lomonosov supercomputer based in the Moscow State University.
  • The importance of the anticipated arrival of the 8-man tablebase lies not only in the impact on the understanding of chess endings and the game of chess in general, but also in how it will be an expression of computing power and algorithm efficiency.?
  • Chess News
  • World Chess Federation
  • Endgame Tablebase Wikipedia

Breakthroughs in supercomputing technology, development of more effective evaluation algorithms, events affecting the rate of Moore's Law

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2029

Resolution Source

Question?will be resolved based on a public announcement of the arrival?of the relevant tablebase. Potential media outlets include, but are not limited to:

  • Chess.com
  • World Chess Federation
  • Chessok
  • Chess News

keywords: Battery Electric Vehicles, CHAdeMO, quick charger
name: By the end of March 2015, will there be at least 1,500 CHAdeMO quick charging stations in Europe for battery electric vehicles?
question_text:
CHAdeMO is the trade name for a quick-charging method for battery electric vehicles. It delivers up to 62.5 kW of high-voltage direct current via a special electrical connector, and?is proposed as a global industry standard by an association of the same name. CHAdeMO is an abbreviation of "CHArge de MOve", equivalent to "charge for moving". The name is a pun?on O cha demo ikaga desukain Japanese, which translates to English as "How about some tea?", referring to the time it would take to charge a car. CHAdeMO can charge low-range electric cars in less than half an hour. According to the information posted on the official CHAdeMO Association's website, there were 1,327 CHAdeMO DC Quick chargers installed in Europe?as of November 26, 2014.
  • http://www.chademo.com/
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CHAdeMO

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

The number of?CHAdeMO stations is?reported on the CHAdeMO Association's website:http://www.chademo.com/

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of South Carolina?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of South Carolina, 41.9% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +3.2% from 2011 (38.7%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 41.0%, the "41.0%-44.4%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Solar energy, solar cells, photovoltaic energy, photovoltaic cells, multijunction solar cells, tandem solar cells, concentrated photovoltaics, chemistry
name: Which organization(s) will first exceed a confirmed conversion efficiency of 46% for multijunction, or tandem, solar cells?
question_text:
Multijunctionsolar cells, also known as tandem solar cells, are cells made up of two or morep-n junctions constructed on top one another within the same monolithic cellstructure. Multijunction cells are able to achieve high conversion ratesbecause each of the individual junctions is optimized for a different segmentof the spectrum of incident solar radiation. As of September of 2013, afour-junction cell design developed jointly by the Fraunhofer Institute forSolar Energy Systems ISE, Soitec, CEA-Leti and the Helmholtz Center Berlinachieved an efficiency of 44.7% at concentrated illumination of 297 suns.

Several major solar research labs around theworld are working on improving the efficiency of tandem solar cells, includingthose listed as possible answers for this question. When research laboratoriesachieve what they believe to be a new conversion record, their designs areindependently confirmed, or verified, by other research facilities before theycan be published as confirmed efficiency benchmarks. Overall conversionefficiencies for multijunction solar cells have been rising steadily from 16%in 1983 to the current 44.7% level. The devices themselves can be made up ofanywhere from two to six layered junctions. This question asks, if the 46%efficiency benchmark is reached by the end of 2014, what organization will haveachieved this first.



Resolution Criteria

Several research institutions around the world are working on multijunction solar cells and may produce a cell that achieves 46% efficiency by year-end 2014. The prominent institutions involved make up the answer choices for this question, and include:? Fraunhofer Institute for Solar Energy Systems ISE,?Soitec (acquired Concentrix Solar),?CEA-Leti,?The Helmholtz Center Berlin,?Sharp,?Spectrolab (part of Boeing), and?National Renewable Energy Laboratory?s National Center for Photovoltaics?


Resolution Sources

Newmultijunction conversion efficiency records are reported in a range oftechnical news outlets that cover the solar industry, including bothspecialized outlets covering solar technology, such as Solar Power World, andalso general science-related outlets, such as phys.org.



Fine Print

Amultijunction solar cell is a solar cell design in which two or more separatep-n junctions are constructed monolithically within the same device.

An efficiency of 46% or higher will be considered achieved once report of its verification (e.g. via press release) has been made by an independent institution.




Useful Information and Links

  • Multi-Junction Solar Cell to Break Efficiency Barrier?
  • Multijunction solar cell could exceed 50% efficiency goal
  • Sharp raises triple-junction non-concentrator solar cell efficiency record to 37.9%





Related Organizations or Individuals

When new efficiency records are achieved these are confirmed by a second, independent laboratory before being reported as confirmed new efficiency records.

name: Will the June 2014 TOP500 rankings announce that the performance of the #1 ranked supercomputer has exceeded 50 million Gflops/s?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014. The June 2013 TOP500 rankings revealed that the performance of the #1 ranked supercomputer was approximately 33 million Gflops/s.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved "yes" if during the June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference, the TOP500 announces that the performance of the #1 ranked supercomputer has exceeded 50 million Gflops/s. The outcome will be resolved based on the presented and published results of the TOP500 at the International Supercomputing Conference (http://www.top500.org/? or http://www.isc-events.com/isc14/). Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from TOP500 or International Supercomputing Conference. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

International Supercomputing Conference:
http://www.isc-events.com/isc14/

Useful Links

  • http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/?
  • http://www.isc-events.com/isc14/

Related Organizations or Individuals

TOP500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

name: When will a transactinide isotope with a half-life longer than 29 hours be discovered?
question_text:
Transactinide elements (chemical elements with atomic numbers above 103) are radioactive and thus far have only been obtained synthetically in laboratories. Transactinides and their isotopes are typically short lived, with half-lives of seconds or minutes, though an isotope of the element Dubnium (Db-268) has a half life of 29 hours - a record for a superheavy isotope. Much of the research on transactinide elements focuses on the discovery of the theorized 'island of stability' - a set of as-yet undiscovered isotopes of superheavy elements which are theorized to be more stable and have much longer half-lives than previously observed transuranium elements. The hypothesis is based upon the nuclear shell model, which implies that atomic nuclei are built up in "shells" in a manner similar to the structure of electron shells in atoms.

In May 2014, physicists created one of the heaviest elements yet, with an atomic number of 117, which has a half life of about 50 thousandths of a second. In the decay of element 177, two previously unknown isotopes were identified: Db-270 (dubnium) and Lr-266 (lawrencium). With half-lives of about one hour and about 11 hours, respectively, they are among the longest-lived superheavy isotopes known to date, perhaps science closer to the fabled the island of stability.

  • Scientific American - Superheavy Element 117 Points to Fabled "Island of Stability" on Periodic Table
  • Wikipedia - Island of Stability
  • Science Daily - Approaching the island of stability: Observation of superheavy element 117

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2021

Resolution Source

The discovery of a transactinide isotope with a half life longer than that of Db-268 would represent a major breakthrough in physics and would likely be covered in a variety of academic journals, such a Nature Physics, as well as by the mainstream media and science publications.

name: On June 2014, what will be the Top 500 performance share by geographic region?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void. ?
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by geographic region, and you think North America?s share will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust North America's chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: Will a dishonest Bitcoin mining pool successfully execute a 51% attack by December 31, 2015?
question_text:
Background:

Bitcoin is?a peer-to-peer cryptographic currency that issues new money and tracks transactions without a central authority.?
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Bitcoin

A 51% attack can be carried out against the Bitcoin network if a dishonest miner controls more than 50% of the network's computing power. The attacker would be able to: reverse transactions (double spend), prevent transactions from gaining confirmations, or prevent miners from mining valid blocks.
More information:?https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Weaknesses#Attacker_has_a_lot_of_computing_power

Relevant articles:
  • Bitcoin Miners Ditch Ghash.io Pool Over Fears of 51% Attack
  • Bitcoin's Fatal Flaw Was Nearly Exposed
  • 51% Attack


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Mining power will be resolved by consulting the pool data on blockchain.info:?https://blockchain.info/pools

Evidence for reversed transactions, confirmation prevention, or mining prevention will be resolved by consulting blockchain data: https://blockchain.info/

?If the attacks are not discernible on the blockchain, but Bitcoin core developers announce that such attacks have taken place, the question will be resolved on their word.

Fine Print

A successful 51% attack will be considered to have occurred if a miner attains more than 50% of the network power AND initiates any one of the following transaction manipulations: reverse transactions (double spend), prevent transactions from gaining confirmations, or prevent miners from mining valid blocks.

name: Paleontologists have recently unveiled the nearly complete skeleton of a large, predatory, semi-aquatic dinosaur. Will second new species of dinosaur with adaptations for aquatic environments be discovered before 2017?
question_text:
In an article recently published in the journal Science, paleontologists described a giant fossil skeleton, unearthed in the Sahara desert, of the largest-known carnivorous dinosaur, Spinosaurus. The 95-million-year-old remains confirm a long-held theory: that this is the first-known swimming dinosaur. Scientists say the beast had flat, paddle-like feet and nostrils on top of its crocodilian head that would allow it to submerge with ease.?

Lead author Nizar Ibrahim, a palaeontologist from the University of Chicago, said, "It is a really bizarre dinosaur - there's no real blueprint for it. It has a long neck, a long trunk, a long tail, a 7ft (2m) sail on its back and a snout like a crocodile.?And when we look at the body proportions, the animal was clearly not as agile on land as other dinosaurs were, so I think it spent a substantial amount of time in the water."

Spinosaurus had been an intriguing mystery for decades. The original fossil of the dinosaur, discovered in Egypt a century ago and moved to a German museum, was destroyed during World War II, leaving paleontologists with little more than a few drawings to ponder.

The new partial skeleton is of a Spinosaurus not fully grown, about 36 feet long. Its forelimbs were large and strong, with scythe-like claws; its hind legs were short, with paddle-shaped feet. Conical teeth in a crocodilian snout overlapped like a snare for trapping fish, and it had nostrils halfway up the skull so it could stick its snout into the water and still breathe.With its flat feet, Spinosaurus may have paddled like a duck. It had a long, flexible tail, which it may have used for propulsion.

?It?s like a cross between an aquatic bird and a crocodile,? said Paul C. Sereno, a paleontologist at the University of Chicago who was part of the research team.

Sources in links:

  • BBC News - Spinosaurus fossil: 'Giant swimming dinosaur' unearthed
  • New York Times - A lost-and-found nomad helps solve the mystery of a swimming dinosaur
  • Wikipedia - Spinosaurus

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Discoveries of new species of dinosaurs are published in academic publications, such as Science or Nature, and covered by scientific and mainstream media outlets.

Fine Print

This question is specifically asking if an article will be published describing the discovery of a separate new dinosaur species with adaptations for swimming or living in aquatic environments

keywords: WiGig, Wi-Fi, Multi-Gigabit Wi-Fi, IEEE 802.11, Internet of Things
name: Will WiGig technology be sold as a component of a commercially available smartphone in the U.S. by March 31, 2015?
question_text:
WiGig, also known as the IEEE 802.11ad protocol, is a wireless protocol that originally began development in May 2009 by the Wireless Gigabit Alliance which included over 40 companies such as Microsoft, Apple, Sony, Cisco, and Intel.?

The wireless protocol operates on a 60 gigahertz (GHz) frequency band, and can support data transmission rates up to a maximum of 7 gigabits per second (Gbit/s) - more than ten times faster than the highest 802.11n Wi-Fi rate.? Qualcomm estimated that over WiGig an upload of 1000 pictures can occur in just five seconds, and an entire feature-length movie can be downloaded in only three minutes ? However the signal range is extremely limited, with an approximate range of only about 30 feet.? Because of this severe limitation on range, WiGig is being touted as an extremely fast but short-range complement to traditional Wi-Fi.?In summary, WiGig can be seen as short-range extremely high-speed Wi-Fi, or as turbo-charged Bluetooth.

A number of companies are preparing for WiGig to be commercially available in smartphones and laptops in 2015 including Qualcomm, Intel, and Samsung. ?
Relevant Links:

  • A Speedy Wireless Protocol Is Coming to Many Gadgets [MIT Tech. Review]
  • WiGig: Wireless Connectivity at Incredible Speeds [Qualcomm]
  • WiGig is Great, But It Won't Replace Your Wi-Fi Network [PC World]
  • Samsung Claims a WiGig Breakthrough That Promises Multi-Gigabit Wireless Speeds [Gigaom]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved true if a smartphone with built-in WiGig capability is commercially available in the U.S. by March 31, 2015.? This will be verified by major technology news sources such as CNET, Engadget, etc. or the device manufacturer's page.?

Fine Print

'Commercially available' means the smartphone is available to the general public for purchase.

name: Will NASA confirm the presence of sea plankton living on the outside of the International Space Station?
question_text:
A news story quoting Russian official Vladimir Solovyov reported that Russian cosmonauts on the International Space Station? have allegedly discovered trace amounts of sea plankton and other microscopic organisms living on the outside of the station, exposed to the vacuum of space. The unconfirmed claims ? reported by the Russian news agency ITAR-TASS ? were the result of a long-term study done using specialized equipment by Russians on the station.

However, NASA has not confirmed the reports. "As far as we're concerned, we haven't heard any official reports from our Roscosmos colleagues that they've found sea plankton," NASA spokesman Dan Huot said. "The Russians did take samples from one of the windows on the Russian segment, and what they're actually looking for is residues that can build up on the visually sensitive elements, like windows, as well as just the hull of the ship itself that will build up whenever they do thruster firings for things like re-boosts. That's what they were taking samples for. I don't know where all the sea plankton talk is coming from."

  • Space.com - Sea Plankton on Space Station? Russian Official Claims It's So
  • Forbes - NASA, Russia Squabble Over International Space Station Sea Plankton Claim

Accepting Forecasts Until:

10/01/2014

Resolution Source

For this question to be resolved as 'yes', an official announcement from NASA must be released confirming the presence of sea plankton living outside of the ISS.

keywords: Prizes, sensing, biochips, biosenors, nanosenors, biological sensors
name: Which technology focus will win the Nokia Sensing XCHALLENGE $525,000 grand prize for a sensor-based device that individuals use to access, understand, and improve their health and well-being?
question_text:
Nokia Sensing XCHALLENGE is an XPrize competition that aims to identify a sensor-based device that allows consumers to monitor their own health data beyond the current available devices. The competition has been open since 2013 with multiple rounds. For this round of the prize, teams submitted study results, diagrams, videos, and prototypes in July.? An expert panel down-selected to 11 finalists based on the following criteria: validity, usability, relevance, originality, interoperability and affordability. These finalists are listed below as a function of their technology focus:

Blood & Tissue Sensors

  • ARCHIMEJ TECHNOLOGY (Evry, France), a start-up led by co-founder Francisco Vega, developing technology focused on making blood analysis available remotely at an affordable price.
  • Atoptix (State College, Pa.), a team of electrical engineering professors at Pennsylvania State University, led by co-founder Perry Edwards, Ph.D., focusing on mobile-based sensing of blood and tissue to assess personal health information.
  • DMI (Cambridge, Mass.), also a finalist team for the $10M Qualcomm Tricorder XPRIZE and led by Eugene Y. Chan, M.D., CEO and Head Scientist at the DNA Medicine Institute, designing a sensor that will assess hundreds clinical lab tests via a single drop of blood.
  • Eigen Lifescience (Stanford, Calif.), a team of engineering faculty and students from Stanford University led by Professor Shan Wang, Ph.D., developing an ultra-portable biosensor platform that embodies a clinical lab in a mobile device.
  • Golden Gopher Magnetic Biosensing Team (Minneapolis, Minn.), a team of researchers from the University of Minnesota, Mayo Clinic and several corporate partners in the life sciences, audio electronics repair and mechanical design space. Led by Professor Jian-Ping Wang, Ph.D., they are developing a sensing device that will simultaneously detect up to 10 health indicators.
Detection of conditions
  • GUES (London, England), a team of electrical engineering faculty and researchers from Imperial College and led by Professor Esther Rodriguez-Villegas, Ph.D., developing a sensor with a companion mobile app that detects sleep apnea and hypopnea.
Chronic condition monitoring
  • Biovotion (Zurich, Switzerland), a team led by founder and CEO Andreas Caduff, Ph.D., developing a wearable multi-sensor concept for monitoring patients with chronic conditions.
  • Endotronix Wireless Health Monitoring (Woodridge, Ill.), a team led by co-founder and CEO Harry D. Rowland, Ph.D., designing a miniature, implantable sensor with an accompanying mobile reader that helps to remotely monitor patients with chronic heart failure.
Detection of early stage diseases
  • Hemolix (Tampa, Fla.), a team of engineers led Anna Pyayt, Ph.D., head of the Innovative Biomedical Instruments and Systems Lab at the University of South Florida, developing a mobile phone-based technology for early detection of HELLP syndrome, a dangerous pregnancy complication.
  • SensoDx (Houston, Texas), a participant in the first Nokia Sensing XCHALLENGE competition (under the name Programmable Bio-Nano-Chip), led by John T. McDevitt, Ph.D., a biochemistry and engineering professor at Rice University and co-founder of SensoDx, LLC, focusing on sensor technology that can assess cardiac risk at a an early stage.
  • eyeMITRA (Cambridge, Mass.), a team affiliated with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab and led by Ramesh Raskar, Ph.D., developing a mobile phone-based imager for the early detection of diabetic retinopathy, a leading cause of adult blindness.
The winning team must demonstrate the highest merit in the areas of accuracy and consistency, demonstration quality, technical innovation, human factors, market opportunity, originality and user experience. The winning teams will be announced on November 10, 2014.

Sources and Links
http://sensing.xprize.org/
http://sensing.xprize.org/press-release/xprize-announces-finalists-225-million-nokia-sensing-xchalle...


Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/09/2014

Resolution Source

Xprize will announce the winners at the Exponential Medicine conference and will issue a press release at http://sensing.xprize.org.
short_name: Nokia Sensing XCHALLENGE grand prize winner

name: How many threatened languages will the Ethnologue language catalog report in its 18th edition?
question_text:
There arecurrently over 7,000 languages spoken in the world, though that estimate variesby source and how languages are counted. Ethnologue:Languages of the World is a comprehensive reference work cataloging all ofthe world?s known living languages. Compilation of Ethnologue data is an activeresearch project involving hundreds of linguists and other researchers aroundthe world. It is widely regarded to be the most comprehensive source ofinformation on language use and prevalence.

Ethnologuecategorizes languages according to their status as spoken languages, and alsoestimates the number of individuals speaking a language as their primarylanguage. Ethnologue data are periodically updated, and the next update, the 18thedition, is scheduled for early 2015.

In the mostrecent edition (17th) of Ethnologue, 1,055 languages were reportedas Threatened, and 424 reported as Nearly Extinct. A Threatened language ?isused for face-to-face communication within all generations, but it is losingusers.? The only remaining users of a Nearly Extinct language ?are members ofthe grandparent generation or older who have little opportunity to use thelanguage.?

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.ethnologue.com/statistics/status
  • http://www.ethnologue.com/statistics/size
  • http://www.helsinkitimes.fi/columns/columns/viewpoint/10658-how-languages-can-survive-in-today-s-world-2.html


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

Languagestatus data from Ethnologue?s 18th edition, due in early 2015, willbe used to resolve this question, and will be reported here:? http://www.ethnologue.com/statistics/status

keywords: digital currency, government, currency exchange, policy
name: Will any government officially accept a digital currency for circulation in their country in 2014?
question_text:
The question asks you to estimate the probability for any government in the world to accept a digital currency, such as Bitcoin or another, for circulation and payments in their respective country. The exchanges of private goods and services for digital currency?do not resolve the question. The question resolves only when a governmental entity (such as a central bank)?officially recognizes a digital currency for circulation. Any governmental purchases paid with digital currency also constitute an official recognition and resolve the question as "yes".

Resolution Sources

www.cnn.com
www.reuters.com
www.economist.com

Fine Print

Officially means that a national government or a representative of a national government issues a statement or passes a law?recognizing the alternative currency for circulation in their country. A digital currency is any currency that is not issued by any government and that circulates through electronic means (such as the internet) and can be exchanged for real goods, services or other official currencies.

Useful Links

http://world.time.com/2013/11/21/university-in-cyprus-becomes-first-to-accept-bitcoin-payments/

Related Organizations or Individuals

Any major mass media outlet

keywords: U.S., Apples, Production, Tons, 2013, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total U.S. apple production during the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of tons?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • U.S. apple?production for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 4,530,600?tons.
  • Apple production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as apples are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is?the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Apple production is reported in thousands of tons, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service.


Fine Print

The '2013 marketing season' begins 07/2012 and ends 06/2013.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.


Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts:?http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/MannUsda/viewDocumentInfo.do?documentID=1113
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Preliminary Summary:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-01-25-2013.pdf
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 11/19/2013 Sequestration Announcement:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-11-19-2013.txt

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Washington?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Washington, 64.5% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -2.0% from 2011 (66.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 63.6%, the "63.6%-67.0%" range will be deemed correct.

name: At the end of 2015, what will be the No.1 ranked crowdfunding website in the United States, in terms of web traffic?
question_text:
Crowdfunding?is the practice of funding a project or venture by raising monetary contributions from a large number of people, typically via the internet.?Crowdfunding has quickly moved from a trendy buzzword to a mainstream fundraising model.?In less than five years, Kickstarter has attracted more than five million contributors pledging close to $1 billion, funding more than 55,000 individual projects. Kickstarter's rival fundraising platform Indiegogo can boast of a campaign that single-handedly generated $12 million in pledges. Numbers like these make crowdfunding an attractive option for first-time entrepreneurs and established businesses alike, giving them the opportunity not only to raise capital but also to gain a sense of the market for a given project.?

On February 11, 2015, the three leading crowdfunding sites in terms of web traffic were Kickstarter, GoFundMe and Indiegogo, as?reported by alexa.com. ?

For more information:

  • Crowdfunding:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowdfunding
  • Top ten crowdfunding sites:?http://www.crowdfunding.com/
  • http://www.alexa.com/??



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The?top ten crowdfunding?website rankings?on both compete.com and alexa.com are published on crowdfunding.com?everyday:?http://www.crowdfunding.com/. The question will be resolved based on the Alexa rankings at COB (EST) on December 31, 2015.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Web traffic is as measured by alexa.com

choices_field_7: No one - The possibility of lossless conduction is theoretically disproven
keywords: Lossless conduction, stanene, Topological insulators, Quantum spin Hall effect, experimental physics
name: Where will the research group that obtains experimental confirmation of lossless conduction at room temperature of stanene be located?
question_text:
Topological insulators are characterized by an insulating bulk and metallic surface or edge state protected by time-reversal symmetry. This is a new quantum state that is promising for the realization of conduction without dissipation.? On September 24, 2013, a paper published in the Physics Review Letters described first-principle calculations that suggest that large-gap quantum spin hall (QSH) insulators in functionalized tin films can be patterned in a controlled way to be used as dissipationless conducting ?wires? for electronic circuits. The authors write:
?The proposal, if realized, could significantly lower the power consumption and heat generation rates of electronic devices, which is crucial for the development of modern integrated circuits.?

This publication only proposes that this is possible. It is up to experimental scientists to show that it is actually exists. This question asks who demonstration of dissipationless functionalized tin films (stanene) will be confirmed experimentally.

Resolution Criteria

?lossless conduction of stanene needs to be observed via experiments

Resolution Sources

This advancement would be covered by major outlets such as Science Magazine, New York Times, etc.

Fine Print

  • Lossless conduction = Dissipationless = That does not involve the dissipation of energy
  • Room Temperature= 298 K = 24.85
  • Stanene is a theoretical topological insulator that may display superconductivity at its edges above room temperature. It is composed of tin atoms arranged in a single layer, in a manner similar to graphene. Stanene got its name by combining stannum (the Latin name for tin) with the suffix -ene used by graphene.
  • Quantum spin Hall effect
  • Disproof of lossless conduction will be defined as a theoretical analysis having been published in a peer reviewed journal that is indexed by the Thomson Reuters Web of Science

The administrator may extend the trading on this question if no team has proven the outcome and no disproof exists by the proposed resolution date.

Useful Information and Links

  • Topological insulator?
  • Stanene
  • Time reversal symmetry
  • "A topological Dirac insulator in a quantum spin Hall phase." NATURE 452(7190): 970-974.?
  • Eugenie Samuel Reich ?Hopes surface for exotic insulator? Nature 492, 165 (13 December 2012) doi:10.1038/492165a?
  • Will 2-D Tin be the Next Super Material?, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, November 21, 2013?

Related Organizations or Individuals

Shou-Cheng Zhang at Stanford University: http://so5.stanford.edu/ (One of many)
short_name: Who proves Stanene lossless room temp conduction?

name: In 1950, the Navy airship Snow Bird set a record for the longest continuous flight of 264 hours (~10 days). When will a maneuverable airship stay aloft for more than 20 days above an altitude of 20 km?
question_text:
• Airships (dirigibles) are lighter-than-air aircraft that can navigate under their own power. Possibly the most famous airship, the Hindenburg, was filled with hydrogen that burned in 1937.?? Airships were popular in the early 1900s, but declined in popularity after disasters such as the Hindenburg. Helium is used now making them much safer.
  • While large-scale passenger applications were suspended in the mid-1900s, development focused on military applications for surveillance until resource issues diverted R&D funds from airships. However, recently non-defense-related attention returned to airships as low-carbon methods for transporting goods, as carriers for telescopes to scan the skies, and as instrument carriers to measure the atmosphere. Airships have high spatial and temporal resolution, daily to seasonal coverage, and local to regional spatial coverage.
  • In Febuary 2014, the Keck Institute for Space Studies published Airships: A New Horizon for Science, a report that reviewed ?the potential of a variety of airships currently operable or under development to serve as observatories and science instrumentation platforms for a range of space, atmospheric and Earth science.? The authors ?found considerable scientific value in both low altitude (< 40 kft) and high altitude (> 60 kft) airships across a wide spectrum of space, atmospheric, and Earth science programs.? Therefore, the authors call for a prize ?for the development of a maneuverable, station-keeping, stratospheric airship, which can stay aloft at an altitude above 65 kft (20 km) for at least a full diurnal cycle (>20 hours) while carrying a science payload of at least 20 kg in mass? as part of a roadmap to stratospheric airship observatories.
Links and sources
  • Airships: A New Horizon for Science? http://kiss.caltech.edu/study/airship/final-report.pdf
  • The flying bum! 300ft-long 'airship' unveiled in Britain is the world's longest aircraft http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2570118/Worlds-longest-aircraft-revealed-300ft-long-a...
  • http://kiss.caltech.edu/workshops/airship2013/presentations/smith.pdf
  • http://www.defenseinnovationmarketplace.mil/resources/Final_LTA_report.pdf
  • http://www.history.navy.mil/download/lta-10.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Press release or other official announcement from company or research group.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

An airship can be a rigid, semi-rigid, or non-rigid lighter-than-air vehicles that can generate their own thrust for maneuvers. The airship must not refuel during the duration of the flight.

keywords: washing machine, laundry, polymer beads, waterless
name: Will a domestic version of the Xeros bead washing machine be commercially available in the US by the end of 2016?
question_text:
The?Xeros Washing Machine?is a new kind of?clothes?washing?technology that cleans laundry using nylon polymer?beads and very little water. The machine releases the nylon polymer beads into a main compartment where laundry is washed. These beads are small and super absorbent which allows them to go through clothing to absorb dirt and stains. This technology was invented by?University of Leeds?professor?Stephen Burkinshaw, who currently has a partnership with?Xeros Ltd. to develop and market the technology.

In the United States, laundromats, athletic clubs and some properties of hotel chains Hyatt and Choice say they've given the beads a spin, and like the results. Xeros researchers are now working on a home version of the machine, targeted to American preferences for side-by-side washer/dryer combos. Pending additional investment, Xeros says that it hopes to market a domestic washer-dryer some time in 2016.

  • Almost waterless washing could come to American homes:?http://www.cbsnews.com/news/almost-waterless-washing-could-come-to-american-homes/
  • Xeros bead washing machine system set to save water and energy in the home:?http://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/oct/19/xeros-bead-washing-machine-system-save-water-energy-...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

When the washing machine is available to US consumers, it could be sold in major appliance stores such as Home Depot (http://www.homedepot.com/), Lowes (http://www.lowes.com/), Best Buy (http://www.bestbuy.com/), and by online retailer Amazon (http://www.amazon.com)

Fine Print

'Domestic' means for use in the home, rather than in commercial settings.
short_name: Home version of bead washing machine

name: How many research papers, as reported by the SCImago Journal & Country Ranking, will the U.S. have in 2014?
question_text:
TheSCImago Journal & Country Ranking is a publicly-accessible platform run by ScimagoLab that uses SCOPUS data on academic journals to rank countries by theirpublication and citation rates and journals by their citation rates. Scopus isa bibliographic database containing abstracts and citations for academicjournal articles from approximately 20,000 peer-reviewed journals in thescientific, technical, medical, and social sciences, including arts andhumanities. It is owned by Elsevier B.V.

For2009 to 2012, SCImago reports the following for total U.S. output of scientificarticles: 2009=505,920; 2010=526,774; 2011=541,765; 2012=537,308. Data for eachyear are posted to the SCImago website at some point during the subsequentyear, and data from past years is also available on the site.Thisquestion asks how many research papers the U.S. will have for 2014, once thosedata are reported sometime in early 2015.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Resolution Sources

TheSCImago country ranking website, (http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php), will report the resultswhen available sometime in early 2015.

Fine Print

Scimago Lab uses SCOPUS data to post country results, once available, to the SCImago website: ?http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php

Useful Information and Links

SCImagowebsites:

  • Main site:? http://www.scimagojr.com/index.php
  • Country ranking website:? http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php

Related Organizations or Individuals

Scimago Lab, http://www.scimagojr.com/countryrank.php

choices_field_23: an element with an atomic number above 126
choices_field_24: none will be discovered by the question deadline
name: If a transactinide isotope with a half-life longer than 29 hours is discovered by 2017, what will its atomic number be?
question_text:
Transactinide elements (chemical elements with atomic numbers above 103) are radioactive and thus far have only been obtained synthetically in laboratories. Transactinides and their isotopes are typically short lived, with half-lives of seconds or minutes, though an isotope of the element Dubnium (Db-268) has a half life of 29 hours - a record for a superheavy isotope.

Much of the research on transactinide elements focuses on the discovery of the theorized 'island of stability' - a set of as-yet undiscovered isotopes of superheavy elements which are theorized to be more stable and have much longer half-lives than previously observed transuranium elements. The hypothesis is based upon the nuclear shell model, which implies that atomic nuclei are built up in "shells" in a manner similar to the structure of electron shells in atoms. In both cases, shells are just groups of quantum energy levelsthat are relatively close to each other. Energy levels from quantum states in two different shells will be separated by a relatively large energy gap. So when the number of neutrons and protons completely fills the energy level of a given shell in the nucleus, the binging energy per nucleon will reach a local maximum and thus that particular configuration will have a longer lifetime than nearby isotopes that do not possess filled shells. A filled shell would have "magic numbers"of neutrons and protons. One possible magic number of neutrons for spherical nuclei is 184, and some possible matching proton numbers are 114, 120 and 126.

In May 2014, physicists created one of the heaviest elements yet, with an atomic number of 117, which? has a half life of about 50 thousandths of a second. In the decay of element 177, two previously unknown isotopes were identified: Db-270 (dubnium) and Lr-266 (lawrencium). With half-lives of about one hour and about 11 hours, respectively, they are among the longest-lived superheavy isotopes known to date, perhaps science closer to the fabled the island of stability.

  • Scientific American - Superheavy Element 117 Points to Fabled "Island of Stability" on Periodic Table
  • Wikipedia - Island of Stability
  • Science Daily - Approaching the island of stability: Observation of superheavy element 117

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

The discovery of a transactinide isotope with a half life longer than that of Db-268 would represent a major breakthrough in physics and would likely be covered in a variety of academic journals, such a Nature Physics, as well as by the mainstream media and science publications.

keywords: physics, space, International Space Station, chemistry
name: Will NASA?s Cold Atom Lab successfully achieve a temperature of 100 picokelvin?
question_text:
NASA?s Cold Atom Lab, set to be deployed in the International Space Station in 2016, is a facility that will study ultra-cold quantum gases in a microgravity environment. It will attempt to will reduce temperatures to 100 picokelvin, or one ten billionth of a degree above ?absolute zero,? which is the temperature where all thermal activity theoretically ceases at the atomic level.

The facility will be working with Bose-Einstein condensates, a type of dilute gas that shows macro-quantum effects at temperatures near absolute zero. The space station will offer a uniquely well-suited environment for this testing. When gas expands, it cools, which is the basis for the cooling that will take place on the International Space Station (ISS). Magnetic traps will expand the gas until it gets down to the desired temperature. These traps can be very low-power because the gas doesn?t need to be supported against the pull of gravity, allowing it to reach incredibly low temperatures.

  • NASA Cold Atom Laboratory
  • NASA: Coldest spot in the known universe
  • Forbes: Atomic refrigerator will be coldest place in known universe

This question is contingent on the successful deployment of the Cold Atom Lab to the ISS

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

NASA will report the results of their experiments on the Cold Atom Lab website
short_name: Cold Atom Lab temperature of 100 picokelvin

The US?and UK governments are strenuously objecting to this on the grounds?that terrorists are helped thereby.?James Comey, the director of the FBI,?said "data encryption such as that employed on Apple?s latest mobile operating system would deprive police and intelligence companies of potentially life-saving information, even when judges grant security agencies access through a warrant.'Criminals and terrorists would like nothing more than for us to miss out.'?

The rhetoric threatens a?reprise of the so-called "Crypto Wars" of the 1990s and may extend?to export controls in the US or import controls in other countries.?As point of the spear, Apple is doubtless under?pressure?to negotiate something more friendly to law enforcement (noting?that Apple's position is that you should trust them as they have?ensured that they, Apple, can no longer respond to subpoenas as?they have destroyed the mechanisms by which they used to do so).

keywords: autonomous minesweeping, IED detection, landmine detection, unmanned military vehicles, autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence, autonomous ground technology
name: When will the US Army debut an unmanned self-driving military vehicle with a robotic minesweeper in a supply convoy on the battlefront?
question_text:
US Defense contractors Oshkosh Defense and Lockheed Martin are working to bring autonomous ground vehicle technology to US military forces on the battlefront as part of the Army and Marine Corps' Autonomous Mobility Applique Systems (AMAS) program. Oshkosh?s autonomous driving technology called TerraMax and its counterpart that Lockheed is developing, are equipped with capabilities like radar and LIDAR, electrical control engine speed, braking, and steering in addition to autonomously controlling a central tire inflation systems and driveline locks to maneuver in deep mud or sand. Controlled by operators who can be farther back in a convoy, these unmanned vehicles can lead a convoy in enemy territory.? Operators can set vehicle speed, following distance, access a live map of the entire convoy, and obtain diagnostics on the vehicles. Oshkosh has spent three years working with the Marine Corp Warfighting Lab and the Office of Naval Research to get the technology ready for use in battlefronts. Lockheed Martin took part in a Capabilities Advancement Demonstration in January 2014 along with other contractors to display the promising progress in this work.

Oshkosh and Lockheed claim that their technology can be installed on any vehicle that drives. In a step further to protect US armed forces, Oshkosh is working to develop software that can also detect IEDs and land mines while autonomously moving in battlefields; thus making way for an autonomous, unmanned minesweeping vehicle.

For more information:
http://www.wired.com/2014/06/oshkosh-autonomous-minesweeping/
http://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/military-robots/lockheeds-robotic-trucks-pass-real-world...
http://spectrum.ieee.org/cars-that-think/robotics/military-robots/robot-minesweeper-vehicle-demoed-i...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

An announcement or news release by the US armed forces or a firm that fits an autonomous minesweeping technology to self-directing unmanned military vehicles in a convoy operation. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first. For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

The question is looking for the debut of autonomous IED and mine detection capabilities in autonomously driven unmanned vehicles like Army supply trucks in a US armed forces logistics convoy operation. These vehicles would be considered to be at least at Level 3 on the NHSTA scale "Vehicles at this level of automation enable the driver to cede full control of all safety-critical functions under certain traffic or environmental conditions and in those conditions to rely heavily on the vehicle to monitor for changes in those conditions requiring transition back to driver control." A robotic minesweeper is defined as a unit equipped with either mine rollers or ground penetrating radar to detect and/or set off mines or improvised explosive devices (IEDs).
short_name: autonomous minesweeping in unmanned vehicle convoy
