keywords: crude oil, exploration and production, enhanced oil recovery
name: Will Saudi Arabia?s proven oil reserves decrease again in 2014?
question_text:
Oil is the byproduct of the anaerobic decomposition of long dead and buried zooplankton and algae. As a fuel it accounts for roughly one third of all the energy production on planet Earth. Oil and gas reserves are defined according to how easily they can be recovered and separated into three categories: proven, probable, and possible. Probable and possible reserves are considered unproven. Proven reserves are considered to have a "reasonable certainty" of being recovered, though definitions of proven vary within the industry.

Total proven reserves can increase when new reserves are found (exploration), and when new technology makes a larger share of existing reserves recoverable (recovery). Technological advancements have nearly doubled the volume of reserves that ultimately are recoverable since 1980. Exploration has been enhanced through such technology as 3D geological modeling and considerable research is ongoing in the area of Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR), which applies a wide range of methods (thermal, chemical, physical, and even biological) to improve recovery.

Reserve measurement and classification requires assumptions and estimation, so estimates from different sources will not match exactly. This question uses estimates from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC). OPEC publishes an Annual Statistical Bulletin that reports proven reserves by country. The most recent bulletin reports 265,789 million barrels of proven crude oil reserves for Saudi Arabia at the end of 2013, down 0.02% from 265,850 at the end of 2012. OPEC will release the next Bulletin sometime in 2015, likely around midyear. As the world?s largest producer of oil, the possible expansion or decline of Saudi oil reserves receives considerable attention.

For more background, see:

  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2013/03/27/how-big-are-the-currently-known-oil-reserves-and-what-a...
  • http://energy.gov/fe/science-innovation/oil-gas-research/enhanced-oil-recovery
  • http://www.emgs.com/content/675/3-D-EM-addresses-exploration-challenges
  • http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/202.htm


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2015

Resolution Source

OPEC?s 2015 Annual Statistical Bulletin will be available here:? http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/202.htm

Fine Print

This question is asking whether Saudi Arabia's proven crude oil reserves will decrease between 2013 (as listed in the 2014 report) and 2014 (which will be included in the 2015 Annual Statistical Bulletin published by OPEC).

keywords: Cybersecurity, hardware updates, computers, cyber security
name: Will a botnet (or other persistent control regime) running on at least 500,000 SOHO routers be acknowledged in 2015?
question_text:
There is a large storm brewing as all or almost all?small-end routers are bought on the basis of price and, as such, are using old chips and old software. To make matters worse, it?s often impossible to patch the software or upgrade the components to the latest version. Often, the complete source code isn?t available. Even if it be, many of the device drivers and other components are just ?binary blobs? ? no source code at all. That?s the most pernicious part of the problem: No one can possibly patch code that?s just binary. ?

We?re at a crisis point now with regard to the security of embedded systems, where computing is embedded into the hardware itself ? as with the Internet of Things. These embedded computers are riddled with vulnerabilities, there?s no good way to patch them, and they?re all connected to the Internet. The computers in our routers and modems are much more powerful than the PCs of the mid-1990s, and the Internet of Things will put computers (and networking)?into all sorts of consumer devices. The industries producing these devices are even less capable of fixing the problem than the PC and software industries were.
These vulnerabilities have been taken advantage of in Brazil,?where Brazil, 4.5 million DSL routers were?compromised?for purposes of financial fraud. Last month, Symantec?reported?on a Linux worm that?targets routers, cameras, and other embedded devices. Finally, a group calling themselves the Lizard Squad has offered their services to push any person or site offline for hours using bandwidth from hacked home and business Internet routers. ?

This problem cannot be fixed?without?replacing the physical hardware and all the hardware in the?retail pipeline.?In the meantime, one a committed opponent could simply turn off the Internet in the U.S. for a monthowever long it would, in fact, take to bring new SOHO routers to market.? ??

For more information:?
  • http://krebsonsecurity.com/2015/01/lizard-stresser-runs-on-hacked-home-routers/
  • http://www.wired.com/2014/01/theres-no-good-way-to-patch-the-internet-of-things-and-thats-a-huge-pro...
  • http://www.acsac.org/2010/openconf/modules/request.php?module=oc_program&action=view.php&a&id=69&typ...
  • http://census2012.sourceforge.net/paper.html


This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by a publication from major news sources and may also be found?either from?Brian Krebs (krebsonsecurity.com) or?threatpost.com.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

Fine Print

A botnet is a collection of Internet-connected programs communicating with other similar programs in order to perform tasks. This can be as mundane as keeping control of an Internet Relay Chat (IRC) channel, or it could be used to send spam email or participate in distributed denial-of-service attacks.

name: When will the existence of a strongly polynomial-time algorithm for linear programming be proven?
question_text:
Strongly polynomial-time means polynomial time in the arithmetic model of computation (unit cost for arbitrary arithmetic operations) given unbounded inputs. Linear programming is used in the usual sense: given a universe of variables, and a set of linear constraints on those variables (with arbitrarily large coefficients), determine whether there is an assignment of variables which satisfies those linear constraints.

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?no? if the existence of a strongly polynomial time for linear programming is not yet discovered by January 1, 2018. Outcome will be resolved based on judgment delivered by the question moderator. If nothing is reported in this source, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting by the question moderator. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Fine Print

"By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Related Organizations or Individuals

keywords: Riesel numbers, prime number, composite number
name: Will researchers announce the discovery of a new Riesel number below 1,000,000 before 2019?
question_text:
A Riesel number is an odd natural number k for which the integers of the form k*2^n ? 1 are composite for all natural numbers n (where ^ denotes exponent). In 1956, Hans Riesel showed that there are an infinite number of integers k such that k*2^n ? 1 is not prime for any integer n. A number can be shown to be a Riesel number by exhibiting a covering set: a set of prime numbers that will divide any member of the sequence. The only known Riesel numbers below one million have covering sets as follows:

  • 509203 ?2^n ? 1 has covering set {3, 5, 7, 13, 17, 241}
  • 762701 ?2^n ? 1 has covering set {3, 5, 7, 13, 17, 241}
  • 777149 ?2^n ? 1 has covering set {3, 5, 7, 13, 19, 37, 73}
  • 790841 ?2^n ? 1 has covering set {3, 5, 7, 13, 19, 37, 73}
  • 992077 ?2^n ? 1 has covering set {3, 5, 7, 13, 17, 241}
Because no covering set has been found for any k less than 509203, it is conjectured that 509203 is the smallest Riesel number, but not proven.

For more information, see:
  • http://mathworld.wolfram.com/RieselNumber.html
  • http://oeis.org/A076336/a076336b.html
  • http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022314X08000462
  • http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022314X1200265X

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in a company official press release.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

keywords: Avian Influenza A, H7N9, Virus, flu, bird flu
name: How many lab-confirmed human cases of the Avian Influenza A (H7N9) virus will be detected in the United States before the end of flu season (by 1 June 2014)?
question_text:
During the spring of 2013, the World Health Organization (WHO) reported 132 human H7N9 infections, with 44 deaths. Most cases had illness onset during the month of April. Beginning in May, new reports of human H7N9 infection in China became less frequent. From June to the end of September 2013, WHO reported three new H7N9 infections in China; one had illness onset in April, and one resulted in death. In the beginning of October, the frequency of reports of human infection with H7N9 began to increase. WHO and China reported more new H7N9 cases in China per month relative to the summer months, including three cases reported by Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of People?s Republic of China in early December. These cases coincided with the arrival of cooler weather in China and were not unexpected. Most of the cases that were reported had poultry exposure and lived in areas where H7N9 had been found previously. As of mid-January, cases continue to be reported and the frequency of these reports has increased.

CDC was aware of a small number of confirmed H7N9 influenza cases in China in which ?limited? person-to-person spread of the virus could not be ruled out. On January 20, Bloomburg News reported "A medical worker at a Shanghaihospital died from bird flu, stoking concern that the influenzavirus known as H7N9 may have spread from person to person."

Chinese New Year, which is on January 31, 2014, is a time for traditional trips to family reunions and celebrations.? The government estimating that 3.62 billion trips would be taken in the next 40 days by road, train, airplane and other modes of transportation, Many of these trips will take place to rural areas where people may have contact with poultry or with people infected with H7N9.? One of these travelers may be from the US and return to the US with the infection or travel to the US after infection resulting in a US case of H7N9 human-infection.

Links:

  • Rise in Bird Flu Cases in China Stokes Worry Before Peak Travel Time
  • CDC Avian Influenza A (H7N9) Virus
  • Bird Flu Kills Health Worker, Stokes Transmission Concern
  • Mapping the H7N9 avian flu outbreaks

The high travel season for the Chinese New Year increases the probability for transmission and movement of the virus.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/01/2014

Resolution Source

  • This question will be resolved by the announced number of lab-confirmed human cases on July 1, 2014.
  • In the United States, the CDC is the US leading authority on Avian Influenza - http://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/h7n9-virus.htm
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) is the leading authority internationally: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/influenza_h7n9/en/

Fine Print

Flu season: 1 January 2014 to 1 June 2014.Lab-confirmed: as announced by the CDC or WHO.This question will be judged on 1 July 2014 to allow time for testing and announcement.

name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "trends in abundance and distribution of selected species " in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

name: Will the twin prime conjecture be resolved by 2024?
question_text:
Prime numbers are numbers that are only divisible by 1 and themselves (e.g. 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13...). ?Twin primes are pairs of primes that have a gap of 2 in between (e.g. 3 & 5, 5 & 7, 11 & 13, 29 & 31, etc.)?In Euclid's Elements (circa 300 BCE) a proof is presented showing there are an infinite number of prime numbers. ?It is unsolved as to whether there are an infinite number of twin primes and this problem has been unsolved for at least 165 years and probably longer. ?Recently Yitang Zhang made a significant breakthrough in finding a finite bound B such that there are an infinite number of primes p, q, such that q - p <= B. ?Following Zhang's work James Maynard reduced the bound to 600. ?The twin prime conjecture will be solved if the bound could be reduced to?2. ?This is significantly harder, however Zhang and Maynard's work looks far more promising than any approaches within the last 150 years so this may be the next great unsolved problem to fall.

If someone extends the current work of Zhang, Maynard, and Polymath on prime gaps, that could make this problem easier.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

A proof will be presented in a peer reviewed math journal.

choices_field_2: Decrease by 5 to less than 10 percent
choices_field_3: Decrease by 0 to less than 5 percent
name: How will NOAA Fisheries' next minimum population estimate of California/Oregon/Washington offshore common bottlenose dolphins change from the 2010 stock assessment of 684 bottlenose dolphins?
question_text:
The Pacific sardine has experienced a severe population crash in recent years, with stock biomass estimates dropping from 1.37 million metric tons in 2006 to 378,120 metric tons in 2014, a decrease of 70 percent.? This crash is expected to have ripple effects throughout the food chain, as the sardine is an important food source for many fish, marine mammals and aquatic birds.

Already, the sardine crash has been blamed for a wave of sick, malnourished sea lion pups that have washed up on California shores in 2013. Sardines represent one of the primary food sources of the common bottlenose dolphin populations living off of coastal California, Oregon and Washington, and the sharp decline in sardine population could have a major impact on these dolphins. However, dolphins may be able to substitute sardines with other food sources, such as anchovy or squid, and there are no signs yet that dolphin populations have been affected by the sardine crash.

  • The Atlantic: Why West Coast Sea Life Has Been Behaving So Strangely
  • LA Times: West Coast sardine crash could radiate throughout ecosystem

Further population decline or a recovery of the Pacific sardine stock


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2015

Resolution Source

Marine Mammal Stock Assessment Reports are maintained by NOAA fisheries and updated on a one to three year basis. The most recent report on common bottlenose dolphins for California-Oregon-Washington Offshore is for 2010, and an updated stock assessment is expected in 2014 or 2015.

name: On June 2014, what will be the Top 500 performance share by vendor?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500, and you think IBM?s machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust IBM?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

keywords: Flu, Region 2, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 2 (NJ, NY, PR, VI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 2' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 2 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS region 2 is the highest. Region 2 is comprised of New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Wyoming?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Wyoming, 53.9% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -7.0% from 2011 (60.9%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 53.0%, the "53.0%-56.4%" range will be deemed correct.

name: By the end March 2015, will the global number of lab-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection reach 1,500?
question_text:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is viral respiratory illness first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012. It is caused by a coronavirus called MERS-CoV. ?This virus?is spread?through close contact, such as caring for or living with an infected person. So far, all?confirmed cases have been linked to countries in and near the Arabian Peninsula.

The first human victims of MERS were a university student and a nurse, who both got sick and died in Jordan in spring?2012. In the two years between then and March 2014, public health officials recorded an average of 14 or 15 cases per month, for a total of 207 cases.?The situation has?worsened significantly since then. In April 2014 alone, the MERS virus was confirmed?in 217 people -?more than in the previous two years combined. As of October 24 2014,?WHO has received notification of 883 lab-confirmed cases of infection with MERS-CoV.

  • Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) -Turkey:?http://www.who.int/csr/don/24-october-2014-mers/en/
  • MERS outbreak picks up pace in Middle East:?https://www.sciencenews.org/article/mers-outbreak-picks-pace-middle-east
  • Corona Map:?http://coronamap.com/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

The Corona Map launched in May 2014 to track the MERS coronavirus in real time on the world map:?http://coronamap.com/. The data is officially?provided by WHO or the Ministry of Health of the respective country.?

Fine Print

The question refers to the total number of cases since the discovery of the virus.

keywords: malaria, vaccine, infectious disease, world health
name: Will the malaria vaccine RTS,S/AS01, developed by GlaxoSmithKline in a partnership with Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, be approved for use by July 31, 2015?
question_text:
Malaria kills over 600,000 people every year, most of them children in Africa.? Potential vaccines target the?deadliest form of the disease which is caused by the parasite?Plasmodium falciparum.?With funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and the non-profit Path Malaria Vaccine Initiative have developed a vaccine candidate, RST,S, that has an efficacy of 46% in young children aged 5-17 mo and 27% in infants.

The vaccine was administered in 3 phases, and although efficacy decreased over time in both age categories and was limited against cases with severe malaria, reports suggest that the vaccine would have a large impact in areas with high rates of the disease. Before advancing to phase four of clinical trials, the vaccine must be approved by the European Medicines Agency and World Health Organization.

Further Information:

  • http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.1001685
  • http://www.malariavaccine.org/malvac-overview.php
  • http://www.bbc.com/news/health-28541939
  • http://www.gatesfoundation.org/What-We-Do/Global-Health/Malaria#TheChallenge
  • http://www.malariavaccine.org/rd-clinical-trials.php#phase4

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will resolve as "true" when an announcement is made declaring the vaccine approved by the European Medicines Agency and World Health Organization:

  • https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/resources/alert
  • http://www.nlm.nih.gov/databases/alerts/clinical_alerts.html

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast Blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

keywords: Wireless, Backscatter, WiFi, Signal Processing, Ultra-Low-Power WiFi
name: Will a backscatter wireless device that can send at least 5Mb per second signals across more than 20 feet be reported by the end of 2015?
question_text:
Forecasts?about the Internet of Things - the idea that cars, appliances, clothes, and other devices will all soon be wired in to the internet - will mean little if IoT devices still require batteries or plugged-in power supplies to operate. The idea behind?backscatter wireless devices is to?reflect ambient wireless signals instead of generating the signals from scratch.?That's a lot easier on the battery than conventional wireless tech, using approximately .01 percent of the conventional wireless tech, and it could make a big difference in the new generation of wearables.

In August 2014,?UCLA and NASA's Jet Propulsion Lab reported?sending?3Mb per second signals across more than 8 feet using backscatter devices. Just a year ago, backscatter signals were limited to just 2Kb per second. With more advanced signal processing,?it is?hoped that such devices will eventually operate up to 65 feet?(20 meters)?with data rates comparable to existing WiFi connections (approx. 50 Mb/s).

  • Ultra Low-Power WiFi Reflector Link For Next Generation Embedded and Wearable Devices:?http://www.ee.ucla.edu/news/news-archive/2014/ultra-low-power-wifi-reflector-link-for-next-generatio...
  • Researchers pack more signal into ultra low-power Wi-Fi gadgets:?http://www.theverge.com/2014/8/11/5990607/researchers-pack-more-signal-into-ultra-low-power-wi-fi-ga...
  • WiFi Backscatter: The Internet of Things Could Talk by Turning Reflective:?http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/computing/networks/internet-of-things-talks-by-turning-reflective

Resolution Source

New development is likely to be published in science and technology journals or websites such as IEEE Spectrum?http://spectrum.ieee.org/

name: Will there be a RFID malware attack by the end of 2014?
question_text:
RadioFrequency Identification (RFID) is a data collection technology similar tobarcodes, but instead of using printed codes to store information, RFID uses radiofrequency communication to collect data from electronic RFID tags. Each tag(transponder) is embedded with an integrated circuit (IC) that can store uniquedata about the object being tagged. A reader transmits radio signals at aspecific radio frequency to communicate with and retrieve data from tags withinits proximity.

RFIDtechnology has an enormous range of commercial and other uses, including logisticsand supply chain management, asset and inventory control, event management andattendee tracking, library systems, real time location monitoring, pet and wildanimal tracking, and many others. Historically, technologists believed RFIDtags were immune from computer viruses because the amount of information storedon them was so small. However, in 2006, researchers in the Netherlandsdemonstrated the first self-replicating computer virus in an RFID tag,highlighting the vulnerability of RFID systems to malware attacks. To date,however, no such attacks have been reported.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/109560/RFID_tags_vulnerable_to_viruses_study_says
  • Is Your Cat Infected with a Computer Virus? http://www.rfidvirus.org/papers/percom.06.pdf

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

A successfulmalware attack involving RFID tags would be reported in the technical press andthe popular press.

name: What will be the next published efficiency over 3 meters at 20 kHz for an Inductive Power Transfer System?
question_text:
• It is a dream of many people to have their wireless devices charge without being near an outlet.? Current commercially available wireless power technology requires the wireless device to be touching the power source.? However, advances in the lab have allowed wireless power to charge devices at significant distances.
  • In 2007, a group at MIT developed the Coupled Magnetic Resonance System and transferred 60 watts with ?40% efficiency over distances in excess of 2 meters.
  • In 2014, Park et al. improved the previous design of conventional-loop-type coils for a magnetic resonance scheme with magnetic dipole type coils. This design resulted in experimentally obtained maximum primary-coil-to-load power efficiencies at 20 kHz of 29% over 3 meters, 16% over 4 meters, and 8% over 5 meters.
Links and sources

  • Innovative 5m-off-distance Inductive Power Transfer Systems with Optimally Shaped Dipole Coils http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?reload=true&arnumber=6762951

01/01/2018

A publication in a peer-review journal indexed by Thomson Reuters' Web of Science.

name: At the end of 2015, will there be at least 15 open clinical trials in the US examining the use of antisense therapy for cancer treatment?
question_text:
Antisense therapy is a form of treatment for genetic disorders or infections. When the genetic sequence of a particular gene is known to be causative of a particular disease, it is possible to synthesize a strand of nucleic acid (DNA, RNA or a chemical analogue) that will bind to the messenger RNA (mRNA) produced by that gene and inactivate it, effectively turning that gene "off". This is because mRNA has to be single stranded for it to be translated. Alternatively, the strand might be targeted to bind a splicing site on pre-mRNA and modify the exon content of an mRNA.

There are currently nine?open clinical trials?in the US examining the use of?antisense therapy for cancer treatment, according to the US NIH clinical trials database:?http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=antisense&recr=Open


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

NIH clinical trials database

http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=antisense&recr=Open

Fine Print

Clinical trials are determined to be 'open' if they are defined as such by NIH's clinicaltrials.gov website. This may include trials at various stages, including recruiting participants (or yet to do so), underway, or yet to publish results.All forms of cancer are included in the count of clinical trials, including carcinoma, leukemia etc.

keywords: Malaysia Airlines, MH370, 7th arc, search area
name: Will the first piece of debris from MH370 be found along the 7th arc by January 1, 2016?
question_text:
According to ATSB, data suggests that MH370 is likely to be found along the "7th arc" from 20 degrees South latitude to 39 degrees South latitude?in the Indian Ocean. The data suggests that at the 7th arc MH 370 ran out of fuel and likely descended?(NBC News, June 2014). This new area is larger than the previously defined search area.

The seventh arc charts the likely direction of the plane based on its seventh and final satellite ?handshake?, at which point the aircraft is believed to have been out of fuel and descending.

Angus Houston, head of JACC - ?I?ve always said that that seventh handshake arc is the most robust data that we have. The aircraft will be found somewhere along that arc.?

  • NY Times Graphic: The Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
  • Australian authorities insist plane will be found along 7th Arc


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved based on corroborated information between the Malaysian, Australian and Chinese governments. All governments must acknowledge the wreckage is in fact from MH 370 in order for the question to resolve to true. All governments must acknowledge that the debris was found along the 7th arc, as it is defined in this question, or the question cannot resolve in the affirmative.

Fine Print

This question will resolve based on which of the 3 possible answers occurs first. 'Debris' includes the plane's airframe (wings, tail, fuselage), cabin and black boxes. The found parts must be positively identified as from MH370.ATSB - Australian Transportation Safety Bureau. "Along the 7th arc arc" includes the range 20 NM (38 km) to the West and 30 NM (55 km) to the East of the 7th arc

name: By the end of 2014, will the total number of cases of Ebola virus infection in West Africa reach 2,000?
question_text:
The Ebola virus is sweeping across West Africa in the largest outbreak of the virus to date. It was first reported in Guinea in March 2014. The virus has spread to neighboring Liberia and Sierra Leone in the last few months. The outbreak has reached unprecedented scale, with over 1,200 people infected, and 672 deaths attributed to the virus as of July 23, 2014.?

  • http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-28522824
  • http://www.who.int/csr/don/2014_07_27_ebola/en/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

The question will be resolved with the final number of infections released by WHO:?http://www.who.int/csr/disease/ebola/en/

Fine Print

The cases of infection include confirmed, probable, suspect cases, as they are reported by the World Health Organization http://www.who.int/csr/don/2014_07_27_ebola/en/

name: When will the Isolation Chip (iChip), which was instrumental in discovering the new antibiotic Teixobactin, result in the discovery of another new antibiotic?
question_text:
Since penicillin was first discovered in 1928, antibiotics have been a crucial component of medical science. While the initial discovery was serendipitous, a successful discovery program was introduced by Selman Waksman in the 1940s. Unfortunately, by the 1960s this method of antibiotic discovery was all but exhausted.?While a few small-scale alternatives were discovered in the 1960s there has been no discovery of a new class of broad-spectrum compounds. Due to use and overuse of antibiotics, resistant strains of bacteria are emerging more and more frequently, reinforcing our need for new classes of?effective antibiotics.?
?
Recently however, a new andibiotic, teixobactin, was discovered using a new way to cultivate bacteria in their native environment. The iChip, short for isolation chip, is a specialized device for cultivating these previously inaccessible microorganisms. The construction of the iChip allows the cells to grow in their natural environment while still keeping them isolated from the general population of bacteria.? Using this method instead of the traditional petri dish, researchers are now able to grow around 50% of organisms found in soil as opposed to the 1% which can be grown in a petri dish. This greatly increases scientists? ability to screen bacteria for novel antibiotics.

Sources:
Teixobactin details: Paper 1; Paper 2
iChip details: Paper 1
Carbapenems: Paper 1

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in a company official press release.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

iChip Cultivation refers to the use of the iChip to grow quantities of a bacteria in their normal soil for study as opposed to the more traditional petri dish method. To positively resolve the question, an antibiotic must be identified and isolated from the bacterium using the iChip instead of it being cultured using another method.

*Admin Update: At minimum the antibiotic must kill bacteria and be non-toxic to mammalian cells. This was mentioned in one of the background papers as being a step before animal testing and is a good early indicator of whether or not a drug has potential. Further steps such as animal testing in mice or larger animals would surpass this standard and it?s possible that a paper would only be published when the research had reached the point of animal testing. However, being inimical to bacteria but not to mammalian cells will be the minimum threshold.

name: Liu et al. reported on 8/27/2014 their discovery and synthesis of a new class of multiferroics that may lead to massive storage capacities for small memory sticks. Will a research team demonstrate a flash-memory device using these multiferroics by 2017?
question_text:
Complex oxides have been widely studied for their application in electronic devices. Progress has been partly limited due to single phase materials either having substantive magnetic or electrical polarization in a single compound ? it is very rare for a material to combine ferroelectricity and ferromagnetism in the same material .? However, a single phase compound with both long range magnetic ordering and spontaneous electric polarization has been predicted for decades, but only recently have materials with a strong magnetic coupling been synthesized.? ?
?
Liu et al reported in Nature Scientific Reports their new class of multiferroic hollandite Ba-Mn-Ti oxides. The team synthesized BaMn3Ti4O14.25? that exhibited an antiferromagnetic phase transition (TN ~ 120?K) with a weak ferromagnetic ordering at lower temperatures, ferroelectricity, a giant dielectric constant at low frequency and a stable intrinsic dielectric constant of ~200 (1-100?MHz). Being able to control both magnetic and ferroelectric properties of a material at room temperature offers the potential for small memory devices with very high storage densities. ?? ? ?

Sources and Links
  • Hollandites as a new class of multiferroics http://www.nature.com/srep/2014/140827/srep06203/full/srep06203.html#affil-auth ? Multiferroics http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiferroics
  • Oxides Discovered by CCNY Team Could Advance Memory Devices http://www.ccny.cuny.edu/news/oxides-discovered.cfm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science or announced in a company official press release. ?

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first. If no announcement is made by the resolution date then the question will resolve as no.

Fine Print

"these multiferroic" = hollandite Ba-Mn-Ti oxides

name: What programming language will be used by the 2014 winner of the ICFP Programming Contest?
question_text:
Every year, a programming contest runs before the International Conference on Functional Programming. Anyone may enter, free of charge, and use any programming language they like. First prize "includes" the bragging rights to proclaim the language used to be "the programming tool of choice for discriminating hackers".

  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ICFP_Programming_Contest (provides links to previous year's contest results)
  • The contest page: http://icfpcontest.org/
The outcome is influenced by a number of factors. The contest problem, when announced, may be more or less amenable to solution in the various programming languages. Use of some programming languages may be correlated with increased programing skill, experience, or stubbornness. Other languages simply have more users.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

7/28/2014

Resolution Source

The contest organizers will announce the winning team, and the programming language(s) used on their web site. This question is only concerned with first place; lightning division and Judges' prize aren't considered.

If multiple languages are used, the question should resolve as a mixture of the languages. For instance, the 2013 winner would resolve such that Java, C#, C++ and Haskell all received 16.6%. PHP and Ruby would combine to give Other 33.3%.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in states with historically 'average' HPV vaccination coverage?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • The 'average' HPV vaccination group of states is comprised of the following: (2011 coverage rate % / 2012 coverage rate %)
    • Alaska (59.5 / 56.1)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/458/trades/create/safe
    • Arizona (55.3 / 54.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/470/trades/create/safe
    • California (65 / 65)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/472/trades/create/safe
    • Colorado (45.9 / 61.4)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/473/trades/create/safe
    • Georgia (48.4 / 52.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/477/trades/create/safe
    • Nevada (55.3 / 62.5)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/499/trades/create/safe
    • New Mexico (58.1 / 51.1)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/502/trades/create/safe
    • Texas (48.8 / 51.2)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/520/trades/create/safe
    • Utah (53.3 / 44.3)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/522/trades/create/safe
    • Wyoming (60.9 / 53.9)?https://scicast.org/#!/questions/528/trades/create/safe
  • These are primarily Western states with young populations. ?They are near the average of U.S. states on variables such as population politics, longevity, and DTAP vaccination rates.
  • The vaccination rate of the group will be determined by calculating an unweighted arithmetic mean of the 2013 data for the 10 states.
Related Predict Question:?What percentage of the US female population aged 13-17 will be vaccinated against HPV by the end of 2013?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here: http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

Clusters of states were created by first analyzing state-level variables that correlate with HPV vaccination coverage in 2011 and 2012. The model for predicting HPV vaccination coverage explained over half the variation among states. On the most useful variables, states in a given cluster are more similar to each other than to states in other clusters. The range of possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 56.5%, the "Between 56.5% and 58.0%" range will be deemed correct.

name: How many states will report at least one 2014 case of a human West Nile infection to the CDC by 1 July 2014?
question_text:
• West Nile virus is an arthropod-borne virus (arbovirus) most commonly spread by infected mosquitoes. West Nile virus can cause febrile illness, encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or meningitis (inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal cord).
  • As of January 7, 2014, 48 states and the District of Columbia reported cases of West Nile virus infections that occurred in 2013 in people, birds, or mosquitoes. A total of 2,374 cases of West Nile virus disease in people, including 114 deaths, have been reported to CDC for 2013. The only two states that did not report a West Nile virus infection in 2013 were Alaska and Hawaii.
  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US at http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • Since it is more likely West Nile infections will appear in a few states by July 1 rather than many states, the bins used in "safe mode" forecasting are asymmetrical based approximately on a log scale.
  • CDC case count is updated once a week during the transmission season.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2014

Resolution Source

  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US. Reports of WNV human disease cases?on their?surveillance page will resolve this question - http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • CDC case counts are updated once a week during the transmission season. The first update after July 1, 2014 will be used to resolve this question.

keywords: gesture based security, cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Will an Android phone offer body movement-based security by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Mobile phone security has become more important as more phones are used to store valuable private data and proprietary data. Notwithstanding this increasing importance, mobile phone passwords are only intermittently used given their inconvenience, and often subject to easy discovery.

In the search for better computer security, including better mobile security, computer scientists are doing research on using human gestures and body movements as a form of password protection. Researchers have found that the way people bring their phones to their ears while answering a call is as distinct as a fingerprint. The precised take up speed and angle is almost impossible for others to replicate. This is something that may be used in place of a password.

For more information, see:

  • http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2500434
  • http://www.researchgate.net/publication/235988370_Gesture-based_User_Authentication_for_Mobile_Devic...
  • http://rd.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10207-012-0154-9

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The availability of gesture-based feature to the general public?on an android phone will be made via announcement from either a phone maker or app developer.

This question will resolve when this feature is first made available, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.??

Fine Print

Body movement-based security refers to any mechanism that unlocks a mobile phone, as an alternative to a password, that relies on a phone's measurement of any movement of the operator's body or of his or her movement of the phone; it excludes activities meant to draw patterns on the phone screen.This question refers to a product feature offered to the general public for sale, not a test of the product. It may be implemented either as a hardware feature or via an app.

name: Will the number of preprint submissions to arXiv be over 9,000 during any single month in the first quarter of 2015?
question_text:
?ArXiv?is an Open Archives Initiative (OAI)-compliant online archive of electronic preprints in physics, mathematics, computer science,?quantitative biology, quantitative finance and statistics.?In many fields of mathematics and physics, almost all scientific papers are?self-archived?on?arXiv. Begun on August 14, 1991, arXiv.org passed the half-million article milestone on October 3, 2008.?By 2012 the submission rate had grown to more than 7,000 per month. According to the arXiv statistics, in late 2014, the monthly submission rate was well over 8,000, peaking at 8,871 in October.

arXiv monthly submission rate:?http://arxiv.org/stats/get_monthly_submissions

name: Will a clinical trial using selenized milk protein supplements for cancer treatment start recruiting participants before the end of 2014?
question_text:
It has been suggested that dietary selenium has the potential to reduce the growth of mammary tumors. Recent research report by scientists from the University of Guelph in Ontario, Canada indicated that dietary Se from selenized casein could effectively reduce the progress of intramammary MCF-7 tumors in mice. The result shows promise for selenized milk protein as an effective supplement during chemotherapy.

Selenized milk casein in the diet of BALB/c nude mice reduces growth of intramammary MCF-7 tumors: http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2407/13/492

categories: Biology & Medicine,Computational Sciences,Information Systems,Engineered Technologies,Prize-Eligible Dec & Feb
keywords: biometrics, iris scanning, retina scanning, security, information security, cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Will an eye-based biometric security system breach in the United States be reported by March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Biometric security refers to the use of human physiological characteristics and traits as a form of identification and access control. It is used to control physical access to specific locations and? computer and data systems. Biometric security mechanisms are generally thought to be more secure than alternative forms of security as they rely on physical characteristics that are unique to individuals, such as fingerprints.

Retinal and iris scanning are two forms of biometric security that rely on tissue patterns in the iris and blood vessels patterns in the retina, respectively, to identify individuals. These eye-based mechanisms are quickly becoming popular forms of security, in large part because they are believed to be very secure. However, a? research team from Universidad Autonoma de Madrid and West Virginia University have created an artificial iris image that was able to fool an iris scanning system.

To breach an eye-based security system in the manner demonstrated by the research team, a hacker would need to access the database that holds the iris scans, stored as templates or digital records of an individual's biometric feature.

Links and sources:
  • http://phys.org/news/2012-07-black-hat-iris-scanning-breach.html#jCp
  • http://findbiometrics.com/applications/biometrics-security/
  • http://blog.m2sys.com/biometric-hardware/iris-recognition-vs-retina-scanning-what-are-the-difference...
  • http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-04-28/iris-scans-seen-shrinking-7-billion-medical-data-breach.htm...
  • http://phys.org/news/2012-07-black-hat-iris-scanning-breach.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

The breach of an eye-based biometrics security system will be reported in the popular press.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

An eye-based biometric security system here is defined as one that uses either tissue patterns in the iris and blood vessels patterns in the retina.A breach here refers to the unwanted breach of an operating security system by an outsider and does not include systems tests or other research projects.

name: On November 2015, what will be the Top 500 performance share by geographic region?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The November? 2015? ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conferencee is scheduled to occur between November 15, 2015 ? November 20, 2015.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by geographic region, and you think North America?s machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust North America?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list
short_name: Top 500 performance share by region NOV-15

name: In 2015, how many weather and climate disaster events with losses exceeding $1 billion will occur in the United States?
question_text:
The National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) maintains a massive archive of weather-related data. As part of this archive, NCDC tracks and evaluates climate events in the U.S. and globally that have great economic and societal impacts, including the damages/costs of extreme weather events, including tropical storms, droughts, winter storms, wildfires, etc.

In 2014, NCDC found there were were 8 weather and climate disaster events with losses exceeding $1 billion each across the United States. How many such events will occur in 2015, according to NCDC?

  • NCDC -? Billion Dollar Climate and Weather Disasters Overview

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

NCDC will announce how many weather and climate disaster events with losses exceeding $1 billion occured in 2015 on their website, which should be updated in early 2016.

http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions/


For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

keywords: Flu, national, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the U.S. 2014-2015 flu season?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select National
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across all HHS regions (i.e., the continental U.S.).

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

choices_field_5: No new record will be set by question deadline
name: How fast will the next 100 meter human sprinting world record be?
question_text:
The 100meter race represents the fastest standard human race distance, in terms ofaverage meters per second. It optimizes the tradeoff between minimizing timespend at the slow speed which occurs at the start of any race (prior to racers reachingtheir top speed) and the point at which runners begin to lose speed due to fatigue.

Since 1965,the world record for the 100 meter race has fallen from 10.06 seconds to 9.58seconds, set in 2009 by Usain Bolt. This represents a roughly 0.01 secondimprovement per year, though the improvements tend to be lumpy. For example,the record prior to 9.58 seconds was 9.69 seconds, a full 0.11 seconds slower.

This increasedhuman speed has come about due to steady improvement in sports science and medicine. It hasbeen suggested by Stanford biologist Mark Denny that the limit to human speed,for natural humans, is a 9.48 second 100 meter run.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2013-05/fyi-there-limit-how-fast-human-can-run
  • http://sciencebasedrunning.com/2011/07/dave/
  • http://io9.com/the-physics-of-usain-bolts-world-record-100-meter-dash-924744818
  • http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/62/World_record_progression_100m_men.svg


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

Official newworld records in track and field are routinely reported in the popular press.



Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the next world record is 9.45s. the "9.45 to 9.50 seconds" range will be deemed correct.

choices_field_3: Will not be achieved by January 1, 2017
name: The HiSentinel program was a family of high altitude airship that had five test flights achieve altitudes over 66,000 ft for 8 hours around 2010. When will a maneuverable airship achieve an altitude over 66,000 feet and float for at least 24 hours?
question_text:
• Airships (dirigibles) are lighter-than-air aircraft that can navigate under their own power. Possibly the most famous airship, the Hindenburg, was filled with hydrogen that burned in 1937.?? Airships were popular in the early 1900s, but declined in popularity after disasters such as the Hindenburg. Helium is used now making them much safer.
  • While large-scale passenger applications were suspended in the mid-1900s, development focused on military applications for surveillance until resource issues diverted R&D funds from airships. However, recently non-defense-related attention returned to airships as low-carbon methods for transporting goods, as carriers for telescopes to scan the skies, and as instrument carriers to measure the atmosphere. Airships have high spatial and temporal resolution, daily to seasonal coverage, and local to regional spatial coverage.
  • In Febuary 2014, the Keck Institute for Space Studies published Airships: A New Horizon for Science, a report that reviewed ?the potential of a variety of airships currently operable or under development to serve as observatories and science instrumentation platforms for a range of space, atmospheric and Earth science.? The authors ?found considerable scientific value in both low altitude (< 40 kft) and high altitude (> 60 kft) airships across a wide spectrum of space, atmospheric, and Earth science programs.? Therefore, the authors call for a prize ?for the development of a maneuverable, station-keeping, stratospheric airship, which can stay aloft at an altitude above 65 kft (20 km) for at least a full diurnal cycle (>20 hours) while carrying a science payload of at least 20 kg in mass? as part of a roadmap to stratospheric airship observatories.
Links and sources
  • Airships: A New Horizon for Science? http://kiss.caltech.edu/study/airship/final-report.pdf
  • The flying bum! 300ft-long 'airship' unveiled in Britain is the world's longest aircraft http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2570118/Worlds-longest-aircraft-revealed-300ft-long-a...
  • http://kiss.caltech.edu/workshops/airship2013/presentations/smith.pdf
  • http://www.defenseinnovationmarketplace.mil/resources/Final_LTA_report.pd

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

Press release or other official announcement from company or research group.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

An airship can be a rigid, semi-rigid, or non-rigid lighter-than-air vehicles that can generate their own thrust for maneuvers.

name: Before the end of 2015, will Merck submit an IND for an intranasal respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) vaccine using nanoemulsion adjuvant technology?
question_text:
NanoBio Corp, a bio pharmaceutical spin-out of the University of Michigan's Center for Biologic Nanotechnology,?recently announced a license agreement with a subsidiary of Merck & Co., Inc. for the use of its nanoemulsion (NE) adjuvant technology. Under the agreement, Merck receives exclusive rights to NanoBio's NE adjuvant for use in an intranasal?respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) vaccine.? Merck and NanoBio had been engaged in preclinical collaboration on the development of the RSV vaccine since 2011. RSV is one of the main causes of pneumonia and bronchiolitis in children.

keywords: Flu, Region 6, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 6 (AR, LA, NM, OK, and TX)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 6' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases in Region 6 for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across HHS region 6. Region 6 is comprised of New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

name: Will D, the programming language, be among the ten most Googled software technologies in the US in any month during 2015?
question_text:
D is an?object-oriented,?imperative,?multi-paradigm?system programming language?created by?Walter Bright?and?Andrei Alexandrescu. Though it originated as a re-engineering of?C++, D is a distinct language, having redesigned some core C++ features while also taking inspiration from other languages, notably?Java,?Python,?Ruby, C#, and?Eiffel.

Facebook is the most high-profile D user. But it is not alone. Sociomantic?a German online advertising outfit recently purchased by British grocery giant Tesco for a reported $200 million?has built its operation in D. About 10,000 people download the D platform each month.

D was the 17th most Googled Software Technologies term in 2014.

keywords: carbon dioxide emissions, fossil fuels, power plants, climate change, chemistry
name: Will carbon dioxide emissions from fossil-fuel power plants in the U.S. be 10% lower in 2016 than they were in 2011?
question_text:
In June 2nd, 2014, the Obama Administration announced proposed rules to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from the nation's existing power plants. The goal is to cut?greenhouse gas emissions from the U.S. power sector by up to 30% by 2030, relative to 2005 levels.?The plan calls for using the Environmental Protection Agency?s (EPA?s) authority under the Clean Air Act to target greenhouse gas emissions from the nation?s roughly 1000 fossil-fuel power plants. These plants emitted more than 2 billion tons of carbon dioxide in 2011, about 40% of U.S. carbon dioxide emissions.?The rules are now under public comment and set to be finalized next year.?However, legal opposition against the?implementation of the regulations is expected.?

  • http://www2.epa.gov/carbon-pollution-standards/clean-power-plan-proposed-rule

12/31/2016

Fine Print

Fossil fuel power plants burn fossil fuels such as coal, natural gas, petroleum (oil) - or any solid, liquid, or gaseous fuel derived from such materials - to produce electricity. The EPA data reports that in 2012 the total carbon dioxide emission from fossil fuel power plants was 2,078 million metric tons in the U.S.

question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Citrus Fruits Summary' following the conclusion ?of the marketing season in September. This full-text report contains the annual summary, by state and citrus fruit crop, of acreage, yield, production, utilization (fresh and processed), price, and value of the current year crop and revised previous two years' crop.
  • All U.S. orange production for the 2012-2013 marketing season totaled 8,349,000 tons.
  • Orange production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as oranges are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is?the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary'.?

Orange production is reported in thousands of tons, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. orange production' includes Valencia, Early, Midseason, and Navel varieties.

The '2013-2014 marketing season' for Valencia oranges ?begins 01/01/2013 and ends 12/20/2013. The '2013-2014 marketing season' for Early, Midseason, and Navel oranges begins 09/25/2013 and ends 06/15/2014.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Citrus Fruits 2014 Summary' that is published annually in September.

question_text:
US scientists have recently discovered a microorganism that anaerobically degrades plant biomass to release sugar for biofuel feedstocks. At present, this is the only known anaerobic microbe capable of solubilising all plant components - including cellulose, glucose, and lignin, all at the same time and at similar rates. name: Will quantum key distribution be integrated into a prototype mobile device by 1 January 2016?
question_text:
Quantum key distribution (QKD) uses quantum mechanics to guarantee secure communication. It enables two parties to produce a shared random secret key known only to them, which can then be used to encrypt and decrypt messages.

Messages can be encrypted and transmitted using traditional techniques; however, the key to encrypt and decrypt messages is encrypted exploiting quantum mechanical properties of photons. This method guarantees secure communication between two parties, because, due to quantum indeterminacy, the key cannot be observed by a third party without changing the quantum states. If the key is observed, it is changed in ways such as the receiver can detect eavesdropping and communication is stopped.

Current quantum cryptography technology is expensive and bulky, which limits it to fixed physical locations. However, recent advances by Zhang et al. enables one party using QKD to decode the key using an optical chip and? ?opens the way for quantum enhanced secure communications between companies and members of the general public equipped with handheld mobile devices, via telecom-fiber tethering.?

Links and Sources

  • University of Bristol. "Quantum cryptography for mobile phones." www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/04/140403132331.htm
  • Zhang et al. Reference-Frame-Independent Quantum-Key-Distribution Server with a Telecom Tether for an On-Chip Client. Physical Review Letters, 2014; 112 (13) DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.112.130501
  • Physicists Test Quantum Cryptography For Handheld Mobile Devices http://www.technologyreview.com/view/518451/physicists-test-quantum-cryptography-for-handheld-mobile...
  • HP Press Release: Quantum Key Distribution: Systems Security Lab http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press_kits/2008/hplabsemea/demo-qkd.pdf
  • Mitsubishi Electric: Quantum Cryptography http://www.mitsubishielectric.com/company/rd/research/highlights/communications/quantum.html
  • Quantum key distribution http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_key_distribution
