name: Where will the Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 be found?
question_text:
Note: Answer choices are based on the map regions below.

On March 8, 2014, a Boeing 777 aircraft operating under Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 went missing on its directed route from KualaLumpur to Beijing.? The aircraft consisted of 227 total passengers and 12 crew members which departed from Kuala Lumpur International Airport at 12:41 am.? The aircraft sent its last transponder signal at 1:21 am and lost radar signal at1:30 am, thereby losing contact.? A search and rescue mission currently spans up to 100,000 nautical miles including theSouth China Sea near the location of the last transponder signal.? In addition to the Malacca Strait along thewest coast of Malaysia and the Andaman Sea.? There are some?indications the aircraft may have traveled westward as far as into the Indian Ocean.

Bayesian search theory began with vessels and objects missing at sea, and is most highly developed for nautical environments. ?Although the core work is highly mathematical, it often begins with subjective weighing of scenarios and integration of initially sparse and?conflicting information. ?SciCast provides a platform to do this, and to relate scenarios to outcomes. ?Although we do not have an elegant map interface, we would like to see how well we can collectively integrate disparate information and update over time.?

Search Regions Map

(Based on this?Australian Broadcast Corp. map.)



Lettered Regions:

  • A: Expanded search region between Gulf of Thailand and South China Sea (mostly north and east of last radar position)
  • B: In the search region on Malaysia (southwest of last radar position)
  • C: Search region in the Strait of Malacca (west/southwest of the last radar position)
  • D: Expanded search region in Strait of Malacca and Andaman Sea (far west of last radar position)
  • E: In the Gulf of Thailand, outside the expanded search region
  • F: In the Andaman Sea, outside the expanded search region
  • G: Elsewhere

Relevant Links:


  • Malaysia Airlines:?What we know about flight MH370
  • Theories Grow without Facts on Lost Flight
  • Malaysia Airliner Communications Shut Down Separately:? US Officials Say
  • Popular Reddit Feed
  • SciCast question on MH370 Scenario
  • Sharon Bertsch-McGrayne's?The Theory that Would not Die?(esp. ?chapter 15)?presents a recent popular account of Bayesian search theory. The 2nd edition includes an appendix on the search for Air France Flight 447.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2014

Resolution Source

OfficialMalaysian government news reported in?mainstream news sources (e.g. CNN, BBC, Reuters, AP). We will wait at least 24 hours for possible retractions or clarifications.

Fine Print

For this question, MH 370 will be deemed to have been found when official sources have located the aircraft, or a debris field positively linked to the aircraft. (If the aircraft sank in the ocean, a separate question may be issued for location on the ocean floor. An underwater search could take years.)

question_text:
The 2014 Atlantic tropical storm names are predetermined. The National Hurricane Center has them listed as: Arthur, Bertha, Cristobal, Dolly, Edouard, Fay, Gonzalo, Hanna, Isaias, Josephine, Kyle, Laura, Marco, Nana, Omar, Paulette, Rene, Sally, Teddy, Vicky, and Wilfred. name: When will a lung cancer vaccine be approved by the FDA for clinical use in humans?
question_text:
Several types of vaccines for boosting the body?s immune response against lung cancer cells are currently being tested in clinical trials. Unlike vaccines against infections like measles or mumps, these vaccines are designed to help treat, but not necessarily prevent, lung cancer. These types of treatments seem to have very limited side effects, so they might be useful in people who cannot tolerate other treatments.?At this time, vaccines are only available in clinical trials.
For more information:
  • What?s new in non-small cell lung cancer research and treatment??http://www.cancer.org/cancer/lungcancer-non-smallcell/detailedguide/non-small-cell-lung-cancer-new-r...
  • Cancer Immunotherapy: A Future Paradigm Shift in the Treatment of Non?Small Cell Lung Cancer:?http://clincancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/21/5/976.short

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

NIH?clinical trial database?https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/home?and FDA approved drug database?http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cder/drugsatfda/?provide the latest information on drug approval.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

name: Will a lab-confirmed case of cephalosporin-resistant gonorrhea be reported in the US before the end of 2015?
question_text:
Gonorrhea is a common sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by infection?with bacteria.??CDC estimates that, annually, 820,000 people in the United States get new gonorrheal infections, and less than half of these infections are detected and reported to CDC. In 2013, 333,004 cases of gonorrhea were reported to CDC.

Gonorrhea is adapting quickly to antibiotic treatments. In 2007, the antibiotic ciprofloxacin lost its CDC recommendation for treating gonorrhea because studies demonstrated that 13.8% of patient samples were resistant to the drug. Between 2007 and today, the CDC has had to change the recommended gonorrhea treatment twice by increasing the dosage of the antibiotic cephalosporin and changing the drug combination. So far, no cephalosporin-resistant gonorrhea cases have been identified in the United States, according to CDC. However, several such cases have been reported in other countries, such as Japan, France and Spain. The resistant bacteria are called by CDC ?an urgent threat?.?

  • Gonorrhea is about to become impossible to treat:?http://www.theverge.com/2014/3/12/5500246/gonorrhea-is-about-to-become-impossible-to-treat
  • Super Gonorrhea Is On The Rise In The US:?http://www.businessinsider.com/ciprofloxacin-resistance-and-gonorrhea-incidence-2014-3



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Any case of infection of?cephalosporin-resistant gonorrhea?within the US is expected to be reported by the?CDC - www.cdc.gov

This question will resolve when a case is published after?the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: Will SpaceX successfully complete the first manned test flight of its Dragon V2 spacecraft before June 30, 2016?
question_text:
In May 2014, SpaceX unveiled the Dragon Version 2, a spacecraft designed to carry astronauts to the Earth's orbit and beyond.?The spacecraft will be capable of carrying up to seven crew members, landing propulsively almost anywhere on Earth, and refueling and flying again for rapid reusability.?The Dragon Version 2 builds on the success of SpaceX's Dragon cargo ships, which are already delivering supplies and equipment to the International Space Station under a $1.6 billion contract with NASA. The cargo ships are the first commercially developed spacecraft to visit the station and the only U.S.-built vehicles now flying that?are capable of bringing cargo back to Earth from orbit. According to?Elon Musk, founder and CEO of SpaceX, uncrewed test flights of Dragon Version 2?could begin as early as late?2015, with first manned test flights anticipated by mid-2016.

  • http://www.spacex.com/news/2014/05/30/dragon-v2-spacexs-next-generation-manned-spacecraft
  • http://www.cbsnews.com/news/spacex-dragon-version-2-elon-musk-future-of-nasa-space-travel/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2016

Resolution Source

SpaceX:?http://www.spacex.com/.

Note: A successful manned test flight is defined as, 'A mission with human crew on-board in which (1) the spacecraft takes off and lands to its desired destination with no damages that impairs primary functionality and (2) the crew lands with no life-threatening injuries caused by a flaw in the spacecraft?s transportation.'

name: On November 2015, what will be the Top 500 performance share by cores per socket?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The November? 2015? ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conferencee is scheduled to occur between November 15, 2015 ? November 20, 2015.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by cores per socket, and you think 8 cores/socket machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust the chances of 8 cores/socket towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Charras
name: What place will the Charras Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The Charras Team's Strategy to Win the Race:

Contractility is a key for efficient migration?in confined environments.?So we doped up our cells to make them fast and furious. Let's just hope they can still steer like Vin Diesel...

Dicty related?information from the Charras?Lab:

Neutrophil Chemotaxis: Neutrophils are the primary cells of the immune system responsible for detecting and preventing bacterial infections, as well as driving inflammation. Neutrophils circulate freely in the bloodstream, and when passing through an inflamed region attach the blood vessel wall, traverse the endothelium (transendothelial migration), and migrate through the connective tissue to the site of infection (chemotaxis). Here a neutrophil (in red) is shown migrating through a 10x3?m microfluidic channel towards a source of chemoattractant (in blue). Scale bar = 5?m. In collaboration with Dr Irimia, Massachusetts General Hospital



Useful Links
  • Link to?Charras Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

keywords: crude oil, exploration and production, enhanced oil recovery
name: By how much will global proven oil reserves change in 2014?
question_text:
Oil is the byproduct of the anaerobic decomposition of long dead and buried zooplankton and algae. As a fuel it accounts for roughly one third of all the energy production on planet Earth. Oil and gas reserves are defined according to how easily they can be recovered and separated into three categories: proven, probable, and possible. Probable and possible reserves are considered unproven. Proven reserves are considered to have a "reasonable certainty" of being recovered, though definitions of proven vary within the industry.

Total proven reserves can increase when new reserves are found (exploration), and when new technology makes a larger share of existing reserves recoverable (recovery). Technological advancements have nearly doubled the volume of reserves that ultimately are recoverable since 1980. Exploration has been enhanced through such technology as 3D geological modeling and considerable research is ongoing in the area of Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR), which applies a wide range of methods (thermal, chemical, physical, and even biological) to improve recovery.

Reserve measurement and classification requires assumptions and estimation, so estimates from different sources will not match exactly. This question uses estimates from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC). OPEC publishes an Annual Statistical Bulletin that reports proven reserves by country. The most recent bulletin reports 1,489,865 million barrels of proven crude oil reserves for the entire globe at the end of 2013, a 0.4% increase over the total reported for the end of 2012. OPEC will release the next Bulletin sometime in 2015, likely around midyear.

For more background, see:

  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2013/03/27/how-big-are-the-currently-known-oil-reserves-and-what-a...
  • http://energy.gov/fe/science-innovation/oil-gas-research/enhanced-oil-recovery
  • http://www.emgs.com/content/675/3-D-EM-addresses-exploration-challenges
  • http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/202.htm


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/30/2015

Resolution Source

OPEC?s 2015 Annual Statistical Bulletin will be available here: http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/202.htm

Fine Print

This question is asking about the change in total world proven crude oil reserves in millions of barrels between 2013 (as listed in the 2014 report) and 2014 (which will be included in the 2015 Annual Statistical Bulletin published by OPEC).

This is a Scaled (Continuous) question. Instead of estimating the chance of a particular outcome, you are asked to forecast the actual expected value, in natural units. Forecasts moving the estimate towards the actual value will be rewarded. Those moving it away will be penalized. As with probability questions, moving towards the extremes is progressively more expensive: we have merely rescaled the usual 0%-100% range and customized the interface.

Should the actual value fall outside the question range, the question will resolve at the nearest extreme. Note that it would take infinite points to move the forecast exactly to that extreme, just as it would take infinite points to move exactly to 0% or 100%.

keywords: Flu, Region 8, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 8 (CO, MO, ND, SD, UT, WY)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 8' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 8 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS region 8 is the highest. Region 8 is comprised of Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will a private organization put a human on Mars before NASA does?
question_text:
Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, recently said he is hopeful that the first people could be taken to Mars, with SpaceX rockets and spacecrafts,?in 10-12 years.?Mars One Foundation, a private not-for-profit organization, is also working on establishing human settlement on Mars. Mars One is planning a private?unmanned mission to Mars in 2018. Meanwhile, NASA is taking a more cautious approach, announcing that it would try to put?astronauts on Mars by 2035, and?only if it can secure the necessary?funding and carry out a number of important milestone missions beforehand.

  • SpaceX says it will put humans on Mars by 2026, almost 10 years ahead of NASA:?http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/184640-spacex-says-it-will-put-humans-on-mars-by-2026-almost-10-y...
  • MarsOne - first private Mars mission in 2018:?https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/mars-one-first-private-mars-mission-in-2018
  • Nasa would speak out if private manned missions to Mars too risky:?http://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2014/may/19/nasa-private-manned-missions-mars

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2025

Resolution Source

A human landing on Mars?is likely to be the leading news story worldwide. The report will be carried out by all news outlets as well NASA, SpaceX and/or Mars One.
http://www.nasa.gov/
http://www.mars-one.com/
http://www.spacex.com/

Fine Print

Mars One is a non-profit organization based in the Netherlands that has put forward conceptual plans to establish a permanent human colony on Mars by 2025. SpaceX, or Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, is a space transport services company headquartered in Hawthorne, California. It was founded in 2002 by former PayPal entrepreneur and Tesla Motors CEO Elon Musk.

For this question to resolve as true, the private organization should have received no funding from NASA in the development of their Mars program (so companies funded through programs such as the Commercial Crew Program do not count, nor do other collaborations involving NASA).

name: On November 2050, what will be the Top 500 performance share by cores per socket?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by cores/socket, and you think 8 cores/socket machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust 8 cores/socket chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

name: Engineered water nanostructures have been shown to remove up to 63% of dangerous airborne pathogens without toxic residue. What will be the next highest reported efficiency of this technology to be published?
question_text:
Airborne infectious diseases are an important public health problem affecting millions of people each year. These include viral diseases such as avian influenza (AI/H5N1) and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), as well as bacterial infections. The use and misuse of antibiotics has led to the development of drug-resistant bacteria, including resistant strains of tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and staph bacteria (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus).

Recent work by Philip Demokritou, Georgios Pyrgiotakis, and others suggests that engineered water nanostructures (EWNS) may constitute a safe, ?green,? and cost-effective new method for inactivating bacteria in the air and on surfaces. In Demokritou et al. (2014), the authors demonstrate that EWNS have the ability to inactivate airborne bacteria at twice the rate as the control. In addition, in an acute in-vivo inhalation study the EWNS did not appear to be toxic to mice. A forthcoming publication Pyrgiotakis G., et al achieves an even higher rate of inactivation; 63% of airborne mycobacteria were removed (compared to the control after 60 minutes).

A new bug killer:
http://www.economist.com/news/technology-quarterly/21603236-water-particles-could-provide-powerful-airborne-shield-against-nasty-bacteria

A chemical free, nanotechnology-based method for airborne bacterial inactivation using engineered water nanostructures:
http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlepdf/2014/en/c3en00007a?page=search

Mycobacteria inactivation using Engineered Water Nanostructures (EWNS):
http://www.nanomedjournal.com/article/S1549-9634%2814%2900119-1/abstract

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2017

Resolution Source

The findings must be published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

The percentage reduction is as compared to a control group after 60 minutes, and may be for any airborne bacteria. The next paper must have an increase in percent reduction compared to the cited paper for this question to resolve.This is a Scaled Continuous question. For more information on how betting works for this question, please see the following link: http://blog.scicast.org/2014/06/23/scaled-continuous-question/This question will resolve as "63%" if no higher efficiency is reported in a journal by the question deadline.

keywords: EVB, Lithium, Electric Cars, Electric Batteries, chemistry
name: Which of the following battery types mentioned in the C&EN July 2014 issue will be the first to be used in an electric car sold by 2020?
question_text:
The July 2014 Issue of Chemical and Engineering News (C&EN) discussed the current state of the electric car battery industry and future electric vehicle battery (EVB) technologies.? Currently one of the limiting factors of electric cars competing with combustion engine-based cars is the costly price of EVB's.? Tesla recently launched the Model S which is on par with the performance of many combustion based cars, however comes with an $80,000 price tag and says the battery accounts for less than half the cost of the car.? Most electric cars currently operate on lithium-ion based batteries like the Tesla Models, or nickel metal hydride (NiMH) batteries which is used in the Toyota Prius Hybrid.?

However several companies and research firms are aiming to developing other technologies to create more cost effective alternatives, while matching the performance of current EVB's.? Faradion is developing a sodium-ion (Na-ion) battery and says is on the track to be one third cheaper than lithium-ion based batteries, while matching the performance.? BASF is researching lithium metal-sulfur batteries which has a theoretical energy density nearly five times that of traditional lithium-ion batteries.? Andreas Fischer, head of the battery materials research at BASF says it may be introduced after 2020.? A handful of other companies are also developing lithium-sulfur batteries such as Oxis Energy, whose CEO Huw Jones believes that in the next few years lithium-sulfur will become competitive on price with lithium-ion and aims to develop the product by late 2016.? IBM is also working on lithium-air batteries, named the Battery 500 Project.? Other analysts and Elon Musk, founder of Tesla are looking to make improvements on current lithium-ion batteries for the future, rather than researching other materials.? Musk was asked if he would stick to lithium-ion for the future and responded, "I really don't know anything better" and is aiming to increase the energy density of lithium-ion by about 8% annually.? Other companies such as Toyota and Sakti3 are developing solid state lithium-ion batteries, which Toyota expects to be ready by the early 2020's.? This question asks if any of these new EVB technologies will make it to the market by 2020.

Relevant Links:

  • Chemistry's Electric Opportunity [C&EN]
  • Revisiting Lithium-Sulfur Batteries [MIT Tech Review]
  • Solid State Batteries [MIT Tech Review]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved to the first battery technology that is used in a commercially available electric car by 2020.? This will be verified by major news sources or the car manufacturers specs page which lists the type of battery used, for example the Nissan Leaf Spec page.

Fine Print

An 'electric car' is defined as an automobile that is powered entirely by electricity (i.e. through electric motors and electric energy stored in batteries or other storage devices'). An electric car as defined here does not include automobiles powered partially by electricity such as hybrid electric vehicles. 'Commercially available' means the car is available to the general public for purchase. If the electric car has more than one of the batteries listed, the question will be settled using a mixture resolution with an equal proportion going to the battery types used in the car.

keywords: Number Theory, Primes, Twin Primes, Prime Gaps
name: Will the gap bound between primes shrink to under 100 by 31 DEC 2014?
question_text:
In May of 2013 Yitang Zhang proved the existence of a finite bound B such that there are infinitely many pairs of primes p, q, such that q - p < B. ?Zhang's bound was 70 million. ?A collaborative group polymath reduced the bound further to 4680 and independently James Maynard in Nov. 2013 reduced the bound to 600. ?It is theoretically possible to reduce the bound to 12, but there is no proof for a bound lower than 600 yet. ?This issue is related to the famous twin prime conjecture.

Not sure

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

A proof will be provided in a refereed math journal.

name: Which automobile will win the North American Truck of the Year award at the 2015 NAIAS?
question_text:
The North American Car and Truck of the Year (NACTOY) Awards are automobile awards announced at a news conference at the annual North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) in Detroit, Michigan.? The evaluation team consists of approximately 50 expert automotive journalists from across the U.S. and Canada.? The nomination and voting process is as follows:? The initial voting of the jurors in early Fall results in the 'long list' of vehicles (which are the answer choices in this question).? A shorter list of a dozen or so vehicles are selected from this long list to form the 'short list' which is announced in late September/October.? After this a further period of assessment which occurs in December results in three finalists.? A final round of voting is commenced afterwards, with the winners announced at the NAIAS in January.? This question asks which automobile will win the North American Truck of the Year award at the 2015 NAIAS.

keywords: Li-Fi, LiFi, VLC, Optical Wireless Communication
name: Will Li-Fi achieving a transmission rate of 40Gbps be reported by the end of March 2015?
question_text:
Li-Fi is bidirectional, high speed and fully networked wireless communication (akin to?Wi-Fi) using visible light rather than radio waves. The term was coined by Prof. Harald Haas during his TED Global talk in 2011.Li-Fi is a subset of?visible light communication?(VLC) and can be a complement to?RF communication?(Wi-Fi?or Cellular network), or a replacement in contexts of data broadcasting.?It has been proposed as a solution to?RF-bandwidth limitations.In 2014,?Russian company?Stins Coman?announced the development of a Li-Fi wireless local network called BeamCaster. Their current module transfers data at 10 Gbps?but they foresee boosting speeds up to 40 Gbps?in the near future.

  • Li-Fi:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li-Fi

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

Announcement?may be reported online on Gizmag (gizmag.com) and other major news outlets such as BBC (bbc.com) and CNN (cnn.com)

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Missouri?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Missouri, 51.6% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +2.1% from 2011 (49.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 50.7%, the "50.7%-54.1%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will the FDA approve a new small molecule antibiotic before 1 January 2016?
question_text:
• Antibacterial drug resistance ?threatens the achievements of modern medicine? according to the World Health Organization (WHO). A recent report found high rates of resistance to at least one type of bacteria in almost every one of the 114 members states that gave the organization data.
  • The number of systemic antibacterial agents approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have decreased significantly. Between 1983 and 1987, 15 new agents were approved compared to two agents approved between 2008 and 2013.? Because of the decrease, the FDA?s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research created an Antibacterial Drug Development Task Force to support the development of new antibacterial drugs.? In addition, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases? Antibacterial Resistance Program supports research specifically in antibacterial drugs.
  • In 2013, the Infectious Disease Society of America reported that only a single new antibiotic (ceftaroline fosamil) has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) since 2010.
  • ?In late September 2013, Butler et al. reported in The Journal of Antibiotics that 16 small molecule antibiotics were in phase-III clinical trials or under non-disclosure agreements (NDA) or MMA review.? As of May 2, 2014, none of these antibiotics had been approved by the FDA.
Links and sources
  • ?WHO?s first global report on antibiotic resistance reveals serious, worldwide threat to public health.? http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2014/amr-report/en/
  • National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases? Antibacterial Resistance Program? http://www.niaid.nih.gov/topics/antimicrobialresistance/Pages/default.aspx
  • Butler, M. et al. ?Antibiotics in the clinical pipeline in 2013.? The Journal of Antibiotics (2013) 66, 571?591; doi:10.1038/ja.2013.86; published online 4 September 2013
  • 10 ? '20 Progress?Development of New Drugs Active Against Gram-Negative Bacilli: An Update From the Infectious Diseases Society of America http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/12/1685

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

US FDA http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/Scripts/cder/drugsatfda/index.cfm

keywords: Flu, Region 8, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 8 (CO, MO, ND, SD, UT, WY)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???

  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 8' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 8 will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 8. Region 8 is comprised of Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: On November 2017, what will be the Top 500 performance share by cores per socket?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

<div>Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.?</div><div>NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution. ?For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by cores per socket, and you think 8 core/socket machines will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust the chances of 8 core/socket machines towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution. ?(See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)</div>

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

categories: Business of Science,Computational Sciences,Information Systems,Engineered Technologies,Physics,Prize-Eligible Nov & Jan
keywords: tactical glasses, augmented reality, Google glass,weapons detection
name: Will the US Army issue tactical glasses equipped with augmented reality technology to detect enemy weaponry and IEDs on the battlefront by the end of 2015?
question_text:
?Augmented reality? (AR) is the technology that superimposes a computer-generated image on a user?s view of the real world, hence providing a composite view. In commercial applications, smartphone apps using AR have revolutionized travel by superimposing data on hotels, restaurants, and tourist spots atop the real world. Google Glass further revolutionized the world of computing by making it wearable and hands-free, making AR more mainstream.

The US Army is working to equip dismounted soldiers on the battlefront with wearable computers like Google Glass to provide tactical information flow and protection from enemy forces in their environment. The Army is collaborating with different organizations to come up with a head-mounted, see-through display technology that can increase soldiers? awareness of their surroundings by providing information about what is not visible to the naked eye. For example, this technology can help detect snipers hiding, out of plain sight, behind a building on the battlefront. DARPA is testing a prototype developed through the Urban Leader Tactical Response, Awareness and Visualization (ULTRA-Vis) program.

http://www.afcea.org/content/?q=node/13002
http://trajectorymagazine.com/component/k2/item/1621-augmenting-reality.html
DARPA


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that the technology is being used on the ground, either as a standalone wearable or as a feature in another combat-ready wearable device or technology.

Fine Print

The tactical glasses must be equipped with augmented reality (AR) technology that can superimpose a computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, graphics or GPS data on a user?s live view of the real world in a combat zone for enhanced battlefront intelligence.

name: Did hackers gain access to the personal data of celebrities via a vulnerability in Apple's Find My iPhone service?
question_text:
Apple Inc. said it is investigating reports that vulnerabilities in its iCloud service were exploited to hack the accounts of celebrities, leading to the publication of nude photos and videos. Initial media reports suggested that the hacks stemmed from individual accounts on iCloud, an online service to store photos, music and other data from Apple devices.

A posting on online code-sharing site GitHub said a user had discovered a bug in Apple's Find My iPhone service, which tracks the location of a missing phone and allows a user to disable the phone remotely if it is stolen. The bug allowed a hacker to keep trying passwords until identifying the right one.

Most online services lock down an account after multiple incorrect password attempts to prevent this type of so-called "brute force" attacks. The GitHub post was updated on Monday to read: "The end of fun, Apple have just patched." ~WSJ

  • Apple Investigating Reports of iCloud Vulnerabilities [WSJ]
  • Apple Denies iCloud Breach [WSJ]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/01/14

Resolution Source

A statement from a spokesperson at Apple Inc. or another reputable organization conducting an investigation (e.g. Federal Bureau of Investigation) will be used to settle this question.

Fine Print

The question will resolve as 'Yes' if at least one celebrity's personal data was compromised by hackers employing a 'brute force' attack to gain passwords and/or appleIDs. This question will resolve as 'no' if neither a reputable investigative organization nor Apple itself release a statement by the question deadline indicating an account was breached using the bug in the Find My iPhone service.

name: When will a prototype of a nanomachine containing a nanomotor and intended for drug delivery be built in lab?
question_text:
Chemotherapy is just one application where it would be preferable for drugs to be delivered to just the tumor instead of to the tumor and all the healthy cells in the body as currently done. One way to deliver medicine in this fashion is through nanomachines. These machines measure less than a micron and can be injected into the body to find tumors or other specific cells. Once found, the nanomachine could release the drug in a very targeted fashion. Currently these machines exist in different forms, but not in the form with a nanomotor and the ability to deliver drugs in the body. However, recent advances in nanomotors make this more of a possibility than before.

Links and sources
  • Smallest and Fastest Nanomotor Could Advance Drug Delivery http://spectrum.ieee.org/nanoclast/biomedical/devices/smallest-and-fastest-nanomotors-to-date-could-advance-drug-delivery
  • Nakano, T., et al. Cooperative drug delivery through molecular communication among biological nanomachines. in Communications Workshops (ICC), 2013 IEEE International Conference on. 2013. http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=6649344&tag=1
  • Kim, K., et al., Ultrahigh-speed rotating nanoelectromechanical system devices assembled from nanoscale building blocks. Nat Commun, 2014. 5. http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2014/140407/ncomms4632/full/ncomms4632.html
  • Wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanorobotics#Nanomedicine

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

Fine Print

The prototype must be on the nano-scale (less than a micrometer) with a mechanical working motor and shown to be able to carry and release drugs.

name: When will a car company first debut a production model of a car capable of vehicle to vehicle (V2V) communication and vehicle to infrastructure (V2I) communication?
question_text:
In IEEE's Spectrum 50th Anniversary Issue (June 2014) the future we will see is one complete with?autonomous vehicle navigation. Within the issue, IEEE makes a speculation that within the next decade?vehicles will make a drastic shift toward autonomous vehicle navigation. The next major milestone is predicted to be V2V and V2I communication.

  • Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) Communications for Safety
  • Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) Communications for Safety

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when a production model of a?vehicle with functioning V2V and V2I capabilities is publicly debuted. Both capabilities must be present within the vehicle for the question to resolve. Look for updates and the question resolution in IEEE Spectrum Newletter: Cars That Think?or any major news source, inclusive of auto show updates.

Fine Print

Vehicle-to-infrastructure communications - wireless exchange of critical safety and operational data between vehicles and highway infrastructure, intended primarily to avoid or mitigate motor vehicle crashes but also to enabe a wide range of other safety, mobility, and environmental benefits. The Department of Transportation's definition of 'infrastructure' will be used for purposes of this question: "Includes highway equipment, systems, and structures (other than vehicles) such as roadside signals (stoplights, warnings, variable message signs, etc.), traffic management centers, weather information systems, or signal phase and timing systems, among others." - See more at: http://www.its.dot.gov/research/v2i.htm#sthash.19yNriK9.dpuf

Vehicle-to-vehicle communications - dynamic wireless exchange of data between nearby vehicles that offers the opportunity for significant safety improvements - See more at: http://www.its.dot.gov/research/v2v.htm#sthash.XmB6Qpzi.dpuf
short_name: V2V and V2I production model debut

name: In which branch will the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry be awarded?
question_text:
Established in 1900, the Nobel Foundation awards the annual Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Economic Sciences, Literature, and Peace. ?Recipients must be living, and in no case may the prize be divided among more than three persons. ?Between 1901 and 2013, 561 prizes have been awarded. ?In some years, some prizes have not been awarded: the latest was 1972 when the Peace prize was not awarded. (Source: http://www.nobelprize.org)

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on reporting by?www.nobelprize.org. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from NobelPrize.org. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

name: When will Facebook release an update to its photo tagging system that utilizes its new facial recognition software?
question_text:
A wide variety of companies and government agencies are interested in the potential of facial recognition software.? For government agencies the interest lies mainly in law and national security.? Numerous police departments in the US and recently the Calgary police in Canada have adopted facial recognition as a method of tracking down criminals.? Thus far there is no evidence that the police departments are comparing surveillance footage with ordinary citizens; rather, they use mug shots of known criminals and compare that to footage of criminals in the act.? However, privacy activists have pointed out the danger that in the future the comparison database will include driver's license photos, so every citizen can be tracked.

The National Institute of Standards and Statistics (NIST) recently ran a test of the variety of facial recognition services now on the market.? The accuracy varied wildly based on the quality of the photo, the number of images to search through, and age of the subject.? Younger subjects have more similar faces than older faces and therefore it is more difficult for the software to accurately identify young people.? The error rate of results ranged from 4.1% for the best software under the best circumstances, to 66.9% with the worst software and worst circumstances.? Other sources put the error rate of the FBI facial recognition software at around 20%, leading to concerns that false positives may become problematic, particularly if the comparison database is expanded to include driver's license photos.

In the private sector Facebook is also pursuing facial recognition software, ostensibly as an improvement over its current photo tagging system (see their paper here).? They have managed to reach an error rate of only 2.75%.? When it comes to recognizing the faces of other humans, people have an error rate of 2.47%, suggesting that Facebook is getting close to human levels of accuracy.? Part of their success is due to an advance they have made in one of the tricky areas of facial recognition.? Often in photographs the entire face of a person is not visible, rendering ordinary facial comparison difficult as it removes many of the comparison points.? Facebook has developed an algorithm which takes a face and adjusts it so that every face is compared at the same angle.? This technique has significantly improved their accuracy. ?

Sources:
https://www.facebook.com/download/233199633549733/deepface.pdf
http://rt.com/usa/deepface-instantaneous-facial-recognition-facebook-706/
https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1354579-nist-8009.html
http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/11/more-police-departments-are-using-facial-recognition-technology/
http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/09/fbi-facial-recognition-system-at-full-operational-capability/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2016

Resolution Source

Announced in an official Facebook announcement.
Previous announcements have been posted here: https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook/making-photo-tagging-easier/467145887130

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

name: Will a lab build a 20 tesla bore field in a superconducting dipole magnet by 2020?
question_text:
Accelerator magnets, in particular, the high-field superconducting magnets, are required for the next generation hadron colliders. The state-of-art (2014) is about 13.5 T in a Nb3Sn dipole magnet based on the block design (HD3). Insert coils based on high-temperature superconductors are probably necessary to reach the 20 T bore field in a dipole magnet as it is beyond the limit of Nb3Sn conductor. A few labs in the US, Europe (CERN), and Asia are working hard to push the performance boundary while making it cost-effective in the mean time.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2020

Resolution Source

This question will resolve based on?a news?release?or published papers from the following laboratories which are actively pursuing the R&D:
www.bnl.gov
www.fnal.gov
www.lbl.gov
http://home.web.cern.ch/
www.ihep.ac.cn
www.kek.jp

Fine Print

The magnet must be successfully demonstrated in a lab, but does not have to be installed in an accelerator complex by the question deadline.

name: By the end of March 2015, will there be at least 1,000 CHAdeMO quick charging stations for battery electric vehicles in the United States?
question_text:
CHAdeMO is the trade name?for a quick-charging method for battery electric vehicles. It delivers up to 62.5 kW of high-voltage direct current via a special electrical connector, and?is proposed as a global industry standard by an association of the same name. CHAdeMO is an abbreviation of "CHArge de MOve", equivalent to "charge for moving". The name is a pun?on O cha demo ikaga desukain Japanese, which translates to English as "How about some tea?", referring to the time it would take to charge a car. CHAdeMO can charge low-range electric cars in less than half an hour. According to the information posted on the official CHAdeMO Association's website, there were 744 CHAdeMO DC Quick chargers installed in the United States?as of November 26, 2014.

keywords: Particle physics, quantum mechanics, axion, dark matter, Axion Dark Matter Experiment, Nobel Prize, ADMX
name: Will Roberto Peccei and Helen Quinn be awarded the Nobel Prize in 2015?
question_text:
Axions are theorized by Roberto Peccei and Helen Quinn in 1977 to solve the charge-parity (CP) symmetry problem. The Axion Dark Matter Experiment (ADMX) is located at the University of Washington and aims to detect the very weak conversion of dark matter axions into microwave photons as evidence of axions. In 2010, the ADMX team showed that the specially designed amplifiers worked as hoped. As of November 1, 2013, they have not started to collect data.

Resolution Criteria

The Axion Dark Matter Experiment needs to begin collecting data and detect evidence of an axion. The Nobel Prize Committee must meet to determine the winner.

Resolution Sources

  • Science Magazine http://www.sciencemag.org
  • The New York Times science section

Useful Information and Links

  • Richard Panek. ?Out There.? New York Times. March 11, 2007 http://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/11/magazine/11dark.t.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0?
  • Marquit, Miranda. ?Is dark matter made of axions?? Physics.org March 3, 2008 http://phys.org/news123770210.html
  • ADMX | Axion Dark Matter eXperiment - University of Washington. http://www.phys.washington.edu/groups/admx/home.html
  • Adrian Cho. ?Dark Matter's Dark Horse.? Science 1 November 2013: 342 (6158), 552-55 http://www.sciencemag.org/content/342/6158/552.full

keywords: Autonomous cars, self-driving cars, driverless vehicles
name: How many of the top 20 international automobile manufacturers will have released a level 2 prototype (Combined Function Automation, with two major systems automated) for an autonomous vehicle by the 2015 North American International Auto Show (NAIAS)?
question_text:
By September 2014, ten of the top twenty international automobile manufacturers had unveiled prototypes of level two self-driving cars.? These include:? Toyota, General Motors, Volkswagen, Ford, Nissan, Daimler AG, Hyundai, Honda, Renault, and BMW.? With the increasing competition for autonomy in motor vehicles, this leads to the question of how many of the other top twenty automobile manufacturers will have an autonomous car prototype by 2015.

The top twenty international automobile manufacturers by the number of vehicles sold in 2012 according to the OICA include:? BMW (Germany), Changan (China), Chrysler (U.S.), Daimler AG (Germany), Dongfeng Motor (China), FIAT (Italy), Ford (U.S.), GM (U.S.), Honda (Japan), Hyundai (South Korea), Mazda (Japan), Mitsubishi (Japan), Nissan (Japan), PSA (France), Renault (France), SAIC (China), Suzuki (Japan), Tata (India), Toyota (Japan), Volkswagen (Germany).?

Relevant Links:
  • Nissan, Mercedez-Benz Top Carmakers Most Linked with Autonomous Driving Technology; But Google Leads All
  • Let the Robot Drive - the Autonomous Car of the Future is Here
  • NHTSA Policy on Automated Vehicle Development

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/25/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the total number of the top 20 automobile manufacturers that have made level 2 prototype or production ready autonomous vehicle by the 2015 NAIAS which takes place during January 12-25, 2015. ?This will be confirmed by major news sources or the press release page of the car manufacturer. ?As of September 2014, the remaining automobile manufacturers include: ?PSA, Suzuki, Chrysler, FIAT, SAIC Motor, TATA Motors, Mazda, Dongfeng Motor, Mitsubishi, Chang'an

Fine Print

A 'level 2 prototype' of an autonomous vehicle refers to the Combined Function Automation, or Level Two of the NHTSA classification of autonomous vehicles: "This level involves automation of at least two primary control functions [such as braking, steering, or accelerating] designed to work in unison to relieve the driver of control of those functions. An example of combined functions enabling a Level 2 system is adaptive cruise control in combination with lane centering." This definition can therefore include both fully autonomous vehicles, and semi-autonomous or vehicles with autonomous driver assisted features.

A ?prototype? is defined as a full scale vehicle or an autonomous added feature to an existing vehicle that has demonstrated the ability to automate to some extent. This means that an announcement of development or research by the manufacturer by itself does not suffice, an actual prototype must be built.

An ?automobile manufacturer? is defined here to be one of the twenty manufacturers listed, and is the largest in the chain of ownership. For example, General Motors includes Chevrolet, Dodge, Cadillac, etc. Volkswagen includes Audi, Bentley, Lamborghini, Porsche, etc. Daimler AG includes Mercedez Benz, Setra, etc.

name: When will the retired RQ-7 Shadow drones successfully provide 1 gigabit-per-second wireless connectivity in a real-world remote military mission?
question_text:
Military missions in remote locations require access tosecure, high-bandwidth communications with forward-operating bases (FOBs),tactical operation centers (TOCs), intelligence, surveillance, reconnaissance(ISR) assets, and fixed communications infrastructure.? Establishingreliable and secure contact in remote, unfriendly territories is verychallenging and extremely critical to the missions. DARPA?s Mobile Hotspotsprogram is working to develop ?a scalable, mobile, millimeter-wave communicationsbackbone? using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to transmit data at gigabit-persecond rates to warfighters in remote areas. The program is working to developadvanced millimeter wave pointing, acquisition, and tracking (PAT) technologiesto provide high speed connectivity in challenging and remote terrains.
?
On April 7th, 2014, DARPA announced that were able tosuccessfully complete phase one of three phases towards developing andflight-testing the complete system.? Phase two of the program started in March2014 under the leadership of L-3 communications and FIRST RF among other Phase1 performers. ?The program is working to retrofit RQ-7 Shadow drones thatpreviously provided surveillance capabilities in Iraq to serve as flying nodeson the mobile high-speed backbone. Using small antennas operating athigh-frequency millimeter-wave amplifier technology will help enhance thesignal sufficiently for the RQ-7s to fly higher and away from possible enemydetection.

DARPA?s Mobile Hotspots Program: http://www.darpa.mil/Our_Work/STO/Programs/Mobile_Hotspots.aspx
Remote Troops Closer to Having High-Speed Wireless Networks Mounted on UAVs: http://www.darpa.mil/NewsEvents/Releases/2014/04/07.aspx

name: What will the cost of an average US domestic flight be for the second quarter of 2015?
question_text:
With the prices of crude oil steadily decreasing, the average consumer is able to see this price change at the pump.This price change of oil is not only impacting the auto industry, but also the air travel industry. the price of jet fuel has fallen 43% from the price a year ago, yet the price of airline tickets (in 2014) remained relatively the same.

The average price of a domestic plane ticket in the second quarter, 2014?in the US was $395.62, this was similar to quarters surrounding it, yet noticeably higher than years before. Many believe that airline prices will not go down, because they have not in the past, yet others think that the prices of oil will decrease?so?signiciantly in 2015,??airline tickets will follow suit.

name: Will the Japan-based over-the-top (OTT) messaging company Line Corporation complete an IPO before the end of 2014?
question_text:
Japan based Line Corporation, a subsidiary of South Korean internet content provider Naver Co., is preparing itself for a possible 2014 IPO with a company valuation of $800 million to $1 billion. The Line IPO could list on either the NASDAQ or Tokyo Stock Exchange, and a deal could be worth as much as $28 billion. If so, it could be capable of topping the Twitter IPO.

The company has denied any such rumor and issued statement saying, that it will be considering various possibilities for business expansion including listing but no concrete decisions has been made yet.

Fine Print

OTT (Over-the-top content) refers to delivery of video and audio over the Internet without a multiple system operator being involved in the control or distribution of the content. The provider may be aware of the contents of the Internet Protocol packets but is not responsible for, nor able to control, the viewing abilities, copyrights, and/or other redistribution of the content. LINE Corporation is a Japanese company, a subsidiary of South Korean company Naver Corporation. The company's business is mainly associated with the development of mobile applications and internet services.Its annual revenue from messaging app games and stickers may hit $1 billion in 2014.

name: Will the implant of an osseointegrated (i.e. bone-anchored) prosthetic device in an amputee in the US be reported before the end of March 2015?
question_text:
It was reported recently that a?Swedish arm amputee?had?become?the first person in the world to receive a prosthesis with a direct connection to bone, nerves and muscles. The osseointegrated (bone-anchored) implant system gives patients new opportunities in their daily life and professional activities.?An article about this achievement and its long-term stability is to be published in?the?Science Translational Medicine?journal.

In the US, the FDA has approved a feasibility study to test an osseointegrated implant system on human. Dr. Roy Bloebaum and his colleagues of the Amputation Research Team at?the University of Utah School of Medicine?have successfully implanted osseointegrated devices in sheep models, and?are planning?to begin implanting?the devices on human participants.?The study, a collaboration between the University of Utah, Walter Reed National Military Medical Center and Brooke Army Medical Center, will include 10 transfemoral amputee participants.?

name: How many states will report at least one case of a West Nile virus human neuroinvasive disease by 1-AUG-2014?
question_text:
• West Nile virus is an arthropod-borne virus (arbovirus) most commonly spread by infected mosquitoes. West Nile virus can cause febrile illness, encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or meningitis (inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal cord).
  • As of January 7, 2014, 48 states and the District of Columbia reported cases of West Nile virus infections that occurred in 2013 in people, birds, or mosquitoes. A total of 2,374 cases of West Nile virus disease in people, including 114 deaths, have been reported to CDC for 2013. The only two states that did not report a West Nile virus infection in 2013 were Alaska and Hawaii.
  • Less than 1% of people who are infected will develop a serious neurologic illness such as encephalitis or meningitis. Neuroinvasive disease cases were reported to the CDC from the following states for 2013: Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming.
  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US at http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • The CDC case count is updated once a week during the transmission season.
  • As of June 10, 2014, there was one state with at least one incidence of human West Nile virus neuroinvasive disease.
  • Since it is more likely West Nile neuroinvasive disease infections will appear in a few states by August 1 rather than many states, the bins used in "safe mode" forecasting are asymmetrical based approximately on a log scale.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

  • The CDC monitors West Nile virus activity in the US. Their surveillance page will resolve this question - http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/statsMaps/preliminaryMapsData/index.html
  • The CDC case count is updated once a week during the transmission season. The first update after August 1, 2014 will be used to resolve this question.
  • The CDC has not been releasing maps every Tuesday/weekly as is stated on their website. If the CDC does release a report August 1 that says as of July 31 that report will be used to resolve the question. However, it is more likely that the CDC will release a report after August 1 and that number will resolve the question even if it includes August data.

Fine Print

Examples of neuroinvasive diseases: meningitis, encephalitis, or acute flaccid paralysis.

keywords: Flu, region 9, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 9 (AZ, CA, HI, NV, AS, MP, FM, GU, MH, PW)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 9' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 9 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 9 is comprised of Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, American Samoa, Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Guam, Marshall Islands, and Republic of Palau.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 9 is 2.7%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will a nanosponge toxoid vaccine, designed to protect against MRSA, enter clinical trials before the end of 2014?
question_text:
Nanosponges that soak up a dangerous pore-forming toxin produced by MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) could serve as a safe and effective vaccine against this toxin. This ?nanosponge vaccine? enabled the immune systems of mice to block the adverse effects of the alpha-haemolysin toxin from MRSA?both within the bloodstream and on the skin. Nanoengineers from the University of California, San Diego described the safety and efficacy of this nanosponge vaccine in Nature Nanotechnology.
