name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Iowa?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Iowa, 57.5% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +4.0% from 2011 (53.5%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 56.6%, the "56.6%-60.0%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Flu, Region 4, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: How many ILI case counts will be reported during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 4 (AL, FL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, and TN)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/28/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 4' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file refer to the column labelled "ILITOTAL"?
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the number of total cases in Region 4 for the 2014-2015 flu season?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'total ILI case counts' is defined as the total ILI related patient visits between the start and the end week, across HHS region 4. Region 4 is comprised of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and TennesseeILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). Consequently, the total ILI count may also vary accordingly. For instance, if the ILL count has been published as 50000, the revised value could be, example, 50000 + 2%(50000) = 51000.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Calcium Regulation Group, Steinckwich-Besancon
name: What place will the Calcium Regulation Group - Steinckwich-Besancon's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The Steinckwich-Besancon Team's Strategy to Win the Race:

With the ?need for speed?, our chemotaxing neutrophil HL-60s do not require nitrous oxide. Instead, we have souped-up and enhanced the cells Calcium-signaling pathways to ?GO NEUTRO?!!
?
For more information on The Calcium Regulation Group, and the work they are doing, please visit their website here:?Calcium Regulation Group

Useful Links
  • Link to Calcium Regulation Group?
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

name: Will the price of road salt reach $200 per ton in any state in the United States before March 2015?
question_text:
The United States consumes an average of 22 million tons of road salt every year. In the winter of '13-'14, due to severe winter storms, there were salt shortages across the United States and the price of road salt rose steeply ? doubling in many cases, almost tripling in others. This year the country is expecting similar weather conditions and states are stocking up on road salt supplies in preparation for the severe winter forecast. For a variety of reasons, including anticipated salt shortages, analysts are expecting even higher road salt prices than last year, which ranged? from $20 to $164.69 per ton, depending on the state. As a result of the anticipated shortage in salt supplies and the rising prices, states around the country are experimenting with alternatives to road salt like beet juice, cheese brine, and waste water from fracking operations to melt ice on the roads; however, most of these options are not yet as effective as road salt. If road salt was to reach a record high this season, then more research and development into these alternatives may take place. ??
  • http://time.com/3590020/road-salt-expensive-snow-storms-weather/
  • http://www.ohio.com/news/local/road-salt-prices-more-than-triple-for-some-areas-raising-concerns-as-winter-looms-1.537909
  • http://www.popsci.com/salt-prices-are-rise-temperatures-drop

Accepting Forecasts Until:

02/28/2015

Resolution Source

An announcement or news release in the news media by March 2015 that a county or a state in the US purchased road salt for $200/ton during the 2014/2015 winter season?will resolve this question.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by?the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

*Admin Update: This question will be resolved by March 7th to give time for a suitable report to be found.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

This question will resolve if any county or any state in the US purchases road salt for $200/ton before March 2015.

keywords: Autonomous cars, self-driving cars, driverless vehicles
name: How many of the top 20 international automobile manufacturers will have released a level 3 prototype (Limited Self-Driving Automation, with all major systems automated) for an autonomous vehicle by the 2015 North American International Auto Show (NAIAS)?
question_text:
By September 2014, seven of the top twenty international automobile manufacturers had unveiled prototypes of level three self-driving cars. ?These include: BMW, Daimler AG, Ford, GM, Honda, Nissan, and Toyota.? With the increasing competition for autonomy in motor vehicles, this leads to the question of how many of the other top twenty automobile manufacturers will have an autonomous car prototype by 2015.

Question #905 asks about level two automation which is directed towards driver-assisted autonomy (or autonomy specifically for safety).? This questions asks about the next level of autonomy, level three, in which (the intention is that) manufacturers will make autonomy for navigation in addition to safety.?

The top twenty international automobile manufacturers by the number of vehicles sold in 2012 according to the OICA include: ?BMW (Germany), Changan (China), Chrysler (US), Daimler AG (Germany), Dongfeng Motor (China), FIAT (Italy), Ford (US), GM (US), Honda (Japan), Hyundai (South Korea), Mazda (Japan), Mitsubishi (Japan), Nissan (Japan), PSA (France), Renault (France), SAIC (China), Suzuki (Japan), Tata (India), Toyota (Japan), Volkswagen (Germany).

Relevant Links:

  • Nissan, Mercedez-Benz Top Carmakers Most Linked with Autonomous Driving Technology; But Google Leads All
  • Let the Robot Drive - the Autonomous Car of the Future is Here
  • NHTSA Policy on Automated Vehicle Development

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/25/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the total number of the top 20 automobile manufacturers that have made a level 3 or higher autonomous vehicle by the 2015 NAIAS which takes place during January 12-25, 2015.? This will be confirmed by major news sources or the press release page of the car manufacturer.? Note that the intent of the automobile manufacturer may also be taken into account in judging if an autonomous car can be classified as level 3 or not.? As of September 2014, the remaining automobile manufacturers include:? Chang'an, Chrysler, Dongfeng Motor, FIAT, Hyundai, Mazda, Mitsubishi, PSA, Renault, SAIC Motor, Suzuki, TATA Motors, and Volkswagen.

Fine Print

The NHTSA classification of autonomous vehicles is based on the level of human supervision. Level two relates to multiple functions being automated such as adaptive cruise control, lane keeping, or self parking, and therefore still needs human supervision. This can be generally referred to as semi-autonomous vehicles. Level three relates to vehicles that are self-driving but under certain circumstances may need human control. This can be generally referred to as limited self-driving autonomy. Level four relates to vehicles that can operate fully autonomously including unmanned operation, and therefore need no human supervision at all. This can be generally referred to as self-driving or autonomous cars in the real sense. The current status of the automotive industry does not follow this classification exactly. Therefore the ambiguous parts of the NHTSA definition will be defined for the purposes of this question, these are included in the brackets:

A 'level 3 prototype' of an autonomous vehicle refers to the Limited Self-Driving Automation, or Level Three of the NHTSA classification of autonomous vehicles: "Vehicles at this level of automation enable the driver to cede full control of all safety-critical functions [this includes acceleration, braking, steering, and lane changing/turning] under certain traffic or environmental conditions and in those conditions to rely heavily on the vehicle to monitor for changes in those conditions requiring transition back to the driver control [however the vehicle must be able to detect objects other than cars such as pedestrians or traffic lights and respond autonomously]. The driver is expected to be available for occasional control, but with sufficiently comfortable transition time. The Google (self-driving Prius) car is an example of limited self-driving automation." For example, the 2015 Hyundai Genesis cannot make autonomous lane changes or turns, and cannot autonomously respond to detected objects (other than cars), and is therefore labeled with level two autonomy. Additionally, the decision to categorize a vehicle as level three for resolution may be at the discretion of the question author.

A ?prototype? is defined as a full scale vehicle or an autonomous added feature to an existing vehicle that has demonstrated level 3 functionality. This means that an announcement of development or research by the manufacturer by itself does not suffice, an actual prototype must be built.

An ?automobile manufacturer? is defined here to be one of the twenty manufacturers listed, and is the largest in the chain of ownership. For example, General Motors includes Chevrolet, Dodge, Cadillac, etc. Volkswagen includes Audi, Bentley, Lamborghini, Porsche, etc. Daimler AG includes Mercedez Benz, Setra, etc.

name: At its initial launch, will the range of Tesla's Gen 3 electric car be greater than 150 miles?
question_text:
The range of the upcoming lower-cost Tesla Gen 3 electric vehicle is important to the company in light of the current and upcoming mix of smaller electric vehicles. For example, the Nissan Leaf, the most popular electric vehicle in history based on sales volume, has a range of about 75 miles with a starting price of $28,800. The BMW i3, which will go on sale in the U.S. later this year, has a range of about 80 miles for a base price of about $41,000. For Tesla to succeed in the market for smaller, nonluxury EVs, it will need to meet or exceed the ranges of cars in that segment.?
Other than saying "it will have a practical range",?Tesla?officials won't say what the range of the company's Gen 3 (also referred to as the 'Model?E')?will be. But some Tesla insiders have speculated that "It's hard to imagine that the Gen 3 wouldn't get 200 miles in range".

  • http://www.ibtimes.com/detroit-auto-show-2014-40000-model-e-tesla-motors-tsla-will-have-practical-ra...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

Question?will be resolved by consulting the company's website:?http://www.teslamotors.com/

Fine Print

All-electric range (AER) is the driving range of a vehicle using only power from its electric battery pack to traverse a given driving cycle. In the case of a battery electric vehicle, it means the total range per charge.

name: When Microsoft launches Windows 10, will it offer it free to owners of Windows 8?
question_text:
There are rumors?that Microsoft will offer?Windows 10 for free (or at a substantial discount) to owners of Windows?8.

This would follow the example of Apple, which?made the first free release of OS X when it announced that OS X 10.9 Mavericks would be released as a free download for OS X 10.8 users in 2013.

  • http://www.techradar.com/news/software/operating-systems/microsoft-may-do-a-mavericks-and-make-windo...

Accepting Forecasts Until:

4/30/2015

Resolution Source

The question will resolve when Microsoft releases?Windows 10:?http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/default.aspx

Fine Print

Note: this question previously referred to Windows 9, however Microsoft officially changed the name to Windows 10. This should not affect forecasting decisions per se since the OS after Windows 8 is still what is referred to.

choices_field_11: None of the storms listed will be the last hurricane of the season
keywords: hurricane, tropical storm, National Hurricane Center
name: Which hurricane will be the last of the 2014 Atlantic hurricane season?
question_text:
Storm watchers and meteorology hobbyists have expressed boredom?with the paucity of tropical storms and hurricanes during the 2014 Atlantic hurricane season. It appears likely that the season will end with far fewer hurricanes than the historical average.

2014 Atlantic hurricane season: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Atlantic_hurricane_season

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/30/2014

Resolution Source

National Hurricane Center of the National Weather Service:?http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/

Fine Print

In order for a listed storm to resolve the question, it must be classified as a hurricane by the National Hurricane Center on or before the end of the season on November 30, 2014. A hurricane that is declared after November 30 does not count for this question. If a hurricane named Paulette is declared before November 30, the question will immediately resolve as "None of the hurricanes listed will be the last of the season." Dates and times are based on those used by the National Hurricane Center. All terms and definitions defer to those used by the National Hurricane Center.

name: Will the physical discovery of a large-gap quantum hall 2D insulator with the structure 1T?-MX2  where M = (tungsten or molybdenum) and X = (tellurium, selenium, or sulfur) be published by 1-JULY 2015?
question_text:
• The quantum spin Hall state is a state of matter proposed to exist in special, two-dimensional, semiconductors that have a quantized spin-Hall conductance and a vanishing charge-Hall conductance.
  • Quantum spin Hall insulators have an insulating bulk but conducting edge states that are topologically protected from backscattering by time-reversal symmetry.?
  • Many Quantum spin Hall insulators that have been synthesized in the lab have band gaps too small for operation in anything but low temperatures. A larger band-gap material may enable operation in higher temperatures.
  • Qain et al used first-principles calculations to predict a class of large-gap QSH insulators in two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides with 1T? structure, namely, 1T?-MX2 with M = (tungsten or molybdenum) and X = (tellurium, selenium, or sulfur). However, they did not synthesize any material.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/01/2015

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when a paper is published?or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

The material must be physically synthesized with the indicated chemical structure and exhibit an insulating bulk but conducting edge states that are topologically protected from backscattering by time-reversal symmetry.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Utah?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Utah, 44.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -9.0% from 2011 (53.3%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 43.4%, the "43.4%-46.8%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will at least one solar cell innovation from NREL win a R&D 100 Award in 2014?
question_text:
Known in the research and development community as "the Oscars of Innovation", R&D 100 Awards are presented to the 100 most important innovations of each year. NREL has won 55?R&D 100 Awards?since 1982.?There was at least one R&D 100 Award-winning solar cell innovation from NREL each year from 2011 to 2013. The R&D 100 Award is normally announced in early July of each year.

  • NREL. http://www.nrel.gov/awards/rd_awards.html
  • R&D Magazine: http://www.rdmag.com





Accepting Forecasts Until:

7/1/2014

Resolution Source

Announcement will be made by R&D Magazine in early July: http://www.rdmag.com and will be on the NREL website: http://www.nrel.gov/awards/rd_awards.html


Fine Print

R&D Magazine honors inventors by identifying the 100 most technologically significant products and advancements for each year and recognizing the winning innovators and their organizations with the R&D 100 Award.NREL: National Renewable Energy Laboratory

keywords: alcohol addiction, alcohol abuse, alcohol substitute
name: When will a beverage, containing a compound created as a limited-intoxication alcohol substitute be commercially available for public consumption?
question_text:
The individual, social, and economic costs of alcohol consumption are enormous. Scientists are identifying compounds, similar to benzodiazepines, that can stimulate neurotransmitters to produce some of the pleasure-inducing effects of alcohol but with limited intoxicating effects. There are numerous public health and financial arguments made to try to replace alcohol consumption, at least to some extent, with beverages based on these compounds.

For more information, see:

  • http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/newsandeventspggrp/imperialcollege/newssummary/news_12-11-2013-9-59-20
  • http://mic.com/articles/108052/why-one-u-k-doctor-wants-you-to-take-a-party-drug-for-your-health
  • http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22530022.900-high-and-dry-party-drug-could-target-excess-drink...
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MEAI

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

The availability of a limited-intoxicating alcohol-like beverage will be announced by its manufacturer, and must be legally available to US customers purchasing it?in stores and/or online.?

This question will resolve when this feature is first made available, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Limited-intoxication alcohol substitute here means a compound sold to the general public that contains no ethanol but is still psychoactive. It excludes stimulants (such as caffeine, nicotine, or amphetamine) and existing legal drugs (including THC), regardless of indication.For this question to resolve as true, the beverage must be available for public consumption without a prescription or other barrier other than a possible age limit similar to that with alcohol.

name: Will researchers observe neutrinoless double-? decay to verify the Majorana nature of the neutrino by January 1, 2017?
question_text:
Majorana-type fermions are particles that are their own anti-particle. They were hypothesized by Ettore Majorana in 1937. In June 2014, The EXO-200 Collaboration published a paper in Nature that detailed their experimental equipment reporting:

  • [N]ew results from EXO-200 based on a large 136Xe exposure that represents an almost fourfold increase from our earlier published data sets.
  • [I]mproved detector resolution and revised the data analysis.
  • A half-life sensitivity obtained of 1.9???1025?years, an improvement by a factor of 2.7 on previous EXO-200 results.
  • The high sensitivity holds promise, they believe, for further running of the EXO-200 detector and future 0??? decay searches with an improved Xe-based experiment, nEXO.
  • Recent searches carried out with 76Ge (the GERDA experiment) and 136Xe (the KamLAND-Zen and EXO (Enriched Xenon Observatory)-200 experiments) have established the lifetime of this decay to be longer than 1025?years, corresponding to a limit on the neutrino mass of 0.2?0.4?electronvolts.
Links and Sources
Search for Majorana neutrinos with the first two years of EXO-200 data http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v510/n7504/full/nature13432.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

A peer-reviewed publication in a journal indexed by Thomas Reuters? Web of Science.?? This question will close when a paper brought to the moderator?s attention or on 1/1/2017.

Fine Print

According to the EOX-200 June 2014 paper ?Observation of neutrinoless double-? decay (0???), a spontaneous transition that may occur in several candidate nuclei, would verify the Majorana nature of the neutrino and constrain the absolute scale of the neutrino mass spectrum.?
short_name: Observation of a neutrinoless double-? decay

name: Which team will win the 2014 AUVSI RoboBoat Competition?
question_text:
The AUVSI Foundation is a non-profit organization established by the Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems International (AUVSI).? They offer a number of robotics competitions every year that allow students to apply STEM knowledge learned in the classroom to practical scenarios.

The International RoboBoat Competition was first held in 2008.? Teams from various universities race autonomous surface vehicles (ASV's) of their own design through an aquatic obstacle course.? This includes littoral area navigation, channel following, and autonomous docking.? It is typically accomplished with computer vision, multi-sensor fusion techniques, proactive and reactive path planning, and machine learning approaches using embedded systems within the vehicle.? The competition provides an opportunity for students to develop skills in systems engineering by accomplishing realistic missions with autonomous vehicles in the maritime environment.

Relevant Links:

  • 7th Annual AUVSI RoboBoat Competition Background and Team List
  • 2014 RoboBoat Competition Rules and Task Descriptions
  • RoboBoat Competition Forum
  • RoboBoat Journal Papers Archive
  • RoboBoat Competition Photo Gallery Archive

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/12/14

Resolution Source

The competition takes place on July 8 to July 13, 2014.? The competition finals take place on July 13 and the results will be announced by AUVSI at the competition page or the forum.

Fine Print

'Win' is defined as the team that earns first place in the 2014 RoboBoat competition. This is determined from the team that earns the highest number of points from the various missions tasks performed.

keywords: Stem cells, stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency, STAP
name: Will a second group successfully reproduce the stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency (STAP) results achieved by H. Obokata et al.?
question_text:
In January 2014, a group of researchers led by Haruko?Obokata announced their success using an acid bath to turn body cells into stem cells describing the technique as ?stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency.? This method surprised many with its ease.

Prior to 2006, it was thought that body cells (also known as differentiated somatic cells) could not be turned back into the pluripotent stem cells from which they originated. In 2006, Dr. Shinya Yamanaka led a group that discovered that differentiated soatic cells could be reprogrammed into a pluripotent stem cell by changing the transcription factors. This was a fundamental discovery; however, the process produced very low yields of stem cells. In addition, the changing of transcription factors tended to generate tumors. These issues, as well as the complexity required to generate stem cells, have spurred many scientists to explore different methods to induce pluripotency.

Dr. Obokata?s papers claim to have generated pluripotent stem cells through surprisingly simple methods of exposing soatic cells to stressful conditions such as acid baths, toxin exposure, or physical stress. These papers have been met with wide spread skepticism and many scientists are attempting to recreate the experiments.? The results of the papers have been called into question and Dr. Obokata?s home institution and the publishing journal, Nature, are investigating the charges. Recently, one author of the paper has called for its retraction.

Sources and Links

  • Study Says New Method Could Be a Quicker Source of Stem Cells http://nyti.ms/1a1LU9A
  • One Author of a Startling Stem Cell Study Calls for Its Retraction http://nyti.ms/1dJwAOg
  • Call for acid-bath stem-cell paper to be retracted http://blogs.nature.com/news/2014/03/call-for-acid-bath-stem-cell-paper-to-be-retracted.html
  • Acid bath offers easy path to stem cells? http://www.nature.com/news/acid-bath-offers-easy-path-to-stem-cells-1.14600
  • Stimulus-triggered fate conversion of somatic cells into pluripotency? http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v505/n7485/full/nature12968.html
  • Bidirectional developmental potential in reprogrammed cells with acquired pluripotency? http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v505/n7485/full/nature12969.html
  • Knoepfler Lab Stem Cell Blog http://www.ipscell.com/stap-new-data/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The results should be announced by the group and published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters Web of Science.?

Fine Print

Confirm as announced by the group and published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters Web of Science.

keywords: Biodiversity, Ecosystem, Habitat, Marine, Ocean, Trophic Index
name: Which of the following changes will be reported about "The Marine Trophic Index" in the fourth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook report?
question_text:
There is no single measurement that captures the current status or trends in global biodiversity. Therefore a range of indicators was developed for the Convention on Biological Diversity, to provide scientifically rigorous assessments of trends in the state of the various components of biodiversity (genes, populations, species, ecosystems);the pressures being imposed upon it; and the responses being adopted to address biodiversity loss. This trend was identified as an indicator of progress toward biodiversity target that was initially set for 2010. It will be reported on in the next Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO) report released by the Convention on Biological Diversity.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved based on the published results of the fourth edition of Global Biodiversity Outlook (GBO-4). The GBO-4 will released in 2014 to enable the twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (held October 6-14, 2014) to assess progress in the implementation of the Strategic Plan . If nothing is published by the Convention on Biological Diversity by October 16, 2014, or in cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, the administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

The Twelfth meeting of the Conference of the Parties in Pyeongchang, Republic of Korea (6 - 17 October 2014)

Useful Links

  • https://www.cbd.int/cop/
  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/gbo/gbo2/cbd-gbo2-en.pdf
  • http://www.cbd.int/doc/publications/gbo/gbo3-final-en.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

The fourth edition of the Global Diversity Outlook report issued by The Convention on Biological Diversity: http://www.cbd.int/gbo/

name: Will a 100 million digit prime number be found before 2016?
question_text:
As of January 2014 the largest prime number is over 17 million digits according to the Prime pages?http://primes.utm.edu/?a website that tracks record prime numbers. ?In 2008 the record was 12.9 million digits. ?Although record setting primes still are found with some frequency the rate of growth is slowing down in recent years. ?Therefore to get to a 100 million digit prime will take significantly more computing power or an improvement in the algorithms used to find them. ?In spite of this, Chris Caldwell who maintains the Prime pages predicts a hundred million digit prime number will be found in late 2015.Improvement in computer hardware or advances in algorithms for testing for primality.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Listed on websites tracking record breaking prime numbers, e.g. http://primes.utm.edu

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Kortholt
name: What place will the Kortholt Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The Kortholt Team's Strategy to Win the Race:

The?combination of natural and artificial?selection has resulted in excellent axenic?Dictyostelium?strains.??Our "lab work horse" AX3 moves very efficiently in a cAMP-gradient using a combination of complex signaling pathways. To further?improve chemotaxis efficiency we?generated a mutant with overexpression of a protein that amplifies the basic signaling pathways.?

For more information on The Kortholt Lab, and the work they are doing, please visit their website here: Kortholt Lab

Useful Links
  • Link to the?Kortholt?Lab?Website
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

keywords: Battery storage, utility storage, renewable energy
name: Will a utility install a quinone-based organic battery for energy storage by January 1, 2017?
question_text:
• Many states have mandatory targets for renewable energy procurement, such as the California Renewables Portfolio Standard, which requires investor-owned utilities, electric service providers, and community choice aggregators to increase procurement from eligible renewable energy resources to 33% of total procurement by 2020. ?
  • One obstacle to utilizing wind energy and solar energy to meet this goal is the fact it is intermittent and may not match up to consumers? needs. However, grid storage would enable utilities to store energy when it is generated (when it is windy or when the sun is shining) and return it to the grid when it is needed.
  • Flow batteries, a category of rechargeable batteries, are recharged by two chemical components dissolved in fluids that are kept in separate tanks and are well suited to store large amounts of energy; however, metal-based flow cells are expensive due to their use of precious metals.
  • The most advanced flow batteries rely on vanadium ions and are very expensive.
  • A few different teams of researchers have announced breakthroughs on a flow battery consisting quinones (an organic molecule) instead of metal ions, which may bring down the cost of flow batteries from $700 per kilowatt-hour of storage capacity to $27.

Links and Sources
  • Organic battery hailed as cheap renewable energy solution http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/organic-battery-hailed-as-cheap-renewable-energy-solution-1.248930...
  • Scientists create new battery that's cheap, clean, rechargeable... and organic
  • http://phys.org/news/2014-06-scientists-battery-cheap-rechargeable.html
  • Cheap battery stores energy for a rainy day http://www.nature.com/news/cheap-battery-stores-energy-for-a-rainy-day-1.14486

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

An official announcement from the company that installs the utility scale quinone-based organic battery. This may be in the form of a press release or coverage by a major newspaper (LA Times, etc.)?

Fine Print

The quinone-based organic battery must be incorporated into an electric grid for this question to resolve as 'yes'. This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

name: On NOV 2015, what will be the (performance-weighted) gigaflops per watt of the Top 500?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

This question asks what the average performance efficiency in terms of power consumption will be of the Top500 when weighted by system performance.

Questions from the Jun 2014 Top 500

Accepting Forecasts Until:

11/30/2015

Resolution Source

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 statistics published at?http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources
Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list?

Fine Print

By performance-weighted, we mean the average of all 500 machines, weighted by each machine?s raw computing performance (Rmax Gflops).So for example, the performance-weighted average <u>efficiency</u> (Gflops/watt) is calculated by: (1/500) * ?i wi * ei, where ei is the efficiency of machine i, and wi is the weight given to that machine. The weight is always that machine?s proportion of the total Top500 computing power (Rmax Gflops): wi = Rmaxi / (?i Rmaxi), where Rmaxi is the Rmax score (Gflops) for machine i.

keywords: quantum key distribution, random number generator, data encryption, cryptography
name: By the end of 2016, will a compact quantum random number generator be commercially available in the US?
question_text:
Los Alamos National Laboratory has recently sign a licensing agreement with Boston based Whitewood Encryption Systems, Inc. to develop a compact random number generator based on several Los Alamos patents on quantum encryption technology. The Los Alamos technology? at heart of the agreement is a compact random-number-generation technology that creates cryptographic keys based on the truly random polarization state of photons. Because the randomness of photon polarization is based on quantum mechanics, an adversary cannot predict the outcome of its random number generator.

  • Quantum key distribution technology: Secure computing for the "Everyman": http://phys.org/news/2014-09-quantum-key-technology-everyman.html
  • Enhance your security with scalable, cost-effective and low-latency advanced cryptography solutions: http://www.whitewoodencryption.com/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The availability of the product will be reported by the manufacturer licensed to make it,?Whitewood Encryption Systems: http://www.whitewoodencryption.com/

Reports may also?appear in?science news reports such as Science News (www.sciencenews.org), MIT Tech Review (http://www.technologyreview.com/), and others?

keywords: Space, Rosetta, comet, European Space Agency
name: Will Rosetta rendezvous with Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko?
question_text:
?In November 1993, the International Rosetta Mission was approved as a Cornerstone Mission in European Space Agency's Horizons 2000 Science Programme.

Rosetta lifted off on March 2004 on a European Ariane 5 rocket from Kourou in French Guiana. During a circuitous ten-year trek across the Solar System, Rosetta crossed the asteroid belt and traveled into deep space. Its destination is a periodic comet known as Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

On January 20, 2014, the European Space Agency confirmed that Rosetta woke from its 31 months in hibernation used to conserve power as it arced beyond the orbit of Jupiter on a path that should take it to Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

The BBC reports: [F]rom mid-March to the end of April, ESA will be switching on the instruments one by one.? [If successful]...Rosetta will begin firing its thrusters to begin zeroing in on Comet 67P. Today, the separation is nine million km away. By mid-September, it should be reduced to just 10km.

Links:

  • Rosetta comet-chaser phones home
  • European Space Agency: Rosetta

Rosetta needs to fully wake up from its hibernation, fire its thrusters, and travel toward the comet.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/03/2015

Resolution Source

The European Space Agency will announce the rendezvous: www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Science/Rosetta

Fine Print

?Rendezvous? for the question purposes means that Rosetta will align its orbit with the comet at a distance of less than 50 km.

keywords: Avian Influenza A, H7N9, Virus, flu, bird flu
name: In how many countries outside of China will a lab-confirmed case of Avian Influenza A (H7N9) be detected before 1 August 2014?
question_text:
During the spring of 2013, the World Health Organization (WHO) reported 132 human H7N9 infections, with 44 deaths. Most cases had illness onset during the month of April. Beginning in May, new reports of human H7N9 infection in China became less frequent. From June to the end of September 2013, WHO reported three new H7N9 infections in China; one had illness onset in April, and one resulted in death. In the beginning of October, the frequency of reports of human infection with H7N9 began to increase. WHO and China reported more new H7N9 cases in China per month relative to the summer months, including three cases reported by Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of People?s Republic of China in early December. Most of the cases that were reported had poultry exposure and lived in areas where H7N9 had been found previously. As of mid-January, cases continue to be reported and the frequency of these reports has increased. ??

CDC was aware of a small number of confirmed H7N9 influenza cases in China in which ?limited? person-to-person spread of the virus could not be ruled out. On January 20, Bloomburg News reported "a medical worker at a Shanghai hospital died from bird flu, stoking concern that the influenza virus known as H7N9 may have spread from person to person."
??
Sources and references:
Rise in Bird Flu Cases in China Stokes Worry Before Peak Travel Time
CDC Avian Influenza A (H7N9) Virus
Bird Flu Kills Health Worker, Stokes Transmission Concern
Mapping the H7N9 avian flu outbreaks
Vietnam on high alert over flu risk

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/01/2014

Resolution Source

  • This question will be resolved by the announced number of lab-confirmed human cases on August 1, 2014.
  • In the United States, the CDC is the US leading authority on Avian Influenza - http://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/h7n9-virus.htm
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) is the leading authority internationally: http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/influenza_h7n9/en/

Fine Print

Lab-confirmed: as announced by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or the World Health Organization (WHO).

name: Will the June 2014 TOP500 rankings announce that the performance of the #500 ranked supercomputer has exceeded 150 thousand Gflops/s?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference. The June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference is scheduled to occur between June 22, 2014 ? June 26, 2014. The June 2013 TOP500 rankings revealed that the performance of the #500 ranked supercomputer was approximately 96.6 thousand Gflops/s.

Resolution Criteria

The outcome will be resolved "yes" if during the June 2014 International Supercomputing Conference, the TOP500 announces that the performance of the #500 ranked supercomputer has exceeded 150 thousand Gflops/s. The outcome will be resolved based on the presented and published results of the TOP500 at the International Supercomputing Conference (http://www.top500.org/? or http://www.isc-events.com/isc14/). Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from TOP500 or International Supercomputing Conference. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or the question may be deemed invalid/void.

name: When will the U.S. Army's special armed forces debut the TALOS suits (also called Iron Man suits) on the battleground?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well equipped as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

Analysts and experts forecast that the suit maybe ready sometime within 2016-2018.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/

http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/11/19/talos-iron-man-suit_n_4300576.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media that the TALOS suits are being or have been deployed on the ground in a combat zone.


Fine Print

'Debut on the battleground' is defined as deployment to a combat zone.

name: How many days in May 2014 will tree pollen concentration levels measure 'high' or 'very high' in Atlanta, Georgia?
question_text:
• The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (AAAAI) is a professional organization with more than 6,800 members in the United States, Canada, and 72 other countries. This membership includes allergist/immunologists, other medical specialists, allied health and related healthcare professionals - all with a special interest in the research and treatment of allergic and immunologic diseases.
  • The National Allergy Bureau (NAB) is the section of the AAAAI?s Aeroallergen Network responsible for reporting current pollen and mold spore levels.The Aeroallergen Network is comprised of pollen and spore counting stations staffed primarily by AAAAI member volunteers who generously donate their time and expertise. The NAB currently provides the most accurate and reliable pollen and mold levels from approximately 79 counting stations throughout the United States, one counting station in Canada, and six counting stations in Argentina. The stations use air sampling equipment to collect airborne pollen and spores which are then examined microscopically. This information is also used for research to aid in the diagnosis, treatment and management of allergic diseases.Pollen counts from the NAB stations are based on actual counts, which reflect the real day to day weather events. Predicted counts reported on many websites may be based on pollen data from previous years and general weather forecasts.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/07/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on data reported by the?AAAAI NAB Pollen and Mold Report/Calendar of Data for the month of May 2014, which can be found here:?http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=AllergenCalendar&stationid=49&qsFullDate=05/06/2014

Fine Print

The NAB pollen levels were developed using the NAB Scale, which can be found here: http://pollen.aaaai.org/nab/index.cfm?p=reading_charts3&statid=147The concentrations in the chart were statistics from all certified counting sites.

The concentrations were translated into levels based on the following:
?- Low levels are concentrations that are less than the median or 50th percentile (i.e. half the counts were below the median.)
- Moderate levels are concentrations that fall between the 50th and 75th percentile
- High levels fall between the 75th and 99th percentile
- Very high levels are above the 99th percentile (99% of the counts are below this level)

"Atlanta, Georgia" refers to data collected from the NAB pollen count station in 'Georgia - Marietta (Atlanta), (Atlanta Allergy and Asthma Clinic)'

name: When will the IPv6 traffic measured by Google surpass 4%?
question_text:
From an FAQ by Google about IPv6:
IPv4 is the current version of the Internet Protocol, the identification system the Internet uses to send information between devices. This system assigns a series of four numbers (each ranging from 0 to 255) to each device. IPv4 only allows for about 4 billion addresses and the Internet needs more room than that. IPv6 is the new version of the Internet Protocol and expands the number of available addresses to a virtually limitless amount?340 trillion trillion trillion addresses.

The?Google IPv6 traffic graph?is one of the most watched barometers of global IPv6 deployment. The weekend of 2/22/14 it crossed another round number ? 3%. The?2% threshold was crossed?on September 21, 2013.?The IPv6 deployment rate is accelerating, since before that it had been almost a year since the measure crossed 1% (on Oct 27, 2012).

Here is an article about passing the 3% threshold.

Internet Service Providers and anyone who is supporting devices connected to the Internet globally is affected by the potential scarcity of Internet addresses.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/31/2014

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved according to the "Total IPv6" adoption data published by?Google?here.

News about additional adoption milestones will likely also be reported by the Internet Society's?Blog.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Florida?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Florida, 39.4% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -10.6% from 2011 (50.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 38.5%, the "38.5%-41.9%" range will be deemed correct.

choices_field_4: Will not be discovered by January 1, 2020
name: When will a distinct source of ultra high-energy cosmic rays be discovered?
question_text:
Ultra?high-energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) are the most energetic subatomic particles in the known universe, with energies millions of times higher than have been achieved with humanmade particle accelerators. These rare particles have been observed infrequently since first observed striking the Earth's atmosphere in 1962, and the source(s) of these cosmic rays is currently unknown. Hypothesized sources range from neutron stars to black hole clusters at galactic cores.?

A recent study made with the Telescope Array, a collection of 507 particle detectors covering 700square kilometers of desert in Utah, has observed a broad "hotspot" in the sky in which such cosmic rays seem to originate. Although not definitive, the observation suggests the cosmic rays emanate from a distinct source near our galaxy and not from sources spread all over theuniverse. From 2008 to 2013, researchers spotted 72 cosmic rays with energies above 57 exaelectron volts?15 million times the highest energy achieved with a particle accelerator?and over 25 percent of them appear to cluster in a hotspot in the sky about 20? in radius.

  • Science Magazine - Physicists spot possible source of 'Oh-My-God' particles
  • Wikipedia - Ultra-high-energy cosmic ray

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

The official source(s) for this question are journals indexed in Thomson Reuters Web of Science. An article describing the discovery of a source of ultra?high-energy cosmic rays would also likely be covered in a variety of scientific publications, such as Science Magazine and Scientific American.

Fine Print

An ultra-high-energy cosmic ray is a cosmic ray particle with a kinetic energy greater than 10^18 eV.For this question to be definitively answered 'Yes', an article must be published in a journal indexed in Thomson Reuters Web of Science describing a distinct source of ultra?high-energy cosmic rays.This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first. The date of the article is published will be used to settle the question.

keywords: FCV, alternative fuels, hydrogen fuel cell vehicle
name: Will there be more than 50 public hydrogen fueling stations in the US by the end of 2015?
question_text:
According to the database maintained by the US Department of Energy, there are currently a total of 12 public hydrogen fueling stations in the country, 10 of them in California. With the introduction of the Hyundai Tucson hydrogen fuel cell SUV this year, and the expected releases of Toyota's and Honda's fuel cell cars in 2015, the demand for?hydrogen refueling stations?is likely to go up.?Last fall, California committed $20 million per year through 2024 to build up to 100 hydrogen stations. The state expects to have 37 public stations up and running?in 2015, from currently available funding.

  • http://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/hydrogen_locations.html
  • http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1083615_california-to-have-up-to-70-hydrogen-fueling-stations-by...


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Data available from US DOE?http://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/hydrogen_locations.html

Fine Print

Only public, government-funded hydrogen fueling stations that are on the US DOE's Alternative Fuels Data Center map are considered: http://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/hydrogen_locations.html

name: The Bloodhound is a supersonic car designed to travel over 1000 mph on land - the existing world record is 763 mph. What top land speed will the Bloodhound SSC reach in 2015?
question_text:
The land speed record (763 mph as of?1/1/2015) is held by the Thrust supersonic car, a jet-propelled car. The record was set in October 1997.? A group in Britain is working on a new design of a pencil-shaped car (the Bloodhound supersonic car (SSC)) powered by a jet engine and a rocket engine. Its goal is to beat the land speed record set by the Thrust supersonic car. To do so, significant engineering advances were needed to overcome challenges related to the aerodynamics of bringing a vehicle past the speed of sound. Computer-aided design and other computational modeling techniques were used to build a vehicle that will attempt to surpass the current land speed record.

Sources and links

  • The 1000 MPH Car Does Not Exist?Yet http://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/news/vintage-speed/the-1000-mph-car-does-not-exist-yet-16577046
  • ?The Bloodhound Project http://www.bloodhoundssc.com/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

The official announcement by the Federation Internationale de l?Automobile http://www.fia.com/sports/fia-world-land-speed-records

If there are no recorded tests in 2015, the question will resolve as "0 mph."

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of California?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of California, 65.0% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of 0.0% from 2011 (65.0%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 64.1%, the "64.1%-67.5%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will a new solution to the Navier-Stokes Existence and Smoothness problem be published in a peer-reviewed journal by the end of 2015?
question_text:
The Navier-Stokes existence and smoothness problem concerns the mathematical properties of solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations, one of the pillars in fluid mechanics.?These equations describe the motion of a fluid (that is, a liquid or a gas) in space. Solutions to the Navier?Stokes equations are used in many practical applications. However, theoretical understanding of the solutions to these equations is incomplete. In particular, solutions of the Navier?Stokes equations often include?turbulence, which remains one of the greatest?unsolved problems in physics, despite its immense importance in science and engineering.??

The Navier?Stokes problem in two dimensions has already been solved positively since the 1960s: there exist smooth and globally defined solutions. But for the three-dimensional system of equations, and given some initial conditions, mathematicians have not yet proved that smooth solutions always exist, or that if they do exist, they have bounded energy per unit mass. This is called the Navier?Stokes existence and smoothness problem.?Since understanding the Navier?Stokes equations is considered to be the first step to understanding the elusive phenomenon of turbulence, the?Clay Mathematics Institute?in May 2000 made this problem one of its seven?Millennium Prize Problems?in mathematics. It offered a?$1,000,000 prize to the first person providing a solution for a specific statement of the problem.

In 2013, Mukhtarbay Otelbaev from the Eurasian National University in Astana, Kazakhstan proposed a solution. As a serious attempt to solve an important open problem, the proof was immediately inspected by others in the field, who found at least one serious flaw. Otelbaev is attempting to fix the proof, and hoping to publish a new, corrected new proof soon,?he claims in about 3 months.?However, other mathematicians are skeptical.

  • Navier-Stokes Existence and Smoothness:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navier%E2%80%93Stokes_existence_and_smoothness
  • Millennium Prize Problems:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennium_Prize_Problems
  • A Fluid New Path in Grand Math Challenge:?http://www.quantamagazine.org/20140224-a-fluid-new-path-in-grand-math-challenge/
  • Fiendish million-dollar proof eludes mathematicians:?http://www.nature.com/news/fiendish-million-dollar-proof-eludes-mathematicians-1.15659



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

A solution would be published in a peer reviewed mathematics publication, such as Annals of Mathematics, Acta Mathematica, and Mathematical Journal,?and may be found on online archive arXiv.org.

Fine Print

The solution fixed by Otelbaev would be considered a new solution.

name: In the week of November 23rd-29th 2014, will Walmart be searched more frequently than Amazon in Google Search for the US?
question_text:
Google Trends is a public web facility of Google, Inc., based on Google Search. It shows how often a particular search term is entered relative to the total search-volume, across various regions of the world, and in various languages. The Friday after Thanksgiving is named Black Friday in the US, and is traditionally a major day for holiday shopping. In 2014, Black Friday will be on November 28th. In 2013, Walmart was ahead of Amazon by 25% in searches during the week encompassing Black Friday.

keywords: Hydrogen production, solar hydrogen production, water splitting, chemistry
name: When will the world record for solar hydrogen production efficiency by a stable oxide semiconductor photoanode system exceed the 2013 record of 5.3%?
question_text:
Scientists since at least as far back as the 1800s have investigated a wide variety of materials searching for combinations that can use solar energy to split water into hydrogen and oxygen efficiently.? Systems delivering a record solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency over 12?% have been demonstrated using III?V semiconductor materials, but their cost and stability remain major disadvantages. Efficiencies of stable oxide systems have been much too low for practical use (considered to be efficiencies >10%). Before September 2013, the record for solar hydrogen production efficiency (water splitting efficiency) was set using a stable oxide semiconductor photoanodes by Gratzel et al at 4.2%

In the 2013 Kim et al demonstrated a solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 5.3% for a "wormlike" hematite photoanode. Hematite (?-Fe2O3) has a small band gap (~2.1?eV) that allows 15.3% of theoretical solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency (or photocurrent generation of 12.6?mA/cm2 at 1.23?V vs. RHE under 1-sun irradiation), excellent stability under alkaline conditions, low price, and environmentally benign characteristics.

Considering that the current record for a hematite photoanode system is only a third of the theoretical solar-to-hydrogen efficiency, this question asks if future work will improve on the current record of 5.3%

Resolution Criteria

Researchers at the Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology and University of Tokyo who set the most recent record may indicate when the new record is set.

Researchers at the ?cole Polytechnique F?d?rale de Lausanne who set the previous record for stable oxide systems, may indicate when the new record is set.?


Resolution Sources

This advancement would be published in a peer-reviewed journals and covered by clean-energy websites such as http://cleantechnica.com/

Fine Print

  • 5.3% = 4.32?mA/cm2 photoelectrochemical water oxidation current at 1.23?V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode under simulated 1-sun (100?mW/cm2) irradiation
  • Any stable oxide photoanode system that produces an efficiency above 5.3% will qualify for this question.

Useful Information and Links

  • Kim, J. Y., G. Magesh, et al. (2013). "Single-crystalline, wormlike hematite photoanodes for efficient solar water splitting." Scientific Reports 3.?
  • Gratzel, M. (2001). "Photoelectrochemical cells." NATURE 414(6861): 338-344
  • Sivula, K., F. Le?Formal, et al. (2011). "Solar Water Splitting: Progress Using Hematite (?-Fe2O3) Photoelectrodes." ChemSusChem 4(4): 432-449
  • Photoelectrochemical Water Splitting @ NREL


Related Organizations or Individuals

M. Gratzel is the leading authority. John Turner and Todd Deutsch of NREL also are sources for information on this topic.
short_name: Solar hydrogen production efficiency new record

keywords: Comet, Rosetta, organc compounds, cometary dust
name: Will the European Space Agency's Rossetta mission find any organic compounds in the cometary dust it collects from Comet 67P/C-G?
question_text:
After a decade long journey, the European Space Agency's (ESA) Rosetta spacecraft has arrived at destination Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, and started collecting cometary dust from the coma encircling the comet's nucleus with the onboard COSIMA instrument in August 2014. COSIMA stands for Cometary Secondary Ion Mass Analyser. Its purpose is to conduct the first "in-situ" analysis of the grains of dust particles emitted from the comet's nucleus and determine their physical and chemical charateristics, including whether they are organic or inorganic. COSIMA will collect the coma dust using 24 specially designed "target holders" - the first of which was opened to study the comets environment on August 10th. ESA plans to keep the target holder open for at least a month and check the progress of any particles collected on a weekly basis. It is expected that any grains found on the first target?will be analyzed by mid-September 2014.

  • Coma dust collection science starts for Rosetta at Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko: http://www.universetoday.com/113777/coma-dust-collection-science-starts-for-Rosetta-at-comet-67pchur...
  • Rosetta (spacecraft): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosetta_%28spacecraft%29


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Discovery will be reported by ESA on http://www.esa.int/ESA
