keywords: TALOS suits, external digital signature, weapons detection
name: Will radar based weapons detection technologies be integrated into the US Army special armed forces' TALOS suits to generate an external digital signature of the enemy?s barreled weapon, by the end of 2018?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well equipped as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

Threat detection is one of the critical concerns of dismounted soldiers. With advances in sensor technologies, acoustic, radar, imaging, and other multisensory technologies can help soldiers detect enemy shots/artillery from a very long distance to better prepare them with intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities. Using advanced sensing and radar signal processing technologies, Firstguard?s Hintz radar weapon detection system can be used to detect and identify the presence of a barreled weapon aimed in the vicinity of a target before the weapon is fired. In a complementary technique (US Patent 7,382,312) utilizing the same radar data, which is used for detection, an external digital signature can be quickly recognized to identify the type of weapon.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/?
http://www.firstguardtech.com/5.html

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that may say the following: 1) the feature has been integrated into a non-prototype suit or 2) that the suits deployed on the ground have this feature.

keywords: Cybersecurity, malware, public-key cryptography, cyber security
name: Will malware signed by a key not previously acknowledged to have been stolen be reported in the news at least once in 2015?
question_text:
Requiring software that will be run by an operating system to be certified by a supplier and the certification to be checkable at run time is well established.? The certification and checking process is completed via public-key signatures, an encryption system intended to be verifiable by end-users who have no prior relationship with the supplier. This system (if well implemented) is very secure but this quite naturally assumes that there has been no theft of the key that confers the ability to construct such signatures.?
??
 In the wake of the recent Sony Pictures Entertainment breaches, researchers discovered that the malware sample was signed by a legitimate certificate stolen from Sony. This sample is essentially identical to an earlier version of Destover malware. that was not signed. In recent years, Destover has been used in a variety of attacks, and it's representative of the genre of malware that doesn't just compromise machines and steal data, but can destroy information as well.
The attackers who have claimed credit for the attack on Sony spent several weeks gradually releasing large amounts of information stolen in the breach, including unreleased movies, personal data of Sony employees and sensitive security information such as digital certificates and passwords.?

For more information:

  • http://it.slashdot.org/story/14/12/10/063216/new-destover-malware-signed-by-stolen-sony-certificate
  • http://www.wired.com/2014/12/sony-hack-what-we-know/


This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by a publication from major news sources and may also be found?either from?Brian Krebs (krebsonsecurity.com) or?threatpost.com.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

Fine Print

A "key" in this question refers to the private (secret) key by which a signature is constructed. The public key used to verify that signature is intentionally widely known.

name: When will the next now-extinct animal clone reach live birth?
question_text:
In 1996,researchers succeeded in cloning the first mammal using genetic material taken froman adult animal. After 276 attempts, Scottish researchers finally produced thenow famous Dolly, the lamb cloned from the udder cell of a 6-year-old adult sheep.Cloning is accomplished by transferring DNA of the adult donor animal cell intoan egg cell that has had its own DNA-containing nucleus removed. The combined egg, allowed to develop into an early-stage embryo in the lab, is then implantedinto the womb of an adult female animal, where it gestates to term. SinceDolly, many other mammal species have been cloned, including cat, deer, dog, horse,mule, ox, rabbit, and rat.

Scientistsare now attempting to use the same method to bring extinct animals back tolife. To do so, they need to find preserved genetic material from an extinctanimal to place into the emptied cell of a donor animal of a similar,non-extinct species. The procedure has been done successfully through to livebirth with just one species, the Pyrenean ibex. After 57 implantations, onlyseven surrogate mothers became pregnant, six of which miscarried. The one live birthnewborn died ten minutes after birth. In 2013 scientists successfully clonedembryos for the extinct frog Rheobatrachus silus, but these died afterdeveloping for several days.

Several extinctspecies are candidates for cloning. These are species for which naturally orartificially preserved genetic material is available, and include the giantsloth, the Cuban red macaw, the saber-toothed cat, and the woolly mammoth,among others.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-25052233
  • http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/04/125-species-revival/zimmer-text
  • http://www.genome.gov/25020028#al-2

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

Successfulcloning of an extinct animal would be reported in scientific literature,the science press, and the popular press.

Fine Print

Successful cloning can be defined as the live birth, via surrogate mother, of an extinct animal cloned from the preserved generic material of the same species. There is no criterion regarding how long the cloned animal lives after birth.

keywords: U.S., Almonds, Production, Tons, 2013, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total U.S. almond utilized production during the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of tons?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • U.S. almond utilized?production (in-shell equivalents)?for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 1,730,100 tons.
  • Almond production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as almonds?are solely dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is?the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Almond production is reported in thousands of tons, in-shell equivalents,?thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service.


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. almond utilized?production' is reported in 'in-shell equivalents'.

The '2013 marketing season' ?for almonds begins 08/05/2013 and ends 11/15/2013.


The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.


Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts:?http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/MannUsda/viewDocumentInfo.do?documentID=1113
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Preliminary Summary:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-01-25-2013.pdf
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 11/19/2013 Sequestration Announcement:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-11-19-2013.txt

name: Will at least one death caused by measles in the US be reported in 2015?
question_text:
As of January 21, 2015, 59 cases of measles have been confirmed in California residents since the start of the year. Of the confirmed cases, 42 have been linked to an initial exposure at the Disney amusement park in Anaheim, California. Confirmed cases have also been reported?in six other states in the US. The U.S. experienced a record number of measles cases in 2014, with 644 cases from 27 states reported to CDC, the greatest number of cases since measles elimination was documented in the US in 2000. According to CDC, the majority of the people who got measles are unvaccinated.

Measles is one of the most contagious human diseases. The airborne virus can linger in an area up to two hours after an infected person leaves, and approximately 90 percent of people without immunity will be infected?if exposed to the virus. Serious complications from measles can include pneumonia and encephalitis, which can lead to long-term deafness or brain damage, and even to?death.

  • California Measles Outbreak Shows How Quickly Disease Can Resurface in U.S.:?https://www.yahoo.com/health/california-measles-outbreak-shows-how-quickly-108833971042.html

name: Will a research group demonstrate a transistor made of graphene and hexagonal boron nitride with a gate response time of 2 mV/dec at 20 K by the end of 2016?
question_text:
• Researchers built a graphene and hexagonal boron nitride superlattice that exploits the topological effects of the graphene while the boron nitride allows researchers to induce and manipulate the topological bulk current with no magnetic field. (B=0)
  • Researchers observed that the electrons moved at controllable angles to applied fields in the superlattice of graphene and hexagonal boron nitride. ?
  • The researchers fabricated a device with the superlattice with a short top gate (15 nm dielectric) that they used to switch on and off valley currents similar to a field effect transistor.
  • A device built with the graphene and hexagonal boron nitride superlattice with sub-threshold slope better than those achievable for conventional charge-based processing devices would enable lower power computer due to the reduction in energy dissipation. ?

name: Researchers have predicted computationally that carbyne is the strongest material known; however, its strength has yet to be measured experimentally.  What will be the first published measured  intrinsic strength of carbyne?
question_text:
In 2014, researchers predicted the tensile strength of carbyne using first-principles calculations and found that ?carbyne is about twice as stiff as the stiffest known materials and has an unrivaled specific strength of up to 7.5 ? 107 N?m/kg, requiring a force of ?10 nN to break a single atomic chain.? The authors noted that tensile strength is hard to determine computationally, but state that the material is ?stiffer by a factor of 2 than graphene and carbon nanotubes.??

Graphene is currently the strongest material that has been experimentally measured in the lab. In 2008, researchers at Columbia University measured the intrinsic strength of graphene and found to be 42?N/m. This intrinsic strength (or intrinsic stiffness) of a defect-free sheet was measured by the team by indenting the graphene film using an atomic force microscope with a diamond tip that has a radius of about 20?nm.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

Published in a peer-reviewed journal indexed by Thomson Reuters? Web of Science.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

Intrinsic strength is the maximum stress that a pristine (or defect-free) material can withstand just before all the atoms in a given cross-section are pulled apart at the same time.

keywords: Flu, Region 1, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: What will be the peak ILI percentage observed during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 1 (CT, ME, MA, NH, RI, VT)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?
This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 1' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for the 2014-2015 flu season in Region 1?will not be revised further.

Fine Print

For this question, 'peak ILI percentage' is defined as the weighted ILI percentage at the peak week across HHS region 1. Region 1 is comprised of Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont.

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 6.0%, the revised value could be, example, 6.0 + 2%(6.0) = 6.12%.

name: Will a phase 2a clinical trial show that AstraZeneca's Src tyrosine kinase inhibitor, a drug original developed for cancer treatment, is effective for treating Alzheimer's disease?
question_text:
Experimental drugs proven safe but perhaps not sufficiently effective in initial testing or against a first disease target may sit gathering dust on the shelves of pharmaceutical companies. An NIH-sponsored effort based on a crowdsourcing strategy to establish collaborations between industrial and academic partners to repurpose these therapeutic compounds was met with an overwhelming response and has led to clinical testing of a broad range of pilot projects. The scope of the pilot limits investigators to using the agents in their original formulation and with short period of support (2-3 years) to complete phase 1b and 2a clinical trials. It will be a few years before we know what the success rate is?of phase 2a clinical trials established using this strategy. In the initial phase,?NCATS funding was awarded to nine projects in 2013, including?the investigations of an AstraZeneca Src tyrosine kinase inhibitor originally developed for cancer treatment for its therapeutic uses in Alzheimer's disease and?Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) treatment. A phase 2a clinical trial for the drug use in Alzheimer's disease is under way.

  • NIH turns to crowdsourcing to repurpose drugs:?http://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-07-nih-crowdsourcing-repurpose-drugs.html#inlRlv
  • The NIH-Industry New Therapeutic Uses Pilot Program: Demonstrating the Power of Crowdsourcing:?http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1089/drrr.2014.0006
  • Fyn Inhibition by AZD0530 for Alzheimer?s Disease:?http://www.ncats.nih.gov/research/reengineering/rescue-repurpose/therapeutic-uses/projects-2013.html...
  • A Phase IIa Multi-Center Study of 18F-FDG PET, Safety, and Tolerability of AZD0530 in Mild Alzheimer's Disease:?http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02167256

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/2016

Resolution Source

Clinical trial status and test results can be found in the NIH clinical trial database:?http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02167256

keywords: Solar energy, solar cells, solar efficiency, photovoltaic energy, photovoltaic cells, photovoltaic efficiency, CdTe, dye-sensitized, Perovskite, organic solar cells, organic tandem cells, CZTSSe, quantum dot solar cells, chemistry
name: What type of solar cell in the NREL emerging photovoltaic cell category will be the first to show a larger research cell efficiency than the CdTe research solar cell efficiency before DEC 31 2015?
question_text:
Cadmium Telluride (CdTe) is a crystalline inorganic compound used in solar modules. It is considered a thin film photovoltaic (PV) technology, meaning CdTe cells are manufactured by depositing a series of thin layers of CdTe and other conductive material on top of a substrate. CdTe solar cells? efficiencies are below single crystal Si photovoltaic cells, but they are less expensive to manufacture. NREL?s best research-cell efficiency chart defines ?emerging PV? to include dye-sensitized cells, Perovskite cells, organic cells of various composition, organic tandem cells, inorganic cells made of CZTSSe, and quantum dot cells. As of the December 4, 2013 chart, the best research-cell efficiency for a CdTe cell is 19.6%, while the best efficiency for an emerging PV cell is 16.2% (a Perovskite cell).

The Perovskite cell is a new type of solar cell introduced into the chart in 2013. In the November 11, 2013 NREL-published chart, the record for Perovskite cells was 14.1%.? On December 4, 2013, NREL published a new chart showing the record efficiency for Perovskite cell is now 16.2%.

GE Global Research holds the current record for CdTe research-cell efficiencies at 19.6%. First Solar held the previous record. Recently, First Solar and GE Global Research announced a partnership in manufacturing and researching CdTe solar cells. Therefore, a combination of the firms may achieve the next record. Alternatively, advancements in efficiencies may be delayed due to the new partnership. A wide variety of companies and academic labs hold efficiency records for emerging PV. The list below contains the efficiency record holder for each technology as published in the Dec. 4, 2013 NREL Chart .?

  • Dye-sensitized cells: Sharp [11.9%]
  • Perovskite cells: Korean Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT) [16.2%]
  • Organic cells (various types): Mitsubishi Chemical [11.1%]
  • Organic tandem cells: UCLA-Sumitomo Chemical [10.6%]
  • Inorganic cells (CZTSSe): IBM [11.1%]
  • Quantum dot cells: MIT [8.6%]

Resolution Criteria

The research cell efficiency of an emerging PV solar cell will need to surprass the CdTe research cell efficiency in order to be the resolution. If this does not occur by 12/31/2015, the question will be resolved as 'None of the above'.

Resolution Sources

NREL Research Cell Efficiency Records:?http://www.nrel.gov/ncpv/images/efficiency_chart.jpg

Fine Print

  • This question will be resolved using the?NREL Research Cell Efficiency Records ? as published at?http://www.nrel.gov/ncpv/images/efficiency_chart.jpg

Useful Information and Links

  • Current Research Cell Efficiency Records Chart
  • Papers that contains the references behind the current chart: Green, M. A., K. Emery, et al. (2013). "Solar cell efficiency tables (version 42)." Progress in Photovoltaics 21(5): 827-837.
  • CdTe market leaders? partnership:?
  • Relevant articles related to emerging PV (outside of references for cell efficiency table):
  • Hodes, G. (2013). "Perovskite-Based Solar Cells." SCIENCE 342(6156): 317-318.
  • Service, R. F. (2004). "Organic solar cells playing catch-up." SCIENCE 306(5704): 2034-2034.
  • McGehee, M. D. (2011). "Paradigm Shifts in Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells." SCIENCE 334(6056): 607-608.
  • Norris, D. J. and E. S. Aydil (2012). "Getting Moore from Solar Cells." SCIENCE 338(6107): 625-626.
  • Jeon, N. J., J. Lee, et al. (2013). "Efficient Inorganic?Organic Hybrid Perovskite Solar Cells Based on Pyrene Arylamine Derivatives as Hole-Transporting Materials." Journal of the American Chemical Society.

Related Organizations or Individuals

The National Renewable Energy Laboratory?s National Center for Photovoltaics.

keywords: Math, Mathematics, Algorithms, Computing, Integers, Factoring
name: When will a classical algorithm be published for factoring arbitrary n-digit numbers in exp(O(n^{1/4} polylog(n))) time or less?
question_text:
Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved ?yes? if the algorithm is authored with an applicable 'running time' as defined by the question moderator. If no significant news is reported by the date in question, then the "status quo" outcome typically will be assumed (i.e., an algorithm has yet to be authored for factoring integers with a running time equal to or less than eO(n1/4) for n digit numbers). In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.

Resolution Sources

'STOC' and/or 'FOCS' or a publicly circulated preprint within the theoretical computer science community

Fine Print

By 'Algorithm' we mean a randomized algorithm which outputs a correct factorization for any number N with some constant probability (say 1/2). 'Running time' requires definition by SME. "By" means at or prior to the end of the specified date (11:59:59 pm ET). ?Between? should be interpreted to mean at any point during the window after the beginning (12 midnight ET) of the first date, but before the end (23:59:59 PM ET) of the second date.

Useful Links

http://www.math.upenn.edu/~pemantle/papers/square-algorithms.pdf

Related Organizations or Individuals

Theoretical Computing Science Journals

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Consumer availabilityof the Aero-Xhoverbike will be announced at the company?s website here:? http://aerofex.com/

Fine Print

Available for sale and use by 2017 means consumers can both purchase an Aero-X hoverbike and use it (for private use) by the end of 2017. The vehicle is not intended to be street legal, so private use does not mean use on public roads.

name: At the end of 2015, will GoFundMe be one of the top three crowdfunding sites reported by compete.com with the most web traffic in the United States?
question_text:
Crowdfunding?is the practice of funding a project or venture by raising monetary contributions from a large number of people, typically via the internet.?Crowdfunding has quickly moved from a trendy buzzword to a mainstream fundraising model.?In less than five years, Kickstarter has attracted more than five million contributors pledging close to $1 billion, funding more than 55,000 individual projects. Kickstarter's rival fundraising platform Indiegogo can boast of a campaign that single-handedly generated $12 million in pledges. Numbers like these make crowdfunding an attractive option for first-time entrepreneurs and established businesses alike, giving them the opportunity not only to raise capital but also to gain a sense of the market for a given project.?

On February 11, 2015, the?crowdfunding website GoFundme.com?was reported to be the?second among?crowdfunding sites in terms of web traffic?in the United States?behind?kickstarter.com. ?

For more information:

  • Crowdfunding:?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowdfunding
  • Top ten crowdfunding sites:?http://www.crowdfunding.com/
  • http://www.alexa.com/

?

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

The?top ten crowdfunding?website rankings are published on crowdfunding.com?every day:?http://www.crowdfunding.com/. The Complete Rank will be used to resolve this question?at COB (EST) on December 31, 2015.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

Rankings are published on www.crowdfunding.com.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of New York?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of New York, 56.0% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +9.4% from 2011 (46.6%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 55.1%, the "55.1%-58.5%" range will be deemed correct.

name: When will the first augmented reality (AR) device be available for consumer purchase?
question_text:
The concept of holograms, manufactured images that exist in the real world rather than on a screen, has long been a staple of science fiction.? Currently, there are several companies pursuing a range of options to bring this form of technology to consumers.? The two broad categories of holograms currently under development are augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR).?


Augmented reality refers to digital images that are superimposed on the world around the user.? For instance, the user might watch television on a blank wall or build a structure on an empty table. ?It is the more difficult of the two to realize because it is interactive in nature.? By contrast virtual reality replaces the real world with digital images.? It is dependent primarily on software that tracks the user?s movement.?

Rudimentary forms of virtual reality are already available, including one that takes the form of instructions from google to make a virtual reality headset out of cardboard and a smartphone app. Google also took the first strides into augmented reality with google glass, but did not fully achieve it because the device did not display images in real space and was not freely available for purchase. True augmented reality represents the possibility of a new computing platform rather than merely a single use entertainment device. Microsoft?s HoloLens and possibly the device underdevelopment by the Google backed company Magic Leap are the two known entrants in this area.

Sources:
Hololens http://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-hololens/en-us/get-ready
http://www.pcpro.co.uk/wearables/1000431/microsoft-hololens-release-date-specs-and-price

Magic Leap: http://www.engadget.com/2015/02/25/magic-leap-explainer/

Google Cardboard: http://www.google.com/get/cardboard/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2017

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved if an announcement is made on?an official company press release stating that an augmented reality device is available for purchase or when the device is available in stores or on the Internet (this cannot be for pre-order or other promotions).?

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

consumer purchase means NOT pre-order and NOT developer additions. A member of the general public must be able to visit a store or a website to purchase the device.

question_text:
As of Dec 31 2013, there were 20 nuclear power reactors in operation in China, while 29 more were under construction.

keywords: Flu, Region 5, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will flu activity peak during the 2014-2015 flu season in HHS Region 5 (IL, IN, MI, MN, OH, WI)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/12/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 5' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"
This question will be settled when the question author or Topic Leader determines there is a reasonable expectation that the existing peak ILI % for for the 2014-2015 flu season will not be revised further.

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.For this question, the 'peak week' of the season for HHS Region 5 is defined as the week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS region 5 is the highest. Region 5 is comprised of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.In the event the peak occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

keywords: thorium, fission, nuclear energy, nuclear reactor
name: Will India have an operating thorium-fueled nuclear power plant by the end of 2016?
question_text:
Nuclear power generated from the fission of uranium or plutonium isotopes supplies large amounts of electricity with zero carbon emissions, but also poses several risks, including the creation of inputs to nuclear weapons development and the hazards of disposing of radioactive waste products. Historically, nuclear power has been uranium or plutonium based precisely because these elements are also inputs to nuclear weapons development. Use of thorium as a fissile fuel source poses none of these problems, and so there are active programs of research on thorium-fueled reactors around the world.

One of the most advanced thorium nuclear programs is in India, and reports have indicated that India plans to have an operational thorium-fueled nuclear power plant by 2016.

For more information, see:

  • http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/2015/01/16/thorium-future-nuclear-energy/#.VLvkNXt_vMs
  • http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/worlds-first-thorium-based-nuclear-reactor-barc/1/343569.html
  • http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/finance/ambroseevans-pritchard/100026863/china-going-for-broke-on-thori...


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

Electricity generated by an operational thorium reactor in India will be reported by the popular and trade press. It is also expected to be recorded here:?http://www.iaea.org/PRIS/CountryStatistics/CountryDetails.aspx?current=IN

This question will resolve when any such infection is mentioned, or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.???

Fine Print

An operational thorium-fueled nuclear power plant is one that produces any electricity from a steam turbine whose steam is created via the head produced from thorium fission. Pilot and demonstration levels of operation count as long as they produce electricity from a steam turbine powered by steam created from the heat generated by thorium fission.

name: In October 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the end of the Ebola outbreak in Senegal and Nigeria. Will the WHO declare the end of the Ebola outbreak in any one of Guinea, Liberia or Sierra Leone before the end of March 2015?
question_text:
After a tough battle with the disease, Senegal was the first West African country to be?declared Ebola free?by the WHO?on October 17th, 2014,?followed by Nigeria on October 20th, 2014. However, the outbreak is still raging in the three other West African countries: Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. As of October 19th, WHO reported a total of 9936 confirmed, probable, and suspected?Ebola cases, of which 1540 are in Guinea, 4665 in Nigeria, and 3706 in Sierra Leone.

  • WHO Ebola Response?Roadmap Situiation Report (October 22, 2014): ?http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/137091/1/roadmapsitrep22Oct2014_eng.pdf
  • WHO congratulates Senegal on ending Ebola transmission:?http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2014/senegal-ends-ebola/en/
  • WHO declares end of Ebola outbreak in Nigeria:?http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2014/nigeria-ends-ebola/en/


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

Declaration will be made and announced by WHO:?http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/en/

Fine Print

According to WHO recommendations, the end of an Ebola virus disease outbreak in a country can be declared once 42 days have passed and no new cases have been detected. The 42 days represents twice the maximum incubation period for Ebola (21 days). This 42-day period starts from the last day that any person in the country had contact with a confirmed or probable Ebola case.
short_name: End of Ebola in W African countries

name: Will the WHO recommended composition of the influenza virus vaccine for the 2015-16 northern hemisphere flu season contain A(H1N1)pdm09-like virus?
question_text:
In February of each year, the WHO consults with experts from?Collaborating Centers in the US, UK, Australia, Japan and China,?plus other partners, to review data gathered by the worldwide network of influenza laboratories.?The WHO then makes recommendations for the composition of the seasonal influenza vaccine for the Northern Hemisphere. The vaccine viruses recommended by WHO for the 2014-15 northern hemisphere influenza season are the same as those for the 2013-14 influenza season, and contain an A/California/7/2009(H1N1)pdm09-like virus, an A/Texas/50/2012(H3N2)-like virus, and a B/Massachusetts/2/2012-like virus.?

  • Recommended composition of influenza virus vaccines for use in the 2014-2015 northern hemisphere influenza season:?http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/recommendations/201402_recommendation.pdf
  • Select viruses for the seasonal influenza vaccine:?http://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/season/vaccine-selection.htm

Accepting Forecasts Until:

1/31/2015

Resolution Source

Recommendation for 2015-16 flu season?will be made by WHO in February 2015:?http://www.who.int/influenza/vaccines/virus/recommendations/en/

Fine Print

H1N1/09 virus strain was responsible for the 2009 swine flu pandemic that caused 17,000 deaths worldwide by the start of 2010.

name: According to the World Health Organization, will overall life expectancy in the United States reach 80 years in 2014?
question_text:
According to the World Health Organization, the overall life expectancy in the United States?(males and females combined) was 79 years in 2012. Will this number reach 80 by 2014?


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2016

Resolution Source

Data from WHO:

http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.688?lang=en

WHO World Health Statistics Reports:
http://www.who.int/gho/publications/world_health_statistics/en/

Fine Print

Life expectancy is measured by different organizations (WHO, United Nations etc) with slightly different results. This question is resolved using WHO statistics. Overall life expectancy is for life expectancy at birth and for both males and females combined. Note: WHO publishes data for life expectancy biennially (every two years). Therefore the 2016 report will publish data about 2014 life expectancy statistics. Accordingly, the previous resolution date of 2014 has been extended to May 2016.

name: Will El Ni?o form in 2014?
question_text:
El Ni?o is a band of anomalously warm ocean water temperatures that periodically develops off the western coast of South America and can cause climatic changes across the Pacific Ocean. There is a phase of 'El Ni?o?Southern Oscillation' (ENSO), which refers to variations in the temperature of the surface of the tropical eastern Pacific Ocean (El Ni?o and La Ni?a) and in air surface pressure in the tropical western Pacific. The two variations are coupled: the warm oceanic phase, El Ni?o, accompanies high air surface pressure in the western Pacific, while the cold phase, La Ni?a, accompanies low air surface pressure in the western Pacific. The extremes of this climate pattern's oscillations cause extreme weather (such as floods and droughts) in many regions of the world.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) issued an official El Ni?o watch in early March 2014. However, El Ni?o is not always certain to develop. An El Ni?o seemed to be forming two years ago suddenly dissipated.

  • NOAA ENSO Diagnostic Discussion:? http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/enso_advisory/ensodisc.html
  • El Ni?o: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o-Southern_Oscillation
  • There is no certainties with El Nino: http://www.roanoke.com/weather/columns_and_blogs/columns/weather_journal/there-are-no-certainties-wi...


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/01/2015

Resolution Source

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA): http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/enso_advisory/ensodisc.html

Fine Print

The Oceanic Ni?o Index (ONI) has become the de-facto standard that NOAA uses for identifying El Ni?o (warm) and La Ni?a (cool) events in the tropical Pacific. It is the running 3-month mean SST anomaly for the Ni?o 3.4 region (i.e., 5oN-5oS, 120o-170oW). El Ni?o events are defined as 5 consecutive overlapping 3-month periods at or above the +0.5o anomaly. This question will resolve as ?Yes? if one or more 3-month periods that is part of an El Ni?o event occurs in 2014. This question will remain open until May 2015 in the event that a string of 5 consecutive 3-month +0.5o anomaly occurs from DEC 2014 ? APR 2015, signifying an El Ni?o event began to form in 2014. This question can resolve prior to MAY 2015, but not before the DEC 2014 ONI number has been released by NOAA.

keywords: Dicty, Race, HL60, Neutrophil, slime mold, Dictyostelium, Insall
name: What place will the Insall Lab's cell line finish in the 2014 Dicty World Race?
question_text:
The Dicty World Race will require cells to navigate a complex microfluidic maze to reach a pool of chemoattractant at the finish line. Diffusion of the chemoattractant will create a spatial gradient to guide cells along the shortest path to the finish line. The challenge is to engineer Dicty or HL60 cells to be both smart and fast! ?

Where Dicty cells shine in precision, they lack in speed, and where HL60 are good sprinters, they lack in precision. Thus, we are asking laboratories around the world to prepare and send us their fastest and smartest Dicty and HL60 cells. Cells will compete against each other and against human neutrophils. The?maze used in the race is manufactured in?the?lab at the BioMEMS Resource Center and recorded using?stereomicroscope cameras.

The?Insall Team's strategy to win the race:

We are a group of three cell biology obsessives who worked together a few years back but have since gone our separate ways. ?We believe that evolution has made cells about as effective as they can be, so the best ways of improving migration are to amplify the cells' own traits, rather than by wholesale changes.

Research being conducted?at the?Insall Lab:

Movement is a fundamental behaviour of cells and its regulation is particularly relevant to cancer because tumour invasion and metastasis are principal causes of death in cancer patients. Our group aims to understand how cell movement is regulated, using a mixture of genetics and microscopy.

We are interested in several aspects of cell movement.One is chemotaxis, in which external signals orient and attract cells, which is increasingly seen as a fundamental cause of metastasis. Metastasis, one of the most feared features of cancer, is caused when cells migrate out from a tumour into the blood, lymph or other tissues. Chemotaxis is clearly important in these processes but exactly how and why remain poorly understood.

Another is the regulation of actin polymerization. Actin is the most abundant protein in eukaryotic cells. It polymerizes into filaments that provide the mechanical force needed to push cells forwards. It also has a number of other biological roles. We are most interested in actin's roles in cell movement and vesicle sorting. In cell movement, the SCAR/WAVE complex, a large multiprotein assembly, promotes movement through the formation of large pseudopods. In vesicles, a related multiprotein complex based around WASH causes actin to polymerize on vesicles, where it mediates sorting of different components within the cell.

We study these two processes in a range of different cells, particularly?Dictyostelium?and melanoma cells.?Dictyostelium?is an amoeba in which the genetic analysis of movement is especially straightforward, and it has been the best experimental organism for studying chemotaxis. Melanoma is a very dangerous and highly metastatic cancer. Its metastasis is derived from the rapid migration of its cells through tissue.

We have recently shown that this migration is underpinned by remarkably accurate chemotaxis.When experimentally appropriate, we also examine human neutrophils, tumour-derived cells, cultured mammalian cells or other amoebas such as?Entamoeba?(the cause of amoebic dysentery) ? anything that will help us to understand the conserved and fundamental mechanisms that drive cell movement.

Useful Links
  • Link to?Insall Lab
  • Dicty World Race Official Webpage
  • Dicty World Race in the Wall Street Journal
  • Link to Dicty Live Stream Site (Coming Soon!)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/17/14

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved based on reporting by the Official Dicty World Race 2014 live stream website.

Fine Print

The first 500 cells to finish the race will be tracked and grouped by the cell type. The winner will be the cell type with largest representation in the "top 100" group. In case of a tie, the cells making the least number of mistakes will be the winners. If there are fewer than 100 cells to finish the race in 2 hours, the winner will be the cell type with the largest number of cells to cross the finish line at the end of the 2 hours.In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, race organizers will deliver judgment decisions required to establish cell performance. SciCast researchers will relay this information to forecasters in real time whenever possible.

This question is asking you to?predict the expected performance of the team in relation to the other cell lines; it is not necessary that you?guess the team's precise rank to gain points. The payout you receive for this question will be proportional to how close your predicted rank is to the team's actual performance. You are able to adjust your prediction in 0.1 increments using Power Mode.?

name: Will the Japanese made influenza drug favipiravir be used in treating the 2014 Ebola outbreak in West Africa?
question_text:
Japan is ready to provide an anti-influenza drug developed by a subsidiary of Fujifilm Holdings Corp. for use in treating patients in the rapid expanding Ebola outbreak in West Africa. The drug, with the brand name Avigan, is approved in Japan to treat new and re-emerging influenza viruses. Although it?has not been proven to be effective against Ebola, influenza and Ebola are similar viruses, so a similar response may occur. The company has enough stocks of favipiravir to treat more than 20,000 patients. According to a?Japanese official, Japan is watching for a decision by WHO that would provide more details on the use of untested drugs against Ebola. In case of emergency, Japan may respond to individual requests before any further decision by WHO.

WHO said earlier in August that it is ethical to use untested drugs on Ebola patients given the magnitude of the outbreak. Two American health workers recovered from Ebola after being treated with the experimental drug ZMapp, though it?is unclear whether they were cured by the drug. However, a Liberian doctor who was among three Africans to receive ZMapp recently died. Only six people in the world are known to have received ZMapp, and?the small supply is now said to be exhausted. It would be months before more can be produced by its US maker.

  • Japan Ready to Offer Flu Drug for Ebola Treatment:?http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/japan-ready-offer-flu-drug-ebola-treatment-25109317
  • Phase 3 Efficacy and Safety Study of Favipiravir for Treatment of Uncomplicated Influenza in Adults:?http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT02008344

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

World Health Organization Ebola News:?http://www.who.int/csr/disease/ebola/en/

Fine Print

Question will be resolved when favipiravir is used in West Africa Ebola outbreak treatment whether by WHO decision or by individual request.

name: Will Cambodia have more threatened species than the Solomon Islands on the next published IUCN Red List of Threatened Species?
question_text:
The InternationalUnion for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) maintains and publishes the IUCN RedList of Threatened Species, widely recognized as the most comprehensive andobjective global approach for evaluating the conservation status of plant andanimal species. In order to produce the Red List, IUCN draws upon a network ofscientists and partner organizations working in almost every country in theworld.

The Red Listidentified species as threatened if they are classified by the IUCN asCritically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), or Vulnerable (VU). Species canalso be classified as extinct (EX) or extinct in the wild (EW); or in one of severalnon-threatened categories: Lower Risk/conservation dependent (LR/cd), NearThreatened (NT), Data Deficient (DD), Least Concern (LC).

In Red Listversion 2014.1 (12 June November 2014), the IUCN reports 234 threatened species forboth the Solomon Islands and Cambodia. The IUCN updates its list at least annually, soa new update should be available and published in 2015.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Thisquestion will be resolved when the IUCN publishes its next update to the RedList. The current list is version 2014.1 from 12 June 2014. The next updated list, once published, will be available in Table 5 and linked to here:? http://www.iucnredlist.org/about/summary-statistics.

If the? countries have the same amount of threatened species on the next published report, this question will resolve as 50%.

Fine Print

IUCN definitions are being used for endangered species, per the discussion in the Background discussion.
short_name: IUCN Solomon Islands v Cambodia Threatened Species

question_text:
Google Trends is a public web facility of Google, Inc., based on Google Search, that shows how often a particular search-term is entered relative to the total search-volume across various regions of the world, and in various languages.

The new Acura NSX is a hybrid-electric supercar that is set to release by Honda's luxury car division for the 2015 model year. This question asks if the Acura NSX will be listed as one of the top five search terms in a Google Trends category.

keywords: Swift, programming language, iOS, OS X, Cocoa Touch, Xcoder
name: Will Swift, the programming language, be among the twenty most Googled software technologies in the US in any month in 2015?
question_text:
Swift is a multi-paradigm compiled programming language created by Apple for iOS and OS X development. Introduced at Apple's 2014 Worldwide Developers Conference, Swift is designed to work with Apple's Cocoa and Cocoa Touch frameworks, plus?the large body of existing Objective-C code written for Apple products. Swift is intended to be more resilient to erroneous code ("safer") than Objective-C, and also more concise (the same idea can be expressed with a smaller quantity of code). It is built with the LLVM compiler framework included in Xcode 6, and uses the Objective-C runtime, allowing C, Objective-C, C++ and Swift code to run within a single program.

Adoption of Swift?has been slow -- developers are wary about fully embracing the new language because its bugs and issues are being worked out. But a large uptick in?Swift?adoption is expected in 2015, especially since there is a possibility that the majority of code samples provided by Apple at WWDC will be written in Swift.

  • Swift (programming language):?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swift_%28programming_language%29
  • Introducing Swift:?https://developer.apple.com/swift/#ftag=YHF87e0214
  • Apple Watch apps will be the next gold rush, and more development predictions for 2015:?https://www.yahoo.com/tech/s/apple-watch-apps-next-gold-080004224.html



Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

Google Trends report can be found here:?https://www.google.com/trends/topcharts#vm=cat&geo=US&date=201412&cid=nature_and_science

keywords: machine learning, reinforcement learning, artificial intelligence, Google products
name: Will Google announce the use of its Deep Q machine learning technology in any of its products by the end of 2016?
question_text:
A recent article in Nature describes an approach to artificial intelligence based on reinforcement learning, an approach to machine learning in which software agents take actions so as to maximize a quantifiable reward parameter. Reinforcement learning in situations approaching real-world complexity require deriving efficient representations of the environment from high-dimensional sensory inputs and using these to generalize past experience to new situations. This is something humans do quite naturally and effectively, but to date its use with machines has focused on limited, artificial domains with low-dimensional state spaces.

The Nature article describes a machine learning agent that can learn directly from high-dimensional sensory inputs using reinforcement learning. This agent, developed by Google and called Deep Q, was tested on classic Atari 2600 games. Receiving only the pixels and the game score as inputs, it was able to? achieve a performance level comparable to that of human gamers. Google hopes to use this technology in its products.

For more information, see:

  • http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v518/n7540/full/nature14236.html
  • http://www.cs.ubc.ca/~murphyk/Bayes/pomdp.html
  • http://googleresearch.blogspot.com/2015/02/from-pixels-to-actions-human-level.html
  • http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/innovations/wp/2015/02/25/5-classic-atari-games-that-totally-stu...


Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

An announcement of the use of the Deep Q technology in any of its products will come directly from Google.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Massachusetts?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Massachusetts, 69.3% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of +8.2% from 2011 (61.1%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 68.4%, the "68.4%-71.8%" range will be deemed correct.

keywords: Air Travel, Crude Oil, ticket prices
name: What will the cost of an average US domestic flight be for the first quarter of 2015?
question_text:
With the prices of crude oil steadily decreasing, the average consumer is able to see this price change at the pump.This price change of oil is not only impacting the auto industry, but also the air travel industry. the price of jet fuel has fallen 43% from the price a year ago, yet the price of airline tickets (in 2014) remained relatively the same.

The average price of a domestic plane ticket in the second quarter, 2014?in the US was $395.62, this was similar to quarters surrounding it, yet noticeably higher than years before. Many believe that airline prices will not go down, because they have not in the past, yet others think that the prices of oil will decrease?so?signiciantly in 2015,??airline tickets will follow suit.

For additional information:

US domestic flight data
Oil Prices?

06/30/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by using the?http://www.rita.dot.gov/bts/airfares/national/table. This question will resolve when the?report is published (expected at the end of the second quarter, 2015).?

Fine Print

This question refers to the U.S. Average (Inflation-Adjusted $) on the data table.

keywords: NAIAS, Car of the Year, automobile, car award
name: Which automobile will win the North American Car of the Year award at the 2015 NAIAS?
question_text:
The North American Car and Truck of the Year (NACTOY) Awards are automobile awards announced at a news conference at the annual North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) in Detroit, Michigan.? The evaluation team consists of approximately 50 expert automotive journalists from across the U.S. and Canada.? The nomination and voting process is as follows:? The initial voting of the jurors in early Fall results in the 'long list' of vehicles (which are the answer choices in this question).? A shorter list of a dozen or so vehicles are selected from this long list to form the 'short list' which is announced in late September/October.? After this a further period of assessment which occurs in December results in three finalists.? A final round of voting is commenced afterwards, with the winners announced at the NAIAS in January.? This question asks which automobile will win the North American Car of the Year award at the 2015 NAIAS.

Relevant Links:
  • 2015 North American Car and Truck/Utility of the Year Candidates Announced
  • North American Car and Truck of the Year Winners: 1994 to 2014
  • Chevrolet Sweeps 2014 NACTOY Awards
  • 2013 Cadillac ATS, Ram 1500 Win Car and Truck of the Year Prizes

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/25/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the automobile that wins the North American Car of the Year award at the 2015 NAIAS.? This will be verified by NACTOY news releases, automotive news sources, and other major news sources.

Fine Print

Note: In the event that the award comes in as a tie, the question will be resolved as a mixture settlement.
short_name: 2015 North American Car of the Year

name: Will a magnitude 4.0 earthquake, or greater, hit Irving, Texas before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Minor earthquakes have been hitting the Irving, Texas area since 2008. To date over 100 earthquakes have been recorded in Irving since 2008 with minimal activity?having been recorded previously. The strongest earthquake recorded?has been?a 3.6 magnitude with one hitting as recently as January 7, 2015.?In addition to the strength of the earthquakes, the frequency with which they have been hitting has been profound. Between January 6-7, 2015, twelve separate earthquakes were recorded in and around the Irving, TX area. When numerous earthquakes hit in sequence, as they did on January 6-7, they are called a 'swarm.'?
??
Scientists are trying to determine the cause of the earthquakes through research being conducted at Southern Methodist University. Possible causes include geological realignment or the aftermath of fracking. Scientists have no way of knowing whether or not a larger, and much more?devastating, earthquake will hit the densely populated region at any point in the future.?

For more information:?

  • http://www.smu.edu/News/NewsIssues/EarthquakeStudy
  • http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Earthquake-Felt-in-Fort-Worth-Dallas-Irving-287697091.html
  • http://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20150110-whats-at-fault-scientists-seek-cause-of-irving-quakes....
  • http://earthquaketrack.com/p/united-states/texas/recent

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved according to?http://earthquaketrack.com/p/united-states/texas/recent, or if another accredited news-source reports a 4.0 earthquake in Irving.?

name: At the end of 2015, will there be at least 25 open clinical trials in the US examining the use of antisense therapy?
question_text:
Antisense therapy is a form of treatment for genetic disorders or infections. When the genetic sequence of a particular gene is known to be causative of a particular disease, it is possible to synthesize a strand of nucleic acid (DNA, RNA or a chemical analogue) that will bind to the messenger RNA (mRNA) produced by that gene and inactivate it, effectively turning that gene "off". This is because mRNA has to be single stranded for it to be translated. Alternatively, the strand might be targeted to bind a splicing site on pre-mRNA and modify the exon content of an mRNA.?

Currently, there are 17 open?clinical trials in the US examining the use of?antisense therapy, according to?the NIH clinical trials database:?http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=antisense&recr=Open


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

NIH Clinical Trial Database:?http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/home

Fine Print

Clinical trials are determined to be 'open' if they are defined as such by NIH's clinicaltrials.gov website. This may include trials at various stages, including recruiting participants (or yet to do so), underway, or yet to publish results.

name: Will a smartphone that incorporates a temperature sensor in the glass be publicly available by June 1st, 2017?
question_text:
A team of researchers from academia and from Corning recently published a paper in Optics Express describing their use of femtosecond lasers to fabricate high quality waveguides in Gorilla Glass that can be used for high-density optoelectronic integration. (Gorilla Glass is widely used in smartphones.) The first complete device the researchers fabricated in the Gorilla Glass was a Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) based temperature sensor. An application of this temperature sensor could be use to detect temperature in a mobile multimedia device.

Links and Sources
"Making Smart Phones Smarter with Photonics," J. Lapointe et al., Optics Express, vol. 22, Issue 13, pp. 15473-15483 (2014). (http://www.opticsinfobase.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-22-13-15473)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

06/01/2017

The product must be available for purchase in stores by the question deadline. This question will closed when the resolution source brought to the moderator?s attention on or before 6/1/2017.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

Fine Print

The temperature sensor must employ the use of waveguides. The smartphone must be available for purchase to the general public (limited release for pilot testing is not applicable) by the question deadline. The feature must be built in to the device by the manufacturer. After market modifications do not satisfy the requirements of the question.

keywords: Black hole, Hawking radiation, event horizon
name: Will the detection of Hawking radiation from a single horizon in the model black hole experiment be reported in a scientific journal before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
In a model black hole experiment, physicists have found radiation?thought to be the analogue of the theoretical Hawking radiation.?Jeff Steinhauer?at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa and his colleagues made a?model black hole using Bose-Eistein condensation (BEC),?a quantum state of matter where a clump of super-cold atoms behaves like a single atom. The team claims that their model black hole has produced the kind of Hawking radiation expected of a real black hole.?The team used one laser to confine the BEC to a narrow tube, and another to accelerate some of it faster than the speed of sound. This fast flow created two horizons: an "outer" one at the point where the flow became supersonic, and an "inner" one further on where the flow slowed down again. The Hawking effect comes from quantum noise at the horizon.?The horizons create pairs of particles of sound, or phonons. One phonon escapes the horizon, and the other is trapped inside it. A single phonon is too weak to observe, but the phonons inside the black hole bounce back and forth between the inner and outer horizons, triggering the creation of more Hawking phonons each time, much like a laser amplifies light.?Physicists call this effect a black hole laser.?

In the future, the researchers?hope to improve their detectors to sense radiation from a single horizon, which could help determine whether the pairs of phonons are entangled ? another predicted feature of real black holes that may have fiery consequences.

  • Desktop sonic black hole emits Hawking radiation:?http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn26366-desktop-sonic-black-hole-emits-hawking-radiation.html#.V...


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

name: Will Nissan Motor Co. produce a line of autonomous vehicles in the US by 2020?
question_text:
In IEEE's Spectrum 50th Anniversary Issue (June 2014) the future we will see is one complete with?autonomous vehicle navigation. Within the issue are claims made by CEO of Nissan Motor Co., Carlos Ghosn. His promise is to introduce "not one but a line of cars that can drive themselves-by 2020" (IEEE Spectrum, June 2014)

  • Another Big Promise by Nissan's Carlos Ghosn

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by the vehicle lines found at?Nissan Motor Co. USA.

name: As of October 15, 2014 220,000 of the approximately 10 million merchants in the US  have contactless payment hardware capable of accepting Apple Pay.  At the end of 2014 how many merchants will accept Apple Pay at checkout?
question_text:
A large number of options exist when it comes to paying for goods in person.? In the United States the dominant method of payment is the traditional credit card via a magnetic strip.? Europe has, to a large degree, switched to the Europay, MasterCard, and Visa (EMV) system.? This is also known as the chip and PIN system where the purchaser has a small chip on the credit card read and inputs their pin rather than swiping the card and signing.? Lesser known niche options such as Google Wallet and Bitcoin exist as well, but are not widely used.

With the release of their latest phone Apple has also announced a new form of payment, called Apple Pay, that is included with the iPhone 6 and the Apple Watch.? Similar to Google Wallet, Apple Pay will use near field communications(nfc) to allow consumers to purchase items simply by placing the phone near a terminal and scanning their fingerprint.? Terminals capable of accepting payment this way are already deployed in approximately 220,000 of the 10 million merchants in the United States. Moreover, credit networks are requiring merchants to update their terminal to one that supports EMV cards by October 2015 and adding nfc capabilities to the terminal would not strain a merchants budget in the same way as purchasing all new terminals.

In terms of security nearly every method available is more secure than the traditional magnetic strip credit cards.? In particular, Apple pay will generate a one-time use ID for each purpose, this way even if the purchase is intercepted that particular code will be of little use to a thief. The card or phone also never leaves the customers hand so there is less opportunity for in person theft. ?However, nfc terminals themselves are known to have certain vulnerabilities rendering the whole process, much like every other process, less than 100% safe.

Sources/More Information:
http://www.forbes.com/sites/hbsworkingknowledge/2014/10/15/why-would-consumers-want-to-adopt-apple-pay/
http://arstechnica.com/apple/2014/09/why-apple-pay-could-succeed-where-others-have-had-underwhelming-results/
http://www.nilsonreport.com/publication_the_current_issue.php?1=1

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

It is expected that Apple will announce this number for end-of-year (EOY) 2014 in January 2015.? If Apple does not announce an EOY 2014 statistic, then the soonest report after January 1, 2015 will resolve this question.

Devices made with CIGS belong to the thin-film category of photovoltaics (PV).

keywords: Flu, Region 10, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, chemistry
name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season end in HHS Region 10 (AK, ID, OR, WA)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via virological surveillance where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.



This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

05/31/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 10' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .cvs file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI";?use this time series to determine the end of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across HHS Region 10 goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week. Region 10 is comprised of Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, and Washington.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 10 is 1.1%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: Will either the United States or China be able to build an encryption cracking quantum computer before the end of 2018?
question_text:

On the other hand, China is also pulling out all the stops to beat its arch rival with a crypto-cracking machine of its own. In 2013, the National Natural Science Foundation of China funded 90 quantum-based projects.
