name: When will the 2014-2015 flu season begin in HHS Region 7 (IA, KS, MO, NE)?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.


Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select 'HHS Regions' and 'Region 7' from the drop down menu
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits in Region 7 exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm. Region 7 is comprised of Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, and Nebraska.ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The baseline value for the 2014-15 influenza season in Region 7 is 1.7%. In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

name: When will SpaceX successfully recover a Falcon 9 rocket booster on a solid sea platform after a mission launch?
question_text:
As part of the?Feb 11, 2015?launch of a NOAA space weather observatory, SpaceX?originally planned to land?the Falcon 9 rocket?s first stage on a barge in the Atlantic Ocean. However, it announced that this will not be possible, due to rough seas in the booster recovery zone off Florida?s East Coast.?The first and only platform landing attempt to date occurred on Jan 10, 2015. In that attempt, the first-stage booster ran out of hydraulic fluid too soon and slammed into the platform, falling over and exploding.

The decision to?forgo the plan means?the next chance to attempt a full flyback experiment ? a challenging maneuver aimed at eventually making SpaceX?s rocket reusable ? is unlikely to?come before?April, when a Falcon 9 rocket is scheduled to send up a package of supplies to the International Space Station.

  • SpaceX to forgo booster recovery on Wednesday?s launch:?http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/02/11/spacex-to-forgo-booster-recovery-on-wednesdays-launch/
  • SpaceX launches observatory on 3rd try, nixes landing test:?http://news.yahoo.com/spacex-tries-3rd-time-launch-observatory-land-rocket-155456078.html
  • Launch schedule:?http://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

10/01/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when a successful landing of the Falcon 9 booster on a solid sea platform is announced by SpaceX?http://www.spacex.com/, or on?October 1, 2015, whichever comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

A solid sea platform refers to a barge or some other type of solid platform placed in the ocean. It does not cover a soft landing in the water.

keywords: Lossless conduction, stanene, Topological insulators, Quantum spin Hall effect, experimental physics
name: When will a research group publish a paper describing experimental confirmation of lossless conduction at room temperature of stanene (2-D sheets of tin that are only 1-atom thick)?
question_text:
Topological insulators are characterized by an insulating bulk and metallic surface or edge state protected by time-reversal symmetry. This is a new quantum state that is promising for the realization of conduction without dissipation.? On September 24, 2013, a paper published in the Physics Review Letters described first-principle calculations that suggest that large-gap quantum spin hall (QSH) insulators in functionalized tin films can be patterned in a controlled way to be used as dissipationless conducting ?wires? for electronic circuits. The authors write:
?The proposal, if realized, could significantly lower the power consumption and heat generation rates of electronic devices, which is crucial for the development of modern integrated circuits.?

This publication only proposes that this is possible. It is up to experimental scientists to show that it is actually exists. This question asks when demonstration of dissipationless functionalized tin films (stanene) will be confirmed experimentally.

On Dec. 17, 2013, DARPA published a news release stating that "Experiments [are] underway to validate topologically insulating stanene as first room temperature lossless conductor".? So it can be expected that results could be announced at any time.

Resolution Criteria

No

Resolution Sources

This advancement would be covered by major outlets such as Science Magazine, New York Times, etc.

Fine Print

  • Lossless conduction = Dissipationless = That does not involve the dissipation of energy
  • Room Temperature= 298 K = 24.85
  • Stanene is a theoretical topological insulator that may display superconductivity at its edges above room temperature. It is composed of tin atoms arranged in a single layer, in a manner similar to graphene. Stanene got its name by combining stannum (the Latin name for tin) with the suffix -ene used by graphene.
  • Quantum spin Hall effect

Useful Information and Links

  • Topological insulator http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_insulators
  • Stanene- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanene
  • Time reversal symmetry - http://wiki.math.toronto.edu/DispersiveWiki/index.php/Time_reversal_symmetry
  • "A topological Dirac insulator in a quantum spin Hall phase." NATURE 452(7190): 970-974. http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v452/n7190/abs/nature06843.html
  • Eugenie Samuel Reich ?Hopes surface for exotic insulator? Nature 492, 165 (13 December 2012) doi:10.1038/492165a http://www.nature.com/news/hopes-surface-for-exotic-insulator-1.12005
  • Will 2-D Tin be the Next Super Material?, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, November 21, 2013 https://www6.slac.stanford.edu/news/2013-11-21-tin-super-material-stanene.aspx?
  • DARPA News Release on experimental progress: http://www.darpa.mil/NewsEvents/Releases/2013/12/17.aspx

Related Organizations or Individuals

Shou-Cheng Zhang at Stanford University: http://so5.stanford.edu/ (one of many)

name: What will be the 2013 estimated vaccination coverage of HPV for females aged 13-17 in the state of Maryland?
question_text:
• HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. See the following link for a fact sheet on HPV from the Center for Disease Control (CDC):?http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats/STI-Estimates-Fact-Sheet-Feb-2013.pdf
  • Since HPV causes cervical cancer and genital warts, great effort has been spent to vaccinate the population against the types of HPV that cause 70% of cervical cancer and 90% of genital warts. Two HPV vaccines have been introduced since 2006 and were originally approved for girls ages 11-12. Since 2007, vaccination rates have been monitored by the CDC in annual surveys. These studies originally focused on the female population aged 13-17, who have been ?targeted during the original vaccination campaign.
  • 53.8% of U.S. females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012.
  • In the state of Maryland, 42.7% of females aged 13-17 had been vaccinated with at least one dose of an HPV vaccine in 2012, with a rate of change of -3.0% from 2011 (45.7%).
  • The average rate of change from 2011 to 2012 for all states, (including the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands), is 0.8%. This was added to the 2012 estimated vaccination coverage to compute a new Center Point as the starting forecast.
  • Bins are developed based on the variation in the rates of change of all states taken as a group. We use the standard deviation (SD) of these rates of change to compute a uniform bin width of 0.5 SDs and center the middle bin on the calculated Center Point described above. This creates an overall range of +/- 1.75 SDs (roughly 90% of the average variation in Year Over Year change) in the 7 interior bins of each questions, to which upper and lower tails are added.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

07/31/2014

Resolution Source

The CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. The NIS-Teen is released annually in August. Past NIS - Teen results can be found here:?http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/imz-managers/coverage/nis/teen/articles.html

Fine Print

HPV stands for Human Papillomavirus. 'Estimated vaccination coverage' is a termed defined by the CDC as the estimated number of people who have received a particular vaccine. In this instance, 2013 HPV estimated vaccination coverage describes the estimated number of people who have received at least one single dose of HPV vaccine according to the CDC's 2014 National Immunization Survey (NIS) - Teen. Previous annual rates have been reported to the 0.1%. The range in possible answer bins will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example if the estimated vaccination coverage is 41.8%, the "41.8%-45.2%" range will be deemed correct.

In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.

The 'end week' is defined as the first week after the peak week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across the US (all 10 HHS regions) goes below the baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. The baseline for the end week is the same as the baseline for the start week.

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The National baseline for the 2014-2015 flu season is 2.0%.

In the event the end occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

question_text:
Known in the research and development community as "the Oscars of Innovation", R&D 100 Awards are presented to the 100 most important innovations of each year.?NREL has won 55?R&D 100 awards?since 1982. In 2013 three NREL innovations won the Award.

keywords: Google, Novartis, Alcon, Smart Contact Lenses
name: Will Google's 'Smart' Contact Lens be commercially available by 2020?
question_text:
In January 2014, Google announced they are developing 'smart' contact lenses.? These contact lenses are to serve two areas:? a lens that monitors sugar levels in tears and sends the data to a smartphone/tablet to help diabetic patients track their glucose levels, and an autofocus lens for people who have difficulty switching between short and long distance vision, a condition known as presbyopia.? In July 2014, one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies, Novartis, announced that they have partnered with Google[x] to help license, develop, and commercialize the contact lens.? This collaboration combines Google's expertise in minituarized electronics and chip design, with Novartis's expertise in physiology, clinical development, and experience with commercialization of contact lens and vision care.? Novartis CEO Joe Jimenez says they expect to have prototypes by early 2015 and plan to start marketing the products within five years.? This question asks if these smart contact lens will be commercially available by 2020.

Relevant Links:

  • Google's New Wearable Project is a Smart Contact Lens with Medical Uses [Engadget]
  • Google Strikes Smart Contact Lens Deal to Track Diabetes and Fix Farsightedness [Engadget]
  • Google Joining with Pharma Company to Build its Smart Contact Lens [TIME]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2019

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved true if Google or Novartis offer a commercially available smart contact lens (for any purpose) by 2020.? This will be verified by press releases from Google, Novartis, or other major news sources.?

Fine Print

'Smart contact lens' is defined here as a contact lens that incorporates sensors, microchips, or other miniaturized electronics. 'Commercially available' means the contact lenses are available to the general public for purchase.

categories: Business of Science,Computational Sciences,Information Systems,Engineered Technologies
keywords: TALOS suit, threat detection, weapon detection, wireless, data sharing
name: Will the US armed forces? TALOS suits be equipped with technology that enables sharing of enemy detection data with other TALOS suits on the battlefront for optimum intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities, by the end of 2016?
question_text:
The U.S. Military is working with engineers from various institutions like MIT to build the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) for armed forces on the ground. The project?s goal is to keep dismounted soldiers as well equipped as possible from gun shot wounds and explosions through next generation technologies like an exoskeleton made of liquid armor, smart fabrics to stop hemorrhaging, enhanced sensor capabilities and Google-glass like visuals. These suits would be donned by U.S. special operations forces and would be able to monitor the user's vital signs, give him/her real-time battlefield information and be bulletproof from head to toe.

Threat detection is one of the critical concerns of dismounted soldiers. With advances in sensor technologies, acoustic, radar, imaging, and other multisensory technologies can help soldiers detect enemy shots/artillery from a very long distance to better prepare them with intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities. It is important that when a threat is detected by one TALOS suit, that they be able to share that intelligence information in the form of images or coordinates or any other form with other TALOS suits on the ground to ensure timely awareness of the enemy environment. This would help the warfighters on the ground with better ISR capabilities.

http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/u-s-military-iron-man-suit-prototype-talos-debuts-in-weeks-video/ ?
http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/11/19/talos-iron-man-suit_n_4300576.html
http://www.cbsnews.com/news/u-s-special-forces-advances-iron-man-suit-project/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2016

Resolution Source

An official announcement by defense analysts, experts, or some official of the US Military or similar office in defense media or any other major news media or an official press release by a sensor technology or other enabling technologies companies that may say the following: 1) the feature has been integrated into a non-prototype suit or 2) that the suits deployed on the ground have this feature.

Fine Print

For this question, the TALOS suit must be capable of sharing ISR information in the form of images or coordinates or any other automated medium with other TALOS suits on the ground in real time.

keywords: Nest Thermostat, Internet of Things, Hack, Cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Will a penetration of the Nest thermostat be reported by December 1, 2015?
question_text:
The Nest thermostat is marketed as a solution to your housing energy bill. The device learns your preferred temperature settings and programs itself to your personal schedule, detecting when you are a way and changing your home?s temperature accordingly. Additionally, one can connect with their device remotely to adjust the temperature of their house or modify the heating schedule. Nest and other smart thermostats are projected to have an incredibly high market penetration, up to nearly 70%, over the next few years and, therefore, are a useful indicator for the adoption for the Internet of Things. However, as a result of this rapid adoption, homeowners are opening themselves to a greater risk of cyber attacks.

?We?re at a crisis point now with regard to the security of embedded systems, where computing is embedded into the hardware itself ? as with the Internet of Things. These embedded computers are riddled with vulnerabilities, there?s no good way to patch them, and they?re all connected to the Internet. The computers in our routers and modems are much more powerful than the PCs of the mid-1990s, and the Internet of Things will put computers into all sorts of consumer devices.? ?

This question uses the Nest thermostat as a indicator for the Internet of Things because its class is high on the list of pending consumer adoption, and it is likely to be better engineered than an ?over the counter? purchase at Wal-Mart. As such, if it is compromised it augurs the future generally. ??
For more information:

  • www.forbes.com/sites/gilpress/2014/08/22/internet-of-things-by-the-numbers-market-estimates-and-forecasts http://www.wired.com/2014/01/theres-no-good-way-to-patch-the-internet-of-things-and-thats-a-huge-problem/


This question was authored by?Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/01/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved by an announcement from Nest?https://store.nest.com/product/thermostat/?or?by a publication from?Brian Krebs (krebsonsecurity.com) or?threatpost.com.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

Fine Print

"Penetration" for the purposes of this question refers to a successful attack on the Nest system that exploited a security weaknesses, and gained access to it, its functionality, and data

name: On November 2020, what will be the Top 500 performance share by geographic region?
question_text:
The TOP500 project ranks and details the 500 most powerful (non-distributed) computer systems in the world. The project was started in 1993 and publishes an updated list of the supercomputers twice a year. The first of these updates always coincides with the International Supercomputing Conference in June, and the second one is presented in November at the ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference.?

Resolution Criteria

Outcome will be resolved based on reporting from official TOP500 published at http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/. Administrator reserves the right to use other sources as needed, provided those sources do not directly contradict concurrent event reporting from the TOP500 list. In cases of substantial controversy or uncertainty, administrator may refer the question to outside subject matter experts, or we may deem the question invalid/void.
NOTE: This is a shares question. The goal is to make the chances of each possible answer match its corresponding proportion of the total measure at resolution.? For example, if the question is about performance-weighted share of the TOP500 by geographic region, and you think North America?s share will account for 45% of the TOP500 performance, you should adjust North America?s chances towards 45%. Payoff will be proportional to the proportions at resolution.? (See the Definition for the precise measure used in this Shares question.)

Resolution Sources

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Fine Print

By performance-weighted share, we mean the proportion of total TOP500 computing power (Rmax Gflops) held by the corresponding entry, and not just the number of named systems.? This proportion is currently given in the Vendors Performance Share pie chart on http://www.top500.org/statistics/list/.

Useful Links

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

Related Organizations or Individuals

Top500: http://www.top500.org/statistics/list

It is anticipated that this year-in-review will be released in March of 2014. name: The clean & jerk world record set during the 2004 Olympic games has remained unbroken despite significant advances in sports science. Will a new clean & jerk world record be set before or during the 2016 Olympic Games?
question_text:
The clean& jerk is one of two Olympic weightlifting events, along with the snatch. Thecurrent world record for the clean & jerk is 263.0 kg, set at the 2004Olympic Games by Iranian weightlifter Hossein Rezazadeh. This record narrowly trumpeda record of 262.5 kg set by Russian lifter Andrey Chemerkin in 1997. A record of 266.0 kg by Soviet weightlifter LeonidTaranenko was set in 1988, but that record is no longer recognized as theweight categories for participants have been since been restructured and allrecords prior to the restructuring have been annulled.

Unlike otherareas of sports performance, such as sprinting and swimming, where there havebeen ongoing improvements in maximum performance, the upper bounds ofweightlifting performance have not progressed much over the last few decades. Thisis despite significant investment and advances in sports science related tostrength.

For morebackground, see:

  • http://people.umass.edu/umberger/univ197k/limits_to_strength.pdf
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_records_in_Olympic_weightlifting
  • http://www.iwf.net/results/olympic-records/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

08/21/2016

Resolution Source

Official newsports-related world records are routinely reported in the popular and sports press.

keywords: CERN, Standard Model, Project NA62, LHC, particle decay, kaon, pion, neutrino, antinutrino
name: Will project NA62 at the CERN in Geneva make a discovery of new unknown particles not predicted by the Standard Model of particle physics in 2014?
question_text:
After the discovery of higgs-boson in 2012, the LHC at CERN is offline for a refit. But the accelerators that feed protons into LHC will continue be operated in several experiments,? including a new project named NA62. This new experiment will involve precise measurements of how often a positively charged kaon decays into a positively charged pion plus a neutrino/antineutrino pair, which may possibly reveal new particles, such as supersymmetric particles that have been predicted by certain alternative models of particle physics.

Resolution Criteria

Precise measurements of the decay have to be made. As the Standard Model predicts exactly how fast kaons should decay, any difference between the measured and predicted decay rate would reveal the existence of new particles. However, measuring the decay is far from easy. Being so rare, the probablity of it happening is just 1 in 10 billion.

Resolution Sources

Physics World

Fine Print

CERN is the European Organization for Nuclear Research based in the northwest suburbs of Geneva on the Franco-Swiss border.

Project NA62 is named because it is located in CERN's "North Area" and 62 is the next number up. The experiment will be seeking "new physics" by searching for tiny "quantum fluctuations" in one particular type of particle decay.

The Standard Model of particle physics is a theory concerning the electromagnetic, weak, and strong nuclear interactions, which mediate the dynamics of the known subatomic particles. A discovery violating the Standard Model would be a major discovery in particle physics and our knowledge of the natural world.

Useful Information and Links

  • The world of physics 2014: http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2013/dec/19/the-world-of-physics-in-2014
  • CERN: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CERN
  • Standard Model: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_model

Related Organizations or Individuals

CERN

name: How many earthquakes will hit Irving, Texas between January 1st, 2015 and March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Minor earthquakes have been hitting the Irving, Texas area since 2008. To date over 100 earthquakes have been recorded in Irving since then with almost zero having been recorded previously. The strongest earthquake recorded?has been?a 3.6 magnitude with one of them hitting as recently as January 7, 2015.?In addition to the strength of the earthquakes, the frequency with which they have been hitting has been profound. Between January 6-7, 2015, twelve separate earthquakes were recorded in and around the Irving, TX area.?
??
Scientists are trying to determine the cause of the earthquakes through research being conducted through Southern Methodist University. Possible causes include geological realignment or the aftermath of fracking. Scientists have no way of knowing whether or not a larger, and much more?devastating, earthquake will hit the densely populated region at any point in the future.?

For more information:

The World Chess Championship is played to determine the World Champion in chess. Official championships began in 1886 and have been conducted with changing specifics and regularity since then. The current champion is Magnus Carlsen of Norway who earned the title in Chennai, India in 2013 by defeating Viswanathan Anand in a match. The latter won the Candidates Tournament in April 2014 to qualify for the next World Chess Championship to be held in Sochi, Russia, from the 7th until the 28th of November 2014. name: When will photonic waveguide sensors being developed by Corning Inc. and Polytechnique Montreal be used in a commercially available smartphone?
question_text:
A research group from Corning Inc. and Polytechnique Montreal are working on a technique that embeds sensors directly into the display glass of a smartphone itself.? These sensors would be able to detect temperature, assess blood sugar levels, provide security authentication for transactions, and more.? This is done through a laser technique that etches photonic waveguides into a smartphone's display glass.? A photonic waveguide is a pathway for light to travel through.? The lasers are used to etch these photonic waveguides into the display glass.? These waveguides act as transparent pathways (cannot be seen with the naked eye) that allow light to travel through, similar to how electric wires let electrical signals to pass through.? Depending on the size, shape, and other characteristics of the photonic waveguides, various sensors can be developed.? Since the technique also uses lasers as opposed to the conventional photolithography technique, these waveguides can be etched on various levels of the glass which means multiple sensors can be embedded into one display glass.

The researchers have already developed a temperature sensor and smartphone authentication system based on these waveguides.? Kashyap, one the researchers says, "We are actively looking to partner with industry to exploit this technology" and believes the two sensors already developed can be integrated into a commercial smartphone within a year.? This question asks when photonic waveguides will be embedded into a commercial smartphone to create a sensor built into the display screen.

Relevant Links:
  • Future Phones Will Have Security Measures Built into the Glass
  • Nextgen Smartphones Could Have Sensors Built Into Display Glass
  • Making Smartphones Smarter with See-through Sensors
  • Making Smartphones Smarter with Photonics [Optics Express]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2018

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved when the first smartphone is released to the public that incorporates photonic waveguides into the display screen to create any kind of sensor by the laser technique developed by Corning Inc. and Polytechnique Montreal.? This will be verified by major news sources such as Cnet, Engadget, Gizmag, etc.? Additionally, the smartphone company may need to be contacted to verify if photonic waveguides were used to make the sensor.

Fine Print

A 'photonic waveguide sensor' is defined here to mean any sensor built into the display glass of a smartphone based on photonic waveguides using the laser technique being developed by Corning and Polytechnique Montreal.

keywords: U.S., Blueberries, Value, Production, USD, 2013, Honeybee, Pollination
name: What will be the total value of U.S. blueberry production for the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of USD?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • The value of?U.S. blueberry production (cultivated and wild)?for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 850,883 in thousands USD.
  • The value of blueberry production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as blueberries are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Total value of blueberry production is reported in thousands of USD, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. blueberry production' includes cultivated and wild blueberries.

The '2013 marketing season' begins 05/2013 and ends 09/2013.

'Total value of production' is the 'packinghouse-door equivalent'. 'Packinghouse-door' equivalent is defined as all fruit, regardless of methods of sale, converted to a price it would have brought if the entire crop, or segment thereof being priced, had been sold at the packinghouse-door.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.


Useful Links

  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts:?http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/MannUsda/viewDocumentInfo.do?documentID=1113
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Preliminary Summary:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-01-25-2013.pdf
  • USDA NASS Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 11/19/2013 Sequestration Announcement:?http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/current/NoncFruiNu/NoncFruiNu-11-19-2013.txt
  • USDA Agricultural Statistics Annual:?http://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/Ag_Statistics/

  • NRDC Honeybee Pollination:?http://www.nrdc.org/wildlife/animals/files/bees.pdf
  • American Beekeeping Federation Pollination Facts:?http://www.abfnet.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=14

Related Organizations or Individuals

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service

name: Will Mauna Loa, one of the five volcanoes that make up the island of Hawaii, erupt before March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Mauna Loa is the largest active volcano on Earth and?has not erupted since 1984. Mauna Loa has been 'silent' for the past three decades, much to the surprise of scientists, since previous eruption patterns have Mauna Loa erupting every 5-10 years, on average.?Recently, Mauna Loa?has been showing signs of possible volcanic activity. According to the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory November report, earthquake rates are elevated and slightly stronger than in previous months, however, they have been small relative to earthquake sequences noticed before the 1984 eruption.?

"The activity includes faint, shallow earthquakes to the west of the summit and ?deep long period? temblors 28 to 31 miles below the surface, both of which point to the intrusion of magma." ? - West Hawaii Today

Scientists do not know why Mauna Loa hasn't erupted in over three decades but it is possible that the volcano could be dying; not producing as much magma and not erupting as frequently. Some?scientists also are looking at possible?connections to its sister?volcano,?Kilauea? and whether her active status in some way affects Mauna Loa.?

For More Information:

  • http://westhawaiitoday.com/news/local-news/mauna-loa-poised-erupt#sthash.ToZj2cWs.dpuf
  • http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/activity/maunaloastatus.php
  • http://westhawaiitoday.com/news/volcano-update/mauna-loa-due-erupt-soon

Accepting Forecasts Until:

3/31/2015

Resolution Source

This resolution will resolve according to?http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/activity/maunaloastatus.php?or major news sources reporting an eruption.

name: Will the winner(s) of the Experimental category of the 2014 Foresight Institute Feynman Prize in Nanotechnology be affiliated with a US organization?
question_text:
The Feynman Prize is an annual prize given for significant accomplishments in nanotechnology. Two separate prizes are given each year, one for Theory and one for Experimental work.

Over the past decade, 6 Experimental prizes have been awarded to scientists affiliated with US organizations, and 4 Experimental prizes have been awarded to scientists affiliated with non-US organizations.

This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Resolution Sources

Foresight Institute website (www.foresight.org)

Affiliation is determined on location of organization in which awarded work was carried out, as is listed on the Foresight website.

keywords: NAFLD, Gestational Diabetes, Type 2 Diabetes, Clinical Trial
name: Will a clinical trial show that Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease is common in women who had gestational diabetes during their pregnancy?
question_text:
It is well known that pregnancy is a state of insulin resistance. The clinical trial is trying to find out the percentage of patients with NAFLD who have developed gestational diabetes during their pregnancy, and to determine whether there is a direct correlation between the two diseases.

Resolution Criteria

About 200 pregnant women enter the clinical study by January 2015.?

Resolution Sources

Diabetes, clinicaltrial.gov

Fine Print

NAFLD: non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
GDM: gestational diabetes

Dr. Maryam Sattari of the?University of Florida will be conducting clinical trials with final data collection scheduled by?January 2015.

It may take a year for the clinical study results to be published after completion of the final data collection. This question will resolve when the cited clinical trial's results are published and the statistical test of the Null Hypothesis is reported. We will accept the p-value chosen by the author and accepted by the journal as the authoritative source for?the resolution. Typically clinical trials use p < .01 as their significance threshold although higher p's are sometimes accepted. If either the published results are not statistically significant or the results are not published by January 1, 2016, this questions will resolve in the negative.

Useful Information and Links

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in gestational diabetes: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01855386?term=diabetes&rank=26
  • How big a problem is non-alcoholic fatty liver disease? http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d3897?tab=responses
  • American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases (AASLD)

Related Organizations or Individuals

American Diabetes Association, the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases.

keywords: Great Lakes, Global Warming, Ice Coverage
name: What will be the peak mean ice concentration in Lake Michigan during the 2013/2014 winter?
question_text:
Understanding the major effect of ice on the Great Lakes is crucial because it impacts a range of societal benefits provided by the lakes, from hydropower generation to commercial shipping to the fishing industry. The amount of ice cover varies from year to year, as well as how long it remains on the lakes. GLERL scientists are observing long-term changes in ice cover as a result of global warming.

According to an analysis by NOAA's Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, ice covered 88.4 percent of the Great Lakes on February 13. Not since early 1994 has ice been so widespread on the Great Lakes. Graphs showing the ice cover trends?for each of the Great Lakes from?1973 to 2002?can be found here.

As of 02/14/2014, the mean concentration of ice in Lake Michigan was 80.9%. Daily reports can be found here under the section 'Modeled Ice Coverage'.?A chart showing the yearly average maximum ice coverage of Lake Michigan can be found here.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/10/2014

Resolution Source

The question will be resolved by via the?Lake Michigan Ice Cover webpage?maintained by the NOAA, and by consulting the 'Modeled Ice Concentration' section.?


Fine Print

The ranges in the possible answers will be treated as half-open intervals, such that the first number is included in the range. For example, if the peak ice coverage is 84.0%, the "84%-86%" range will be deemed correct.

name: Will a first stage launch vehicle attempt to return to a solid surface on or before 31 March 2015?
question_text:
Currently, expendable launch vehicles are carrying unmanned capsules to the International Space Station.? However, a long-term goal is for launch vehicles to be fully reusable heavy lift launch vehicles.? Companies have been working on achieving a launch vehicle with a first stage launch vehicle that returns to the launch site in minutes and the second stage vehicle that returns within 24 hours.

The first step to a reusable launch vehicle is for the first stage launch vehicle to simply return to a specific geographical place as opposed to splashing down into the ocean. The second step is for a successful landing that enables the vehicle to be reused.

Sources and links

  • Next Falcon 9 Launch Could See First-stage Platform Landing
  • SpaceX reusable launch system development program

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

Offical press release or announcement.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

return to = launch vehicle attempts to go to a specific geographical place (round or floating platforms engineered for the mission) after its stage is over.

keywords: NASA, space taxi, International Space Station
name: Will a NASA-funded 'space taxi' transport astronauts to the International Space Station before the end of 2017?
question_text:
Three companies are now in the final stretch of the competition to build the next-generation of manned spacecraft to the International Space Station. According to experts, Boeing?Co., SpaceX and Sierra Nevada Corp.?are pushing rival designs for NASA?s next manned spacecraft, which by 2017 could start taking American astronauts to the International Space Station. NASA is expected to pick one or possibly two companies by September for the next phase of the program.

  • Elon Musk's Bid to Build NASA's New Space Taxi
  • Competition Heats up for NASA's Space Taxi Design

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2017

Resolution Source

NASA:?http://www.nasa.gov/exploration/commercial/crew/index.html#.U8QukfldXy0

keywords: Data security, government, Cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Before January 1st, 2017, will one of the top 5 Fortune 500 companies adopt a 30-day notification standard to alert customers of a data breach?
question_text:
Last year, JP Morgan, Target, and the US Postal Service contributed to?the disclosure of hundreds of millions of records?in a series of high-profile hacks and data breaches.

On January 13,?after a turbulent year in cybersecurity and data protection, President Obama unveiled proposed laws aimed at protecting Americans' data. The three new proposed laws, announced ahead of the president's State of the Union address, land in the aftermath of a year of high-profile hacks and data breaches which affected millions of Americans. Among the proposals, Obama announced a new federal standard -- dubbed the Personal Data Notification and Protection Act, which would require companies to tell their customers within 30 days from the discovery of a data breach that their information had been compromised.

For more information:

  • http://www.zdnet.com/article/obama-calls-for-new-privacy-laws-including-mandatory-hack-notifications-within-30-days/
  • http://www.ncsl.org/research/telecommunications-and-information-technology/security-breach-notificat...


This question was authored by Dan Geer.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

02/01/2017

Resolution Source

This question would be resolved by a press release,?stating the change in policy has occurred?from one of the five companies, or by the resolution date, whichever comes first.?

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution. ?

Fine Print

For the purposes of this question, the 5 companies will be the top five from 2014: Walmart, Exxon Mobil, Chevron, Berkshire Hathaway, and Apple.

*Admin Update: For this question to resolve as "true", one of the companies must adopt the policy prior to the resolution date - the reason behind the change is not part of the prediction. If a 30-day notification is legislated, it will not necessarily cause any of these companies to immediately change their policy as the legislation must first come in to effect.

name: When will the first artificial internal organ created using AAM technology be successfully transplanted into a human?
question_text:
Additive Manufacturing (AM) is defined by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) as a manufacturing process in which 3D digital design data is used to build up a component in layers by depositing material. This is in stark contrast to traditional manufacturing in which material is removed from a solid block to create the product. The AM process starts by drawing a 3D model of the product on CAD software. The software takes this drawing and slices it digitally into thin cross sections. The printer is then loaded with the desired material such as metals or plastics, and uses an AM technique such as selective laser sintering (SLS) or stereolithography (SLA) to build the product layer by layer until complete. This process is being applied in industries as diverse as aviation, aerospace, automotive, medical, and others.?

Researches have already successfully used 3D printing to create prosthetic limbs, other prosthetic parts to replace missing or defective body parts (such as artificial noses), models of body parts to use as guides for reconstructive surgery, and hollow organs (such as bladders). Scientists are working to develop techniques to print more complex organs. This leads to the following question:? Can living cells themselves be used as the input material (instead of metals or plastics) to print replacement organs?

Relevant Links:

  • Lungs on a chip, 3-D printed hearts: The shape of medicine to come [CNN]
  • How 3-D Printing Body Parts Will Revolutionize Medicine [Popular Science]

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2020

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved true if an internal organ (as defined in the 'Fine Print') is successfully printed using AAM technology AND successfully transplanted into a human. This will be confirmed by major medical journals or associations such as the American Medical Association, the Lancet, etc., or major news outlets such as CNN, BBC, etc.

Fine Print

In this instance, "internal organs" should be defined as solid organs created using AAM deposition and placement of cells, not just a scaffolding which cells are grown over. Appropriate organs include: Liver, Heart, Lungs, Stomach, Intestines, Kidney, Gall Bladder, Spleen, or Pancreas.

keywords: internet, internet of things, wireless internet, mobile
name: How many mobile wireless devices in the U.S. will the FCC report as connected to the internet for the end of 2013?
question_text:
The U.S. FederalCommunications Commission (FCC) is required to report annually to Congress onthe state of competition in the mobile services marketplace. The data in thisreport cover a range of wireless topics, and typically lag the year of reportpublication by one or two years. In March of 2013 the FCC released the 16thannual report. This report indicates that by the end of 2011, there were more mobile wireless devices connected to the internet than there were people in the United Statesfor the first time in history; 317.3 million devices versus 312 million people.Growth in mobile wireless connected devices from 2008 to 2011, as reported by the FCC, was asfollows:

2008 = 279.6million
2009 = 290.7million
2010 = 309.0million
2011 = 317.3million

Thisquestion asks how many mobile wireless internet connected devices the FCC will report for theU.S. for the end of 2013, via the same report, when the 2013 year end dataare available.

The FCC MobileWireless Competition reports can be found here:?http://www.fcc.gov/reports/mobile-wireless-competition-report-16th-annual

A non-FCCwebsite (linked from the FCC site) with summary and trend data for this question can befound here: http://fcc.github.io/competition-reports/mobile-wireless/16/

The penetration of smart phones continues to increase the number of connected devices in the United States, but some commentators believe the household penetration of tablets will do more to drive growth in connected devices, as this latter category of devices is experiencing very rapid growth.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2014

Resolution Source

The MobileWireless Competition report expected to be issued by the FCC in early 2015 willinclude the official FCC statistic on number of connected devices. That reportcan be found here once published:? http://www.fcc.gov/document/16th-mobile-competition-report

A non-FCCwebsite (one that is linked to from the FCC site) also reports this data in auser-friendly graphical manor, showing historical trends for this metric:? http://fcc.github.io/competition-reports/mobile-wireless/16/?

keywords: chalcopyrite, solar cell, cadmium buffer, chemistry
name: By the end of 2014, will a chalopyrite solar cell with no cadmium-based buffer be reported with an efficiency greater than 20%?
question_text:
A chalcopyrite thin film solar cell is normally made up of five layers. From an economic perspective, reducing the number of steps of production and uniting the functionalities of separate layers into fewer layers is of great interest. Researchers from the Helmholtz Zentrum Berlin (HZB) Institute for Heterogeneous Material Systems have developed chalcopyrite solar cells without a cadium-based buffer layer.?They reported an?efficiency of 18.3% in lab tests.

  • Junction formation by Zn(O,S) sputtering yields CIGSe-based cells with efficiencies exceeding 18% , Progress in Photovoltaics: Research and Applications http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/pip.2445/abstract;jsessionid=41B408D6DE8A1C336DEFC2BE4241...
  • HZB Team Develops Chalcopyrite Solar Cells Without Cadmium-Based Buffer Layer: http://www.helmholtz-berlin.de/pubbin/news_seite?nid=13894;sprache=en;typoid=3228
  • HZB Scientists Upgrade Chalcopyrite Solar Cells: http://dailyfusion.net/2013/12/hzb-scientists-upgrade-chalcopyrite-solar-cells-25747/

12/31/2014

name: When will 99% of the top 1 million web domains in the world be immune to Heartbleed?
question_text:
The Heartbleed vulnerability (http://blog.cloudflare.com/answering-the-critical-question-can-you-get-private-ssl-keys-using-heartb...)exposes server memory over a network connection. Remote attackers may collect other user's access credentials, session content, and server-side private?encryption keys.

Alexa (http://www.alexa.com/topsites) tracks top sites, and Zmap (https://zmap.io/heartbleed/vulnerable.html) tracks which of the top 1 million websites remain vulnerable to Heartbleed.

Here is a paper presented in 2008 which examines?vulnerability management policies intended to?reduce potential exposure windows (LINK)

Some common?culprits for a slow response time include poor site?administration, difficulty reconciling a?patch with site's code, and?lengthy review & testing procedures.?

As of 04/16/14, 22,265 websites were listed?on Zmap's Heartbleed report for web sites.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

6/30/14

Resolution Source

This question will resolve when there are 10,000 or less web domains listed on Zmap's Heartbleed Bug Health Report: https://zmap.io/heartbleed/vulnerable.html.

Fine Print

Zmap's Heartbleed Bug Health Report is not updated daily, so the number of sites vulnerable to Heartbleed on any given day will be based on the most recent report appearing on Zmap.io.The list of "top 1 million web domains" is calculated by Alexa Internet, Inc. Additional information on Alexa rankings here: https://alexa.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/200449744-How-are-Alexa-s-traffic-rankings-determined-

name: Where will Malaysian Air Flight MH 370 be found (extended version)?
question_text:
Image from?http://i.imgur.com/zNgnicG.png?1. (HTT amsiegel)
On March 8, 2014, a Boeing 777 aircraft operating under Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 went missing on its directed route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.? The aircraft consisted of 227 total passengers and 12 crew members which departed from Kuala Lumpur International Airport at 12:41 am.? The aircraft sent its last transponder signal at 1:21 am and lost radar signal at 1:30 am, thereby losing contact. ?Based on that information, last Friday?we created?"Q.364: MH 370 Location".?

Since then it's become clear that the ACARS system continued to ping the satellite hourly?until 8:11am. The satellite is geostationary, and signal geometry confined the last ping to two arcs: a Northern arc across China to Kazakhstan, and a Southern arc through the Indian Ocean. ?Because there was no 9:11 ping, a buffer can be drawn around these to yield possible areas the plane could have reached in the remaining 59 minutes.?

On 18/19 March,?Australia revealed they had spotted two large debris pieces on satellite images of?the very southern Indian ocean, just on the edge of that region. ?As of writing, they have been unable to relocate those pieces from aircraft, partly due to bad weather. The debris is not known to belong to MH 370, but it is consistent with NTSB high-probability tracks.?

Relevant Links

  • Original "MH 370?Location"?(Q.364)
  • "MH 370?Scenario" (Q365)

Accepting Forecasts Until:

04/30/2014

Resolution Source

Official Malaysian government news reported in?mainstream news sources (e.g. CNN, BBC, Reuters, AP). We will wait at least 24 hours for possible retractions or clarifications. ?This question will resolve when official sources have located the aircraft, or a debris field positively linked to the aircraft. (If the aircraft sank in the ocean, a separate question may be issued for location on the ocean floor. An underwater search could take years.)

Fine Print

Previous search regions are those defined in Q.364, extending no further West than the Andaman Sea. (Except for Region B, these were water regions.) The Northern and Southern satellite arcs are as shown on the map above, EXCLUDING regions A-F from Q.364 (there may be a small overlap e.g. in the Andaman Sea).'Other water' and 'Other land' cover the rest of the planet. 'Not before 30-APR' means there will be no definitive find by 30-APR-2014. As with Q.364, 'find' means finding the aircraft, or debris positively linked to the aircraft. If floating debris, this is the LOCATION OF DEBRIS WHEN FIRST FOUND: (1) Disregard drift while confirming the debris belongs to MH 370, but (2) do include the 2+ weeks of drift before anything was found.

keywords: renewable energy, solar energy, wind energy, biofuel
name: Will new investment in renewable energy in Europe be higher in 2015 than it was in 2014?
question_text:
The Bloomberg New Energy Finance (BNEF) report?collates data on?renewable energy organizations, projects and investments, and?classifies it according to transaction type, sector, geography and timing. Quarterly reports are available for download on the BNEF website, which includes historic data and current trends in clean energy investment. ?According to the most recent BNEF data available, new investment in?renewable energy in Europe?peaked?in 2011, when?$117.5 billion dollar of new investment was reported, and has been declining since.?In 2014, new investment totaled only?$54 billion, less than half?the?2011 total.?However, a surge of?investment money in the?final quarter of 2014?may indicate the start?of a upward trend.

For more information:

  • CLEAN ENERGY INVESTMENT JUMPS 16%, SHAKING OFF OIL?S DROP:?http://about.bnef.com/bnef-news/clean-energy-investment-jumps-16-on-china-s-support-for-solar-2/
  • CLEAN ENERGY INVESTMENT ? Q4 2014 FACT PACK:?http://about.bnef.com/presentations/clean-energy-investment-q4-2014-fact-pack/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/10/2016

Resolution Source

Question will be resolved when BNEF releases its quarterly "Clean Energy Investment" report for Q4 2015, which is expected to be in early January 2016.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog:http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.

Fine Print

New investments in renewable energy include funds invested in wind, solar, biofuel, and other low-carbon energy technologies worldwide, as reported by Bloomberg New Energy Finance.

choices_field_3: decrease by 0 to less than 5 percent
name: How will NOAA Fisheries' next minimum population estimate of the U.S. stock of California sea lions change from the 2011 stock assessment?
question_text:
The Pacific sardine has experienced a severe population crash in recent years, with stock biomass estimates dropping from 1.37 million metric tons in 2006 to 378,120 metric tons in 2014, a decrease of 70 percent.? This crash is expected to have ripple effects throughout the food chain, as the sardine is an important food source for many fish, marine mammals and aquatic birds.

Already, the sardine crash has been blamed for a wave of sick, malnourished sea lion pups that washed up on California shores in 2013. Sea lion mothers depend on the oily fish to pack on pounds before giving birth, and with sea lions no longer able to depend on sardines for nutrition, they are forced to eat less nutritious prey. That leaves them unable to feed their pups enough milk.

  • The Atlantic: Why West Coast Sea Life Has Been Behaving So Strangely
  • LA Times: West Coast sardine crash could radiate throughout ecosystem
  • NBC Los Angeles: Scientists May Have Solved Sea Lion Mystery Sickness

Further population decline or a recovery of the Pacific sardine population


This question is part of the SciCast Accuracy Contest. For more information about the contest itself and the official rules please see the following links:

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement
  • Official Contest Rules

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/01/2015

Resolution Source

Marine Mammal Stock Assessment Reports are maintained by NOAA fisheries and updated on a one to three year basis. The most recent report on California sea lions is from 2011, and an updated stock assessment is expected in 2014 or 2015.
short_name: U.S. stock of California sea lion population

name: Which small molecule antibiotic will the FDA approve first?
question_text:
• Antibacterial drug resistance ?threatens the achievements of modern medicine? according to the World Health Organization (WHO). A recent report found high rates of resistance to at least one type of bacteria in almost every one of the 114 members states that gave the organization data.
  • The number of systemic antibacterial agents approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have decreased significantly. Between 1983 and 1987, 15 new agents were approved compared to two agents approved between 2008 and 2013.?
  • Because of the decrease, the FDA?s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research created an Antibacterial Drug Development Task Force to support the development of new antibacterial drugs.? In addition, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases? Antibacterial Resistance Program supports research specifically in antibacterial drugs.
  • In 2013, the Infectious Disease Society of America reported that only a single new antibiotic (ceftaroline fosamil) has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) since 2010.
  • In late September 2013, Butler et al. reported in The Journal of Antibiotics that 16 small molecule antibiotics were in phase-III clinical trials or under non-disclosure agreements (NDA) or MMA review.? As of May 2, 2014, none of these antibiotics had been approved by the FDA.

keywords: Flu, national, CDC, influenza, ILI, outpatient, continental, chemistry
name: When will the U.S. 2014-2015 flu season begin?
question_text:
Influenza, commonly known as the "flu", affects more than half a million people every year in the US. Effective planning and public health response requires accurate and timely forecasts of the flu season, such as its timing, duration, and severity.?The common way to understand the spread of flu is via?virological surveillance?where respiratory specimens are analyzed in laboratories to determine the number of samples that test positive for the influenza virus. For this question, we are focusing on?outpatient surveillance, where we are forecasting the percentage of patients who have influenza-like illness (ILI) symptoms.?

The CDC-run U.S. Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) defines ILI as ?fever (temperature of 100?F [37.8?C] or greater) and a cough and/or a sore throat without a KNOWN cause other than influenza.? ILINet draws from a network of nearly 3000 outpatient providers and hospitals across the US who report data to CDC weekly on the total number of patients seen and the percentage of those patients with ILI symptoms.

Accepting Forecasts Until:

01/11/2015

Resolution Source

ILINet data will be used to resolve this question. Data from the past 15 years is readily downloadable from http://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/fluview/fluportaldashboard.html. ???
  1. Click on ?Download data?
  2. Make sure only ?ILINet? is selected (deselect WHO/NREVSS)
  3. Select National?
  4. Select 2014-15 season
  5. In the downloaded .csv file, refer to the column labelled "% Weighted ILI"; use this time series to determine the start of season

Fine Print

An epidemiological week, commonly referred to as an ?epi week? or a CDC week, is a standardized method of counting weeks to allow for the comparison of data year after year. It is used by epidemiologists all over the world. In the United States, epi weeks are defined as running from Sunday to Saturday, where the first epi week of the year is defined to be the one which ends on the first Saturday of January, and contains at least four days of January. For example, the first epi-week of 2014 started on 2013/12/29 as it contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/04) and 4 days of the January in that week. On the contrary, the first epi-week of 2009 started on 2009/01/04 because the week that contained the first Saturday of January (2013/01/03) had only 3 days of January.

The 'start week' is defined as the first week for which the weighted percentage of ILI related visits across the US (all 10 HHS regions) exceeds the corresponding baseline for three consecutive weeks, starting from the said week. In other words, for a particular year, the ILI season is said to begin when the weighted percentage of ILI related patient visits exceeds a predefined baseline for three consecutive weeks (first week in the three week sequence). This ?baseline? is developed by calculating the mean percentage of patient visits for ILI during non-influenza weeks for the previous three seasons and adding two standard deviations. The baseline is calculated separately for the national and the individual regions using the historical data for the national and the individual regions, respectively. The calculated baselines for 2013-2014 season can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/overview.htm while details of the previous seasons can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm.

ILINet can revise published values over time. In general, values are revised upward so that at any point in time, published values can be viewed as a lower bound over the final values. In practice, revisions are typically in the range of 1-3% (of the weighted percentage value). For instance, if the weighted percentage has been published as 0.8%, the revised value could be, example, 0.8 + 2%(0.8) = 0.816%.

The National baseline for the 2014-2015 flu season is 2.0%.

In the event the start occurs outside the range of weeks listed, this question will resolve at the nearest extreme.

keywords: quantum teleportation, quantum entanglement, cybersecurity, cyber security
name: Will a new free-space distance record for quantum teleportation be reported by March 31, 2015?
question_text:
Quantum teleportation is a process by which quantum information (e.g. the state of a photon) can be transmitted from one location to another, with the help of classical communication and previously shared quantum entanglement between the sending and receiving location. Because quantum teleportation depends on classical communication, which is limited by the speed of that communication, and capped at the speed of light, quantum teleportation cannot be used for superluminal communication of classical (non-quantum) information.

Quantum teleportation was first proposed in a paper in Physics Review Letters in 1993, and lab demonstrated was reported in Nature in 1997. Since then the distance over which the quantum phenomenon has been achieved has grown steadily, and now stands as 143 kilometers across free space. The mark was achieved in September of 2012 between the two Canary Islands of La Palma and Tenerife. 97 Kilometers was achieved just a month earlier. In May of 2010 the record was only 16 kilometers. The field of study is important to the development of quantum computing.

For more information, see:

  • http://researcher.watson.ibm.com/researcher/view_group.php?id=2862
  • http://www.askamathematician.com/2013/01/q-what-is-quantum-teleportation-why-cant-we-use-it-to-commu...
  • http://www.wired.com/2012/10/quantum-satellite-teleportation/all/
  • http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2409368,00.asp
  • http://www.technologyreview.com/view/520886/japanese-telco-smashes-entanglement-distance-record/

Accepting Forecasts Until:

03/31/2015

Resolution Source

A new quantum teleportation record will be reported in the peer-reviewed scientific literature and likely in the popular science press as well.

This question will resolve when an announcement is made or by the resolution date, whichever one comes first.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution

Fine Print

The distance record for this question is defined as the "free space" distance record of quantum teleportation achieved through open space or air, but not through a solid medium such as finer optic cable.

name: Which organization will be the first to conduct human trials using optogenetics techniques?
question_text:
Optogenetics is a field of neuroscience that uses a combination of techniques from both optics and genetics to control and monitor the activities of individual neurons in living tissue. Optogenetics makes use of light-absorbing proteins called opsins, which are found in the eyes of humans and other animals and in microbes. By genetically splicing opsins into neurons, scientists can manipulate the behavior of the neurons by exposing them to light. To stimulate superficial brain areas such as the cerebral cortex, optical fibers or LED lights can be directly mounted to the skull of the test subject. More deeply implanted optical fibers have been used to deliver light to deeper brain areas.

Optogenetics was chosen as the Method of the Year in 2010 across all fields of science and engineering by the interdisciplinary research journal Nature Methods, and it has been proposed as a possible treatment for various neurological disorders. However, research on optogenetics is still in its infancy. Tests using various optogenetics techniques on animals and primates are currently underway, but there are no set plans to test optogenetics as a treatment on humans as of yet.

Karl Deisseroth's lab at Stanford University is conducting the most high-profile work in optogenetics at the moment, but there are several other organizations doing research in the field. Deisseroth has collaborated with researchers at MIT and?Max Planck, while researchers at Oxford and the?University of Texas proved optogenetics could work back in 2002.?Retrosense Therapeutics is a biotech startup that aims to use optogenetics to cure blindness.?

  • Wikipedia - Optogenetics
  • New York Times - Brain Control in a Flash of Light
  • MIT Technology Review - Company Aims to Cure Blindness with Optogenetics
  • Stanford University - New Light on the Brain
  • Scientific American -?Optogenetics: Controlling the Brain with Light?

  • SciCast Recruitment Announcement

01/01/2017

Human trials would be a major milestone in a very promising and exciting new technology, and would likely be covered in the mainstream press, such as the New York Times and BBC News, as well as academic and scientific publications.

Human trials would also be listed at http://www.clinicaltrials.gov

keywords: Cold Fusion, Low Energy Nuclear Reaction, Andrea Rossi
name: Will a paper describing Andrea Rossi?s alleged Low Energy Nuclear Reaction device (aka cold fusion) be published in a journal indexed on Thomson Rueters' Web of Science before JAN 1 2015?
question_text:
In 2011, inventor Andrea Rossi received an Italian patent for a device he claimed capable of net energy positive low energy nuclear reactions ? also known as cold fusion. The device allegedly works by infusing heated hydrogen into nickel powder, transmuting it into copper and producing heat. Rossi has demonstrated the device numerous times, but hesitated to allow for independent testing of the device until spring of 2013, when a team of researchers were allowed to test the device?s performance ? though they were not allowed to inspect the inner working of the device. These researchers have published a paper claiming the device has computed volumetric and gravimetric energy densities far above those of any known chemical source. However, this paper has yet to undergo the peer review process and be published in a journal.


Resolution Sources

Numerous scientific journals and news outlets would likely report if this paper makes it through the peer review process including the New York Times, Science Magazine, etc.

Fine Print

Forecasters should monitor public sources of science news and Rossi's website for information on publications. Official resolution will be determined by SciCast administrators using the Thomson Reuters Web of Science database to confirm public announcements.

Useful Information and Links

  • Andrea Rossi's Website:?http://ecat.com/
  • Energy Catalyzer
  • Unpublished paper on Rossi's device
  • Extremetech?- Cold Fusion Reactor
  • Forbes?- Why Rossi E-Cat Doesn't Work

Related Organizations or Individuals

name: Which country will have the greatest change in the percentage of forest area between 2012 and 2013?
question_text:
Earth's forests are the world?s primary source of oxygen, biodiversity, and wood and paper products, and are also essential as a source of agricultural products, for maintenance of the watershed, for soil protection, and for pollution abatement. Despite these benefits, the world?s forests are being threatened by deforestation. According to the United Nations, subsistence farming is responsible for 48% of deforestation, commercial agriculture is responsible for 32%, logging for 14%, and fuel wood removal makes up 5%.

Estimates of annual rates of deforestation vary widely, though the number is in the millions of acres per year. The World Bank World Development Indicators includes forest cover (percentage of total) for all countries and for the globe. The most recent World Bank data indicate that 30.97% of the world's land is forested, down from 32.06% in 1990. While countries around the world are facing loss of forested land, the greatest rates of deforestation tend be concentrated in Central/South America and southeast Asia.

For more information, see:

  • http://environment.nationalgeographic.com/environment/global-warming/deforestation-overview/
  • http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/about_forests/deforestation/
  • http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/landsat/news/40th-top10-amazon.html
  • http://www.pnas.org/content/111/2/567.short

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2015

Resolution Source

This question will be resolved using percent forest area?data reported by?the World Bank provided here: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.LND.FRST.ZS

These data are current to 2012; 2013 data are not yet reported. This question will resolve when the new data are updated.

For additional information about the question resolution process, please see the following post on the SciCast blog: http://blog.scicast.org/about/resolution.???

name: Will a foldable tablet computer made with inkjet-printed graphene be commercially available by the end of 2018?
question_text:
Northwestern University researchers have developed a graphene-based ink that is highly conductive and tolerant to bending, and they have used it to inkjet-print graphene patterns that could be used for extremely detailed, conductive electrodes.? The researchers demonstrated printing the ink in multiple layers, each 14 nanometers thick, to create precise patterns. The ink's conductivity remains virtually unchanged, even when bent to a great degree, suggesting that graphene inks could be used to create foldable electronic devices.

  • Opening doors to foldable electronics with inkjet-printed graphene:?http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/05/130520154257.htm
  • Foldable electronics with inkjet-printed graphene:?http://www.kurzweilai.net/foldable-electronics-with-inkjet-printed-graphene

Accepting Forecasts Until:

12/31/2018

Resolution Source

The question will resolve positive if?a qualifying?product is for sale through websites such as amazon.com; bestbuy.com; and their future equivalents.

Fine Print

Graphene is a two dimensional material consisting of a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a honeycomb or chicken wire structure. It is the thinnest material known and yet is also one of the strongest. It conducts electricity as efficiently as copper and outperforms all other materials as a conductor of heat. Graphene is almost completely transparent, yet so dense that even the smallest atom helium cannot pass through it. Commercially available means that the product is for sale through websites such as amazon.com; bestbuy.com; and their future equivalents.

name: What will be the total value of U.S. cherry production for the 2013 marketing season, in thousands of USD?
question_text:
• The United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) issues an annual 'Noncitrus?Fruits and Nuts?Summary' each July.?This full-text report contains the annual summary?of acreage, yield, production, use, price and value by states of the noncitrus fruit and nut crop by state.
  • The USDA's NASS 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2012 Annual Summary' was not published as originally scheduled due to the U.S. federal government's?2013 budget sequestration; however, according to a statement published by the NASS on 11/19/2013, the NASS will publish the 'Non-Citrus Fruit and Nut Annual Summary' in FY2014.
  • The value of?U.S. cherry production (sweet and tart)?for the 2012 marketing season?totaled 893,831 in thousands USD.
  • The value of cherry production may potentially be impacted by honeybee colony collapse disorder as cherries are primarily dependent upon honeybee pollination.?Note: the potential future loss of honeybee colonies is the subject of an existing forecast question.
  • Possible answers have been determined by: 1. Calculating the average production from the past three marketing seasons to determine a midpoint, 2. Calculating the average change in productivity from the past three marketing seasons, 3. Using the average change from the midpoint?to create an equal distribution among four bins, and 4. Adding the two tails.

Resolution Criteria

The United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service?must publish its 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'.

Total value of cherry production is reported in thousands of USD, thus this format will be used to determine the correct answer.


Resolution Sources

The United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service.


Fine Print

The 'total U.S. cherry production' includes sweet and tart cherries.

The '2013 marketing season' ?for sweet cherries begins 04/25/2013 and ends 08/20/2013. The '2013 marketing season' for tart cherries begins 06/25/2013 and ends 08/15/2013.

'Total value of production' is the 'packinghouse-door equivalent'. 'Packinghouse-door' equivalent is defined as all fruit, regardless of methods of sale, converted to a price it would have brought if the entire crop, or segment thereof being priced, had been sold at the packinghouse-door.

The outcome will be resolved based on the results published by the United States Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service 'Noncitrus Fruits and Nuts 2013 Annual Summary'?that is scheduled to be published in 07/2014.
